46 
47 INTRODUCTION AND ANALYSIS.
48 
49 The Republic of Plato is the longest of his works with the exception
50 of the Laws, and is certainly the greatest of them. There are nearer
51 approaches to modern metaphysics in the Philebus and in the Sophist; the
52 Politicus or Statesman is more ideal; the form and institutions of
53 the State are more clearly drawn out in the Laws; as works of art, the
54 Symposium and the Protagoras are of higher excellence. But no other
55 Dialogue of Plato has the same largeness of view and the same perfection
56 of style; no other shows an equal knowledge of the world, or contains
57 more of those thoughts which are new as well as old, and not of one age
58 only but of all. Nowhere in Plato is there a deeper irony or a greater
59 wealth of humour or imagery, or more dramatic power. Nor in any other of
60 his writings is the attempt made to interweave life and speculation, or
61 to connect politics with philosophy. The Republic is the centre around
62 which the other Dialogues may be grouped; here philosophy reaches the
63 highest point (cp, especially in Books V, VI, VII) to which ancient
64 thinkers ever attained. Plato among the Greeks, like Bacon among the
65 moderns, was the first who conceived a method of knowledge, although
66 neither of them always distinguished the bare outline or form from
67 the substance of truth; and both of them had to be content with an
68 abstraction of science which was not yet realized. He was the greatest
69 metaphysical genius whom the world has seen; and in him, more than in
70 any other ancient thinker, the germs of future knowledge are contained.
71 The sciences of logic and psychology, which have supplied so many
72 instruments of thought to after-ages, are based upon the analyses
73 of Socrates and Plato. The principles of definition, the law of
74 contradiction, the fallacy of arguing in a circle, the distinction
75 between the essence and accidents of a thing or notion, between means
76 and ends, between causes and conditions; also the division of the mind
77 into the rational, concupiscent, and irascible elements, or of pleasures
78 and desires into necessary and unnecessary--these and other great
79 forms of thought are all of them to be found in the Republic, and were
80 probably first invented by Plato. The greatest of all logical truths,
81 and the one of which writers on philosophy are most apt to lose sight,
82 the difference between words and things, has been most strenuously
83 insisted on by him (cp. Rep.; Polit.; Cratyl. 435, 436 ff), although he
84 has not always avoided the confusion of them in his own writings (e.g.
85 Rep.). But he does not bind up truth in logical formulae,--logic is
86 still veiled in metaphysics; and the science which he imagines to
87 'contemplate all truth and all existence' is very unlike the doctrine of
88 the syllogism which Aristotle claims to have discovered (Soph. Elenchi,
89 33. 18).
90 
91 Neither must we forget that the Republic is but the third part of a
92 still larger design which was to have included an ideal history of
93 Athens, as well as a political and physical philosophy. The fragment of
94 the Critias has given birth to a world-famous fiction, second only in
95 importance to the tale of Troy and the legend of Arthur; and is said as
96 a fact to have inspired some of the early navigators of the sixteenth
97 century. This mythical tale, of which the subject was a history of the
98 wars of the Athenians against the Island of Atlantis, is supposed to be
99 founded upon an unfinished poem of Solon, to which it would have stood
100 in the same relation as the writings of the logographers to the poems of
101 Homer. It would have told of a struggle for Liberty (cp. Tim. 25 C), intended
102 to represent the conflict of Persia and Hellas. We may judge from the
103 noble commencement of the Timaeus, from the fragment of the Critias
104 itself, and from the third book of the Laws, in what manner Plato would
105 have treated this high argument. We can only guess why the great design
106 was abandoned; perhaps because Plato became sensible of some incongruity
107 in a fictitious history, or because he had lost his interest in it, or
108 because advancing years forbade the completion of it; and we may please
109 ourselves with the fancy that had this imaginary narrative ever been
110 finished, we should have found Plato himself sympathising with the
111 struggle for Hellenic independence (cp. Laws  iii. 698 ff.), singing a
112 hymn of triumph over Marathon and Salamis, perhaps making the reflection
113 of Herodotus (v. 78) where he contemplates the growth of the Athenian
114 empire--'How brave a thing is freedom of speech, which has made the
115 Athenians so far exceed every other state of Hellas in greatness!' or,
116 more probably, attributing the victory to the ancient good order of
117 Athens and to the favor of Apollo and Athene (cp. Introd. to Critias).
118 
119 Again, Plato may be regarded as the 'captain' ('arhchegoz') or leader
120 of a goodly band of followers; for in the Republic is to be found the
121 original of Cicero's De Republica, of St. Augustine's City of God,
122 of the Utopia of Sir Thomas More, and of the numerous other imaginary
123 States which are framed upon the same model. The extent to which
124 Aristotle or the Aristotelian school were indebted to him in the
125 Politics has been little recognised, and the recognition is the
126 more necessary because it is not made by Aristotle himself. The two
127 philosophers had more in common than they were conscious of; and
128 probably some elements of Plato remain still undetected in Aristotle. In
129 English philosophy too, many affinities may be traced, not only in the
130 works of the Cambridge Platonists, but in great original writers like
131 Berkeley or Coleridge, to Plato and his ideas. That there is a truth
132 higher than experience, of which the mind bears witness to herself, is
133 a conviction which in our own generation has been enthusiastically
134 asserted, and is perhaps gaining ground. Of the Greek authors who at the
135 Renaissance brought a new life into the world Plato has had the greatest
136 influence. The Republic of Plato is also the first treatise upon
137 education, of which the writings of Milton and Locke, Rousseau, Jean
138 Paul, and Goethe are the legitimate descendants. Like Dante or Bunyan,
139 he has a revelation of another life; like Bacon, he is profoundly
140 impressed with the unity of knowledge; in the early Church he exercised
141 a real influence on theology, and at the Revival of Literature on
142 politics. Even the fragments of his words when 'repeated at second-hand'
143 (Symp. 215 D) have in all ages ravished the hearts of men, who have seen
144 reflected in them their own higher nature. He is the father of idealism
145 in philosophy, in politics, in literature. And many of the latest
146 conceptions of modern thinkers and statesmen, such as the unity of
147 knowledge, the reign of law, and the equality of the sexes, have been
148 anticipated in a dream by him.
149 
150 The argument of the Republic is the search after Justice, the nature
151 of which is first hinted at by Cephalus, the just and blameless old
152 man--then discussed on the basis of proverbial morality by Socrates and
153 Polemarchus--then caricatured by Thrasymachus and partially explained
154 by Socrates--reduced to an abstraction by Glaucon and Adeimantus, and
155 having become invisible in the individual reappears at length in the
156 ideal State which is constructed by Socrates. The first care of the
157 rulers is to be education, of which an outline is drawn after the old
158 Hellenic model, providing only for an improved religion and morality,
159 and more simplicity in music and gymnastic, a manlier strain of poetry,
160 and greater harmony of the individual and the State. We are thus led on
161 to the conception of a higher State, in which 'no man calls anything his
162 own,' and in which there is neither 'marrying nor giving in marriage,'
163 and 'kings are philosophers' and 'philosophers are kings;' and there
164 is another and higher education, intellectual as well as moral and
165 religious, of science as well as of art, and not of youth only but of
166 the whole of life. Such a State is hardly to be realized in this world
167 and quickly degenerates. To the perfect ideal succeeds the government
168 of the soldier and the lover of honour, this again declining into
169 democracy, and democracy into tyranny, in an imaginary but regular order
170 having not much resemblance to the actual facts. When 'the wheel has
171 come full circle' we do not begin again with a new period of human life;
172 but we have passed from the best to the worst, and there we end. The
173 subject is then changed and the old quarrel of poetry and philosophy
174 which had been more lightly treated in the earlier books of the Republic
175 is now resumed and fought out to a conclusion. Poetry is discovered to
176 be an imitation thrice removed from the truth, and Homer, as well as
177 the dramatic poets, having been condemned as an imitator, is sent into
178 banishment along with them. And the idea of the State is supplemented by
179 the revelation of a future life.
180 
181 The division into books, like all similar divisions (Cp. Sir G.C. Lewis
182 in the Classical Museum, vol. ii. p 1.), is probably later than the age of Plato. The
183 natural divisions are five in number;--(1) Book I and the first half
184 of Book II down to the paragraph beginning, 'I had always admired the
185 genius of Glaucon and Adeimantus,' which is introductory; the first
186 book containing a refutation of the popular and sophistical notions of
187 justice, and concluding, like some of the earlier Dialogues, without
188 arriving at any definite result. To this is appended a restatement of
189 the nature of justice according to common opinion, and an answer is
190 demanded to the question--What is justice, stripped of appearances? The
191 second division (2) includes the remainder of the second and the whole
192 of the third and fourth books, which are mainly occupied with the
193 construction of the first State and the first education. The third
194 division (3) consists of the fifth, sixth, and seventh books, in which
195 philosophy rather than justice is the subject of enquiry, and the
196 second State is constructed on principles of communism and ruled by
197 philosophers, and the contemplation of the idea of good takes the place
198 of the social and political virtues. In the eighth and ninth books (4)
199 the perversions of States and of the individuals who correspond to them
200 are reviewed in succession; and the nature of pleasure and the principle
201 of tyranny are further analysed in the individual man. The tenth book
202 (5) is the conclusion of the whole, in which the relations of philosophy
203 to poetry are finally determined, and the happiness of the citizens
204 in this life, which has now been assured, is crowned by the vision of
205 another.
206 
207 Or a more general division into two parts may be adopted; the first
208 (Books I - IV) containing the description of a State framed generally in
209 accordance with Hellenic notions of religion and morality, while in the
210 second (Books V - X) the Hellenic State is transformed into an
211 ideal kingdom of philosophy, of which all other governments are the
212 perversions. These two points of view are really opposed, and the
213 opposition is only veiled by the genius of Plato. The Republic, like
214 the Phaedrus (see Introduction to Phaedrus), is an imperfect whole; the
215 higher light of philosophy breaks through the regularity of the
216 Hellenic temple, which at last fades away into the heavens. Whether this
217 imperfection of structure arises from an enlargement of the plan;
218 or from the imperfect reconcilement in the writer's own mind of the
219 struggling elements of thought which are now first brought together
220 by him; or, perhaps, from the composition of the work at different
221 times--are questions, like the similar question about the Iliad and
222 the Odyssey, which are worth asking, but which cannot have a distinct
223 answer. In the age of Plato there was no regular mode of publication,
224 and an author would have the less scruple in altering or adding to a
225 work which was known only to a few of his friends. There is no absurdity
226 in supposing that he may have laid his labours aside for a time, or
227 turned from one work to another; and such interruptions would be more
228 likely to occur in the case of a long than of a short writing. In all
229 attempts to determine the chronological order of the Platonic writings
230 on internal evidence, this uncertainty about any single Dialogue being
231 composed at one time is a disturbing element, which must be admitted
232 to affect longer works, such as the Republic and the Laws, more than
233 shorter ones. But, on the other hand, the seeming discrepancies of
234 the Republic may only arise out of the discordant elements which the
235 philosopher has attempted to unite in a single whole, perhaps without
236 being himself able to recognise the inconsistency which is obvious to
237 us. For there is a judgment of after ages which few great writers have
238 ever been able to anticipate for themselves. They do not perceive the
239 want of connexion in their own writings, or the gaps in their systems
240 which are visible enough to those who come after them. In the beginnings
241 of literature and philosophy, amid the first efforts of thought and
242 language, more inconsistencies occur than now, when the paths of
243 speculation are well worn and the meaning of words precisely defined.
244 For consistency, too, is the growth of time; and some of the greatest
245 creations of the human mind have been wanting in unity. Tried by this
246 test, several of the Platonic Dialogues, according to our modern ideas,
247 appear to be defective, but the deficiency is no proof that they were
248 composed at different times or by different hands. And the supposition
249 that the Republic was written uninterruptedly and by a continuous effort
250 is in some degree confirmed by the numerous references from one part of
251 the work to another.
252 
253 The second title, 'Concerning Justice,' is not the one by which the
254 Republic is quoted, either by Aristotle or generally in antiquity, and,
255 like the other second titles of the Platonic Dialogues, may therefore be
256 assumed to be of later date. Morgenstern and others have asked
257 whether the definition of justice, which is the professed aim, or the
258 construction of the State is the principal argument of the work. The
259 answer is, that the two blend in one, and are two faces of the same
260 truth; for justice is the order of the State, and the State is the
261 visible embodiment of justice under the conditions of human society. The
262 one is the soul and the other is the body, and the Greek ideal of the
263 State, as of the individual, is a fair mind in a fair body. In Hegelian
264 phraseology the state is the reality of which justice is the idea. Or,
265 described in Christian language, the kingdom of God is within, and yet
266 developes into a Church or external kingdom; 'the house not made with
267 hands, eternal in the heavens,' is reduced to the proportions of an
268 earthly building. Or, to use a Platonic image, justice and the State are
269 the warp and the woof which run through the whole texture. And when the
270 constitution of the State is completed, the conception of justice is not
271 dismissed, but reappears under the same or different names throughout
272 the work, both as the inner law of the individual soul, and finally as
273 the principle of rewards and punishments in another life. The virtues
274 are based on justice, of which common honesty in buying and selling
275 is the shadow, and justice is based on the idea of good, which is the
276 harmony of the world, and is reflected both in the institutions of
277 states and in motions of the heavenly bodies (cp. Tim. 47). The Timaeus,
278 which takes up the political rather than the ethical side of the
279 Republic, and is chiefly occupied with hypotheses concerning the outward
280 world, yet contains many indications that the same law is supposed to
281 reign over the State, over nature, and over man.
282 
283 Too much, however, has been made of this question both in ancient and
284 modern times. There is a stage of criticism in which all works, whether
285 of nature or of art, are referred to design. Now in ancient writings,
286 and indeed in literature generally, there remains often a large element
287 which was not comprehended in the original design. For the plan grows
288 under the author's hand; new thoughts occur to him in the act of
289 writing; he has not worked out the argument to the end before he begins.
290 The reader who seeks to find some one idea under which the whole may be
291 conceived, must necessarily seize on the vaguest and most general. Thus
292 Stallbaum, who is dissatisfied with the ordinary explanations of the
293 argument of the Republic, imagines himself to have found the true
294 argument 'in the representation of human life in a State perfected by
295 justice, and governed according to the idea of good.' There may be some
296 use in such general descriptions, but they can hardly be said to express
297 the design of the writer. The truth is, that we may as well speak of
298 many designs as of one; nor need anything be excluded from the plan of
299 a great work to which the mind is naturally led by the association of
300 ideas, and which does not interfere with the general purpose. What kind
301 or degree of unity is to be sought after in a building, in the plastic
302 arts, in poetry, in prose, is a problem which has to be determined
303 relatively to the subject-matter. To Plato himself, the enquiry 'what
304 was the intention of the writer,' or 'what was the principal argument
305 of the Republic' would have been hardly intelligible, and therefore had
306 better be at once dismissed (cp. the Introduction to the Phaedrus).
307 
308 Is not the Republic the vehicle of three or four great truths which,
309 to Plato's own mind, are most naturally represented in the form of the
310 State? Just as in the Jewish prophets the reign of Messiah, or 'the day
311 of the Lord,' or the suffering Servant or people of God, or the 'Sun of
312 righteousness with healing in his wings' only convey, to us at least,
313 their great spiritual ideals, so through the Greek State Plato reveals
314 to us his own thoughts about divine perfection, which is the idea of
315 good--like the sun in the visible world;--about human perfection, which
316 is justice--about education beginning in youth and continuing in later
317 years--about poets and sophists and tyrants who are the false teachers
318 and evil rulers of mankind--about 'the world' which is the embodiment of
319 them--about a kingdom which exists nowhere upon earth but is laid up
320 in heaven to be the pattern and rule of human life. No such inspired
321 creation is at unity with itself, any more than the clouds of heaven
322 when the sun pierces through them. Every shade of light and dark, of
323 truth, and of fiction which is the veil of truth, is allowable in a work
324 of philosophical imagination. It is not all on the same plane; it easily
325 passes from ideas to myths and fancies, from facts to figures of speech.
326 It is not prose but poetry, at least a great part of it, and ought not
327 to be judged by the rules of logic or the probabilities of history. The
328 writer is not fashioning his ideas into an artistic whole; they take
329 possession of him and are too much for him. We have no need therefore
330 to discuss whether a State such as Plato has conceived is practicable or
331 not, or whether the outward form or the inward life came first into the
332 mind of the writer. For the practicability of his ideas has nothing to
333 do with their truth; and the highest thoughts to which he attains may be
334 truly said to bear the greatest 'marks of design'--justice more than the
335 external frame-work of the State, the idea of good more than justice.
336 The great science of dialectic or the organisation of ideas has no real
337 content; but is only a type of the method or spirit in which the
338 higher knowledge is to be pursued by the spectator of all time and
339 all existence. It is in the fifth, sixth, and seventh books that Plato
340 reaches the 'summit of speculation,' and these, although they fail to
341 satisfy the requirements of a modern thinker, may therefore be regarded
342 as the most important, as they are also the most original, portions of
343 the work.
344 
345 It is not necessary to discuss at length a minor question which has
346 been raised by Boeckh, respecting the imaginary date at which the
347 conversation was held (the year 411 B.C. which is proposed by him will
348 do as well as any other); for a writer of fiction, and especially a
349 writer who, like Plato, is notoriously careless of chronology (cp. Rep.,
350 Symp., 193 A, etc.), only aims at general probability. Whether all the persons
351 mentioned in the Republic could ever have met at any one time is not
352 a difficulty which would have occurred to an Athenian reading the work
353 forty years later, or to Plato himself at the time of writing (any more
354 than to Shakespeare respecting one of his own dramas); and need not
355 greatly trouble us now. Yet this may be a question having no answer
356 'which is still worth asking,' because the investigation shows that we
357 cannot argue historically from the dates in Plato; it would be useless
358 therefore to waste time in inventing far-fetched reconcilements of them
359 in order to avoid chronological difficulties, such, for example, as
360 the conjecture of C.F. Hermann, that Glaucon and Adeimantus are not the
361 brothers but the uncles of Plato (cp. Apol. 34 A), or the fancy of Stallbaum
362 that Plato intentionally left anachronisms indicating the dates at which
363 some of his Dialogues were written.
364 
365 The principal characters in the Republic are Cephalus, Polemarchus,
366 Thrasymachus, Socrates, Glaucon, and Adeimantus. Cephalus appears in the
367 introduction only, Polemarchus drops at the end of the first argument,
368 and Thrasymachus is reduced to silence at the close of the first book.
369 The main discussion is carried on by Socrates, Glaucon, and Adeimantus.
370 Among the company are Lysias (the orator) and Euthydemus, the sons of
371 Cephalus and brothers of Polemarchus, an unknown Charmantides--these are
372 mute auditors; also there is Cleitophon, who once interrupts, where, as
373 in the Dialogue which bears his name, he appears as the friend and ally
374 of Thrasymachus.
375 
376 Cephalus, the patriarch of the house, has been appropriately engaged
377 in offering a sacrifice. He is the pattern of an old man who has almost
378 done with life, and is at peace with himself and with all mankind. He
379 feels that he is drawing nearer to the world below, and seems to linger
380 around the memory of the past. He is eager that Socrates should come
381 to visit him, fond of the poetry of the last generation, happy in the
382 consciousness of a well-spent life, glad at having escaped from the
383 tyranny of youthful lusts. His love of conversation, his affection, his
384 indifference to riches, even his garrulity, are interesting traits of
385 character. He is not one of those who have nothing to say, because their
386 whole mind has been absorbed in making money. Yet he acknowledges
387 that riches have the advantage of placing men above the temptation
388 to dishonesty or falsehood. The respectful attention shown to him by
389 Socrates, whose love of conversation, no less than the mission imposed
390 upon him by the Oracle, leads him to ask questions of all men, young and
391 old alike, should also be noted. Who better suited to raise the question
392 of justice than Cephalus, whose life might seem to be the expression of
393 it? The moderation with which old age is pictured by Cephalus as a very
394 tolerable portion of existence is characteristic, not only of him,
395 but of Greek feeling generally, and contrasts with the exaggeration of
396 Cicero in the De Senectute. The evening of life is described by Plato
397 in the most expressive manner, yet with the fewest possible touches. As
398 Cicero remarks (Ep. ad Attic. iv. 16), the aged Cephalus would have been out of
399 place in the discussion which follows, and which he could neither have
400 understood nor taken part in without a violation of dramatic propriety
401 (cp. Lysimachus in the Laches).
402 
403 His 'son and heir' Polemarchus has the frankness and impetuousness of
404 youth; he is for detaining Socrates by force in the opening scene,
405 and will not 'let him off' on the subject of women and children.
406 Like Cephalus, he is limited in his point of view, and represents
407 the proverbial stage of morality which has rules of life rather than
408 principles; and he quotes Simonides (cp. Aristoph. Clouds) as his father
409 had quoted Pindar. But after this he has no more to say; the answers
410 which he makes are only elicited from him by the dialectic of Socrates.
411 He has not yet experienced the influence of the Sophists like Glaucon
412 and Adeimantus, nor is he sensible of the necessity of refuting them; he
413 belongs to the pre-Socratic or pre-dialectical age. He is incapable of
414 arguing, and is bewildered by Socrates to such a degree that he does not
415 know what he is saying. He is made to admit that justice is a thief, and
416 that the virtues follow the analogy of the arts. From his brother Lysias
417 (contra Eratosth.) we learn that he fell a victim to the Thirty Tyrants,
418 but no allusion is here made to his fate, nor to the circumstance that
419 Cephalus and his family were of Syracusan origin, and had migrated from
420 Thurii to Athens.
421 
422 The 'Chalcedonian giant,' Thrasymachus, of whom we have already heard
423 in the Phaedrus, is the personification of the Sophists, according to
424 Plato's conception of them, in some of their worst characteristics. He
425 is vain and blustering, refusing to discourse unless he is paid, fond of
426 making an oration, and hoping thereby to escape the inevitable Socrates;
427 but a mere child in argument, and unable to foresee that the next 'move'
428 (to use a Platonic expression) will 'shut him up.' He has reached the
429 stage of framing general notions, and in this respect is in advance of
430 Cephalus and Polemarchus. But he is incapable of defending them in a
431 discussion, and vainly tries to cover his confusion with banter and
432 insolence. Whether such doctrines as are attributed to him by Plato were
433 really held either by him or by any other Sophist is uncertain; in the
434 infancy of philosophy serious errors about morality might easily grow
435 up--they are certainly put into the mouths of speakers in Thucydides;
436 but we are concerned at present with Plato's description of him, and not
437 with the historical reality. The inequality of the contest adds greatly
438 to the humour of the scene. The pompous and empty Sophist is utterly
439 helpless in the hands of the great master of dialectic, who knows how
440 to touch all the springs of vanity and weakness in him. He is greatly
441 irritated by the irony of Socrates, but his noisy and imbecile rage
442 only lays him more and more open to the thrusts of his assailant. His
443 determination to cram down their throats, or put 'bodily into their
444 souls' his own words, elicits a cry of horror from Socrates. The
445 state of his temper is quite as worthy of remark as the process of the
446 argument. Nothing is more amusing than his complete submission when
447 he has been once thoroughly beaten. At first he seems to continue the
448 discussion with reluctance, but soon with apparent good-will, and he
449 even testifies his interest at a later stage by one or two occasional
450 remarks. When attacked by Glaucon he is humorously protected by Socrates
451 'as one who has never been his enemy and is now his friend.' From Cicero
452 and Quintilian and from Aristotle's Rhetoric we learn that the Sophist
453 whom Plato has made so ridiculous was a man of note whose writings were
454 preserved in later ages. The play on his name which was made by his
455 contemporary Herodicus (Aris. Rhet.), 'thou wast ever bold in
456 battle,' seems to show that the description of him is not devoid of
457 verisimilitude.
458 
459 When Thrasymachus has been silenced, the two principal respondents,
460 Glaucon and Adeimantus, appear on the scene: here, as in Greek tragedy
461 (cp. Introd. to Phaedo), three actors are introduced. At first sight
462 the two sons of Ariston may seem to wear a family likeness, like the two
463 friends Simmias and Cebes in the Phaedo. But on a nearer examination
464 of them the similarity vanishes, and they are seen to be distinct
465 characters. Glaucon is the impetuous youth who can 'just never have
466 enough of fechting' (cp. the character of him in Xen. Mem. iii. 6);
467 the man of pleasure who is acquainted with the mysteries of love; the
468 'juvenis qui gaudet canibus,' and who improves the breed of animals; the
469 lover of art and music who has all the experiences of youthful life. He
470 is full of quickness and penetration, piercing easily below the clumsy
471 platitudes of Thrasymachus to the real difficulty; he turns out to the
472 light the seamy side of human life, and yet does not lose faith in the
473 just and true. It is Glaucon who seizes what may be termed the ludicrous
474 relation of the philosopher to the world, to whom a state of simplicity
475 is 'a city of pigs,' who is always prepared with a jest when the
476 argument offers him an opportunity, and who is ever ready to second
477 the humour of Socrates and to appreciate the ridiculous, whether in
478 the connoisseurs of music, or in the lovers of theatricals, or in the
479 fantastic behaviour of the citizens of democracy. His weaknesses are
480 several times alluded to by Socrates, who, however, will not allow him
481 to be attacked by his brother Adeimantus. He is a soldier, and, like
482 Adeimantus, has been distinguished at the battle of Megara (anno
483 456?)...The character of Adeimantus is deeper and graver, and the
484 profounder objections are commonly put into his mouth. Glaucon is more
485 demonstrative, and generally opens the game. Adeimantus pursues the
486 argument further. Glaucon has more of the liveliness and quick sympathy
487 of youth; Adeimantus has the maturer judgment of a grown-up man of
488 the world. In the second book, when Glaucon insists that justice and
489 injustice shall be considered without regard to their consequences,
490 Adeimantus remarks that they are regarded by mankind in general only for
491 the sake of their consequences; and in a similar vein of reflection he
492 urges at the beginning of the fourth book that Socrates fails in making
493 his citizens happy, and is answered that happiness is not the first but
494 the second thing, not the direct aim but the indirect consequence of
495 the good government of a State. In the discussion about religion and
496 mythology, Adeimantus is the respondent, but Glaucon breaks in with a
497 slight jest, and carries on the conversation in a lighter tone about
498 music and gymnastic to the end of the book. It is Adeimantus again
499 who volunteers the criticism of common sense on the Socratic method of
500 argument, and who refuses to let Socrates pass lightly over the question
501 of women and children. It is Adeimantus who is the respondent in the
502 more argumentative, as Glaucon in the lighter and more imaginative
503 portions of the Dialogue. For example, throughout the greater part
504 of the sixth book, the causes of the corruption of philosophy and the
505 conception of the idea of good are discussed with Adeimantus. Glaucon
506 resumes his place of principal respondent; but he has a difficulty in
507 apprehending the higher education of Socrates, and makes some false hits
508 in the course of the discussion. Once more Adeimantus returns with the
509 allusion to his brother Glaucon whom he compares to the contentious
510 State; in the next book he is again superseded, and Glaucon continues to
511 the end.
512 
513 Thus in a succession of characters Plato represents the successive
514 stages of morality, beginning with the Athenian gentleman of the olden
515 time, who is followed by the practical man of that day regulating his
516 life by proverbs and saws; to him succeeds the wild generalization of
517 the Sophists, and lastly come the young disciples of the great teacher,
518 who know the sophistical arguments but will not be convinced by them,
519 and desire to go deeper into the nature of things. These too, like
520 Cephalus, Polemarchus, Thrasymachus, are clearly distinguished from one
521 another. Neither in the Republic, nor in any other Dialogue of Plato, is
522 a single character repeated.
523 
524 The delineation of Socrates in the Republic is not wholly consistent. In
525 the first book we have more of the real Socrates, such as he is depicted
526 in the Memorabilia of Xenophon, in the earliest Dialogues of Plato, and
527 in the Apology. He is ironical, provoking, questioning, the old enemy
528 of the Sophists, ready to put on the mask of Silenus as well as to argue
529 seriously. But in the sixth book his enmity towards the Sophists abates;
530 he acknowledges that they are the representatives rather than the
531 corrupters of the world. He also becomes more dogmatic and constructive,
532 passing beyond the range either of the political or the speculative
533 ideas of the real Socrates. In one passage Plato himself seems to
534 intimate that the time had now come for Socrates, who had passed his
535 whole life in philosophy, to give his own opinion and not to be always
536 repeating the notions of other men. There is no evidence that either the
537 idea of good or the conception of a perfect state were comprehended in
538 the Socratic teaching, though he certainly dwelt on the nature of
539 the universal and of final causes (cp. Xen. Mem.; Phaedo); and a deep
540 thinker like him, in his thirty or forty years of public teaching, could
541 hardly have failed to touch on the nature of family relations, for
542 which there is also some positive evidence in the Memorabilia (Mem.) The
543 Socratic method is nominally retained; and every inference is either put
544 into the mouth of the respondent or represented as the common discovery
545 of him and Socrates. But any one can see that this is a mere form, of
546 which the affectation grows wearisome as the work advances. The method
547 of enquiry has passed into a method of teaching in which by the help of
548 interlocutors the same thesis is looked at from various points of view.
549 The nature of the process is truly characterized by Glaucon, when
550 he describes himself as a companion who is not good for much in an
551 investigation, but can see what he is shown, and may, perhaps, give the
552 answer to a question more fluently than another.
553 
554 Neither can we be absolutely certain that Socrates himself taught the
555 immortality of the soul, which is unknown to his disciple Glaucon in the
556 Republic (cp. Apol.); nor is there any reason to suppose that he used
557 myths or revelations of another world as a vehicle of instruction,
558 or that he would have banished poetry or have denounced the Greek
559 mythology. His favorite oath is retained, and a slight mention is made
560 of the daemonium, or internal sign, which is alluded to by Socrates as
561 a phenomenon peculiar to himself. A real element of Socratic teaching,
562 which is more prominent in the Republic than in any of the other
563 Dialogues of Plato, is the use of example and illustration (Greek):
564 'Let us apply the test of common instances.' 'You,' says Adeimantus,
565 ironically, in the sixth book, 'are so unaccustomed to speak in images.'
566 And this use of examples or images, though truly Socratic in origin, is
567 enlarged by the genius of Plato into the form of an allegory or parable,
568 which embodies in the concrete what has been already described, or is
569 about to be described, in the abstract. Thus the figure of the cave in
570 Book VII is a recapitulation of the divisions of knowledge in Book VI.
571 The composite animal in Book IX is an allegory of the parts of the
572 soul. The noble captain and the ship and the true pilot in Book VI are
573 a figure of the relation of the people to the philosophers in the
574 State which has been described. Other figures, such as the dog, or
575 the marriage of the portionless maiden, or the drones and wasps in the
576 eighth and ninth books, also form links of connexion in long passages,
577 or are used to recall previous discussions.
578 
579 Plato is most true to the character of his master when he describes him
580 as 'not of this world.' And with this representation of him the ideal
581 state and the other paradoxes of the Republic are quite in accordance,
582 though they cannot be shown to have been speculations of Socrates. To
583 him, as to other great teachers both philosophical and religious, when
584 they looked upward, the world seemed to be the embodiment of error and
585 evil. The common sense of mankind has revolted against this view, or
586 has only partially admitted it. And even in Socrates himself the sterner
587 judgement of the multitude at times passes into a sort of ironical pity
588 or love. Men in general are incapable of philosophy, and are therefore
589 at enmity with the philosopher; but their misunderstanding of him is
590 unavoidable: for they have never seen him as he truly is in his own
591 image; they are only acquainted with artificial systems possessing no
592 native force of truth--words which admit of many applications. Their
593 leaders have nothing to measure with, and are therefore ignorant of
594 their own stature. But they are to be pitied or laughed at, not to be
595 quarrelled with; they mean well with their nostrums, if they could only
596 learn that they are cutting off a Hydra's head. This moderation towards
597 those who are in error is one of the most characteristic features
598 of Socrates in the Republic. In all the different representations of
599 Socrates, whether of Xenophon or Plato, and amid the differences of
600 the earlier or later Dialogues, he always retains the character of the
601 unwearied and disinterested seeker after truth, without which he would
602 have ceased to be Socrates.
603 
604 Leaving the characters we may now analyse the contents of the Republic,
605 and then proceed to consider (1) The general aspects of this Hellenic
606 ideal of the State, (2) The modern lights in which the thoughts of Plato
607 may be read.
608 
609 BOOK I. The Republic opens with a truly Greek scene--a festival in
610 honour of the goddess Bendis which is held in the Piraeus; to this is
611 added the promise of an equestrian torch-race in the evening. The whole
612 work is supposed to be recited by Socrates on the day after the festival
613 to a small party, consisting of Critias, Timaeus, Hermocrates, and
614 another; this we learn from the first words of the Timaeus.
615 
616 When the rhetorical advantage of reciting the Dialogue has been gained,
617 the attention is not distracted by any reference to the audience; nor
618 is the reader further reminded of the extraordinary length of the
619 narrative. Of the numerous company, three only take any serious part in
620 the discussion; nor are we informed whether in the evening they went to
621 the torch-race, or talked, as in the Symposium, through the night.
622 The manner in which the conversation has arisen is described as
623 follows:--Socrates and his companion Glaucon are about to leave the
624 festival when they are detained by a message from Polemarchus, who
625 speedily appears accompanied by Adeimantus, the brother of Glaucon, and
626 with playful violence compels them to remain, promising them not only
627 the torch-race, but the pleasure of conversation with the young, which
628 to Socrates is a far greater attraction. They return to the house of
629 Cephalus, Polemarchus' father, now in extreme old age, who is found
630 sitting upon a cushioned seat crowned for a sacrifice. 'You should come
631 to me oftener, Socrates, for I am too old to go to you; and at my time
632 of life, having lost other pleasures, I care the more for conversation.'
633 Socrates asks him what he thinks of age, to which the old man replies,
634 that the sorrows and discontents of age are to be attributed to the
635 tempers of men, and that age is a time of peace in which the tyranny
636 of the passions is no longer felt. Yes, replies Socrates, but the world
637 will say, Cephalus, that you are happy in old age because you are rich.
638 'And there is something in what they say, Socrates, but not so much as
639 they imagine--as Themistocles replied to the Seriphian, "Neither you, if
640 you had been an Athenian, nor I, if I had been a Seriphian, would ever
641 have been famous," I might in like manner reply to you, Neither a good
642 poor man can be happy in age, nor yet a bad rich man.' Socrates remarks
643 that Cephalus appears not to care about riches, a quality which he
644 ascribes to his having inherited, not acquired them, and would like
645 to know what he considers to be the chief advantage of them. Cephalus
646 answers that when you are old the belief in the world below grows upon
647 you, and then to have done justice and never to have been compelled to
648 do injustice through poverty, and never to have deceived anyone, are
649 felt to be unspeakable blessings. Socrates, who is evidently preparing
650 for an argument, next asks, What is the meaning of the word justice? To
651 tell the truth and pay your debts? No more than this? Or must we admit
652 exceptions? Ought I, for example, to put back into the hands of my
653 friend, who has gone mad, the sword which I borrowed of him when he
654 was in his right mind? 'There must be exceptions.' 'And yet,' says
655 Polemarchus, 'the definition which has been given has the authority
656 of Simonides.' Here Cephalus retires to look after the sacrifices,
657 and bequeaths, as Socrates facetiously remarks, the possession of the
658 argument to his heir, Polemarchus...
659 
660 The description of old age is finished, and Plato, as his manner is, has
661 touched the key-note of the whole work in asking for the definition of
662 justice, first suggesting the question which Glaucon afterwards pursues
663 respecting external goods, and preparing for the concluding mythus of
664 the world below in the slight allusion of Cephalus. The portrait of the
665 just man is a natural frontispiece or introduction to the long discourse
666 which follows, and may perhaps imply that in all our perplexity about
667 the nature of justice, there is no difficulty in discerning 'who is
668 a just man.' The first explanation has been supported by a saying of
669 Simonides; and now Socrates has a mind to show that the resolution of
670 justice into two unconnected precepts, which have no common principle,
671 fails to satisfy the demands of dialectic.
672 
673 ...He proceeds: What did Simonides mean by this saying of his? Did he
674 mean that I was to give back arms to a madman? 'No, not in that case,
675 not if the parties are friends, and evil would result. He meant that you
676 were to do what was proper, good to friends and harm to enemies.' Every
677 act does something to somebody; and following this analogy, Socrates
678 asks, What is this due and proper thing which justice does, and to whom?
679 He is answered that justice does good to friends and harm to enemies.
680 But in what way good or harm? 'In making alliances with the one, and
681 going to war with the other.' Then in time of peace what is the good
682 of justice? The answer is that justice is of use in contracts, and
683 contracts are money partnerships. Yes; but how in such partnerships
684 is the just man of more use than any other man? 'When you want to have
685 money safely kept and not used.' Then justice will be useful when money
686 is useless. And there is another difficulty: justice, like the art of
687 war or any other art, must be of opposites, good at attack as well as
688 at defence, at stealing as well as at guarding. But then justice is a
689 thief, though a hero notwithstanding, like Autolycus, the Homeric hero,
690 who was 'excellent above all men in theft and perjury'--to such a pass
691 have you and Homer and Simonides brought us; though I do not forget that
692 the thieving must be for the good of friends and the harm of enemies.
693 And still there arises another question: Are friends to be interpreted
694 as real or seeming; enemies as real or seeming? And are our friends to
695 be only the good, and our enemies to be the evil? The answer is, that
696 we must do good to our seeming and real good friends, and evil to our
697 seeming and real evil enemies--good to the good, evil to the evil. But
698 ought we to render evil for evil at all, when to do so will only make
699 men more evil? Can justice produce injustice any more than the art of
700 horsemanship can make bad horsemen, or heat produce cold? The final
701 conclusion is, that no sage or poet ever said that the just return
702 evil for evil; this was a maxim of some rich and mighty man, Periander,
703 Perdiccas, or Ismenias the Theban (about B.C. 398-381)...
704 
705 Thus the first stage of aphoristic or unconscious morality is shown to
706 be inadequate to the wants of the age; the authority of the poets is set
707 aside, and through the winding mazes of dialectic we make an approach
708 to the Christian precept of forgiveness of injuries. Similar words
709 are applied by the Persian mystic poet to the Divine being when the
710 questioning spirit is stirred within him:--'If because I do evil, Thou
711 punishest me by evil, what is the difference between Thee and me?' In
712 this both Plato and Kheyam rise above the level of many Christian (?)
713 theologians. The first definition of justice easily passes into the
714 second; for the simple words 'to speak the truth and pay your debts' is
715 substituted the more abstract 'to do good to your friends and harm to
716 your enemies.' Either of these explanations gives a sufficient rule
717 of life for plain men, but they both fall short of the precision of
718 philosophy. We may note in passing the antiquity of casuistry, which not
719 only arises out of the conflict of established principles in particular
720 cases, but also out of the effort to attain them, and is prior as well
721 as posterior to our fundamental notions of morality. The 'interrogation'
722 of moral ideas; the appeal to the authority of Homer; the conclusion
723 that the maxim, 'Do good to your friends and harm to your enemies,'
724 being erroneous, could not have been the word of any great man, are all
725 of them very characteristic of the Platonic Socrates.
726 
727 ...Here Thrasymachus, who has made several attempts to interrupt, but
728 has hitherto been kept in order by the company, takes advantage of a
729 pause and rushes into the arena, beginning, like a savage animal, with a
730 roar. 'Socrates,' he says, 'what folly is this?--Why do you agree to be
731 vanquished by one another in a pretended argument?' He then prohibits
732 all the ordinary definitions of justice; to which Socrates replies that
733 he cannot tell how many twelve is, if he is forbidden to say 2 x 6, or
734 3 x 4, or 6 x 2, or 4 x 3. At first Thrasymachus is reluctant to argue;
735 but at length, with a promise of payment on the part of the company and
736 of praise from Socrates, he is induced to open the game. 'Listen,' he
737 says, 'my answer is that might is right, justice the interest of the
738 stronger: now praise me.' Let me understand you first. Do you mean that
739 because Polydamas the wrestler, who is stronger than we are, finds the
740 eating of beef for his interest, the eating of beef is also for our
741 interest, who are not so strong? Thrasymachus is indignant at the
742 illustration, and in pompous words, apparently intended to restore
743 dignity to the argument, he explains his meaning to be that the rulers
744 make laws for their own interests. But suppose, says Socrates, that the
745 ruler or stronger makes a mistake--then the interest of the stronger is
746 not his interest. Thrasymachus is saved from this speedy downfall by his
747 disciple Cleitophon, who introduces the word 'thinks;'--not the actual
748 interest of the ruler, but what he thinks or what seems to be his
749 interest, is justice. The contradiction is escaped by the unmeaning
750 evasion: for though his real and apparent interests may differ, what the
751 ruler thinks to be his interest will always remain what he thinks to be
752 his interest.
753 
754 Of course this was not the original assertion, nor is the new
755 interpretation accepted by Thrasymachus himself. But Socrates is not
756 disposed to quarrel about words, if, as he significantly insinuates,
757 his adversary has changed his mind. In what follows Thrasymachus does
758 in fact withdraw his admission that the ruler may make a mistake, for he
759 affirms that the ruler as a ruler is infallible. Socrates is quite ready
760 to accept the new position, which he equally turns against Thrasymachus
761 by the help of the analogy of the arts. Every art or science has an
762 interest, but this interest is to be distinguished from the accidental
763 interest of the artist, and is only concerned with the good of the
764 things or persons which come under the art. And justice has an interest
765 which is the interest not of the ruler or judge, but of those who come
766 under his sway.
767 
768 Thrasymachus is on the brink of the inevitable conclusion, when he makes
769 a bold diversion. 'Tell me, Socrates,' he says, 'have you a nurse?' What
770 a question! Why do you ask? 'Because, if you have, she neglects you and
771 lets you go about drivelling, and has not even taught you to know the
772 shepherd from the sheep. For you fancy that shepherds and rulers never
773 think of their own interest, but only of their sheep or subjects,
774 whereas the truth is that they fatten them for their use, sheep and
775 subjects alike. And experience proves that in every relation of life
776 the just man is the loser and the unjust the gainer, especially where
777 injustice is on the grand scale, which is quite another thing from the
778 petty rogueries of swindlers and burglars and robbers of temples. The
779 language of men proves this--our 'gracious' and 'blessed' tyrant and the
780 like--all which tends to show (1) that justice is the interest of the
781 stronger; and (2) that injustice is more profitable and also stronger
782 than justice.'
783 
784 Thrasymachus, who is better at a speech than at a close argument, having
785 deluged the company with words, has a mind to escape. But the others
786 will not let him go, and Socrates adds a humble but earnest request that
787 he will not desert them at such a crisis of their fate. 'And what can I
788 do more for you?' he says; 'would you have me put the words bodily
789 into your souls?' God forbid! replies Socrates; but we want you to be
790 consistent in the use of terms, and not to employ 'physician' in an
791 exact sense, and then again 'shepherd' or 'ruler' in an inexact,--if the
792 words are strictly taken, the ruler and the shepherd look only to the
793 good of their people or flocks and not to their own: whereas you insist
794 that rulers are solely actuated by love of office. 'No doubt about it,'
795 replies Thrasymachus. Then why are they paid? Is not the reason, that
796 their interest is not comprehended in their art, and is therefore the
797 concern of another art, the art of pay, which is common to the arts in
798 general, and therefore not identical with any one of them? Nor would any
799 man be a ruler unless he were induced by the hope of reward or the fear
800 of punishment;--the reward is money or honour, the punishment is the
801 necessity of being ruled by a man worse than himself. And if a State (or
802 Church) were composed entirely of good men, they would be affected by
803 the last motive only; and there would be as much 'nolo episcopari' as
804 there is at present of the opposite...
805 
806 The satire on existing governments is heightened by the simple and
807 apparently incidental manner in which the last remark is introduced.
808 There is a similar irony in the argument that the governors of mankind
809 do not like being in office, and that therefore they demand pay.
810 
811 ...Enough of this: the other assertion of Thrasymachus is far more
812 important--that the unjust life is more gainful than the just. Now, as
813 you and I, Glaucon, are not convinced by him, we must reply to him; but
814 if we try to compare their respective gains we shall want a judge
815 to decide for us; we had better therefore proceed by making mutual
816 admissions of the truth to one another.
817 
818 Thrasymachus had asserted that perfect injustice was more gainful than
819 perfect justice, and after a little hesitation he is induced by Socrates
820 to admit the still greater paradox that injustice is virtue and justice
821 vice. Socrates praises his frankness, and assumes the attitude of one
822 whose only wish is to understand the meaning of his opponents. At the
823 same time he is weaving a net in which Thrasymachus is finally enclosed.
824 The admission is elicited from him that the just man seeks to gain an
825 advantage over the unjust only, but not over the just, while the unjust
826 would gain an advantage over either. Socrates, in order to test this
827 statement, employs once more the favourite analogy of the arts. The
828 musician, doctor, skilled artist of any sort, does not seek to gain more
829 than the skilled, but only more than the unskilled (that is to say, he
830 works up to a rule, standard, law, and does not exceed it), whereas the
831 unskilled makes random efforts at excess. Thus the skilled falls on the
832 side of the good, and the unskilled on the side of the evil, and the
833 just is the skilled, and the unjust is the unskilled.
834 
835 There was great difficulty in bringing Thrasymachus to the point; the
836 day was hot and he was streaming with perspiration, and for the first
837 time in his life he was seen to blush. But his other thesis that
838 injustice was stronger than justice has not yet been refuted, and
839 Socrates now proceeds to the consideration of this, which, with the
840 assistance of Thrasymachus, he hopes to clear up; the latter is at first
841 churlish, but in the judicious hands of Socrates is soon restored to
842 good-humour: Is there not honour among thieves? Is not the strength of
843 injustice only a remnant of justice? Is not absolute injustice absolute
844 weakness also? A house that is divided against itself cannot stand; two
845 men who quarrel detract from one another's strength, and he who is at
846 war with himself is the enemy of himself and the gods. Not wickedness
847 therefore, but semi-wickedness flourishes in states,--a remnant of
848 good is needed in order to make union in action possible,--there is no
849 kingdom of evil in this world.
850 
851 Another question has not been answered: Is the just or the unjust the
852 happier? To this we reply, that every art has an end and an excellence
853 or virtue by which the end is accomplished. And is not the end of
854 the soul happiness, and justice the excellence of the soul by which
855 happiness is attained? Justice and happiness being thus shown to be
856 inseparable, the question whether the just or the unjust is the happier
857 has disappeared.
858 
859 Thrasymachus replies: 'Let this be your entertainment, Socrates, at the
860 festival of Bendis.' Yes; and a very good entertainment with which your
861 kindness has supplied me, now that you have left off scolding. And yet
862 not a good entertainment--but that was my own fault, for I tasted of too
863 many things. First of all the nature of justice was the subject of our
864 enquiry, and then whether justice is virtue and wisdom, or evil and
865 folly; and then the comparative advantages of just and unjust: and the
866 sum of all is that I know not what justice is; how then shall I know
867 whether the just is happy or not?...
868 
869 Thus the sophistical fabric has been demolished, chiefly by appealing
870 to the analogy of the arts. 'Justice is like the arts (1) in having no
871 external interest, and (2) in not aiming at excess, and (3) justice is
872 to happiness what the implement of the workman is to his work.' At this
873 the modern reader is apt to stumble, because he forgets that Plato is
874 writing in an age when the arts and the virtues, like the moral
875 and intellectual faculties, were still undistinguished. Among early
876 enquirers into the nature of human action the arts helped to fill up
877 the void of speculation; and at first the comparison of the arts and the
878 virtues was not perceived by them to be fallacious. They only saw the
879 points of agreement in them and not the points of difference. Virtue,
880 like art, must take means to an end; good manners are both an art and
881 a virtue; character is naturally described under the image of a statue;
882 and there are many other figures of speech which are readily transferred
883 from art to morals. The next generation cleared up these perplexities;
884 or at least supplied after ages with a further analysis of them. The
885 contemporaries of Plato were in a state of transition, and had not yet
886 fully realized the common-sense distinction of Aristotle, that 'virtue
887 is concerned with action, art with production' (Nic. Eth.), or that
888 'virtue implies intention and constancy of purpose,' whereas 'art
889 requires knowledge only'. And yet in the absurdities which follow from
890 some uses of the analogy, there seems to be an intimation conveyed that
891 virtue is more than art. This is implied in the reductio ad absurdum
892 that 'justice is a thief,' and in the dissatisfaction which Socrates
893 expresses at the final result.
894 
895 The expression 'an art of pay' which is described as 'common to all the
896 arts' is not in accordance with the ordinary use of language. Nor is it
897 employed elsewhere either by Plato or by any other Greek writer. It is
898 suggested by the argument, and seems to extend the conception of art to
899 doing as well as making. Another flaw or inaccuracy of language may be
900 noted in the words 'men who are injured are made more unjust.' For
901 those who are injured are not necessarily made worse, but only harmed or
902 ill-treated.
903 
904 The second of the three arguments, 'that the just does not aim at
905 excess,' has a real meaning, though wrapped up in an enigmatical form.
906 That the good is of the nature of the finite is a peculiarly Hellenic
907 sentiment, which may be compared with the language of those modern
908 writers who speak of virtue as fitness, and of freedom as obedience to
909 law. The mathematical or logical notion of limit easily passes into an
910 ethical one, and even finds a mythological expression in the conception
911 of envy (Greek). Ideas of measure, equality, order, unity, proportion,
912 still linger in the writings of moralists; and the true spirit of the
913 fine arts is better conveyed by such terms than by superlatives.
914 
915    'When workmen strive to do better than well,
916    They do confound their skill in covetousness.'  (King John.)
917 
918 The harmony of the soul and body, and of the parts of the soul with
919 one another, a harmony 'fairer than that of musical notes,' is the true
920 Hellenic mode of conceiving the perfection of human nature.
921 
922 In what may be called the epilogue of the discussion with Thrasymachus,
923 Plato argues that evil is not a principle of strength, but of discord
924 and dissolution, just touching the question which has been often treated
925 in modern times by theologians and philosophers, of the negative nature
926 of evil. In the last argument we trace the germ of the Aristotelian
927 doctrine of an end and a virtue directed towards the end, which again is
928 suggested by the arts. The final reconcilement of justice and happiness
929 and the identity of the individual and the State are also intimated.
930 Socrates reassumes the character of a 'know-nothing;' at the same time
931 he appears to be not wholly satisfied with the manner in which the
932 argument has been conducted. Nothing is concluded; but the tendency of
933 the dialectical process, here as always, is to enlarge our conception of
934 ideas, and to widen their application to human life.
935 
936 BOOK II. Thrasymachus is pacified, but the intrepid Glaucon insists on
937 continuing the argument. He is not satisfied with the indirect manner
938 in which, at the end of the last book, Socrates had disposed of the
939 question 'Whether the just or the unjust is the happier.' He begins
940 by dividing goods into three classes:--first, goods desirable in
941 themselves; secondly, goods desirable in themselves and for their
942 results; thirdly, goods desirable for their results only. He then asks
943 Socrates in which of the three classes he would place justice. In the
944 second class, replies Socrates, among goods desirable for themselves and
945 also for their results. 'Then the world in general are of another mind,
946 for they say that justice belongs to the troublesome class of goods
947 which are desirable for their results only. Socrates answers that this
948 is the doctrine of Thrasymachus which he rejects. Glaucon thinks that
949 Thrasymachus was too ready to listen to the voice of the charmer, and
950 proposes to consider the nature of justice and injustice in themselves
951 and apart from the results and rewards of them which the world is always
952 dinning in his ears. He will first of all speak of the nature and origin
953 of justice; secondly, of the manner in which men view justice as a
954 necessity and not a good; and thirdly, he will prove the reasonableness
955 of this view.
956 
957 'To do injustice is said to be a good; to suffer injustice an evil. As
958 the evil is discovered by experience to be greater than the good, the
959 sufferers, who cannot also be doers, make a compact that they will have
960 neither, and this compact or mean is called justice, but is really the
961 impossibility of doing injustice. No one would observe such a compact
962 if he were not obliged. Let us suppose that the just and unjust have
963 two rings, like that of Gyges in the well-known story, which make them
964 invisible, and then no difference will appear in them, for every one
965 will do evil if he can. And he who abstains will be regarded by the
966 world as a fool for his pains. Men may praise him in public out of
967 fear for themselves, but they will laugh at him in their hearts (Cp.
968 Gorgias.)
969 
970 'And now let us frame an ideal of the just and unjust. Imagine the
971 unjust man to be master of his craft, seldom making mistakes and easily
972 correcting them; having gifts of money, speech, strength--the greatest
973 villain bearing the highest character: and at his side let us place the
974 just in his nobleness and simplicity--being, not seeming--without name
975 or reward--clothed in his justice only--the best of men who is thought
976 to be the worst, and let him die as he has lived. I might add (but
977 I would rather put the rest into the mouth of the panegyrists of
978 injustice--they will tell you) that the just man will be scourged,
979 racked, bound, will have his eyes put out, and will at last be crucified
980 (literally impaled)--and all this because he ought to have preferred
981 seeming to being. How different is the case of the unjust who clings to
982 appearance as the true reality! His high character makes him a ruler;
983 he can marry where he likes, trade where he likes, help his friends and
984 hurt his enemies; having got rich by dishonesty he can worship the gods
985 better, and will therefore be more loved by them than the just.'
986 
987 I was thinking what to answer, when Adeimantus joined in the already
988 unequal fray. He considered that the most important point of all had
989 been omitted:--'Men are taught to be just for the sake of rewards;
990 parents and guardians make reputation the incentive to virtue. And other
991 advantages are promised by them of a more solid kind, such as wealthy
992 marriages and high offices. There are the pictures in Homer and Hesiod
993 of fat sheep and heavy fleeces, rich corn-fields and trees toppling with
994 fruit, which the gods provide in this life for the just. And the Orphic
995 poets add a similar picture of another. The heroes of Musaeus and
996 Eumolpus lie on couches at a festival, with garlands on their heads,
997 enjoying as the meed of virtue a paradise of immortal drunkenness.
998 Some go further, and speak of a fair posterity in the third and fourth
999 generation. But the wicked they bury in a slough and make them carry
1000 water in a sieve: and in this life they attribute to them the infamy
1001 which Glaucon was assuming to be the lot of the just who are supposed to
1002 be unjust.
1003 
1004 'Take another kind of argument which is found both in poetry and
1005 prose:--"Virtue," as Hesiod says, "is honourable but difficult, vice is
1006 easy and profitable." You may often see the wicked in great prosperity
1007 and the righteous afflicted by the will of heaven. And mendicant
1008 prophets knock at rich men's doors, promising to atone for the sins
1009 of themselves or their fathers in an easy fashion with sacrifices and
1010 festive games, or with charms and invocations to get rid of an enemy
1011 good or bad by divine help and at a small charge;--they appeal to books
1012 professing to be written by Musaeus and Orpheus, and carry away the
1013 minds of whole cities, and promise to "get souls out of purgatory;" and
1014 if we refuse to listen to them, no one knows what will happen to us.
1015 
1016 'When a lively-minded ingenuous youth hears all this, what will be his
1017 conclusion? "Will he," in the language of Pindar, "make justice his high
1018 tower, or fortify himself with crooked deceit?" Justice, he reflects,
1019 without the appearance of justice, is misery and ruin; injustice has the
1020 promise of a glorious life. Appearance is master of truth and lord of
1021 happiness. To appearance then I will turn,--I will put on the show
1022 of virtue and trail behind me the fox of Archilochus. I hear some one
1023 saying that "wickedness is not easily concealed," to which I reply that
1024 "nothing great is easy." Union and force and rhetoric will do much; and
1025 if men say that they cannot prevail over the gods, still how do we know
1026 that there are gods? Only from the poets, who acknowledge that they may
1027 be appeased by sacrifices. Then why not sin and pay for indulgences out
1028 of your sin? For if the righteous are only unpunished, still they have
1029 no further reward, while the wicked may be unpunished and have the
1030 pleasure of sinning too. But what of the world below? Nay, says the
1031 argument, there are atoning powers who will set that matter right, as
1032 the poets, who are the sons of the gods, tell us; and this is confirmed
1033 by the authority of the State.
1034 
1035 'How can we resist such arguments in favour of injustice? Add good
1036 manners, and, as the wise tell us, we shall make the best of both
1037 worlds. Who that is not a miserable caitiff will refrain from smiling at
1038 the praises of justice? Even if a man knows the better part he will not
1039 be angry with others; for he knows also that more than human virtue is
1040 needed to save a man, and that he only praises justice who is incapable
1041 of injustice.
1042 
1043 'The origin of the evil is that all men from the beginning, heroes,
1044 poets, instructors of youth, have always asserted "the temporal
1045 dispensation," the honours and profits of justice. Had we been taught in
1046 early youth the power of justice and injustice inherent in the soul, and
1047 unseen by any human or divine eye, we should not have needed others to
1048 be our guardians, but every one would have been the guardian of himself.
1049 This is what I want you to show, Socrates;--other men use arguments
1050 which rather tend to strengthen the position of Thrasymachus that "might
1051 is right;" but from you I expect better things. And please, as Glaucon
1052 said, to exclude reputation; let the just be thought unjust and the
1053 unjust just, and do you still prove to us the superiority of justice'...
1054 
1055 The thesis, which for the sake of argument has been maintained by
1056 Glaucon, is the converse of that of Thrasymachus--not right is the
1057 interest of the stronger, but right is the necessity of the weaker.
1058 Starting from the same premises he carries the analysis of society a
1059 step further back;--might is still right, but the might is the weakness
1060 of the many combined against the strength of the few.
1061 
1062 There have been theories in modern as well as in ancient times which
1063 have a family likeness to the speculations of Glaucon; e.g. that power
1064 is the foundation of right; or that a monarch has a divine right to
1065 govern well or ill; or that virtue is self-love or the love of power; or
1066 that war is the natural state of man; or that private vices are public
1067 benefits. All such theories have a kind of plausibility from their
1068 partial agreement with experience. For human nature oscillates between
1069 good and evil, and the motives of actions and the origin of institutions
1070 may be explained to a certain extent on either hypothesis according to
1071 the character or point of view of a particular thinker. The obligation
1072 of maintaining authority under all circumstances and sometimes by rather
1073 questionable means is felt strongly and has become a sort of instinct
1074 among civilized men. The divine right of kings, or more generally of
1075 governments, is one of the forms under which this natural feeling is
1076 expressed. Nor again is there any evil which has not some accompaniment
1077 of good or pleasure; nor any good which is free from some alloy of evil;
1078 nor any noble or generous thought which may not be attended by a shadow
1079 or the ghost of a shadow of self-interest or of self-love. We know that
1080 all human actions are imperfect; but we do not therefore attribute
1081 them to the worse rather than to the better motive or principle. Such
1082 a philosophy is both foolish and false, like that opinion of the clever
1083 rogue who assumes all other men to be like himself. And theories of this
1084 sort do not represent the real nature of the State, which is based on a
1085 vague sense of right gradually corrected and enlarged by custom and law
1086 (although capable also of perversion), any more than they describe the
1087 origin of society, which is to be sought in the family and in the
1088 social and religious feelings of man. Nor do they represent the average
1089 character of individuals, which cannot be explained simply on a theory
1090 of evil, but has always a counteracting element of good. And as men
1091 become better such theories appear more and more untruthful to them,
1092 because they are more conscious of their own disinterestedness. A little
1093 experience may make a man a cynic; a great deal will bring him back to
1094 a truer and kindlier view of the mixed nature of himself and his fellow
1095 men.
1096 
1097 The two brothers ask Socrates to prove to them that the just is happy
1098 when they have taken from him all that in which happiness is ordinarily
1099 supposed to consist. Not that there is (1) any absurdity in the attempt
1100 to frame a notion of justice apart from circumstances. For the ideal
1101 must always be a paradox when compared with the ordinary conditions of
1102 human life. Neither the Stoical ideal nor the Christian ideal is true as
1103 a fact, but they may serve as a basis of education, and may exercise an
1104 ennobling influence. An ideal is none the worse because 'some one has
1105 made the discovery' that no such ideal was ever realized. And in a
1106 few exceptional individuals who are raised above the ordinary level of
1107 humanity, the ideal of happiness may be realized in death and misery.
1108 This may be the state which the reason deliberately approves, and which
1109 the utilitarian as well as every other moralist may be bound in certain
1110 cases to prefer.
1111 
1112 Nor again, (2) must we forget that Plato, though he agrees generally
1113 with the view implied in the argument of the two brothers, is not
1114 expressing his own final conclusion, but rather seeking to dramatize one
1115 of the aspects of ethical truth. He is developing his idea gradually in
1116 a series of positions or situations. He is exhibiting Socrates for the
1117 first time undergoing the Socratic interrogation. Lastly, (3) the word
1118 'happiness' involves some degree of confusion because associated in the
1119 language of modern philosophy with conscious pleasure or satisfaction,
1120 which was not equally present to his mind.
1121 
1122 Glaucon has been drawing a picture of the misery of the just and the
1123 happiness of the unjust, to which the misery of the tyrant in Book IX is
1124 the answer and parallel. And still the unjust must appear just; that is
1125 'the homage which vice pays to virtue.' But now Adeimantus, taking up
1126 the hint which had been already given by Glaucon, proceeds to show
1127 that in the opinion of mankind justice is regarded only for the sake of
1128 rewards and reputation, and points out the advantage which is given to
1129 such arguments as those of Thrasymachus and Glaucon by the conventional
1130 morality of mankind. He seems to feel the difficulty of 'justifying the
1131 ways of God to man.' Both the brothers touch upon the question, whether
1132 the morality of actions is determined by their consequences; and both
1133 of them go beyond the position of Socrates, that justice belongs to
1134 the class of goods not desirable for themselves only, but desirable for
1135 themselves and for their results, to which he recalls them. In
1136 their attempt to view justice as an internal principle, and in their
1137 condemnation of the poets, they anticipate him. The common life of
1138 Greece is not enough for them; they must penetrate deeper into the
1139 nature of things.
1140 
1141 It has been objected that justice is honesty in the sense of Glaucon and
1142 Adeimantus, but is taken by Socrates to mean all virtue. May we not
1143 more truly say that the old-fashioned notion of justice is enlarged by
1144 Socrates, and becomes equivalent to universal order or well-being, first
1145 in the State, and secondly in the individual? He has found a new answer
1146 to his old question (Protag.), 'whether the virtues are one or many,'
1147 viz. that one is the ordering principle of the three others. In seeking
1148 to establish the purely internal nature of justice, he is met by the
1149 fact that man is a social being, and he tries to harmonise the two
1150 opposite theses as well as he can. There is no more inconsistency in
1151 this than was inevitable in his age and country; there is no use in
1152 turning upon him the cross lights of modern philosophy, which, from some
1153 other point of view, would appear equally inconsistent. Plato does not
1154 give the final solution of philosophical questions for us; nor can he be
1155 judged of by our standard.
1156 
1157 The remainder of the Republic is developed out of the question of
1158 the sons of Ariston. Three points are deserving of remark in what
1159 immediately follows:--First, that the answer of Socrates is altogether
1160 indirect. He does not say that happiness consists in the contemplation
1161 of the idea of justice, and still less will he be tempted to affirm the
1162 Stoical paradox that the just man can be happy on the rack. But first he
1163 dwells on the difficulty of the problem and insists on restoring man to
1164 his natural condition, before he will answer the question at all. He
1165 too will frame an ideal, but his ideal comprehends not only abstract
1166 justice, but the whole relations of man. Under the fanciful illustration
1167 of the large letters he implies that he will only look for justice in
1168 society, and that from the State he will proceed to the individual. His
1169 answer in substance amounts to this,--that under favourable conditions,
1170 i.e. in the perfect State, justice and happiness will coincide, and that
1171 when justice has been once found, happiness may be left to take care
1172 of itself. That he falls into some degree of inconsistency, when in
1173 the tenth book he claims to have got rid of the rewards and honours
1174 of justice, may be admitted; for he has left those which exist in the
1175 perfect State. And the philosopher 'who retires under the shelter of a
1176 wall' can hardly have been esteemed happy by him, at least not in this
1177 world. Still he maintains the true attitude of moral action. Let a man
1178 do his duty first, without asking whether he will be happy or not, and
1179 happiness will be the inseparable accident which attends him. 'Seek ye
1180 first the kingdom of God and his righteousness, and all these things
1181 shall be added unto you.'
1182 
1183 Secondly, it may be remarked that Plato preserves the genuine character
1184 of Greek thought in beginning with the State and in going on to the
1185 individual. First ethics, then politics--this is the order of ideas to
1186 us; the reverse is the order of history. Only after many struggles of
1187 thought does the individual assert his right as a moral being. In early
1188 ages he is not ONE, but one of many, the citizen of a State which is
