1189 prior to him; and he has no notion of good or evil apart from the law
1190 of his country or the creed of his church. And to this type he is
1191 constantly tending to revert, whenever the influence of custom, or of
1192 party spirit, or the recollection of the past becomes too strong for
1193 him.
1194 
1195 Thirdly, we may observe the confusion or identification of the
1196 individual and the State, of ethics and politics, which pervades early
1197 Greek speculation, and even in modern times retains a certain degree of
1198 influence. The subtle difference between the collective and individual
1199 action of mankind seems to have escaped early thinkers, and we too are
1200 sometimes in danger of forgetting the conditions of united human action,
1201 whenever we either elevate politics into ethics, or lower ethics to the
1202 standard of politics. The good man and the good citizen only coincide in
1203 the perfect State; and this perfection cannot be attained by legislation
1204 acting upon them from without, but, if at all, by education fashioning
1205 them from within.
1206 
1207 ...Socrates praises the sons of Ariston, 'inspired offspring of
1208 the renowned hero,' as the elegiac poet terms them; but he does not
1209 understand how they can argue so eloquently on behalf of injustice while
1210 their character shows that they are uninfluenced by their own arguments.
1211 He knows not how to answer them, although he is afraid of deserting
1212 justice in the hour of need. He therefore makes a condition, that having
1213 weak eyes he shall be allowed to read the large letters first and then
1214 go on to the smaller, that is, he must look for justice in the State
1215 first, and will then proceed to the individual. Accordingly he begins to
1216 construct the State.
1217 
1218 Society arises out of the wants of man. His first want is food; his
1219 second a house; his third a coat. The sense of these needs and the
1220 possibility of satisfying them by exchange, draw individuals together on
1221 the same spot; and this is the beginning of a State, which we take the
1222 liberty to invent, although necessity is the real inventor. There must
1223 be first a husbandman, secondly a builder, thirdly a weaver, to which
1224 may be added a cobbler. Four or five citizens at least are required to
1225 make a city. Now men have different natures, and one man will do one
1226 thing better than many; and business waits for no man. Hence there must
1227 be a division of labour into different employments; into wholesale
1228 and retail trade; into workers, and makers of workmen's tools; into
1229 shepherds and husbandmen. A city which includes all this will have far
1230 exceeded the limit of four or five, and yet not be very large. But then
1231 again imports will be required, and imports necessitate exports,
1232 and this implies variety of produce in order to attract the taste of
1233 purchasers; also merchants and ships. In the city too we must have a
1234 market and money and retail trades; otherwise buyers and sellers will
1235 never meet, and the valuable time of the producers will be wasted in
1236 vain efforts at exchange. If we add hired servants the State will be
1237 complete. And we may guess that somewhere in the intercourse of the
1238 citizens with one another justice and injustice will appear.
1239 
1240 Here follows a rustic picture of their way of life. They spend their
1241 days in houses which they have built for themselves; they make their
1242 own clothes and produce their own corn and wine. Their principal food is
1243 meal and flour, and they drink in moderation. They live on the best
1244 of terms with each other, and take care not to have too many children.
1245 'But,' said Glaucon, interposing, 'are they not to have a relish?'
1246 Certainly; they will have salt and olives and cheese, vegetables and
1247 fruits, and chestnuts to roast at the fire. ''Tis a city of pigs,
1248 Socrates.' Why, I replied, what do you want more? 'Only the comforts of
1249 life,--sofas and tables, also sauces and sweets.' I see; you want not
1250 only a State, but a luxurious State; and possibly in the more complex
1251 frame we may sooner find justice and injustice. Then the fine arts must
1252 go to work--every conceivable instrument and ornament of luxury will be
1253 wanted. There will be dancers, painters, sculptors, musicians, cooks,
1254 barbers, tire-women, nurses, artists; swineherds and neatherds too for
1255 the animals, and physicians to cure the disorders of which luxury is the
1256 source. To feed all these superfluous mouths we shall need a part of
1257 our neighbour's land, and they will want a part of ours. And this is the
1258 origin of war, which may be traced to the same causes as other political
1259 evils. Our city will now require the slight addition of a camp, and
1260 the citizen will be converted into a soldier. But then again our old
1261 doctrine of the division of labour must not be forgotten. The art of
1262 war cannot be learned in a day, and there must be a natural aptitude
1263 for military duties. There will be some warlike natures who have this
1264 aptitude--dogs keen of scent, swift of foot to pursue, and strong of
1265 limb to fight. And as spirit is the foundation of courage, such natures,
1266 whether of men or animals, will be full of spirit. But these spirited
1267 natures are apt to bite and devour one another; the union of
1268 gentleness to friends and fierceness against enemies appears to be an
1269 impossibility, and the guardian of a State requires both qualities. Who
1270 then can be a guardian? The image of the dog suggests an answer. For
1271 dogs are gentle to friends and fierce to strangers. Your dog is a
1272 philosopher who judges by the rule of knowing or not knowing; and
1273 philosophy, whether in man or beast, is the parent of gentleness. The
1274 human watchdogs must be philosophers or lovers of learning which will
1275 make them gentle. And how are they to be learned without education?
1276 
1277 But what shall their education be? Is any better than the old-fashioned
1278 sort which is comprehended under the name of music and gymnastic? Music
1279 includes literature, and literature is of two kinds, true and false.
1280 'What do you mean?' he said. I mean that children hear stories before
1281 they learn gymnastics, and that the stories are either untrue, or have
1282 at most one or two grains of truth in a bushel of falsehood. Now early
1283 life is very impressible, and children ought not to learn what they will
1284 have to unlearn when they grow up; we must therefore have a censorship
1285 of nursery tales, banishing some and keeping others. Some of them are
1286 very improper, as we may see in the great instances of Homer and Hesiod,
1287 who not only tell lies but bad lies; stories about Uranus and Saturn,
1288 which are immoral as well as false, and which should never be spoken of
1289 to young persons, or indeed at all; or, if at all, then in a mystery,
1290 after the sacrifice, not of an Eleusinian pig, but of some unprocurable
1291 animal. Shall our youth be encouraged to beat their fathers by the
1292 example of Zeus, or our citizens be incited to quarrel by hearing or
1293 seeing representations of strife among the gods? Shall they listen to
1294 the narrative of Hephaestus binding his mother, and of Zeus sending him
1295 flying for helping her when she was beaten? Such tales may possibly have
1296 a mystical interpretation, but the young are incapable of understanding
1297 allegory. If any one asks what tales are to be allowed, we will answer
1298 that we are legislators and not book-makers; we only lay down the
1299 principles according to which books are to be written; to write them is
1300 the duty of others.
1301 
1302 And our first principle is, that God must be represented as he is; not
1303 as the author of all things, but of good only. We will not suffer the
1304 poets to say that he is the steward of good and evil, or that he has two
1305 casks full of destinies;--or that Athene and Zeus incited Pandarus to
1306 break the treaty; or that God caused the sufferings of Niobe, or of
1307 Pelops, or the Trojan war; or that he makes men sin when he wishes to
1308 destroy them. Either these were not the actions of the gods, or God was
1309 just, and men were the better for being punished. But that the deed was
1310 evil, and God the author, is a wicked, suicidal fiction which we will
1311 allow no one, old or young, to utter. This is our first and great
1312 principle--God is the author of good only.
1313 
1314 And the second principle is like unto it:--With God is no variableness
1315 or change of form. Reason teaches us this; for if we suppose a change
1316 in God, he must be changed either by another or by himself. By
1317 another?--but the best works of nature and art and the noblest qualities
1318 of mind are least liable to be changed by any external force. By
1319 himself?--but he cannot change for the better; he will hardly change
1320 for the worse. He remains for ever fairest and best in his own image.
1321 Therefore we refuse to listen to the poets who tell us of Here begging
1322 in the likeness of a priestess or of other deities who prowl about at
1323 night in strange disguises; all that blasphemous nonsense with which
1324 mothers fool the manhood out of their children must be suppressed. But
1325 some one will say that God, who is himself unchangeable, may take a form
1326 in relation to us. Why should he? For gods as well as men hate the lie
1327 in the soul, or principle of falsehood; and as for any other form of
1328 lying which is used for a purpose and is regarded as innocent in certain
1329 exceptional cases--what need have the gods of this? For they are not
1330 ignorant of antiquity like the poets, nor are they afraid of their
1331 enemies, nor is any madman a friend of theirs. God then is true, he is
1332 absolutely true; he changes not, he deceives not, by day or night, by
1333 word or sign. This is our second great principle--God is true. Away
1334 with the lying dream of Agamemnon in Homer, and the accusation of Thetis
1335 against Apollo in Aeschylus...
1336 
1337 In order to give clearness to his conception of the State, Plato
1338 proceeds to trace the first principles of mutual need and of division
1339 of labour in an imaginary community of four or five citizens. Gradually
1340 this community increases; the division of labour extends to countries;
1341 imports necessitate exports; a medium of exchange is required, and
1342 retailers sit in the market-place to save the time of the producers.
1343 These are the steps by which Plato constructs the first or primitive
1344 State, introducing the elements of political economy by the way. As
1345 he is going to frame a second or civilized State, the simple naturally
1346 comes before the complex. He indulges, like Rousseau, in a picture of
1347 primitive life--an idea which has indeed often had a powerful influence
1348 on the imagination of mankind, but he does not seriously mean to say
1349 that one is better than the other (Politicus); nor can any inference
1350 be drawn from the description of the first state taken apart from the
1351 second, such as Aristotle appears to draw in the Politics. We should not
1352 interpret a Platonic dialogue any more than a poem or a parable in too
1353 literal or matter-of-fact a style. On the other hand, when we compare
1354 the lively fancy of Plato with the dried-up abstractions of modern
1355 treatises on philosophy, we are compelled to say with Protagoras, that
1356 the 'mythus is more interesting' (Protag.)
1357 
1358 Several interesting remarks which in modern times would have a place in
1359 a treatise on Political Economy are scattered up and down the writings
1360 of Plato: especially Laws, Population; Free Trade; Adulteration; Wills
1361 and Bequests; Begging; Eryxias, (though not Plato's), Value and Demand;
1362 Republic, Division of Labour. The last subject, and also the origin of
1363 Retail Trade, is treated with admirable lucidity in the second book of
1364 the Republic. But Plato never combined his economic ideas into a system,
1365 and never seems to have recognized that Trade is one of the great motive
1366 powers of the State and of the world. He would make retail traders
1367 only of the inferior sort of citizens (Rep., Laws), though he remarks,
1368 quaintly enough (Laws), that 'if only the best men and the best women
1369 everywhere were compelled to keep taverns for a time or to carry on
1370 retail trade, etc., then we should knew how pleasant and agreeable all
1371 these things are.'
1372 
1373 The disappointment of Glaucon at the 'city of pigs,' the ludicrous
1374 description of the ministers of luxury in the more refined State, and
1375 the afterthought of the necessity of doctors, the illustration of the
1376 nature of the guardian taken from the dog, the desirableness of
1377 offering some almost unprocurable victim when impure mysteries are to be
1378 celebrated, the behaviour of Zeus to his father and of Hephaestus to
1379 his mother, are touches of humour which have also a serious meaning. In
1380 speaking of education Plato rather startles us by affirming that a child
1381 must be trained in falsehood first and in truth afterwards. Yet this is
1382 not very different from saying that children must be taught through
1383 the medium of imagination as well as reason; that their minds can only
1384 develope gradually, and that there is much which they must learn without
1385 understanding. This is also the substance of Plato's view, though he
1386 must be acknowledged to have drawn the line somewhat differently from
1387 modern ethical writers, respecting truth and falsehood. To us, economies
1388 or accommodations would not be allowable unless they were required by
1389 the human faculties or necessary for the communication of knowledge to
1390 the simple and ignorant. We should insist that the word was inseparable
1391 from the intention, and that we must not be 'falsely true,' i.e. speak
1392 or act falsely in support of what was right or true. But Plato would
1393 limit the use of fictions only by requiring that they should have a good
1394 moral effect, and that such a dangerous weapon as falsehood should be
1395 employed by the rulers alone and for great objects.
1396 
1397 A Greek in the age of Plato attached no importance to the question
1398 whether his religion was an historical fact. He was just beginning to be
1399 conscious that the past had a history; but he could see nothing beyond
1400 Homer and Hesiod. Whether their narratives were true or false did not
1401 seriously affect the political or social life of Hellas. Men only began
1402 to suspect that they were fictions when they recognised them to be
1403 immoral. And so in all religions: the consideration of their morality
1404 comes first, afterwards the truth of the documents in which they are
1405 recorded, or of the events natural or supernatural which are told of
1406 them. But in modern times, and in Protestant countries perhaps more than
1407 in Catholic, we have been too much inclined to identify the historical
1408 with the moral; and some have refused to believe in religion at all,
1409 unless a superhuman accuracy was discernible in every part of the
1410 record. The facts of an ancient or religious history are amongst the
1411 most important of all facts; but they are frequently uncertain, and we
1412 only learn the true lesson which is to be gathered from them when we
1413 place ourselves above them. These reflections tend to show that the
1414 difference between Plato and ourselves, though not unimportant, is not
1415 so great as might at first sight appear. For we should agree with him
1416 in placing the moral before the historical truth of religion; and,
1417 generally, in disregarding those errors or misstatements of fact which
1418 necessarily occur in the early stages of all religions. We know also
1419 that changes in the traditions of a country cannot be made in a day; and
1420 are therefore tolerant of many things which science and criticism would
1421 condemn.
1422 
1423 We note in passing that the allegorical interpretation of mythology,
1424 said to have been first introduced as early as the sixth century before
1425 Christ by Theagenes of Rhegium, was well established in the age of
1426 Plato, and here, as in the Phaedrus, though for a different reason, was
1427 rejected by him. That anachronisms whether of religion or law, when
1428 men have reached another stage of civilization, should be got rid of by
1429 fictions is in accordance with universal experience. Great is the art of
1430 interpretation; and by a natural process, which when once discovered was
1431 always going on, what could not be altered was explained away. And so
1432 without any palpable inconsistency there existed side by side two forms
1433 of religion, the tradition inherited or invented by the poets and
1434 the customary worship of the temple; on the other hand, there was the
1435 religion of the philosopher, who was dwelling in the heaven of ideas,
1436 but did not therefore refuse to offer a cock to Aesculapius, or to
1437 be seen saying his prayers at the rising of the sun. At length the
1438 antagonism between the popular and philosophical religion, never so
1439 great among the Greeks as in our own age, disappeared, and was only felt
1440 like the difference between the religion of the educated and uneducated
1441 among ourselves. The Zeus of Homer and Hesiod easily passed into
1442 the 'royal mind' of Plato (Philebus); the giant Heracles became the
1443 knight-errant and benefactor of mankind. These and still more wonderful
1444 transformations were readily effected by the ingenuity of Stoics and
1445 neo-Platonists in the two or three centuries before and after Christ.
1446 The Greek and Roman religions were gradually permeated by the spirit of
1447 philosophy; having lost their ancient meaning, they were resolved into
1448 poetry and morality; and probably were never purer than at the time of
1449 their decay, when their influence over the world was waning.
1450 
1451 A singular conception which occurs towards the end of the book is
1452 the lie in the soul; this is connected with the Platonic and Socratic
1453 doctrine that involuntary ignorance is worse than voluntary. The lie
1454 in the soul is a true lie, the corruption of the highest truth, the
1455 deception of the highest part of the soul, from which he who is deceived
1456 has no power of delivering himself. For example, to represent God
1457 as false or immoral, or, according to Plato, as deluding men with
1458 appearances or as the author of evil; or again, to affirm with
1459 Protagoras that 'knowledge is sensation,' or that 'being is becoming,'
1460 or with Thrasymachus 'that might is right,' would have been regarded by
1461 Plato as a lie of this hateful sort. The greatest unconsciousness of the
1462 greatest untruth, e.g. if, in the language of the Gospels (John), 'he
1463 who was blind' were to say 'I see,' is another aspect of the state
1464 of mind which Plato is describing. The lie in the soul may be further
1465 compared with the sin against the Holy Ghost (Luke), allowing for the
1466 difference between Greek and Christian modes of speaking. To this is
1467 opposed the lie in words, which is only such a deception as may occur
1468 in a play or poem, or allegory or figure of speech, or in any sort of
1469 accommodation,--which though useless to the gods may be useful to men
1470 in certain cases. Socrates is here answering the question which he had
1471 himself raised about the propriety of deceiving a madman; and he is also
1472 contrasting the nature of God and man. For God is Truth, but mankind can
1473 only be true by appearing sometimes to be partial, or false. Reserving
1474 for another place the greater questions of religion or education, we
1475 may note further, (1) the approval of the old traditional education
1476 of Greece; (2) the preparation which Plato is making for the attack on
1477 Homer and the poets; (3) the preparation which he is also making for the
1478 use of economies in the State; (4) the contemptuous and at the same time
1479 euphemistic manner in which here as below he alludes to the 'Chronique
1480 Scandaleuse' of the gods.
1481 
1482 BOOK III. There is another motive in purifying religion, which is to
1483 banish fear; for no man can be courageous who is afraid of death, or who
1484 believes the tales which are repeated by the poets concerning the world
1485 below. They must be gently requested not to abuse hell; they may be
1486 reminded that their stories are both untrue and discouraging. Nor must
1487 they be angry if we expunge obnoxious passages, such as the depressing
1488 words of Achilles--'I would rather be a serving-man than rule over
1489 all the dead;' and the verses which tell of the squalid mansions, the
1490 senseless shadows, the flitting soul mourning over lost strength and
1491 youth, the soul with a gibber going beneath the earth like smoke, or
1492 the souls of the suitors which flutter about like bats. The terrors and
1493 horrors of Cocytus and Styx, ghosts and sapless shades, and the rest
1494 of their Tartarean nomenclature, must vanish. Such tales may have their
1495 use; but they are not the proper food for soldiers. As little can we
1496 admit the sorrows and sympathies of the Homeric heroes:--Achilles, the
1497 son of Thetis, in tears, throwing ashes on his head, or pacing up and
1498 down the sea-shore in distraction; or Priam, the cousin of the gods,
1499 crying aloud, rolling in the mire. A good man is not prostrated at
1500 the loss of children or fortune. Neither is death terrible to him; and
1501 therefore lamentations over the dead should not be practised by men of
1502 note; they should be the concern of inferior persons only, whether women
1503 or men. Still worse is the attribution of such weakness to the gods; as
1504 when the goddesses say, 'Alas! my travail!' and worst of all, when the
1505 king of heaven himself laments his inability to save Hector, or sorrows
1506 over the impending doom of his dear Sarpedon. Such a character of God,
1507 if not ridiculed by our young men, is likely to be imitated by them.
1508 Nor should our citizens be given to excess of laughter--'Such violent
1509 delights' are followed by a violent re-action. The description in the
1510 Iliad of the gods shaking their sides at the clumsiness of Hephaestus
1511 will not be admitted by us. 'Certainly not.'
1512 
1513 Truth should have a high place among the virtues, for falsehood, as
1514 we were saying, is useless to the gods, and only useful to men as a
1515 medicine. But this employment of falsehood must remain a privilege of
1516 state; the common man must not in return tell a lie to the ruler; any
1517 more than the patient would tell a lie to his physician, or the sailor
1518 to his captain.
1519 
1520 In the next place our youth must be temperate, and temperance consists
1521 in self-control and obedience to authority. That is a lesson which Homer
1522 teaches in some places: 'The Achaeans marched on breathing prowess, in
1523 silent awe of their leaders;'--but a very different one in other places:
1524 'O heavy with wine, who hast the eyes of a dog, but the heart of a
1525 stag.' Language of the latter kind will not impress self-control on the
1526 minds of youth. The same may be said about his praises of eating and
1527 drinking and his dread of starvation; also about the verses in which he
1528 tells of the rapturous loves of Zeus and Here, or of how Hephaestus once
1529 detained Ares and Aphrodite in a net on a similar occasion. There is a
1530 nobler strain heard in the words:--'Endure, my soul, thou hast endured
1531 worse.' Nor must we allow our citizens to receive bribes, or to say,
1532 'Gifts persuade the gods, gifts reverend kings;' or to applaud the
1533 ignoble advice of Phoenix to Achilles that he should get money out of
1534 the Greeks before he assisted them; or the meanness of Achilles himself
1535 in taking gifts from Agamemnon; or his requiring a ransom for the body
1536 of Hector; or his cursing of Apollo; or his insolence to the river-god
1537 Scamander; or his dedication to the dead Patroclus of his own hair which
1538 had been already dedicated to the other river-god Spercheius; or his
1539 cruelty in dragging the body of Hector round the walls, and slaying
1540 the captives at the pyre: such a combination of meanness and cruelty in
1541 Cheiron's pupil is inconceivable. The amatory exploits of Peirithous and
1542 Theseus are equally unworthy. Either these so-called sons of gods were
1543 not the sons of gods, or they were not such as the poets imagine them,
1544 any more than the gods themselves are the authors of evil. The youth who
1545 believes that such things are done by those who have the blood of heaven
1546 flowing in their veins will be too ready to imitate their example.
1547 
1548 Enough of gods and heroes;--what shall we say about men? What the poets
1549 and story-tellers say--that the wicked prosper and the righteous are
1550 afflicted, or that justice is another's gain? Such misrepresentations
1551 cannot be allowed by us. But in this we are anticipating the definition
1552 of justice, and had therefore better defer the enquiry.
1553 
1554 The subjects of poetry have been sufficiently treated; next follows
1555 style. Now all poetry is a narrative of events past, present, or to
1556 come; and narrative is of three kinds, the simple, the imitative, and
1557 a composition of the two. An instance will make my meaning clear.
1558 The first scene in Homer is of the last or mixed kind, being partly
1559 description and partly dialogue. But if you throw the dialogue into the
1560 'oratio obliqua,' the passage will run thus: The priest came and prayed
1561 Apollo that the Achaeans might take Troy and have a safe return if
1562 Agamemnon would only give him back his daughter; and the other Greeks
1563 assented, but Agamemnon was wroth, and so on--The whole then becomes
1564 descriptive, and the poet is the only speaker left; or, if you omit the
1565 narrative, the whole becomes dialogue. These are the three styles--which
1566 of them is to be admitted into our State? 'Do you ask whether tragedy
1567 and comedy are to be admitted?' Yes, but also something more--Is it not
1568 doubtful whether our guardians are to be imitators at all? Or rather,
1569 has not the question been already answered, for we have decided that one
1570 man cannot in his life play many parts, any more than he can act both
1571 tragedy and comedy, or be rhapsodist and actor at once? Human nature
1572 is coined into very small pieces, and as our guardians have their own
1573 business already, which is the care of freedom, they will have enough
1574 to do without imitating. If they imitate they should imitate, not any
1575 meanness or baseness, but the good only; for the mask which the actor
1576 wears is apt to become his face. We cannot allow men to play the parts
1577 of women, quarrelling, weeping, scolding, or boasting against the
1578 gods,--least of all when making love or in labour. They must not
1579 represent slaves, or bullies, or cowards, drunkards, or madmen, or
1580 blacksmiths, or neighing horses, or bellowing bulls, or sounding rivers,
1581 or a raging sea. A good or wise man will be willing to perform good and
1582 wise actions, but he will be ashamed to play an inferior part which he
1583 has never practised; and he will prefer to employ the descriptive style
1584 with as little imitation as possible. The man who has no self-respect,
1585 on the contrary, will imitate anybody and anything; sounds of nature
1586 and cries of animals alike; his whole performance will be imitation of
1587 gesture and voice. Now in the descriptive style there are few changes,
1588 but in the dramatic there are a great many. Poets and musicians use
1589 either, or a compound of both, and this compound is very attractive
1590 to youth and their teachers as well as to the vulgar. But our State in
1591 which one man plays one part only is not adapted for complexity. And
1592 when one of these polyphonous pantomimic gentlemen offers to exhibit
1593 himself and his poetry we will show him every observance of respect,
1594 but at the same time tell him that there is no room for his kind in our
1595 State; we prefer the rough, honest poet, and will not depart from our
1596 original models (Laws).
1597 
1598 Next as to the music. A song or ode has three parts,--the subject, the
1599 harmony, and the rhythm; of which the two last are dependent upon the
1600 first. As we banished strains of lamentation, so we may now banish the
1601 mixed Lydian harmonies, which are the harmonies of lamentation; and
1602 as our citizens are to be temperate, we may also banish convivial
1603 harmonies, such as the Ionian and pure Lydian. Two remain--the
1604 Dorian and Phrygian, the first for war, the second for peace; the
1605 one expressive of courage, the other of obedience or instruction or
1606 religious feeling. And as we reject varieties of harmony, we shall
1607 also reject the many-stringed, variously-shaped instruments which give
1608 utterance to them, and in particular the flute, which is more complex
1609 than any of them. The lyre and the harp may be permitted in the town,
1610 and the Pan's-pipe in the fields. Thus we have made a purgation of
1611 music, and will now make a purgation of metres. These should be like the
1612 harmonies, simple and suitable to the occasion. There are four notes
1613 of the tetrachord, and there are three ratios of metre, 3/2, 2/2,
1614 2/1, which have all their characteristics, and the feet have different
1615 characteristics as well as the rhythms. But about this you and I must
1616 ask Damon, the great musician, who speaks, if I remember rightly, of a
1617 martial measure as well as of dactylic, trochaic, and iambic rhythms,
1618 which he arranges so as to equalize the syllables with one another,
1619 assigning to each the proper quantity. We only venture to affirm the
1620 general principle that the style is to conform to the subject and the
1621 metre to the style; and that the simplicity and harmony of the soul
1622 should be reflected in them all. This principle of simplicity has to
1623 be learnt by every one in the days of his youth, and may be gathered
1624 anywhere, from the creative and constructive arts, as well as from the
1625 forms of plants and animals.
1626 
1627 Other artists as well as poets should be warned against meanness or
1628 unseemliness. Sculpture and painting equally with music must conform to
1629 the law of simplicity. He who violates it cannot be allowed to work in
1630 our city, and to corrupt the taste of our citizens. For our guardians
1631 must grow up, not amid images of deformity which will gradually poison
1632 and corrupt their souls, but in a land of health and beauty where they
1633 will drink in from every object sweet and harmonious influences. And of
1634 all these influences the greatest is the education given by music,
1635 which finds a way into the innermost soul and imparts to it the sense
1636 of beauty and of deformity. At first the effect is unconscious; but when
1637 reason arrives, then he who has been thus trained welcomes her as the
1638 friend whom he always knew. As in learning to read, first we acquire the
1639 elements or letters separately, and afterwards their combinations,
1640 and cannot recognize reflections of them until we know the letters
1641 themselves;--in like manner we must first attain the elements or
1642 essential forms of the virtues, and then trace their combinations in
1643 life and experience. There is a music of the soul which answers to the
1644 harmony of the world; and the fairest object of a musical soul is the
1645 fair mind in the fair body. Some defect in the latter may be excused,
1646 but not in the former. True love is the daughter of temperance, and
1647 temperance is utterly opposed to the madness of bodily pleasure. Enough
1648 has been said of music, which makes a fair ending with love.
1649 
1650 Next we pass on to gymnastics; about which I would remark, that the
1651 soul is related to the body as a cause to an effect, and therefore if we
1652 educate the mind we may leave the education of the body in her charge,
1653 and need only give a general outline of the course to be pursued. In
1654 the first place the guardians must abstain from strong drink, for they
1655 should be the last persons to lose their wits. Whether the habits of
1656 the palaestra are suitable to them is more doubtful, for the ordinary
1657 gymnastic is a sleepy sort of thing, and if left off suddenly is apt to
1658 endanger health. But our warrior athletes must be wide-awake dogs, and
1659 must also be inured to all changes of food and climate. Hence they will
1660 require a simpler kind of gymnastic, akin to their simple music; and for
1661 their diet a rule may be found in Homer, who feeds his heroes on roast
1662 meat only, and gives them no fish although they are living at the
1663 sea-side, nor boiled meats which involve an apparatus of pots and pans;
1664 and, if I am not mistaken, he nowhere mentions sweet sauces. Sicilian
1665 cookery and Attic confections and Corinthian courtezans, which are
1666 to gymnastic what Lydian and Ionian melodies are to music, must be
1667 forbidden. Where gluttony and intemperance prevail the town quickly
1668 fills with doctors and pleaders; and law and medicine give themselves
1669 airs as soon as the freemen of a State take an interest in them. But
1670 what can show a more disgraceful state of education than to have to go
1671 abroad for justice because you have none of your own at home? And yet
1672 there IS a worse stage of the same disease--when men have learned
1673 to take a pleasure and pride in the twists and turns of the law; not
1674 considering how much better it would be for them so to order their lives
1675 as to have no need of a nodding justice. And there is a like disgrace in
1676 employing a physician, not for the cure of wounds or epidemic disorders,
1677 but because a man has by laziness and luxury contracted diseases
1678 which were unknown in the days of Asclepius. How simple is the Homeric
1679 practice of medicine. Eurypylus after he has been wounded drinks a
1680 posset of Pramnian wine, which is of a heating nature; and yet the
1681 sons of Asclepius blame neither the damsel who gives him the drink, nor
1682 Patroclus who is attending on him. The truth is that this modern system
1683 of nursing diseases was introduced by Herodicus the trainer; who,
1684 being of a sickly constitution, by a compound of training and medicine
1685 tortured first himself and then a good many other people, and lived
1686 a great deal longer than he had any right. But Asclepius would not
1687 practise this art, because he knew that the citizens of a well-ordered
1688 State have no leisure to be ill, and therefore he adopted the 'kill
1689 or cure' method, which artisans and labourers employ. 'They must be
1690 at their business,' they say, 'and have no time for coddling: if they
1691 recover, well; if they don't, there is an end of them.' Whereas the rich
1692 man is supposed to be a gentleman who can afford to be ill. Do you know
1693 a maxim of Phocylides--that 'when a man begins to be rich' (or, perhaps,
1694 a little sooner) 'he should practise virtue'? But how can excessive
1695 care of health be inconsistent with an ordinary occupation, and yet
1696 consistent with that practice of virtue which Phocylides inculcates?
1697 When a student imagines that philosophy gives him a headache, he never
1698 does anything; he is always unwell. This was the reason why Asclepius
1699 and his sons practised no such art. They were acting in the interest of
1700 the public, and did not wish to preserve useless lives, or raise up a
1701 puny offspring to wretched sires. Honest diseases they honestly cured;
1702 and if a man was wounded, they applied the proper remedies, and then let
1703 him eat and drink what he liked. But they declined to treat intemperate
1704 and worthless subjects, even though they might have made large fortunes
1705 out of them. As to the story of Pindar, that Asclepius was slain by a
1706 thunderbolt for restoring a rich man to life, that is a lie--following
1707 our old rule we must say either that he did not take bribes, or that he
1708 was not the son of a god.
1709 
1710 Glaucon then asks Socrates whether the best physicians and the best
1711 judges will not be those who have had severally the greatest experience
1712 of diseases and of crimes. Socrates draws a distinction between the two
1713 professions. The physician should have had experience of disease in
1714 his own body, for he cures with his mind and not with his body. But
1715 the judge controls mind by mind; and therefore his mind should not be
1716 corrupted by crime. Where then is he to gain experience? How is he to be
1717 wise and also innocent? When young a good man is apt to be deceived by
1718 evil-doers, because he has no pattern of evil in himself; and therefore
1719 the judge should be of a certain age; his youth should have been
1720 innocent, and he should have acquired insight into evil not by the
1721 practice of it, but by the observation of it in others. This is
1722 the ideal of a judge; the criminal turned detective is wonderfully
1723 suspicious, but when in company with good men who have experience, he is
1724 at fault, for he foolishly imagines that every one is as bad as himself.
1725 Vice may be known of virtue, but cannot know virtue. This is the sort of
1726 medicine and this the sort of law which will prevail in our State; they
1727 will be healing arts to better natures; but the evil body will be left
1728 to die by the one, and the evil soul will be put to death by the other.
1729 And the need of either will be greatly diminished by good music which
1730 will give harmony to the soul, and good gymnastic which will give
1731 health to the body. Not that this division of music and gymnastic really
1732 corresponds to soul and body; for they are both equally concerned with
1733 the soul, which is tamed by the one and aroused and sustained by the
1734 other. The two together supply our guardians with their twofold nature.
1735 The passionate disposition when it has too much gymnastic is hardened
1736 and brutalized, the gentle or philosophic temper which has too much
1737 music becomes enervated. While a man is allowing music to pour like
1738 water through the funnel of his ears, the edge of his soul gradually
1739 wears away, and the passionate or spirited element is melted out of
1740 him. Too little spirit is easily exhausted; too much quickly passes into
1741 nervous irritability. So, again, the athlete by feeding and training has
1742 his courage doubled, but he soon grows stupid; he is like a wild beast,
1743 ready to do everything by blows and nothing by counsel or policy. There
1744 are two principles in man, reason and passion, and to these, not to the
1745 soul and body, the two arts of music and gymnastic correspond. He who
1746 mingles them in harmonious concord is the true musician,--he shall be
1747 the presiding genius of our State.
1748 
1749 The next question is, Who are to be our rulers? First, the elder must
1750 rule the younger; and the best of the elders will be the best guardians.
1751 Now they will be the best who love their subjects most, and think that
1752 they have a common interest with them in the welfare of the state. These
1753 we must select; but they must be watched at every epoch of life to see
1754 whether they have retained the same opinions and held out against force
1755 and enchantment. For time and persuasion and the love of pleasure may
1756 enchant a man into a change of purpose, and the force of grief and pain
1757 may compel him. And therefore our guardians must be men who have been
1758 tried by many tests, like gold in the refiner's fire, and have been
1759 passed first through danger, then through pleasure, and at every age
1760 have come out of such trials victorious and without stain, in full
1761 command of themselves and their principles; having all their faculties
1762 in harmonious exercise for their country's good. These shall receive the
1763 highest honours both in life and death. (It would perhaps be better to
1764 confine the term 'guardians' to this select class: the younger men may
1765 be called 'auxiliaries.')
1766 
1767 And now for one magnificent lie, in the belief of which, Oh that we
1768 could train our rulers!--at any rate let us make the attempt with the
1769 rest of the world. What I am going to tell is only another version of
1770 the legend of Cadmus; but our unbelieving generation will be slow to
1771 accept such a story. The tale must be imparted, first to the rulers,
1772 then to the soldiers, lastly to the people. We will inform them that
1773 their youth was a dream, and that during the time when they seemed to
1774 be undergoing their education they were really being fashioned in the
1775 earth, who sent them up when they were ready; and that they must protect
1776 and cherish her whose children they are, and regard each other as
1777 brothers and sisters. 'I do not wonder at your being ashamed to propound
1778 such a fiction.' There is more behind. These brothers and sisters
1779 have different natures, and some of them God framed to rule, whom he
1780 fashioned of gold; others he made of silver, to be auxiliaries; others
1781 again to be husbandmen and craftsmen, and these were formed by him of
1782 brass and iron. But as they are all sprung from a common stock, a golden
1783 parent may have a silver son, or a silver parent a golden son, and then
1784 there must be a change of rank; the son of the rich must descend, and
1785 the child of the artisan rise, in the social scale; for an oracle says
1786 'that the State will come to an end if governed by a man of brass or
1787 iron.' Will our citizens ever believe all this? 'Not in the present
1788 generation, but in the next, perhaps, Yes.'
1789 
1790 Now let the earthborn men go forth under the command of their rulers,
1791 and look about and pitch their camp in a high place, which will be safe
1792 against enemies from without, and likewise against insurrections from
1793 within. There let them sacrifice and set up their tents; for soldiers
1794 they are to be and not shopkeepers, the watchdogs and guardians of the
1795 sheep; and luxury and avarice will turn them into wolves and tyrants.
1796 Their habits and their dwellings should correspond to their education.
1797 They should have no property; their pay should only meet their expenses;
1798 and they should have common meals. Gold and silver we will tell them
1799 that they have from God, and this divine gift in their souls they must
1800 not alloy with that earthly dross which passes under the name of gold.
1801 They only of the citizens may not touch it, or be under the same roof
1802 with it, or drink from it; it is the accursed thing. Should they
1803 ever acquire houses or lands or money of their own, they will become
1804 householders and tradesmen instead of guardians, enemies and tyrants
1805 instead of helpers, and the hour of ruin, both to themselves and the
1806 rest of the State, will be at hand.
1807 
1808 The religious and ethical aspect of Plato's education will hereafter
1809 be considered under a separate head. Some lesser points may be more
1810 conveniently noticed in this place.
1811 
1812 1. The constant appeal to the authority of Homer, whom, with grave
1813 irony, Plato, after the manner of his age, summons as a witness about
1814 ethics and psychology, as well as about diet and medicine; attempting
1815 to distinguish the better lesson from the worse, sometimes altering
1816 the text from design; more than once quoting or alluding to Homer
1817 inaccurately, after the manner of the early logographers turning the
1818 Iliad into prose, and delighting to draw far-fetched inferences from
1819 his words, or to make ludicrous applications of them. He does not, like
1820 Heracleitus, get into a rage with Homer and Archilochus (Heracl.), but
1821 uses their words and expressions as vehicles of a higher truth; not on
1822 a system like Theagenes of Rhegium or Metrodorus, or in later times the
1823 Stoics, but as fancy may dictate. And the conclusions drawn from them
1824 are sound, although the premises are fictitious. These fanciful appeals
1825 to Homer add a charm to Plato's style, and at the same time they have
1826 the effect of a satire on the follies of Homeric interpretation. To us
1827 (and probably to himself), although they take the form of arguments,
1828 they are really figures of speech. They may be compared with modern
1829 citations from Scripture, which have often a great rhetorical power even
1830 when the original meaning of the words is entirely lost sight of. The
1831 real, like the Platonic Socrates, as we gather from the Memorabilia of
1832 Xenophon, was fond of making similar adaptations. Great in all ages and
1833 countries, in religion as well as in law and literature, has been the
1834 art of interpretation.
1835 
1836 2. 'The style is to conform to the subject and the metre to the style.'
1837 Notwithstanding the fascination which the word 'classical' exercises
1838 over us, we can hardly maintain that this rule is observed in all the
1839 Greek poetry which has come down to us. We cannot deny that the thought
1840 often exceeds the power of lucid expression in Aeschylus and Pindar;
1841 or that rhetoric gets the better of the thought in the Sophist-poet
1842 Euripides. Only perhaps in Sophocles is there a perfect harmony of the
1843 two; in him alone do we find a grace of language like the beauty of a
1844 Greek statue, in which there is nothing to add or to take away; at
1845 least this is true of single plays or of large portions of them. The
1846 connection in the Tragic Choruses and in the Greek lyric poets is not
1847 unfrequently a tangled thread which in an age before logic the poet was
1848 unable to draw out. Many thoughts and feelings mingled in his mind, and
1849 he had no power of disengaging or arranging them. For there is a subtle
1850 influence of logic which requires to be transferred from prose to
1851 poetry, just as the music and perfection of language are infused by
1852 poetry into prose. In all ages the poet has been a bad judge of his
1853 own meaning (Apol.); for he does not see that the word which is full
1854 of associations to his own mind is difficult and unmeaning to that of
1855 another; or that the sequence which is clear to himself is puzzling to
1856 others. There are many passages in some of our greatest modern poets
1857 which are far too obscure; in which there is no proportion between style
1858 and subject, in which any half-expressed figure, any harsh construction,
1859 any distorted collocation of words, any remote sequence of ideas is
1860 admitted; and there is no voice 'coming sweetly from nature,' or music
1861 adding the expression of feeling to thought. As if there could be poetry
1862 without beauty, or beauty without ease and clearness. The obscurities
1863 of early Greek poets arose necessarily out of the state of language and
1864 logic which existed in their age. They are not examples to be followed
1865 by us; for the use of language ought in every generation to become
1866 clearer and clearer. Like Shakespere, they were great in spite, not
1867 in consequence, of their imperfections of expression. But there is no
1868 reason for returning to the necessary obscurity which prevailed in
1869 the infancy of literature. The English poets of the last century were
1870 certainly not obscure; and we have no excuse for losing what they had
1871 gained, or for going back to the earlier or transitional age which
1872 preceded them. The thought of our own times has not out-stripped
1873 language; a want of Plato's 'art of measuring' is the rule cause of the
1874 disproportion between them.
1875 
1876 3. In the third book of the Republic a nearer approach is made to a
1877 theory of art than anywhere else in Plato. His views may be summed up
1878 as follows:--True art is not fanciful and imitative, but simple and
1879 ideal,--the expression of the highest moral energy, whether in action or
1880 repose. To live among works of plastic art which are of this noble
1881 and simple character, or to listen to such strains, is the best of
1882 influences,--the true Greek atmosphere, in which youth should be brought
1883 up. That is the way to create in them a natural good taste, which will
1884 have a feeling of truth and beauty in all things. For though the
1885 poets are to be expelled, still art is recognized as another aspect of
1886 reason--like love in the Symposium, extending over the same sphere, but
1887 confined to the preliminary education, and acting through the power of
1888 habit; and this conception of art is not limited to strains of music or
1889 the forms of plastic art, but pervades all nature and has a wide kindred
1890 in the world. The Republic of Plato, like the Athens of Pericles, has an
1891 artistic as well as a political side.
1892 
1893 There is hardly any mention in Plato of the creative arts; only in two
1894 or three passages does he even allude to them (Rep.; Soph.). He is
1895 not lost in rapture at the great works of Phidias, the Parthenon, the
1896 Propylea, the statues of Zeus or Athene. He would probably have regarded
1897 any abstract truth of number or figure as higher than the greatest of
1898 them. Yet it is hard to suppose that some influence, such as he hopes to
1899 inspire in youth, did not pass into his own mind from the works of art
1900 which he saw around him. We are living upon the fragments of them, and
1901 find in a few broken stones the standard of truth and beauty. But in
1902 Plato this feeling has no expression; he nowhere says that beauty is the
1903 object of art; he seems to deny that wisdom can take an external form
1904 (Phaedrus); he does not distinguish the fine from the mechanical arts.
1905 Whether or no, like some writers, he felt more than he expressed, it
1906 is at any rate remarkable that the greatest perfection of the fine arts
1907 should coincide with an almost entire silence about them. In one very
1908 striking passage he tells us that a work of art, like the State, is a
1909 whole; and this conception of a whole and the love of the newly-born
1910 mathematical sciences may be regarded, if not as the inspiring, at any
1911 rate as the regulating principles of Greek art (Xen. Mem.; and Sophist).
1912 
1913 4. Plato makes the true and subtle remark that the physician had better
1914 not be in robust health; and should have known what illness is in his
1915 own person. But the judge ought to have had no similar experience of
1916 evil; he is to be a good man who, having passed his youth in innocence,
1917 became acquainted late in life with the vices of others. And therefore,
1918 according to Plato, a judge should not be young, just as a young man
1919 according to Aristotle is not fit to be a hearer of moral philosophy.
1920 The bad, on the other hand, have a knowledge of vice, but no knowledge
1921 of virtue. It may be doubted, however, whether this train of reflection
1922 is well founded. In a remarkable passage of the Laws it is acknowledged
1923 that the evil may form a correct estimate of the good. The union of
1924 gentleness and courage in Book ii. at first seemed to be a paradox,
1925 yet was afterwards ascertained to be a truth. And Plato might also have
1926 found that the intuition of evil may be consistent with the abhorrence
1927 of it. There is a directness of aim in virtue which gives an insight
1928 into vice. And the knowledge of character is in some degree a natural
1929 sense independent of any special experience of good or evil.
1930 
1931 5. One of the most remarkable conceptions of Plato, because un-Greek and
1932 also very different from anything which existed at all in his age of
1933 the world, is the transposition of ranks. In the Spartan state there had
1934 been enfranchisement of Helots and degradation of citizens under
1935 special circumstances. And in the ancient Greek aristocracies, merit
1936 was certainly recognized as one of the elements on which government was
1937 based. The founders of states were supposed to be their benefactors, who
1938 were raised by their great actions above the ordinary level of humanity;
1939 at a later period, the services of warriors and legislators were held to
1940 entitle them and their descendants to the privileges of citizenship and
1941 to the first rank in the state. And although the existence of an ideal
1942 aristocracy is slenderly proven from the remains of early Greek history,
1943 and we have a difficulty in ascribing such a character, however the idea
1944 may be defined, to any actual Hellenic state--or indeed to any state
1945 which has ever existed in the world--still the rule of the best was
1946 certainly the aspiration of philosophers, who probably accommodated a
1947 good deal their views of primitive history to their own notions of good
1948 government. Plato further insists on applying to the guardians of his
1949 state a series of tests by which all those who fell short of a fixed
1950 standard were either removed from the governing body, or not admitted
1951 to it; and this 'academic' discipline did to a certain extent prevail in
1952 Greek states, especially in Sparta. He also indicates that the system of
1953 caste, which existed in a great part of the ancient, and is by no means
1954 extinct in the modern European world, should be set aside from time
1955 to time in favour of merit. He is aware how deeply the greater part of
1956 mankind resent any interference with the order of society, and therefore
1957 he proposes his novel idea in the form of what he himself calls a
1958 'monstrous fiction.' (Compare the ceremony of preparation for the two
1959 'great waves' in Book v.) Two principles are indicated by him: first,
1960 that there is a distinction of ranks dependent on circumstances prior to
1961 the individual: second, that this distinction is and ought to be broken
1962 through by personal qualities. He adapts mythology like the Homeric
1963 poems to the wants of the state, making 'the Phoenician tale' the
1964 vehicle of his ideas. Every Greek state had a myth respecting its own
1965 origin; the Platonic republic may also have a tale of earthborn men. The
1966 gravity and verisimilitude with which the tale is told, and the analogy
1967 of Greek tradition, are a sufficient verification of the 'monstrous
1968 falsehood.' Ancient poetry had spoken of a gold and silver and brass and
1969 iron age succeeding one another, but Plato supposes these differences
1970 in the natures of men to exist together in a single state. Mythology
1971 supplies a figure under which the lesson may be taught (as Protagoras
1972 says, 'the myth is more interesting'), and also enables Plato to touch
1973 lightly on new principles without going into details. In this passage he
1974 shadows forth a general truth, but he does not tell us by what steps the
1975 transposition of ranks is to be effected. Indeed throughout the Republic
1976 he allows the lower ranks to fade into the distance. We do not know
1977 whether they are to carry arms, and whether in the fifth book they are
1978 or are not included in the communistic regulations respecting property
1979 and marriage. Nor is there any use in arguing strictly either from a
1980 few chance words, or from the silence of Plato, or in drawing inferences
1981 which were beyond his vision. Aristotle, in his criticism on the
1982 position of the lower classes, does not perceive that the poetical
1983 creation is 'like the air, invulnerable,' and cannot be penetrated by
1984 the shafts of his logic (Pol.).
1985 
1986 6. Two paradoxes which strike the modern reader as in the highest degree
1987 fanciful and ideal, and which suggest to him many reflections, are to
1988 be found in the third book of the Republic: first, the great power of
1989 music, so much beyond any influence which is experienced by us in modern
1990 times, when the art or science has been far more developed, and has
1991 found the secret of harmony, as well as of melody; secondly, the
1992 indefinite and almost absolute control which the soul is supposed to
1993 exercise over the body.
1994 
1995 In the first we suspect some degree of exaggeration, such as we may
1996 also observe among certain masters of the art, not unknown to us, at the
1997 present day. With this natural enthusiasm, which is felt by a few only,
1998 there seems to mingle in Plato a sort of Pythagorean reverence for
1999 numbers and numerical proportion to which Aristotle is a stranger.
2000 Intervals of sound and number are to him sacred things which have a law
2001 of their own, not dependent on the variations of sense. They rise above
2002 sense, and become a connecting link with the world of ideas. But it is
2003 evident that Plato is describing what to him appears to be also a fact.
2004 The power of a simple and characteristic melody on the impressible
2005 mind of the Greek is more than we can easily appreciate. The effect of
2006 national airs may bear some comparison with it. And, besides all this,
2007 there is a confusion between the harmony of musical notes and the
2008 harmony of soul and body, which is so potently inspired by them.
2009 
2010 The second paradox leads up to some curious and interesting
2011 questions--How far can the mind control the body? Is the relation
2012 between them one of mutual antagonism or of mutual harmony? Are they
2013 two or one, and is either of them the cause of the other? May we not at
2014 times drop the opposition between them, and the mode of describing them,
2015 which is so familiar to us, and yet hardly conveys any precise meaning,
2016 and try to view this composite creature, man, in a more simple manner?
2017 Must we not at any rate admit that there is in human nature a higher
2018 and a lower principle, divided by no distinct line, which at times
2019 break asunder and take up arms against one another? Or again, they are
2020 reconciled and move together, either unconsciously in the ordinary work
2021 of life, or consciously in the pursuit of some noble aim, to be attained
2022 not without an effort, and for which every thought and nerve are
2023 strained. And then the body becomes the good friend or ally, or servant
2024 or instrument of the mind. And the mind has often a wonderful and almost
2025 superhuman power of banishing disease and weakness and calling out a
2026 hidden strength. Reason and the desires, the intellect and the senses
2027 are brought into harmony and obedience so as to form a single human
2028 being. They are ever parting, ever meeting; and the identity or
2029 diversity of their tendencies or operations is for the most part
2030 unnoticed by us. When the mind touches the body through the appetites,
2031 we acknowledge the responsibility of the one to the other. There is a
2032 tendency in us which says 'Drink.' There is another which says, 'Do
2033 not drink; it is not good for you.' And we all of us know which is the
2034 rightful superior. We are also responsible for our health, although into
2035 this sphere there enter some elements of necessity which may be beyond
2036 our control. Still even in the management of health, care and thought,
2037 continued over many years, may make us almost free agents, if we do
2038 not exact too much of ourselves, and if we acknowledge that all human
2039 freedom is limited by the laws of nature and of mind.
2040 
2041 We are disappointed to find that Plato, in the general condemnation
2042 which he passes on the practice of medicine prevailing in his own day,
2043 depreciates the effects of diet. He would like to have diseases of a
2044 definite character and capable of receiving a definite treatment. He is
2045 afraid of invalidism interfering with the business of life. He does
2046 not recognize that time is the great healer both of mental and bodily
2047 disorders; and that remedies which are gradual and proceed little by
2048 little are safer than those which produce a sudden catastrophe. Neither
2049 does he see that there is no way in which the mind can more surely
2050 influence the body than by the control of eating and drinking; or any
2051 other action or occasion of human life on which the higher freedom of
2052 the will can be more simple or truly asserted.
2053 
2054 7. Lesser matters of style may be remarked.
2055 
2056 (1) The affected ignorance of music, which is Plato's way of expressing
2057 that he is passing lightly over the subject.
2058 
2059 (2) The tentative manner in which here, as in the second book, he
2060 proceeds with the construction of the State.
2061 
2062 (3) The description of the State sometimes as a reality, and then again
2063 as a work of imagination only; these are the arts by which he sustains
2064 the reader's interest.
2065 
2066 (4) Connecting links, or the preparation for the entire expulsion of the
2067 poets in Book X.
2068 
2069 (5) The companion pictures of the lover of litigation and the
2070 valetudinarian, the satirical jest about the maxim of Phocylides, the
2071 manner in which the image of the gold and silver citizens is taken
2072 up into the subject, and the argument from the practice of Asclepius,
2073 should not escape notice.
2074 
2075 BOOK IV. Adeimantus said: 'Suppose a person to argue, Socrates, that you
2076 make your citizens miserable, and this by their own free-will; they are
2077 the lords of the city, and yet instead of having, like other men, lands
2078 and houses and money of their own, they live as mercenaries and are
2079 always mounting guard.' You may add, I replied, that they receive no
2080 pay but only their food, and have no money to spend on a journey or a
2081 mistress. 'Well, and what answer do you give?' My answer is, that
2082 our guardians may or may not be the happiest of men,--I should not be
2083 surprised to find in the long-run that they were,--but this is not the
2084 aim of our constitution, which was designed for the good of the whole
2085 and not of any one part. If I went to a sculptor and blamed him for
2086 having painted the eye, which is the noblest feature of the face, not
2087 purple but black, he would reply: 'The eye must be an eye, and you
2088 should look at the statue as a whole.' 'Now I can well imagine a fool's
2089 paradise, in which everybody is eating and drinking, clothed in purple
2090 and fine linen, and potters lie on sofas and have their wheel at hand,
2091 that they may work a little when they please; and cobblers and all the
2092 other classes of a State lose their distinctive character. And a State
2093 may get on without cobblers; but when the guardians degenerate into boon
2094 companions, then the ruin is complete. Remember that we are not talking
2095 of peasants keeping holiday, but of a State in which every man is
2096 expected to do his own work. The happiness resides not in this or that
2097 class, but in the State as a whole. I have another remark to make:--A
2098 middle condition is best for artisans; they should have money enough to
2099 buy tools, and not enough to be independent of business. And will not
2100 the same condition be best for our citizens? If they are poor, they will
2101 be mean; if rich, luxurious and lazy; and in neither case contented.
2102 'But then how will our poor city be able to go to war against an enemy
2103 who has money?' There may be a difficulty in fighting against one enemy;
2104 against two there will be none. In the first place, the contest will be
2105 carried on by trained warriors against well-to-do citizens: and is not a
2106 regular athlete an easy match for two stout opponents at least? Suppose
2107 also, that before engaging we send ambassadors to one of the two cities,
2108 saying, 'Silver and gold we have not; do you help us and take our share
2109 of the spoil;'--who would fight against the lean, wiry dogs, when they
2110 might join with them in preying upon the fatted sheep? 'But if many
2111 states join their resources, shall we not be in danger?' I am amused
2112 to hear you use the word 'state' of any but our own State. They are
2113 'states,' but not 'a state'--many in one. For in every state there are
2114 two hostile nations, rich and poor, which you may set one against the
2115 other. But our State, while she remains true to her principles, will be
2116 in very deed the mightiest of Hellenic states.
2117 
2118 To the size of the state there is no limit but the necessity of unity;
2119 it must be neither too large nor too small to be one. This is a matter
2120 of secondary importance, like the principle of transposition which was
2121 intimated in the parable of the earthborn men. The meaning there implied
2122 was that every man should do that for which he was fitted, and be at
2123 one with himself, and then the whole city would be united. But all these
2124 things are secondary, if education, which is the great matter, be duly
2125 regarded. When the wheel has once been set in motion, the speed is
2126 always increasing; and each generation improves upon the preceding, both
2127 in physical and moral qualities. The care of the governors should be
2128 directed to preserve music and gymnastic from innovation; alter the
2129 songs of a country, Damon says, and you will soon end by altering its
2130 laws. The change appears innocent at first, and begins in play; but
2131 the evil soon becomes serious, working secretly upon the characters of
2132 individuals, then upon social and commercial relations, and lastly upon
2133 the institutions of a state; and there is ruin and confusion everywhere.
2134 But if education remains in the established form, there will be no
2135 danger. A restorative process will be always going on; the spirit of law
2136 and order will raise up what has fallen down. Nor will any regulations
2137 be needed for the lesser matters of life--rules of deportment or
2138 fashions of dress. Like invites like for good or for evil. Education
2139 will correct deficiencies and supply the power of self-government. Far
2140 be it from us to enter into the particulars of legislation; let the
2141 guardians take care of education, and education will take care of all
2142 other things.
2143 
2144 But without education they may patch and mend as they please; they will
2145 make no progress, any more than a patient who thinks to cure himself by
2146 some favourite remedy and will not give up his luxurious mode of living.
2147 If you tell such persons that they must first alter their habits, then
2148 they grow angry; they are charming people. 'Charming,--nay, the very
2149 reverse.' Evidently these gentlemen are not in your good graces, nor the
2150 state which is like them. And such states there are which first ordain
2151 under penalty of death that no one shall alter the constitution, and
2152 then suffer themselves to be flattered into and out of anything; and
2153 he who indulges them and fawns upon them, is their leader and saviour.
2154 'Yes, the men are as bad as the states.' But do you not admire their
2155 cleverness? 'Nay, some of them are stupid enough to believe what the
2156 people tell them.' And when all the world is telling a man that he is
2157 six feet high, and he has no measure, how can he believe anything
2158 else? But don't get into a passion: to see our statesmen trying their
2159 nostrums, and fancying that they can cut off at a blow the Hydra-like
2160 rogueries of mankind, is as good as a play. Minute enactments are
2161 superfluous in good states, and are useless in bad ones.
2162 
2163 And now what remains of the work of legislation? Nothing for us; but to
2164 Apollo the god of Delphi we leave the ordering of the greatest of all
2165 things--that is to say, religion. Only our ancestral deity sitting upon
2166 the centre and navel of the earth will be trusted by us if we have any
2167 sense, in an affair of such magnitude. No foreign god shall be supreme
2168 in our realms...
2169 
2170 Here, as Socrates would say, let us 'reflect on' (Greek) what has
2171 preceded: thus far we have spoken not of the happiness of the citizens,
2172 but only of the well-being of the State. They may be the happiest of
2173 men, but our principal aim in founding the State was not to make them
2174 happy. They were to be guardians, not holiday-makers. In this pleasant
2175 manner is presented to us the famous question both of ancient and modern
2176 philosophy, touching the relation of duty to happiness, of right to
2177 utility.
2178 
2179 First duty, then happiness, is the natural order of our moral ideas. The
2180 utilitarian principle is valuable as a corrective of error, and shows
2181 to us a side of ethics which is apt to be neglected. It may be admitted
2182 further that right and utility are co-extensive, and that he who makes
2183 the happiness of mankind his object has one of the highest and noblest
2184 motives of human action. But utility is not the historical basis of
2185 morality; nor the aspect in which moral and religious ideas commonly
2186 occur to the mind. The greatest happiness of all is, as we believe, the
2187 far-off result of the divine government of the universe. The greatest
2188 happiness of the individual is certainly to be found in a life of virtue
2189 and goodness. But we seem to be more assured of a law of right than we
2190 can be of a divine purpose, that 'all mankind should be saved;' and
2191 we infer the one from the other. And the greatest happiness of the
2192 individual may be the reverse of the greatest happiness in the ordinary
2193 sense of the term, and may be realised in a life of pain, or in a
2194 voluntary death. Further, the word 'happiness' has several ambiguities;
2195 it may mean either pleasure or an ideal life, happiness subjective or
2196 objective, in this world or in another, of ourselves only or of
2197 our neighbours and of all men everywhere. By the modern founder of
2198 Utilitarianism the self-regarding and disinterested motives of action
2199 are included under the same term, although they are commonly opposed
2200 by us as benevolence and self-love. The word happiness has not the
2201 definiteness or the sacredness of 'truth' and 'right'; it does
2202 not equally appeal to our higher nature, and has not sunk into the
2203 conscience of mankind. It is associated too much with the comforts and
2204 conveniences of life; too little with 'the goods of the soul which we
2205 desire for their own sake.' In a great trial, or danger, or temptation,
2206 or in any great and heroic action, it is scarcely thought of. For these
2207 reasons 'the greatest happiness' principle is not the true foundation of
2208 ethics. But though not the first principle, it is the second, which is
2209 like unto it, and is often of easier application. For the larger part of
2210 human actions are neither right nor wrong, except in so far as they tend
2211 to the happiness of mankind (Introd. to Gorgias and Philebus).
2212 
2213 The same question reappears in politics, where the useful or expedient
2214 seems to claim a larger sphere and to have a greater authority. For
2215 concerning political measures, we chiefly ask: How will they affect
2216 the happiness of mankind? Yet here too we may observe that what we term
2217 expediency is merely the law of right limited by the conditions of human
2218 society. Right and truth are the highest aims of government as well as
2219 of individuals; and we ought not to lose sight of them because we cannot
2220 directly enforce them. They appeal to the better mind of nations; and
2221 sometimes they are too much for merely temporal interests to resist.
2222 They are the watchwords which all men use in matters of public policy,
2223 as well as in their private dealings; the peace of Europe may be said
2224 to depend upon them. In the most commercial and utilitarian states
2225 of society the power of ideas remains. And all the higher class of
2226 statesmen have in them something of that idealism which Pericles is said
2227 to have gathered from the teaching of Anaxagoras. They recognise that
2228 the true leader of men must be above the motives of ambition, and
2229 that national character is of greater value than material comfort and
2230 prosperity. And this is the order of thought in Plato; first, he expects
2231 his citizens to do their duty, and then under favourable circumstances,
2232 that is to say, in a well-ordered State, their happiness is assured.
2233 That he was far from excluding the modern principle of utility in
2234 politics is sufficiently evident from other passages; in which 'the most
2235 beneficial is affirmed to be the most honourable', and also 'the most
2236 sacred'.
2237 
2238 We may note
2239 
2240 (1) The manner in which the objection of Adeimantus here, is designed to
2241 draw out and deepen the argument of Socrates.
2242 
2243 (2) The conception of a whole as lying at the foundation both of
2244 politics and of art, in the latter supplying the only principle of
2245 criticism, which, under the various names of harmony, symmetry, measure,
2246 proportion, unity, the Greek seems to have applied to works of art.
2247 
2248 (3) The requirement that the State should be limited in size, after the
2249 traditional model of a Greek state; as in the Politics of Aristotle, the
2250 fact that the cities of Hellas were small is converted into a principle.
2251 
2252 (4) The humorous pictures of the lean dogs and the fatted sheep, of
2253 the light active boxer upsetting two stout gentlemen at least, of the
2254 'charming' patients who are always making themselves worse; or again,
2255 the playful assumption that there is no State but our own; or the grave
2256 irony with which the statesman is excused who believes that he is six
2257 feet high because he is told so, and having nothing to measure with
2258 is to be pardoned for his ignorance--he is too amusing for us to be
2259 seriously angry with him.
2260 
2261 (5) The light and superficial manner in which religion is passed over
2262 when provision has been made for two great principles,--first, that
2263 religion shall be based on the highest conception of the gods, secondly,
2264 that the true national or Hellenic type shall be maintained...
2265 
2266 Socrates proceeds: But where amid all this is justice? Son of Ariston,
2267 tell me where. Light a candle and search the city, and get your brother
2268 and the rest of our friends to help in seeking for her. 'That won't do,'
2269 replied Glaucon, 'you yourself promised to make the search and talked
2270 about the impiety of deserting justice.' Well, I said, I will lead the
2271 way, but do you follow. My notion is, that our State being perfect will
2272 contain all the four virtues--wisdom, courage, temperance, justice. If
2273 we eliminate the three first, the unknown remainder will be justice.
2274 
2275 First then, of wisdom: the State which we have called into being will be
2276 wise because politic. And policy is one among many kinds of skill,--not
2277 the skill of the carpenter, or of the worker in metal, or of the
2278 husbandman, but the skill of him who advises about the interests of the
2279 whole State. Of such a kind is the skill of the guardians, who are a
2280 small class in number, far smaller than the blacksmiths; but in them
2281 is concentrated the wisdom of the State. And if this small ruling class
2282 have wisdom, then the whole State will be wise.
2283 
2284 Our second virtue is courage, which we have no difficulty in finding
2285 in another class--that of soldiers. Courage may be defined as a sort
2286 of salvation--the never-failing salvation of the opinions which law and
2287 education have prescribed concerning dangers. You know the way in which
2288 dyers first prepare the white ground and then lay on the dye of purple
2289 or of any other colour. Colours dyed in this way become fixed, and no
2290 soap or lye will ever wash them out. Now the ground is education, and
2291 the laws are the colours; and if the ground is properly laid, neither
2292 the soap of pleasure nor the lye of pain or fear will ever wash them
2293 out. This power which preserves right opinion about danger I would ask
2294 you to call 'courage,' adding the epithet 'political' or 'civilized'
2295 in order to distinguish it from mere animal courage and from a higher
2296 courage which may hereafter be discussed.
2297 
2298 Two virtues remain; temperance and justice. More than the preceding
2299 virtues temperance suggests the idea of harmony. Some light is thrown
2300 upon the nature of this virtue by the popular description of a man as
2301 'master of himself'--which has an absurd sound, because the master is
2302 also the servant. The expression really means that the better principle
2303 in a man masters the worse. There are in cities whole classes--women,
2304 slaves and the like--who correspond to the worse, and a few only to the
2305 better; and in our State the former class are held under control by the
2306 latter. Now to which of these classes does temperance belong? 'To both
2307 of them.' And our State if any will be the abode of temperance; and
2308 we were right in describing this virtue as a harmony which is diffused
2309 through the whole, making the dwellers in the city to be of one mind,
2310 and attuning the upper and middle and lower classes like the strings of
2311 an instrument, whether you suppose them to differ in wisdom, strength or
2312 wealth.
2313 
2314 And now we are near the spot; let us draw in and surround the cover and
2315 watch with all our eyes, lest justice should slip away and escape. Tell
2316 me, if you see the thicket move first. 'Nay, I would have you lead.'
2317 Well then, offer up a prayer and follow. The way is dark and difficult;
2318 but we must push on. I begin to see a track. 'Good news.' Why, Glaucon,
