2319 our dulness of scent is quite ludicrous! While we are straining our eyes
2320 into the distance, justice is tumbling out at our feet. We are as bad
2321 as people looking for a thing which they have in their hands. Have you
2322 forgotten our old principle of the division of labour, or of every man
2323 doing his own business, concerning which we spoke at the foundation
2324 of the State--what but this was justice? Is there any other virtue
2325 remaining which can compete with wisdom and temperance and courage in
2326 the scale of political virtue? For 'every one having his own' is the
2327 great object of government; and the great object of trade is that
2328 every man should do his own business. Not that there is much harm in a
2329 carpenter trying to be a cobbler, or a cobbler transforming himself into
2330 a carpenter; but great evil may arise from the cobbler leaving his last
2331 and turning into a guardian or legislator, or when a single individual
2332 is trainer, warrior, legislator, all in one. And this evil is injustice,
2333 or every man doing another's business. I do not say that as yet we are
2334 in a condition to arrive at a final conclusion. For the definition
2335 which we believe to hold good in states has still to be tested by the
2336 individual. Having read the large letters we will now come back to the
2337 small. From the two together a brilliant light may be struck out...
2338 
2339 Socrates proceeds to discover the nature of justice by a method of
2340 residues. Each of the first three virtues corresponds to one of the
2341 three parts of the soul and one of the three classes in the State,
2342 although the third, temperance, has more of the nature of a harmony than
2343 the first two. If there be a fourth virtue, that can only be sought for
2344 in the relation of the three parts in the soul or classes in the State
2345 to one another. It is obvious and simple, and for that very reason has
2346 not been found out. The modern logician will be inclined to object that
2347 ideas cannot be separated like chemical substances, but that they run
2348 into one another and may be only different aspects or names of the
2349 same thing, and such in this instance appears to be the case. For the
2350 definition here given of justice is verbally the same as one of the
2351 definitions of temperance given by Socrates in the Charmides, which
2352 however is only provisional, and is afterwards rejected. And so far
2353 from justice remaining over when the other virtues are eliminated,
2354 the justice and temperance of the Republic can with difficulty be
2355 distinguished. Temperance appears to be the virtue of a part only, and
2356 one of three, whereas justice is a universal virtue of the whole soul.
2357 Yet on the other hand temperance is also described as a sort of harmony,
2358 and in this respect is akin to justice. Justice seems to differ from
2359 temperance in degree rather than in kind; whereas temperance is the
2360 harmony of discordant elements, justice is the perfect order by which
2361 all natures and classes do their own business, the right man in the
2362 right place, the division and co-operation of all the citizens. Justice,
2363 again, is a more abstract notion than the other virtues, and therefore,
2364 from Plato's point of view, the foundation of them, to which they
2365 are referred and which in idea precedes them. The proposal to omit
2366 temperance is a mere trick of style intended to avoid monotony.
2367 
2368 There is a famous question discussed in one of the earlier Dialogues of
2369 Plato (Protagoras; Arist. Nic. Ethics), 'Whether the virtues are one
2370 or many?' This receives an answer which is to the effect that there
2371 are four cardinal virtues (now for the first time brought together in
2372 ethical philosophy), and one supreme over the rest, which is not like
2373 Aristotle's conception of universal justice, virtue relative to others,
2374 but the whole of virtue relative to the parts. To this universal
2375 conception of justice or order in the first education and in the moral
2376 nature of man, the still more universal conception of the good in the
2377 second education and in the sphere of speculative knowledge seems to
2378 succeed. Both might be equally described by the terms 'law,' 'order,'
2379 'harmony;' but while the idea of good embraces 'all time and all
2380 existence,' the conception of justice is not extended beyond man.
2381 
2382 ...Socrates is now going to identify the individual and the State. But
2383 first he must prove that there are three parts of the individual soul.
2384 His argument is as follows:--Quantity makes no difference in quality.
2385 The word 'just,' whether applied to the individual or to the State, has
2386 the same meaning. And the term 'justice' implied that the same three
2387 principles in the State and in the individual were doing their own
2388 business. But are they really three or one? The question is difficult,
2389 and one which can hardly be solved by the methods which we are now
2390 using; but the truer and longer way would take up too much of our time.
2391 'The shorter will satisfy me.' Well then, you would admit that the
2392 qualities of states mean the qualities of the individuals who compose
2393 them? The Scythians and Thracians are passionate, our own race
2394 intellectual, and the Egyptians and Phoenicians covetous, because
2395 the individual members of each have such and such a character; the
2396 difficulty is to determine whether the several principles are one or
2397 three; whether, that is to say, we reason with one part of our nature,
2398 desire with another, are angry with another, or whether the whole soul
2399 comes into play in each sort of action. This enquiry, however, requires
2400 a very exact definition of terms. The same thing in the same relation
2401 cannot be affected in two opposite ways. But there is no impossibility
2402 in a man standing still, yet moving his arms, or in a top which is fixed
2403 on one spot going round upon its axis. There is no necessity to mention
2404 all the possible exceptions; let us provisionally assume that opposites
2405 cannot do or be or suffer opposites in the same relation. And to the
2406 class of opposites belong assent and dissent, desire and avoidance.
2407 And one form of desire is thirst and hunger: and here arises a new
2408 point--thirst is thirst of drink, hunger is hunger of food; not of warm
2409 drink or of a particular kind of food, with the single exception of
2410 course that the very fact of our desiring anything implies that it is
2411 good. When relative terms have no attributes, their correlatives have
2412 no attributes; when they have attributes, their correlatives also have
2413 them. For example, the term 'greater' is simply relative to 'less,' and
2414 knowledge refers to a subject of knowledge. But on the other hand, a
2415 particular knowledge is of a particular subject. Again, every science
2416 has a distinct character, which is defined by an object; medicine, for
2417 example, is the science of health, although not to be confounded with
2418 health. Having cleared our ideas thus far, let us return to the original
2419 instance of thirst, which has a definite object--drink. Now the thirsty
2420 soul may feel two distinct impulses; the animal one saying 'Drink;'
2421 the rational one, which says 'Do not drink.' The two impulses are
2422 contradictory; and therefore we may assume that they spring from
2423 distinct principles in the soul. But is passion a third principle, or
2424 akin to desire? There is a story of a certain Leontius which throws some
2425 light on this question. He was coming up from the Piraeus outside the
2426 north wall, and he passed a spot where there were dead bodies lying
2427 by the executioner. He felt a longing desire to see them and also an
2428 abhorrence of them; at first he turned away and shut his eyes, then,
2429 suddenly tearing them open, he said,--'Take your fill, ye wretches, of
2430 the fair sight.' Now is there not here a third principle which is often
2431 found to come to the assistance of reason against desire, but never
2432 of desire against reason? This is passion or spirit, of the separate
2433 existence of which we may further convince ourselves by putting the
2434 following case:--When a man suffers justly, if he be of a generous
2435 nature he is not indignant at the hardships which he undergoes: but when
2436 he suffers unjustly, his indignation is his great support; hunger and
2437 thirst cannot tame him; the spirit within him must do or die, until the
2438 voice of the shepherd, that is, of reason, bidding his dog bark no
2439 more, is heard within. This shows that passion is the ally of reason. Is
2440 passion then the same with reason? No, for the former exists in children
2441 and brutes; and Homer affords a proof of the distinction between them
2442 when he says, 'He smote his breast, and thus rebuked his soul.'
2443 
2444 And now, at last, we have reached firm ground, and are able to infer
2445 that the virtues of the State and of the individual are the same. For
2446 wisdom and courage and justice in the State are severally the wisdom and
2447 courage and justice in the individuals who form the State. Each of the
2448 three classes will do the work of its own class in the State, and each
2449 part in the individual soul; reason, the superior, and passion, the
2450 inferior, will be harmonized by the influence of music and gymnastic.
2451 The counsellor and the warrior, the head and the arm, will act together
2452 in the town of Mansoul, and keep the desires in proper subjection. The
2453 courage of the warrior is that quality which preserves a right opinion
2454 about dangers in spite of pleasures and pains. The wisdom of the
2455 counsellor is that small part of the soul which has authority and
2456 reason. The virtue of temperance is the friendship of the ruling and the
2457 subject principles, both in the State and in the individual. Of justice
2458 we have already spoken; and the notion already given of it may
2459 be confirmed by common instances. Will the just state or the just
2460 individual steal, lie, commit adultery, or be guilty of impiety to
2461 gods and men? 'No.' And is not the reason of this that the several
2462 principles, whether in the state or in the individual, do their own
2463 business? And justice is the quality which makes just men and just
2464 states. Moreover, our old division of labour, which required that there
2465 should be one man for one use, was a dream or anticipation of what was
2466 to follow; and that dream has now been realized in justice, which
2467 begins by binding together the three chords of the soul, and then acts
2468 harmoniously in every relation of life. And injustice, which is the
2469 insubordination and disobedience of the inferior elements in the soul,
2470 is the opposite of justice, and is inharmonious and unnatural, being to
2471 the soul what disease is to the body; for in the soul as well as in the
2472 body, good or bad actions produce good or bad habits. And virtue is the
2473 health and beauty and well-being of the soul, and vice is the disease
2474 and weakness and deformity of the soul.
2475 
2476 Again the old question returns upon us: Is justice or injustice the
2477 more profitable? The question has become ridiculous. For injustice, like
2478 mortal disease, makes life not worth having. Come up with me to the hill
2479 which overhangs the city and look down upon the single form of virtue,
2480 and the infinite forms of vice, among which are four special ones,
2481 characteristic both of states and of individuals. And the state which
2482 corresponds to the single form of virtue is that which we have been
2483 describing, wherein reason rules under one of two names--monarchy and
2484 aristocracy. Thus there are five forms in all, both of states and of
2485 souls...
2486 
2487 In attempting to prove that the soul has three separate faculties, Plato
2488 takes occasion to discuss what makes difference of faculties. And
2489 the criterion which he proposes is difference in the working of the
2490 faculties. The same faculty cannot produce contradictory effects. But
2491 the path of early reasoners is beset by thorny entanglements, and he
2492 will not proceed a step without first clearing the ground. This leads
2493 him into a tiresome digression, which is intended to explain the nature
2494 of contradiction. First, the contradiction must be at the same time and
2495 in the same relation. Secondly, no extraneous word must be introduced
2496 into either of the terms in which the contradictory proposition is
2497 expressed: for example, thirst is of drink, not of warm drink. He
2498 implies, what he does not say, that if, by the advice of reason, or by
2499 the impulse of anger, a man is restrained from drinking, this proves
2500 that thirst, or desire under which thirst is included, is distinct
2501 from anger and reason. But suppose that we allow the term 'thirst' or
2502 'desire' to be modified, and say an 'angry thirst,' or a 'revengeful
2503 desire,' then the two spheres of desire and anger overlap and become
2504 confused. This case therefore has to be excluded. And still there
2505 remains an exception to the rule in the use of the term 'good,' which is
2506 always implied in the object of desire. These are the discussions of
2507 an age before logic; and any one who is wearied by them should remember
2508 that they are necessary to the clearing up of ideas in the first
2509 development of the human faculties.
2510 
2511 The psychology of Plato extends no further than the division of the soul
2512 into the rational, irascible, and concupiscent elements, which, as far
2513 as we know, was first made by him, and has been retained by Aristotle
2514 and succeeding ethical writers. The chief difficulty in this early
2515 analysis of the mind is to define exactly the place of the irascible
2516 faculty (Greek), which may be variously described under the terms
2517 righteous indignation, spirit, passion. It is the foundation of courage,
2518 which includes in Plato moral courage, the courage of enduring pain, and
2519 of surmounting intellectual difficulties, as well as of meeting dangers
2520 in war. Though irrational, it inclines to side with the rational: it
2521 cannot be aroused by punishment when justly inflicted: it sometimes
2522 takes the form of an enthusiasm which sustains a man in the performance
2523 of great actions. It is the 'lion heart' with which the reason makes
2524 a treaty. On the other hand it is negative rather than positive; it
2525 is indignant at wrong or falsehood, but does not, like Love in the
2526 Symposium and Phaedrus, aspire to the vision of Truth or Good. It is the
2527 peremptory military spirit which prevails in the government of honour.
2528 It differs from anger (Greek), this latter term having no accessory
2529 notion of righteous indignation. Although Aristotle has retained the
2530 word, yet we may observe that 'passion' (Greek) has with him lost its
2531 affinity to the rational and has become indistinguishable from 'anger'
2532 (Greek). And to this vernacular use Plato himself in the Laws seems to
2533 revert, though not always. By modern philosophy too, as well as in our
2534 ordinary conversation, the words anger or passion are employed almost
2535 exclusively in a bad sense; there is no connotation of a just or
2536 reasonable cause by which they are aroused. The feeling of 'righteous
2537 indignation' is too partial and accidental to admit of our regarding
2538 it as a separate virtue or habit. We are tempted also to doubt whether
2539 Plato is right in supposing that an offender, however justly condemned,
2540 could be expected to acknowledge the justice of his sentence; this is
2541 the spirit of a philosopher or martyr rather than of a criminal.
2542 
2543 We may observe how nearly Plato approaches Aristotle's famous thesis,
2544 that 'good actions produce good habits.' The words 'as healthy practices
2545 (Greek) produce health, so do just practices produce justice,' have
2546 a sound very like the Nicomachean Ethics. But we note also that an
2547 incidental remark in Plato has become a far-reaching principle in
2548 Aristotle, and an inseparable part of a great Ethical system.
2549 
2550 There is a difficulty in understanding what Plato meant by 'the longer
2551 way': he seems to intimate some metaphysic of the future which will not
2552 be satisfied with arguing from the principle of contradiction. In the
2553 sixth and seventh books (compare Sophist and Parmenides) he has given
2554 us a sketch of such a metaphysic; but when Glaucon asks for the final
2555 revelation of the idea of good, he is put off with the declaration
2556 that he has not yet studied the preliminary sciences. How he would have
2557 filled up the sketch, or argued about such questions from a higher point
2558 of view, we can only conjecture. Perhaps he hoped to find some a priori
2559 method of developing the parts out of the whole; or he might have asked
2560 which of the ideas contains the other ideas, and possibly have stumbled
2561 on the Hegelian identity of the 'ego' and the 'universal.' Or he may
2562 have imagined that ideas might be constructed in some manner analogous
2563 to the construction of figures and numbers in the mathematical sciences.
2564 The most certain and necessary truth was to Plato the universal; and to
2565 this he was always seeking to refer all knowledge or opinion, just as in
2566 modern times we seek to rest them on the opposite pole of induction and
2567 experience. The aspirations of metaphysicians have always tended to
2568 pass beyond the limits of human thought and language: they seem to have
2569 reached a height at which they are 'moving about in worlds unrealized,'
2570 and their conceptions, although profoundly affecting their own minds,
2571 become invisible or unintelligible to others. We are not therefore
2572 surprized to find that Plato himself has nowhere clearly explained his
2573 doctrine of ideas; or that his school in a later generation, like his
2574 contemporaries Glaucon and Adeimantus, were unable to follow him in
2575 this region of speculation. In the Sophist, where he is refuting the
2576 scepticism which maintained either that there was no such thing as
2577 predication, or that all might be predicated of all, he arrives at the
2578 conclusion that some ideas combine with some, but not all with all. But
2579 he makes only one or two steps forward on this path; he nowhere attains
2580 to any connected system of ideas, or even to a knowledge of the most
2581 elementary relations of the sciences to one another.
2582 
2583 BOOK V. I was going to enumerate the four forms of vice or decline in
2584 states, when Polemarchus--he was sitting a little farther from me
2585 than Adeimantus--taking him by the coat and leaning towards him, said
2586 something in an undertone, of which I only caught the words, 'Shall we
2587 let him off?' 'Certainly not,' said Adeimantus, raising his voice. Whom,
2588 I said, are you not going to let off? 'You,' he said. Why? 'Because
2589 we think that you are not dealing fairly with us in omitting women and
2590 children, of whom you have slily disposed under the general formula
2591 that friends have all things in common.' And was I not right? 'Yes,'
2592 he replied, 'but there are many sorts of communism or community, and
2593 we want to know which of them is right. The company, as you have just
2594 heard, are resolved to have a further explanation.' Thrasymachus said,
2595 'Do you think that we have come hither to dig for gold, or to hear you
2596 discourse?' Yes, I said; but the discourse should be of a reasonable
2597 length. Glaucon added, 'Yes, Socrates, and there is reason in spending
2598 the whole of life in such discussions; but pray, without more ado, tell
2599 us how this community is to be carried out, and how the interval between
2600 birth and education is to be filled up.' Well, I said, the subject has
2601 several difficulties--What is possible? is the first question. What is
2602 desirable? is the second. 'Fear not,' he replied, 'for you are speaking
2603 among friends.' That, I replied, is a sorry consolation; I shall
2604 destroy my friends as well as myself. Not that I mind a little innocent
2605 laughter; but he who kills the truth is a murderer. 'Then,' said
2606 Glaucon, laughing, 'in case you should murder us we will acquit you
2607 beforehand, and you shall be held free from the guilt of deceiving us.'
2608 
2609 Socrates proceeds:--The guardians of our state are to be watch-dogs, as
2610 we have already said. Now dogs are not divided into hes and shes--we do
2611 not take the masculine gender out to hunt and leave the females at home
2612 to look after their puppies. They have the same employments--the only
2613 difference between them is that the one sex is stronger and the other
2614 weaker. But if women are to have the same employments as men, they must
2615 have the same education--they must be taught music and gymnastics, and
2616 the art of war. I know that a great joke will be made of their riding
2617 on horseback and carrying weapons; the sight of the naked old wrinkled
2618 women showing their agility in the palaestra will certainly not be a
2619 vision of beauty, and may be expected to become a famous jest. But we
2620 must not mind the wits; there was a time when they might have laughed at
2621 our present gymnastics. All is habit: people have at last found out that
2622 the exposure is better than the concealment of the person, and now they
2623 laugh no more. Evil only should be the subject of ridicule.
2624 
2625 The first question is, whether women are able either wholly or partially
2626 to share in the employments of men. And here we may be charged with
2627 inconsistency in making the proposal at all. For we started originally
2628 with the division of labour; and the diversity of employments was based
2629 on the difference of natures. But is there no difference between men
2630 and women? Nay, are they not wholly different? THERE was the difficulty,
2631 Glaucon, which made me unwilling to speak of family relations. However,
2632 when a man is out of his depth, whether in a pool or in an ocean, he can
2633 only swim for his life; and we must try to find a way of escape, if we
2634 can.
2635 
2636 The argument is, that different natures have different uses, and the
2637 natures of men and women are said to differ. But this is only a verbal
2638 opposition. We do not consider that the difference may be purely nominal
2639 and accidental; for example, a bald man and a hairy man are opposed in a
2640 single point of view, but you cannot infer that because a bald man is
2641 a cobbler a hairy man ought not to be a cobbler. Now why is such an
2642 inference erroneous? Simply because the opposition between them is
2643 partial only, like the difference between a male physician and a female
2644 physician, not running through the whole nature, like the difference
2645 between a physician and a carpenter. And if the difference of the sexes
2646 is only that the one beget and the other bear children, this does not
2647 prove that they ought to have distinct educations. Admitting that women
2648 differ from men in capacity, do not men equally differ from one another?
2649 Has not nature scattered all the qualities which our citizens require
2650 indifferently up and down among the two sexes? and even in their
2651 peculiar pursuits, are not women often, though in some cases superior to
2652 men, ridiculously enough surpassed by them? Women are the same in kind
2653 as men, and have the same aptitude or want of aptitude for medicine
2654 or gymnastic or war, but in a less degree. One woman will be a good
2655 guardian, another not; and the good must be chosen to be the colleagues
2656 of our guardians. If however their natures are the same, the inference
2657 is that their education must also be the same; there is no longer
2658 anything unnatural or impossible in a woman learning music and
2659 gymnastic. And the education which we give them will be the very best,
2660 far superior to that of cobblers, and will train up the very best women,
2661 and nothing can be more advantageous to the State than this. Therefore
2662 let them strip, clothed in their chastity, and share in the toils of war
2663 and in the defence of their country; he who laughs at them is a fool for
2664 his pains.
2665 
2666 The first wave is past, and the argument is compelled to admit that men
2667 and women have common duties and pursuits. A second and greater wave is
2668 rolling in--community of wives and children; is this either expedient
2669 or possible? The expediency I do not doubt; I am not so sure of the
2670 possibility. 'Nay, I think that a considerable doubt will be entertained
2671 on both points.' I meant to have escaped the trouble of proving the
2672 first, but as you have detected the little stratagem I must even submit.
2673 Only allow me to feed my fancy like the solitary in his walks, with a
2674 dream of what might be, and then I will return to the question of what
2675 can be.
2676 
2677 In the first place our rulers will enforce the laws and make new ones
2678 where they are wanted, and their allies or ministers will obey. You, as
2679 legislator, have already selected the men; and now you shall select
2680 the women. After the selection has been made, they will dwell in common
2681 houses and have their meals in common, and will be brought together by
2682 a necessity more certain than that of mathematics. But they cannot be
2683 allowed to live in licentiousness; that is an unholy thing, which
2684 the rulers are determined to prevent. For the avoidance of this, holy
2685 marriage festivals will be instituted, and their holiness will be in
2686 proportion to their usefulness. And here, Glaucon, I should like to ask
2687 (as I know that you are a breeder of birds and animals), Do you not take
2688 the greatest care in the mating? 'Certainly.' And there is no reason to
2689 suppose that less care is required in the marriage of human beings. But
2690 then our rulers must be skilful physicians of the State, for they will
2691 often need a strong dose of falsehood in order to bring about desirable
2692 unions between their subjects. The good must be paired with the good,
2693 and the bad with the bad, and the offspring of the one must be reared,
2694 and of the other destroyed; in this way the flock will be preserved in
2695 prime condition. Hymeneal festivals will be celebrated at times fixed
2696 with an eye to population, and the brides and bridegrooms will meet at
2697 them; and by an ingenious system of lots the rulers will contrive that
2698 the brave and the fair come together, and that those of inferior breed
2699 are paired with inferiors--the latter will ascribe to chance what is
2700 really the invention of the rulers. And when children are born, the
2701 offspring of the brave and fair will be carried to an enclosure in a
2702 certain part of the city, and there attended by suitable nurses; the
2703 rest will be hurried away to places unknown. The mothers will be brought
2704 to the fold and will suckle the children; care however must be taken
2705 that none of them recognise their own offspring; and if necessary other
2706 nurses may also be hired. The trouble of watching and getting up
2707 at night will be transferred to attendants. 'Then the wives of our
2708 guardians will have a fine easy time when they are having children.' And
2709 quite right too, I said, that they should.
2710 
2711 The parents ought to be in the prime of life, which for a man may be
2712 reckoned at thirty years--from twenty-five, when he has 'passed the
2713 point at which the speed of life is greatest,' to fifty-five; and at
2714 twenty years for a woman--from twenty to forty. Any one above or below
2715 those ages who partakes in the hymeneals shall be guilty of impiety;
2716 also every one who forms a marriage connexion at other times without the
2717 consent of the rulers. This latter regulation applies to those who are
2718 within the specified ages, after which they may range at will, provided
2719 they avoid the prohibited degrees of parents and children, or
2720 of brothers and sisters, which last, however, are not absolutely
2721 prohibited, if a dispensation be procured. 'But how shall we know the
2722 degrees of affinity, when all things are common?' The answer is, that
2723 brothers and sisters are all such as are born seven or nine months after
2724 the espousals, and their parents those who are then espoused, and every
2725 one will have many children and every child many parents.
2726 
2727 Socrates proceeds: I have now to prove that this scheme is advantageous
2728 and also consistent with our entire polity. The greatest good of a State
2729 is unity; the greatest evil, discord and distraction. And there will be
2730 unity where there are no private pleasures or pains or interests--where
2731 if one member suffers all the members suffer, if one citizen is touched
2732 all are quickly sensitive; and the least hurt to the little finger of
2733 the State runs through the whole body and vibrates to the soul. For the
2734 true State, like an individual, is injured as a whole when any part is
2735 affected. Every State has subjects and rulers, who in a democracy are
2736 called rulers, and in other States masters: but in our State they are
2737 called saviours and allies; and the subjects who in other States are
2738 termed slaves, are by us termed nurturers and paymasters, and those who
2739 are termed comrades and colleagues in other places, are by us called
2740 fathers and brothers. And whereas in other States members of the same
2741 government regard one of their colleagues as a friend and another as an
2742 enemy, in our State no man is a stranger to another; for every citizen
2743 is connected with every other by ties of blood, and these names and
2744 this way of speaking will have a corresponding reality--brother, father,
2745 sister, mother, repeated from infancy in the ears of children, will not
2746 be mere words. Then again the citizens will have all things in common,
2747 in having common property they will have common pleasures and pains.
2748 
2749 Can there be strife and contention among those who are of one mind; or
2750 lawsuits about property when men have nothing but their bodies which
2751 they call their own; or suits about violence when every one is bound
2752 to defend himself? The permission to strike when insulted will be an
2753 'antidote' to the knife and will prevent disturbances in the State. But
2754 no younger man will strike an elder; reverence will prevent him from
2755 laying hands on his kindred, and he will fear that the rest of the
2756 family may retaliate. Moreover, our citizens will be rid of the
2757 lesser evils of life; there will be no flattery of the rich, no sordid
2758 household cares, no borrowing and not paying. Compared with the
2759 citizens of other States, ours will be Olympic victors, and crowned
2760 with blessings greater still--they and their children having a better
2761 maintenance during life, and after death an honourable burial. Nor has
2762 the happiness of the individual been sacrificed to the happiness of the
2763 State; our Olympic victor has not been turned into a cobbler, but he
2764 has a happiness beyond that of any cobbler. At the same time, if any
2765 conceited youth begins to dream of appropriating the State to himself,
2766 he must be reminded that 'half is better than the whole.' 'I should
2767 certainly advise him to stay where he is when he has the promise of such
2768 a brave life.'
2769 
2770 But is such a community possible?--as among the animals, so also among
2771 men; and if possible, in what way possible? About war there is no
2772 difficulty; the principle of communism is adapted to military service.
2773 Parents will take their children to look on at a battle, just as
2774 potters' boys are trained to the business by looking on at the wheel.
2775 And to the parents themselves, as to other animals, the sight of their
2776 young ones will prove a great incentive to bravery. Young warriors must
2777 learn, but they must not run into danger, although a certain degree of
2778 risk is worth incurring when the benefit is great. The young creatures
2779 should be placed under the care of experienced veterans, and they should
2780 have wings--that is to say, swift and tractable steeds on which they may
2781 fly away and escape. One of the first things to be done is to teach a
2782 youth to ride.
2783 
2784 Cowards and deserters shall be degraded to the class of husbandmen;
2785 gentlemen who allow themselves to be taken prisoners, may be presented
2786 to the enemy. But what shall be done to the hero? First of all he shall
2787 be crowned by all the youths in the army; secondly, he shall receive the
2788 right hand of fellowship; and thirdly, do you think that there is any
2789 harm in his being kissed? We have already determined that he shall have
2790 more wives than others, in order that he may have as many children
2791 as possible. And at a feast he shall have more to eat; we have the
2792 authority of Homer for honouring brave men with 'long chines,' which is
2793 an appropriate compliment, because meat is a very strengthening thing.
2794 Fill the bowl then, and give the best seats and meats to the brave--may
2795 they do them good! And he who dies in battle will be at once declared to
2796 be of the golden race, and will, as we believe, become one of Hesiod's
2797 guardian angels. He shall be worshipped after death in the manner
2798 prescribed by the oracle; and not only he, but all other benefactors
2799 of the State who die in any other way, shall be admitted to the same
2800 honours.
2801 
2802 The next question is, How shall we treat our enemies? Shall Hellenes be
2803 enslaved? No; for there is too great a risk of the whole race passing
2804 under the yoke of the barbarians. Or shall the dead be despoiled?
2805 Certainly not; for that sort of thing is an excuse for skulking, and has
2806 been the ruin of many an army. There is meanness and feminine malice in
2807 making an enemy of the dead body, when the soul which was the owner has
2808 fled--like a dog who cannot reach his assailants, and quarrels with
2809 the stones which are thrown at him instead. Again, the arms of Hellenes
2810 should not be offered up in the temples of the Gods; they are a
2811 pollution, for they are taken from brethren. And on similar grounds
2812 there should be a limit to the devastation of Hellenic territory--the
2813 houses should not be burnt, nor more than the annual produce carried
2814 off. For war is of two kinds, civil and foreign; the first of which is
2815 properly termed 'discord,' and only the second 'war;' and war between
2816 Hellenes is in reality civil war--a quarrel in a family, which is ever
2817 to be regarded as unpatriotic and unnatural, and ought to be prosecuted
2818 with a view to reconciliation in a true phil-Hellenic spirit, as of
2819 those who would chasten but not utterly enslave. The war is not against
2820 a whole nation who are a friendly multitude of men, women, and children,
2821 but only against a few guilty persons; when they are punished peace will
2822 be restored. That is the way in which Hellenes should war against one
2823 another--and against barbarians, as they war against one another now.
2824 
2825 'But, my dear Socrates, you are forgetting the main question: Is such a
2826 State possible? I grant all and more than you say about the blessedness
2827 of being one family--fathers, brothers, mothers, daughters, going out
2828 to war together; but I want to ascertain the possibility of this ideal
2829 State.' You are too unmerciful. The first wave and the second wave I
2830 have hardly escaped, and now you will certainly drown me with the third.
2831 When you see the towering crest of the wave, I expect you to take pity.
2832 'Not a whit.'
2833 
2834 Well, then, we were led to form our ideal polity in the search after
2835 justice, and the just man answered to the just State. Is this ideal at
2836 all the worse for being impracticable? Would the picture of a perfectly
2837 beautiful man be any the worse because no such man ever lived? Can any
2838 reality come up to the idea? Nature will not allow words to be fully
2839 realized; but if I am to try and realize the ideal of the State in a
2840 measure, I think that an approach may be made to the perfection of which
2841 I dream by one or two, I do not say slight, but possible changes in the
2842 present constitution of States. I would reduce them to a single one--the
2843 great wave, as I call it. Until, then, kings are philosophers, or
2844 philosophers are kings, cities will never cease from ill: no, nor the
2845 human race; nor will our ideal polity ever come into being. I know that
2846 this is a hard saying, which few will be able to receive. 'Socrates,
2847 all the world will take off his coat and rush upon you with sticks and
2848 stones, and therefore I would advise you to prepare an answer.' You got
2849 me into the scrape, I said. 'And I was right,' he replied; 'however, I
2850 will stand by you as a sort of do-nothing, well-meaning ally.' Having
2851 the help of such a champion, I will do my best to maintain my position.
2852 And first, I must explain of whom I speak and what sort of natures these
2853 are who are to be philosophers and rulers. As you are a man of pleasure,
2854 you will not have forgotten how indiscriminate lovers are in their
2855 attachments; they love all, and turn blemishes into beauties. The
2856 snub-nosed youth is said to have a winning grace; the beak of another
2857 has a royal look; the featureless are faultless; the dark are manly, the
2858 fair angels; the sickly have a new term of endearment invented expressly
2859 for them, which is 'honey-pale.' Lovers of wine and lovers of ambition
2860 also desire the objects of their affection in every form. Now here comes
2861 the point:--The philosopher too is a lover of knowledge in every form;
2862 he has an insatiable curiosity. 'But will curiosity make a philosopher?
2863 Are the lovers of sights and sounds, who let out their ears to every
2864 chorus at the Dionysiac festivals, to be called philosophers?' They
2865 are not true philosophers, but only an imitation. 'Then how are we to
2866 describe the true?'
2867 
2868 You would acknowledge the existence of abstract ideas, such as justice,
2869 beauty, good, evil, which are severally one, yet in their various
2870 combinations appear to be many. Those who recognize these realities are
2871 philosophers; whereas the other class hear sounds and see colours,
2872 and understand their use in the arts, but cannot attain to the true or
2873 waking vision of absolute justice or beauty or truth; they have not the
2874 light of knowledge, but of opinion, and what they see is a dream only.
2875 Perhaps he of whom we say the last will be angry with us; can we pacify
2876 him without revealing the disorder of his mind? Suppose we say that,
2877 if he has knowledge we rejoice to hear it, but knowledge must be of
2878 something which is, as ignorance is of something which is not; and there
2879 is a third thing, which both is and is not, and is matter of opinion
2880 only. Opinion and knowledge, then, having distinct objects, must also
2881 be distinct faculties. And by faculties I mean powers unseen and
2882 distinguishable only by the difference in their objects, as opinion
2883 and knowledge differ, since the one is liable to err, but the other
2884 is unerring and is the mightiest of all our faculties. If being is
2885 the object of knowledge, and not-being of ignorance, and these are the
2886 extremes, opinion must lie between them, and may be called darker than
2887 the one and brighter than the other. This intermediate or contingent
2888 matter is and is not at the same time, and partakes both of existence
2889 and of non-existence. Now I would ask my good friend, who denies
2890 abstract beauty and justice, and affirms a many beautiful and a
2891 many just, whether everything he sees is not in some point of view
2892 different--the beautiful ugly, the pious impious, the just unjust? Is
2893 not the double also the half, and are not heavy and light relative terms
2894 which pass into one another? Everything is and is not, as in the old
2895 riddle--'A man and not a man shot and did not shoot a bird and not a
2896 bird with a stone and not a stone.' The mind cannot be fixed on either
2897 alternative; and these ambiguous, intermediate, erring, half-lighted
2898 objects, which have a disorderly movement in the region between being
2899 and not-being, are the proper matter of opinion, as the immutable
2900 objects are the proper matter of knowledge. And he who grovels in the
2901 world of sense, and has only this uncertain perception of things, is not
2902 a philosopher, but a lover of opinion only...
2903 
2904 The fifth book is the new beginning of the Republic, in which the
2905 community of property and of family are first maintained, and the
2906 transition is made to the kingdom of philosophers. For both of these
2907 Plato, after his manner, has been preparing in some chance words of Book
2908 IV, which fall unperceived on the reader's mind, as they are supposed
2909 at first to have fallen on the ear of Glaucon and Adeimantus. The
2910 'paradoxes,' as Morgenstern terms them, of this book of the Republic
2911 will be reserved for another place; a few remarks on the style, and some
2912 explanations of difficulties, may be briefly added.
2913 
2914 First, there is the image of the waves, which serves for a sort of
2915 scheme or plan of the book. The first wave, the second wave, the third
2916 and greatest wave come rolling in, and we hear the roar of them. All
2917 that can be said of the extravagance of Plato's proposals is anticipated
2918 by himself. Nothing is more admirable than the hesitation with which he
2919 proposes the solemn text, 'Until kings are philosophers,' etc.; or the
2920 reaction from the sublime to the ridiculous, when Glaucon describes the
2921 manner in which the new truth will be received by mankind.
2922 
2923 Some defects and difficulties may be noted in the execution of the
2924 communistic plan. Nothing is told us of the application of communism
2925 to the lower classes; nor is the table of prohibited degrees capable of
2926 being made out. It is quite possible that a child born at one hymeneal
2927 festival may marry one of its own brothers or sisters, or even one of
2928 its parents, at another. Plato is afraid of incestuous unions, but at
2929 the same time he does not wish to bring before us the fact that the city
2930 would be divided into families of those born seven and nine months after
2931 each hymeneal festival. If it were worth while to argue seriously about
2932 such fancies, we might remark that while all the old affinities are
2933 abolished, the newly prohibited affinity rests not on any natural or
2934 rational principle, but only upon the accident of children having been
2935 born in the same month and year. Nor does he explain how the lots could
2936 be so manipulated by the legislature as to bring together the fairest
2937 and best. The singular expression which is employed to describe the age
2938 of five-and-twenty may perhaps be taken from some poet.
2939 
2940 In the delineation of the philosopher, the illustrations of the nature
2941 of philosophy derived from love are more suited to the apprehension
2942 of Glaucon, the Athenian man of pleasure, than to modern tastes or
2943 feelings. They are partly facetious, but also contain a germ of truth.
2944 That science is a whole, remains a true principle of inductive as well
2945 as of metaphysical philosophy; and the love of universal knowledge is
2946 still the characteristic of the philosopher in modern as well as in
2947 ancient times.
2948 
2949 At the end of the fifth book Plato introduces the figment of contingent
2950 matter, which has exercised so great an influence both on the Ethics and
2951 Theology of the modern world, and which occurs here for the first time
2952 in the history of philosophy. He did not remark that the degrees of
2953 knowledge in the subject have nothing corresponding to them in the
2954 object. With him a word must answer to an idea; and he could not
2955 conceive of an opinion which was an opinion about nothing. The influence
2956 of analogy led him to invent 'parallels and conjugates' and to overlook
2957 facts. To us some of his difficulties are puzzling only from their
2958 simplicity: we do not perceive that the answer to them 'is tumbling out
2959 at our feet.' To the mind of early thinkers, the conception of not-being
2960 was dark and mysterious; they did not see that this terrible apparition
2961 which threatened destruction to all knowledge was only a logical
2962 determination. The common term under which, through the accidental use
2963 of language, two entirely different ideas were included was another
2964 source of confusion. Thus through the ambiguity of (Greek) Plato,
2965 attempting to introduce order into the first chaos of human thought,
2966 seems to have confused perception and opinion, and to have failed to
2967 distinguish the contingent from the relative. In the Theaetetus the
2968 first of these difficulties begins to clear up; in the Sophist the
2969 second; and for this, as well as for other reasons, both these dialogues
2970 are probably to be regarded as later than the Republic.
2971 
2972 BOOK VI. Having determined that the many have no knowledge of true
2973 being, and have no clear patterns in their minds of justice, beauty,
2974 truth, and that philosophers have such patterns, we have now to ask
2975 whether they or the many shall be rulers in our State. But who can doubt
2976 that philosophers should be chosen, if they have the other qualities
2977 which are required in a ruler? For they are lovers of the knowledge of
2978 the eternal and of all truth; they are haters of falsehood; their meaner
2979 desires are absorbed in the interests of knowledge; they are spectators
2980 of all time and all existence; and in the magnificence of their
2981 contemplation the life of man is as nothing to them, nor is death
2982 fearful. Also they are of a social, gracious disposition, equally free
2983 from cowardice and arrogance. They learn and remember easily; they have
2984 harmonious, well-regulated minds; truth flows to them sweetly by nature.
2985 Can the god of Jealousy himself find any fault with such an assemblage
2986 of good qualities?
2987 
2988 Here Adeimantus interposes:--'No man can answer you, Socrates; but every
2989 man feels that this is owing to his own deficiency in argument. He is
2990 driven from one position to another, until he has nothing more to say,
2991 just as an unskilful player at draughts is reduced to his last move by
2992 a more skilled opponent. And yet all the time he may be right. He may
2993 know, in this very instance, that those who make philosophy the business
2994 of their lives, generally turn out rogues if they are bad men, and fools
2995 if they are good. What do you say?' I should say that he is quite right.
2996 'Then how is such an admission reconcileable with the doctrine that
2997 philosophers should be kings?'
2998 
2999 I shall answer you in a parable which will also let you see how poor a
3000 hand I am at the invention of allegories. The relation of good men to
3001 their governments is so peculiar, that in order to defend them I must
3002 take an illustration from the world of fiction. Conceive the captain
3003 of a ship, taller by a head and shoulders than any of the crew, yet a
3004 little deaf, a little blind, and rather ignorant of the seaman's art.
3005 The sailors want to steer, although they know nothing of the art; and
3006 they have a theory that it cannot be learned. If the helm is refused
3007 them, they drug the captain's posset, bind him hand and foot, and take
3008 possession of the ship. He who joins in the mutiny is termed a good
3009 pilot and what not; they have no conception that the true pilot must
3010 observe the winds and the stars, and must be their master, whether
3011 they like it or not;--such an one would be called by them fool, prater,
3012 star-gazer. This is my parable; which I will beg you to interpret for
3013 me to those gentlemen who ask why the philosopher has such an evil name,
3014 and to explain to them that not he, but those who will not use him, are
3015 to blame for his uselessness. The philosopher should not beg of mankind
3016 to be put in authority over them. The wise man should not seek the rich,
3017 as the proverb bids, but every man, whether rich or poor, must knock at
3018 the door of the physician when he has need of him. Now the pilot is
3019 the philosopher--he whom in the parable they call star-gazer, and the
3020 mutinous sailors are the mob of politicians by whom he is rendered
3021 useless. Not that these are the worst enemies of philosophy, who is far
3022 more dishonoured by her own professing sons when they are corrupted by
3023 the world. Need I recall the original image of the philosopher? Did we
3024 not say of him just now, that he loved truth and hated falsehood, and
3025 that he could not rest in the multiplicity of phenomena, but was led by
3026 a sympathy in his own nature to the contemplation of the absolute? All
3027 the virtues as well as truth, who is the leader of them, took up their
3028 abode in his soul. But as you were observing, if we turn aside to view
3029 the reality, we see that the persons who were thus described, with the
3030 exception of a small and useless class, are utter rogues.
3031 
3032 The point which has to be considered, is the origin of this corruption
3033 in nature. Every one will admit that the philosopher, in our description
3034 of him, is a rare being. But what numberless causes tend to destroy
3035 these rare beings! There is no good thing which may not be a cause of
3036 evil--health, wealth, strength, rank, and the virtues themselves,
3037 when placed under unfavourable circumstances. For as in the animal or
3038 vegetable world the strongest seeds most need the accompaniment of good
3039 air and soil, so the best of human characters turn out the worst when
3040 they fall upon an unsuitable soil; whereas weak natures hardly ever
3041 do any considerable good or harm; they are not the stuff out of which
3042 either great criminals or great heroes are made. The philosopher follows
3043 the same analogy: he is either the best or the worst of all men. Some
3044 persons say that the Sophists are the corrupters of youth; but is not
3045 public opinion the real Sophist who is everywhere present--in those very
3046 persons, in the assembly, in the courts, in the camp, in the applauses
3047 and hisses of the theatre re-echoed by the surrounding hills? Will not
3048 a young man's heart leap amid these discordant sounds? and will any
3049 education save him from being carried away by the torrent? Nor is this
3050 all. For if he will not yield to opinion, there follows the gentle
3051 compulsion of exile or death. What principle of rival Sophists or
3052 anybody else can overcome in such an unequal contest? Characters there
3053 may be more than human, who are exceptions--God may save a man, but not
3054 his own strength. Further, I would have you consider that the hireling
3055 Sophist only gives back to the world their own opinions; he is the
3056 keeper of the monster, who knows how to flatter or anger him, and
3057 observes the meaning of his inarticulate grunts. Good is what pleases
3058 him, evil what he dislikes; truth and beauty are determined only by
3059 the taste of the brute. Such is the Sophist's wisdom, and such is the
3060 condition of those who make public opinion the test of truth, whether in
3061 art or in morals. The curse is laid upon them of being and doing what
3062 it approves, and when they attempt first principles the failure is
3063 ludicrous. Think of all this and ask yourself whether the world is more
3064 likely to be a believer in the unity of the idea, or in the multiplicity
3065 of phenomena. And the world if not a believer in the idea cannot be a
3066 philosopher, and must therefore be a persecutor of philosophers. There
3067 is another evil:--the world does not like to lose the gifted nature, and
3068 so they flatter the young (Alcibiades) into a magnificent opinion of his
3069 own capacity; the tall, proper youth begins to expand, and is dreaming
3070 of kingdoms and empires. If at this instant a friend whispers to
3071 him, 'Now the gods lighten thee; thou art a great fool' and must be
3072 educated--do you think that he will listen? Or suppose a better sort of
3073 man who is attracted towards philosophy, will they not make Herculean
3074 efforts to spoil and corrupt him? Are we not right in saying that the
3075 love of knowledge, no less than riches, may divert him? Men of this
3076 class (Critias) often become politicians--they are the authors of
3077 great mischief in states, and sometimes also of great good. And thus
3078 philosophy is deserted by her natural protectors, and others enter in
3079 and dishonour her. Vulgar little minds see the land open and rush from
3080 the prisons of the arts into her temple. A clever mechanic having a
3081 soul coarse as his body, thinks that he will gain caste by becoming her
3082 suitor. For philosophy, even in her fallen estate, has a dignity of her
3083 own--and he, like a bald little blacksmith's apprentice as he is, having
3084 made some money and got out of durance, washes and dresses himself as a
3085 bridegroom and marries his master's daughter. What will be the issue of
3086 such marriages? Will they not be vile and bastard, devoid of truth
3087 and nature? 'They will.' Small, then, is the remnant of genuine
3088 philosophers; there may be a few who are citizens of small states, in
3089 which politics are not worth thinking of, or who have been detained by
3090 Theages' bridle of ill health; for my own case of the oracular sign is
3091 almost unique, and too rare to be worth mentioning. And these few when
3092 they have tasted the pleasures of philosophy, and have taken a look at
3093 that den of thieves and place of wild beasts, which is human life,
3094 will stand aside from the storm under the shelter of a wall, and try to
3095 preserve their own innocence and to depart in peace. 'A great work, too,
3096 will have been accomplished by them.' Great, yes, but not the greatest;
3097 for man is a social being, and can only attain his highest development
3098 in the society which is best suited to him.
3099 
3100 Enough, then, of the causes why philosophy has such an evil name.
3101 Another question is, Which of existing states is suited to her? Not one
3102 of them; at present she is like some exotic seed which degenerates in
3103 a strange soil; only in her proper state will she be shown to be of
3104 heavenly growth. 'And is her proper state ours or some other?' Ours in
3105 all points but one, which was left undetermined. You may remember our
3106 saying that some living mind or witness of the legislator was needed in
3107 states. But we were afraid to enter upon a subject of such difficulty,
3108 and now the question recurs and has not grown easier:--How may
3109 philosophy be safely studied? Let us bring her into the light of day,
3110 and make an end of the inquiry.
3111 
3112 In the first place, I say boldly that nothing can be worse than the
3113 present mode of study. Persons usually pick up a little philosophy in
3114 early youth, and in the intervals of business, but they never master the
3115 real difficulty, which is dialectic. Later, perhaps, they occasionally
3116 go to a lecture on philosophy. Years advance, and the sun of philosophy,
3117 unlike that of Heracleitus, sets never to rise again. This order of
3118 education should be reversed; it should begin with gymnastics in youth,
3119 and as the man strengthens, he should increase the gymnastics of
3120 his soul. Then, when active life is over, let him finally return to
3121 philosophy. 'You are in earnest, Socrates, but the world will be equally
3122 earnest in withstanding you--no more than Thrasymachus.' Do not make a
3123 quarrel between Thrasymachus and me, who were never enemies and are
3124 now good friends enough. And I shall do my best to convince him and
3125 all mankind of the truth of my words, or at any rate to prepare for
3126 the future when, in another life, we may again take part in similar
3127 discussions. 'That will be a long time hence.' Not long in comparison
3128 with eternity. The many will probably remain incredulous, for they
3129 have never seen the natural unity of ideas, but only artificial
3130 juxtapositions; not free and generous thoughts, but tricks of
3131 controversy and quips of law;--a perfect man ruling in a perfect state,
3132 even a single one they have not known. And we foresaw that there was no
3133 chance of perfection either in states or individuals until a necessity
3134 was laid upon philosophers--not the rogues, but those whom we called
3135 the useless class--of holding office; or until the sons of kings were
3136 inspired with a true love of philosophy. Whether in the infinity of
3137 past time there has been, or is in some distant land, or ever will be
3138 hereafter, an ideal such as we have described, we stoutly maintain
3139 that there has been, is, and will be such a state whenever the Muse of
3140 philosophy rules. Will you say that the world is of another mind? O, my
3141 friend, do not revile the world! They will soon change their opinion
3142 if they are gently entreated, and are taught the true nature of the
3143 philosopher. Who can hate a man who loves him? Or be jealous of one who
3144 has no jealousy? Consider, again, that the many hate not the true but
3145 the false philosophers--the pretenders who force their way in without
3146 invitation, and are always speaking of persons and not of principles,
3147 which is unlike the spirit of philosophy. For the true philosopher
3148 despises earthly strife; his eye is fixed on the eternal order in
3149 accordance with which he moulds himself into the Divine image (and not
3150 himself only, but other men), and is the creator of the virtues private
3151 as well as public. When mankind see that the happiness of states is only
3152 to be found in that image, will they be angry with us for attempting
3153 to delineate it? 'Certainly not. But what will be the process of
3154 delineation?' The artist will do nothing until he has made a tabula
3155 rasa; on this he will inscribe the constitution of a state, glancing
3156 often at the divine truth of nature, and from that deriving the godlike
3157 among men, mingling the two elements, rubbing out and painting in,
3158 until there is a perfect harmony or fusion of the divine and human. But
3159 perhaps the world will doubt the existence of such an artist. What will
3160 they doubt? That the philosopher is a lover of truth, having a nature
3161 akin to the best?--and if they admit this will they still quarrel with
3162 us for making philosophers our kings? 'They will be less disposed to
3163 quarrel.' Let us assume then that they are pacified. Still, a person may
3164 hesitate about the probability of the son of a king being a philosopher.
3165 And we do not deny that they are very liable to be corrupted; but yet
3166 surely in the course of ages there might be one exception--and one
3167 is enough. If one son of a king were a philosopher, and had obedient
3168 citizens, he might bring the ideal polity into being. Hence we conclude
3169 that our laws are not only the best, but that they are also possible,
3170 though not free from difficulty.
3171 
3172 I gained nothing by evading the troublesome questions which arose
3173 concerning women and children. I will be wiser now and acknowledge
3174 that we must go to the bottom of another question: What is to be the
3175 education of our guardians? It was agreed that they were to be lovers of
3176 their country, and were to be tested in the refiner's fire of pleasures
3177 and pains, and those who came forth pure and remained fixed in their
3178 principles were to have honours and rewards in life and after death.
3179 But at this point, the argument put on her veil and turned into another
3180 path. I hesitated to make the assertion which I now hazard,--that our
3181 guardians must be philosophers. You remember all the contradictory
3182 elements, which met in the philosopher--how difficult to find them all
3183 in a single person! Intelligence and spirit are not often combined with
3184 steadiness; the stolid, fearless, nature is averse to intellectual toil.
3185 And yet these opposite elements are all necessary, and therefore, as
3186 we were saying before, the aspirant must be tested in pleasures and
3187 dangers; and also, as we must now further add, in the highest branches
3188 of knowledge. You will remember, that when we spoke of the virtues
3189 mention was made of a longer road, which you were satisfied to leave
3190 unexplored. 'Enough seemed to have been said.' Enough, my friend; but
3191 what is enough while anything remains wanting? Of all men the guardian
3192 must not faint in the search after truth; he must be prepared to take
3193 the longer road, or he will never reach that higher region which is
3194 above the four virtues; and of the virtues too he must not only get an
3195 outline, but a clear and distinct vision. (Strange that we should be so
3196 precise about trifles, so careless about the highest truths!) 'And what
3197 are the highest?' You to pretend unconsciousness, when you have so often
3198 heard me speak of the idea of good, about which we know so little, and
3199 without which though a man gain the world he has no profit of it! Some
3200 people imagine that the good is wisdom; but this involves a circle,--the
3201 good, they say, is wisdom, wisdom has to do with the good. According to
3202 others the good is pleasure; but then comes the absurdity that good is
3203 bad, for there are bad pleasures as well as good. Again, the good must
3204 have reality; a man may desire the appearance of virtue, but he will not
3205 desire the appearance of good. Ought our guardians then to be ignorant
3206 of this supreme principle, of which every man has a presentiment, and
3207 without which no man has any real knowledge of anything? 'But, Socrates,
3208 what is this supreme principle, knowledge or pleasure, or what? You may
3209 think me troublesome, but I say that you have no business to be always
3210 repeating the doctrines of others instead of giving us your own.' Can
3211 I say what I do not know? 'You may offer an opinion.' And will the
3212 blindness and crookedness of opinion content you when you might have
3213 the light and certainty of science? 'I will only ask you to give such
3214 an explanation of the good as you have given already of temperance and
3215 justice.' I wish that I could, but in my present mood I cannot reach to
3216 the height of the knowledge of the good. To the parent or principal I
3217 cannot introduce you, but to the child begotten in his image, which
3218 I may compare with the interest on the principal, I will. (Audit the
3219 account, and do not let me give you a false statement of the debt.)
3220 You remember our old distinction of the many beautiful and the one
3221 beautiful, the particular and the universal, the objects of sight and
3222 the objects of thought? Did you ever consider that the objects of sight
3223 imply a faculty of sight which is the most complex and costly of our
3224 senses, requiring not only objects of sense, but also a medium, which is
3225 light; without which the sight will not distinguish between colours and
3226 all will be a blank? For light is the noble bond between the perceiving
3227 faculty and the thing perceived, and the god who gives us light is the
3228 sun, who is the eye of the day, but is not to be confounded with the eye
3229 of man. This eye of the day or sun is what I call the child of the good,
3230 standing in the same relation to the visible world as the good to the
3231 intellectual. When the sun shines the eye sees, and in the intellectual
3232 world where truth is, there is sight and light. Now that which is the
3233 sun of intelligent natures, is the idea of good, the cause of knowledge
3234 and truth, yet other and fairer than they are, and standing in the
3235 same relation to them in which the sun stands to light. O inconceivable
3236 height of beauty, which is above knowledge and above truth! ('You cannot
3237 surely mean pleasure,' he said. Peace, I replied.) And this idea of
3238 good, like the sun, is also the cause of growth, and the author not of
3239 knowledge only, but of being, yet greater far than either in dignity
3240 and power. 'That is a reach of thought more than human; but, pray, go
3241 on with the image, for I suspect that there is more behind.' There is,
3242 I said; and bearing in mind our two suns or principles, imagine further
3243 their corresponding worlds--one of the visible, the other of the
3244 intelligible; you may assist your fancy by figuring the distinction
3245 under the image of a line divided into two unequal parts, and may again
3246 subdivide each part into two lesser segments representative of the
3247 stages of knowledge in either sphere. The lower portion of the lower or
3248 visible sphere will consist of shadows and reflections, and its upper
3249 and smaller portion will contain real objects in the world of nature
3250 or of art. The sphere of the intelligible will also have two
3251 divisions,--one of mathematics, in which there is no ascent but all is
3252 descent; no inquiring into premises, but only drawing of inferences.
3253 In this division the mind works with figures and numbers, the images of
3254 which are taken not from the shadows, but from the objects, although
3255 the truth of them is seen only with the mind's eye; and they are used as
3256 hypotheses without being analysed. Whereas in the other division reason
3257 uses the hypotheses as stages or steps in the ascent to the idea of
3258 good, to which she fastens them, and then again descends, walking firmly
3259 in the region of ideas, and of ideas only, in her ascent as well as
3260 descent, and finally resting in them. 'I partly understand,' he replied;
3261 'you mean that the ideas of science are superior to the hypothetical,
3262 metaphorical conceptions of geometry and the other arts or sciences,
3263 whichever is to be the name of them; and the latter conceptions you
3264 refuse to make subjects of pure intellect, because they have no first
3265 principle, although when resting on a first principle, they pass into
3266 the higher sphere.' You understand me very well, I said. And now to
3267 those four divisions of knowledge you may assign four corresponding
3268 faculties--pure intelligence to the highest sphere; active intelligence
3269 to the second; to the third, faith; to the fourth, the perception of
3270 shadows--and the clearness of the several faculties will be in the same
3271 ratio as the truth of the objects to which they are related...
3272 
3273 Like Socrates, we may recapitulate the virtues of the philosopher.
3274 In language which seems to reach beyond the horizon of that age
3275 and country, he is described as 'the spectator of all time and all
3276 existence.' He has the noblest gifts of nature, and makes the highest
3277 use of them. All his desires are absorbed in the love of wisdom, which
3278 is the love of truth. None of the graces of a beautiful soul are wanting
3279 in him; neither can he fear death, or think much of human life. The
3280 ideal of modern times hardly retains the simplicity of the antique;
3281 there is not the same originality either in truth or error which
3282 characterized the Greeks. The philosopher is no longer living in the
3283 unseen, nor is he sent by an oracle to convince mankind of ignorance;
3284 nor does he regard knowledge as a system of ideas leading upwards by
3285 regular stages to the idea of good. The eagerness of the pursuit has
3286 abated; there is more division of labour and less of comprehensive
3287 reflection upon nature and human life as a whole; more of exact
3288 observation and less of anticipation and inspiration. Still, in the
3289 altered conditions of knowledge, the parallel is not wholly lost; and
3290 there may be a use in translating the conception of Plato into the
3291 language of our own age. The philosopher in modern times is one who
3292 fixes his mind on the laws of nature in their sequence and connexion,
3293 not on fragments or pictures of nature; on history, not on controversy;
3294 on the truths which are acknowledged by the few, not on the opinions
3295 of the many. He is aware of the importance of 'classifying according to
3296 nature,' and will try to 'separate the limbs of science without breaking
3297 them' (Phaedr.). There is no part of truth, whether great or small,
3298 which he will dishonour; and in the least things he will discern the
3299 greatest (Parmen.). Like the ancient philosopher he sees the world
3300 pervaded by analogies, but he can also tell 'why in some cases a single
3301 instance is sufficient for an induction' (Mill's Logic), while in
3302 other cases a thousand examples would prove nothing. He inquires into
3303 a portion of knowledge only, because the whole has grown too vast to be
3304 embraced by a single mind or life. He has a clearer conception of the
3305 divisions of science and of their relation to the mind of man than was
3306 possible to the ancients. Like Plato, he has a vision of the unity of
3307 knowledge, not as the beginning of philosophy to be attained by a study
3308 of elementary mathematics, but as the far-off result of the working
3309 of many minds in many ages. He is aware that mathematical studies are
3310 preliminary to almost every other; at the same time, he will not reduce
3311 all varieties of knowledge to the type of mathematics. He too must have
3312 a nobility of character, without which genius loses the better half
3313 of greatness. Regarding the world as a point in immensity, and each
3314 individual as a link in a never-ending chain of existence, he will not
3315 think much of his own life, or be greatly afraid of death.
3316 
3317 Adeimantus objects first of all to the form of the Socratic reasoning,
3318 thus showing that Plato is aware of the imperfection of his own method.
3319 He brings the accusation against himself which might be brought against
3320 him by a modern logician--that he extracts the answer because he knows
3321 how to put the question. In a long argument words are apt to change
3322 their meaning slightly, or premises may be assumed or conclusions
3323 inferred with rather too much certainty or universality; the variation
3324 at each step may be unobserved, and yet at last the divergence becomes
3325 considerable. Hence the failure of attempts to apply arithmetical or
3326 algebraic formulae to logic. The imperfection, or rather the higher
3327 and more elastic nature of language, does not allow words to have the
3328 precision of numbers or of symbols. And this quality in language impairs
3329 the force of an argument which has many steps.
3330 
3331 The objection, though fairly met by Socrates in this particular
3332 instance, may be regarded as implying a reflection upon the Socratic
3333 mode of reasoning. And here, as elsewhere, Plato seems to intimate that
3334 the time had come when the negative and interrogative method of Socrates
3335 must be superseded by a positive and constructive one, of which examples
3336 are given in some of the later dialogues. Adeimantus further argues
3337 that the ideal is wholly at variance with facts; for experience proves
3338 philosophers to be either useless or rogues. Contrary to all expectation
3339 Socrates has no hesitation in admitting the truth of this, and explains
3340 the anomaly in an allegory, first characteristically depreciating his
3341 own inventive powers. In this allegory the people are distinguished from
3342 the professional politicians, and, as elsewhere, are spoken of in a tone
3343 of pity rather than of censure under the image of 'the noble captain who
3344 is not very quick in his perceptions.'
3345 
3346 The uselessness of philosophers is explained by the circumstance that
3347 mankind will not use them. The world in all ages has been divided
3348 between contempt and fear of those who employ the power of ideas and
3349 know no other weapons. Concerning the false philosopher, Socrates argues
3350 that the best is most liable to corruption; and that the finer nature is
3351 more likely to suffer from alien conditions. We too observe that there
3352 are some kinds of excellence which spring from a peculiar delicacy
3353 of constitution; as is evidently true of the poetical and imaginative
3354 temperament, which often seems to depend on impressions, and hence can
3355 only breathe or live in a certain atmosphere. The man of genius
3356 has greater pains and greater pleasures, greater powers and greater
3357 weaknesses, and often a greater play of character than is to be found in
3358 ordinary men. He can assume the disguise of virtue or disinterestedness
3359 without having them, or veil personal enmity in the language of
3360 patriotism and philosophy,--he can say the word which all men are
3361 thinking, he has an insight which is terrible into the follies and
3362 weaknesses of his fellow-men. An Alcibiades, a Mirabeau, or a Napoleon
3363 the First, are born either to be the authors of great evils in states,
3364 or 'of great good, when they are drawn in that direction.'
3365 
3366 Yet the thesis, 'corruptio optimi pessima,' cannot be maintained
3367 generally or without regard to the kind of excellence which is
3368 corrupted. The alien conditions which are corrupting to one nature, may
3369 be the elements of culture to another. In general a man can only receive
3370 his highest development in a congenial state or family, among friends
3371 or fellow-workers. But also he may sometimes be stirred by adverse
3372 circumstances to such a degree that he rises up against them and reforms
3373 them. And while weaker or coarser characters will extract good out of
3374 evil, say in a corrupt state of the church or of society, and live on
3375 happily, allowing the evil to remain, the finer or stronger natures may
3376 be crushed or spoiled by surrounding influences--may become misanthrope
3377 and philanthrope by turns; or in a few instances, like the founders
3378 of the monastic orders, or the Reformers, owing to some peculiarity in
3379 themselves or in their age, may break away entirely from the world and
3380 from the church, sometimes into great good, sometimes into great evil,
3381 sometimes into both. And the same holds in the lesser sphere of a
3382 convent, a school, a family.
3383 
3384 Plato would have us consider how easily the best natures are overpowered
3385 by public opinion, and what efforts the rest of mankind will make to
3386 get possession of them. The world, the church, their own profession, any
3387 political or party organization, are always carrying them off their legs
3388 and teaching them to apply high and holy names to their own prejudices
3389 and interests. The 'monster' corporation to which they belong judges
3390 right and truth to be the pleasure of the community. The individual
3391 becomes one with his order; or, if he resists, the world is too much for
3392 him, and will sooner or later be revenged on him. This is, perhaps, a
3393 one-sided but not wholly untrue picture of the maxims and practice of
3394 mankind when they 'sit down together at an assembly,' either in ancient
3395 or modern times.
3396 
3397 When the higher natures are corrupted by politics, the lower take
3398 possession of the vacant place of philosophy. This is described in one
3399 of those continuous images in which the argument, to use a Platonic
3400 expression, 'veils herself,' and which is dropped and reappears at
3401 intervals. The question is asked,--Why are the citizens of states so
3402 hostile to philosophy? The answer is, that they do not know her. And yet
3403 there is also a better mind of the many; they would believe if they were
3404 taught. But hitherto they have only known a conventional imitation of
3405 philosophy, words without thoughts, systems which have no life in them;
3406 a (divine) person uttering the words of beauty and freedom, the friend
3407 of man holding communion with the Eternal, and seeking to frame the
3408 state in that image, they have never known. The same double feeling
3409 respecting the mass of mankind has always existed among men. The first
3410 thought is that the people are the enemies of truth and right; the
3411 second, that this only arises out of an accidental error and confusion,
3412 and that they do not really hate those who love them, if they could be
3413 educated to know them.
3414 
3415 In the latter part of the sixth book, three questions have to be
3416 considered: 1st, the nature of the longer and more circuitous way, which
3417 is contrasted with the shorter and more imperfect method of Book IV;
3418 2nd, the heavenly pattern or idea of the state; 3rd, the relation of the
3419 divisions of knowledge to one another and to the corresponding faculties
3420 of the soul:
3421 
3422 1. Of the higher method of knowledge in Plato we have only a glimpse.
3423 Neither here nor in the Phaedrus or Symposium, nor yet in the Philebus
3424 or Sophist, does he give any clear explanation of his meaning. He would
3425 probably have described his method as proceeding by regular steps to a
3426 system of universal knowledge, which inferred the parts from the whole
3427 rather than the whole from the parts. This ideal logic is not practised
3428 by him in the search after justice, or in the analysis of the parts of
