3429 the soul; there, like Aristotle in the Nicomachean Ethics, he argues
3430 from experience and the common use of language. But at the end of the
3431 sixth book he conceives another and more perfect method, in which
3432 all ideas are only steps or grades or moments of thought, forming a
3433 connected whole which is self-supporting, and in which consistency is
3434 the test of truth. He does not explain to us in detail the nature of the
3435 process. Like many other thinkers both in ancient and modern times
3436 his mind seems to be filled with a vacant form which he is unable to
3437 realize. He supposes the sciences to have a natural order and connexion
3438 in an age when they can hardly be said to exist. He is hastening on to
3439 the 'end of the intellectual world' without even making a beginning of
3440 them.
3441 
3442 In modern times we hardly need to be reminded that the process of
3443 acquiring knowledge is here confused with the contemplation of absolute
3444 knowledge. In all science a priori and a posteriori truths mingle in
3445 various proportions. The a priori part is that which is derived from the
3446 most universal experience of men, or is universally accepted by
3447 them; the a posteriori is that which grows up around the more
3448 general principles and becomes imperceptibly one with them. But Plato
3449 erroneously imagines that the synthesis is separable from the analysis,
3450 and that the method of science can anticipate science. In entertaining
3451 such a vision of a priori knowledge he is sufficiently justified, or at
3452 least his meaning may be sufficiently explained by the similar attempts
3453 of Descartes, Kant, Hegel, and even of Bacon himself, in modern
3454 philosophy. Anticipations or divinations, or prophetic glimpses of
3455 truths whether concerning man or nature, seem to stand in the same
3456 relation to ancient philosophy which hypotheses bear to modern inductive
3457 science. These 'guesses at truth' were not made at random; they arose
3458 from a superficial impression of uniformities and first principles
3459 in nature which the genius of the Greek, contemplating the expanse of
3460 heaven and earth, seemed to recognize in the distance. Nor can we deny
3461 that in ancient times knowledge must have stood still, and the human
3462 mind been deprived of the very instruments of thought, if philosophy had
3463 been strictly confined to the results of experience.
3464 
3465 2. Plato supposes that when the tablet has been made blank the artist
3466 will fill in the lineaments of the ideal state. Is this a pattern laid
3467 up in heaven, or mere vacancy on which he is supposed to gaze with
3468 wondering eye? The answer is, that such ideals are framed partly by the
3469 omission of particulars, partly by imagination perfecting the form which
3470 experience supplies (Phaedo). Plato represents these ideals in a
3471 figure as belonging to another world; and in modern times the idea will
3472 sometimes seem to precede, at other times to co-operate with the hand
3473 of the artist. As in science, so also in creative art, there is a
3474 synthetical as well as an analytical method. One man will have the whole
3475 in his mind before he begins; to another the processes of mind and hand
3476 will be simultaneous.
3477 
3478 3. There is no difficulty in seeing that Plato's divisions of knowledge
3479 are based, first, on the fundamental antithesis of sensible and
3480 intellectual which pervades the whole pre-Socratic philosophy; in which
3481 is implied also the opposition of the permanent and transient, of the
3482 universal and particular. But the age of philosophy in which he lived
3483 seemed to require a further distinction;--numbers and figures were
3484 beginning to separate from ideas. The world could no longer regard
3485 justice as a cube, and was learning to see, though imperfectly, that
3486 the abstractions of sense were distinct from the abstractions of mind.
3487 Between the Eleatic being or essence and the shadows of phenomena, the
3488 Pythagorean principle of number found a place, and was, as Aristotle
3489 remarks, a conducting medium from one to the other. Hence Plato is led
3490 to introduce a third term which had not hitherto entered into the scheme
3491 of his philosophy. He had observed the use of mathematics in education;
3492 they were the best preparation for higher studies. The subjective
3493 relation between them further suggested an objective one; although
3494 the passage from one to the other is really imaginary (Metaph.). For
3495 metaphysical and moral philosophy has no connexion with mathematics;
3496 number and figure are the abstractions of time and space, not the
3497 expressions of purely intellectual conceptions. When divested of
3498 metaphor, a straight line or a square has no more to do with right and
3499 justice than a crooked line with vice. The figurative association was
3500 mistaken for a real one; and thus the three latter divisions of the
3501 Platonic proportion were constructed.
3502 
3503 There is more difficulty in comprehending how he arrived at the
3504 first term of the series, which is nowhere else mentioned, and has no
3505 reference to any other part of his system. Nor indeed does the relation
3506 of shadows to objects correspond to the relation of numbers to ideas.
3507 Probably Plato has been led by the love of analogy (Timaeus) to make
3508 four terms instead of three, although the objects perceived in both
3509 divisions of the lower sphere are equally objects of sense. He is also
3510 preparing the way, as his manner is, for the shadows of images at the
3511 beginning of the seventh book, and the imitation of an imitation in the
3512 tenth. The line may be regarded as reaching from unity to infinity, and
3513 is divided into two unequal parts, and subdivided into two more;
3514 each lower sphere is the multiplication of the preceding. Of the four
3515 faculties, faith in the lower division has an intermediate position (cp.
3516 for the use of the word faith or belief, (Greek), Timaeus), contrasting
3517 equally with the vagueness of the perception of shadows (Greek) and the
3518 higher certainty of understanding (Greek) and reason (Greek).
3519 
3520 The difference between understanding and mind or reason (Greek) is
3521 analogous to the difference between acquiring knowledge in the parts
3522 and the contemplation of the whole. True knowledge is a whole, and is
3523 at rest; consistency and universality are the tests of truth. To this
3524 self-evidencing knowledge of the whole the faculty of mind is supposed
3525 to correspond. But there is a knowledge of the understanding which
3526 is incomplete and in motion always, because unable to rest in
3527 the subordinate ideas. Those ideas are called both images and
3528 hypotheses--images because they are clothed in sense, hypotheses because
3529 they are assumptions only, until they are brought into connexion with
3530 the idea of good.
3531 
3532 The general meaning of the passage, 'Noble, then, is the bond which
3533 links together sight...And of this kind I spoke as the intelligible...'
3534 so far as the thought contained in it admits of being translated
3535 into the terms of modern philosophy, may be described or explained as
3536 follows:--There is a truth, one and self-existent, to which by the help
3537 of a ladder let down from above, the human intelligence may ascend. This
3538 unity is like the sun in the heavens, the light by which all things are
3539 seen, the being by which they are created and sustained. It is the
3540 IDEA of good. And the steps of the ladder leading up to this highest or
3541 universal existence are the mathematical sciences, which also contain
3542 in themselves an element of the universal. These, too, we see in a new
3543 manner when we connect them with the idea of good. They then cease to
3544 be hypotheses or pictures, and become essential parts of a higher truth
3545 which is at once their first principle and their final cause.
3546 
3547 We cannot give any more precise meaning to this remarkable passage, but
3548 we may trace in it several rudiments or vestiges of thought which are
3549 common to us and to Plato: such as (1) the unity and correlation of the
3550 sciences, or rather of science, for in Plato's time they were not yet
3551 parted off or distinguished; (2) the existence of a Divine Power,
3552 or life or idea or cause or reason, not yet conceived or no longer
3553 conceived as in the Timaeus and elsewhere under the form of a person;
3554 (3) the recognition of the hypothetical and conditional character of the
3555 mathematical sciences, and in a measure of every science when isolated
3556 from the rest; (4) the conviction of a truth which is invisible, and of
3557 a law, though hardly a law of nature, which permeates the intellectual
3558 rather than the visible world.
3559 
3560 The method of Socrates is hesitating and tentative, awaiting the fuller
3561 explanation of the idea of good, and of the nature of dialectic in the
3562 seventh book. The imperfect intelligence of Glaucon, and the reluctance
3563 of Socrates to make a beginning, mark the difficulty of the subject.
3564 The allusion to Theages' bridle, and to the internal oracle, or demonic
3565 sign, of Socrates, which here, as always in Plato, is only prohibitory;
3566 the remark that the salvation of any remnant of good in the present evil
3567 state of the world is due to God only; the reference to a future state
3568 of existence, which is unknown to Glaucon in the tenth book, and in
3569 which the discussions of Socrates and his disciples would be resumed;
3570 the surprise in the answers; the fanciful irony of Socrates, where
3571 he pretends that he can only describe the strange position of the
3572 philosopher in a figure of speech; the original observation that the
3573 Sophists, after all, are only the representatives and not the leaders
3574 of public opinion; the picture of the philosopher standing aside in the
3575 shower of sleet under a wall; the figure of 'the great beast' followed
3576 by the expression of good-will towards the common people who would not
3577 have rejected the philosopher if they had known him; the 'right noble
3578 thought' that the highest truths demand the greatest exactness; the
3579 hesitation of Socrates in returning once more to his well-worn theme of
3580 the idea of good; the ludicrous earnestness of Glaucon; the comparison
3581 of philosophy to a deserted maiden who marries beneath her--are some of
3582 the most interesting characteristics of the sixth book.
3583 
3584 Yet a few more words may be added, on the old theme, which was so
3585 oft discussed in the Socratic circle, of which we, like Glaucon and
3586 Adeimantus, would fain, if possible, have a clearer notion. Like them,
3587 we are dissatisfied when we are told that the idea of good can only be
3588 revealed to a student of the mathematical sciences, and we are inclined
3589 to think that neither we nor they could have been led along that path to
3590 any satisfactory goal. For we have learned that differences of quantity
3591 cannot pass into differences of quality, and that the mathematical
3592 sciences can never rise above themselves into the sphere of our higher
3593 thoughts, although they may sometimes furnish symbols and expressions
3594 of them, and may train the mind in habits of abstraction and
3595 self-concentration. The illusion which was natural to an ancient
3596 philosopher has ceased to be an illusion to us. But if the process by
3597 which we are supposed to arrive at the idea of good be really imaginary,
3598 may not the idea itself be also a mere abstraction? We remark, first,
3599 that in all ages, and especially in primitive philosophy, words such
3600 as being, essence, unity, good, have exerted an extraordinary influence
3601 over the minds of men. The meagreness or negativeness of their content
3602 has been in an inverse ratio to their power. They have become the forms
3603 under which all things were comprehended. There was a need or instinct
3604 in the human soul which they satisfied; they were not ideas, but gods,
3605 and to this new mythology the men of a later generation began to attach
3606 the powers and associations of the elder deities.
3607 
3608 The idea of good is one of those sacred words or forms of thought, which
3609 were beginning to take the place of the old mythology. It meant unity,
3610 in which all time and all existence were gathered up. It was the truth
3611 of all things, and also the light in which they shone forth, and became
3612 evident to intelligences human and divine. It was the cause of all
3613 things, the power by which they were brought into being. It was the
3614 universal reason divested of a human personality. It was the life
3615 as well as the light of the world, all knowledge and all power were
3616 comprehended in it. The way to it was through the mathematical sciences,
3617 and these too were dependent on it. To ask whether God was the maker of
3618 it, or made by it, would be like asking whether God could be conceived
3619 apart from goodness, or goodness apart from God. The God of the Timaeus
3620 is not really at variance with the idea of good; they are aspects of
3621 the same, differing only as the personal from the impersonal, or the
3622 masculine from the neuter, the one being the expression or language of
3623 mythology, the other of philosophy.
3624 
3625 This, or something like this, is the meaning of the idea of good as
3626 conceived by Plato. Ideas of number, order, harmony, development may
3627 also be said to enter into it. The paraphrase which has just been given
3628 of it goes beyond the actual words of Plato. We have perhaps arrived at
3629 the stage of philosophy which enables us to understand what he is aiming
3630 at, better than he did himself. We are beginning to realize what he saw
3631 darkly and at a distance. But if he could have been told that this, or
3632 some conception of the same kind, but higher than this, was the truth
3633 at which he was aiming, and the need which he sought to supply, he would
3634 gladly have recognized that more was contained in his own thoughts
3635 than he himself knew. As his words are few and his manner reticent
3636 and tentative, so must the style of his interpreter be. We should not
3637 approach his meaning more nearly by attempting to define it further. In
3638 translating him into the language of modern thought, we might insensibly
3639 lose the spirit of ancient philosophy. It is remarkable that although
3640 Plato speaks of the idea of good as the first principle of truth and
3641 being, it is nowhere mentioned in his writings except in this passage.
3642 Nor did it retain any hold upon the minds of his disciples in a later
3643 generation; it was probably unintelligible to them. Nor does the mention
3644 of it in Aristotle appear to have any reference to this or any other
3645 passage in his extant writings.
3646 
3647 BOOK VII. And now I will describe in a figure the enlightenment or
3648 unenlightenment of our nature:--Imagine human beings living in an
3649 underground den which is open towards the light; they have been there
3650 from childhood, having their necks and legs chained, and can only see
3651 into the den. At a distance there is a fire, and between the fire and
3652 the prisoners a raised way, and a low wall is built along the way, like
3653 the screen over which marionette players show their puppets. Behind the
3654 wall appear moving figures, who hold in their hands various works of
3655 art, and among them images of men and animals, wood and stone, and some
3656 of the passers-by are talking and others silent. 'A strange parable,'
3657 he said, 'and strange captives.' They are ourselves, I replied; and they
3658 see only the shadows of the images which the fire throws on the wall of
3659 the den; to these they give names, and if we add an echo which returns
3660 from the wall, the voices of the passengers will seem to proceed from
3661 the shadows. Suppose now that you suddenly turn them round and make them
3662 look with pain and grief to themselves at the real images; will they
3663 believe them to be real? Will not their eyes be dazzled, and will they
3664 not try to get away from the light to something which they are able to
3665 behold without blinking? And suppose further, that they are dragged up
3666 a steep and rugged ascent into the presence of the sun himself, will not
3667 their sight be darkened with the excess of light? Some time will pass
3668 before they get the habit of perceiving at all; and at first they will
3669 be able to perceive only shadows and reflections in the water; then they
3670 will recognize the moon and the stars, and will at length behold the sun
3671 in his own proper place as he is. Last of all they will conclude:--This
3672 is he who gives us the year and the seasons, and is the author of all
3673 that we see. How will they rejoice in passing from darkness to light!
3674 How worthless to them will seem the honours and glories of the den! But
3675 now imagine further, that they descend into their old habitations;--in
3676 that underground dwelling they will not see as well as their fellows,
3677 and will not be able to compete with them in the measurement of the
3678 shadows on the wall; there will be many jokes about the man who went on
3679 a visit to the sun and lost his eyes, and if they find anybody trying to
3680 set free and enlighten one of their number, they will put him to death,
3681 if they can catch him. Now the cave or den is the world of sight, the
3682 fire is the sun, the way upwards is the way to knowledge, and in the
3683 world of knowledge the idea of good is last seen and with difficulty,
3684 but when seen is inferred to be the author of good and right--parent of
3685 the lord of light in this world, and of truth and understanding in the
3686 other. He who attains to the beatific vision is always going upwards; he
3687 is unwilling to descend into political assemblies and courts of law; for
3688 his eyes are apt to blink at the images or shadows of images which they
3689 behold in them--he cannot enter into the ideas of those who have never
3690 in their lives understood the relation of the shadow to the substance.
3691 But blindness is of two kinds, and may be caused either by passing out
3692 of darkness into light or out of light into darkness, and a man of sense
3693 will distinguish between them, and will not laugh equally at both of
3694 them, but the blindness which arises from fulness of light he will deem
3695 blessed, and pity the other; or if he laugh at the puzzled soul looking
3696 at the sun, he will have more reason to laugh than the inhabitants
3697 of the den at those who descend from above. There is a further lesson
3698 taught by this parable of ours. Some persons fancy that instruction is
3699 like giving eyes to the blind, but we say that the faculty of sight was
3700 always there, and that the soul only requires to be turned round towards
3701 the light. And this is conversion; other virtues are almost like bodily
3702 habits, and may be acquired in the same manner, but intelligence has
3703 a diviner life, and is indestructible, turning either to good or evil
3704 according to the direction given. Did you never observe how the mind of
3705 a clever rogue peers out of his eyes, and the more clearly he sees, the
3706 more evil he does? Now if you take such an one, and cut away from him
3707 those leaden weights of pleasure and desire which bind his soul to
3708 earth, his intelligence will be turned round, and he will behold the
3709 truth as clearly as he now discerns his meaner ends. And have we not
3710 decided that our rulers must neither be so uneducated as to have no
3711 fixed rule of life, nor so over-educated as to be unwilling to leave
3712 their paradise for the business of the world? We must choose out
3713 therefore the natures who are most likely to ascend to the light and
3714 knowledge of the good; but we must not allow them to remain in the
3715 region of light; they must be forced down again among the captives in
3716 the den to partake of their labours and honours. 'Will they not think
3717 this a hardship?' You should remember that our purpose in framing the
3718 State was not that our citizens should do what they like, but that they
3719 should serve the State for the common good of all. May we not fairly
3720 say to our philosopher,--Friend, we do you no wrong; for in other States
3721 philosophy grows wild, and a wild plant owes nothing to the gardener,
3722 but you have been trained by us to be the rulers and kings of our hive,
3723 and therefore we must insist on your descending into the den. You must,
3724 each of you, take your turn, and become able to use your eyes in the
3725 dark, and with a little practice you will see far better than those who
3726 quarrel about the shadows, whose knowledge is a dream only, whilst yours
3727 is a waking reality. It may be that the saint or philosopher who is best
3728 fitted, may also be the least inclined to rule, but necessity is laid
3729 upon him, and he must no longer live in the heaven of ideas. And this
3730 will be the salvation of the State. For those who rule must not be those
3731 who are desirous to rule; and, if you can offer to our citizens a better
3732 life than that of rulers generally is, there will be a chance that the
3733 rich, not only in this world's goods, but in virtue and wisdom, may
3734 bear rule. And the only life which is better than the life of political
3735 ambition is that of philosophy, which is also the best preparation for
3736 the government of a State.
3737 
3738 Then now comes the question,--How shall we create our rulers; what way
3739 is there from darkness to light? The change is effected by philosophy;
3740 it is not the turning over of an oyster-shell, but the conversion of a
3741 soul from night to day, from becoming to being. And what training will
3742 draw the soul upwards? Our former education had two branches, gymnastic,
3743 which was occupied with the body, and music, the sister art, which
3744 infused a natural harmony into mind and literature; but neither of these
3745 sciences gave any promise of doing what we want. Nothing remains to us
3746 but that universal or primary science of which all the arts and sciences
3747 are partakers, I mean number or calculation. 'Very true.' Including the
3748 art of war? 'Yes, certainly.' Then there is something ludicrous about
3749 Palamedes in the tragedy, coming in and saying that he had invented
3750 number, and had counted the ranks and set them in order. For if
3751 Agamemnon could not count his feet (and without number how could he?)
3752 he must have been a pretty sort of general indeed. No man should be a
3753 soldier who cannot count, and indeed he is hardly to be called a man.
3754 But I am not speaking of these practical applications of arithmetic, for
3755 number, in my view, is rather to be regarded as a conductor to thought
3756 and being. I will explain what I mean by the last expression:--Things
3757 sensible are of two kinds; the one class invite or stimulate the mind,
3758 while in the other the mind acquiesces. Now the stimulating class are
3759 the things which suggest contrast and relation. For example, suppose
3760 that I hold up to the eyes three fingers--a fore finger, a middle
3761 finger, a little finger--the sight equally recognizes all three fingers,
3762 but without number cannot further distinguish them. Or again, suppose
3763 two objects to be relatively great and small, these ideas of greatness
3764 and smallness are supplied not by the sense, but by the mind. And the
3765 perception of their contrast or relation quickens and sets in motion
3766 the mind, which is puzzled by the confused intimations of sense, and has
3767 recourse to number in order to find out whether the things indicated are
3768 one or more than one. Number replies that they are two and not one, and
3769 are to be distinguished from one another. Again, the sight beholds
3770 great and small, but only in a confused chaos, and not until they are
3771 distinguished does the question arise of their respective natures; we
3772 are thus led on to the distinction between the visible and intelligible.
3773 That was what I meant when I spoke of stimulants to the intellect; I was
3774 thinking of the contradictions which arise in perception. The idea
3775 of unity, for example, like that of a finger, does not arouse thought
3776 unless involving some conception of plurality; but when the one is also
3777 the opposite of one, the contradiction gives rise to reflection; an
3778 example of this is afforded by any object of sight. All number has also
3779 an elevating effect; it raises the mind out of the foam and flux of
3780 generation to the contemplation of being, having lesser military and
3781 retail uses also. The retail use is not required by us; but as our
3782 guardian is to be a soldier as well as a philosopher, the military one
3783 may be retained. And to our higher purpose no science can be better
3784 adapted; but it must be pursued in the spirit of a philosopher, not of a
3785 shopkeeper. It is concerned, not with visible objects, but with abstract
3786 truth; for numbers are pure abstractions--the true arithmetician
3787 indignantly denies that his unit is capable of division. When you
3788 divide, he insists that you are only multiplying; his 'one' is not
3789 material or resolvable into fractions, but an unvarying and absolute
3790 equality; and this proves the purely intellectual character of his
3791 study. Note also the great power which arithmetic has of sharpening the
3792 wits; no other discipline is equally severe, or an equal test of general
3793 ability, or equally improving to a stupid person.
3794 
3795 Let our second branch of education be geometry. 'I can easily see,'
3796 replied Glaucon, 'that the skill of the general will be doubled by his
3797 knowledge of geometry.' That is a small matter; the use of geometry, to
3798 which I refer, is the assistance given by it in the contemplation of the
3799 idea of good, and the compelling the mind to look at true being, and not
3800 at generation only. Yet the present mode of pursuing these studies,
3801 as any one who is the least of a mathematician is aware, is mean and
3802 ridiculous; they are made to look downwards to the arts, and not upwards
3803 to eternal existence. The geometer is always talking of squaring,
3804 subtending, apposing, as if he had in view action; whereas knowledge is
3805 the real object of the study. It should elevate the soul, and create
3806 the mind of philosophy; it should raise up what has fallen down, not to
3807 speak of lesser uses in war and military tactics, and in the improvement
3808 of the faculties.
3809 
3810 Shall we propose, as a third branch of our education, astronomy? 'Very
3811 good,' replied Glaucon; 'the knowledge of the heavens is necessary at
3812 once for husbandry, navigation, military tactics.' I like your way of
3813 giving useful reasons for everything in order to make friends of the
3814 world. And there is a difficulty in proving to mankind that education is
3815 not only useful information but a purification of the eye of the soul,
3816 which is better than the bodily eye, for by this alone is truth seen.
3817 Now, will you appeal to mankind in general or to the philosopher? or
3818 would you prefer to look to yourself only? 'Every man is his own best
3819 friend.' Then take a step backward, for we are out of order, and insert
3820 the third dimension which is of solids, after the second which is of
3821 planes, and then you may proceed to solids in motion. But solid geometry
3822 is not popular and has not the patronage of the State, nor is the use
3823 of it fully recognized; the difficulty is great, and the votaries of the
3824 study are conceited and impatient. Still the charm of the pursuit wins
3825 upon men, and, if government would lend a little assistance, there
3826 might be great progress made. 'Very true,' replied Glaucon; 'but do
3827 I understand you now to begin with plane geometry, and to place next
3828 geometry of solids, and thirdly, astronomy, or the motion of solids?'
3829 Yes, I said; my hastiness has only hindered us.
3830 
3831 'Very good, and now let us proceed to astronomy, about which I am
3832 willing to speak in your lofty strain. No one can fail to see that the
3833 contemplation of the heavens draws the soul upwards.' I am an exception,
3834 then; astronomy as studied at present appears to me to draw the soul
3835 not upwards, but downwards. Star-gazing is just looking up at the
3836 ceiling--no better; a man may lie on his back on land or on water--he
3837 may look up or look down, but there is no science in that. The vision of
3838 knowledge of which I speak is seen not with the eyes, but with the mind.
3839 All the magnificence of the heavens is but the embroidery of a copy
3840 which falls far short of the divine Original, and teaches nothing about
3841 the absolute harmonies or motions of things. Their beauty is like the
3842 beauty of figures drawn by the hand of Daedalus or any other great
3843 artist, which may be used for illustration, but no mathematician would
3844 seek to obtain from them true conceptions of equality or numerical
3845 relations. How ridiculous then to look for these in the map of the
3846 heavens, in which the imperfection of matter comes in everywhere as a
3847 disturbing element, marring the symmetry of day and night, of months and
3848 years, of the sun and stars in their courses. Only by problems can we
3849 place astronomy on a truly scientific basis. Let the heavens alone, and
3850 exert the intellect.
3851 
3852 Still, mathematics admit of other applications, as the Pythagoreans say,
3853 and we agree. There is a sister science of harmonical motion, adapted to
3854 the ear as astronomy is to the eye, and there may be other applications
3855 also. Let us inquire of the Pythagoreans about them, not forgetting
3856 that we have an aim higher than theirs, which is the relation of these
3857 sciences to the idea of good. The error which pervades astronomy also
3858 pervades harmonics. The musicians put their ears in the place of their
3859 minds. 'Yes,' replied Glaucon, 'I like to see them laying their ears
3860 alongside of their neighbours' faces--some saying, "That's a new note,"
3861 others declaring that the two notes are the same.' Yes, I said; but you
3862 mean the empirics who are always twisting and torturing the strings
3863 of the lyre, and quarrelling about the tempers of the strings; I am
3864 referring rather to the Pythagorean harmonists, who are almost equally
3865 in error. For they investigate only the numbers of the consonances which
3866 are heard, and ascend no higher,--of the true numerical harmony which
3867 is unheard, and is only to be found in problems, they have not even a
3868 conception. 'That last,' he said, 'must be a marvellous thing.' A thing,
3869 I replied, which is only useful if pursued with a view to the good.
3870 
3871 All these sciences are the prelude of the strain, and are profitable
3872 if they are regarded in their natural relations to one another. 'I
3873 dare say, Socrates,' said Glaucon; 'but such a study will be an endless
3874 business.' What study do you mean--of the prelude, or what? For all
3875 these things are only the prelude, and you surely do not suppose that a
3876 mere mathematician is also a dialectician? 'Certainly not. I have hardly
3877 ever known a mathematician who could reason.' And yet, Glaucon, is
3878 not true reasoning that hymn of dialectic which is the music of the
3879 intellectual world, and which was by us compared to the effort of sight,
3880 when from beholding the shadows on the wall we arrived at last at
3881 the images which gave the shadows? Even so the dialectical faculty
3882 withdrawing from sense arrives by the pure intellect at the
3883 contemplation of the idea of good, and never rests but at the very end
3884 of the intellectual world. And the royal road out of the cave into
3885 the light, and the blinking of the eyes at the sun and turning to
3886 contemplate the shadows of reality, not the shadows of an image
3887 only--this progress and gradual acquisition of a new faculty of sight by
3888 the help of the mathematical sciences, is the elevation of the soul to
3889 the contemplation of the highest ideal of being.
3890 
3891 'So far, I agree with you. But now, leaving the prelude, let us proceed
3892 to the hymn. What, then, is the nature of dialectic, and what are the
3893 paths which lead thither?' Dear Glaucon, you cannot follow me here.
3894 There can be no revelation of the absolute truth to one who has not been
3895 disciplined in the previous sciences. But that there is a science of
3896 absolute truth, which is attained in some way very different from
3897 those now practised, I am confident. For all other arts or sciences are
3898 relative to human needs and opinions; and the mathematical sciences are
3899 but a dream or hypothesis of true being, and never analyse their own
3900 principles. Dialectic alone rises to the principle which is above
3901 hypotheses, converting and gently leading the eye of the soul out of the
3902 barbarous slough of ignorance into the light of the upper world, with
3903 the help of the sciences which we have been describing--sciences, as
3904 they are often termed, although they require some other name, implying
3905 greater clearness than opinion and less clearness than science, and this
3906 in our previous sketch was understanding. And so we get four names--two
3907 for intellect, and two for opinion,--reason or mind, understanding,
3908 faith, perception of shadows--which make a proportion--
3909 being:becoming::intellect:opinion--and science:belief::understanding:
3910 perception of shadows. Dialectic may be further described as that
3911 science which defines and explains the essence or being of each nature,
3912 which distinguishes and abstracts the good, and is ready to do battle
3913 against all opponents in the cause of good. To him who is not a
3914 dialectician life is but a sleepy dream; and many a man is in his grave
3915 before his is well waked up. And would you have the future rulers of
3916 your ideal State intelligent beings, or stupid as posts? 'Certainly not
3917 the latter.' Then you must train them in dialectic, which will teach
3918 them to ask and answer questions, and is the coping-stone of the
3919 sciences.
3920 
3921 I dare say that you have not forgotten how our rulers were chosen; and
3922 the process of selection may be carried a step further:--As before, they
3923 must be constant and valiant, good-looking, and of noble manners, but
3924 now they must also have natural ability which education will improve;
3925 that is to say, they must be quick at learning, capable of mental toil,
3926 retentive, solid, diligent natures, who combine intellectual with
3927 moral virtues; not lame and one-sided, diligent in bodily exercise
3928 and indolent in mind, or conversely; not a maimed soul, which hates
3929 falsehood and yet unintentionally is always wallowing in the mire of
3930 ignorance; not a bastard or feeble person, but sound in wind and limb,
3931 and in perfect condition for the great gymnastic trial of the mind.
3932 Justice herself can find no fault with natures such as these; and they
3933 will be the saviours of our State; disciples of another sort would
3934 only make philosophy more ridiculous than she is at present. Forgive
3935 my enthusiasm; I am becoming excited; but when I see her trampled
3936 underfoot, I am angry at the authors of her disgrace. 'I did not notice
3937 that you were more excited than you ought to have been.' But I felt that
3938 I was. Now do not let us forget another point in the selection of our
3939 disciples--that they must be young and not old. For Solon is mistaken
3940 in saying that an old man can be always learning; youth is the time of
3941 study, and here we must remember that the mind is free and dainty, and,
3942 unlike the body, must not be made to work against the grain. Learning
3943 should be at first a sort of play, in which the natural bent is
3944 detected. As in training them for war, the young dogs should at first
3945 only taste blood; but when the necessary gymnastics are over which
3946 during two or three years divide life between sleep and bodily exercise,
3947 then the education of the soul will become a more serious matter. At
3948 twenty years of age, a selection must be made of the more promising
3949 disciples, with whom a new epoch of education will begin. The sciences
3950 which they have hitherto learned in fragments will now be brought into
3951 relation with each other and with true being; for the power of combining
3952 them is the test of speculative and dialectical ability. And afterwards
3953 at thirty a further selection shall be made of those who are able to
3954 withdraw from the world of sense into the abstraction of ideas. But
3955 at this point, judging from present experience, there is a danger that
3956 dialectic may be the source of many evils. The danger may be illustrated
3957 by a parallel case:--Imagine a person who has been brought up in wealth
3958 and luxury amid a crowd of flatterers, and who is suddenly informed that
3959 he is a supposititious son. He has hitherto honoured his reputed parents
3960 and disregarded the flatterers, and now he does the reverse. This is
3961 just what happens with a man's principles. There are certain doctrines
3962 which he learnt at home and which exercised a parental authority
3963 over him. Presently he finds that imputations are cast upon them; a
3964 troublesome querist comes and asks, 'What is the just and good?'
3965 or proves that virtue is vice and vice virtue, and his mind becomes
3966 unsettled, and he ceases to love, honour, and obey them as he has
3967 hitherto done. He is seduced into the life of pleasure, and becomes
3968 a lawless person and a rogue. The case of such speculators is very
3969 pitiable, and, in order that our thirty years' old pupils may not
3970 require this pity, let us take every possible care that young persons do
3971 not study philosophy too early. For a young man is a sort of puppy
3972 who only plays with an argument; and is reasoned into and out of his
3973 opinions every day; he soon begins to believe nothing, and brings
3974 himself and philosophy into discredit. A man of thirty does not run
3975 on in this way; he will argue and not merely contradict, and adds new
3976 honour to philosophy by the sobriety of his conduct. What time shall we
3977 allow for this second gymnastic training of the soul?--say, twice the
3978 time required for the gymnastics of the body; six, or perhaps five
3979 years, to commence at thirty, and then for fifteen years let the student
3980 go down into the den, and command armies, and gain experience of life.
3981 At fifty let him return to the end of all things, and have his eyes
3982 uplifted to the idea of good, and order his life after that pattern; if
3983 necessary, taking his turn at the helm of State, and training up others
3984 to be his successors. When his time comes he shall depart in peace to
3985 the islands of the blest. He shall be honoured with sacrifices, and
3986 receive such worship as the Pythian oracle approves.
3987 
3988 'You are a statuary, Socrates, and have made a perfect image of our
3989 governors.' Yes, and of our governesses, for the women will share in
3990 all things with the men. And you will admit that our State is not a
3991 mere aspiration, but may really come into being when there shall arise
3992 philosopher-kings, one or more, who will despise earthly vanities, and
3993 will be the servants of justice only. 'And how will they begin their
3994 work?' Their first act will be to send away into the country all those
3995 who are more than ten years of age, and to proceed with those who are
3996 left...
3997 
3998 At the commencement of the sixth book, Plato anticipated his explanation
3999 of the relation of the philosopher to the world in an allegory, in
4000 this, as in other passages, following the order which he prescribes
4001 in education, and proceeding from the concrete to the abstract. At the
4002 commencement of Book VII, under the figure of a cave having an opening
4003 towards a fire and a way upwards to the true light, he returns to view
4004 the divisions of knowledge, exhibiting familiarly, as in a picture, the
4005 result which had been hardly won by a great effort of thought in the
4006 previous discussion; at the same time casting a glance onward at the
4007 dialectical process, which is represented by the way leading from
4008 darkness to light. The shadows, the images, the reflection of the
4009 sun and stars in the water, the stars and sun themselves, severally
4010 correspond,--the first, to the realm of fancy and poetry,--the second,
4011 to the world of sense,--the third, to the abstractions or universals of
4012 sense, of which the mathematical sciences furnish the type,--the fourth
4013 and last to the same abstractions, when seen in the unity of the idea,
4014 from which they derive a new meaning and power. The true dialectical
4015 process begins with the contemplation of the real stars, and not mere
4016 reflections of them, and ends with the recognition of the sun, or idea
4017 of good, as the parent not only of light but of warmth and growth.
4018 To the divisions of knowledge the stages of education partly
4019 answer:--first, there is the early education of childhood and youth
4020 in the fancies of the poets, and in the laws and customs of the
4021 State;--then there is the training of the body to be a warrior athlete,
4022 and a good servant of the mind;--and thirdly, after an interval follows
4023 the education of later life, which begins with mathematics and proceeds
4024 to philosophy in general.
4025 
4026 There seem to be two great aims in the philosophy of Plato,--first, to
4027 realize abstractions; secondly, to connect them. According to him, the
4028 true education is that which draws men from becoming to being, and to
4029 a comprehensive survey of all being. He desires to develop in the human
4030 mind the faculty of seeing the universal in all things; until at last
4031 the particulars of sense drop away and the universal alone remains. He
4032 then seeks to combine the universals which he has disengaged from sense,
4033 not perceiving that the correlation of them has no other basis but the
4034 common use of language. He never understands that abstractions, as Hegel
4035 says, are 'mere abstractions'--of use when employed in the arrangement
4036 of facts, but adding nothing to the sum of knowledge when pursued apart
4037 from them, or with reference to an imaginary idea of good. Still the
4038 exercise of the faculty of abstraction apart from facts has enlarged the
4039 mind, and played a great part in the education of the human race.
4040 Plato appreciated the value of this faculty, and saw that it might be
4041 quickened by the study of number and relation. All things in which
4042 there is opposition or proportion are suggestive of reflection. The
4043 mere impression of sense evokes no power of thought or of mind, but when
4044 sensible objects ask to be compared and distinguished, then philosophy
4045 begins. The science of arithmetic first suggests such distinctions. The
4046 follow in order the other sciences of plain and solid geometry, and of
4047 solids in motion, one branch of which is astronomy or the harmony of
4048 the spheres,--to this is appended the sister science of the harmony
4049 of sounds. Plato seems also to hint at the possibility of other
4050 applications of arithmetical or mathematical proportions, such as we
4051 employ in chemistry and natural philosophy, such as the Pythagoreans and
4052 even Aristotle make use of in Ethics and Politics, e.g. his distinction
4053 between arithmetical and geometrical proportion in the Ethics (Book V),
4054 or between numerical and proportional equality in the Politics.
4055 
4056 The modern mathematician will readily sympathise with Plato's delight
4057 in the properties of pure mathematics. He will not be disinclined to say
4058 with him:--Let alone the heavens, and study the beauties of number and
4059 figure in themselves. He too will be apt to depreciate their application
4060 to the arts. He will observe that Plato has a conception of geometry,
4061 in which figures are to be dispensed with; thus in a distant and
4062 shadowy way seeming to anticipate the possibility of working geometrical
4063 problems by a more general mode of analysis. He will remark with
4064 interest on the backward state of solid geometry, which, alas! was not
4065 encouraged by the aid of the State in the age of Plato; and he will
4066 recognize the grasp of Plato's mind in his ability to conceive of
4067 one science of solids in motion including the earth as well as the
4068 heavens,--not forgetting to notice the intimation to which allusion has
4069 been already made, that besides astronomy and harmonics the science
4070 of solids in motion may have other applications. Still more will he be
4071 struck with the comprehensiveness of view which led Plato, at a time
4072 when these sciences hardly existed, to say that they must be studied in
4073 relation to one another, and to the idea of good, or common principle
4074 of truth and being. But he will also see (and perhaps without surprise)
4075 that in that stage of physical and mathematical knowledge, Plato has
4076 fallen into the error of supposing that he can construct the heavens a
4077 priori by mathematical problems, and determine the principles of harmony
4078 irrespective of the adaptation of sounds to the human ear. The illusion
4079 was a natural one in that age and country. The simplicity and certainty
4080 of astronomy and harmonics seemed to contrast with the variation and
4081 complexity of the world of sense; hence the circumstance that there was
4082 some elementary basis of fact, some measurement of distance or time or
4083 vibrations on which they must ultimately rest, was overlooked by him.
4084 The modern predecessors of Newton fell into errors equally great; and
4085 Plato can hardly be said to have been very far wrong, or may even claim
4086 a sort of prophetic insight into the subject, when we consider that
4087 the greater part of astronomy at the present day consists of abstract
4088 dynamics, by the help of which most astronomical discoveries have been
4089 made.
4090 
4091 The metaphysical philosopher from his point of view recognizes
4092 mathematics as an instrument of education,--which strengthens the
4093 power of attention, developes the sense of order and the faculty of
4094 construction, and enables the mind to grasp under simple formulae the
4095 quantitative differences of physical phenomena. But while acknowledging
4096 their value in education, he sees also that they have no connexion with
4097 our higher moral and intellectual ideas. In the attempt which Plato
4098 makes to connect them, we easily trace the influences of ancient
4099 Pythagorean notions. There is no reason to suppose that he is speaking
4100 of the ideal numbers; but he is describing numbers which are pure
4101 abstractions, to which he assigns a real and separate existence, which,
4102 as 'the teachers of the art' (meaning probably the Pythagoreans) would
4103 have affirmed, repel all attempts at subdivision, and in which unity and
4104 every other number are conceived of as absolute. The truth and certainty
4105 of numbers, when thus disengaged from phenomena, gave them a kind of
4106 sacredness in the eyes of an ancient philosopher. Nor is it easy to say
4107 how far ideas of order and fixedness may have had a moral and elevating
4108 influence on the minds of men, 'who,' in the words of the Timaeus,
4109 'might learn to regulate their erring lives according to them.' It is
4110 worthy of remark that the old Pythagorean ethical symbols still exist as
4111 figures of speech among ourselves. And those who in modern times see the
4112 world pervaded by universal law, may also see an anticipation of this
4113 last word of modern philosophy in the Platonic idea of good, which
4114 is the source and measure of all things, and yet only an abstraction
4115 (Philebus).
4116 
4117 Two passages seem to require more particular explanations. First, that
4118 which relates to the analysis of vision. The difficulty in this passage
4119 may be explained, like many others, from differences in the modes of
4120 conception prevailing among ancient and modern thinkers. To us, the
4121 perceptions of sense are inseparable from the act of the mind which
4122 accompanies them. The consciousness of form, colour, distance, is
4123 indistinguishable from the simple sensation, which is the medium of
4124 them. Whereas to Plato sense is the Heraclitean flux of sense, not the
4125 vision of objects in the order in which they actually present themselves
4126 to the experienced sight, but as they may be imagined to appear confused
4127 and blurred to the half-awakened eye of the infant. The first action of
4128 the mind is aroused by the attempt to set in order this chaos, and
4129 the reason is required to frame distinct conceptions under which
4130 the confused impressions of sense may be arranged. Hence arises
4131 the question, 'What is great, what is small?' and thus begins the
4132 distinction of the visible and the intelligible.
4133 
4134 The second difficulty relates to Plato's conception of harmonics.
4135 Three classes of harmonists are distinguished by him:--first, the
4136 Pythagoreans, whom he proposes to consult as in the previous discussion
4137 on music he was to consult Damon--they are acknowledged to be masters
4138 in the art, but are altogether deficient in the knowledge of its higher
4139 import and relation to the good; secondly, the mere empirics, whom
4140 Glaucon appears to confuse with them, and whom both he and Socrates
4141 ludicrously describe as experimenting by mere auscultation on the
4142 intervals of sounds. Both of these fall short in different degrees of
4143 the Platonic idea of harmony, which must be studied in a purely
4144 abstract way, first by the method of problems, and secondly as a part of
4145 universal knowledge in relation to the idea of good.
4146 
4147 The allegory has a political as well as a philosophical meaning. The
4148 den or cave represents the narrow sphere of politics or law (compare the
4149 description of the philosopher and lawyer in the Theaetetus), and
4150 the light of the eternal ideas is supposed to exercise a disturbing
4151 influence on the minds of those who return to this lower world. In other
4152 words, their principles are too wide for practical application; they are
4153 looking far away into the past and future, when their business is with
4154 the present. The ideal is not easily reduced to the conditions of actual
4155 life, and may often be at variance with them. And at first, those who
4156 return are unable to compete with the inhabitants of the den in the
4157 measurement of the shadows, and are derided and persecuted by them; but
4158 after a while they see the things below in far truer proportions than
4159 those who have never ascended into the upper world. The difference
4160 between the politician turned into a philosopher and the philosopher
4161 turned into a politician, is symbolized by the two kinds of disordered
4162 eyesight, the one which is experienced by the captive who is transferred
4163 from darkness to day, the other, of the heavenly messenger who
4164 voluntarily for the good of his fellow-men descends into the den. In
4165 what way the brighter light is to dawn on the inhabitants of the lower
4166 world, or how the idea of good is to become the guiding principle of
4167 politics, is left unexplained by Plato. Like the nature and divisions of
4168 dialectic, of which Glaucon impatiently demands to be informed, perhaps
4169 he would have said that the explanation could not be given except to a
4170 disciple of the previous sciences. (Symposium.)
4171 
4172 Many illustrations of this part of the Republic may be found in modern
4173 Politics and in daily life. For among ourselves, too, there have
4174 been two sorts of Politicians or Statesmen, whose eyesight has become
4175 disordered in two different ways. First, there have been great men who,
4176 in the language of Burke, 'have been too much given to general
4177 maxims,' who, like J.S. Mill or Burke himself, have been theorists or
4178 philosophers before they were politicians, or who, having been students
4179 of history, have allowed some great historical parallel, such as the
4180 English Revolution of 1688, or possibly Athenian democracy or Roman
4181 Imperialism, to be the medium through which they viewed contemporary
4182 events. Or perhaps the long projecting shadow of some existing
4183 institution may have darkened their vision. The Church of the future,
4184 the Commonwealth of the future, the Society of the future, have
4185 so absorbed their minds, that they are unable to see in their true
4186 proportions the Politics of to-day. They have been intoxicated with
4187 great ideas, such as liberty, or equality, or the greatest happiness of
4188 the greatest number, or the brotherhood of humanity, and they no
4189 longer care to consider how these ideas must be limited in practice or
4190 harmonized with the conditions of human life. They are full of light,
4191 but the light to them has become only a sort of luminous mist or
4192 blindness. Almost every one has known some enthusiastic half-educated
4193 person, who sees everything at false distances, and in erroneous
4194 proportions.
4195 
4196 With this disorder of eyesight may be contrasted another--of those who
4197 see not far into the distance, but what is near only; who have been
4198 engaged all their lives in a trade or a profession; who are limited to
4199 a set or sect of their own. Men of this kind have no universal except
4200 their own interests or the interests of their class, no principle but
4201 the opinion of persons like themselves, no knowledge of affairs beyond
4202 what they pick up in the streets or at their club. Suppose them to be
4203 sent into a larger world, to undertake some higher calling, from being
4204 tradesmen to turn generals or politicians, from being schoolmasters to
4205 become philosophers:--or imagine them on a sudden to receive an inward
4206 light which reveals to them for the first time in their lives a higher
4207 idea of God and the existence of a spiritual world, by this sudden
4208 conversion or change is not their daily life likely to be upset; and on
4209 the other hand will not many of their old prejudices and narrownesses
4210 still adhere to them long after they have begun to take a more
4211 comprehensive view of human things? From familiar examples like these we
4212 may learn what Plato meant by the eyesight which is liable to two kinds
4213 of disorders.
4214 
4215 Nor have we any difficulty in drawing a parallel between the young
4216 Athenian in the fifth century before Christ who became unsettled by new
4217 ideas, and the student of a modern University who has been the subject
4218 of a similar 'aufklarung.' We too observe that when young men begin to
4219 criticise customary beliefs, or to analyse the constitution of human
4220 nature, they are apt to lose hold of solid principle (Greek). They are
4221 like trees which have been frequently transplanted. The earth about them
4222 is loose, and they have no roots reaching far into the soil. They 'light
4223 upon every flower,' following their own wayward wills, or because the
4224 wind blows them. They catch opinions, as diseases are caught--when
4225 they are in the air. Borne hither and thither, 'they speedily fall
4226 into beliefs' the opposite of those in which they were brought up. They
4227 hardly retain the distinction of right and wrong; they seem to think one
4228 thing as good as another. They suppose themselves to be searching after
4229 truth when they are playing the game of 'follow my leader.' They fall
4230 in love 'at first sight' with paradoxes respecting morality, some fancy
4231 about art, some novelty or eccentricity in religion, and like lovers
4232 they are so absorbed for a time in their new notion that they can think
4233 of nothing else. The resolution of some philosophical or theological
4234 question seems to them more interesting and important than any
4235 substantial knowledge of literature or science or even than a good life.
4236 Like the youth in the Philebus, they are ready to discourse to any one
4237 about a new philosophy. They are generally the disciples of some eminent
4238 professor or sophist, whom they rather imitate than understand. They may
4239 be counted happy if in later years they retain some of the simple truths
4240 which they acquired in early education, and which they may, perhaps,
4241 find to be worth all the rest. Such is the picture which Plato draws and
4242 which we only reproduce, partly in his own words, of the dangers which
4243 beset youth in times of transition, when old opinions are fading
4244 away and the new are not yet firmly established. Their condition is
4245 ingeniously compared by him to that of a supposititious son, who has
4246 made the discovery that his reputed parents are not his real ones, and,
4247 in consequence, they have lost their authority over him.
4248 
4249 The distinction between the mathematician and the dialectician is
4250 also noticeable. Plato is very well aware that the faculty of the
4251 mathematician is quite distinct from the higher philosophical sense
4252 which recognizes and combines first principles. The contempt which
4253 he expresses for distinctions of words, the danger of involuntary
4254 falsehood, the apology which Socrates makes for his earnestness of
4255 speech, are highly characteristic of the Platonic style and mode of
4256 thought. The quaint notion that if Palamedes was the inventor of number
4257 Agamemnon could not have counted his feet; the art by which we are made
4258 to believe that this State of ours is not a dream only; the gravity
4259 with which the first step is taken in the actual creation of the State,
4260 namely, the sending out of the city all who had arrived at ten years of
4261 age, in order to expedite the business of education by a generation, are
4262 also truly Platonic. (For the last, compare the passage at the end of
4263 the third book, in which he expects the lie about the earthborn men to
4264 be believed in the second generation.)
4265 
4266 BOOK VIII. And so we have arrived at the conclusion, that in the perfect
4267 State wives and children are to be in common; and the education and
4268 pursuits of men and women, both in war and peace, are to be common, and
4269 kings are to be philosophers and warriors, and the soldiers of the State
4270 are to live together, having all things in common; and they are to be
4271 warrior athletes, receiving no pay but only their food, from the other
4272 citizens. Now let us return to the point at which we digressed. 'That is
4273 easily done,' he replied: 'You were speaking of the State which you had
4274 constructed, and of the individual who answered to this, both of whom
4275 you affirmed to be good; and you said that of inferior States there were
4276 four forms and four individuals corresponding to them, which although
4277 deficient in various degrees, were all of them worth inspecting with
4278 a view to determining the relative happiness or misery of the best or
4279 worst man. Then Polemarchus and Adeimantus interrupted you, and this led
4280 to another argument,--and so here we are.' Suppose that we put ourselves
4281 again in the same position, and do you repeat your question. 'I should
4282 like to know of what constitutions you were speaking?' Besides the
4283 perfect State there are only four of any note in Hellas:--first, the
4284 famous Lacedaemonian or Cretan commonwealth; secondly, oligarchy, a
4285 State full of evils; thirdly, democracy, which follows next in order;
4286 fourthly, tyranny, which is the disease or death of all government.
4287 Now, States are not made of 'oak and rock,' but of flesh and blood; and
4288 therefore as there are five States there must be five human natures in
4289 individuals, which correspond to them. And first, there is the ambitious
4290 nature, which answers to the Lacedaemonian State; secondly, the
4291 oligarchical nature; thirdly, the democratical; and fourthly, the
4292 tyrannical. This last will have to be compared with the perfectly just,
4293 which is the fifth, that we may know which is the happier, and then we
4294 shall be able to determine whether the argument of Thrasymachus or our
4295 own is the more convincing. And as before we began with the State and
4296 went on to the individual, so now, beginning with timocracy, let us
4297 go on to the timocratical man, and then proceed to the other forms of
4298 government, and the individuals who answer to them.
4299 
4300 But how did timocracy arise out of the perfect State? Plainly, like
4301 all changes of government, from division in the rulers. But whence came
4302 division? 'Sing, heavenly Muses,' as Homer says;--let them condescend to
4303 answer us, as if we were children, to whom they put on a solemn face
4304 in jest. 'And what will they say?' They will say that human things are
4305 fated to decay, and even the perfect State will not escape from this
4306 law of destiny, when 'the wheel comes full circle' in a period short or
4307 long. Plants or animals have times of fertility and sterility, which the
4308 intelligence of rulers because alloyed by sense will not enable them to
4309 ascertain, and children will be born out of season. For whereas divine
4310 creations are in a perfect cycle or number, the human creation is in
4311 a number which declines from perfection, and has four terms and three
4312 intervals of numbers, increasing, waning, assimilating, dissimilating,
4313 and yet perfectly commensurate with each other. The base of the number
4314 with a fourth added (or which is 3:4), multiplied by five and cubed,
4315 gives two harmonies:--the first a square number, which is a hundred
4316 times the base (or a hundred times a hundred); the second, an oblong,
4317 being a hundred squares of the rational diameter of a figure the side of
4318 which is five, subtracting one from each square or two perfect squares
4319 from all, and adding a hundred cubes of three. This entire number is
4320 geometrical and contains the rule or law of generation. When this law is
4321 neglected marriages will be unpropitious; the inferior offspring who are
4322 then born will in time become the rulers; the State will decline, and
4323 education fall into decay; gymnastic will be preferred to music, and
4324 the gold and silver and brass and iron will form a chaotic mass--thus
4325 division will arise. Such is the Muses' answer to our question. 'And a
4326 true answer, of course:--but what more have they to say?' They say that
4327 the two races, the iron and brass, and the silver and gold, will draw
4328 the State different ways;--the one will take to trade and moneymaking,
4329 and the others, having the true riches and not caring for money, will
4330 resist them: the contest will end in a compromise; they will agree to
4331 have private property, and will enslave their fellow-citizens who were
4332 once their friends and nurturers. But they will retain their warlike
4333 character, and will be chiefly occupied in fighting and exercising rule.
4334 Thus arises timocracy, which is intermediate between aristocracy and
4335 oligarchy.
4336 
4337 The new form of government resembles the ideal in obedience to rulers
4338 and contempt for trade, and having common meals, and in devotion
4339 to warlike and gymnastic exercises. But corruption has crept into
4340 philosophy, and simplicity of character, which was once her note, is now
4341 looked for only in the military class. Arts of war begin to prevail over
4342 arts of peace; the ruler is no longer a philosopher; as in oligarchies,
4343 there springs up among them an extravagant love of gain--get another
4344 man's and save your own, is their principle; and they have dark places
4345 in which they hoard their gold and silver, for the use of their women
4346 and others; they take their pleasures by stealth, like boys who are
4347 running away from their father--the law; and their education is not
4348 inspired by the Muse, but imposed by the strong arm of power. The
4349 leading characteristic of this State is party spirit and ambition.
4350 
4351 And what manner of man answers to such a State? 'In love of contention,'
4352 replied Adeimantus, 'he will be like our friend Glaucon.' In that
4353 respect, perhaps, but not in others. He is self-asserting and
4354 ill-educated, yet fond of literature, although not himself a
4355 speaker,--fierce with slaves, but obedient to rulers, a lover of power
4356 and honour, which he hopes to gain by deeds of arms,--fond, too, of
4357 gymnastics and of hunting. As he advances in years he grows avaricious,
4358 for he has lost philosophy, which is the only saviour and guardian of
4359 men. His origin is as follows:--His father is a good man dwelling in an
4360 ill-ordered State, who has retired from politics in order that he may
4361 lead a quiet life. His mother is angry at her loss of precedence among
4362 other women; she is disgusted at her husband's selfishness, and she
4363 expatiates to her son on the unmanliness and indolence of his father.
4364 The old family servant takes up the tale, and says to the youth:--'When
4365 you grow up you must be more of a man than your father.' All the world
4366 are agreed that he who minds his own business is an idiot, while a
4367 busybody is highly honoured and esteemed. The young man compares this
4368 spirit with his father's words and ways, and as he is naturally well
4369 disposed, although he has suffered from evil influences, he rests at a
4370 middle point and becomes ambitious and a lover of honour.
4371 
4372 And now let us set another city over against another man. The next form
4373 of government is oligarchy, in which the rule is of the rich only; nor
4374 is it difficult to see how such a State arises. The decline begins with
4375 the possession of gold and silver; illegal modes of expenditure are
4376 invented; one draws another on, and the multitude are infected; riches
4377 outweigh virtue; lovers of money take the place of lovers of honour;
4378 misers of politicians; and, in time, political privileges are confined
4379 by law to the rich, who do not shrink from violence in order to effect
4380 their purposes.
4381 
4382 Thus much of the origin,--let us next consider the evils of oligarchy.
4383 Would a man who wanted to be safe on a voyage take a bad pilot because
4384 he was rich, or refuse a good one because he was poor? And does not the
4385 analogy apply still more to the State? And there are yet greater evils:
4386 two nations are struggling together in one--the rich and the poor; and
4387 the rich dare not put arms into the hands of the poor, and are unwilling
4388 to pay for defenders out of their own money. And have we not already
4389 condemned that State in which the same persons are warriors as well
4390 as shopkeepers? The greatest evil of all is that a man may sell his
4391 property and have no place in the State; while there is one class which
4392 has enormous wealth, the other is entirely destitute. But observe that
4393 these destitutes had not really any more of the governing nature in them
4394 when they were rich than now that they are poor; they were miserable
4395 spendthrifts always. They are the drones of the hive; only whereas the
4396 actual drone is unprovided by nature with a sting, the two-legged things
4397 whom we call drones are some of them without stings and some of them
4398 have dreadful stings; in other words, there are paupers and there are
4399 rogues. These are never far apart; and in oligarchical cities, where
4400 nearly everybody is a pauper who is not a ruler, you will find abundance
4401 of both. And this evil state of society originates in bad education and
4402 bad government.
4403 
4404 Like State, like man,--the change in the latter begins with the
4405 representative of timocracy; he walks at first in the ways of his
4406 father, who may have been a statesman, or general, perhaps; and
4407 presently he sees him 'fallen from his high estate,' the victim of
4408 informers, dying in prison or exile, or by the hand of the executioner.
4409 The lesson which he thus receives, makes him cautious; he leaves
4410 politics, represses his pride, and saves pence. Avarice is enthroned as
4411 his bosom's lord, and assumes the style of the Great King; the rational
4412 and spirited elements sit humbly on the ground at either side, the one
4413 immersed in calculation, the other absorbed in the admiration of
4414 wealth. The love of honour turns to love of money; the conversion
4415 is instantaneous. The man is mean, saving, toiling, the slave of one
4416 passion which is the master of the rest: Is he not the very image of the
4417 State? He has had no education, or he would never have allowed the blind
4418 god of riches to lead the dance within him. And being uneducated he will
4419 have many slavish desires, some beggarly, some knavish, breeding in his
4420 soul. If he is the trustee of an orphan, and has the power to defraud,
4421 he will soon prove that he is not without the will, and that his
4422 passions are only restrained by fear and not by reason. Hence he leads a
4423 divided existence; in which the better desires mostly prevail. But when
4424 he is contending for prizes and other distinctions, he is afraid to
4425 incur a loss which is to be repaid only by barren honour; in time of
4426 war he fights with a small part of his resources, and usually keeps his
4427 money and loses the victory.
4428 
4429 Next comes democracy and the democratic man, out of oligarchy and
4430 the oligarchical man. Insatiable avarice is the ruling passion of an
4431 oligarchy; and they encourage expensive habits in order that they may
4432 gain by the ruin of extravagant youth. Thus men of family often lose
4433 their property or rights of citizenship; but they remain in the city,
4434 full of hatred against the new owners of their estates and ripe for
4435 revolution. The usurer with stooping walk pretends not to see them;
4436 he passes by, and leaves his sting--that is, his money--in some other
4437 victim; and many a man has to pay the parent or principal sum multiplied
4438 into a family of children, and is reduced into a state of dronage by
4439 him. The only way of diminishing the evil is either to limit a man in
4440 his use of his property, or to insist that he shall lend at his own
4441 risk. But the ruling class do not want remedies; they care only for
4442 money, and are as careless of virtue as the poorest of the citizens.
4443 Now there are occasions on which the governors and the governed meet
4444 together,--at festivals, on a journey, voyaging or fighting. The sturdy
4445 pauper finds that in the hour of danger he is not despised; he sees
4446 the rich man puffing and panting, and draws the conclusion which he
4447 privately imparts to his companions,--'that our people are not good for
4448 much;' and as a sickly frame is made ill by a mere touch from without,
4449 or sometimes without external impulse is ready to fall to pieces of
4450 itself, so from the least cause, or with none at all, the city falls ill
4451 and fights a battle for life or death. And democracy comes into power
4452 when the poor are the victors, killing some and exiling some, and giving
4453 equal shares in the government to all the rest.
4454 
4455 The manner of life in such a State is that of democrats; there is
4456 freedom and plainness of speech, and every man does what is right in
4457 his own eyes, and has his own way of life. Hence arise the most various
4458 developments of character; the State is like a piece of embroidery of
4459 which the colours and figures are the manners of men, and there are many
4460 who, like women and children, prefer this variety to real beauty and
4461 excellence. The State is not one but many, like a bazaar at which you
4462 can buy anything. The great charm is, that you may do as you like; you
4463 may govern if you like, let it alone if you like; go to war and make
4464 peace if you feel disposed, and all quite irrespective of anybody
4465 else. When you condemn men to death they remain alive all the same; a
4466 gentleman is desired to go into exile, and he stalks about the streets
4467 like a hero; and nobody sees him or cares for him. Observe, too,
4468 how grandly Democracy sets her foot upon all our fine theories of
4469 education,--how little she cares for the training of her statesmen! The
4470 only qualification which she demands is the profession of patriotism.
4471 Such is democracy;--a pleasing, lawless, various sort of government,
4472 distributing equality to equals and unequals alike.
4473 
4474 Let us now inspect the individual democrat; and first, as in the case
4475 of the State, we will trace his antecedents. He is the son of a miserly
4476 oligarch, and has been taught by him to restrain the love of unnecessary
4477 pleasures. Perhaps I ought to explain this latter term:--Necessary
4478 pleasures are those which are good, and which we cannot do without;
4479 unnecessary pleasures are those which do no good, and of which the
4480 desire might be eradicated by early training. For example, the pleasures
4481 of eating and drinking are necessary and healthy, up to a certain point;
4482 beyond that point they are alike hurtful to body and mind, and the
4483 excess may be avoided. When in excess, they may be rightly called
4484 expensive pleasures, in opposition to the useful ones. And the drone, as
4485 we called him, is the slave of these unnecessary pleasures and desires,
4486 whereas the miserly oligarch is subject only to the necessary.
4487 
4488 The oligarch changes into the democrat in the following manner:--The
4489 youth who has had a miserly bringing up, gets a taste of the drone's
4490 honey; he meets with wild companions, who introduce him to every new
4491 pleasure. As in the State, so in the individual, there are allies on
4492 both sides, temptations from without and passions from within; there is
4493 reason also and external influences of parents and friends in alliance
4494 with the oligarchical principle; and the two factions are in violent
4495 conflict with one another. Sometimes the party of order prevails, but
4496 then again new desires and new disorders arise, and the whole mob of
4497 passions gets possession of the Acropolis, that is to say, the soul,
4498 which they find void and unguarded by true words and works. Falsehoods
4499 and illusions ascend to take their place; the prodigal goes back into
4500 the country of the Lotophagi or drones, and openly dwells there. And if
4501 any offer of alliance or parley of individual elders comes from home,
4502 the false spirits shut the gates of the castle and permit no one to
4503 enter,--there is a battle, and they gain the victory; and straightway
4504 making alliance with the desires, they banish modesty, which they call
4505 folly, and send temperance over the border. When the house has been
4506 swept and garnished, they dress up the exiled vices, and, crowning them
4507 with garlands, bring them back under new names. Insolence they call good
4508 breeding, anarchy freedom, waste magnificence, impudence courage. Such
4509 is the process by which the youth passes from the necessary pleasures to
4510 the unnecessary. After a while he divides his time impartially between
4511 them; and perhaps, when he gets older and the violence of passion
4512 has abated, he restores some of the exiles and lives in a sort of
4513 equilibrium, indulging first one pleasure and then another; and if
4514 reason comes and tells him that some pleasures are good and honourable,
4515 and others bad and vile, he shakes his head and says that he can make
4516 no distinction between them. Thus he lives in the fancy of the hour;
4517 sometimes he takes to drink, and then he turns abstainer; he practises
4518 in the gymnasium or he does nothing at all; then again he would be a
4519 philosopher or a politician; or again, he would be a warrior or a man of
4520 business; he is
4521 
4522    'Every thing by starts and nothing long.'
4523 
4524 There remains still the finest and fairest of all men and all
4525 States--tyranny and the tyrant. Tyranny springs from democracy much as
4526 democracy springs from oligarchy. Both arise from excess; the one from
4527 excess of wealth, the other from excess of freedom. 'The great natural
4528 good of life,' says the democrat, 'is freedom.' And this exclusive love
4529 of freedom and regardlessness of everything else, is the cause of the
4530 change from democracy to tyranny. The State demands the strong wine of
4531 freedom, and unless her rulers give her a plentiful draught, punishes
4532 and insults them; equality and fraternity of governors and governed is
4533 the approved principle. Anarchy is the law, not of the State only, but
4534 of private houses, and extends even to the animals. Father and son,
4535 citizen and foreigner, teacher and pupil, old and young, are all on a
4536 level; fathers and teachers fear their sons and pupils, and the wisdom
4537 of the young man is a match for the elder, and the old imitate the
4538 jaunty manners of the young because they are afraid of being thought
4539 morose. Slaves are on a level with their masters and mistresses, and
4540 there is no difference between men and women. Nay, the very animals in
4541 a democratic State have a freedom which is unknown in other places. The
4542 she-dogs are as good as their she-mistresses, and horses and asses march
