4543 along with dignity and run their noses against anybody who comes in
4544 their way. 'That has often been my experience.' At last the citizens
4545 become so sensitive that they cannot endure the yoke of laws, written or
4546 unwritten; they would have no man call himself their master. Such is the
4547 glorious beginning of things out of which tyranny springs. 'Glorious,
4548 indeed; but what is to follow?' The ruin of oligarchy is the ruin of
4549 democracy; for there is a law of contraries; the excess of freedom
4550 passes into the excess of slavery, and the greater the freedom the
4551 greater the slavery. You will remember that in the oligarchy were found
4552 two classes--rogues and paupers, whom we compared to drones with and
4553 without stings. These two classes are to the State what phlegm and bile
4554 are to the human body; and the State-physician, or legislator, must get
4555 rid of them, just as the bee-master keeps the drones out of the hive.
4556 Now in a democracy, too, there are drones, but they are more numerous
4557 and more dangerous than in the oligarchy; there they are inert and
4558 unpractised, here they are full of life and animation; and the keener
4559 sort speak and act, while the others buzz about the bema and prevent
4560 their opponents from being heard. And there is another class in
4561 democratic States, of respectable, thriving individuals, who can be
4562 squeezed when the drones have need of their possessions; there is
4563 moreover a third class, who are the labourers and the artisans, and
4564 they make up the mass of the people. When the people meet, they
4565 are omnipotent, but they cannot be brought together unless they are
4566 attracted by a little honey; and the rich are made to supply the honey,
4567 of which the demagogues keep the greater part themselves, giving a taste
4568 only to the mob. Their victims attempt to resist; they are driven mad
4569 by the stings of the drones, and so become downright oligarchs in
4570 self-defence. Then follow informations and convictions for treason. The
4571 people have some protector whom they nurse into greatness, and from this
4572 root the tree of tyranny springs. The nature of the change is indicated
4573 in the old fable of the temple of Zeus Lycaeus, which tells how he who
4574 tastes human flesh mixed up with the flesh of other victims will turn
4575 into a wolf. Even so the protector, who tastes human blood, and slays
4576 some and exiles others with or without law, who hints at abolition of
4577 debts and division of lands, must either perish or become a wolf--that
4578 is, a tyrant. Perhaps he is driven out, but he soon comes back from
4579 exile; and then if his enemies cannot get rid of him by lawful means,
4580 they plot his assassination. Thereupon the friend of the people makes
4581 his well-known request to them for a body-guard, which they readily
4582 grant, thinking only of his danger and not of their own. Now let the
4583 rich man make to himself wings, for he will never run away again if he
4584 does not do so then. And the Great Protector, having crushed all his
4585 rivals, stands proudly erect in the chariot of State, a full-blown
4586 tyrant: Let us enquire into the nature of his happiness.
4587 
4588 In the early days of his tyranny he smiles and beams upon everybody; he
4589 is not a 'dominus,' no, not he: he has only come to put an end to debt
4590 and the monopoly of land. Having got rid of foreign enemies, he makes
4591 himself necessary to the State by always going to war. He is thus
4592 enabled to depress the poor by heavy taxes, and so keep them at work;
4593 and he can get rid of bolder spirits by handing them over to the enemy.
4594 Then comes unpopularity; some of his old associates have the courage to
4595 oppose him. The consequence is, that he has to make a purgation of the
4596 State; but, unlike the physician who purges away the bad, he must get
4597 rid of the high-spirited, the wise and the wealthy; for he has no choice
4598 between death and a life of shame and dishonour. And the more hated he
4599 is, the more he will require trusty guards; but how will he obtain them?
4600 'They will come flocking like birds--for pay.' Will he not rather obtain
4601 them on the spot? He will take the slaves from their owners and make
4602 them his body-guard; these are his trusted friends, who admire and
4603 look up to him. Are not the tragic poets wise who magnify and exalt the
4604 tyrant, and say that he is wise by association with the wise? And are
4605 not their praises of tyranny alone a sufficient reason why we should
4606 exclude them from our State? They may go to other cities, and gather the
4607 mob about them with fine words, and change commonwealths into tyrannies
4608 and democracies, receiving honours and rewards for their services; but
4609 the higher they and their friends ascend constitution hill, the more
4610 their honour will fail and become 'too asthmatic to mount.' To return to
4611 the tyrant--How will he support that rare army of his? First, by robbing
4612 the temples of their treasures, which will enable him to lighten the
4613 taxes; then he will take all his father's property, and spend it on
4614 his companions, male or female. Now his father is the demus, and if the
4615 demus gets angry, and says that a great hulking son ought not to be a
4616 burden on his parents, and bids him and his riotous crew begone, then
4617 will the parent know what a monster he has been nurturing, and that the
4618 son whom he would fain expel is too strong for him. 'You do not mean to
4619 say that he will beat his father?' Yes, he will, after having taken away
4620 his arms. 'Then he is a parricide and a cruel, unnatural son.' And the
4621 people have jumped from the fear of slavery into slavery, out of the
4622 smoke into the fire. Thus liberty, when out of all order and reason,
4623 passes into the worst form of servitude...
4624 
4625 In the previous books Plato has described the ideal State; now he
4626 returns to the perverted or declining forms, on which he had lightly
4627 touched at the end of Book IV. These he describes in a succession of
4628 parallels between the individuals and the States, tracing the origin of
4629 either in the State or individual which has preceded them. He begins
4630 by asking the point at which he digressed; and is thus led shortly to
4631 recapitulate the substance of the three former books, which also contain
4632 a parallel of the philosopher and the State.
4633 
4634 Of the first decline he gives no intelligible account; he would not have
4635 liked to admit the most probable causes of the fall of his ideal State,
4636 which to us would appear to be the impracticability of communism or the
4637 natural antagonism of the ruling and subject classes. He throws a
4638 veil of mystery over the origin of the decline, which he attributes to
4639 ignorance of the law of population. Of this law the famous geometrical
4640 figure or number is the expression. Like the ancients in general, he had
4641 no idea of the gradual perfectibility of man or of the education of the
4642 human race. His ideal was not to be attained in the course of ages, but
4643 was to spring in full armour from the head of the legislator. When good
4644 laws had been given, he thought only of the manner in which they were
4645 likely to be corrupted, or of how they might be filled up in detail or
4646 restored in accordance with their original spirit. He appears not to
4647 have reflected upon the full meaning of his own words, 'In the brief
4648 space of human life, nothing great can be accomplished'; or again, as he
4649 afterwards says in the Laws, 'Infinite time is the maker of cities.' The
4650 order of constitutions which is adopted by him represents an order of
4651 thought rather than a succession of time, and may be considered as the
4652 first attempt to frame a philosophy of history.
4653 
4654 The first of these declining States is timocracy, or the government of
4655 soldiers and lovers of honour, which answers to the Spartan State; this
4656 is a government of force, in which education is not inspired by the
4657 Muses, but imposed by the law, and in which all the finer elements of
4658 organization have disappeared. The philosopher himself has lost the
4659 love of truth, and the soldier, who is of a simpler and honester nature,
4660 rules in his stead. The individual who answers to timocracy has some
4661 noticeable qualities. He is described as ill educated, but, like the
4662 Spartan, a lover of literature; and although he is a harsh master to his
4663 servants he has no natural superiority over them. His character is
4664 based upon a reaction against the circumstances of his father, who in
4665 a troubled city has retired from politics; and his mother, who is
4666 dissatisfied at her own position, is always urging him towards the life
4667 of political ambition. Such a character may have had this origin, and
4668 indeed Livy attributes the Licinian laws to a feminine jealousy of a
4669 similar kind. But there is obviously no connection between the manner
4670 in which the timocratic State springs out of the ideal, and the mere
4671 accident by which the timocratic man is the son of a retired statesman.
4672 
4673 The two next stages in the decline of constitutions have even less
4674 historical foundation. For there is no trace in Greek history of a
4675 polity like the Spartan or Cretan passing into an oligarchy of wealth,
4676 or of the oligarchy of wealth passing into a democracy. The order of
4677 history appears to be different; first, in the Homeric times there is
4678 the royal or patriarchal form of government, which a century or two
4679 later was succeeded by an oligarchy of birth rather than of wealth, and
4680 in which wealth was only the accident of the hereditary possession of
4681 land and power. Sometimes this oligarchical government gave way to a
4682 government based upon a qualification of property, which, according to
4683 Aristotle's mode of using words, would have been called a timocracy;
4684 and this in some cities, as at Athens, became the conducting medium to
4685 democracy. But such was not the necessary order of succession in States;
4686 nor, indeed, can any order be discerned in the endless fluctuation of
4687 Greek history (like the tides in the Euripus), except, perhaps, in the
4688 almost uniform tendency from monarchy to aristocracy in the earliest
4689 times. At first sight there appears to be a similar inversion in the
4690 last step of the Platonic succession; for tyranny, instead of being the
4691 natural end of democracy, in early Greek history appears rather as a
4692 stage leading to democracy; the reign of Peisistratus and his sons is
4693 an episode which comes between the legislation of Solon and the
4694 constitution of Cleisthenes; and some secret cause common to them all
4695 seems to have led the greater part of Hellas at her first appearance
4696 in the dawn of history, e.g. Athens, Argos, Corinth, Sicyon, and nearly
4697 every State with the exception of Sparta, through a similar stage of
4698 tyranny which ended either in oligarchy or democracy. But then we must
4699 remember that Plato is describing rather the contemporary governments
4700 of the Sicilian States, which alternated between democracy and tyranny,
4701 than the ancient history of Athens or Corinth.
4702 
4703 The portrait of the tyrant himself is just such as the later Greek
4704 delighted to draw of Phalaris and Dionysius, in which, as in the lives
4705 of mediaeval saints or mythic heroes, the conduct and actions of one
4706 were attributed to another in order to fill up the outline. There was
4707 no enormity which the Greek was not today to believe of them; the tyrant
4708 was the negation of government and law; his assassination was glorious;
4709 there was no crime, however unnatural, which might not with probability
4710 be attributed to him. In this, Plato was only following the common
4711 thought of his countrymen, which he embellished and exaggerated with all
4712 the power of his genius. There is no need to suppose that he drew
4713 from life; or that his knowledge of tyrants is derived from a personal
4714 acquaintance with Dionysius. The manner in which he speaks of them would
4715 rather tend to render doubtful his ever having 'consorted' with them, or
4716 entertained the schemes, which are attributed to him in the Epistles, of
4717 regenerating Sicily by their help.
4718 
4719 Plato in a hyperbolical and serio-comic vein exaggerates the follies of
4720 democracy which he also sees reflected in social life. To him democracy
4721 is a state of individualism or dissolution; in which every one is doing
4722 what is right in his own eyes. Of a people animated by a common spirit
4723 of liberty, rising as one man to repel the Persian host, which is the
4724 leading idea of democracy in Herodotus and Thucydides, he never seems to
4725 think. But if he is not a believer in liberty, still less is he a lover
4726 of tyranny. His deeper and more serious condemnation is reserved for the
4727 tyrant, who is the ideal of wickedness and also of weakness, and who
4728 in his utter helplessness and suspiciousness is leading an almost
4729 impossible existence, without that remnant of good which, in Plato's
4730 opinion, was required to give power to evil (Book I). This ideal of
4731 wickedness living in helpless misery, is the reverse of that other
4732 portrait of perfect injustice ruling in happiness and splendour, which
4733 first of all Thrasymachus, and afterwards the sons of Ariston had drawn,
4734 and is also the reverse of the king whose rule of life is the good of
4735 his subjects.
4736 
4737 Each of these governments and individuals has a corresponding
4738 ethical gradation: the ideal State is under the rule of reason, not
4739 extinguishing but harmonizing the passions, and training them in virtue;
4740 in the timocracy and the timocratic man the constitution, whether of the
4741 State or of the individual, is based, first, upon courage, and secondly,
4742 upon the love of honour; this latter virtue, which is hardly to be
4743 esteemed a virtue, has superseded all the rest. In the second stage of
4744 decline the virtues have altogether disappeared, and the love of gain
4745 has succeeded to them; in the third stage, or democracy, the various
4746 passions are allowed to have free play, and the virtues and vices are
4747 impartially cultivated. But this freedom, which leads to many curious
4748 extravagances of character, is in reality only a state of weakness and
4749 dissipation. At last, one monster passion takes possession of the whole
4750 nature of man--this is tyranny. In all of them excess--the excess first
4751 of wealth and then of freedom, is the element of decay.
4752 
4753 The eighth book of the Republic abounds in pictures of life and fanciful
4754 allusions; the use of metaphorical language is carried to a greater
4755 extent than anywhere else in Plato. We may remark,
4756 
4757 (1), the description of the two nations in one, which become more and
4758 more divided in the Greek Republics, as in feudal times, and perhaps
4759 also in our own;
4760 
4761 (2), the notion of democracy expressed in a sort of Pythagorean formula
4762 as equality among unequals;
4763 
4764 (3), the free and easy ways of men and animals, which are characteristic
4765 of liberty, as foreign mercenaries and universal mistrust are of the
4766 tyrant;
4767 
4768 (4), the proposal that mere debts should not be recoverable by law is a
4769 speculation which has often been entertained by reformers of the law
4770 in modern times, and is in harmony with the tendencies of modern
4771 legislation. Debt and land were the two great difficulties of the
4772 ancient lawgiver: in modern times we may be said to have almost, if not
4773 quite, solved the first of these difficulties, but hardly the second.
4774 
4775 Still more remarkable are the corresponding portraits of individuals:
4776 there is the family picture of the father and mother and the old servant
4777 of the timocratical man, and the outward respectability and inherent
4778 meanness of the oligarchical; the uncontrolled licence and freedom of
4779 the democrat, in which the young Alcibiades seems to be depicted, doing
4780 right or wrong as he pleases, and who at last, like the prodigal,
4781 goes into a far country (note here the play of language by which the
4782 democratic man is himself represented under the image of a State having
4783 a citadel and receiving embassies); and there is the wild-beast nature,
4784 which breaks loose in his successor. The hit about the tyrant being a
4785 parricide; the representation of the tyrant's life as an obscene dream;
4786 the rhetorical surprise of a more miserable than the most miserable of
4787 men in Book IX; the hint to the poets that if they are the friends of
4788 tyrants there is no place for them in a constitutional State, and that
4789 they are too clever not to see the propriety of their own expulsion; the
4790 continuous image of the drones who are of two kinds, swelling at last
4791 into the monster drone having wings (Book IX),--are among Plato's
4792 happiest touches.
4793 
4794 There remains to be considered the great difficulty of this book of the
4795 Republic, the so-called number of the State. This is a puzzle almost as
4796 great as the Number of the Beast in the Book of Revelation, and though
4797 apparently known to Aristotle, is referred to by Cicero as a proverb of
4798 obscurity (Ep. ad Att.). And some have imagined that there is no answer
4799 to the puzzle, and that Plato has been practising upon his readers.
4800 But such a deception as this is inconsistent with the manner in which
4801 Aristotle speaks of the number (Pol.), and would have been ridiculous to
4802 any reader of the Republic who was acquainted with Greek mathematics.
4803 As little reason is there for supposing that Plato intentionally used
4804 obscure expressions; the obscurity arises from our want of familiarity
4805 with the subject. On the other hand, Plato himself indicates that he is
4806 not altogether serious, and in describing his number as a solemn jest of
4807 the Muses, he appears to imply some degree of satire on the symbolical
4808 use of number. (Compare Cratylus; Protag.)
4809 
4810 Our hope of understanding the passage depends principally on an accurate
4811 study of the words themselves; on which a faint light is thrown by the
4812 parallel passage in the ninth book. Another help is the allusion in
4813 Aristotle, who makes the important remark that the latter part of the
4814 passage (Greek) describes a solid figure. (Pol.--'He only says that
4815 nothing is abiding, but that all things change in a certain cycle; and
4816 that the origin of the change is a base of numbers which are in the
4817 ratio of 4:3; and this when combined with a figure of five gives two
4818 harmonies; he means when the number of this figure becomes solid.')
4819 Some further clue may be gathered from the appearance of the Pythagorean
4820 triangle, which is denoted by the numbers 3, 4, 5, and in which, as in
4821 every right-angled triangle, the squares of the two lesser sides equal
4822 the square of the hypotenuse (9 + 16 = 25).
4823 
4824 Plato begins by speaking of a perfect or cyclical number (Tim.), i.e.
4825 a number in which the sum of the divisors equals the whole; this is the
4826 divine or perfect number in which all lesser cycles or revolutions are
4827 complete. He also speaks of a human or imperfect number, having four
4828 terms and three intervals of numbers which are related to one another in
4829 certain proportions; these he converts into figures, and finds in
4830 them when they have been raised to the third power certain elements of
4831 number, which give two 'harmonies,' the one square, the other oblong;
4832 but he does not say that the square number answers to the divine, or the
4833 oblong number to the human cycle; nor is any intimation given that the
4834 first or divine number represents the period of the world, the second
4835 the period of the state, or of the human race as Zeller supposes; nor
4836 is the divine number afterwards mentioned (Arist.). The second is the
4837 number of generations or births, and presides over them in the same
4838 mysterious manner in which the stars preside over them, or in which,
4839 according to the Pythagoreans, opportunity, justice, marriage, are
4840 represented by some number or figure. This is probably the number 216.
4841 
4842 The explanation given in the text supposes the two harmonies to make up
4843 the number 8000. This explanation derives a certain plausibility from
4844 the circumstance that 8000 is the ancient number of the Spartan citizens
4845 (Herod.), and would be what Plato might have called 'a number which
4846 nearly concerns the population of a city'; the mysterious disappearance
4847 of the Spartan population may possibly have suggested to him the first
4848 cause of his decline of States. The lesser or square 'harmony,' of 400,
4849 might be a symbol of the guardians,--the larger or oblong 'harmony,'
4850 of the people, and the numbers 3, 4, 5 might refer respectively to the
4851 three orders in the State or parts of the soul, the four virtues, the
4852 five forms of government. The harmony of the musical scale, which
4853 is elsewhere used as a symbol of the harmony of the state, is also
4854 indicated. For the numbers 3, 4, 5, which represent the sides of the
4855 Pythagorean triangle, also denote the intervals of the scale.
4856 
4857 The terms used in the statement of the problem may be explained as
4858 follows. A perfect number (Greek), as already stated, is one which is
4859 equal to the sum of its divisors. Thus 6, which is the first perfect or
4860 cyclical number, = 1 + 2 + 3. The words (Greek), 'terms' or 'notes,' and
4861 (Greek), 'intervals,' are applicable to music as well as to number and
4862 figure. (Greek) is the 'base' on which the whole calculation depends,
4863 or the 'lowest term' from which it can be worked out. The words (Greek)
4864 have been variously translated--'squared and cubed' (Donaldson),
4865 'equalling and equalled in power' (Weber), 'by involution and
4866 evolution,' i.e. by raising the power and extracting the root (as in
4867 the translation). Numbers are called 'like and unlike' (Greek) when the
4868 factors or the sides of the planes and cubes which they represent are
4869 or are not in the same ratio: e.g. 8 and 27 = 2 cubed and 3 cubed; and
4870 conversely. 'Waxing' (Greek) numbers, called also 'increasing' (Greek),
4871 are those which are exceeded by the sum of their divisors: e.g. 12
4872 and 18 are less than 16 and 21. 'Waning' (Greek) numbers, called also
4873 'decreasing' (Greek) are those which succeed the sum of their divisors:
4874 e.g. 8 and 27 exceed 7 and 13. The words translated 'commensurable
4875 and agreeable to one another' (Greek) seem to be different ways of
4876 describing the same relation, with more or less precision. They are
4877 equivalent to 'expressible in terms having the same relation to one
4878 another,' like the series 8, 12, 18, 27, each of which numbers is in the
4879 relation of (1 and 1/2) to the preceding. The 'base,' or 'fundamental
4880 number, which has 1/3 added to it' (1 and 1/3) = 4/3 or a musical
4881 fourth. (Greek) is a 'proportion' of numbers as of musical notes,
4882 applied either to the parts or factors of a single number or to the
4883 relation of one number to another. The first harmony is a 'square'
4884 number (Greek); the second harmony is an 'oblong' number (Greek), i.e. a
4885 number representing a figure of which the opposite sides only are
4886 equal. (Greek) = 'numbers squared from' or 'upon diameters'; (Greek)
4887 = 'rational,' i.e. omitting fractions, (Greek), 'irrational,' i.e.
4888 including fractions; e.g. 49 is a square of the rational diameter of a
4889 figure the side of which = 5: 50, of an irrational diameter of the same.
4890 For several of the explanations here given and for a good deal besides
4891 I am indebted to an excellent article on the Platonic Number by Dr.
4892 Donaldson (Proc. of the Philol. Society).
4893 
4894 The conclusions which he draws from these data are summed up by him as
4895 follows. Having assumed that the number of the perfect or divine cycle
4896 is the number of the world, and the number of the imperfect cycle the
4897 number of the state, he proceeds: 'The period of the world is defined
4898 by the perfect number 6, that of the state by the cube of that number
4899 or 216, which is the product of the last pair of terms in the Platonic
4900 Tetractys (a series of seven terms, 1, 2, 3, 4, 9, 8, 27); and if
4901 we take this as the basis of our computation, we shall have two cube
4902 numbers (Greek), viz. 8 and 27; and the mean proportionals between
4903 these, viz. 12 and 18, will furnish three intervals and four terms,
4904 and these terms and intervals stand related to one another in the
4905 sesqui-altera ratio, i.e. each term is to the preceding as 3/2. Now if
4906 we remember that the number 216 = 8 x 27 = 3 cubed + 4 cubed + 5 cubed,
4907 and 3 squared + 4 squared = 5 squared, we must admit that this
4908 number implies the numbers 3, 4, 5, to which musicians attach so much
4909 importance. And if we combine the ratio 4/3 with the number 5, or
4910 multiply the ratios of the sides by the hypotenuse, we shall by first
4911 squaring and then cubing obtain two expressions, which denote the ratio
4912 of the two last pairs of terms in the Platonic Tetractys, the former
4913 multiplied by the square, the latter by the cube of the number 10, the
4914 sum of the first four digits which constitute the Platonic Tetractys.'
4915 The two (Greek) he elsewhere explains as follows: 'The first (Greek) is
4916 (Greek), in other words (4/3 x 5) all squared = 100 x 2 squared over 3
4917 squared. The second (Greek), a cube of the same root, is described
4918 as 100 multiplied (alpha) by the rational diameter of 5 diminished
4919 by unity, i.e., as shown above, 48: (beta) by two incommensurable
4920 diameters, i.e. the two first irrationals, or 2 and 3: and (gamma) by
4921 the cube of 3, or 27. Thus we have (48 + 5 + 27) 100 = 1000 x 2 cubed.
4922 This second harmony is to be the cube of the number of which the former
4923 harmony is the square, and therefore must be divided by the cube of
4924 3. In other words, the whole expression will be: (1), for the first
4925 harmony, 400/9: (2), for the second harmony, 8000/27.'
4926 
4927 The reasons which have inclined me to agree with Dr. Donaldson and also
4928 with Schleiermacher in supposing that 216 is the Platonic number of
4929 births are: (1) that it coincides with the description of the number
4930 given in the first part of the passage (Greek...): (2) that the
4931 number 216 with its permutations would have been familiar to a Greek
4932 mathematician, though unfamiliar to us: (3) that 216 is the cube of
4933 6, and also the sum of 3 cubed, 4 cubed, 5 cubed, the numbers 3, 4, 5
4934 representing the Pythagorean triangle, of which the sides when squared
4935 equal the square of the hypotenuse (9 + 16 = 25): (4) that it is also
4936 the period of the Pythagorean Metempsychosis: (5) the three ultimate
4937 terms or bases (3, 4, 5) of which 216 is composed answer to the third,
4938 fourth, fifth in the musical scale: (6) that the number 216 is the
4939 product of the cubes of 2 and 3, which are the two last terms in
4940 the Platonic Tetractys: (7) that the Pythagorean triangle is said by
4941 Plutarch (de Is. et Osir.), Proclus (super prima Eucl.), and Quintilian
4942 (de Musica) to be contained in this passage, so that the tradition
4943 of the school seems to point in the same direction: (8) that the
4944 Pythagorean triangle is called also the figure of marriage (Greek).
4945 
4946 But though agreeing with Dr. Donaldson thus far, I see no reason for
4947 supposing, as he does, that the first or perfect number is the world,
4948 the human or imperfect number the state; nor has he given any proof that
4949 the second harmony is a cube. Nor do I think that (Greek) can mean
4950 'two incommensurables,' which he arbitrarily assumes to be 2 and 3,
4951 but rather, as the preceding clause implies, (Greek), i.e. two square
4952 numbers based upon irrational diameters of a figure the side of which is
4953 5 = 50 x 2.
4954 
4955 The greatest objection to the translation is the sense given to the
4956 words (Greek), 'a base of three with a third added to it, multiplied
4957 by 5.' In this somewhat forced manner Plato introduces once more the
4958 numbers of the Pythagorean triangle. But the coincidences in the numbers
4959 which follow are in favour of the explanation. The first harmony of 400,
4960 as has been already remarked, probably represents the rulers; the second
4961 and oblong harmony of 7600, the people.
4962 
4963 And here we take leave of the difficulty. The discovery of the riddle
4964 would be useless, and would throw no light on ancient mathematics. The
4965 point of interest is that Plato should have used such a symbol, and
4966 that so much of the Pythagorean spirit should have prevailed in him. His
4967 general meaning is that divine creation is perfect, and is represented
4968 or presided over by a perfect or cyclical number; human generation is
4969 imperfect, and represented or presided over by an imperfect number or
4970 series of numbers. The number 5040, which is the number of the citizens
4971 in the Laws, is expressly based by him on utilitarian grounds, namely,
4972 the convenience of the number for division; it is also made up of
4973 the first seven digits multiplied by one another. The contrast of the
4974 perfect and imperfect number may have been easily suggested by the
4975 corrections of the cycle, which were made first by Meton and secondly
4976 by Callippus; (the latter is said to have been a pupil of Plato). Of the
4977 degree of importance or of exactness to be attributed to the problem,
4978 the number of the tyrant in Book IX (729 = 365 x 2), and the slight
4979 correction of the error in the number 5040/12 (Laws), may furnish a
4980 criterion. There is nothing surprising in the circumstance that those
4981 who were seeking for order in nature and had found order in number,
4982 should have imagined one to give law to the other. Plato believes in
4983 a power of number far beyond what he could see realized in the world
4984 around him, and he knows the great influence which 'the little matter
4985 of 1, 2, 3' exercises upon education. He may even be thought to have a
4986 prophetic anticipation of the discoveries of Quetelet and others, that
4987 numbers depend upon numbers; e.g.--in population, the numbers of births
4988 and the respective numbers of children born of either sex, on the
4989 respective ages of parents, i.e. on other numbers.
4990 
4991 BOOK IX. Last of all comes the tyrannical man, about whom we have to
4992 enquire, Whence is he, and how does he live--in happiness or in misery?
4993 There is, however, a previous question of the nature and number of
4994 the appetites, which I should like to consider first. Some of them
4995 are unlawful, and yet admit of being chastened and weakened in various
4996 degrees by the power of reason and law. 'What appetites do you mean?' I
4997 mean those which are awake when the reasoning powers are asleep, which
4998 get up and walk about naked without any self-respect or shame; and there
4999 is no conceivable folly or crime, however cruel or unnatural, of which,
5000 in imagination, they may not be guilty. 'True,' he said; 'very true.'
5001 But when a man's pulse beats temperately; and he has supped on a feast
5002 of reason and come to a knowledge of himself before going to rest, and
5003 has satisfied his desires just enough to prevent their perturbing his
5004 reason, which remains clear and luminous, and when he is free from
5005 quarrel and heat,--the visions which he has on his bed are least
5006 irregular and abnormal. Even in good men there is such an irregular
5007 wild-beast nature, which peers out in sleep.
5008 
5009 To return:--You remember what was said of the democrat; that he was the
5010 son of a miserly father, who encouraged the saving desires and repressed
5011 the ornamental and expensive ones; presently the youth got into fine
5012 company, and began to entertain a dislike to his father's narrow ways;
5013 and being a better man than the corrupters of his youth, he came to a
5014 mean, and led a life, not of lawless or slavish passion, but of regular
5015 and successive indulgence. Now imagine that the youth has become a
5016 father, and has a son who is exposed to the same temptations, and has
5017 companions who lead him into every sort of iniquity, and parents and
5018 friends who try to keep him right. The counsellors of evil find that
5019 their only chance of retaining him is to implant in his soul a monster
5020 drone, or love; while other desires buzz around him and mystify him with
5021 sweet sounds and scents, this monster love takes possession of him,
5022 and puts an end to every true or modest thought or wish. Love, like
5023 drunkenness and madness, is a tyranny; and the tyrannical man, whether
5024 made by nature or habit, is just a drinking, lusting, furious sort of
5025 animal.
5026 
5027 And how does such an one live? 'Nay, that you must tell me.' Well then,
5028 I fancy that he will live amid revelries and harlotries, and love will
5029 be the lord and master of the house. Many desires require much money,
5030 and so he spends all that he has and borrows more; and when he has
5031 nothing the young ravens are still in the nest in which they were
5032 hatched, crying for food. Love urges them on; and they must be gratified
5033 by force or fraud, or if not, they become painful and troublesome;
5034 and as the new pleasures succeed the old ones, so will the son take
5035 possession of the goods of his parents; if they show signs of refusing,
5036 he will defraud and deceive them; and if they openly resist, what then?
5037 'I can only say, that I should not much like to be in their place.'
5038 But, O heavens, Adeimantus, to think that for some new-fangled and
5039 unnecessary love he will give up his old father and mother, best and
5040 dearest of friends, or enslave them to the fancies of the hour! Truly a
5041 tyrannical son is a blessing to his father and mother! When there is no
5042 more to be got out of them, he turns burglar or pickpocket, or robs a
5043 temple. Love overmasters the thoughts of his youth, and he becomes
5044 in sober reality the monster that he was sometimes in sleep. He waxes
5045 strong in all violence and lawlessness; and is ready for any deed of
5046 daring that will supply the wants of his rabble-rout. In a well-ordered
5047 State there are only a few such, and these in time of war go out and
5048 become the mercenaries of a tyrant. But in time of peace they stay
5049 at home and do mischief; they are the thieves, footpads, cut-purses,
5050 man-stealers of the community; or if they are able to speak, they turn
5051 false-witnesses and informers. 'No small catalogue of crimes truly,
5052 even if the perpetrators are few.' Yes, I said; but small and great are
5053 relative terms, and no crimes which are committed by them approach those
5054 of the tyrant, whom this class, growing strong and numerous, create out
5055 of themselves. If the people yield, well and good, but, if they resist,
5056 then, as before he beat his father and mother, so now he beats his
5057 fatherland and motherland, and places his mercenaries over them. Such
5058 men in their early days live with flatterers, and they themselves
5059 flatter others, in order to gain their ends; but they soon discard their
5060 followers when they have no longer any need of them; they are always
5061 either masters or servants,--the joys of friendship are unknown to them.
5062 And they are utterly treacherous and unjust, if the nature of justice be
5063 at all understood by us. They realize our dream; and he who is the most
5064 of a tyrant by nature, and leads the life of a tyrant for the longest
5065 time, will be the worst of them, and being the worst of them, will also
5066 be the most miserable.
5067 
5068 Like man, like State,--the tyrannical man will answer to tyranny, which
5069 is the extreme opposite of the royal State; for one is the best and the
5070 other the worst. But which is the happier? Great and terrible as the
5071 tyrant may appear enthroned amid his satellites, let us not be afraid to
5072 go in and ask; and the answer is, that the monarchical is the happiest,
5073 and the tyrannical the most miserable of States. And may we not ask the
5074 same question about the men themselves, requesting some one to look into
5075 them who is able to penetrate the inner nature of man, and will not be
5076 panic-struck by the vain pomp of tyranny? I will suppose that he is one
5077 who has lived with him, and has seen him in family life, or perhaps in
5078 the hour of trouble and danger.
5079 
5080 Assuming that we ourselves are the impartial judge for whom we seek, let
5081 us begin by comparing the individual and State, and ask first of all,
5082 whether the State is likely to be free or enslaved--Will there not be
5083 a little freedom and a great deal of slavery? And the freedom is of the
5084 bad, and the slavery of the good; and this applies to the man as well
5085 as to the State; for his soul is full of meanness and slavery, and the
5086 better part is enslaved to the worse. He cannot do what he would, and
5087 his mind is full of confusion; he is the very reverse of a freeman. The
5088 State will be poor and full of misery and sorrow; and the man's soul
5089 will also be poor and full of sorrows, and he will be the most miserable
5090 of men. No, not the most miserable, for there is yet a more miserable.
5091 'Who is that?' The tyrannical man who has the misfortune also to become
5092 a public tyrant. 'There I suspect that you are right.' Say rather, 'I
5093 am sure;' conjecture is out of place in an enquiry of this nature. He
5094 is like a wealthy owner of slaves, only he has more of them than
5095 any private individual. You will say, 'The owners of slaves are not
5096 generally in any fear of them.' But why? Because the whole city is in a
5097 league which protects the individual. Suppose however that one of these
5098 owners and his household is carried off by a god into a wilderness,
5099 where there are no freemen to help him--will he not be in an agony of
5100 terror?--will he not be compelled to flatter his slaves and to promise
5101 them many things sore against his will? And suppose the same god who
5102 carried him off were to surround him with neighbours who declare that no
5103 man ought to have slaves, and that the owners of them should be punished
5104 with death. 'Still worse and worse! He will be in the midst of his
5105 enemies.' And is not our tyrant such a captive soul, who is tormented by
5106 a swarm of passions which he cannot indulge; living indoors always like
5107 a woman, and jealous of those who can go out and see the world?
5108 
5109 Having so many evils, will not the most miserable of men be still more
5110 miserable in a public station? Master of others when he is not master of
5111 himself; like a sick man who is compelled to be an athlete; the meanest
5112 of slaves and the most abject of flatterers; wanting all things, and
5113 never able to satisfy his desires; always in fear and distraction,
5114 like the State of which he is the representative. His jealous,
5115 hateful, faithless temper grows worse with command; he is more and more
5116 faithless, envious, unrighteous,--the most wretched of men, a misery
5117 to himself and to others. And so let us have a final trial and
5118 proclamation; need we hire a herald, or shall I proclaim the result?
5119 'Made the proclamation yourself.' The son of Ariston (the best) is of
5120 opinion that the best and justest of men is also the happiest, and that
5121 this is he who is the most royal master of himself; and that the unjust
5122 man is he who is the greatest tyrant of himself and of his State. And I
5123 add further--'seen or unseen by gods or men.'
5124 
5125 This is our first proof. The second is derived from the three kinds
5126 of pleasure, which answer to the three elements of the soul--reason,
5127 passion, desire; under which last is comprehended avarice as well as
5128 sensual appetite, while passion includes ambition, party-feeling, love
5129 of reputation. Reason, again, is solely directed to the attainment of
5130 truth, and careless of money and reputation. In accordance with the
5131 difference of men's natures, one of these three principles is in the
5132 ascendant, and they have their several pleasures corresponding to them.
5133 Interrogate now the three natures, and each one will be found praising
5134 his own pleasures and depreciating those of others. The money-maker will
5135 contrast the vanity of knowledge with the solid advantages of wealth.
5136 The ambitious man will despise knowledge which brings no honour; whereas
5137 the philosopher will regard only the fruition of truth, and will call
5138 other pleasures necessary rather than good. Now, how shall we decide
5139 between them? Is there any better criterion than experience and
5140 knowledge? And which of the three has the truest knowledge and the
5141 widest experience? The experience of youth makes the philosopher
5142 acquainted with the two kinds of desire, but the avaricious and the
5143 ambitious man never taste the pleasures of truth and wisdom. Honour he
5144 has equally with them; they are 'judged of him,' but he is 'not judged
5145 of them,' for they never attain to the knowledge of true being. And his
5146 instrument is reason, whereas their standard is only wealth and honour;
5147 and if by reason we are to judge, his good will be the truest. And so we
5148 arrive at the result that the pleasure of the rational part of the soul,
5149 and a life passed in such pleasure is the pleasantest. He who has a
5150 right to judge judges thus. Next comes the life of ambition, and, in the
5151 third place, that of money-making.
5152 
5153 Twice has the just man overthrown the unjust--once more, as in an
5154 Olympian contest, first offering up a prayer to the saviour Zeus, let
5155 him try a fall. A wise man whispers to me that the pleasures of the wise
5156 are true and pure; all others are a shadow only. Let us examine this:
5157 Is not pleasure opposed to pain, and is there not a mean state which
5158 is neither? When a man is sick, nothing is more pleasant to him than
5159 health. But this he never found out while he was well. In pain he
5160 desires only to cease from pain; on the other hand, when he is in an
5161 ecstasy of pleasure, rest is painful to him. Thus rest or cessation
5162 is both pleasure and pain. But can that which is neither become both?
5163 Again, pleasure and pain are motions, and the absence of them is rest;
5164 but if so, how can the absence of either of them be the other? Thus
5165 we are led to infer that the contradiction is an appearance only, and
5166 witchery of the senses. And these are not the only pleasures, for there
5167 are others which have no preceding pains. Pure pleasure then is not the
5168 absence of pain, nor pure pain the absence of pleasure; although most of
5169 the pleasures which reach the mind through the body are reliefs of
5170 pain, and have not only their reactions when they depart, but their
5171 anticipations before they come. They can be best described in a simile.
5172 There is in nature an upper, lower, and middle region, and he who passes
5173 from the lower to the middle imagines that he is going up and is already
5174 in the upper world; and if he were taken back again would think,
5175 and truly think, that he was descending. All this arises out of his
5176 ignorance of the true upper, middle, and lower regions. And a like
5177 confusion happens with pleasure and pain, and with many other things.
5178 The man who compares grey with black, calls grey white; and the man who
5179 compares absence of pain with pain, calls the absence of pain pleasure.
5180 Again, hunger and thirst are inanitions of the body, ignorance and folly
5181 of the soul; and food is the satisfaction of the one, knowledge of the
5182 other. Now which is the purer satisfaction--that of eating and drinking,
5183 or that of knowledge? Consider the matter thus: The satisfaction of
5184 that which has more existence is truer than of that which has less. The
5185 invariable and immortal has a more real existence than the variable
5186 and mortal, and has a corresponding measure of knowledge and truth. The
5187 soul, again, has more existence and truth and knowledge than the body,
5188 and is therefore more really satisfied and has a more natural pleasure.
5189 Those who feast only on earthly food, are always going at random up
5190 to the middle and down again; but they never pass into the true upper
5191 world, or have a taste of true pleasure. They are like fatted beasts,
5192 full of gluttony and sensuality, and ready to kill one another by reason
5193 of their insatiable lust; for they are not filled with true being, and
5194 their vessel is leaky (Gorgias). Their pleasures are mere shadows of
5195 pleasure, mixed with pain, coloured and intensified by contrast,
5196 and therefore intensely desired; and men go fighting about them, as
5197 Stesichorus says that the Greeks fought about the shadow of Helen at
5198 Troy, because they know not the truth.
5199 
5200 The same may be said of the passionate element:--the desires of
5201 the ambitious soul, as well as of the covetous, have an inferior
5202 satisfaction. Only when under the guidance of reason do either of the
5203 other principles do their own business or attain the pleasure which is
5204 natural to them. When not attaining, they compel the other parts of the
5205 soul to pursue a shadow of pleasure which is not theirs. And the more
5206 distant they are from philosophy and reason, the more distant they will
5207 be from law and order, and the more illusive will be their pleasures.
5208 The desires of love and tyranny are the farthest from law, and those
5209 of the king are nearest to it. There is one genuine pleasure, and two
5210 spurious ones: the tyrant goes beyond even the latter; he has run away
5211 altogether from law and reason. Nor can the measure of his inferiority
5212 be told, except in a figure. The tyrant is the third removed from the
5213 oligarch, and has therefore, not a shadow of his pleasure, but the
5214 shadow of a shadow only. The oligarch, again, is thrice removed from
5215 the king, and thus we get the formula 3 x 3, which is the number of a
5216 surface, representing the shadow which is the tyrant's pleasure, and
5217 if you like to cube this 'number of the beast,' you will find that the
5218 measure of the difference amounts to 729; the king is 729 times more
5219 happy than the tyrant. And this extraordinary number is NEARLY equal
5220 to the number of days and nights in a year (365 x 2 = 730); and is
5221 therefore concerned with human life. This is the interval between a good
5222 and bad man in happiness only: what must be the difference between them
5223 in comeliness of life and virtue!
5224 
5225 Perhaps you may remember some one saying at the beginning of our
5226 discussion that the unjust man was profited if he had the reputation of
5227 justice. Now that we know the nature of justice and injustice, let us
5228 make an image of the soul, which will personify his words. First of all,
5229 fashion a multitudinous beast, having a ring of heads of all manner of
5230 animals, tame and wild, and able to produce and change them at pleasure.
5231 Suppose now another form of a lion, and another of a man; the second
5232 smaller than the first, the third than the second; join them together
5233 and cover them with a human skin, in which they are completely
5234 concealed. When this has been done, let us tell the supporter of
5235 injustice that he is feeding up the beasts and starving the man. The
5236 maintainer of justice, on the other hand, is trying to strengthen the
5237 man; he is nourishing the gentle principle within him, and making an
5238 alliance with the lion heart, in order that he may be able to keep down
5239 the many-headed hydra, and bring all into unity with each other and
5240 with themselves. Thus in every point of view, whether in relation to
5241 pleasure, honour, or advantage, the just man is right, and the unjust
5242 wrong.
5243 
5244 But now, let us reason with the unjust, who is not intentionally in
5245 error. Is not the noble that which subjects the beast to the man, or
5246 rather to the God in man; the ignoble, that which subjects the man to
5247 the beast? And if so, who would receive gold on condition that he was to
5248 degrade the noblest part of himself under the worst?--who would sell his
5249 son or daughter into the hands of brutal and evil men, for any amount
5250 of money? And will he sell his own fairer and diviner part without any
5251 compunction to the most godless and foul? Would he not be worse than
5252 Eriphyle, who sold her husband's life for a necklace? And intemperance
5253 is the letting loose of the multiform monster, and pride and sullenness
5254 are the growth and increase of the lion and serpent element, while
5255 luxury and effeminacy are caused by a too great relaxation of spirit.
5256 Flattery and meanness again arise when the spirited element is subjected
5257 to avarice, and the lion is habituated to become a monkey. The real
5258 disgrace of handicraft arts is, that those who are engaged in them have
5259 to flatter, instead of mastering their desires; therefore we say that
5260 they should be placed under the control of the better principle in
5261 another because they have none in themselves; not, as Thrasymachus
5262 imagined, to the injury of the subjects, but for their good. And our
5263 intention in educating the young, is to give them self-control; the
5264 law desires to nurse up in them a higher principle, and when they have
5265 acquired this, they may go their ways.
5266 
5267 'What, then, shall a man profit, if he gain the whole world' and become
5268 more and more wicked? Or what shall he profit by escaping discovery, if
5269 the concealment of evil prevents the cure? If he had been punished,
5270 the brute within him would have been silenced, and the gentler element
5271 liberated; and he would have united temperance, justice, and wisdom in
5272 his soul--a union better far than any combination of bodily gifts. The
5273 man of understanding will honour knowledge above all; in the next
5274 place he will keep under his body, not only for the sake of health and
5275 strength, but in order to attain the most perfect harmony of body
5276 and soul. In the acquisition of riches, too, he will aim at order and
5277 harmony; he will not desire to heap up wealth without measure, but he
5278 will fear that the increase of wealth will disturb the constitution of
5279 his own soul. For the same reason he will only accept such honours as
5280 will make him a better man; any others he will decline. 'In that case,'
5281 said he, 'he will never be a politician.' Yes, but he will, in his own
5282 city; though probably not in his native country, unless by some divine
5283 accident. 'You mean that he will be a citizen of the ideal city, which
5284 has no place upon earth.' But in heaven, I replied, there is a pattern
5285 of such a city, and he who wishes may order his life after that image.
5286 Whether such a state is or ever will be matters not; he will act
5287 according to that pattern and no other...
5288 
5289 The most noticeable points in the 9th Book of the Republic are:--(1) the
5290 account of pleasure; (2) the number of the interval which divides the
5291 king from the tyrant; (3) the pattern which is in heaven.
5292 
5293 1. Plato's account of pleasure is remarkable for moderation, and in
5294 this respect contrasts with the later Platonists and the views which are
5295 attributed to them by Aristotle. He is not, like the Cynics, opposed
5296 to all pleasure, but rather desires that the several parts of the
5297 soul shall have their natural satisfaction; he even agrees with the
5298 Epicureans in describing pleasure as something more than the absence of
5299 pain. This is proved by the circumstance that there are pleasures which
5300 have no antecedent pains (as he also remarks in the Philebus), such as
5301 the pleasures of smell, and also the pleasures of hope and anticipation.
5302 In the previous book he had made the distinction between necessary
5303 and unnecessary pleasure, which is repeated by Aristotle, and he now
5304 observes that there are a further class of 'wild beast' pleasures,
5305 corresponding to Aristotle's (Greek). He dwells upon the relative and
5306 unreal character of sensual pleasures and the illusion which arises out
5307 of the contrast of pleasure and pain, pointing out the superiority of
5308 the pleasures of reason, which are at rest, over the fleeting pleasures
5309 of sense and emotion. The pre-eminence of royal pleasure is shown by
5310 the fact that reason is able to form a judgment of the lower pleasures,
5311 while the two lower parts of the soul are incapable of judging the
5312 pleasures of reason. Thus, in his treatment of pleasure, as in many
5313 other subjects, the philosophy of Plato is 'sawn up into quantities' by
5314 Aristotle; the analysis which was originally made by him became in the
5315 next generation the foundation of further technical distinctions. Both
5316 in Plato and Aristotle we note the illusion under which the ancients
5317 fell of regarding the transience of pleasure as a proof of its
5318 unreality, and of confounding the permanence of the intellectual
5319 pleasures with the unchangeableness of the knowledge from which they are
5320 derived. Neither do we like to admit that the pleasures of knowledge,
5321 though more elevating, are not more lasting than other pleasures,
5322 and are almost equally dependent on the accidents of our bodily state
5323 (Introduction to Philebus).
5324 
5325 2. The number of the interval which separates the king from the tyrant,
5326 and royal from tyrannical pleasures, is 729, the cube of 9. Which Plato
5327 characteristically designates as a number concerned with human life,
5328 because NEARLY equivalent to the number of days and nights in the
5329 year. He is desirous of proclaiming that the interval between them is
5330 immeasurable, and invents a formula to give expression to his idea.
5331 Those who spoke of justice as a cube, of virtue as an art of measuring
5332 (Prot.), saw no inappropriateness in conceiving the soul under the
5333 figure of a line, or the pleasure of the tyrant as separated from the
5334 pleasure of the king by the numerical interval of 729. And in modern
5335 times we sometimes use metaphorically what Plato employed as a
5336 philosophical formula. 'It is not easy to estimate the loss of the
5337 tyrant, except perhaps in this way,' says Plato. So we might say, that
5338 although the life of a good man is not to be compared to that of a bad
5339 man, yet you may measure the difference between them by valuing one
5340 minute of the one at an hour of the other ('One day in thy courts is
5341 better than a thousand'), or you might say that 'there is an infinite
5342 difference.' But this is not so much as saying, in homely phrase, 'They
5343 are a thousand miles asunder.' And accordingly Plato finds the natural
5344 vehicle of his thoughts in a progression of numbers; this arithmetical
5345 formula he draws out with the utmost seriousness, and both here and in
5346 the number of generation seems to find an additional proof of the truth
5347 of his speculation in forming the number into a geometrical figure; just
5348 as persons in our own day are apt to fancy that a statement is verified
5349 when it has been only thrown into an abstract form. In speaking of the
5350 number 729 as proper to human life, he probably intended to intimate
5351 that one year of the tyrannical = 12 hours of the royal life.
5352 
5353 The simple observation that the comparison of two similar solids
5354 is effected by the comparison of the cubes of their sides, is the
5355 mathematical groundwork of this fanciful expression. There is some
5356 difficulty in explaining the steps by which the number 729 is obtained;
5357 the oligarch is removed in the third degree from the royal and
5358 aristocratical, and the tyrant in the third degree from the
5359 oligarchical; but we have to arrange the terms as the sides of a square
5360 and to count the oligarch twice over, thus reckoning them not as = 5 but
5361 as = 9. The square of 9 is passed lightly over as only a step towards
5362 the cube.
5363 
5364 3. Towards the close of the Republic, Plato seems to be more and more
5365 convinced of the ideal character of his own speculations. At the end of
5366 the 9th Book the pattern which is in heaven takes the place of the
5367 city of philosophers on earth. The vision which has received form and
5368 substance at his hands, is now discovered to be at a distance. And yet
5369 this distant kingdom is also the rule of man's life. ('Say not lo! here,
5370 or lo! there, for the kingdom of God is within you.') Thus a note
5371 is struck which prepares for the revelation of a future life in the
5372 following Book. But the future life is present still; the ideal of
5373 politics is to be realized in the individual.
5374 
5375 BOOK X. Many things pleased me in the order of our State, but there
5376 was nothing which I liked better than the regulation about poetry. The
5377 division of the soul throws a new light on our exclusion of imitation.
5378 I do not mind telling you in confidence that all poetry is an outrage on
5379 the understanding, unless the hearers have that balm of knowledge which
5380 heals error. I have loved Homer ever since I was a boy, and even now
5381 he appears to me to be the great master of tragic poetry. But much as
5382 I love the man, I love truth more, and therefore I must speak out: and
5383 first of all, will you explain what is imitation, for really I do not
5384 understand? 'How likely then that I should understand!' That might very
5385 well be, for the duller often sees better than the keener eye. 'True,
5386 but in your presence I can hardly venture to say what I think.'
5387 Then suppose that we begin in our old fashion, with the doctrine of
5388 universals. Let us assume the existence of beds and tables. There is one
5389 idea of a bed, or of a table, which the maker of each had in his mind
5390 when making them; he did not make the ideas of beds and tables, but he
5391 made beds and tables according to the ideas. And is there not a maker
5392 of the works of all workmen, who makes not only vessels but plants and
5393 animals, himself, the earth and heaven, and things in heaven and under
5394 the earth? He makes the Gods also. 'He must be a wizard indeed!' But do
5395 you not see that there is a sense in which you could do the same? You
5396 have only to take a mirror, and catch the reflection of the sun, and the
5397 earth, or anything else--there now you have made them. 'Yes, but only
5398 in appearance.' Exactly so; and the painter is such a creator as you are
5399 with the mirror, and he is even more unreal than the carpenter; although
5400 neither the carpenter nor any other artist can be supposed to make the
5401 absolute bed. 'Not if philosophers may be believed.' Nor need we wonder
5402 that his bed has but an imperfect relation to the truth. Reflect:--Here
5403 are three beds; one in nature, which is made by God; another, which is
5404 made by the carpenter; and the third, by the painter. God only made one,
5405 nor could he have made more than one; for if there had been two, there
5406 would always have been a third--more absolute and abstract than either,
5407 under which they would have been included. We may therefore conceive God
5408 to be the natural maker of the bed, and in a lower sense the carpenter
5409 is also the maker; but the painter is rather the imitator of what the
5410 other two make; he has to do with a creation which is thrice removed
5411 from reality. And the tragic poet is an imitator, and, like every
5412 other imitator, is thrice removed from the king and from the truth.
5413 The painter imitates not the original bed, but the bed made by the
5414 carpenter. And this, without being really different, appears to be
5415 different, and has many points of view, of which only one is caught by
5416 the painter, who represents everything because he represents a piece of
5417 everything, and that piece an image. And he can paint any other artist,
5418 although he knows nothing of their arts; and this with sufficient skill
5419 to deceive children or simple people. Suppose now that somebody came to
5420 us and told us, how he had met a man who knew all that everybody knows,
5421 and better than anybody:--should we not infer him to be a simpleton who,
5422 having no discernment of truth and falsehood, had met with a wizard
5423 or enchanter, whom he fancied to be all-wise? And when we hear persons
5424 saying that Homer and the tragedians know all the arts and all the
5425 virtues, must we not infer that they are under a similar delusion? they
5426 do not see that the poets are imitators, and that their creations are
5427 only imitations. 'Very true.' But if a person could create as well as
5428 imitate, he would rather leave some permanent work and not an imitation
5429 only; he would rather be the receiver than the giver of praise? 'Yes,
5430 for then he would have more honour and advantage.'
5431 
5432 Let us now interrogate Homer and the poets. Friend Homer, say I to him,
5433 I am not going to ask you about medicine, or any art to which your
5434 poems incidentally refer, but about their main subjects--war, military
5435 tactics, politics. If you are only twice and not thrice removed from the
5436 truth--not an imitator or an image-maker, please to inform us what good
5437 you have ever done to mankind? Is there any city which professes to have
5438 received laws from you, as Sicily and Italy have from Charondas, Sparta
5439 from Lycurgus, Athens from Solon? Or was any war ever carried on by your
5440 counsels? or is any invention attributed to you, as there is to Thales
5441 and Anacharsis? Or is there any Homeric way of life, such as the
5442 Pythagorean was, in which you instructed men, and which is called after
5443 you? 'No, indeed; and Creophylus (Flesh-child) was even more unfortunate
5444 in his breeding than he was in his name, if, as tradition says, Homer in
5445 his lifetime was allowed by him and his other friends to starve.' Yes,
5446 but could this ever have happened if Homer had really been the educator
5447 of Hellas? Would he not have had many devoted followers? If Protagoras
5448 and Prodicus can persuade their contemporaries that no one can manage
5449 house or State without them, is it likely that Homer and Hesiod would
5450 have been allowed to go about as beggars--I mean if they had really been
5451 able to do the world any good?--would not men have compelled them
5452 to stay where they were, or have followed them about in order to get
5453 education? But they did not; and therefore we may infer that Homer and
5454 all the poets are only imitators, who do but imitate the appearances of
5455 things. For as a painter by a knowledge of figure and colour can paint a
5456 cobbler without any practice in cobbling, so the poet can delineate
5457 any art in the colours of language, and give harmony and rhythm to the
5458 cobbler and also to the general; and you know how mere narration, when
5459 deprived of the ornaments of metre, is like a face which has lost the
5460 beauty of youth and never had any other. Once more, the imitator has no
5461 knowledge of reality, but only of appearance. The painter paints, and
5462 the artificer makes a bridle and reins, but neither understands the use
5463 of them--the knowledge of this is confined to the horseman; and so of
5464 other things. Thus we have three arts: one of use, another of invention,
5465 a third of imitation; and the user furnishes the rule to the two others.
5466 The flute-player will know the good and bad flute, and the maker
5467 will put faith in him; but the imitator will neither know nor have
5468 faith--neither science nor true opinion can be ascribed to him.
5469 Imitation, then, is devoid of knowledge, being only a kind of play
5470 or sport, and the tragic and epic poets are imitators in the highest
5471 degree.
5472 
5473 And now let us enquire, what is the faculty in man which answers to
5474 imitation. Allow me to explain my meaning: Objects are differently seen
5475 when in the water and when out of the water, when near and when at a
5476 distance; and the painter or juggler makes use of this variation to
5477 impose upon us. And the art of measuring and weighing and calculating
5478 comes in to save our bewildered minds from the power of appearance; for,
5479 as we were saying, two contrary opinions of the same about the same and
5480 at the same time, cannot both of them be true. But which of them is
5481 true is determined by the art of calculation; and this is allied to the
5482 better faculty in the soul, as the arts of imitation are to the worse.
5483 And the same holds of the ear as well as of the eye, of poetry as well
5484 as painting. The imitation is of actions voluntary or involuntary,
5485 in which there is an expectation of a good or bad result, and present
5486 experience of pleasure and pain. But is a man in harmony with himself
5487 when he is the subject of these conflicting influences? Is there not
5488 rather a contradiction in him? Let me further ask, whether he is more
5489 likely to control sorrow when he is alone or when he is in company.
5490 'In the latter case.' Feeling would lead him to indulge his sorrow, but
5491 reason and law control him and enjoin patience; since he cannot know
5492 whether his affliction is good or evil, and no human thing is of
5493 any great consequence, while sorrow is certainly a hindrance to good
5494 counsel. For when we stumble, we should not, like children, make an
5495 uproar; we should take the measures which reason prescribes, not raising
5496 a lament, but finding a cure. And the better part of us is ready to
5497 follow reason, while the irrational principle is full of sorrow and
5498 distraction at the recollection of our troubles. Unfortunately, however,
5499 this latter furnishes the chief materials of the imitative arts. Whereas
5500 reason is ever in repose and cannot easily be displayed, especially to a
5501 mixed multitude who have no experience of her. Thus the poet is like the
5502 painter in two ways: first he paints an inferior degree of truth, and
5503 secondly, he is concerned with an inferior part of the soul. He indulges
5504 the feelings, while he enfeebles the reason; and we refuse to allow him
5505 to have authority over the mind of man; for he has no measure of greater
5506 and less, and is a maker of images and very far gone from truth.
5507 
5508 But we have not yet mentioned the heaviest count in the indictment--the
5509 power which poetry has of injuriously exciting the feelings. When we
5510 hear some passage in which a hero laments his sufferings at tedious
5511 length, you know that we sympathize with him and praise the poet; and
5512 yet in our own sorrows such an exhibition of feeling is regarded as
5513 effeminate and unmanly (Ion). Now, ought a man to feel pleasure in
5514 seeing another do what he hates and abominates in himself? Is he not
5515 giving way to a sentiment which in his own case he would control?--he is
5516 off his guard because the sorrow is another's; and he thinks that he
5517 may indulge his feelings without disgrace, and will be the gainer by
5518 the pleasure. But the inevitable consequence is that he who begins by
5519 weeping at the sorrows of others, will end by weeping at his own. The
5520 same is true of comedy,--you may often laugh at buffoonery which you
5521 would be ashamed to utter, and the love of coarse merriment on the stage
5522 will at last turn you into a buffoon at home. Poetry feeds and waters
5523 the passions and desires; she lets them rule instead of ruling them. And
5524 therefore, when we hear the encomiasts of Homer affirming that he is
5525 the educator of Hellas, and that all life should be regulated by his
5526 precepts, we may allow the excellence of their intentions, and agree
5527 with them in thinking Homer a great poet and tragedian. But we shall
5528 continue to prohibit all poetry which goes beyond hymns to the Gods and
5529 praises of famous men. Not pleasure and pain, but law and reason shall
5530 rule in our State.
5531 
5532 These are our grounds for expelling poetry; but lest she should charge
5533 us with discourtesy, let us also make an apology to her. We will remind
5534 her that there is an ancient quarrel between poetry and philosophy, of
5535 which there are many traces in the writings of the poets, such as the
5536 saying of 'the she-dog, yelping at her mistress,' and 'the philosophers
5537 who are ready to circumvent Zeus,' and 'the philosophers who are
5538 paupers.' Nevertheless we bear her no ill-will, and will gladly allow
5539 her to return upon condition that she makes a defence of herself in
5540 verse; and her supporters who are not poets may speak in prose. We
5541 confess her charms; but if she cannot show that she is useful as well
5542 as delightful, like rational lovers, we must renounce our love,
5543 though endeared to us by early associations. Having come to years of
5544 discretion, we know that poetry is not truth, and that a man should be
5545 careful how he introduces her to that state or constitution which he
5546 himself is; for there is a mighty issue at stake--no less than the good
5547 or evil of a human soul. And it is not worth while to forsake justice
5548 and virtue for the attractions of poetry, any more than for the sake of
5549 honour or wealth. 'I agree with you.'
5550 
5551 And yet the rewards of virtue are greater far than I have described.
5552 'And can we conceive things greater still?' Not, perhaps, in this brief
5553 span of life: but should an immortal being care about anything short of
5554 eternity? 'I do not understand what you mean?' Do you not know that the
5555 soul is immortal? 'Surely you are not prepared to prove that?' Indeed I
5556 am. 'Then let me hear this argument, of which you make so light.'
5557 
5558 You would admit that everything has an element of good and of evil. In
5559 all things there is an inherent corruption; and if this cannot destroy
5560 them, nothing else will. The soul too has her own corrupting principles,
5561 which are injustice, intemperance, cowardice, and the like. But none of
5562 these destroy the soul in the same sense that disease destroys the body.
5563 The soul may be full of all iniquities, but is not, by reason of them,
5564 brought any nearer to death. Nothing which was not destroyed from within
5565 ever perished by external affection of evil. The body, which is one
5566 thing, cannot be destroyed by food, which is another, unless the badness
5567 of the food is communicated to the body. Neither can the soul, which
5568 is one thing, be corrupted by the body, which is another, unless she
5569 herself is infected. And as no bodily evil can infect the soul, neither
5570 can any bodily evil, whether disease or violence, or any other destroy
5571 the soul, unless it can be shown to render her unholy and unjust. But no
5572 one will ever prove that the souls of men become more unjust when
5573 they die. If a person has the audacity to say the contrary, the answer
5574 is--Then why do criminals require the hand of the executioner, and
5575 not die of themselves? 'Truly,' he said, 'injustice would not be very
5576 terrible if it brought a cessation of evil; but I rather believe that
5577 the injustice which murders others may tend to quicken and stimulate
5578 the life of the unjust.' You are quite right. If sin which is her own
5579 natural and inherent evil cannot destroy the soul, hardly will anything
5580 else destroy her. But the soul which cannot be destroyed either by
5581 internal or external evil must be immortal and everlasting. And if
5582 this be true, souls will always exist in the same number. They cannot
5583 diminish, because they cannot be destroyed; nor yet increase, for the
5584 increase of the immortal must come from something mortal, and so all
5585 would end in immortality. Neither is the soul variable and diverse; for
5586 that which is immortal must be of the fairest and simplest composition.
5587 If we would conceive her truly, and so behold justice and injustice in
5588 their own nature, she must be viewed by the light of reason pure as at
5589 birth, or as she is reflected in philosophy when holding converse with
5590 the divine and immortal and eternal. In her present condition we see her
5591 only like the sea-god Glaucus, bruised and maimed in the sea which is
5592 the world, and covered with shells and stones which are incrusted upon
5593 her from the entertainments of earth.
5594 
5595 Thus far, as the argument required, we have said nothing of the rewards
5596 and honours which the poets attribute to justice; we have contented
5597 ourselves with showing that justice in herself is best for the soul in
5598 herself, even if a man should put on a Gyges' ring and have the helmet
5599 of Hades too. And now you shall repay me what you borrowed; and I will
5600 enumerate the rewards of justice in life and after death. I granted,
5601 for the sake of argument, as you will remember, that evil might
5602 perhaps escape the knowledge of Gods and men, although this was really
5603 impossible. And since I have shown that justice has reality, you must
5604 grant me also that she has the palm of appearance. In the first place,
5605 the just man is known to the Gods, and he is therefore the friend of the
5606 Gods, and he will receive at their hands every good, always excepting
5607 such evil as is the necessary consequence of former sins. All things end
5608 in good to him, either in life or after death, even what appears to
5609 be evil; for the Gods have a care of him who desires to be in their
5610 likeness. And what shall we say of men? Is not honesty the best policy?
5611 The clever rogue makes a great start at first, but breaks down before he
5612 reaches the goal, and slinks away in dishonour; whereas the true runner
5613 perseveres to the end, and receives the prize. And you must allow me
5614 to repeat all the blessings which you attributed to the fortunate
5615 unjust--they bear rule in the city, they marry and give in marriage to
5616 whom they will; and the evils which you attributed to the unfortunate
5617 just, do really fall in the end on the unjust, although, as you implied,
5618 their sufferings are better veiled in silence.
5619 
5620 But all the blessings of this present life are as nothing when compared
5621 with those which await good men after death. 'I should like to hear
5622 about them.' Come, then, and I will tell you the story of Er, the son of
5623 Armenius, a valiant man. He was supposed to have died in battle, but ten
5624 days afterwards his body was found untouched by corruption and sent home
5625 for burial. On the twelfth day he was placed on the funeral pyre and
5626 there he came to life again, and told what he had seen in the world
5627 below. He said that his soul went with a great company to a place, in
5628 which there were two chasms near together in the earth beneath, and two
5629 corresponding chasms in the heaven above. And there were judges sitting
5630 in the intermediate space, bidding the just ascend by the heavenly
5631 way on the right hand, having the seal of their judgment set upon them
5632 before, while the unjust, having the seal behind, were bidden to descend
5633 by the way on the left hand. Him they told to look and listen, as he was
5634 to be their messenger to men from the world below. And he beheld and saw
5635 the souls departing after judgment at either chasm; some who came from
5636 earth, were worn and travel-stained; others, who came from heaven,
5637 were clean and bright. They seemed glad to meet and rest awhile in the
5638 meadow; here they discoursed with one another of what they had seen in
5639 the other world. Those who came from earth wept at the remembrance of
5640 their sorrows, but the spirits from above spoke of glorious sights and
5641 heavenly bliss. He said that for every evil deed they were punished
5642 tenfold--now the journey was of a thousand years' duration, because the
5643 life of man was reckoned as a hundred years--and the rewards of virtue
5644 were in the same proportion. He added something hardly worth repeating
5645 about infants dying almost as soon as they were born. Of parricides and
5646 other murderers he had tortures still more terrible to narrate. He was
5647 present when one of the spirits asked--Where is Ardiaeus the Great?
5648 (This Ardiaeus was a cruel tyrant, who had murdered his father, and his
5649 elder brother, a thousand years before.) Another spirit answered,
5650 'He comes not hither, and will never come. And I myself,' he added,
5651 'actually saw this terrible sight. At the entrance of the chasm, as we
5652 were about to reascend, Ardiaeus appeared, and some other sinners--most
5653 of whom had been tyrants, but not all--and just as they fancied that
5654 they were returning to life, the chasm gave a roar, and then wild,
5655 fiery-looking men who knew the meaning of the sound, seized him and
5656 several others, and bound them hand and foot and threw them down, and
5657 dragged them along at the side of the road, lacerating them and carding
5658 them like wool, and explaining to the passers-by, that they were going
