5659 to be cast into hell.' The greatest terror of the pilgrims ascending was
5660 lest they should hear the voice, and when there was silence one by one
5661 they passed up with joy. To these sufferings there were corresponding
5662 delights.
5663 
5664 On the eighth day the souls of the pilgrims resumed their journey,
5665 and in four days came to a spot whence they looked down upon a line of
5666 light, in colour like a rainbow, only brighter and clearer. One day
5667 more brought them to the place, and they saw that this was the column
5668 of light which binds together the whole universe. The ends of the column
5669 were fastened to heaven, and from them hung the distaff of Necessity,
5670 on which all the heavenly bodies turned--the hook and spindle were of
5671 adamant, and the whorl of a mixed substance. The whorl was in form
5672 like a number of boxes fitting into one another with their edges
5673 turned upwards, making together a single whorl which was pierced by the
5674 spindle. The outermost had the rim broadest, and the inner whorls were
5675 smaller and smaller, and had their rims narrower. The largest (the fixed
5676 stars) was spangled--the seventh (the sun) was brightest--the eighth
5677 (the moon) shone by the light of the seventh--the second and fifth
5678 (Saturn and Mercury) were most like one another and yellower than the
5679 eighth--the third (Jupiter) had the whitest light--the fourth (Mars)
5680 was red--the sixth (Venus) was in whiteness second. The whole had one
5681 motion, but while this was revolving in one direction the seven inner
5682 circles were moving in the opposite, with various degrees of swiftness
5683 and slowness. The spindle turned on the knees of Necessity, and a Siren
5684 stood hymning upon each circle, while Lachesis, Clotho, and Atropos, the
5685 daughters of Necessity, sat on thrones at equal intervals, singing of
5686 past, present, and future, responsive to the music of the Sirens; Clotho
5687 from time to time guiding the outer circle with a touch of her right
5688 hand; Atropos with her left hand touching and guiding the inner circles;
5689 Lachesis in turn putting forth her hand from time to time to guide both
5690 of them. On their arrival the pilgrims went to Lachesis, and there was
5691 an interpreter who arranged them, and taking from her knees lots, and
5692 samples of lives, got up into a pulpit and said: 'Mortal souls, hear
5693 the words of Lachesis, the daughter of Necessity. A new period of
5694 mortal life has begun, and you may choose what divinity you please;
5695 the responsibility of choosing is with you--God is blameless.' After
5696 speaking thus, he cast the lots among them and each one took up the
5697 lot which fell near him. He then placed on the ground before them the
5698 samples of lives, many more than the souls present; and there were all
5699 sorts of lives, of men and of animals. There were tyrannies ending in
5700 misery and exile, and lives of men and women famous for their different
5701 qualities; and also mixed lives, made up of wealth and poverty,
5702 sickness and health. Here, Glaucon, is the great risk of human life, and
5703 therefore the whole of education should be directed to the acquisition
5704 of such a knowledge as will teach a man to refuse the evil and choose
5705 the good. He should know all the combinations which occur in life--of
5706 beauty with poverty or with wealth,--of knowledge with external
5707 goods,--and at last choose with reference to the nature of the soul,
5708 regarding that only as the better life which makes men better, and
5709 leaving the rest. And a man must take with him an iron sense of truth
5710 and right into the world below, that there too he may remain undazzled
5711 by wealth or the allurements of evil, and be determined to avoid the
5712 extremes and choose the mean. For this, as the messenger reported the
5713 interpreter to have said, is the true happiness of man; and any one, as
5714 he proclaimed, may, if he choose with understanding, have a good lot,
5715 even though he come last. 'Let not the first be careless in his choice,
5716 nor the last despair.' He spoke; and when he had spoken, he who had
5717 drawn the first lot chose a tyranny: he did not see that he was fated to
5718 devour his own children--and when he discovered his mistake, he wept
5719 and beat his breast, blaming chance and the Gods and anybody rather
5720 than himself. He was one of those who had come from heaven, and in his
5721 previous life had been a citizen of a well-ordered State, but he had
5722 only habit and no philosophy. Like many another, he made a bad choice,
5723 because he had no experience of life; whereas those who came from earth
5724 and had seen trouble were not in such a hurry to choose. But if a
5725 man had followed philosophy while upon earth, and had been moderately
5726 fortunate in his lot, he might not only be happy here, but his
5727 pilgrimage both from and to this world would be smooth and heavenly.
5728 Nothing was more curious than the spectacle of the choice, at once sad
5729 and laughable and wonderful; most of the souls only seeking to avoid
5730 their own condition in a previous life. He saw the soul of Orpheus
5731 changing into a swan because he would not be born of a woman; there was
5732 Thamyras becoming a nightingale; musical birds, like the swan, choosing
5733 to be men; the twentieth soul, which was that of Ajax, preferring the
5734 life of a lion to that of a man, in remembrance of the injustice which
5735 was done to him in the judgment of the arms; and Agamemnon, from a like
5736 enmity to human nature, passing into an eagle. About the middle was the
5737 soul of Atalanta choosing the honours of an athlete, and next to her
5738 Epeus taking the nature of a workwoman; among the last was Thersites,
5739 who was changing himself into a monkey. Thither, the last of all, came
5740 Odysseus, and sought the lot of a private man, which lay neglected and
5741 despised, and when he found it he went away rejoicing, and said that if
5742 he had been first instead of last, his choice would have been the same.
5743 Men, too, were seen passing into animals, and wild and tame animals
5744 changing into one another.
5745 
5746 When all the souls had chosen they went to Lachesis, who sent with each
5747 of them their genius or attendant to fulfil their lot. He first of
5748 all brought them under the hand of Clotho, and drew them within the
5749 revolution of the spindle impelled by her hand; from her they were
5750 carried to Atropos, who made the threads irreversible; whence, without
5751 turning round, they passed beneath the throne of Necessity; and when
5752 they had all passed, they moved on in scorching heat to the plain of
5753 Forgetfulness and rested at evening by the river Unmindful, whose water
5754 could not be retained in any vessel; of this they had all to drink a
5755 certain quantity--some of them drank more than was required, and he who
5756 drank forgot all things. Er himself was prevented from drinking.
5757 When they had gone to rest, about the middle of the night there were
5758 thunderstorms and earthquakes, and suddenly they were all driven divers
5759 ways, shooting like stars to their birth. Concerning his return to the
5760 body, he only knew that awaking suddenly in the morning he found himself
5761 lying on the pyre.
5762 
5763 Thus, Glaucon, the tale has been saved, and will be our salvation, if we
5764 believe that the soul is immortal, and hold fast to the heavenly way
5765 of Justice and Knowledge. So shall we pass undefiled over the river
5766 of Forgetfulness, and be dear to ourselves and to the Gods, and have
5767 a crown of reward and happiness both in this world and also in the
5768 millennial pilgrimage of the other.
5769 
5770 The Tenth Book of the Republic of Plato falls into two divisions: first,
5771 resuming an old thread which has been interrupted, Socrates assails the
5772 poets, who, now that the nature of the soul has been analyzed, are
5773 seen to be very far gone from the truth; and secondly, having shown the
5774 reality of the happiness of the just, he demands that appearance shall
5775 be restored to him, and then proceeds to prove the immortality of the
5776 soul. The argument, as in the Phaedo and Gorgias, is supplemented by the
5777 vision of a future life.
5778 
5779 Why Plato, who was himself a poet, and whose dialogues are poems and
5780 dramas, should have been hostile to the poets as a class, and especially
5781 to the dramatic poets; why he should not have seen that truth may
5782 be embodied in verse as well as in prose, and that there are some
5783 indefinable lights and shadows of human life which can only be expressed
5784 in poetry--some elements of imagination which always entwine with
5785 reason; why he should have supposed epic verse to be inseparably
5786 associated with the impurities of the old Hellenic mythology; why
5787 he should try Homer and Hesiod by the unfair and prosaic test of
5788 utility,--are questions which have always been debated amongst students
5789 of Plato. Though unable to give a complete answer to them, we may
5790 show--first, that his views arose naturally out of the circumstances
5791 of his age; and secondly, we may elicit the truth as well as the error
5792 which is contained in them.
5793 
5794 He is the enemy of the poets because poetry was declining in his own
5795 lifetime, and a theatrocracy, as he says in the Laws, had taken the
5796 place of an intellectual aristocracy. Euripides exhibited the last phase
5797 of the tragic drama, and in him Plato saw the friend and apologist of
5798 tyrants, and the Sophist of tragedy. The old comedy was almost extinct;
5799 the new had not yet arisen. Dramatic and lyric poetry, like every other
5800 branch of Greek literature, was falling under the power of rhetoric.
5801 There was no 'second or third' to Aeschylus and Sophocles in the
5802 generation which followed them. Aristophanes, in one of his later
5803 comedies (Frogs), speaks of 'thousands of tragedy-making prattlers,'
5804 whose attempts at poetry he compares to the chirping of swallows; 'their
5805 garrulity went far beyond Euripides,'--'they appeared once upon the
5806 stage, and there was an end of them.' To a man of genius who had a
5807 real appreciation of the godlike Aeschylus and the noble and gentle
5808 Sophocles, though disagreeing with some parts of their 'theology'
5809 (Rep.), these 'minor poets' must have been contemptible and intolerable.
5810 There is no feeling stronger in the dialogues of Plato than a sense of
5811 the decline and decay both in literature and in politics which marked
5812 his own age. Nor can he have been expected to look with favour on the
5813 licence of Aristophanes, now at the end of his career, who had begun by
5814 satirizing Socrates in the Clouds, and in a similar spirit forty years
5815 afterwards had satirized the founders of ideal commonwealths in his
5816 Eccleziazusae, or Female Parliament (Laws).
5817 
5818 There were other reasons for the antagonism of Plato to poetry. The
5819 profession of an actor was regarded by him as a degradation of human
5820 nature, for 'one man in his life' cannot 'play many parts;' the
5821 characters which the actor performs seem to destroy his own character,
5822 and to leave nothing which can be truly called himself. Neither can any
5823 man live his life and act it. The actor is the slave of his art, not the
5824 master of it. Taking this view Plato is more decided in his expulsion of
5825 the dramatic than of the epic poets, though he must have known that
5826 the Greek tragedians afforded noble lessons and examples of virtue
5827 and patriotism, to which nothing in Homer can be compared. But great
5828 dramatic or even great rhetorical power is hardly consistent with
5829 firmness or strength of mind, and dramatic talent is often incidentally
5830 associated with a weak or dissolute character.
5831 
5832 In the Tenth Book Plato introduces a new series of objections. First,
5833 he says that the poet or painter is an imitator, and in the third
5834 degree removed from the truth. His creations are not tested by rule and
5835 measure; they are only appearances. In modern times we should say that
5836 art is not merely imitation, but rather the expression of the ideal in
5837 forms of sense. Even adopting the humble image of Plato, from which
5838 his argument derives a colour, we should maintain that the artist may
5839 ennoble the bed which he paints by the folds of the drapery, or by the
5840 feeling of home which he introduces; and there have been modern
5841 painters who have imparted such an ideal interest to a blacksmith's or
5842 a carpenter's shop. The eye or mind which feels as well as sees can give
5843 dignity and pathos to a ruined mill, or a straw-built shed (Rembrandt),
5844 to the hull of a vessel 'going to its last home' (Turner). Still more
5845 would this apply to the greatest works of art, which seem to be the
5846 visible embodiment of the divine. Had Plato been asked whether the Zeus
5847 or Athene of Pheidias was the imitation of an imitation only, would he
5848 not have been compelled to admit that something more was to be found in
5849 them than in the form of any mortal; and that the rule of proportion
5850 to which they conformed was 'higher far than any geometry or arithmetic
5851 could express?' (Statesman.)
5852 
5853 Again, Plato objects to the imitative arts that they express the
5854 emotional rather than the rational part of human nature. He does not
5855 admit Aristotle's theory, that tragedy or other serious imitations are
5856 a purgation of the passions by pity and fear; to him they appear only to
5857 afford the opportunity of indulging them. Yet we must acknowledge that
5858 we may sometimes cure disordered emotions by giving expression to them;
5859 and that they often gain strength when pent up within our own breast.
5860 It is not every indulgence of the feelings which is to be condemned.
5861 For there may be a gratification of the higher as well as of the
5862 lower--thoughts which are too deep or too sad to be expressed by
5863 ourselves, may find an utterance in the words of poets. Every one would
5864 acknowledge that there have been times when they were consoled and
5865 elevated by beautiful music or by the sublimity of architecture or by
5866 the peacefulness of nature. Plato has himself admitted, in the earlier
5867 part of the Republic, that the arts might have the effect of harmonizing
5868 as well as of enervating the mind; but in the Tenth Book he regards them
5869 through a Stoic or Puritan medium. He asks only 'What good have they
5870 done?' and is not satisfied with the reply, that 'They have given
5871 innocent pleasure to mankind.'
5872 
5873 He tells us that he rejoices in the banishment of the poets, since he
5874 has found by the analysis of the soul that they are concerned with the
5875 inferior faculties. He means to say that the higher faculties have to do
5876 with universals, the lower with particulars of sense. The poets are on
5877 a level with their own age, but not on a level with Socrates and Plato;
5878 and he was well aware that Homer and Hesiod could not be made a rule of
5879 life by any process of legitimate interpretation; his ironical use of
5880 them is in fact a denial of their authority; he saw, too, that the
5881 poets were not critics--as he says in the Apology, 'Any one was a better
5882 interpreter of their writings than they were themselves. He himself
5883 ceased to be a poet when he became a disciple of Socrates; though, as he
5884 tells us of Solon, 'he might have been one of the greatest of them, if
5885 he had not been deterred by other pursuits' (Tim.) Thus from many points
5886 of view there is an antagonism between Plato and the poets, which was
5887 foreshadowed to him in the old quarrel between philosophy and poetry.
5888 The poets, as he says in the Protagoras, were the Sophists of their day;
5889 and his dislike of the one class is reflected on the other. He regards
5890 them both as the enemies of reasoning and abstraction, though in the
5891 case of Euripides more with reference to his immoral sentiments about
5892 tyrants and the like. For Plato is the prophet who 'came into the world
5893 to convince men'--first of the fallibility of sense and opinion, and
5894 secondly of the reality of abstract ideas. Whatever strangeness there
5895 may be in modern times in opposing philosophy to poetry, which to us
5896 seem to have so many elements in common, the strangeness will disappear
5897 if we conceive of poetry as allied to sense, and of philosophy as
5898 equivalent to thought and abstraction. Unfortunately the very word
5899 'idea,' which to Plato is expressive of the most real of all things, is
5900 associated in our minds with an element of subjectiveness and unreality.
5901 We may note also how he differs from Aristotle who declares poetry to
5902 be truer than history, for the opposite reason, because it is concerned
5903 with universals, not like history, with particulars (Poet).
5904 
5905 The things which are seen are opposed in Scripture to the things which
5906 are unseen--they are equally opposed in Plato to universals and ideas.
5907 To him all particulars appear to be floating about in a world of sense;
5908 they have a taint of error or even of evil. There is no difficulty in
5909 seeing that this is an illusion; for there is no more error or variation
5910 in an individual man, horse, bed, etc., than in the class man, horse,
5911 bed, etc.; nor is the truth which is displayed in individual instances
5912 less certain than that which is conveyed through the medium of
5913 ideas. But Plato, who is deeply impressed with the real importance of
5914 universals as instruments of thought, attributes to them an essential
5915 truth which is imaginary and unreal; for universals may be often false
5916 and particulars true. Had he attained to any clear conception of the
5917 individual, which is the synthesis of the universal and the particular;
5918 or had he been able to distinguish between opinion and sensation, which
5919 the ambiguity of the words (Greek) and the like, tended to confuse, he
5920 would not have denied truth to the particulars of sense.
5921 
5922 But the poets are also the representatives of falsehood and feigning
5923 in all departments of life and knowledge, like the sophists and
5924 rhetoricians of the Gorgias and Phaedrus; they are the false priests,
5925 false prophets, lying spirits, enchanters of the world. There is another
5926 count put into the indictment against them by Plato, that they are
5927 the friends of the tyrant, and bask in the sunshine of his patronage.
5928 Despotism in all ages has had an apparatus of false ideas and false
5929 teachers at its service--in the history of Modern Europe as well as of
5930 Greece and Rome. For no government of men depends solely upon force;
5931 without some corruption of literature and morals--some appeal to the
5932 imagination of the masses--some pretence to the favour of heaven--some
5933 element of good giving power to evil, tyranny, even for a short time,
5934 cannot be maintained. The Greek tyrants were not insensible to the
5935 importance of awakening in their cause a Pseudo-Hellenic feeling; they
5936 were proud of successes at the Olympic games; they were not devoid of
5937 the love of literature and art. Plato is thinking in the first instance
5938 of Greek poets who had graced the courts of Dionysius or Archelaus: and
5939 the old spirit of freedom is roused within him at their prostitution of
5940 the Tragic Muse in the praises of tyranny. But his prophetic eye extends
5941 beyond them to the false teachers of other ages who are the creatures of
5942 the government under which they live. He compares the corruption of his
5943 contemporaries with the idea of a perfect society, and gathers up
5944 into one mass of evil the evils and errors of mankind; to him they are
5945 personified in the rhetoricians, sophists, poets, rulers who deceive and
5946 govern the world.
5947 
5948 A further objection which Plato makes to poetry and the imitative
5949 arts is that they excite the emotions. Here the modern reader will be
5950 disposed to introduce a distinction which appears to have escaped him.
5951 For the emotions are neither bad nor good in themselves, and are not
5952 most likely to be controlled by the attempt to eradicate them, but by
5953 the moderate indulgence of them. And the vocation of art is to present
5954 thought in the form of feeling, to enlist the feelings on the side of
5955 reason, to inspire even for a moment courage or resignation; perhaps to
5956 suggest a sense of infinity and eternity in a way which mere language is
5957 incapable of attaining. True, the same power which in the purer age of
5958 art embodies gods and heroes only, may be made to express the voluptuous
5959 image of a Corinthian courtezan. But this only shows that art, like
5960 other outward things, may be turned to good and also to evil, and is not
5961 more closely connected with the higher than with the lower part of the
5962 soul. All imitative art is subject to certain limitations, and therefore
5963 necessarily partakes of the nature of a compromise. Something of ideal
5964 truth is sacrificed for the sake of the representation, and something in
5965 the exactness of the representation is sacrificed to the ideal. Still,
5966 works of art have a permanent element; they idealize and detain the
5967 passing thought, and are the intermediates between sense and ideas.
5968 
5969 In the present stage of the human mind, poetry and other forms of
5970 fiction may certainly be regarded as a good. But we can also imagine the
5971 existence of an age in which a severer conception of truth has either
5972 banished or transformed them. At any rate we must admit that they hold
5973 a different place at different periods of the world's history. In the
5974 infancy of mankind, poetry, with the exception of proverbs, is the
5975 whole of literature, and the only instrument of intellectual culture; in
5976 modern times she is the shadow or echo of her former self, and appears
5977 to have a precarious existence. Milton in his day doubted whether an
5978 epic poem was any longer possible. At the same time we must remember,
5979 that what Plato would have called the charms of poetry have been partly
5980 transferred to prose; he himself (Statesman) admits rhetoric to be the
5981 handmaiden of Politics, and proposes to find in the strain of law (Laws)
5982 a substitute for the old poets. Among ourselves the creative power seems
5983 often to be growing weaker, and scientific fact to be more engrossing
5984 and overpowering to the mind than formerly. The illusion of the feelings
5985 commonly called love, has hitherto been the inspiring influence of
5986 modern poetry and romance, and has exercised a humanizing if not a
5987 strengthening influence on the world. But may not the stimulus which
5988 love has given to fancy be some day exhausted? The modern English novel
5989 which is the most popular of all forms of reading is not more than a
5990 century or two old: will the tale of love a hundred years hence, after
5991 so many thousand variations of the same theme, be still received with
5992 unabated interest?
5993 
5994 Art cannot claim to be on a level with philosophy or religion, and may
5995 often corrupt them. It is possible to conceive a mental state in which
5996 all artistic representations are regarded as a false and imperfect
5997 expression, either of the religious ideal or of the philosophical ideal.
5998 The fairest forms may be revolting in certain moods of mind, as is
5999 proved by the fact that the Mahometans, and many sects of Christians,
6000 have renounced the use of pictures and images. The beginning of a great
6001 religion, whether Christian or Gentile, has not been 'wood or stone,'
6002 but a spirit moving in the hearts of men. The disciples have met in a
6003 large upper room or in 'holes and caves of the earth'; in the second or
6004 third generation, they have had mosques, temples, churches, monasteries.
6005 And the revival or reform of religions, like the first revelation
6006 of them, has come from within and has generally disregarded external
6007 ceremonies and accompaniments.
6008 
6009 But poetry and art may also be the expression of the highest truth and
6010 the purest sentiment. Plato himself seems to waver between two opposite
6011 views--when, as in the third Book, he insists that youth should be
6012 brought up amid wholesome imagery; and again in Book X, when he banishes
6013 the poets from his Republic. Admitting that the arts, which some of us
6014 almost deify, have fallen short of their higher aim, we must admit on
6015 the other hand that to banish imagination wholly would be suicidal as
6016 well as impossible. For nature too is a form of art; and a breath of
6017 the fresh air or a single glance at the varying landscape would in an
6018 instant revive and reillumine the extinguished spark of poetry in the
6019 human breast. In the lower stages of civilization imagination more than
6020 reason distinguishes man from the animals; and to banish art would be
6021 to banish thought, to banish language, to banish the expression of
6022 all truth. No religion is wholly devoid of external forms; even the
6023 Mahometan who renounces the use of pictures and images has a temple in
6024 which he worships the Most High, as solemn and beautiful as any Greek or
6025 Christian building. Feeling too and thought are not really opposed; for
6026 he who thinks must feel before he can execute. And the highest thoughts,
6027 when they become familiarized to us, are always tending to pass into the
6028 form of feeling.
6029 
6030 Plato does not seriously intend to expel poets from life and society.
6031 But he feels strongly the unreality of their writings; he is protesting
6032 against the degeneracy of poetry in his own day as we might protest
6033 against the want of serious purpose in modern fiction, against the
6034 unseemliness or extravagance of some of our poets or novelists,
6035 against the time-serving of preachers or public writers, against the
6036 regardlessness of truth which to the eye of the philosopher seems to
6037 characterize the greater part of the world. For we too have reason to
6038 complain that our poets and novelists 'paint inferior truth' and 'are
6039 concerned with the inferior part of the soul'; that the readers of them
6040 become what they read and are injuriously affected by them. And we look
6041 in vain for that healthy atmosphere of which Plato speaks,--'the beauty
6042 which meets the sense like a breeze and imperceptibly draws the soul,
6043 even in childhood, into harmony with the beauty of reason.'
6044 
6045 For there might be a poetry which would be the hymn of divine
6046 perfection, the harmony of goodness and truth among men: a strain which
6047 should renew the youth of the world, and bring back the ages in which
6048 the poet was man's only teacher and best friend,--which would find
6049 materials in the living present as well as in the romance of the
6050 past, and might subdue to the fairest forms of speech and verse the
6051 intractable materials of modern civilisation,--which might elicit the
6052 simple principles, or, as Plato would have called them, the essential
6053 forms, of truth and justice out of the variety of opinion and the
6054 complexity of modern society,--which would preserve all the good of each
6055 generation and leave the bad unsung,--which should be based not on vain
6056 longings or faint imaginings, but on a clear insight into the nature of
6057 man. Then the tale of love might begin again in poetry or prose, two in
6058 one, united in the pursuit of knowledge, or the service of God and man;
6059 and feelings of love might still be the incentive to great thoughts
6060 and heroic deeds as in the days of Dante or Petrarch; and many types
6061 of manly and womanly beauty might appear among us, rising above the
6062 ordinary level of humanity, and many lives which were like poems (Laws),
6063 be not only written, but lived by us. A few such strains have been
6064 heard among men in the tragedies of Aeschylus and Sophocles, whom Plato
6065 quotes, not, as Homer is quoted by him, in irony, but with deep and
6066 serious approval,--in the poetry of Milton and Wordsworth, and in
6067 passages of other English poets,--first and above all in the Hebrew
6068 prophets and psalmists. Shakespeare has taught us how great men should
6069 speak and act; he has drawn characters of a wonderful purity and depth;
6070 he has ennobled the human mind, but, like Homer (Rep.), he 'has left
6071 no way of life.' The next greatest poet of modern times, Goethe, is
6072 concerned with 'a lower degree of truth'; he paints the world as a stage
6073 on which 'all the men and women are merely players'; he cultivates life
6074 as an art, but he furnishes no ideals of truth and action. The poet may
6075 rebel against any attempt to set limits to his fancy; and he may
6076 argue truly that moralizing in verse is not poetry. Possibly, like
6077 Mephistopheles in Faust, he may retaliate on his adversaries. But the
6078 philosopher will still be justified in asking, 'How may the heavenly
6079 gift of poesy be devoted to the good of mankind?'
6080 
6081 Returning to Plato, we may observe that a similar mixture of truth
6082 and error appears in other parts of the argument. He is aware of the
6083 absurdity of mankind framing their whole lives according to Homer; just
6084 as in the Phaedrus he intimates the absurdity of interpreting mythology
6085 upon rational principles; both these were the modern tendencies of his
6086 own age, which he deservedly ridicules. On the other hand, his argument
6087 that Homer, if he had been able to teach mankind anything worth knowing,
6088 would not have been allowed by them to go about begging as a rhapsodist,
6089 is both false and contrary to the spirit of Plato (Rep.). It may be
6090 compared with those other paradoxes of the Gorgias, that 'No statesman
6091 was ever unjustly put to death by the city of which he was the head';
6092 and that 'No Sophist was ever defrauded by his pupils' (Gorg.)...
6093 
6094 The argument for immortality seems to rest on the absolute dualism of
6095 soul and body. Admitting the existence of the soul, we know of no force
6096 which is able to put an end to her. Vice is her own proper evil; and if
6097 she cannot be destroyed by that, she cannot be destroyed by any other.
6098 Yet Plato has acknowledged that the soul may be so overgrown by the
6099 incrustations of earth as to lose her original form; and in the Timaeus
6100 he recognizes more strongly than in the Republic the influence which the
6101 body has over the mind, denying even the voluntariness of human actions,
6102 on the ground that they proceed from physical states (Tim.). In the
6103 Republic, as elsewhere, he wavers between the original soul which has
6104 to be restored, and the character which is developed by training and
6105 education...
6106 
6107 The vision of another world is ascribed to Er, the son of Armenius, who
6108 is said by Clement of Alexandria to have been Zoroaster. The tale
6109 has certainly an oriental character, and may be compared with the
6110 pilgrimages of the soul in the Zend Avesta (Haug, Avesta). But no trace
6111 of acquaintance with Zoroaster is found elsewhere in Plato's writings,
6112 and there is no reason for giving him the name of Er the Pamphylian. The
6113 philosophy of Heracleitus cannot be shown to be borrowed from Zoroaster,
6114 and still less the myths of Plato.
6115 
6116 The local arrangement of the vision is less distinct than that of the
6117 Phaedrus and Phaedo. Astronomy is mingled with symbolism and mythology;
6118 the great sphere of heaven is represented under the symbol of a cylinder
6119 or box, containing the seven orbits of the planets and the fixed stars;
6120 this is suspended from an axis or spindle which turns on the knees of
6121 Necessity; the revolutions of the seven orbits contained in the cylinder
6122 are guided by the fates, and their harmonious motion produces the music
6123 of the spheres. Through the innermost or eighth of these, which is the
6124 moon, is passed the spindle; but it is doubtful whether this is the
6125 continuation of the column of light, from which the pilgrims contemplate
6126 the heavens; the words of Plato imply that they are connected, but
6127 not the same. The column itself is clearly not of adamant. The spindle
6128 (which is of adamant) is fastened to the ends of the chains which
6129 extend to the middle of the column of light--this column is said to hold
6130 together the heaven; but whether it hangs from the spindle, or is at
6131 right angles to it, is not explained. The cylinder containing the orbits
6132 of the stars is almost as much a symbol as the figure of Necessity
6133 turning the spindle;--for the outermost rim is the sphere of the fixed
6134 stars, and nothing is said about the intervals of space which divide the
6135 paths of the stars in the heavens. The description is both a picture and
6136 an orrery, and therefore is necessarily inconsistent with itself. The
6137 column of light is not the Milky Way--which is neither straight, nor
6138 like a rainbow--but the imaginary axis of the earth. This is compared
6139 to the rainbow in respect not of form but of colour, and not to the
6140 undergirders of a trireme, but to the straight rope running from prow to
6141 stern in which the undergirders meet.
6142 
6143 The orrery or picture of the heavens given in the Republic differs in
6144 its mode of representation from the circles of the same and of the
6145 other in the Timaeus. In both the fixed stars are distinguished from the
6146 planets, and they move in orbits without them, although in an opposite
6147 direction: in the Republic as in the Timaeus they are all moving round
6148 the axis of the world. But we are not certain that in the former they
6149 are moving round the earth. No distinct mention is made in the Republic
6150 of the circles of the same and other; although both in the Timaeus and
6151 in the Republic the motion of the fixed stars is supposed to coincide
6152 with the motion of the whole. The relative thickness of the rims is
6153 perhaps designed to express the relative distances of the planets.
6154 Plato probably intended to represent the earth, from which Er and his
6155 companions are viewing the heavens, as stationary in place; but whether
6156 or not herself revolving, unless this is implied in the revolution of
6157 the axis, is uncertain (Timaeus). The spectator may be supposed to look
6158 at the heavenly bodies, either from above or below. The earth is a sort
6159 of earth and heaven in one, like the heaven of the Phaedrus, on the back
6160 of which the spectator goes out to take a peep at the stars and is borne
6161 round in the revolution. There is no distinction between the equator and
6162 the ecliptic. But Plato is no doubt led to imagine that the planets have
6163 an opposite motion to that of the fixed stars, in order to account for
6164 their appearances in the heavens. In the description of the meadow, and
6165 the retribution of the good and evil after death, there are traces of
6166 Homer.
6167 
6168 The description of the axis as a spindle, and of the heavenly bodies as
6169 forming a whole, partly arises out of the attempt to connect the motions
6170 of the heavenly bodies with the mythological image of the web, or
6171 weaving of the Fates. The giving of the lots, the weaving of them,
6172 and the making of them irreversible, which are ascribed to the three
6173 Fates--Lachesis, Clotho, Atropos, are obviously derived from their
6174 names. The element of chance in human life is indicated by the order of
6175 the lots. But chance, however adverse, may be overcome by the wisdom
6176 of man, if he knows how to choose aright; there is a worse enemy to man
6177 than chance; this enemy is himself. He who was moderately fortunate in
6178 the number of the lot--even the very last comer--might have a good life
6179 if he chose with wisdom. And as Plato does not like to make an assertion
6180 which is unproven, he more than confirms this statement a few sentences
6181 afterwards by the example of Odysseus, who chose last. But the virtue
6182 which is founded on habit is not sufficient to enable a man to choose;
6183 he must add to virtue knowledge, if he is to act rightly when placed
6184 in new circumstances. The routine of good actions and good habits is
6185 an inferior sort of goodness; and, as Coleridge says, 'Common sense
6186 is intolerable which is not based on metaphysics,' so Plato would have
6187 said, 'Habit is worthless which is not based upon philosophy.'
6188 
6189 The freedom of the will to refuse the evil and to choose the good is
6190 distinctly asserted. 'Virtue is free, and as a man honours or dishonours
6191 her he will have more or less of her.' The life of man is 'rounded'
6192 by necessity; there are circumstances prior to birth which affect him
6193 (Pol.). But within the walls of necessity there is an open space in
6194 which he is his own master, and can study for himself the effects which
6195 the variously compounded gifts of nature or fortune have upon the soul,
6196 and act accordingly. All men cannot have the first choice in everything.
6197 But the lot of all men is good enough, if they choose wisely and will
6198 live diligently.
6199 
6200 The verisimilitude which is given to the pilgrimage of a thousand years,
6201 by the intimation that Ardiaeus had lived a thousand years before;
6202 the coincidence of Er coming to life on the twelfth day after he was
6203 supposed to have been dead with the seven days which the pilgrims passed
6204 in the meadow, and the four days during which they journeyed to the
6205 column of light; the precision with which the soul is mentioned who
6206 chose the twentieth lot; the passing remarks that there was no definite
6207 character among the souls, and that the souls which had chosen ill
6208 blamed any one rather than themselves; or that some of the souls drank
6209 more than was necessary of the waters of Forgetfulness, while Er himself
6210 was hindered from drinking; the desire of Odysseus to rest at last,
6211 unlike the conception of him in Dante and Tennyson; the feigned
6212 ignorance of how Er returned to the body, when the other souls went
6213 shooting like stars to their birth,--add greatly to the probability of
6214 the narrative. They are such touches of nature as the art of Defoe
6215 might have introduced when he wished to win credibility for marvels and
6216 apparitions.
6217 
6218 *****
6219 
6220 There still remain to be considered some points which have been
6221 intentionally reserved to the end: (1) the Janus-like character of the
6222 Republic, which presents two faces--one an Hellenic state, the other a
6223 kingdom of philosophers. Connected with the latter of the two aspects
6224 are (2) the paradoxes of the Republic, as they have been termed by
6225 Morgenstern: (a) the community of property; (b) of families; (c) the
6226 rule of philosophers; (d) the analogy of the individual and the State,
6227 which, like some other analogies in the Republic, is carried too far. We
6228 may then proceed to consider (3) the subject of education as conceived
6229 by Plato, bringing together in a general view the education of youth
6230 and the education of after-life; (4) we may note further some essential
6231 differences between ancient and modern politics which are suggested by
6232 the Republic; (5) we may compare the Politicus and the Laws; (6) we may
6233 observe the influence exercised by Plato on his imitators; and (7)
6234 take occasion to consider the nature and value of political, and (8) of
6235 religious ideals.
6236 
6237 1. Plato expressly says that he is intending to found an Hellenic State
6238 (Book V). Many of his regulations are characteristically Spartan; such
6239 as the prohibition of gold and silver, the common meals of the men, the
6240 military training of the youth, the gymnastic exercises of the women.
6241 The life of Sparta was the life of a camp (Laws), enforced even more
6242 rigidly in time of peace than in war; the citizens of Sparta, like
6243 Plato's, were forbidden to trade--they were to be soldiers and not
6244 shopkeepers. Nowhere else in Greece was the individual so completely
6245 subjected to the State; the time when he was to marry, the education of
6246 his children, the clothes which he was to wear, the food which he was
6247 to eat, were all prescribed by law. Some of the best enactments in the
6248 Republic, such as the reverence to be paid to parents and elders,
6249 and some of the worst, such as the exposure of deformed children, are
6250 borrowed from the practice of Sparta. The encouragement of friendships
6251 between men and youths, or of men with one another, as affording
6252 incentives to bravery, is also Spartan; in Sparta too a nearer approach
6253 was made than in any other Greek State to equality of the sexes, and
6254 to community of property; and while there was probably less of
6255 licentiousness in the sense of immorality, the tie of marriage was
6256 regarded more lightly than in the rest of Greece. The 'suprema lex'
6257 was the preservation of the family, and the interest of the State. The
6258 coarse strength of a military government was not favourable to purity
6259 and refinement; and the excessive strictness of some regulations seems
6260 to have produced a reaction. Of all Hellenes the Spartans were most
6261 accessible to bribery; several of the greatest of them might be
6262 described in the words of Plato as having a 'fierce secret longing
6263 after gold and silver.' Though not in the strict sense communists, the
6264 principle of communism was maintained among them in their division of
6265 lands, in their common meals, in their slaves, and in the free use of
6266 one another's goods. Marriage was a public institution: and the women
6267 were educated by the State, and sang and danced in public with the men.
6268 
6269 Many traditions were preserved at Sparta of the severity with which the
6270 magistrates had maintained the primitive rule of music and poetry; as in
6271 the Republic of Plato, the new-fangled poet was to be expelled. Hymns
6272 to the Gods, which are the only kind of music admitted into the ideal
6273 State, were the only kind which was permitted at Sparta. The Spartans,
6274 though an unpoetical race, were nevertheless lovers of poetry; they had
6275 been stirred by the Elegiac strains of Tyrtaeus, they had crowded around
6276 Hippias to hear his recitals of Homer; but in this they resembled the
6277 citizens of the timocratic rather than of the ideal State. The council
6278 of elder men also corresponds to the Spartan gerousia; and the freedom
6279 with which they are permitted to judge about matters of detail agrees
6280 with what we are told of that institution. Once more, the military rule
6281 of not spoiling the dead or offering arms at the temples; the moderation
6282 in the pursuit of enemies; the importance attached to the physical
6283 well-being of the citizens; the use of warfare for the sake of defence
6284 rather than of aggression--are features probably suggested by the spirit
6285 and practice of Sparta.
6286 
6287 To the Spartan type the ideal State reverts in the first decline; and
6288 the character of the individual timocrat is borrowed from the Spartan
6289 citizen. The love of Lacedaemon not only affected Plato and Xenophon,
6290 but was shared by many undistinguished Athenians; there they seemed to
6291 find a principle which was wanting in their own democracy. The (Greek)
6292 of the Spartans attracted them, that is to say, not the goodness
6293 of their laws, but the spirit of order and loyalty which prevailed.
6294 Fascinated by the idea, citizens of Athens would imitate the
6295 Lacedaemonians in their dress and manners; they were known to the
6296 contemporaries of Plato as 'the persons who had their ears bruised,'
6297 like the Roundheads of the Commonwealth. The love of another church
6298 or country when seen at a distance only, the longing for an imaginary
6299 simplicity in civilized times, the fond desire of a past which never has
6300 been, or of a future which never will be,--these are aspirations of the
6301 human mind which are often felt among ourselves. Such feelings meet with
6302 a response in the Republic of Plato.
6303 
6304 But there are other features of the Platonic Republic, as, for example,
6305 the literary and philosophical education, and the grace and beauty
6306 of life, which are the reverse of Spartan. Plato wishes to give his
6307 citizens a taste of Athenian freedom as well as of Lacedaemonian
6308 discipline. His individual genius is purely Athenian, although in theory
6309 he is a lover of Sparta; and he is something more than either--he has
6310 also a true Hellenic feeling. He is desirous of humanizing the wars of
6311 Hellenes against one another; he acknowledges that the Delphian God is
6312 the grand hereditary interpreter of all Hellas. The spirit of harmony
6313 and the Dorian mode are to prevail, and the whole State is to have an
6314 external beauty which is the reflex of the harmony within. But he
6315 has not yet found out the truth which he afterwards enunciated in the
6316 Laws--that he was a better legislator who made men to be of one mind,
6317 than he who trained them for war. The citizens, as in other Hellenic
6318 States, democratic as well as aristocratic, are really an upper class;
6319 for, although no mention is made of slaves, the lower classes are
6320 allowed to fade away into the distance, and are represented in the
6321 individual by the passions. Plato has no idea either of a social State
6322 in which all classes are harmonized, or of a federation of Hellas or
6323 the world in which different nations or States have a place. His city
6324 is equipped for war rather than for peace, and this would seem to be
6325 justified by the ordinary condition of Hellenic States. The myth of the
6326 earth-born men is an embodiment of the orthodox tradition of Hellas,
6327 and the allusion to the four ages of the world is also sanctioned by
6328 the authority of Hesiod and the poets. Thus we see that the Republic is
6329 partly founded on the ideal of the old Greek polis, partly on the actual
6330 circumstances of Hellas in that age. Plato, like the old painters,
6331 retains the traditional form, and like them he has also a vision of a
6332 city in the clouds.
6333 
6334 There is yet another thread which is interwoven in the texture of the
6335 work; for the Republic is not only a Dorian State, but a Pythagorean
6336 league. The 'way of life' which was connected with the name of
6337 Pythagoras, like the Catholic monastic orders, showed the power which
6338 the mind of an individual might exercise over his contemporaries, and
6339 may have naturally suggested to Plato the possibility of reviving such
6340 'mediaeval institutions.' The Pythagoreans, like Plato, enforced a rule
6341 of life and a moral and intellectual training. The influence ascribed to
6342 music, which to us seems exaggerated, is also a Pythagorean feature; it
6343 is not to be regarded as representing the real influence of music in
6344 the Greek world. More nearly than any other government of Hellas, the
6345 Pythagorean league of three hundred was an aristocracy of virtue. For
6346 once in the history of mankind the philosophy of order or (Greek),
6347 expressing and consequently enlisting on its side the combined
6348 endeavours of the better part of the people, obtained the management of
6349 public affairs and held possession of it for a considerable time (until
6350 about B.C. 500). Probably only in States prepared by Dorian institutions
6351 would such a league have been possible. The rulers, like Plato's
6352 (Greek), were required to submit to a severe training in order to
6353 prepare the way for the education of the other members of the community.
6354 Long after the dissolution of the Order, eminent Pythagoreans, such as
6355 Archytas of Tarentum, retained their political influence over the cities
6356 of Magna Graecia. There was much here that was suggestive to the kindred
6357 spirit of Plato, who had doubtless meditated deeply on the 'way of life
6358 of Pythagoras' (Rep.) and his followers. Slight traces of Pythagoreanism
6359 are to be found in the mystical number of the State, in the number which
6360 expresses the interval between the king and the tyrant, in the doctrine
6361 of transmigration, in the music of the spheres, as well as in the great
6362 though secondary importance ascribed to mathematics in education.
6363 
6364 But as in his philosophy, so also in the form of his State, he goes far
6365 beyond the old Pythagoreans. He attempts a task really impossible, which
6366 is to unite the past of Greek history with the future of philosophy,
6367 analogous to that other impossibility, which has often been the dream
6368 of Christendom, the attempt to unite the past history of Europe with
6369 the kingdom of Christ. Nothing actually existing in the world at all
6370 resembles Plato's ideal State; nor does he himself imagine that such
6371 a State is possible. This he repeats again and again; e.g. in the
6372 Republic, or in the Laws where, casting a glance back on the Republic,
6373 he admits that the perfect state of communism and philosophy was
6374 impossible in his own age, though still to be retained as a pattern.
6375 The same doubt is implied in the earnestness with which he argues in the
6376 Republic that ideals are none the worse because they cannot be realized
6377 in fact, and in the chorus of laughter, which like a breaking wave will,
6378 as he anticipates, greet the mention of his proposals; though like
6379 other writers of fiction, he uses all his art to give reality to his
6380 inventions. When asked how the ideal polity can come into being, he
6381 answers ironically, 'When one son of a king becomes a philosopher'; he
6382 designates the fiction of the earth-born men as 'a noble lie'; and when
6383 the structure is finally complete, he fairly tells you that his Republic
6384 is a vision only, which in some sense may have reality, but not in the
6385 vulgar one of a reign of philosophers upon earth. It has been said that
6386 Plato flies as well as walks, but this falls short of the truth; for he
6387 flies and walks at the same time, and is in the air and on firm ground
6388 in successive instants.
6389 
6390 Niebuhr has asked a trifling question, which may be briefly noticed in
6391 this place--Was Plato a good citizen? If by this is meant, Was he loyal
6392 to Athenian institutions?--he can hardly be said to be the friend of
6393 democracy: but neither is he the friend of any other existing form of
6394 government; all of them he regarded as 'states of faction' (Laws); none
6395 attained to his ideal of a voluntary rule over voluntary subjects, which
6396 seems indeed more nearly to describe democracy than any other; and the
6397 worst of them is tyranny. The truth is, that the question has hardly any
6398 meaning when applied to a great philosopher whose writings are not meant
6399 for a particular age and country, but for all time and all mankind. The
6400 decline of Athenian politics was probably the motive which led Plato to
6401 frame an ideal State, and the Republic may be regarded as reflecting the
6402 departing glory of Hellas. As well might we complain of St. Augustine,
6403 whose great work 'The City of God' originated in a similar motive, for
6404 not being loyal to the Roman Empire. Even a nearer parallel might be
6405 afforded by the first Christians, who cannot fairly be charged with
6406 being bad citizens because, though 'subject to the higher powers,' they
6407 were looking forward to a city which is in heaven.
6408 
6409 2. The idea of the perfect State is full of paradox when judged of
6410 according to the ordinary notions of mankind. The paradoxes of one age
6411 have been said to become the commonplaces of the next; but the
6412 paradoxes of Plato are at least as paradoxical to us as they were to his
6413 contemporaries. The modern world has either sneered at them as absurd,
6414 or denounced them as unnatural and immoral; men have been pleased to
6415 find in Aristotle's criticisms of them the anticipation of their own
6416 good sense. The wealthy and cultivated classes have disliked and also
6417 dreaded them; they have pointed with satisfaction to the failure of
6418 efforts to realize them in practice. Yet since they are the thoughts of
6419 one of the greatest of human intelligences, and of one who had done
6420 most to elevate morality and religion, they seem to deserve a better
6421 treatment at our hands. We may have to address the public, as Plato does
6422 poetry, and assure them that we mean no harm to existing institutions.
6423 There are serious errors which have a side of truth and which therefore
6424 may fairly demand a careful consideration: there are truths mixed with
6425 error of which we may indeed say, 'The half is better than the whole.'
6426 Yet 'the half' may be an important contribution to the study of human
6427 nature.
6428 
6429 (a) The first paradox is the community of goods, which is mentioned
6430 slightly at the end of the third Book, and seemingly, as Aristotle
6431 observes, is confined to the guardians; at least no mention is made of
6432 the other classes. But the omission is not of any real significance, and
6433 probably arises out of the plan of the work, which prevents the writer
6434 from entering into details.
6435 
6436 Aristotle censures the community of property much in the spirit of
6437 modern political economy, as tending to repress industry, and as doing
6438 away with the spirit of benevolence. Modern writers almost refuse to
6439 consider the subject, which is supposed to have been long ago settled
6440 by the common opinion of mankind. But it must be remembered that the
6441 sacredness of property is a notion far more fixed in modern than
6442 in ancient times. The world has grown older, and is therefore more
6443 conservative. Primitive society offered many examples of land held in
6444 common, either by a tribe or by a township, and such may probably
6445 have been the original form of landed tenure. Ancient legislators had
6446 invented various modes of dividing and preserving the divisions of land
6447 among the citizens; according to Aristotle there were nations who held
6448 the land in common and divided the produce, and there were others who
6449 divided the land and stored the produce in common. The evils of debt and
6450 the inequality of property were far greater in ancient than in modern
6451 times, and the accidents to which property was subject from war, or
6452 revolution, or taxation, or other legislative interference, were also
6453 greater. All these circumstances gave property a less fixed and sacred
6454 character. The early Christians are believed to have held their property
6455 in common, and the principle is sanctioned by the words of Christ
6456 himself, and has been maintained as a counsel of perfection in almost
6457 all ages of the Church. Nor have there been wanting instances of modern
6458 enthusiasts who have made a religion of communism; in every age of
6459 religious excitement notions like Wycliffe's 'inheritance of grace'
6460 have tended to prevail. A like spirit, but fiercer and more violent,
6461 has appeared in politics. 'The preparation of the Gospel of peace' soon
6462 becomes the red flag of Republicanism.
6463 
6464 We can hardly judge what effect Plato's views would have upon his
6465 own contemporaries; they would perhaps have seemed to them only an
6466 exaggeration of the Spartan commonwealth. Even modern writers would
6467 acknowledge that the right of private property is based on expediency,
6468 and may be interfered with in a variety of ways for the public good. Any
6469 other mode of vesting property which was found to be more advantageous,
6470 would in time acquire the same basis of right; 'the most useful,' in
6471 Plato's words, 'would be the most sacred.' The lawyers and ecclesiastics
6472 of former ages would have spoken of property as a sacred institution.
6473 But they only meant by such language to oppose the greatest amount
6474 of resistance to any invasion of the rights of individuals and of the
6475 Church.
6476 
6477 When we consider the question, without any fear of immediate application
6478 to practice, in the spirit of Plato's Republic, are we quite sure that
6479 the received notions of property are the best? Is the distribution of
6480 wealth which is customary in civilized countries the most favourable
6481 that can be conceived for the education and development of the mass
6482 of mankind? Can 'the spectator of all time and all existence' be quite
6483 convinced that one or two thousand years hence, great changes will not
6484 have taken place in the rights of property, or even that the very notion
6485 of property, beyond what is necessary for personal maintenance, may not
6486 have disappeared? This was a distinction familiar to Aristotle, though
6487 likely to be laughed at among ourselves. Such a change would not be
6488 greater than some other changes through which the world has passed
6489 in the transition from ancient to modern society, for example, the
6490 emancipation of the serfs in Russia, or the abolition of slavery in
6491 America and the West Indies; and not so great as the difference which
6492 separates the Eastern village community from the Western world. To
6493 accomplish such a revolution in the course of a few centuries, would
6494 imply a rate of progress not more rapid than has actually taken place
6495 during the last fifty or sixty years. The kingdom of Japan underwent
6496 more change in five or six years than Europe in five or six hundred.
6497 Many opinions and beliefs which have been cherished among ourselves
6498 quite as strongly as the sacredness of property have passed away; and
6499 the most untenable propositions respecting the right of bequests or
6500 entail have been maintained with as much fervour as the most moderate.
6501 Some one will be heard to ask whether a state of society can be final in
6502 which the interests of thousands are perilled on the life or character
6503 of a single person. And many will indulge the hope that our present
6504 condition may, after all, be only transitional, and may conduct to a
6505 higher, in which property, besides ministering to the enjoyment of the
6506 few, may also furnish the means of the highest culture to all, and will
6507 be a greater benefit to the public generally, and also more under the
6508 control of public authority. There may come a time when the saying,
6509 'Have I not a right to do what I will with my own?' will appear to be a
6510 barbarous relic of individualism;--when the possession of a part may be
6511 a greater blessing to each and all than the possession of the whole is
6512 now to any one.
6513 
6514 Such reflections appear visionary to the eye of the practical statesman,
6515 but they are within the range of possibility to the philosopher. He can
6516 imagine that in some distant age or clime, and through the influence of
6517 some individual, the notion of common property may or might have sunk
6518 as deep into the heart of a race, and have become as fixed to them, as
6519 private property is to ourselves. He knows that this latter institution
6520 is not more than four or five thousand years old: may not the end revert
6521 to the beginning? In our own age even Utopias affect the spirit of
6522 legislation, and an abstract idea may exercise a great influence on
6523 practical politics.
6524 
6525 The objections that would be generally urged against Plato's community
6526 of property, are the old ones of Aristotle, that motives for exertion
6527 would be taken away, and that disputes would arise when each was
6528 dependent upon all. Every man would produce as little and consume as
6529 much as he liked. The experience of civilized nations has hitherto been
6530 adverse to Socialism. The effort is too great for human nature; men try
6531 to live in common, but the personal feeling is always breaking in. On
6532 the other hand it may be doubted whether our present notions of property
6533 are not conventional, for they differ in different countries and in
6534 different states of society. We boast of an individualism which is not
6535 freedom, but rather an artificial result of the industrial state
6536 of modern Europe. The individual is nominally free, but he is also
6537 powerless in a world bound hand and foot in the chains of economic
6538 necessity. Even if we cannot expect the mass of mankind to become
6539 disinterested, at any rate we observe in them a power of organization
6540 which fifty years ago would never have been suspected. The same forces
6541 which have revolutionized the political system of Europe, may effect a
6542 similar change in the social and industrial relations of mankind. And if
6543 we suppose the influence of some good as well as neutral motives working
6544 in the community, there will be no absurdity in expecting that the
6545 mass of mankind having power, and becoming enlightened about the higher
6546 possibilities of human life, when they learn how much more is attainable
6547 for all than is at present the possession of a favoured few, may pursue
6548 the common interest with an intelligence and persistency which mankind
6549 have hitherto never seen.
6550 
6551 Now that the world has once been set in motion, and is no longer held
6552 fast under the tyranny of custom and ignorance; now that criticism has
6553 pierced the veil of tradition and the past no longer overpowers the
6554 present,--the progress of civilization may be expected to be far greater
6555 and swifter than heretofore. Even at our present rate of speed the point
6556 at which we may arrive in two or three generations is beyond the power
6557 of imagination to foresee. There are forces in the world which work, not
6558 in an arithmetical, but in a geometrical ratio of increase.
6559 Education, to use the expression of Plato, moves like a wheel with
6560 an ever-multiplying rapidity. Nor can we say how great may be its
6561 influence, when it becomes universal,--when it has been inherited by
6562 many generations,--when it is freed from the trammels of superstition
6563 and rightly adapted to the wants and capacities of different classes
6564 of men and women. Neither do we know how much more the co-operation of
6565 minds or of hands may be capable of accomplishing, whether in labour or
6566 in study. The resources of the natural sciences are not half-developed
6567 as yet; the soil of the earth, instead of growing more barren, may
6568 become many times more fertile than hitherto; the uses of machinery far
6569 greater, and also more minute than at present. New secrets of physiology
6570 may be revealed, deeply affecting human nature in its innermost
6571 recesses. The standard of health may be raised and the lives of men
6572 prolonged by sanitary and medical knowledge. There may be peace, there
6573 may be leisure, there may be innocent refreshments of many kinds. The
6574 ever-increasing power of locomotion may join the extremes of earth.
6575 There may be mysterious workings of the human mind, such as occur only
6576 at great crises of history. The East and the West may meet together, and
6577 all nations may contribute their thoughts and their experience to the
6578 common stock of humanity. Many other elements enter into a speculation
6579 of this kind. But it is better to make an end of them. For such
6580 reflections appear to the majority far-fetched, and to men of science,
6581 commonplace.
6582 
6583 (b) Neither to the mind of Plato nor of Aristotle did the doctrine of
6584 community of property present at all the same difficulty, or appear to
6585 be the same violation of the common Hellenic sentiment, as the community
6586 of wives and children. This paradox he prefaces by another proposal,
6587 that the occupations of men and women shall be the same, and that to
6588 this end they shall have a common training and education. Male and
6589 female animals have the same pursuits--why not also the two sexes of
6590 man?
6591 
6592 But have we not here fallen into a contradiction? for we were saying
6593 that different natures should have different pursuits. How then can men
6594 and women have the same? And is not the proposal inconsistent with our
6595 notion of the division of labour?--These objections are no sooner raised
6596 than answered; for, according to Plato, there is no organic difference
6597 between men and women, but only the accidental one that men beget and
6598 women bear children. Following the analogy of the other animals, he
6599 contends that all natural gifts are scattered about indifferently among
6600 both sexes, though there may be a superiority of degree on the part of
6601 the men. The objection on the score of decency to their taking part
6602 in the same gymnastic exercises, is met by Plato's assertion that the
6603 existing feeling is a matter of habit.
6604 
6605 That Plato should have emancipated himself from the ideas of his own
6606 country and from the example of the East, shows a wonderful independence
6607 of mind. He is conscious that women are half the human race, in some
6608 respects the more important half (Laws); and for the sake both of men
6609 and women he desires to raise the woman to a higher level of existence.
6610 He brings, not sentiment, but philosophy to bear upon a question which
6611 both in ancient and modern times has been chiefly regarded in the light
6612 of custom or feeling. The Greeks had noble conceptions of womanhood
6613 in the goddesses Athene and Artemis, and in the heroines Antigone and
6614 Andromache. But these ideals had no counterpart in actual life. The
6615 Athenian woman was in no way the equal of her husband; she was not the
6616 entertainer of his guests or the mistress of his house, but only his
6617 housekeeper and the mother of his children. She took no part in military
6618 or political matters; nor is there any instance in the later ages of
6619 Greece of a woman becoming famous in literature. 'Hers is the greatest
6620 glory who has the least renown among men,' is the historian's conception
6621 of feminine excellence. A very different ideal of womanhood is held up
6622 by Plato to the world; she is to be the companion of the man, and to
6623 share with him in the toils of war and in the cares of government. She
6624 is to be similarly trained both in bodily and mental exercises. She
6625 is to lose as far as possible the incidents of maternity and the
6626 characteristics of the female sex.
6627 
6628 The modern antagonist of the equality of the sexes would argue that the
6629 differences between men and women are not confined to the single point
6630 urged by Plato; that sensibility, gentleness, grace, are the qualities
6631 of women, while energy, strength, higher intelligence, are to be looked
6632 for in men. And the criticism is just: the differences affect the whole
6633 nature, and are not, as Plato supposes, confined to a single point. But
6634 neither can we say how far these differences are due to education and
6635 the opinions of mankind, or physically inherited from the habits and
6636 opinions of former generations. Women have been always taught, not
6637 exactly that they are slaves, but that they are in an inferior position,
6638 which is also supposed to have compensating advantages; and to this
6639 position they have conformed. It is also true that the physical form may
6640 easily change in the course of generations through the mode of life; and
6641 the weakness or delicacy, which was once a matter of opinion, may become
6642 a physical fact. The characteristics of sex vary greatly in different
6643 countries and ranks of society, and at different ages in the same
6644 individuals. Plato may have been right in denying that there was any
6645 ultimate difference in the sexes of man other than that which exists in
6646 animals, because all other differences may be conceived to disappear in
6647 other states of society, or under different circumstances of life and
6648 training.
6649 
6650 The first wave having been passed, we proceed to the second--community
6651 of wives and children. 'Is it possible? Is it desirable?' For as Glaucon
6652 intimates, and as we far more strongly insist, 'Great doubts may
6653 be entertained about both these points.' Any free discussion of the
6654 question is impossible, and mankind are perhaps right in not allowing
6655 the ultimate bases of social life to be examined. Few of us can safely
6656 enquire into the things which nature hides, any more than we can
6657 dissect our own bodies. Still, the manner in which Plato arrived at his
6658 conclusions should be considered. For here, as Mr. Grote has remarked,
6659 is a wonderful thing, that one of the wisest and best of men should have
6660 entertained ideas of morality which are wholly at variance with our
6661 own. And if we would do Plato justice, we must examine carefully the
6662 character of his proposals. First, we may observe that the relations of
6663 the sexes supposed by him are the reverse of licentious: he seems rather
6664 to aim at an impossible strictness. Secondly, he conceives the family
6665 to be the natural enemy of the state; and he entertains the serious
6666 hope that an universal brotherhood may take the place of private
6667 interests--an aspiration which, although not justified by experience,
6668 has possessed many noble minds. On the other hand, there is no sentiment
6669 or imagination in the connections which men and women are supposed by
6670 him to form; human beings return to the level of the animals, neither
6671 exalting to heaven, nor yet abusing the natural instincts. All that
6672 world of poetry and fancy which the passion of love has called forth
6673 in modern literature and romance would have been banished by Plato. The
6674 arrangements of marriage in the Republic are directed to one object--the
6675 improvement of the race. In successive generations a great development
6676 both of bodily and mental qualities might be possible. The analogy of
6677 animals tends to show that mankind can within certain limits receive a
6678 change of nature. And as in animals we should commonly choose the best
6679 for breeding, and destroy the others, so there must be a selection made
6680 of the human beings whose lives are worthy to be preserved.
6681 
6682 We start back horrified from this Platonic ideal, in the belief, first,
6683 that the higher feelings of humanity are far too strong to be crushed
6684 out; secondly, that if the plan could be carried into execution we
6685 should be poorly recompensed by improvements in the breed for the loss
6686 of the best things in life. The greatest regard for the weakest and
6687 meanest of human beings--the infant, the criminal, the insane, the
6688 idiot, truly seems to us one of the noblest results of Christianity. We
6689 have learned, though as yet imperfectly, that the individual man has an
6690 endless value in the sight of God, and that we honour Him when we honour
6691 the darkened and disfigured image of Him (Laws). This is the lesson
6692 which Christ taught in a parable when He said, 'Their angels do always
6693 behold the face of My Father which is in heaven.' Such lessons are only
6694 partially realized in any age; they were foreign to the age of Plato, as
6695 they have very different degrees of strength in different countries or
6696 ages of the Christian world. To the Greek the family was a religious and
6697 customary institution binding the members together by a tie inferior
6698 in strength to that of friendship, and having a less solemn and sacred
6699 sound than that of country. The relationship which existed on the lower
6700 level of custom, Plato imagined that he was raising to the higher level
6701 of nature and reason; while from the modern and Christian point of view
6702 we regard him as sanctioning murder and destroying the first principles
6703 of morality.
6704 
6705 The great error in these and similar speculations is that the difference
6706 between man and the animals is forgotten in them. The human being
6707 is regarded with the eye of a dog- or bird-fancier, or at best of a
6708 slave-owner; the higher or human qualities are left out. The breeder
6709 of animals aims chiefly at size or speed or strength; in a few cases at
6710 courage or temper; most often the fitness of the animal for food is the
6711 great desideratum. But mankind are not bred to be eaten, nor yet for
6712 their superiority in fighting or in running or in drawing carts. Neither
6713 does the improvement of the human race consist merely in the increase
6714 of the bones and flesh, but in the growth and enlightenment of the mind.
6715 Hence there must be 'a marriage of true minds' as well as of bodies, of
6716 imagination and reason as well as of lusts and instincts. Men and women
6717 without feeling or imagination are justly called brutes; yet Plato
6718 takes away these qualities and puts nothing in their place, not even
6719 the desire of a noble offspring, since parents are not to know their own
6720 children. The most important transaction of social life, he who is the
6721 idealist philosopher converts into the most brutal. For the pair are to
6722 have no relation to one another, except at the hymeneal festival; their
6723 children are not theirs, but the state's; nor is any tie of affection to
6724 unite them. Yet here the analogy of the animals might have saved
6725 Plato from a gigantic error, if he had 'not lost sight of his own
6726 illustration.' For the 'nobler sort of birds and beasts' nourish and
6727 protect their offspring and are faithful to one another.
6728 
6729 An eminent physiologist thinks it worth while 'to try and place life
6730 on a physical basis.' But should not life rest on the moral rather than
6731 upon the physical? The higher comes first, then the lower, first the
6732 human and rational, afterwards the animal. Yet they are not absolutely
6733 divided; and in times of sickness or moments of self-indulgence they
6734 seem to be only different aspects of a common human nature which
6735 includes them both. Neither is the moral the limit of the physical,
6736 but the expansion and enlargement of it,--the highest form which the
6737 physical is capable of receiving. As Plato would say, the body does not
6738 take care of the body, and still less of the mind, but the mind takes
6739 care of both. In all human action not that which is common to man and
6740 the animals is the characteristic element, but that which distinguishes
6741 him from them. Even if we admit the physical basis, and resolve all
6742 virtue into health of body 'la facon que notre sang circule,' still on
6743 merely physical grounds we must come back to ideas. Mind and reason and
6744 duty and conscience, under these or other names, are always reappearing.
6745 There cannot be health of body without health of mind; nor health of
6746 mind without the sense of duty and the love of truth (Charm).
6747 
6748 That the greatest of ancient philosophers should in his regulations
6749 about marriage have fallen into the error of separating body and mind,
6750 does indeed appear surprising. Yet the wonder is not so much that Plato
6751 should have entertained ideas of morality which to our own age are
6752 revolting, but that he should have contradicted himself to an extent
6753 which is hardly credible, falling in an instant from the heaven of
6754 idealism into the crudest animalism. Rejoicing in the newly found gift
6755 of reflection, he appears to have thought out a subject about which he
6756 had better have followed the enlightened feeling of his own age. The
6757 general sentiment of Hellas was opposed to his monstrous fancy. The old
6758 poets, and in later time the tragedians, showed no want of respect for
6759 the family, on which much of their religion was based. But the example
6760 of Sparta, and perhaps in some degree the tendency to defy public
6761 opinion, seems to have misled him. He will make one family out of all
6762 the families of the state. He will select the finest specimens of men
6763 and women and breed from these only.
6764 
6765 Yet because the illusion is always returning (for the animal part of
6766 human nature will from time to time assert itself in the disguise of
6767 philosophy as well as of poetry), and also because any departure from
6768 established morality, even where this is not intended, is apt to be
6769 unsettling, it may be worth while to draw out a little more at length
6770 the objections to the Platonic marriage. In the first place, history
6771 shows that wherever polygamy has been largely allowed the race has
6772 deteriorated. One man to one woman is the law of God and nature. Nearly
6773 all the civilized peoples of the world at some period before the age of
6774 written records, have become monogamists; and the step when once taken
6775 has never been retraced. The exceptions occurring among Brahmins or
6776 Mahometans or the ancient Persians, are of that sort which may be said
6777 to prove the rule. The connexions formed between superior and
6778 inferior races hardly ever produce a noble offspring, because they are
6779 licentious; and because the children in such cases usually despise the
6780 mother and are neglected by the father who is ashamed of them.
6781 Barbarous nations when they are introduced by Europeans to vice die
6782 out; polygamist peoples either import and adopt children from other
6783 countries, or dwindle in numbers, or both. Dynasties and aristocracies
6784 which have disregarded the laws of nature have decreased in numbers and
