6785 degenerated in stature; 'mariages de convenance' leave their enfeebling
6786 stamp on the offspring of them (King Lear). The marriage of near
6787 relations, or the marrying in and in of the same family tends constantly
6788 to weakness or idiocy in the children, sometimes assuming the form as
6789 they grow older of passionate licentiousness. The common prostitute
6790 rarely has any offspring. By such unmistakable evidence is the authority
6791 of morality asserted in the relations of the sexes: and so many more
6792 elements enter into this 'mystery' than are dreamed of by Plato and some
6793 other philosophers.
6794 
6795 Recent enquirers have indeed arrived at the conclusion that among
6796 primitive tribes there existed a community of wives as of property, and
6797 that the captive taken by the spear was the only wife or slave whom any
6798 man was permitted to call his own. The partial existence of such customs
6799 among some of the lower races of man, and the survival of peculiar
6800 ceremonies in the marriages of some civilized nations, are thought to
6801 furnish a proof of similar institutions having been once universal.
6802 There can be no question that the study of anthropology has considerably
6803 changed our views respecting the first appearance of man upon the earth.
6804 We know more about the aborigines of the world than formerly, but our
6805 increasing knowledge shows above all things how little we know. With all
6806 the helps which written monuments afford, we do but faintly realize the
6807 condition of man two thousand or three thousand years ago. Of what his
6808 condition was when removed to a distance 200,000 or 300,000 years, when
6809 the majority of mankind were lower and nearer the animals than any tribe
6810 now existing upon the earth, we cannot even entertain conjecture. Plato
6811 (Laws) and Aristotle (Metaph.) may have been more right than we imagine
6812 in supposing that some forms of civilisation were discovered and lost
6813 several times over. If we cannot argue that all barbarism is a degraded
6814 civilization, neither can we set any limits to the depth of degradation
6815 to which the human race may sink through war, disease, or isolation.
6816 And if we are to draw inferences about the origin of marriage from
6817 the practice of barbarous nations, we should also consider the
6818 remoter analogy of the animals. Many birds and animals, especially the
6819 carnivorous, have only one mate, and the love and care of offspring
6820 which seems to be natural is inconsistent with the primitive theory of
6821 marriage. If we go back to an imaginary state in which men were almost
6822 animals and the companions of them, we have as much right to argue from
6823 what is animal to what is human as from the barbarous to the civilized
6824 man. The record of animal life on the globe is fragmentary,--the
6825 connecting links are wanting and cannot be supplied; the record of
6826 social life is still more fragmentary and precarious. Even if we admit
6827 that our first ancestors had no such institution as marriage, still
6828 the stages by which men passed from outer barbarism to the comparative
6829 civilization of China, Assyria, and Greece, or even of the ancient
6830 Germans, are wholly unknown to us.
6831 
6832 Such speculations are apt to be unsettling, because they seem to show
6833 that an institution which was thought to be a revelation from heaven, is
6834 only the growth of history and experience. We ask what is the origin of
6835 marriage, and we are told that like the right of property, after many
6836 wars and contests, it has gradually arisen out of the selfishness of
6837 barbarians. We stand face to face with human nature in its primitive
6838 nakedness. We are compelled to accept, not the highest, but the lowest
6839 account of the origin of human society. But on the other hand we
6840 may truly say that every step in human progress has been in the same
6841 direction, and that in the course of ages the idea of marriage and of
6842 the family has been more and more defined and consecrated. The civilized
6843 East is immeasurably in advance of any savage tribes; the Greeks and
6844 Romans have improved upon the East; the Christian nations have been
6845 stricter in their views of the marriage relation than any of the
6846 ancients. In this as in so many other things, instead of looking back
6847 with regret to the past, we should look forward with hope to the future.
6848 We must consecrate that which we believe to be the most holy, and that
6849 'which is the most holy will be the most useful.' There is more reason
6850 for maintaining the sacredness of the marriage tie, when we see the
6851 benefit of it, than when we only felt a vague religious horror about
6852 the violation of it. But in all times of transition, when established
6853 beliefs are being undermined, there is a danger that in the passage from
6854 the old to the new we may insensibly let go the moral principle, finding
6855 an excuse for listening to the voice of passion in the uncertainty of
6856 knowledge, or the fluctuations of opinion. And there are many persons
6857 in our own day who, enlightened by the study of anthropology, and
6858 fascinated by what is new and strange, some using the language of fear,
6859 others of hope, are inclined to believe that a time will come when
6860 through the self-assertion of women, or the rebellious spirit of
6861 children, by the analysis of human relations, or by the force of outward
6862 circumstances, the ties of family life may be broken or greatly relaxed.
6863 They point to societies in America and elsewhere which tend to show that
6864 the destruction of the family need not necessarily involve the overthrow
6865 of all morality. Wherever we may think of such speculations, we can
6866 hardly deny that they have been more rife in this generation than in any
6867 other; and whither they are tending, who can predict?
6868 
6869 To the doubts and queries raised by these 'social reformers' respecting
6870 the relation of the sexes and the moral nature of man, there is a
6871 sufficient answer, if any is needed. The difference about them and us is
6872 really one of fact. They are speaking of man as they wish or fancy him
6873 to be, but we are speaking of him as he is. They isolate the animal
6874 part of his nature; we regard him as a creature having many sides, or
6875 aspects, moving between good and evil, striving to rise above himself
6876 and to become 'a little lower than the angels.' We also, to use
6877 a Platonic formula, are not ignorant of the dissatisfactions and
6878 incompatibilities of family life, of the meannesses of trade, of the
6879 flatteries of one class of society by another, of the impediments which
6880 the family throws in the way of lofty aims and aspirations. But we are
6881 conscious that there are evils and dangers in the background greater
6882 still, which are not appreciated, because they are either concealed
6883 or suppressed. What a condition of man would that be, in which human
6884 passions were controlled by no authority, divine or human, in which
6885 there was no shame or decency, no higher affection overcoming or
6886 sanctifying the natural instincts, but simply a rule of health! Is it
6887 for this that we are asked to throw away the civilization which is the
6888 growth of ages?
6889 
6890 For strength and health are not the only qualities to be desired; there
6891 are the more important considerations of mind and character and soul. We
6892 know how human nature may be degraded; we do not know how by artificial
6893 means any improvement in the breed can be effected. The problem is a
6894 complex one, for if we go back only four steps (and these at least enter
6895 into the composition of a child), there are commonly thirty progenitors
6896 to be taken into account. Many curious facts, rarely admitting of proof,
6897 are told us respecting the inheritance of disease or character from a
6898 remote ancestor. We can trace the physical resemblances of parents and
6899 children in the same family--
6900 
6901 'Sic oculos, sic ille manus, sic ora ferebat';
6902 
6903 but scarcely less often the differences which distinguish children both
6904 from their parents and from one another. We are told of similar mental
6905 peculiarities running in families, and again of a tendency, as in
6906 the animals, to revert to a common or original stock. But we have a
6907 difficulty in distinguishing what is a true inheritance of genius or
6908 other qualities, and what is mere imitation or the result of similar
6909 circumstances. Great men and great women have rarely had great fathers
6910 and mothers. Nothing that we know of in the circumstances of their birth
6911 or lineage will explain their appearance. Of the English poets of the
6912 last and two preceding centuries scarcely a descendant remains,--none
6913 have ever been distinguished. So deeply has nature hidden her secret,
6914 and so ridiculous is the fancy which has been entertained by some that
6915 we might in time by suitable marriage arrangements or, as Plato would
6916 have said, 'by an ingenious system of lots,' produce a Shakespeare or
6917 a Milton. Even supposing that we could breed men having the tenacity
6918 of bulldogs, or, like the Spartans, 'lacking the wit to run away
6919 in battle,' would the world be any the better? Many of the noblest
6920 specimens of the human race have been among the weakest physically.
6921 Tyrtaeus or Aesop, or our own Newton, would have been exposed at Sparta;
6922 and some of the fairest and strongest men and women have been among the
6923 wickedest and worst. Not by the Platonic device of uniting the strong
6924 and fair with the strong and fair, regardless of sentiment and morality,
6925 nor yet by his other device of combining dissimilar natures (Statesman),
6926 have mankind gradually passed from the brutality and licentiousness of
6927 primitive marriage to marriage Christian and civilized.
6928 
6929 Few persons would deny that we bring into the world an inheritance of
6930 mental and physical qualities derived first from our parents, or through
6931 them from some remoter ancestor, secondly from our race, thirdly from
6932 the general condition of mankind into which we are born. Nothing is
6933 commoner than the remark, that 'So and so is like his father or his
6934 uncle'; and an aged person may not unfrequently note a resemblance in
6935 a youth to a long-forgotten ancestor, observing that 'Nature sometimes
6936 skips a generation.' It may be true also, that if we knew more about
6937 our ancestors, these similarities would be even more striking to us.
6938 Admitting the facts which are thus described in a popular way, we may
6939 however remark that there is no method of difference by which they can
6940 be defined or estimated, and that they constitute only a small part of
6941 each individual. The doctrine of heredity may seem to take out of our
6942 hands the conduct of our own lives, but it is the idea, not the fact,
6943 which is really terrible to us. For what we have received from our
6944 ancestors is only a fraction of what we are, or may become. The
6945 knowledge that drunkenness or insanity has been prevalent in a
6946 family may be the best safeguard against their recurrence in a future
6947 generation. The parent will be most awake to the vices or diseases in
6948 his child of which he is most sensible within himself. The whole of life
6949 may be directed to their prevention or cure. The traces of consumption
6950 may become fainter, or be wholly effaced: the inherent tendency to vice
6951 or crime may be eradicated. And so heredity, from being a curse, may
6952 become a blessing. We acknowledge that in the matter of our birth, as in
6953 our nature generally, there are previous circumstances which affect
6954 us. But upon this platform of circumstances or within this wall of
6955 necessity, we have still the power of creating a life for ourselves by
6956 the informing energy of the human will.
6957 
6958 There is another aspect of the marriage question to which Plato is a
6959 stranger. All the children born in his state are foundlings. It never
6960 occurred to him that the greater part of them, according to universal
6961 experience, would have perished. For children can only be brought up in
6962 families. There is a subtle sympathy between the mother and the child
6963 which cannot be supplied by other mothers, or by 'strong nurses one or
6964 more' (Laws). If Plato's 'pen' was as fatal as the Creches of Paris, or
6965 the foundling hospital of Dublin, more than nine-tenths of his children
6966 would have perished. There would have been no need to expose or put
6967 out of the way the weaklier children, for they would have died of
6968 themselves. So emphatically does nature protest against the destruction
6969 of the family.
6970 
6971 What Plato had heard or seen of Sparta was applied by him in a mistaken
6972 way to his ideal commonwealth. He probably observed that both the
6973 Spartan men and women were superior in form and strength to the other
6974 Greeks; and this superiority he was disposed to attribute to the laws
6975 and customs relating to marriage. He did not consider that the desire
6976 of a noble offspring was a passion among the Spartans, or that their
6977 physical superiority was to be attributed chiefly, not to their marriage
6978 customs, but to their temperance and training. He did not reflect that
6979 Sparta was great, not in consequence of the relaxation of morality, but
6980 in spite of it, by virtue of a political principle stronger far than
6981 existed in any other Grecian state. Least of all did he observe that
6982 Sparta did not really produce the finest specimens of the Greek
6983 race. The genius, the political inspiration of Athens, the love of
6984 liberty--all that has made Greece famous with posterity, were wanting
6985 among the Spartans. They had no Themistocles, or Pericles, or Aeschylus,
6986 or Sophocles, or Socrates, or Plato. The individual was not allowed to
6987 appear above the state; the laws were fixed, and he had no business to
6988 alter or reform them. Yet whence has the progress of cities and nations
6989 arisen, if not from remarkable individuals, coming into the world we
6990 know not how, and from causes over which we have no control?
6991 Something too much may have been said in modern times of the value of
6992 individuality. But we can hardly condemn too strongly a system which,
6993 instead of fostering the scattered seeds or sparks of genius and
6994 character, tends to smother and extinguish them.
6995 
6996 Still, while condemning Plato, we must acknowledge that neither
6997 Christianity, nor any other form of religion and society, has hitherto
6998 been able to cope with this most difficult of social problems, and that
6999 the side from which Plato regarded it is that from which we turn away.
7000 Population is the most untameable force in the political and social
7001 world. Do we not find, especially in large cities, that the greatest
7002 hindrance to the amelioration of the poor is their improvidence in
7003 marriage?--a small fault truly, if not involving endless consequences.
7004 There are whole countries too, such as India, or, nearer home, Ireland,
7005 in which a right solution of the marriage question seems to lie at the
7006 foundation of the happiness of the community. There are too many people
7007 on a given space, or they marry too early and bring into the world a
7008 sickly and half-developed offspring; or owing to the very conditions
7009 of their existence, they become emaciated and hand on a similar life
7010 to their descendants. But who can oppose the voice of prudence to the
7011 'mightiest passions of mankind' (Laws), especially when they have
7012 been licensed by custom and religion? In addition to the influences of
7013 education, we seem to require some new principles of right and wrong in
7014 these matters, some force of opinion, which may indeed be already heard
7015 whispering in private, but has never affected the moral sentiments
7016 of mankind in general. We unavoidably lose sight of the principle of
7017 utility, just in that action of our lives in which we have the most need
7018 of it. The influences which we can bring to bear upon this question
7019 are chiefly indirect. In a generation or two, education, emigration,
7020 improvements in agriculture and manufactures, may have provided the
7021 solution. The state physician hardly likes to probe the wound: it is
7022 beyond his art; a matter which he cannot safely let alone, but which he
7023 dare not touch:
7024 
7025 'We do but skin and film the ulcerous place.'
7026 
7027 When again in private life we see a whole family one by one dropping
7028 into the grave under the Ate of some inherited malady, and the parents
7029 perhaps surviving them, do our minds ever go back silently to that day
7030 twenty-five or thirty years before on which under the fairest auspices,
7031 amid the rejoicings of friends and acquaintances, a bride and bridegroom
7032 joined hands with one another? In making such a reflection we are not
7033 opposing physical considerations to moral, but moral to physical; we are
7034 seeking to make the voice of reason heard, which drives us back from the
7035 extravagance of sentimentalism on common sense. The late Dr. Combe is
7036 said by his biographer to have resisted the temptation to marriage,
7037 because he knew that he was subject to hereditary consumption. One who
7038 deserved to be called a man of genius, a friend of my youth, was in the
7039 habit of wearing a black ribbon on his wrist, in order to remind him
7040 that, being liable to outbreaks of insanity, he must not give way to the
7041 natural impulses of affection: he died unmarried in a lunatic asylum.
7042 These two little facts suggest the reflection that a very few persons
7043 have done from a sense of duty what the rest of mankind ought to have
7044 done under like circumstances, if they had allowed themselves to think
7045 of all the misery which they were about to bring into the world. If
7046 we could prevent such marriages without any violation of feeling or
7047 propriety, we clearly ought; and the prohibition in the course of time
7048 would be protected by a 'horror naturalis' similar to that which, in
7049 all civilized ages and countries, has prevented the marriage of near
7050 relations by blood. Mankind would have been the happier, if some things
7051 which are now allowed had from the beginning been denied to them; if the
7052 sanction of religion could have prohibited practices inimical to health;
7053 if sanitary principles could in early ages have been invested with a
7054 superstitious awe. But, living as we do far on in the world's history,
7055 we are no longer able to stamp at once with the impress of religion a
7056 new prohibition. A free agent cannot have his fancies regulated by law;
7057 and the execution of the law would be rendered impossible, owing to the
7058 uncertainty of the cases in which marriage was to be forbidden. Who
7059 can weigh virtue, or even fortune against health, or moral and mental
7060 qualities against bodily? Who can measure probabilities against
7061 certainties? There has been some good as well as evil in the discipline
7062 of suffering; and there are diseases, such as consumption, which have
7063 exercised a refining and softening influence on the character. Youth is
7064 too inexperienced to balance such nice considerations; parents do not
7065 often think of them, or think of them too late. They are at a distance
7066 and may probably be averted; change of place, a new state of life, the
7067 interests of a home may be the cure of them. So persons vainly reason
7068 when their minds are already made up and their fortunes irrevocably
7069 linked together. Nor is there any ground for supposing that marriages
7070 are to any great extent influenced by reflections of this sort, which
7071 seem unable to make any head against the irresistible impulse of
7072 individual attachment.
7073 
7074 Lastly, no one can have observed the first rising flood of the passions
7075 in youth, the difficulty of regulating them, and the effects on the
7076 whole mind and nature which follow from them, the stimulus which
7077 is given to them by the imagination, without feeling that there is
7078 something unsatisfactory in our method of treating them. That the most
7079 important influence on human life should be wholly left to chance or
7080 shrouded in mystery, and instead of being disciplined or understood,
7081 should be required to conform only to an external standard of
7082 propriety--cannot be regarded by the philosopher as a safe or
7083 satisfactory condition of human things. And still those who have the
7084 charge of youth may find a way by watchfulness, by affection, by the
7085 manliness and innocence of their own lives, by occasional hints, by
7086 general admonitions which every one can apply for himself, to mitigate
7087 this terrible evil which eats out the heart of individuals and corrupts
7088 the moral sentiments of nations. In no duty towards others is there more
7089 need of reticence and self-restraint. So great is the danger lest he who
7090 would be the counsellor of another should reveal the secret prematurely,
7091 lest he should get another too much into his power; or fix the passing
7092 impression of evil by demanding the confession of it.
7093 
7094 Nor is Plato wrong in asserting that family attachments may interfere
7095 with higher aims. If there have been some who 'to party gave up what was
7096 meant for mankind,' there have certainly been others who to family
7097 gave up what was meant for mankind or for their country. The cares
7098 of children, the necessity of procuring money for their support, the
7099 flatteries of the rich by the poor, the exclusiveness of caste, the
7100 pride of birth or wealth, the tendency of family life to divert men from
7101 the pursuit of the ideal or the heroic, are as lowering in our own age
7102 as in that of Plato. And if we prefer to look at the gentle influences
7103 of home, the development of the affections, the amenities of society,
7104 the devotion of one member of a family for the good of the others, which
7105 form one side of the picture, we must not quarrel with him, or perhaps
7106 ought rather to be grateful to him, for having presented to us the
7107 reverse. Without attempting to defend Plato on grounds of morality, we
7108 may allow that there is an aspect of the world which has not unnaturally
7109 led him into error.
7110 
7111 We hardly appreciate the power which the idea of the State, like all
7112 other abstract ideas, exercised over the mind of Plato. To us the State
7113 seems to be built up out of the family, or sometimes to be the framework
7114 in which family and social life is contained. But to Plato in his
7115 present mood of mind the family is only a disturbing influence which,
7116 instead of filling up, tends to disarrange the higher unity of the
7117 State. No organization is needed except a political, which,
7118 regarded from another point of view, is a military one. The State is
7119 all-sufficing for the wants of man, and, like the idea of the Church in
7120 later ages, absorbs all other desires and affections. In time of war the
7121 thousand citizens are to stand like a rampart impregnable against the
7122 world or the Persian host; in time of peace the preparation for war and
7123 their duties to the State, which are also their duties to one another,
7124 take up their whole life and time. The only other interest which is
7125 allowed to them besides that of war, is the interest of philosophy. When
7126 they are too old to be soldiers they are to retire from active life
7127 and to have a second novitiate of study and contemplation. There is an
7128 element of monasticism even in Plato's communism. If he could have done
7129 without children, he might have converted his Republic into a religious
7130 order. Neither in the Laws, when the daylight of common sense breaks in
7131 upon him, does he retract his error. In the state of which he would be
7132 the founder, there is no marrying or giving in marriage: but because of
7133 the infirmity of mankind, he condescends to allow the law of nature to
7134 prevail.
7135 
7136 (c) But Plato has an equal, or, in his own estimation, even greater
7137 paradox in reserve, which is summed up in the famous text, 'Until kings
7138 are philosophers or philosophers are kings, cities will never cease
7139 from ill.' And by philosophers he explains himself to mean those who
7140 are capable of apprehending ideas, especially the idea of good. To the
7141 attainment of this higher knowledge the second education is directed.
7142 Through a process of training which has already made them good citizens
7143 they are now to be made good legislators. We find with some surprise
7144 (not unlike the feeling which Aristotle in a well-known passage
7145 describes the hearers of Plato's lectures as experiencing, when they
7146 went to a discourse on the idea of good, expecting to be instructed in
7147 moral truths, and received instead of them arithmetical and mathematical
7148 formulae) that Plato does not propose for his future legislators any
7149 study of finance or law or military tactics, but only of abstract
7150 mathematics, as a preparation for the still more abstract conception of
7151 good. We ask, with Aristotle, What is the use of a man knowing the idea
7152 of good, if he does not know what is good for this individual, this
7153 state, this condition of society? We cannot understand how Plato's
7154 legislators or guardians are to be fitted for their work of statesmen by
7155 the study of the five mathematical sciences. We vainly search in Plato's
7156 own writings for any explanation of this seeming absurdity.
7157 
7158 The discovery of a great metaphysical conception seems to ravish the
7159 mind with a prophetic consciousness which takes away the power
7160 of estimating its value. No metaphysical enquirer has ever fairly
7161 criticised his own speculations; in his own judgment they have been
7162 above criticism; nor has he understood that what to him seemed to be
7163 absolute truth may reappear in the next generation as a form of logic
7164 or an instrument of thought. And posterity have also sometimes equally
7165 misapprehended the real value of his speculations. They appear to them
7166 to have contributed nothing to the stock of human knowledge. The IDEA
7167 of good is apt to be regarded by the modern thinker as an unmeaning
7168 abstraction; but he forgets that this abstraction is waiting ready for
7169 use, and will hereafter be filled up by the divisions of knowledge.
7170 When mankind do not as yet know that the world is subject to law, the
7171 introduction of the mere conception of law or design or final cause, and
7172 the far-off anticipation of the harmony of knowledge, are great steps
7173 onward. Even the crude generalization of the unity of all things leads
7174 men to view the world with different eyes, and may easily affect their
7175 conception of human life and of politics, and also their own conduct and
7176 character (Tim). We can imagine how a great mind like that of Pericles
7177 might derive elevation from his intercourse with Anaxagoras (Phaedr.).
7178 To be struggling towards a higher but unattainable conception is a more
7179 favourable intellectual condition than to rest satisfied in a narrow
7180 portion of ascertained fact. And the earlier, which have sometimes been
7181 the greater ideas of science, are often lost sight of at a later period.
7182 How rarely can we say of any modern enquirer in the magnificent language
7183 of Plato, that 'He is the spectator of all time and of all existence!'
7184 
7185 Nor is there anything unnatural in the hasty application of these vast
7186 metaphysical conceptions to practical and political life. In the first
7187 enthusiasm of ideas men are apt to see them everywhere, and to apply
7188 them in the most remote sphere. They do not understand that the
7189 experience of ages is required to enable them to fill up 'the
7190 intermediate axioms.' Plato himself seems to have imagined that the
7191 truths of psychology, like those of astronomy and harmonics, would be
7192 arrived at by a process of deduction, and that the method which he has
7193 pursued in the Fourth Book, of inferring them from experience and the
7194 use of language, was imperfect and only provisional. But when, after
7195 having arrived at the idea of good, which is the end of the science of
7196 dialectic, he is asked, What is the nature, and what are the divisions
7197 of the science? He refuses to answer, as if intending by the refusal to
7198 intimate that the state of knowledge which then existed was not such as
7199 would allow the philosopher to enter into his final rest. The previous
7200 sciences must first be studied, and will, we may add, continue to be
7201 studied tell the end of time, although in a sense different from any
7202 which Plato could have conceived. But we may observe, that while he is
7203 aware of the vacancy of his own ideal, he is full of enthusiasm in the
7204 contemplation of it. Looking into the orb of light, he sees nothing, but
7205 he is warmed and elevated. The Hebrew prophet believed that faith in
7206 God would enable him to govern the world; the Greek philosopher imagined
7207 that contemplation of the good would make a legislator. There is as much
7208 to be filled up in the one case as in the other, and the one mode of
7209 conception is to the Israelite what the other is to the Greek. Both find
7210 a repose in a divine perfection, which, whether in a more personal or
7211 impersonal form, exists without them and independently of them, as well
7212 as within them.
7213 
7214 There is no mention of the idea of good in the Timaeus, nor of the
7215 divine Creator of the world in the Republic; and we are naturally led
7216 to ask in what relation they stand to one another. Is God above or below
7217 the idea of good? Or is the Idea of Good another mode of conceiving God?
7218 The latter appears to be the truer answer. To the Greek philosopher
7219 the perfection and unity of God was a far higher conception than his
7220 personality, which he hardly found a word to express, and which to him
7221 would have seemed to be borrowed from mythology. To the Christian, on
7222 the other hand, or to the modern thinker in general, it is difficult,
7223 if not impossible, to attach reality to what he terms mere abstraction;
7224 while to Plato this very abstraction is the truest and most real of all
7225 things. Hence, from a difference in forms of thought, Plato appears to
7226 be resting on a creation of his own mind only. But if we may be allowed
7227 to paraphrase the idea of good by the words 'intelligent principle of
7228 law and order in the universe, embracing equally man and nature,' we
7229 begin to find a meeting-point between him and ourselves.
7230 
7231 The question whether the ruler or statesman should be a philosopher is
7232 one that has not lost interest in modern times. In most countries of
7233 Europe and Asia there has been some one in the course of ages who
7234 has truly united the power of command with the power of thought and
7235 reflection, as there have been also many false combinations of these
7236 qualities. Some kind of speculative power is necessary both in practical
7237 and political life; like the rhetorician in the Phaedrus, men require to
7238 have a conception of the varieties of human character, and to be raised
7239 on great occasions above the commonplaces of ordinary life. Yet the idea
7240 of the philosopher-statesman has never been popular with the mass of
7241 mankind; partly because he cannot take the world into his confidence or
7242 make them understand the motives from which he acts; and also because
7243 they are jealous of a power which they do not understand. The revolution
7244 which human nature desires to effect step by step in many ages is likely
7245 to be precipitated by him in a single year or life. They are afraid that
7246 in the pursuit of his greater aims he may disregard the common feelings
7247 of humanity, he is too apt to be looking into the distant future or back
7248 into the remote past, and unable to see actions or events which, to use
7249 an expression of Plato's 'are tumbling out at his feet.' Besides, as
7250 Plato would say, there are other corruptions of these philosophical
7251 statesmen. Either 'the native hue of resolution is sicklied o'er with
7252 the pale cast of thought,' and at the moment when action above all
7253 things is required he is undecided, or general principles are enunciated
7254 by him in order to cover some change of policy; or his ignorance of the
7255 world has made him more easily fall a prey to the arts of others; or in
7256 some cases he has been converted into a courtier, who enjoys the luxury
7257 of holding liberal opinions, but was never known to perform a liberal
7258 action. No wonder that mankind have been in the habit of calling
7259 statesmen of this class pedants, sophisters, doctrinaires, visionaries.
7260 For, as we may be allowed to say, a little parodying the words of Plato,
7261 'they have seen bad imitations of the philosopher-statesman.' But a man
7262 in whom the power of thought and action are perfectly balanced, equal to
7263 the present, reaching forward to the future, 'such a one,' ruling in a
7264 constitutional state, 'they have never seen.'
7265 
7266 But as the philosopher is apt to fail in the routine of political life,
7267 so the ordinary statesman is also apt to fail in extraordinary crises.
7268 When the face of the world is beginning to alter, and thunder is heard
7269 in the distance, he is still guided by his old maxims, and is the slave
7270 of his inveterate party prejudices; he cannot perceive the signs of the
7271 times; instead of looking forward he looks back; he learns nothing and
7272 forgets nothing; with 'wise saws and modern instances' he would stem the
7273 rising tide of revolution. He lives more and more within the circle of
7274 his own party, as the world without him becomes stronger. This seems to
7275 be the reason why the old order of things makes so poor a figure
7276 when confronted with the new, why churches can never reform, why most
7277 political changes are made blindly and convulsively. The great crises
7278 in the history of nations have often been met by an ecclesiastical
7279 positiveness, and a more obstinate reassertion of principles which
7280 have lost their hold upon a nation. The fixed ideas of a reactionary
7281 statesman may be compared to madness; they grow upon him, and he becomes
7282 possessed by them; no judgement of others is ever admitted by him to be
7283 weighed in the balance against his own.
7284 
7285 (d) Plato, labouring under what, to modern readers, appears to have been
7286 a confusion of ideas, assimilates the state to the individual, and fails
7287 to distinguish Ethics from Politics. He thinks that to be most of a
7288 state which is most like one man, and in which the citizens have the
7289 greatest uniformity of character. He does not see that the analogy is
7290 partly fallacious, and that the will or character of a state or nation
7291 is really the balance or rather the surplus of individual wills, which
7292 are limited by the condition of having to act in common. The movement
7293 of a body of men can never have the pliancy or facility of a single man;
7294 the freedom of the individual, which is always limited, becomes still
7295 more straitened when transferred to a nation. The powers of action and
7296 feeling are necessarily weaker and more balanced when they are diffused
7297 through a community; whence arises the often discussed question, 'Can a
7298 nation, like an individual, have a conscience?' We hesitate to say
7299 that the characters of nations are nothing more than the sum of the
7300 characters of the individuals who compose them; because there may be
7301 tendencies in individuals which react upon one another. A whole nation
7302 may be wiser than any one man in it; or may be animated by some common
7303 opinion or feeling which could not equally have affected the mind of
7304 a single person, or may have been inspired by a leader of genius to
7305 perform acts more than human. Plato does not appear to have analysed
7306 the complications which arise out of the collective action of mankind.
7307 Neither is he capable of seeing that analogies, though specious as
7308 arguments, may often have no foundation in fact, or of distinguishing
7309 between what is intelligible or vividly present to the mind, and what
7310 is true. In this respect he is far below Aristotle, who is comparatively
7311 seldom imposed upon by false analogies. He cannot disentangle the arts
7312 from the virtues--at least he is always arguing from one to the other.
7313 His notion of music is transferred from harmony of sounds to harmony of
7314 life: in this he is assisted by the ambiguities of language as well as
7315 by the prevalence of Pythagorean notions. And having once assimilated
7316 the state to the individual, he imagines that he will find the
7317 succession of states paralleled in the lives of individuals.
7318 
7319 Still, through this fallacious medium, a real enlargement of ideas is
7320 attained. When the virtues as yet presented no distinct conception to
7321 the mind, a great advance was made by the comparison of them with the
7322 arts; for virtue is partly art, and has an outward form as well as an
7323 inward principle. The harmony of music affords a lively image of the
7324 harmonies of the world and of human life, and may be regarded as a
7325 splendid illustration which was naturally mistaken for a real analogy.
7326 In the same way the identification of ethics with politics has a
7327 tendency to give definiteness to ethics, and also to elevate and ennoble
7328 men's notions of the aims of government and of the duties of citizens;
7329 for ethics from one point of view may be conceived as an idealized law
7330 and politics; and politics, as ethics reduced to the conditions of human
7331 society. There have been evils which have arisen out of the attempt to
7332 identify them, and this has led to the separation or antagonism of
7333 them, which has been introduced by modern political writers. But we may
7334 likewise feel that something has been lost in their separation, and
7335 that the ancient philosophers who estimated the moral and intellectual
7336 wellbeing of mankind first, and the wealth of nations and individuals
7337 second, may have a salutary influence on the speculations of modern
7338 times. Many political maxims originate in a reaction against an opposite
7339 error; and when the errors against which they were directed have passed
7340 away, they in turn become errors.
7341 
7342 3. Plato's views of education are in several respects remarkable;
7343 like the rest of the Republic they are partly Greek and partly ideal,
7344 beginning with the ordinary curriculum of the Greek youth, and extending
7345 to after-life. Plato is the first writer who distinctly says that
7346 education is to comprehend the whole of life, and to be a preparation
7347 for another in which education begins again. This is the continuous
7348 thread which runs through the Republic, and which more than any other of
7349 his ideas admits of an application to modern life.
7350 
7351 He has long given up the notion that virtue cannot be taught; and he is
7352 disposed to modify the thesis of the Protagoras, that the virtues are
7353 one and not many. He is not unwilling to admit the sensible world
7354 into his scheme of truth. Nor does he assert in the Republic the
7355 involuntariness of vice, which is maintained by him in the Timaeus,
7356 Sophist, and Laws (Protag., Apol., Gorg.). Nor do the so-called Platonic
7357 ideas recovered from a former state of existence affect his theory
7358 of mental improvement. Still we observe in him the remains of the old
7359 Socratic doctrine, that true knowledge must be elicited from within, and
7360 is to be sought for in ideas, not in particulars of sense. Education, as
7361 he says, will implant a principle of intelligence which is better than
7362 ten thousand eyes. The paradox that the virtues are one, and the kindred
7363 notion that all virtue is knowledge, are not entirely renounced; the
7364 first is seen in the supremacy given to justice over the rest; the
7365 second in the tendency to absorb the moral virtues in the intellectual,
7366 and to centre all goodness in the contemplation of the idea of good. The
7367 world of sense is still depreciated and identified with opinion, though
7368 admitted to be a shadow of the true. In the Republic he is evidently
7369 impressed with the conviction that vice arises chiefly from ignorance
7370 and may be cured by education; the multitude are hardly to be deemed
7371 responsible for what they do. A faint allusion to the doctrine of
7372 reminiscence occurs in the Tenth Book; but Plato's views of education
7373 have no more real connection with a previous state of existence than
7374 our own; he only proposes to elicit from the mind that which is there
7375 already. Education is represented by him, not as the filling of a
7376 vessel, but as the turning the eye of the soul towards the light.
7377 
7378 He treats first of music or literature, which he divides into true and
7379 false, and then goes on to gymnastics; of infancy in the Republic he
7380 takes no notice, though in the Laws he gives sage counsels about the
7381 nursing of children and the management of the mothers, and would have
7382 an education which is even prior to birth. But in the Republic he begins
7383 with the age at which the child is capable of receiving ideas, and
7384 boldly asserts, in language which sounds paradoxical to modern ears,
7385 that he must be taught the false before he can learn the true. The
7386 modern and ancient philosophical world are not agreed about truth and
7387 falsehood; the one identifies truth almost exclusively with fact, the
7388 other with ideas. This is the difference between ourselves and Plato,
7389 which is, however, partly a difference of words. For we too should admit
7390 that a child must receive many lessons which he imperfectly understands;
7391 he must be taught some things in a figure only, some too which he can
7392 hardly be expected to believe when he grows older; but we should limit
7393 the use of fiction by the necessity of the case. Plato would draw the
7394 line differently; according to him the aim of early education is not
7395 truth as a matter of fact, but truth as a matter of principle; the child
7396 is to be taught first simple religious truths, and then simple moral
7397 truths, and insensibly to learn the lesson of good manners and good
7398 taste. He would make an entire reformation of the old mythology; like
7399 Xenophanes and Heracleitus he is sensible of the deep chasm which
7400 separates his own age from Homer and Hesiod, whom he quotes and invests
7401 with an imaginary authority, but only for his own purposes. The lusts
7402 and treacheries of the gods are to be banished; the terrors of the world
7403 below are to be dispelled; the misbehaviour of the Homeric heroes is
7404 not to be a model for youth. But there is another strain heard in Homer
7405 which may teach our youth endurance; and something may be learnt in
7406 medicine from the simple practice of the Homeric age. The principles
7407 on which religion is to be based are two only: first, that God is true;
7408 secondly, that he is good. Modern and Christian writers have often
7409 fallen short of these; they can hardly be said to have gone beyond them.
7410 
7411 The young are to be brought up in happy surroundings, out of the way of
7412 sights or sounds which may hurt the character or vitiate the taste.
7413 They are to live in an atmosphere of health; the breeze is always to
7414 be wafting to them the impressions of truth and goodness. Could such
7415 an education be realized, or if our modern religious education could
7416 be bound up with truth and virtue and good manners and good taste, that
7417 would be the best hope of human improvement. Plato, like ourselves,
7418 is looking forward to changes in the moral and religious world, and is
7419 preparing for them. He recognizes the danger of unsettling young men's
7420 minds by sudden changes of laws and principles, by destroying the
7421 sacredness of one set of ideas when there is nothing else to take their
7422 place. He is afraid too of the influence of the drama, on the ground
7423 that it encourages false sentiment, and therefore he would not have
7424 his children taken to the theatre; he thinks that the effect on the
7425 spectators is bad, and on the actors still worse. His idea of education
7426 is that of harmonious growth, in which are insensibly learnt the lessons
7427 of temperance and endurance, and the body and mind develope in equal
7428 proportions. The first principle which runs through all art and nature
7429 is simplicity; this also is to be the rule of human life.
7430 
7431 The second stage of education is gymnastic, which answers to the period
7432 of muscular growth and development. The simplicity which is enforced in
7433 music is extended to gymnastic; Plato is aware that the training of the
7434 body may be inconsistent with the training of the mind, and that bodily
7435 exercise may be easily overdone. Excessive training of the body is
7436 apt to give men a headache or to render them sleepy at a lecture on
7437 philosophy, and this they attribute not to the true cause, but to the
7438 nature of the subject. Two points are noticeable in Plato's treatment of
7439 gymnastic:--First, that the time of training is entirely separated from
7440 the time of literary education. He seems to have thought that two things
7441 of an opposite and different nature could not be learnt at the same
7442 time. Here we can hardly agree with him; and, if we may judge by
7443 experience, the effect of spending three years between the ages of
7444 fourteen and seventeen in mere bodily exercise would be far from
7445 improving to the intellect. Secondly, he affirms that music and
7446 gymnastic are not, as common opinion is apt to imagine, intended, the
7447 one for the cultivation of the mind and the other of the body, but that
7448 they are both equally designed for the improvement of the mind. The
7449 body, in his view, is the servant of the mind; the subjection of the
7450 lower to the higher is for the advantage of both. And doubtless the
7451 mind may exercise a very great and paramount influence over the body,
7452 if exerted not at particular moments and by fits and starts, but
7453 continuously, in making preparation for the whole of life. Other Greek
7454 writers saw the mischievous tendency of Spartan discipline (Arist. Pol;
7455 Thuc.). But only Plato recognized the fundamental error on which the
7456 practice was based.
7457 
7458 The subject of gymnastic leads Plato to the sister subject of medicine,
7459 which he further illustrates by the parallel of law. The modern
7460 disbelief in medicine has led in this, as in some other departments of
7461 knowledge, to a demand for greater simplicity; physicians are becoming
7462 aware that they often make diseases 'greater and more complicated' by
7463 their treatment of them (Rep.). In two thousand years their art has made
7464 but slender progress; what they have gained in the analysis of the parts
7465 is in a great degree lost by their feebler conception of the human frame
7466 as a whole. They have attended more to the cure of diseases than to the
7467 conditions of health; and the improvements in medicine have been more
7468 than counterbalanced by the disuse of regular training. Until lately
7469 they have hardly thought of air and water, the importance of which was
7470 well understood by the ancients; as Aristotle remarks, 'Air and water,
7471 being the elements which we most use, have the greatest effect upon
7472 health' (Polit.). For ages physicians have been under the dominion of
7473 prejudices which have only recently given way; and now there are as many
7474 opinions in medicine as in theology, and an equal degree of scepticism
7475 and some want of toleration about both. Plato has several good notions
7476 about medicine; according to him, 'the eye cannot be cured without the
7477 rest of the body, nor the body without the mind' (Charm.). No man
7478 of sense, he says in the Timaeus, would take physic; and we heartily
7479 sympathize with him in the Laws when he declares that 'the limbs of the
7480 rustic worn with toil will derive more benefit from warm baths than from
7481 the prescriptions of a not over wise doctor.' But we can hardly praise
7482 him when, in obedience to the authority of Homer, he depreciates diet,
7483 or approve of the inhuman spirit in which he would get rid of invalid
7484 and useless lives by leaving them to die. He does not seem to have
7485 considered that the 'bridle of Theages' might be accompanied by
7486 qualities which were of far more value to the State than the health
7487 or strength of the citizens; or that the duty of taking care of the
7488 helpless might be an important element of education in a State. The
7489 physician himself (this is a delicate and subtle observation) should
7490 not be a man in robust health; he should have, in modern phraseology,
7491 a nervous temperament; he should have experience of disease in his own
7492 person, in order that his powers of observation may be quickened in the
7493 case of others.
7494 
7495 The perplexity of medicine is paralleled by the perplexity of law; in
7496 which, again, Plato would have men follow the golden rule of simplicity.
7497 Greater matters are to be determined by the legislator or by the oracle
7498 of Delphi, lesser matters are to be left to the temporary regulation
7499 of the citizens themselves. Plato is aware that laissez faire is an
7500 important element of government. The diseases of a State are like the
7501 heads of a hydra; they multiply when they are cut off. The true remedy
7502 for them is not extirpation but prevention. And the way to prevent them
7503 is to take care of education, and education will take care of all the
7504 rest. So in modern times men have often felt that the only political
7505 measure worth having--the only one which would produce any certain or
7506 lasting effect, was a measure of national education. And in our own more
7507 than in any previous age the necessity has been recognized of restoring
7508 the ever-increasing confusion of law to simplicity and common sense.
7509 
7510 When the training in music and gymnastic is completed, there follows the
7511 first stage of active and public life. But soon education is to begin
7512 again from a new point of view. In the interval between the Fourth and
7513 Seventh Books we have discussed the nature of knowledge, and have thence
7514 been led to form a higher conception of what was required of us. For
7515 true knowledge, according to Plato, is of abstractions, and has to do,
7516 not with particulars or individuals, but with universals only; not with
7517 the beauties of poetry, but with the ideas of philosophy. And the great
7518 aim of education is the cultivation of the habit of abstraction. This
7519 is to be acquired through the study of the mathematical sciences. They
7520 alone are capable of giving ideas of relation, and of arousing the
7521 dormant energies of thought.
7522 
7523 Mathematics in the age of Plato comprehended a very small part of that
7524 which is now included in them; but they bore a much larger proportion to
7525 the sum of human knowledge. They were the only organon of thought which
7526 the human mind at that time possessed, and the only measure by which
7527 the chaos of particulars could be reduced to rule and order. The
7528 faculty which they trained was naturally at war with the poetical
7529 or imaginative; and hence to Plato, who is everywhere seeking for
7530 abstractions and trying to get rid of the illusions of sense, nearly
7531 the whole of education is contained in them. They seemed to have an
7532 inexhaustible application, partly because their true limits were not yet
7533 understood. These Plato himself is beginning to investigate; though
7534 not aware that number and figure are mere abstractions of sense,
7535 he recognizes that the forms used by geometry are borrowed from the
7536 sensible world. He seeks to find the ultimate ground of mathematical
7537 ideas in the idea of good, though he does not satisfactorily explain the
7538 connexion between them; and in his conception of the relation of ideas
7539 to numbers, he falls very far short of the definiteness attributed to
7540 him by Aristotle (Met.). But if he fails to recognize the true limits of
7541 mathematics, he also reaches a point beyond them; in his view, ideas
7542 of number become secondary to a higher conception of knowledge. The
7543 dialectician is as much above the mathematician as the mathematician is
7544 above the ordinary man. The one, the self-proving, the good which is
7545 the higher sphere of dialectic, is the perfect truth to which all things
7546 ascend, and in which they finally repose.
7547 
7548 This self-proving unity or idea of good is a mere vision of which no
7549 distinct explanation can be given, relative only to a particular stage
7550 in Greek philosophy. It is an abstraction under which no individuals
7551 are comprehended, a whole which has no parts (Arist., Nic. Eth.). The
7552 vacancy of such a form was perceived by Aristotle, but not by Plato.
7553 Nor did he recognize that in the dialectical process are included two or
7554 more methods of investigation which are at variance with each other.
7555 He did not see that whether he took the longer or the shorter road, no
7556 advance could be made in this way. And yet such visions often have an
7557 immense effect; for although the method of science cannot anticipate
7558 science, the idea of science, not as it is, but as it will be in the
7559 future, is a great and inspiring principle. In the pursuit of knowledge
7560 we are always pressing forward to something beyond us; and as a false
7561 conception of knowledge, for example the scholastic philosophy, may lead
7562 men astray during many ages, so the true ideal, though vacant, may draw
7563 all their thoughts in a right direction. It makes a great difference
7564 whether the general expectation of knowledge, as this indefinite feeling
7565 may be termed, is based upon a sound judgment. For mankind may often
7566 entertain a true conception of what knowledge ought to be when they have
7567 but a slender experience of facts. The correlation of the sciences, the
7568 consciousness of the unity of nature, the idea of classification, the
7569 sense of proportion, the unwillingness to stop short of certainty or to
7570 confound probability with truth, are important principles of the higher
7571 education. Although Plato could tell us nothing, and perhaps knew that
7572 he could tell us nothing, of the absolute truth, he has exercised
7573 an influence on the human mind which even at the present day is not
7574 exhausted; and political and social questions may yet arise in which the
7575 thoughts of Plato may be read anew and receive a fresh meaning.
7576 
7577 The Idea of good is so called only in the Republic, but there are traces
7578 of it in other dialogues of Plato. It is a cause as well as an idea, and
7579 from this point of view may be compared with the creator of the Timaeus,
7580 who out of his goodness created all things. It corresponds to a certain
7581 extent with the modern conception of a law of nature, or of a final
7582 cause, or of both in one, and in this regard may be connected with the
7583 measure and symmetry of the Philebus. It is represented in the Symposium
7584 under the aspect of beauty, and is supposed to be attained there by
7585 stages of initiation, as here by regular gradations of knowledge. Viewed
7586 subjectively, it is the process or science of dialectic. This is the
7587 science which, according to the Phaedrus, is the true basis of rhetoric,
7588 which alone is able to distinguish the natures and classes of men and
7589 things; which divides a whole into the natural parts, and reunites the
7590 scattered parts into a natural or organized whole; which defines the
7591 abstract essences or universal ideas of all things, and connects them;
7592 which pierces the veil of hypotheses and reaches the final cause or
7593 first principle of all; which regards the sciences in relation to the
7594 idea of good. This ideal science is the highest process of thought,
7595 and may be described as the soul conversing with herself or holding
7596 communion with eternal truth and beauty, and in another form is
7597 the everlasting question and answer--the ceaseless interrogative of
7598 Socrates. The dialogues of Plato are themselves examples of the nature
7599 and method of dialectic. Viewed objectively, the idea of good is a power
7600 or cause which makes the world without us correspond with the world
7601 within. Yet this world without us is still a world of ideas. With Plato
7602 the investigation of nature is another department of knowledge, and in
7603 this he seeks to attain only probable conclusions (Timaeus).
7604 
7605 If we ask whether this science of dialectic which Plato only half
7606 explains to us is more akin to logic or to metaphysics, the answer is
7607 that in his mind the two sciences are not as yet distinguished, any more
7608 than the subjective and objective aspects of the world and of man, which
7609 German philosophy has revealed to us. Nor has he determined whether
7610 his science of dialectic is at rest or in motion, concerned with the
7611 contemplation of absolute being, or with a process of development
7612 and evolution. Modern metaphysics may be described as the science of
7613 abstractions, or as the science of the evolution of thought; modern
7614 logic, when passing beyond the bounds of mere Aristotelian forms, may be
7615 defined as the science of method. The germ of both of them is contained
7616 in the Platonic dialectic; all metaphysicians have something in common
7617 with the ideas of Plato; all logicians have derived something from
7618 the method of Plato. The nearest approach in modern philosophy to the
7619 universal science of Plato, is to be found in the Hegelian 'succession
7620 of moments in the unity of the idea.' Plato and Hegel alike seem to
7621 have conceived the world as the correlation of abstractions; and not
7622 impossibly they would have understood one another better than any of
7623 their commentators understand them (Swift's Voyage to Laputa. 'Having
7624 a desire to see those ancients who were most renowned for wit and
7625 learning, I set apart one day on purpose. I proposed that Homer and
7626 Aristotle might appear at the head of all their commentators; but these
7627 were so numerous that some hundreds were forced to attend in the court
7628 and outward rooms of the palace. I knew, and could distinguish these two
7629 heroes, at first sight, not only from the crowd, but from each other.
7630 Homer was the taller and comelier person of the two, walked very erect
7631 for one of his age, and his eyes were the most quick and piercing I ever
7632 beheld. Aristotle stooped much, and made use of a staff. His visage was
7633 meagre, his hair lank and thin, and his voice hollow. I soon discovered
7634 that both of them were perfect strangers to the rest of the company,
7635 and had never seen or heard of them before. And I had a whisper from a
7636 ghost, who shall be nameless, "That these commentators always kept in
7637 the most distant quarters from their principals, in the lower world,
7638 through a consciousness of shame and guilt, because they had so horribly
7639 misrepresented the meaning of these authors to posterity." I introduced
7640 Didymus and Eustathius to Homer, and prevailed on him to treat them
7641 better than perhaps they deserved, for he soon found they wanted a
7642 genius to enter into the spirit of a poet. But Aristotle was out of all
7643 patience with the account I gave him of Scotus and Ramus, as I presented
7644 them to him; and he asked them "whether the rest of the tribe were as
7645 great dunces as themselves?"'). There is, however, a difference between
7646 them: for whereas Hegel is thinking of all the minds of men as one mind,
7647 which developes the stages of the idea in different countries or at
7648 different times in the same country, with Plato these gradations are
7649 regarded only as an order of thought or ideas; the history of the human
7650 mind had not yet dawned upon him.
7651 
7652 Many criticisms may be made on Plato's theory of education. While in
7653 some respects he unavoidably falls short of modern thinkers, in others
7654 he is in advance of them. He is opposed to the modes of education which
7655 prevailed in his own time; but he can hardly be said to have discovered
7656 new ones. He does not see that education is relative to the characters
7657 of individuals; he only desires to impress the same form of the state on
7658 the minds of all. He has no sufficient idea of the effect of literature
7659 on the formation of the mind, and greatly exaggerates that of
7660 mathematics. His aim is above all things to train the reasoning
7661 faculties; to implant in the mind the spirit and power of abstraction;
7662 to explain and define general notions, and, if possible, to connect
7663 them. No wonder that in the vacancy of actual knowledge his followers,
7664 and at times even he himself, should have fallen away from the doctrine
7665 of ideas, and have returned to that branch of knowledge in which alone
7666 the relation of the one and many can be truly seen--the science of
7667 number. In his views both of teaching and training he might be styled,
7668 in modern language, a doctrinaire; after the Spartan fashion he would
7669 have his citizens cast in one mould; he does not seem to consider that
7670 some degree of freedom, 'a little wholesome neglect,' is necessary to
7671 strengthen and develope the character and to give play to the individual
7672 nature. His citizens would not have acquired that knowledge which in
7673 the vision of Er is supposed to be gained by the pilgrims from their
7674 experience of evil.
7675 
7676 On the other hand, Plato is far in advance of modern philosophers and
7677 theologians when he teaches that education is to be continued through
7678 life and will begin again in another. He would never allow education of
7679 some kind to cease; although he was aware that the proverbial saying of
7680 Solon, 'I grow old learning many things,' cannot be applied literally.
7681 Himself ravished with the contemplation of the idea of good, and
7682 delighting in solid geometry (Rep.), he has no difficulty in imagining
7683 that a lifetime might be passed happily in such pursuits. We who know
7684 how many more men of business there are in the world than real students
7685 or thinkers, are not equally sanguine. The education which he proposes
7686 for his citizens is really the ideal life of the philosopher or man of
7687 genius, interrupted, but only for a time, by practical duties,--a life
7688 not for the many, but for the few.
7689 
7690 Yet the thought of Plato may not be wholly incapable of application to
7691 our own times. Even if regarded as an ideal which can never be realized,
7692 it may have a great effect in elevating the characters of mankind,
7693 and raising them above the routine of their ordinary occupation or
7694 profession. It is the best form under which we can conceive the whole
7695 of life. Nevertheless the idea of Plato is not easily put into practice.
7696 For the education of after life is necessarily the education which each
7697 one gives himself. Men and women cannot be brought together in schools
7698 or colleges at forty or fifty years of age; and if they could the result
7699 would be disappointing. The destination of most men is what Plato would
7700 call 'the Den' for the whole of life, and with that they are content.
7701 Neither have they teachers or advisers with whom they can take counsel
7702 in riper years. There is no 'schoolmaster abroad' who will tell them of
7703 their faults, or inspire them with the higher sense of duty, or with the
7704 ambition of a true success in life; no Socrates who will convict them
7705 of ignorance; no Christ, or follower of Christ, who will reprove them
7706 of sin. Hence they have a difficulty in receiving the first element of
7707 improvement, which is self-knowledge. The hopes of youth no longer stir
7708 them; they rather wish to rest than to pursue high objects. A few
7709 only who have come across great men and women, or eminent teachers of
7710 religion and morality, have received a second life from them, and have
7711 lighted a candle from the fire of their genius.
7712 
7713 The want of energy is one of the main reasons why so few persons
7714 continue to improve in later years. They have not the will, and do not
7715 know the way. They 'never try an experiment,' or look up a point
7716 of interest for themselves; they make no sacrifices for the sake of
7717 knowledge; their minds, like their bodies, at a certain age become
7718 fixed. Genius has been defined as 'the power of taking pains'; but
7719 hardly any one keeps up his interest in knowledge throughout a whole
7720 life. The troubles of a family, the business of making money, the
7721 demands of a profession destroy the elasticity of the mind. The waxen
7722 tablet of the memory which was once capable of receiving 'true thoughts
7723 and clear impressions' becomes hard and crowded; there is not room
7724 for the accumulations of a long life (Theaet.). The student, as years
7725 advance, rather makes an exchange of knowledge than adds to his stores.
7726 There is no pressing necessity to learn; the stock of Classics or
7727 History or Natural Science which was enough for a man at twenty-five is
7728 enough for him at fifty. Neither is it easy to give a definite answer to
7729 any one who asks how he is to improve. For self-education consists in a
7730 thousand things, commonplace in themselves,--in adding to what we are
7731 by nature something of what we are not; in learning to see ourselves as
7732 others see us; in judging, not by opinion, but by the evidence of facts;
7733 in seeking out the society of superior minds; in a study of lives and
7734 writings of great men; in observation of the world and character; in
7735 receiving kindly the natural influence of different times of life; in
7736 any act or thought which is raised above the practice or opinions of
7737 mankind; in the pursuit of some new or original enquiry; in any effort
7738 of mind which calls forth some latent power.
7739 
7740 If any one is desirous of carrying out in detail the Platonic education
7741 of after-life, some such counsels as the following may be offered to
7742 him:--That he shall choose the branch of knowledge to which his own mind
7743 most distinctly inclines, and in which he takes the greatest delight,
7744 either one which seems to connect with his own daily employment, or,
7745 perhaps, furnishes the greatest contrast to it. He may study from the
7746 speculative side the profession or business in which he is practically
7747 engaged. He may make Homer, Dante, Shakespeare, Plato, Bacon the friends
7748 and companions of his life. He may find opportunities of hearing the
7749 living voice of a great teacher. He may select for enquiry some point of
7750 history or some unexplained phenomenon of nature. An hour a day passed
7751 in such scientific or literary pursuits will furnish as many facts as
7752 the memory can retain, and will give him 'a pleasure not to be repented
7753 of' (Timaeus). Only let him beware of being the slave of crotchets, or
7754 of running after a Will o' the Wisp in his ignorance, or in his vanity
7755 of attributing to himself the gifts of a poet or assuming the air of
7756 a philosopher. He should know the limits of his own powers. Better to
7757 build up the mind by slow additions, to creep on quietly from one
7758 thing to another, to gain insensibly new powers and new interests in
7759 knowledge, than to form vast schemes which are never destined to be
7760 realized. But perhaps, as Plato would say, 'This is part of another
7761 subject' (Tim.); though we may also defend our digression by his example
7762 (Theaet.).
7763 
7764 4. We remark with surprise that the progress of nations or the natural
7765 growth of institutions which fill modern treatises on political
7766 philosophy seem hardly ever to have attracted the attention of Plato
7767 and Aristotle. The ancients were familiar with the mutability of human
7768 affairs; they could moralize over the ruins of cities and the fall of
7769 empires (Plato, Statesman, and Sulpicius' Letter to Cicero); by them
7770 fate and chance were deemed to be real powers, almost persons, and
7771 to have had a great share in political events. The wiser of them like
7772 Thucydides believed that 'what had been would be again,' and that a
7773 tolerable idea of the future could be gathered from the past. Also they
7774 had dreams of a Golden Age which existed once upon a time and might
7775 still exist in some unknown land, or might return again in the remote
7776 future. But the regular growth of a state enlightened by experience,
7777 progressing in knowledge, improving in the arts, of which the citizens
7778 were educated by the fulfilment of political duties, appears never to
7779 have come within the range of their hopes and aspirations. Such a state
7780 had never been seen, and therefore could not be conceived by them. Their
7781 experience (Aristot. Metaph.; Plato, Laws) led them to conclude that
7782 there had been cycles of civilization in which the arts had been
7783 discovered and lost many times over, and cities had been overthrown and
7784 rebuilt again and again, and deluges and volcanoes and other natural
7785 convulsions had altered the face of the earth. Tradition told them of
7786 many destructions of mankind and of the preservation of a remnant.
7787 The world began again after a deluge and was reconstructed out of the
7788 fragments of itself. Also they were acquainted with empires of unknown
7789 antiquity, like the Egyptian or Assyrian; but they had never seen them
7790 grow, and could not imagine, any more than we can, the state of man
7791 which preceded them. They were puzzled and awestricken by the Egyptian
7792 monuments, of which the forms, as Plato says, not in a figure, but
7793 literally, were ten thousand years old (Laws), and they contrasted the
7794 antiquity of Egypt with their own short memories.
7795 
7796 The early legends of Hellas have no real connection with the later
7797 history: they are at a distance, and the intermediate region is
7798 concealed from view; there is no road or path which leads from one to
7799 the other. At the beginning of Greek history, in the vestibule of the
7800 temple, is seen standing first of all the figure of the legislator,
7801 himself the interpreter and servant of the God. The fundamental laws
7802 which he gives are not supposed to change with time and circumstances.
7803 The salvation of the state is held rather to depend on the inviolable
7804 maintenance of them. They were sanctioned by the authority of heaven,
7805 and it was deemed impiety to alter them. The desire to maintain
7806 them unaltered seems to be the origin of what at first sight is very
7807 surprising to us--the intolerant zeal of Plato against innovators in
7808 religion or politics (Laws); although with a happy inconsistency he
7809 is also willing that the laws of other countries should be studied and
7810 improvements in legislation privately communicated to the Nocturnal
7811 Council (Laws). The additions which were made to them in later ages in
7812 order to meet the increasing complexity of affairs were still ascribed
7813 by a fiction to the original legislator; and the words of such
7814 enactments at Athens were disputed over as if they had been the words of
7815 Solon himself. Plato hopes to preserve in a later generation the mind of
7816 the legislator; he would have his citizens remain within the lines
7817 which he has laid down for them. He would not harass them with minute
7818 regulations, he would have allowed some changes in the laws: but not
7819 changes which would affect the fundamental institutions of the state,
7820 such for example as would convert an aristocracy into a timocracy, or a
7821 timocracy into a popular form of government.
7822 
7823 Passing from speculations to facts, we observe that progress has been
7824 the exception rather than the law of human history. And therefore we are
7825 not surprised to find that the idea of progress is of modern rather than
7826 of ancient date; and, like the idea of a philosophy of history, is
7827 not more than a century or two old. It seems to have arisen out of the
7828 impression left on the human mind by the growth of the Roman Empire
7829 and of the Christian Church, and to be due to the political and social
7830 improvements which they introduced into the world; and still more in
7831 our own century to the idealism of the first French Revolution and the
7832 triumph of American Independence; and in a yet greater degree to the
7833 vast material prosperity and growth of population in England and her
7834 colonies and in America. It is also to be ascribed in a measure to the
7835 greater study of the philosophy of history. The optimist temperament of
7836 some great writers has assisted the creation of it, while the opposite
7837 character has led a few to regard the future of the world as dark.
7838 The 'spectator of all time and of all existence' sees more of 'the
7839 increasing purpose which through the ages ran' than formerly: but to the
7840 inhabitant of a small state of Hellas the vision was necessarily limited
7841 like the valley in which he dwelt. There was no remote past on which his
7842 eye could rest, nor any future from which the veil was partly lifted up
7843 by the analogy of history. The narrowness of view, which to ourselves
7844 appears so singular, was to him natural, if not unavoidable.
7845 
7846 5. For the relation of the Republic to the Statesman and the Laws, and
7847 the two other works of Plato which directly treat of politics, see the
7848 Introductions to the two latter; a few general points of comparison may
7849 be touched upon in this place.
7850 
7851 And first of the Laws.
7852 
7853 (1) The Republic, though probably written at intervals, yet speaking
7854 generally and judging by the indications of thought and style, may be
7855 reasonably ascribed to the middle period of Plato's life: the Laws are
7856 certainly the work of his declining years, and some portions of them at
7857 any rate seem to have been written in extreme old age.
7858 
7859 (2) The Republic is full of hope and aspiration: the Laws bear the stamp
7860 of failure and disappointment. The one is a finished work which received
7861 the last touches of the author: the other is imperfectly executed, and
7862 apparently unfinished. The one has the grace and beauty of youth: the
7863 other has lost the poetical form, but has more of the severity and
7864 knowledge of life which is characteristic of old age.
7865 
7866 (3) The most conspicuous defect of the Laws is the failure of dramatic
7867 power, whereas the Republic is full of striking contrasts of ideas and
7868 oppositions of character.
7869 
7870 (4) The Laws may be said to have more the nature of a sermon,
7871 the Republic of a poem; the one is more religious, the other more
7872 intellectual.
7873 
7874 (5) Many theories of Plato, such as the doctrine of ideas, the
7875 government of the world by philosophers, are not found in the Laws;
7876 the immortality of the soul is first mentioned in xii; the person of
7877 Socrates has altogether disappeared. The community of women and children
7878 is renounced; the institution of common or public meals for women (Laws)
7879 is for the first time introduced (Ar. Pol.).
7880 
7881 (6) There remains in the Laws the old enmity to the poets, who are
7882 ironically saluted in high-flown terms, and, at the same time, are
7883 peremptorily ordered out of the city, if they are not willing to submit
7884 their poems to the censorship of the magistrates (Rep.).
7885 
7886 (7) Though the work is in most respects inferior, there are a few
7887 passages in the Laws, such as the honour due to the soul, the evils
7888 of licentious or unnatural love, the whole of Book x. (religion), the
7889 dishonesty of retail trade, and bequests, which come more home to us,
7890 and contain more of what may be termed the modern element in Plato than
7891 almost anything in the Republic.
7892 
7893 The relation of the two works to one another is very well given:
7894 
7895 (1) by Aristotle in the Politics from the side of the Laws:--
7896 
7897 'The same, or nearly the same, objections apply to Plato's later work,
7898 the Laws, and therefore we had better examine briefly the constitution
7899 which is therein described. In the Republic, Socrates has definitely
7900 settled in all a few questions only; such as the community of women and
7901 children, the community of property, and the constitution of the state.
7902 The population is divided into two classes--one of husbandmen, and
7903 the other of warriors; from this latter is taken a third class of
7904 counsellors and rulers of the state. But Socrates has not determined
7905 whether the husbandmen and artists are to have a share in the
7906 government, and whether they too are to carry arms and share in military
7907 service or not. He certainly thinks that the women ought to share in the
