7908 education of the guardians, and to fight by their side. The remainder of
7909 the work is filled up with digressions foreign to the main subject, and
7910 with discussions about the education of the guardians. In the Laws there
7911 is hardly anything but laws; not much is said about the constitution.
7912 This, which he had intended to make more of the ordinary type, he
7913 gradually brings round to the other or ideal form. For with the
7914 exception of the community of women and property, he supposes everything
7915 to be the same in both states; there is to be the same education; the
7916 citizens of both are to live free from servile occupations, and there
7917 are to be common meals in both. The only difference is that in the Laws
7918 the common meals are extended to women, and the warriors number about
7919 5000, but in the Republic only 1000.'
7920 
7921 (2) by Plato in the Laws (Book v.), from the side of the Republic:--
7922 
7923 'The first and highest form of the state and of the government and of
7924 the law is that in which there prevails most widely the ancient saying
7925 that "Friends have all things in common." Whether there is now, or ever
7926 will be, this communion of women and children and of property, in which
7927 the private and individual is altogether banished from life, and things
7928 which are by nature private, such as eyes and ears and hands, have
7929 become common, and all men express praise and blame, and feel joy
7930 and sorrow, on the same occasions, and the laws unite the city to the
7931 utmost,--whether all this is possible or not, I say that no man, acting
7932 upon any other principle, will ever constitute a state more exalted in
7933 virtue, or truer or better than this. Such a state, whether inhabited
7934 by Gods or sons of Gods, will make them blessed who dwell therein; and
7935 therefore to this we are to look for the pattern of the state, and to
7936 cling to this, and, as far as possible, to seek for one which is like
7937 this. The state which we have now in hand, when created, will be nearest
7938 to immortality and unity in the next degree; and after that, by the
7939 grace of God, we will complete the third one. And we will begin by
7940 speaking of the nature and origin of the second.'
7941 
7942 The comparatively short work called the Statesman or Politicus in its
7943 style and manner is more akin to the Laws, while in its idealism
7944 it rather resembles the Republic. As far as we can judge by various
7945 indications of language and thought, it must be later than the one and
7946 of course earlier than the other. In both the Republic and Statesman a
7947 close connection is maintained between Politics and Dialectic. In the
7948 Statesman, enquiries into the principles of Method are interspersed with
7949 discussions about Politics. The comparative advantages of the rule of
7950 law and of a person are considered, and the decision given in favour of
7951 a person (Arist. Pol.). But much may be said on the other side, nor is
7952 the opposition necessary; for a person may rule by law, and law may
7953 be so applied as to be the living voice of the legislator. As in the
7954 Republic, there is a myth, describing, however, not a future, but a
7955 former existence of mankind. The question is asked, 'Whether the state
7956 of innocence which is described in the myth, or a state like our own
7957 which possesses art and science and distinguishes good from evil, is
7958 the preferable condition of man.' To this question of the comparative
7959 happiness of civilized and primitive life, which was so often discussed
7960 in the last century and in our own, no answer is given. The Statesman,
7961 though less perfect in style than the Republic and of far less range,
7962 may justly be regarded as one of the greatest of Plato's dialogues.
7963 
7964 6. Others as well as Plato have chosen an ideal Republic to be the
7965 vehicle of thoughts which they could not definitely express, or which
7966 went beyond their own age. The classical writing which approaches most
7967 nearly to the Republic of Plato is the 'De Republica' of Cicero; but
7968 neither in this nor in any other of his dialogues does he rival the
7969 art of Plato. The manners are clumsy and inferior; the hand of the
7970 rhetorician is apparent at every turn. Yet noble sentiments are
7971 constantly recurring: the true note of Roman patriotism--'We Romans are
7972 a great people'--resounds through the whole work. Like Socrates, Cicero
7973 turns away from the phenomena of the heavens to civil and political
7974 life. He would rather not discuss the 'two Suns' of which all Rome was
7975 talking, when he can converse about 'the two nations in one' which had
7976 divided Rome ever since the days of the Gracchi. Like Socrates again,
7977 speaking in the person of Scipio, he is afraid lest he should assume
7978 too much the character of a teacher, rather than of an equal who is
7979 discussing among friends the two sides of a question. He would confine
7980 the terms King or State to the rule of reason and justice, and he will
7981 not concede that title either to a democracy or to a monarchy. But under
7982 the rule of reason and justice he is willing to include the natural
7983 superior ruling over the natural inferior, which he compares to the soul
7984 ruling over the body. He prefers a mixture of forms of government to any
7985 single one. The two portraits of the just and the unjust, which occur in
7986 the second book of the Republic, are transferred to the state--Philus,
7987 one of the interlocutors, maintaining against his will the necessity
7988 of injustice as a principle of government, while the other, Laelius,
7989 supports the opposite thesis. His views of language and number are
7990 derived from Plato; like him he denounces the drama. He also declares
7991 that if his life were to be twice as long he would have no time to read
7992 the lyric poets. The picture of democracy is translated by him word for
7993 word, though he had hardly shown himself able to 'carry the jest' of
7994 Plato. He converts into a stately sentence the humorous fancy about the
7995 animals, who 'are so imbued with the spirit of democracy that they make
7996 the passers-by get out of their way.' His description of the tyrant is
7997 imitated from Plato, but is far inferior. The second book is historical,
7998 and claims for the Roman constitution (which is to him the ideal) a
7999 foundation of fact such as Plato probably intended to have given to the
8000 Republic in the Critias. His most remarkable imitation of Plato is the
8001 adaptation of the vision of Er, which is converted by Cicero into the
8002 'Somnium Scipionis'; he has 'romanized' the myth of the Republic, adding
8003 an argument for the immortality of the soul taken from the Phaedrus,
8004 and some other touches derived from the Phaedo and the Timaeus. Though a
8005 beautiful tale and containing splendid passages, the 'Somnium Scipionis;
8006 is very inferior to the vision of Er; it is only a dream, and hardly
8007 allows the reader to suppose that the writer believes in his own
8008 creation. Whether his dialogues were framed on the model of the lost
8009 dialogues of Aristotle, as he himself tells us, or of Plato, to which
8010 they bear many superficial resemblances, he is still the Roman orator;
8011 he is not conversing, but making speeches, and is never able to mould
8012 the intractable Latin to the grace and ease of the Greek Platonic
8013 dialogue. But if he is defective in form, much more is he inferior to
8014 the Greek in matter; he nowhere in his philosophical writings leaves
8015 upon our minds the impression of an original thinker.
8016 
8017 Plato's Republic has been said to be a church and not a state; and such
8018 an ideal of a city in the heavens has always hovered over the Christian
8019 world, and is embodied in St. Augustine's 'De Civitate Dei,' which is
8020 suggested by the decay and fall of the Roman Empire, much in the same
8021 manner in which we may imagine the Republic of Plato to have been
8022 influenced by the decline of Greek politics in the writer's own age. The
8023 difference is that in the time of Plato the degeneracy, though certain,
8024 was gradual and insensible: whereas the taking of Rome by the Goths
8025 stirred like an earthquake the age of St. Augustine. Men were inclined
8026 to believe that the overthrow of the city was to be ascribed to the
8027 anger felt by the old Roman deities at the neglect of their worship. St.
8028 Augustine maintains the opposite thesis; he argues that the destruction
8029 of the Roman Empire is due, not to the rise of Christianity, but to
8030 the vices of Paganism. He wanders over Roman history, and over Greek
8031 philosophy and mythology, and finds everywhere crime, impiety and
8032 falsehood. He compares the worst parts of the Gentile religions with
8033 the best elements of the faith of Christ. He shows nothing of the spirit
8034 which led others of the early Christian Fathers to recognize in the
8035 writings of the Greek philosophers the power of the divine truth. He
8036 traces the parallel of the kingdom of God, that is, the history of the
8037 Jews, contained in their scriptures, and of the kingdoms of the world,
8038 which are found in gentile writers, and pursues them both into an ideal
8039 future. It need hardly be remarked that his use both of Greek and
8040 of Roman historians and of the sacred writings of the Jews is wholly
8041 uncritical. The heathen mythology, the Sybilline oracles, the myths
8042 of Plato, the dreams of Neo-Platonists are equally regarded by him as
8043 matter of fact. He must be acknowledged to be a strictly polemical or
8044 controversial writer who makes the best of everything on one side and
8045 the worst of everything on the other. He has no sympathy with the old
8046 Roman life as Plato has with Greek life, nor has he any idea of the
8047 ecclesiastical kingdom which was to arise out of the ruins of the Roman
8048 empire. He is not blind to the defects of the Christian Church, and
8049 looks forward to a time when Christian and Pagan shall be alike brought
8050 before the judgment-seat, and the true City of God shall appear...The
8051 work of St. Augustine is a curious repertory of antiquarian learning and
8052 quotations, deeply penetrated with Christian ethics, but showing little
8053 power of reasoning, and a slender knowledge of the Greek literature
8054 and language. He was a great genius, and a noble character, yet hardly
8055 capable of feeling or understanding anything external to his own
8056 theology. Of all the ancient philosophers he is most attracted by Plato,
8057 though he is very slightly acquainted with his writings. He is inclined
8058 to believe that the idea of creation in the Timaeus is derived from the
8059 narrative in Genesis; and he is strangely taken with the coincidence (?)
8060 of Plato's saying that 'the philosopher is the lover of God,' and
8061 the words of the Book of Exodus in which God reveals himself to Moses
8062 (Exod.) He dwells at length on miracles performed in his own day, of
8063 which the evidence is regarded by him as irresistible. He speaks in a
8064 very interesting manner of the beauty and utility of nature and of the
8065 human frame, which he conceives to afford a foretaste of the heavenly
8066 state and of the resurrection of the body. The book is not really what
8067 to most persons the title of it would imply, and belongs to an age which
8068 has passed away. But it contains many fine passages and thoughts which
8069 are for all time.
8070 
8071 The short treatise de Monarchia of Dante is by far the most remarkable
8072 of mediaeval ideals, and bears the impress of the great genius in whom
8073 Italy and the Middle Ages are so vividly reflected. It is the vision of
8074 an Universal Empire, which is supposed to be the natural and necessary
8075 government of the world, having a divine authority distinct from the
8076 Papacy, yet coextensive with it. It is not 'the ghost of the dead Roman
8077 Empire sitting crowned upon the grave thereof,' but the legitimate heir
8078 and successor of it, justified by the ancient virtues of the Romans and
8079 the beneficence of their rule. Their right to be the governors of the
8080 world is also confirmed by the testimony of miracles, and acknowledged
8081 by St. Paul when he appealed to Caesar, and even more emphatically by
8082 Christ Himself, Who could not have made atonement for the sins of men
8083 if He had not been condemned by a divinely authorized tribunal. The
8084 necessity for the establishment of an Universal Empire is proved partly
8085 by a priori arguments such as the unity of God and the unity of the
8086 family or nation; partly by perversions of Scripture and history, by
8087 false analogies of nature, by misapplied quotations from the classics,
8088 and by odd scraps and commonplaces of logic, showing a familiar but by
8089 no means exact knowledge of Aristotle (of Plato there is none). But
8090 a more convincing argument still is the miserable state of the world,
8091 which he touchingly describes. He sees no hope of happiness or peace
8092 for mankind until all nations of the earth are comprehended in a single
8093 empire. The whole treatise shows how deeply the idea of the Roman Empire
8094 was fixed in the minds of his contemporaries. Not much argument was
8095 needed to maintain the truth of a theory which to his own contemporaries
8096 seemed so natural and congenial. He speaks, or rather preaches, from the
8097 point of view, not of the ecclesiastic, but of the layman, although, as
8098 a good Catholic, he is willing to acknowledge that in certain respects
8099 the Empire must submit to the Church. The beginning and end of all his
8100 noble reflections and of his arguments, good and bad, is the aspiration
8101 'that in this little plot of earth belonging to mortal man life may pass
8102 in freedom and peace.' So inextricably is his vision of the future bound
8103 up with the beliefs and circumstances of his own age.
8104 
8105 The 'Utopia' of Sir Thomas More is a surprising monument of his genius,
8106 and shows a reach of thought far beyond his contemporaries. The book was
8107 written by him at the age of about 34 or 35, and is full of the generous
8108 sentiments of youth. He brings the light of Plato to bear upon the
8109 miserable state of his own country. Living not long after the Wars of
8110 the Roses, and in the dregs of the Catholic Church in England, he is
8111 indignant at the corruption of the clergy, at the luxury of the nobility
8112 and gentry, at the sufferings of the poor, at the calamities caused by
8113 war. To the eye of More the whole world was in dissolution and decay;
8114 and side by side with the misery and oppression which he has described
8115 in the First Book of the Utopia, he places in the Second Book the ideal
8116 state which by the help of Plato he had constructed. The times were full
8117 of stir and intellectual interest. The distant murmur of the Reformation
8118 was beginning to be heard. To minds like More's, Greek literature was
8119 a revelation: there had arisen an art of interpretation, and the New
8120 Testament was beginning to be understood as it had never been before,
8121 and has not often been since, in its natural sense. The life there
8122 depicted appeared to him wholly unlike that of Christian commonwealths,
8123 in which 'he saw nothing but a certain conspiracy of rich men procuring
8124 their own commodities under the name and title of the Commonwealth.'
8125 He thought that Christ, like Plato, 'instituted all things common,' for
8126 which reason, he tells us, the citizens of Utopia were the more willing
8127 to receive his doctrines ('Howbeit, I think this was no small help and
8128 furtherance in the matter, that they heard us say that Christ instituted
8129 among his, all things common, and that the same community doth yet
8130 remain in the rightest Christian communities' (Utopia).). The community
8131 of property is a fixed idea with him, though he is aware of the
8132 arguments which may be urged on the other side ('These things (I say),
8133 when I consider with myself, I hold well with Plato, and do nothing
8134 marvel that he would make no laws for them that refused those laws,
8135 whereby all men should have and enjoy equal portions of riches and
8136 commodities. For the wise men did easily foresee this to be the one and
8137 only way to the wealth of a community, if equality of all things should
8138 be brought in and established' (Utopia).). We wonder how in the reign of
8139 Henry VIII, though veiled in another language and published in a foreign
8140 country, such speculations could have been endured.
8141 
8142 He is gifted with far greater dramatic invention than any one who
8143 succeeded him, with the exception of Swift. In the art of feigning he is
8144 a worthy disciple of Plato. Like him, starting from a small portion
8145 of fact, he founds his tale with admirable skill on a few lines in the
8146 Latin narrative of the voyages of Amerigo Vespucci. He is very precise
8147 about dates and facts, and has the power of making us believe that the
8148 narrator of the tale must have been an eyewitness. We are fairly puzzled
8149 by his manner of mixing up real and imaginary persons; his boy John
8150 Clement and Peter Giles, citizen of Antwerp, with whom he disputes
8151 about the precise words which are supposed to have been used by the
8152 (imaginary) Portuguese traveller, Raphael Hythloday. 'I have the more
8153 cause,' says Hythloday, 'to fear that my words shall not be believed,
8154 for that I know how difficultly and hardly I myself would have believed
8155 another man telling the same, if I had not myself seen it with mine own
8156 eyes.' Or again: 'If you had been with me in Utopia, and had presently
8157 seen their fashions and laws as I did which lived there five years and
8158 more, and would never have come thence, but only to make the new land
8159 known here,' etc. More greatly regrets that he forgot to ask Hythloday
8160 in what part of the world Utopia is situated; he 'would have spent no
8161 small sum of money rather than it should have escaped him,' and he begs
8162 Peter Giles to see Hythloday or write to him and obtain an answer to the
8163 question. After this we are not surprised to hear that a Professor of
8164 Divinity (perhaps 'a late famous vicar of Croydon in Surrey,' as the
8165 translator thinks) is desirous of being sent thither as a missionary by
8166 the High Bishop, 'yea, and that he may himself be made Bishop of Utopia,
8167 nothing doubting that he must obtain this Bishopric with suit; and he
8168 counteth that a godly suit which proceedeth not of the desire of honour
8169 or lucre, but only of a godly zeal.' The design may have failed through
8170 the disappearance of Hythloday, concerning whom we have 'very uncertain
8171 news' after his departure. There is no doubt, however, that he had told
8172 More and Giles the exact situation of the island, but unfortunately at
8173 the same moment More's attention, as he is reminded in a letter from
8174 Giles, was drawn off by a servant, and one of the company from a cold
8175 caught on shipboard coughed so loud as to prevent Giles from hearing.
8176 And 'the secret has perished' with him; to this day the place of Utopia
8177 remains unknown.
8178 
8179 The words of Phaedrus, 'O Socrates, you can easily invent Egyptians or
8180 anything,' are recalled to our mind as we read this lifelike fiction.
8181 Yet the greater merit of the work is not the admirable art, but the
8182 originality of thought. More is as free as Plato from the prejudices
8183 of his age, and far more tolerant. The Utopians do not allow him
8184 who believes not in the immortality of the soul to share in the
8185 administration of the state (Laws), 'howbeit they put him to no
8186 punishment, because they be persuaded that it is in no man's power to
8187 believe what he list'; and 'no man is to be blamed for reasoning in
8188 support of his own religion ('One of our company in my presence was
8189 sharply punished. He, as soon as he was baptised, began, against our
8190 wills, with more earnest affection than wisdom, to reason of Christ's
8191 religion, and began to wax so hot in his matter, that he did not only
8192 prefer our religion before all other, but also did despise and condemn
8193 all other, calling them profane, and the followers of them wicked and
8194 devilish, and the children of everlasting damnation. When he had thus
8195 long reasoned the matter, they laid hold on him, accused him, and
8196 condemned him into exile, not as a despiser of religion, but as a
8197 seditious person and a raiser up of dissension among the people').'
8198 In the public services 'no prayers be used, but such as every man
8199 may boldly pronounce without giving offence to any sect.' He says
8200 significantly, 'There be that give worship to a man that was once of
8201 excellent virtue or of famous glory, not only as God, but also the
8202 chiefest and highest God. But the most and the wisest part, rejecting
8203 all these, believe that there is a certain godly power unknown, far
8204 above the capacity and reach of man's wit, dispersed throughout all the
8205 world, not in bigness, but in virtue and power. Him they call the Father
8206 of all. To Him alone they attribute the beginnings, the increasings, the
8207 proceedings, the changes, and the ends of all things. Neither give they
8208 any divine honours to any other than him.' So far was More from sharing
8209 the popular beliefs of his time. Yet at the end he reminds us that he
8210 does not in all respects agree with the customs and opinions of the
8211 Utopians which he describes. And we should let him have the benefit of
8212 this saving clause, and not rudely withdraw the veil behind which he has
8213 been pleased to conceal himself.
8214 
8215 Nor is he less in advance of popular opinion in his political and moral
8216 speculations. He would like to bring military glory into contempt; he
8217 would set all sorts of idle people to profitable occupation, including
8218 in the same class, priests, women, noblemen, gentlemen, and 'sturdy and
8219 valiant beggars,' that the labour of all may be reduced to six hours a
8220 day. His dislike of capital punishment, and plans for the reformation of
8221 offenders; his detestation of priests and lawyers (Compare his satirical
8222 observation: 'They (the Utopians) have priests of exceeding holiness,
8223 and therefore very few.); his remark that 'although every one may hear
8224 of ravenous dogs and wolves and cruel man-eaters, it is not easy to find
8225 states that are well and wisely governed,' are curiously at variance
8226 with the notions of his age and indeed with his own life. There are many
8227 points in which he shows a modern feeling and a prophetic insight like
8228 Plato. He is a sanitary reformer; he maintains that civilized states
8229 have a right to the soil of waste countries; he is inclined to the
8230 opinion which places happiness in virtuous pleasures, but herein, as he
8231 thinks, not disagreeing from those other philosophers who define virtue
8232 to be a life according to nature. He extends the idea of happiness so as
8233 to include the happiness of others; and he argues ingeniously, 'All men
8234 agree that we ought to make others happy; but if others, how much more
8235 ourselves!' And still he thinks that there may be a more excellent way,
8236 but to this no man's reason can attain unless heaven should inspire him
8237 with a higher truth. His ceremonies before marriage; his humane proposal
8238 that war should be carried on by assassinating the leaders of the enemy,
8239 may be compared to some of the paradoxes of Plato. He has a charming
8240 fancy, like the affinities of Greeks and barbarians in the Timaeus, that
8241 the Utopians learnt the language of the Greeks with the more readiness
8242 because they were originally of the same race with them. He is
8243 penetrated with the spirit of Plato, and quotes or adapts many thoughts
8244 both from the Republic and from the Timaeus. He prefers public duties to
8245 private, and is somewhat impatient of the importunity of relations. His
8246 citizens have no silver or gold of their own, but are ready enough to
8247 pay them to their mercenaries. There is nothing of which he is more
8248 contemptuous than the love of money. Gold is used for fetters of
8249 criminals, and diamonds and pearls for children's necklaces (When the
8250 ambassadors came arrayed in gold and peacocks' feathers 'to the eyes of
8251 all the Utopians except very few, which had been in other countries for
8252 some reasonable cause, all that gorgeousness of apparel seemed shameful
8253 and reproachful. In so much that they most reverently saluted the
8254 vilest and most abject of them for lords--passing over the ambassadors
8255 themselves without any honour, judging them by their wearing of golden
8256 chains to be bondmen. You should have seen children also, that had cast
8257 away their pearls and precious stones, when they saw the like sticking
8258 upon the ambassadors' caps, dig and push their mothers under the sides,
8259 saying thus to them--"Look, though he were a little child still." But
8260 the mother; yea and that also in good earnest: "Peace, son," saith she,
8261 "I think he be some of the ambassadors' fools."')
8262 
8263 Like Plato he is full of satirical reflections on governments and
8264 princes; on the state of the world and of knowledge. The hero of his
8265 discourse (Hythloday) is very unwilling to become a minister of state,
8266 considering that he would lose his independence and his advice would
8267 never be heeded (Compare an exquisite passage, of which the conclusion
8268 is as follows: 'And verily it is naturally given...suppressed and
8269 ended.') He ridicules the new logic of his time; the Utopians could
8270 never be made to understand the doctrine of Second Intentions ('For they
8271 have not devised one of all those rules of restrictions, amplifications,
8272 and suppositions, very wittily invented in the small Logicals, which
8273 here our children in every place do learn. Furthermore, they were never
8274 yet able to find out the second intentions; insomuch that none of them
8275 all could ever see man himself in common, as they call him, though he be
8276 (as you know) bigger than was ever any giant, yea, and pointed to of us
8277 even with our finger.') He is very severe on the sports of the gentry;
8278 the Utopians count 'hunting the lowest, the vilest, and the most abject
8279 part of butchery.' He quotes the words of the Republic in which the
8280 philosopher is described 'standing out of the way under a wall until the
8281 driving storm of sleet and rain be overpast,' which admit of a singular
8282 application to More's own fate; although, writing twenty years before
8283 (about the year 1514), he can hardly be supposed to have foreseen this.
8284 There is no touch of satire which strikes deeper than his quiet remark
8285 that the greater part of the precepts of Christ are more at variance
8286 with the lives of ordinary Christians than the discourse of Utopia ('And
8287 yet the most part of them is more dissident from the manners of the
8288 world now a days, than my communication was. But preachers, sly and
8289 wily men, following your counsel (as I suppose) because they saw men
8290 evil-willing to frame their manners to Christ's rule, they have wrested
8291 and wried his doctrine, and, like a rule of lead, have applied it to
8292 men's manners, that by some means at the least way, they might agree
8293 together.')
8294 
8295 The 'New Atlantis' is only a fragment, and far inferior in merit to the
8296 'Utopia.' The work is full of ingenuity, but wanting in creative fancy,
8297 and by no means impresses the reader with a sense of credibility. In
8298 some places Lord Bacon is characteristically different from Sir Thomas
8299 More, as, for example, in the external state which he attributes to the
8300 governor of Solomon's House, whose dress he minutely describes, while to
8301 Sir Thomas More such trappings appear simple ridiculous. Yet, after this
8302 programme of dress, Bacon adds the beautiful trait, 'that he had a look
8303 as though he pitied men.' Several things are borrowed by him from the
8304 Timaeus; but he has injured the unity of style by adding thoughts and
8305 passages which are taken from the Hebrew Scriptures.
8306 
8307 The 'City of the Sun' written by Campanella (1568-1639), a Dominican
8308 friar, several years after the 'New Atlantis' of Bacon, has many
8309 resemblances to the Republic of Plato. The citizens have wives and
8310 children in common; their marriages are of the same temporary sort, and
8311 are arranged by the magistrates from time to time. They do not, however,
8312 adopt his system of lots, but bring together the best natures, male and
8313 female, 'according to philosophical rules.' The infants until two years
8314 of age are brought up by their mothers in public temples; and since
8315 individuals for the most part educate their children badly, at the
8316 beginning of their third year they are committed to the care of the
8317 State, and are taught at first, not out of books, but from paintings of
8318 all kinds, which are emblazoned on the walls of the city. The city has
8319 six interior circuits of walls, and an outer wall which is the
8320 seventh. On this outer wall are painted the figures of legislators and
8321 philosophers, and on each of the interior walls the symbols or forms
8322 of some one of the sciences are delineated. The women are, for the most
8323 part, trained, like the men, in warlike and other exercises; but they
8324 have two special occupations of their own. After a battle, they and the
8325 boys soothe and relieve the wounded warriors; also they encourage them
8326 with embraces and pleasant words. Some elements of the Christian or
8327 Catholic religion are preserved among them. The life of the Apostles is
8328 greatly admired by this people because they had all things in common;
8329 and the short prayer which Jesus Christ taught men is used in their
8330 worship. It is a duty of the chief magistrates to pardon sins, and
8331 therefore the whole people make secret confession of them to the
8332 magistrates, and they to their chief, who is a sort of Rector
8333 Metaphysicus; and by this means he is well informed of all that is going
8334 on in the minds of men. After confession, absolution is granted to
8335 the citizens collectively, but no one is mentioned by name. There
8336 also exists among them a practice of perpetual prayer, performed by
8337 a succession of priests, who change every hour. Their religion is
8338 a worship of God in Trinity, that is of Wisdom, Love and Power,
8339 but without any distinction of persons. They behold in the sun the
8340 reflection of His glory; mere graven images they reject, refusing to
8341 fall under the 'tyranny' of idolatry.
8342 
8343 Many details are given about their customs of eating and drinking, about
8344 their mode of dressing, their employments, their wars. Campanella looks
8345 forward to a new mode of education, which is to be a study of nature,
8346 and not of Aristotle. He would not have his citizens waste their time
8347 in the consideration of what he calls 'the dead signs of things.' He
8348 remarks that he who knows one science only, does not really know that
8349 one any more than the rest, and insists strongly on the necessity of a
8350 variety of knowledge. More scholars are turned out in the City of the
8351 Sun in one year than by contemporary methods in ten or fifteen. He
8352 evidently believes, like Bacon, that henceforward natural science will
8353 play a great part in education, a hope which seems hardly to have
8354 been realized, either in our own or in any former age; at any rate the
8355 fulfilment of it has been long deferred.
8356 
8357 There is a good deal of ingenuity and even originality in this work, and
8358 a most enlightened spirit pervades it. But it has little or no charm
8359 of style, and falls very far short of the 'New Atlantis' of Bacon,
8360 and still more of the 'Utopia' of Sir Thomas More. It is full of
8361 inconsistencies, and though borrowed from Plato, shows but a superficial
8362 acquaintance with his writings. It is a work such as one might expect
8363 to have been written by a philosopher and man of genius who was also a
8364 friar, and who had spent twenty-seven years of his life in a prison of
8365 the Inquisition. The most interesting feature of the book, common to
8366 Plato and Sir Thomas More, is the deep feeling which is shown by the
8367 writer, of the misery and ignorance prevailing among the lower classes
8368 in his own time. Campanella takes note of Aristotle's answer to Plato's
8369 community of property, that in a society where all things are common, no
8370 individual would have any motive to work (Arist. Pol.): he replies, that
8371 his citizens being happy and contented in themselves (they are required
8372 to work only four hours a day), will have greater regard for their
8373 fellows than exists among men at present. He thinks, like Plato, that if
8374 he abolishes private feelings and interests, a great public feeling will
8375 take their place.
8376 
8377 Other writings on ideal states, such as the 'Oceana' of Harrington, in
8378 which the Lord Archon, meaning Cromwell, is described, not as he was,
8379 but as he ought to have been; or the 'Argenis' of Barclay, which is an
8380 historical allegory of his own time, are too unlike Plato to be worth
8381 mentioning. More interesting than either of these, and far more Platonic
8382 in style and thought, is Sir John Eliot's 'Monarchy of Man,' in which
8383 the prisoner of the Tower, no longer able 'to be a politician in the
8384 land of his birth,' turns away from politics to view 'that other city
8385 which is within him,' and finds on the very threshold of the grave that
8386 the secret of human happiness is the mastery of self. The change of
8387 government in the time of the English Commonwealth set men thinking
8388 about first principles, and gave rise to many works of this class...The
8389 great original genius of Swift owes nothing to Plato; nor is there
8390 any trace in the conversation or in the works of Dr. Johnson of any
8391 acquaintance with his writings. He probably would have refuted Plato
8392 without reading him, in the same fashion in which he supposed himself to
8393 have refuted Bishop Berkeley's theory of the non-existence of matter.
8394 If we except the so-called English Platonists, or rather Neo-Platonists,
8395 who never understood their master, and the writings of Coleridge,
8396 who was to some extent a kindred spirit, Plato has left no permanent
8397 impression on English literature.
8398 
8399 7. Human life and conduct are affected by ideals in the same way that
8400 they are affected by the examples of eminent men. Neither the one nor
8401 the other are immediately applicable to practice, but there is a virtue
8402 flowing from them which tends to raise individuals above the common
8403 routine of society or trade, and to elevate States above the mere
8404 interests of commerce or the necessities of self-defence. Like the
8405 ideals of art they are partly framed by the omission of particulars;
8406 they require to be viewed at a certain distance, and are apt to fade
8407 away if we attempt to approach them. They gain an imaginary distinctness
8408 when embodied in a State or in a system of philosophy, but they still
8409 remain the visions of 'a world unrealized.' More striking and obvious to
8410 the ordinary mind are the examples of great men, who have served their
8411 own generation and are remembered in another. Even in our own family
8412 circle there may have been some one, a woman, or even a child, in
8413 whose face has shone forth a goodness more than human. The ideal then
8414 approaches nearer to us, and we fondly cling to it. The ideal of the
8415 past, whether of our own past lives or of former states of society, has
8416 a singular fascination for the minds of many. Too late we learn that
8417 such ideals cannot be recalled, though the recollection of them may
8418 have a humanizing influence on other times. But the abstractions of
8419 philosophy are to most persons cold and vacant; they give light without
8420 warmth; they are like the full moon in the heavens when there are no
8421 stars appearing. Men cannot live by thought alone; the world of sense is
8422 always breaking in upon them. They are for the most part confined to a
8423 corner of earth, and see but a little way beyond their own home or place
8424 of abode; they 'do not lift up their eyes to the hills'; they are not
8425 awake when the dawn appears. But in Plato we have reached a height from
8426 which a man may look into the distance and behold the future of the
8427 world and of philosophy. The ideal of the State and of the life of
8428 the philosopher; the ideal of an education continuing through life and
8429 extending equally to both sexes; the ideal of the unity and correlation
8430 of knowledge; the faith in good and immortality--are the vacant forms of
8431 light on which Plato is seeking to fix the eye of mankind.
8432 
8433 8. Two other ideals, which never appeared above the horizon in Greek
8434 Philosophy, float before the minds of men in our own day: one seen more
8435 clearly than formerly, as though each year and each generation brought
8436 us nearer to some great change; the other almost in the same degree
8437 retiring from view behind the laws of nature, as if oppressed by them,
8438 but still remaining a silent hope of we know not what hidden in the
8439 heart of man. The first ideal is the future of the human race in this
8440 world; the second the future of the individual in another. The first is
8441 the more perfect realization of our own present life; the second,
8442 the abnegation of it: the one, limited by experience, the other,
8443 transcending it. Both of them have been and are powerful motives of
8444 action; there are a few in whom they have taken the place of all earthly
8445 interests. The hope of a future for the human race at first sight seems
8446 to be the more disinterested, the hope of individual existence the more
8447 egotistical, of the two motives. But when men have learned to resolve
8448 their hope of a future either for themselves or for the world into the
8449 will of God--'not my will but Thine,' the difference between them falls
8450 away; and they may be allowed to make either of them the basis of their
8451 lives, according to their own individual character or temperament. There
8452 is as much faith in the willingness to work for an unseen future in this
8453 world as in another. Neither is it inconceivable that some rare nature
8454 may feel his duty to another generation, or to another century, almost
8455 as strongly as to his own, or that living always in the presence of God,
8456 he may realize another world as vividly as he does this.
8457 
8458 The greatest of all ideals may, or rather must be conceived by us under
8459 similitudes derived from human qualities; although sometimes, like the
8460 Jewish prophets, we may dash away these figures of speech and describe
8461 the nature of God only in negatives. These again by degrees acquire a
8462 positive meaning. It would be well, if when meditating on the higher
8463 truths either of philosophy or religion, we sometimes substituted one
8464 form of expression for another, lest through the necessities of language
8465 we should become the slaves of mere words.
8466 
8467 There is a third ideal, not the same, but akin to these, which has a
8468 place in the home and heart of every believer in the religion of Christ,
8469 and in which men seem to find a nearer and more familiar truth,
8470 the Divine man, the Son of Man, the Saviour of mankind, Who is the
8471 first-born and head of the whole family in heaven and earth, in Whom
8472 the Divine and human, that which is without and that which is within the
8473 range of our earthly faculties, are indissolubly united. Neither is this
8474 divine form of goodness wholly separable from the ideal of the Christian
8475 Church, which is said in the New Testament to be 'His body,' or at
8476 variance with those other images of good which Plato sets before us. We
8477 see Him in a figure only, and of figures of speech we select but a few,
8478 and those the simplest, to be the expression of Him. We behold Him in
8479 a picture, but He is not there. We gather up the fragments of His
8480 discourses, but neither do they represent Him as He truly was. His
8481 dwelling is neither in heaven nor earth, but in the heart of man.
8482 This is that image which Plato saw dimly in the distance, which, when
8483 existing among men, he called, in the language of Homer, 'the likeness
8484 of God,' the likeness of a nature which in all ages men have felt to be
8485 greater and better than themselves, and which in endless forms, whether
8486 derived from Scripture or nature, from the witness of history or from
8487 the human heart, regarded as a person or not as a person, with or
8488 without parts or passions, existing in space or not in space, is and
8489 will always continue to be to mankind the Idea of Good.
8490 
8491 
8492 
8493 
8494 
8495 THE REPUBLIC.
8496 
8497 
8498 
8499 
8500 PERSONS OF THE DIALOGUE.
8501 
8502 Socrates, who is the narrator.
8503 
8504 Glaucon.
8505 
8506 Adeimantus.
8507 
8508 Polemarchus.
8509 
8510 Cephalus.
8511 
8512 Thrasymachus.
8513 
8514 Cleitophon.
8515 
8516 And others who are mute auditors.
8517 
8518 The scene is laid in the house of Cephalus at the Piraeus; and the whole
8519 dialogue is narrated by Socrates the day after it actually took place to
8520 Timaeus, Hermocrates, Critias, and a nameless person, who are introduced
8521 in the Timaeus.
8522 
8523 
8524 
8525 
8526 BOOK I.
8527 
8528 I went down yesterday to the Piraeus with Glaucon the son of Ariston,
8529 that I might offer up my prayers to the goddess (Bendis, the Thracian
8530 Artemis.); and also because I wanted to see in what manner they would
8531 celebrate the festival, which was a new thing. I was delighted with the
8532 procession of the inhabitants; but that of the Thracians was equally,
8533 if not more, beautiful. When we had finished our prayers and viewed the
8534 spectacle, we turned in the direction of the city; and at that instant
8535 Polemarchus the son of Cephalus chanced to catch sight of us from a
8536 distance as we were starting on our way home, and told his servant to
8537 run and bid us wait for him. The servant took hold of me by the cloak
8538 behind, and said: Polemarchus desires you to wait.
8539 
8540 I turned round, and asked him where his master was.
8541 
8542 There he is, said the youth, coming after you, if you will only wait.
8543 
8544 Certainly we will, said Glaucon; and in a few minutes Polemarchus
8545 appeared, and with him Adeimantus, Glaucon's brother, Niceratus the son
8546 of Nicias, and several others who had been at the procession.
8547 
8548 Polemarchus said to me: I perceive, Socrates, that you and your
8549 companion are already on your way to the city.
8550 
8551 You are not far wrong, I said.
8552 
8553 But do you see, he rejoined, how many we are?
8554 
8555 Of course.
8556 
8557 And are you stronger than all these? for if not, you will have to remain
8558 where you are.
8559 
8560 May there not be the alternative, I said, that we may persuade you to
8561 let us go?
8562 
8563 But can you persuade us, if we refuse to listen to you? he said.
8564 
8565 Certainly not, replied Glaucon.
8566 
8567 Then we are not going to listen; of that you may be assured.
8568 
8569 Adeimantus added: Has no one told you of the torch-race on horseback in
8570 honour of the goddess which will take place in the evening?
8571 
8572 With horses! I replied: That is a novelty. Will horsemen carry torches
8573 and pass them one to another during the race?
8574 
8575 Yes, said Polemarchus, and not only so, but a festival will be
8576 celebrated at night, which you certainly ought to see. Let us rise soon
8577 after supper and see this festival; there will be a gathering of young
8578 men, and we will have a good talk. Stay then, and do not be perverse.
8579 
8580 Glaucon said: I suppose, since you insist, that we must.
8581 
8582 Very good, I replied.
8583 
8584 Accordingly we went with Polemarchus to his house; and there we found
8585 his brothers Lysias and Euthydemus, and with them Thrasymachus the
8586 Chalcedonian, Charmantides the Paeanian, and Cleitophon the son of
8587 Aristonymus. There too was Cephalus the father of Polemarchus, whom I
8588 had not seen for a long time, and I thought him very much aged. He was
8589 seated on a cushioned chair, and had a garland on his head, for he had
8590 been sacrificing in the court; and there were some other chairs in the
8591 room arranged in a semicircle, upon which we sat down by him. He saluted
8592 me eagerly, and then he said:--
8593 
8594 You don't come to see me, Socrates, as often as you ought: If I were
8595 still able to go and see you I would not ask you to come to me. But
8596 at my age I can hardly get to the city, and therefore you should come
8597 oftener to the Piraeus. For let me tell you, that the more the pleasures
8598 of the body fade away, the greater to me is the pleasure and charm
8599 of conversation. Do not then deny my request, but make our house your
8600 resort and keep company with these young men; we are old friends, and
8601 you will be quite at home with us.
8602 
8603 I replied: There is nothing which for my part I like better, Cephalus,
8604 than conversing with aged men; for I regard them as travellers who
8605 have gone a journey which I too may have to go, and of whom I ought to
8606 enquire, whether the way is smooth and easy, or rugged and difficult.
8607 And this is a question which I should like to ask of you who have
8608 arrived at that time which the poets call the 'threshold of old age'--Is
8609 life harder towards the end, or what report do you give of it?
8610 
8611 I will tell you, Socrates, he said, what my own feeling is. Men of my
8612 age flock together; we are birds of a feather, as the old proverb says;
8613 and at our meetings the tale of my acquaintance commonly is--I cannot
8614 eat, I cannot drink; the pleasures of youth and love are fled away:
8615 there was a good time once, but now that is gone, and life is no longer
8616 life. Some complain of the slights which are put upon them by relations,
8617 and they will tell you sadly of how many evils their old age is the
8618 cause. But to me, Socrates, these complainers seem to blame that which
8619 is not really in fault. For if old age were the cause, I too being old,
8620 and every other old man, would have felt as they do. But this is not
8621 my own experience, nor that of others whom I have known. How well I
8622 remember the aged poet Sophocles, when in answer to the question, How
8623 does love suit with age, Sophocles,--are you still the man you were?
8624 Peace, he replied; most gladly have I escaped the thing of which you
8625 speak; I feel as if I had escaped from a mad and furious master. His
8626 words have often occurred to my mind since, and they seem as good to
8627 me now as at the time when he uttered them. For certainly old age has
8628 a great sense of calm and freedom; when the passions relax their hold,
8629 then, as Sophocles says, we are freed from the grasp not of one mad
8630 master only, but of many. The truth is, Socrates, that these regrets,
8631 and also the complaints about relations, are to be attributed to the
8632 same cause, which is not old age, but men's characters and tempers; for
8633 he who is of a calm and happy nature will hardly feel the pressure of
8634 age, but to him who is of an opposite disposition youth and age are
8635 equally a burden.
8636 
8637 I listened in admiration, and wanting to draw him out, that he might go
8638 on--Yes, Cephalus, I said: but I rather suspect that people in general
8639 are not convinced by you when you speak thus; they think that old
8640 age sits lightly upon you, not because of your happy disposition, but
8641 because you are rich, and wealth is well known to be a great comforter.
8642 
8643 You are right, he replied; they are not convinced: and there is
8644 something in what they say; not, however, so much as they imagine. I
8645 might answer them as Themistocles answered the Seriphian who was abusing
8646 him and saying that he was famous, not for his own merits but because he
8647 was an Athenian: 'If you had been a native of my country or I of yours,
8648 neither of us would have been famous.' And to those who are not rich and
8649 are impatient of old age, the same reply may be made; for to the good
8650 poor man old age cannot be a light burden, nor can a bad rich man ever
8651 have peace with himself.
8652 
8653 May I ask, Cephalus, whether your fortune was for the most part
8654 inherited or acquired by you?
8655 
8656 Acquired! Socrates; do you want to know how much I acquired? In the art
8657 of making money I have been midway between my father and grandfather:
8658 for my grandfather, whose name I bear, doubled and trebled the value of
8659 his patrimony, that which he inherited being much what I possess now;
8660 but my father Lysanias reduced the property below what it is at present:
8661 and I shall be satisfied if I leave to these my sons not less but a
8662 little more than I received.
8663 
8664 That was why I asked you the question, I replied, because I see that you
8665 are indifferent about money, which is a characteristic rather of those
8666 who have inherited their fortunes than of those who have acquired them;
8667 the makers of fortunes have a second love of money as a creation of
8668 their own, resembling the affection of authors for their own poems, or
8669 of parents for their children, besides that natural love of it for the
8670 sake of use and profit which is common to them and all men. And hence
8671 they are very bad company, for they can talk about nothing but the
8672 praises of wealth.
8673 
8674 That is true, he said.
8675 
8676 Yes, that is very true, but may I ask another question?--What do you
8677 consider to be the greatest blessing which you have reaped from your
8678 wealth?
8679 
8680 One, he said, of which I could not expect easily to convince others.
8681 For let me tell you, Socrates, that when a man thinks himself to be near
8682 death, fears and cares enter into his mind which he never had before;
8683 the tales of a world below and the punishment which is exacted there
8684 of deeds done here were once a laughing matter to him, but now he
8685 is tormented with the thought that they may be true: either from the
8686 weakness of age, or because he is now drawing nearer to that other
8687 place, he has a clearer view of these things; suspicions and alarms
8688 crowd thickly upon him, and he begins to reflect and consider what
8689 wrongs he has done to others. And when he finds that the sum of his
8690 transgressions is great he will many a time like a child start up in his
8691 sleep for fear, and he is filled with dark forebodings. But to him who
8692 is conscious of no sin, sweet hope, as Pindar charmingly says, is the
8693 kind nurse of his age:
8694 
8695 'Hope,' he says, 'cherishes the soul of him who lives in justice
8696 and holiness, and is the nurse of his age and the companion of his
8697 journey;--hope which is mightiest to sway the restless soul of man.'
8698 
8699 How admirable are his words! And the great blessing of riches, I do not
8700 say to every man, but to a good man, is, that he has had no occasion to
8701 deceive or to defraud others, either intentionally or unintentionally;
8702 and when he departs to the world below he is not in any apprehension
8703 about offerings due to the gods or debts which he owes to men. Now to
8704 this peace of mind the possession of wealth greatly contributes; and
8705 therefore I say, that, setting one thing against another, of the many
8706 advantages which wealth has to give, to a man of sense this is in my
8707 opinion the greatest.
8708 
8709 Well said, Cephalus, I replied; but as concerning justice, what is
8710 it?--to speak the truth and to pay your debts--no more than this? And
8711 even to this are there not exceptions? Suppose that a friend when in his
8712 right mind has deposited arms with me and he asks for them when he is
8713 not in his right mind, ought I to give them back to him? No one would
8714 say that I ought or that I should be right in doing so, any more than
8715 they would say that I ought always to speak the truth to one who is in
8716 his condition.
8717 
8718 You are quite right, he replied.
8719 
8720 But then, I said, speaking the truth and paying your debts is not a
8721 correct definition of justice.
8722 
8723 Quite correct, Socrates, if Simonides is to be believed, said
8724 Polemarchus interposing.
8725 
8726 I fear, said Cephalus, that I must go now, for I have to look after the
8727 sacrifices, and I hand over the argument to Polemarchus and the company.
8728 
8729 Is not Polemarchus your heir? I said.
8730 
8731 To be sure, he answered, and went away laughing to the sacrifices.
8732 
8733 Tell me then, O thou heir of the argument, what did Simonides say, and
8734 according to you truly say, about justice?
8735 
8736 He said that the repayment of a debt is just, and in saying so he
8737 appears to me to be right.
8738 
8739 I should be sorry to doubt the word of such a wise and inspired man, but
8740 his meaning, though probably clear to you, is the reverse of clear to
8741 me. For he certainly does not mean, as we were just now saying, that I
8742 ought to return a deposit of arms or of anything else to one who asks
8743 for it when he is not in his right senses; and yet a deposit cannot be
8744 denied to be a debt.
8745 
8746 True.
8747 
8748 Then when the person who asks me is not in his right mind I am by no
8749 means to make the return?
8750 
8751 Certainly not.
8752 
8753 When Simonides said that the repayment of a debt was justice, he did not
8754 mean to include that case?
8755 
8756 Certainly not; for he thinks that a friend ought always to do good to a
8757 friend and never evil.
8758 
8759 You mean that the return of a deposit of gold which is to the injury of
8760 the receiver, if the two parties are friends, is not the repayment of a
8761 debt,--that is what you would imagine him to say?
8762 
8763 Yes.
8764 
8765 And are enemies also to receive what we owe to them?
8766 
8767 To be sure, he said, they are to receive what we owe them, and an enemy,
8768 as I take it, owes to an enemy that which is due or proper to him--that
8769 is to say, evil.
8770 
8771 Simonides, then, after the manner of poets, would seem to have spoken
8772 darkly of the nature of justice; for he really meant to say that justice
8773 is the giving to each man what is proper to him, and this he termed a
8774 debt.
8775 
8776 That must have been his meaning, he said.
8777 
8778 By heaven! I replied; and if we asked him what due or proper thing is
8779 given by medicine, and to whom, what answer do you think that he would
8780 make to us?
8781 
8782 He would surely reply that medicine gives drugs and meat and drink to
8783 human bodies.
8784 
8785 And what due or proper thing is given by cookery, and to what?
8786 
8787 Seasoning to food.
8788 
8789 And what is that which justice gives, and to whom?
8790 
8791 If, Socrates, we are to be guided at all by the analogy of the preceding
8792 instances, then justice is the art which gives good to friends and evil
8793 to enemies.
8794 
8795 That is his meaning then?
8796 
8797 I think so.
8798 
8799 And who is best able to do good to his friends and evil to his enemies
8800 in time of sickness?
8801 
8802 The physician.
8803 
8804 Or when they are on a voyage, amid the perils of the sea?
8805 
8806 The pilot.
8807 
8808 And in what sort of actions or with a view to what result is the just
8809 man most able to do harm to his enemy and good to his friend?
8810 
8811 In going to war against the one and in making alliances with the other.
8812 
8813 But when a man is well, my dear Polemarchus, there is no need of a
8814 physician?
8815 
8816 No.
8817 
8818 And he who is not on a voyage has no need of a pilot?
8819 
8820 No.
8821 
8822 Then in time of peace justice will be of no use?
8823 
8824 I am very far from thinking so.
8825 
8826 You think that justice may be of use in peace as well as in war?
8827 
8828 Yes.
8829 
8830 Like husbandry for the acquisition of corn?
8831 
8832 Yes.
8833 
8834 Or like shoemaking for the acquisition of shoes,--that is what you mean?
8835 
8836 Yes.
8837 
8838 And what similar use or power of acquisition has justice in time of
8839 peace?
8840 
8841 In contracts, Socrates, justice is of use.
8842 
8843 And by contracts you mean partnerships?
8844 
8845 Exactly.
8846 
8847 But is the just man or the skilful player a more useful and better
8848 partner at a game of draughts?
8849 
8850 The skilful player.
8851 
8852 And in the laying of bricks and stones is the just man a more useful or
8853 better partner than the builder?
8854 
8855 Quite the reverse.
8856 
8857 Then in what sort of partnership is the just man a better partner than
8858 the harp-player, as in playing the harp the harp-player is certainly a
8859 better partner than the just man?
8860 
8861 In a money partnership.
8862 
8863 Yes, Polemarchus, but surely not in the use of money; for you do not
8864 want a just man to be your counsellor in the purchase or sale of a
8865 horse; a man who is knowing about horses would be better for that, would
8866 he not?
8867 
8868 Certainly.
8869 
8870 And when you want to buy a ship, the shipwright or the pilot would be
8871 better?
8872 
8873 True.
8874 
8875 Then what is that joint use of silver or gold in which the just man is
8876 to be preferred?
8877 
8878 When you want a deposit to be kept safely.
8879 
8880 You mean when money is not wanted, but allowed to lie?
8881 
8882 Precisely.
8883 
8884 That is to say, justice is useful when money is useless?
8885 
8886 That is the inference.
8887 
8888 And when you want to keep a pruning-hook safe, then justice is useful to
8889 the individual and to the state; but when you want to use it, then the
8890 art of the vine-dresser?
8891 
8892 Clearly.
8893 
8894 And when you want to keep a shield or a lyre, and not to use them, you
8895 would say that justice is useful; but when you want to use them, then
8896 the art of the soldier or of the musician?
8897 
8898 Certainly.
8899 
8900 And so of all other things;--justice is useful when they are useless,
8901 and useless when they are useful?
8902 
8903 That is the inference.
8904 
8905 Then justice is not good for much. But let us consider this further
8906 point: Is not he who can best strike a blow in a boxing match or in any
8907 kind of fighting best able to ward off a blow?
8908 
8909 Certainly.
8910 
8911 And he who is most skilful in preventing or escaping from a disease is
8912 best able to create one?
8913 
8914 True.
8915 
8916 And he is the best guard of a camp who is best able to steal a march
8917 upon the enemy?
8918 
8919 Certainly.
8920 
8921 Then he who is a good keeper of anything is also a good thief?
8922 
8923 That, I suppose, is to be inferred.
8924 
8925 Then if the just man is good at keeping money, he is good at stealing
8926 it.
8927 
8928 That is implied in the argument.
8929 
8930 Then after all the just man has turned out to be a thief. And this is
8931 a lesson which I suspect you must have learnt out of Homer; for he,
8932 speaking of Autolycus, the maternal grandfather of Odysseus, who is a
8933 favourite of his, affirms that
8934 
8935 'He was excellent above all men in theft and perjury.'
8936 
8937 And so, you and Homer and Simonides are agreed that justice is an art of
8938 theft; to be practised however 'for the good of friends and for the harm
8939 of enemies,'--that was what you were saying?
8940 
8941 No, certainly not that, though I do not now know what I did say; but I
8942 still stand by the latter words.
8943 
8944 Well, there is another question: By friends and enemies do we mean those
8945 who are so really, or only in seeming?
8946 
8947 Surely, he said, a man may be expected to love those whom he thinks
8948 good, and to hate those whom he thinks evil.
8949 
8950 Yes, but do not persons often err about good and evil: many who are not
8951 good seem to be so, and conversely?
8952 
8953 That is true.
8954 
8955 Then to them the good will be enemies and the evil will be their
8956 friends? True.
8957 
8958 And in that case they will be right in doing good to the evil and evil
8959 to the good?
8960 
8961 Clearly.
8962 
8963 But the good are just and would not do an injustice?
8964 
8965 True.
8966 
8967 Then according to your argument it is just to injure those who do no
8968 wrong?
8969 
8970 Nay, Socrates; the doctrine is immoral.
8971 
8972 Then I suppose that we ought to do good to the just and harm to the
8973 unjust?
8974 
8975 I like that better.
8976 
8977 But see the consequence:--Many a man who is ignorant of human nature
8978 has friends who are bad friends, and in that case he ought to do harm to
8979 them; and he has good enemies whom he ought to benefit; but, if so, we
8980 shall be saying the very opposite of that which we affirmed to be the
8981 meaning of Simonides.
8982 
8983 Very true, he said: and I think that we had better correct an error
8984 into which we seem to have fallen in the use of the words 'friend' and
8985 'enemy.'
8986 
8987 What was the error, Polemarchus? I asked.
8988 
8989 We assumed that he is a friend who seems to be or who is thought good.
8990 
8991 And how is the error to be corrected?
8992 
8993 We should rather say that he is a friend who is, as well as seems, good;
8994 and that he who seems only, and is not good, only seems to be and is not
8995 a friend; and of an enemy the same may be said.
8996 
8997 You would argue that the good are our friends and the bad our enemies?
8998 
8999 Yes.
9000 
9001 And instead of saying simply as we did at first, that it is just to do
9002 good to our friends and harm to our enemies, we should further say: It
9003 is just to do good to our friends when they are good and harm to our
9004 enemies when they are evil?
9005 
9006 Yes, that appears to me to be the truth.
9007 
9008 But ought the just to injure any one at all?
9009 
9010 Undoubtedly he ought to injure those who are both wicked and his
9011 enemies.
9012 
9013 When horses are injured, are they improved or deteriorated?
9014 
9015 The latter.
9016 
9017 Deteriorated, that is to say, in the good qualities of horses, not of
9018 dogs?
9019 
9020 Yes, of horses.
9021 
9022 And dogs are deteriorated in the good qualities of dogs, and not of
9023 horses?
9024 
9025 Of course.
9026 
9027 And will not men who are injured be deteriorated in that which is the
9028 proper virtue of man?
9029 
9030 Certainly.
9031 
9032 And that human virtue is justice?
9033 
9034 To be sure.
9035 
9036 Then men who are injured are of necessity made unjust?
9037 
9038 That is the result.
9039 
9040 But can the musician by his art make men unmusical?
9041 
9042 Certainly not.
9043 
9044 Or the horseman by his art make them bad horsemen?
9045 
9046 Impossible.
9047 
9048 And can the just by justice make men unjust, or speaking generally, can
9049 the good by virtue make them bad?
9050 
9051 Assuredly not.
9052 
9053 Any more than heat can produce cold?
9054 
9055 It cannot.
9056 
9057 Or drought moisture?
9058 
9059 Clearly not.
9060 
9061 Nor can the good harm any one?
9062 
9063 Impossible.
9064 
9065 And the just is the good?
9066 
9067 Certainly.
9068 
9069 Then to injure a friend or any one else is not the act of a just man,
9070 but of the opposite, who is the unjust?
9071 
9072 I think that what you say is quite true, Socrates.
9073 
9074 Then if a man says that justice consists in the repayment of debts, and
9075 that good is the debt which a just man owes to his friends, and evil the
9076 debt which he owes to his enemies,--to say this is not wise; for it is
9077 not true, if, as has been clearly shown, the injuring of another can be
9078 in no case just.
9079 
9080 I agree with you, said Polemarchus.
9081 
9082 Then you and I are prepared to take up arms against any one who
9083 attributes such a saying to Simonides or Bias or Pittacus, or any other
9084 wise man or seer?
9085 
9086 I am quite ready to do battle at your side, he said.
9087 
9088 Shall I tell you whose I believe the saying to be?
9089 
9090 Whose?
9091 
9092 I believe that Periander or Perdiccas or Xerxes or Ismenias the Theban,
9093 or some other rich and mighty man, who had a great opinion of his own
9094 power, was the first to say that justice is 'doing good to your friends
9095 and harm to your enemies.'
9096 
9097 Most true, he said.
9098 
9099 Yes, I said; but if this definition of justice also breaks down, what
9100 other can be offered?
9101 
9102 Several times in the course of the discussion Thrasymachus had made an
9103 attempt to get the argument into his own hands, and had been put down
9104 by the rest of the company, who wanted to hear the end. But when
9105 Polemarchus and I had done speaking and there was a pause, he could no
9106 longer hold his peace; and, gathering himself up, he came at us like a
9107 wild beast, seeking to devour us. We were quite panic-stricken at the
9108 sight of him.
9109 
9110 He roared out to the whole company: What folly, Socrates, has taken
9111 possession of you all? And why, sillybillies, do you knock under to
9112 one another? I say that if you want really to know what justice is,
9113 you should not only ask but answer, and you should not seek honour to
9114 yourself from the refutation of an opponent, but have your own answer;
9115 for there is many a one who can ask and cannot answer. And now I will
9116 not have you say that justice is duty or advantage or profit or gain
9117 or interest, for this sort of nonsense will not do for me; I must have
9118 clearness and accuracy.
9119 
9120 I was panic-stricken at his words, and could not look at him without
9121 trembling. Indeed I believe that if I had not fixed my eye upon him, I
9122 should have been struck dumb: but when I saw his fury rising, I looked
9123 at him first, and was therefore able to reply to him.
9124 
9125 Thrasymachus, I said, with a quiver, don't be hard upon us. Polemarchus
9126 and I may have been guilty of a little mistake in the argument, but I
9127 can assure you that the error was not intentional. If we were seeking
9128 for a piece of gold, you would not imagine that we were 'knocking under
9129 to one another,' and so losing our chance of finding it. And why, when
9130 we are seeking for justice, a thing more precious than many pieces of
9131 gold, do you say that we are weakly yielding to one another and not
9132 doing our utmost to get at the truth? Nay, my good friend, we are most
9133 willing and anxious to do so, but the fact is that we cannot. And if so,
9134 you people who know all things should pity us and not be angry with us.
9135 
9136 How characteristic of Socrates! he replied, with a bitter laugh;--that's
9137 your ironical style! Did I not foresee--have I not already told you,
9138 that whatever he was asked he would refuse to answer, and try irony or
9139 any other shuffle, in order that he might avoid answering?
9140 
9141 You are a philosopher, Thrasymachus, I replied, and well know that if
9142 you ask a person what numbers make up twelve, taking care to prohibit
9143 him whom you ask from answering twice six, or three times four, or six
9144 times two, or four times three, 'for this sort of nonsense will not do
9145 for me,'--then obviously, if that is your way of putting the
9146 question, no one can answer you. But suppose that he were to retort,
9147 'Thrasymachus, what do you mean? If one of these numbers which you
9148 interdict be the true answer to the question, am I falsely to say some
9149 other number which is not the right one?--is that your meaning?'--How
9150 would you answer him?
9151 
9152 Just as if the two cases were at all alike! he said.
9153 
9154 Why should they not be? I replied; and even if they are not, but only
9155 appear to be so to the person who is asked, ought he not to say what he
9156 thinks, whether you and I forbid him or not?
9157 
9158 I presume then that you are going to make one of the interdicted
9159 answers?
9160 
9161 I dare say that I may, notwithstanding the danger, if upon reflection I
9162 approve of any of them.
9163 
9164 But what if I give you an answer about justice other and better, he
9165 said, than any of these? What do you deserve to have done to you?
9166 
9167 Done to me!--as becomes the ignorant, I must learn from the wise--that
9168 is what I deserve to have done to me.
9169 
9170 What, and no payment! a pleasant notion!
9171 
9172 I will pay when I have the money, I replied.
9173 
9174 But you have, Socrates, said Glaucon: and you, Thrasymachus, need be
9175 under no anxiety about money, for we will all make a contribution for
9176 Socrates.
9177 
9178 Yes, he replied, and then Socrates will do as he always does--refuse to
9179 answer himself, but take and pull to pieces the answer of some one else.
9180 
9181 Why, my good friend, I said, how can any one answer who knows, and says
9182 that he knows, just nothing; and who, even if he has some faint notions
9183 of his own, is told by a man of authority not to utter them? The
9184 natural thing is, that the speaker should be some one like yourself
9185 who professes to know and can tell what he knows. Will you then kindly
9186 answer, for the edification of the company and of myself?
9187 
9188 Glaucon and the rest of the company joined in my request, and
9189 Thrasymachus, as any one might see, was in reality eager to speak;
9190 for he thought that he had an excellent answer, and would distinguish
9191 himself. But at first he affected to insist on my answering; at length
9192 he consented to begin. Behold, he said, the wisdom of Socrates; he
9193 refuses to teach himself, and goes about learning of others, to whom he
9194 never even says Thank you.
9195 
9196 That I learn of others, I replied, is quite true; but that I am
9197 ungrateful I wholly deny. Money I have none, and therefore I pay in
9198 praise, which is all I have; and how ready I am to praise any one who
9199 appears to me to speak well you will very soon find out when you answer;
9200 for I expect that you will answer well.
9201 
9202 Listen, then, he said; I proclaim that justice is nothing else than
9203 the interest of the stronger. And now why do you not praise me? But of
9204 course you won't.
9205 
9206 Let me first understand you, I replied. Justice, as you say, is the
9207 interest of the stronger. What, Thrasymachus, is the meaning of this?
9208 You cannot mean to say that because Polydamas, the pancratiast, is
9209 stronger than we are, and finds the eating of beef conducive to his
9210 bodily strength, that to eat beef is therefore equally for our good who
9211 are weaker than he is, and right and just for us?
9212 
9213 That's abominable of you, Socrates; you take the words in the sense
9214 which is most damaging to the argument.
9215 
9216 Not at all, my good sir, I said; I am trying to understand them; and I
9217 wish that you would be a little clearer.
9218 
9219 Well, he said, have you never heard that forms of government differ;
9220 there are tyrannies, and there are democracies, and there are
9221 aristocracies?
9222 
9223 Yes, I know.
9224 
9225 And the government is the ruling power in each state?
9226 
9227 Certainly.
9228 
9229 And the different forms of government make laws democratical,
9230 aristocratical, tyrannical, with a view to their several interests;
9231 and these laws, which are made by them for their own interests, are the
9232 justice which they deliver to their subjects, and him who transgresses
9233 them they punish as a breaker of the law, and unjust. And that is what
9234 I mean when I say that in all states there is the same principle of
9235 justice, which is the interest of the government; and as the government
9236 must be supposed to have power, the only reasonable conclusion is, that
9237 everywhere there is one principle of justice, which is the interest of
9238 the stronger.
9239 
9240 Now I understand you, I said; and whether you are right or not I will
9241 try to discover. But let me remark, that in defining justice you have
9242 yourself used the word 'interest' which you forbade me to use. It is
9243 true, however, that in your definition the words 'of the stronger' are
9244 added.
9245 
9246 A small addition, you must allow, he said.
9247 
9248 Great or small, never mind about that: we must first enquire whether
9249 what you are saying is the truth. Now we are both agreed that justice
9250 is interest of some sort, but you go on to say 'of the stronger'; about
9251 this addition I am not so sure, and must therefore consider further.
9252 
9253 Proceed.
9254 
9255 I will; and first tell me, Do you admit that it is just for subjects to
9256 obey their rulers?
9257 
9258 I do.
9259 
9260 But are the rulers of states absolutely infallible, or are they
9261 sometimes liable to err?
9262 
9263 To be sure, he replied, they are liable to err.
9264 
9265 Then in making their laws they may sometimes make them rightly, and
9266 sometimes not?
9267 
9268 True.
9269 
9270 When they make them rightly, they make them agreeably to their interest;
9271 when they are mistaken, contrary to their interest; you admit that?
9272 
9273 Yes.
9274 
9275 And the laws which they make must be obeyed by their subjects,--and that
9276 is what you call justice?
9277 
9278 Doubtless.
9279 
9280 Then justice, according to your argument, is not only obedience to the
9281 interest of the stronger but the reverse?
9282 
9283 What is that you are saying? he asked.
9284 
9285 I am only repeating what you are saying, I believe. But let us consider:
9286 Have we not admitted that the rulers may be mistaken about their own
9287 interest in what they command, and also that to obey them is justice?
9288 Has not that been admitted?
9289 
9290 Yes.
9291 
9292 Then you must also have acknowledged justice not to be for the interest
9293 of the stronger, when the rulers unintentionally command things to be
9294 done which are to their own injury. For if, as you say, justice is the
9295 obedience which the subject renders to their commands, in that case, O
9296 wisest of men, is there any escape from the conclusion that the weaker
9297 are commanded to do, not what is for the interest, but what is for the
9298 injury of the stronger?
9299 
9300 Nothing can be clearer, Socrates, said Polemarchus.
9301 
9302 Yes, said Cleitophon, interposing, if you are allowed to be his witness.
9303 
9304 But there is no need of any witness, said Polemarchus, for Thrasymachus
9305 himself acknowledges that rulers may sometimes command what is not for
9306 their own interest, and that for subjects to obey them is justice.
9307 
9308 Yes, Polemarchus,--Thrasymachus said that for subjects to do what was
9309 commanded by their rulers is just.
9310 
9311 Yes, Cleitophon, but he also said that justice is the interest of the
9312 stronger, and, while admitting both these propositions, he further
9313 acknowledged that the stronger may command the weaker who are his
9314 subjects to do what is not for his own interest; whence follows that
9315 justice is the injury quite as much as the interest of the stronger.
9316 
9317 But, said Cleitophon, he meant by the interest of the stronger what the
9318 stronger thought to be his interest,--this was what the weaker had to
9319 do; and this was affirmed by him to be justice.
9320 
9321 Those were not his words, rejoined Polemarchus.
9322 
9323 Never mind, I replied, if he now says that they are, let us accept his
9324 statement. Tell me, Thrasymachus, I said, did you mean by justice what
9325 the stronger thought to be his interest, whether really so or not?
9326 
9327 Certainly not, he said. Do you suppose that I call him who is mistaken
9328 the stronger at the time when he is mistaken?
9329 
9330 Yes, I said, my impression was that you did so, when you admitted that
9331 the ruler was not infallible but might be sometimes mistaken.
9332 
9333 You argue like an informer, Socrates. Do you mean, for example, that he
9334 who is mistaken about the sick is a physician in that he is mistaken?
9335 or that he who errs in arithmetic or grammar is an arithmetician or
9336 grammarian at the time when he is making the mistake, in respect of the
9337 mistake? True, we say that the physician or arithmetician or grammarian
9338 has made a mistake, but this is only a way of speaking; for the fact is
9339 that neither the grammarian nor any other person of skill ever makes a
9340 mistake in so far as he is what his name implies; they none of them
9341 err unless their skill fails them, and then they cease to be skilled
9342 artists. No artist or sage or ruler errs at the time when he is what
9343 his name implies; though he is commonly said to err, and I adopted the
9344 common mode of speaking. But to be perfectly accurate, since you are
9345 such a lover of accuracy, we should say that the ruler, in so far as he
9346 is a ruler, is unerring, and, being unerring, always commands that which
9347 is for his own interest; and the subject is required to execute his
9348 commands; and therefore, as I said at first and now repeat, justice is
9349 the interest of the stronger.
9350
