9351 Indeed, Thrasymachus, and do I really appear to you to argue like an
9352 informer?
9353 
9354 Certainly, he replied.
9355 
9356 And do you suppose that I ask these questions with any design of
9357 injuring you in the argument?
9358 
9359 Nay, he replied, 'suppose' is not the word--I know it; but you will be
9360 found out, and by sheer force of argument you will never prevail.
9361 
9362 I shall not make the attempt, my dear man; but to avoid any
9363 misunderstanding occurring between us in future, let me ask, in what
9364 sense do you speak of a ruler or stronger whose interest, as you were
9365 saying, he being the superior, it is just that the inferior should
9366 execute--is he a ruler in the popular or in the strict sense of the
9367 term?
9368 
9369 In the strictest of all senses, he said. And now cheat and play the
9370 informer if you can; I ask no quarter at your hands. But you never will
9371 be able, never.
9372 
9373 And do you imagine, I said, that I am such a madman as to try and cheat,
9374 Thrasymachus? I might as well shave a lion.
9375 
9376 Why, he said, you made the attempt a minute ago, and you failed.
9377 
9378 Enough, I said, of these civilities. It will be better that I should ask
9379 you a question: Is the physician, taken in that strict sense of which
9380 you are speaking, a healer of the sick or a maker of money? And remember
9381 that I am now speaking of the true physician.
9382 
9383 A healer of the sick, he replied.
9384 
9385 And the pilot--that is to say, the true pilot--is he a captain of
9386 sailors or a mere sailor?
9387 
9388 A captain of sailors.
9389 
9390 The circumstance that he sails in the ship is not to be taken into
9391 account; neither is he to be called a sailor; the name pilot by which he
9392 is distinguished has nothing to do with sailing, but is significant of
9393 his skill and of his authority over the sailors.
9394 
9395 Very true, he said.
9396 
9397 Now, I said, every art has an interest?
9398 
9399 Certainly.
9400 
9401 For which the art has to consider and provide?
9402 
9403 Yes, that is the aim of art.
9404 
9405 And the interest of any art is the perfection of it--this and nothing
9406 else?
9407 
9408 What do you mean?
9409 
9410 I mean what I may illustrate negatively by the example of the body.
9411 Suppose you were to ask me whether the body is self-sufficing or has
9412 wants, I should reply: Certainly the body has wants; for the body may
9413 be ill and require to be cured, and has therefore interests to which
9414 the art of medicine ministers; and this is the origin and intention of
9415 medicine, as you will acknowledge. Am I not right?
9416 
9417 Quite right, he replied.
9418 
9419 But is the art of medicine or any other art faulty or deficient in any
9420 quality in the same way that the eye may be deficient in sight or the
9421 ear fail of hearing, and therefore requires another art to provide
9422 for the interests of seeing and hearing--has art in itself, I say, any
9423 similar liability to fault or defect, and does every art require another
9424 supplementary art to provide for its interests, and that another and
9425 another without end? Or have the arts to look only after their
9426 own interests? Or have they no need either of themselves or of
9427 another?--having no faults or defects, they have no need to correct
9428 them, either by the exercise of their own art or of any other; they have
9429 only to consider the interest of their subject-matter. For every art
9430 remains pure and faultless while remaining true--that is to say, while
9431 perfect and unimpaired. Take the words in your precise sense, and tell
9432 me whether I am not right.
9433 
9434 Yes, clearly.
9435 
9436 Then medicine does not consider the interest of medicine, but the
9437 interest of the body?
9438 
9439 True, he said.
9440 
9441 Nor does the art of horsemanship consider the interests of the art of
9442 horsemanship, but the interests of the horse; neither do any other arts
9443 care for themselves, for they have no needs; they care only for that
9444 which is the subject of their art?
9445 
9446 True, he said.
9447 
9448 But surely, Thrasymachus, the arts are the superiors and rulers of their
9449 own subjects?
9450 
9451 To this he assented with a good deal of reluctance.
9452 
9453 Then, I said, no science or art considers or enjoins the interest of the
9454 stronger or superior, but only the interest of the subject and weaker?
9455 
9456 He made an attempt to contest this proposition also, but finally
9457 acquiesced.
9458 
9459 Then, I continued, no physician, in so far as he is a physician,
9460 considers his own good in what he prescribes, but the good of his
9461 patient; for the true physician is also a ruler having the human body as
9462 a subject, and is not a mere money-maker; that has been admitted?
9463 
9464 Yes.
9465 
9466 And the pilot likewise, in the strict sense of the term, is a ruler of
9467 sailors and not a mere sailor?
9468 
9469 That has been admitted.
9470 
9471 And such a pilot and ruler will provide and prescribe for the interest
9472 of the sailor who is under him, and not for his own or the ruler's
9473 interest?
9474 
9475 He gave a reluctant 'Yes.'
9476 
9477 Then, I said, Thrasymachus, there is no one in any rule who, in so far
9478 as he is a ruler, considers or enjoins what is for his own interest, but
9479 always what is for the interest of his subject or suitable to his art;
9480 to that he looks, and that alone he considers in everything which he
9481 says and does.
9482 
9483 When we had got to this point in the argument, and every one saw that
9484 the definition of justice had been completely upset, Thrasymachus,
9485 instead of replying to me, said: Tell me, Socrates, have you got a
9486 nurse?
9487 
9488 Why do you ask such a question, I said, when you ought rather to be
9489 answering?
9490 
9491 Because she leaves you to snivel, and never wipes your nose: she has not
9492 even taught you to know the shepherd from the sheep.
9493 
9494 What makes you say that? I replied.
9495 
9496 Because you fancy that the shepherd or neatherd fattens or tends the
9497 sheep or oxen with a view to their own good and not to the good of
9498 himself or his master; and you further imagine that the rulers of
9499 states, if they are true rulers, never think of their subjects as sheep,
9500 and that they are not studying their own advantage day and night. Oh,
9501 no; and so entirely astray are you in your ideas about the just and
9502 unjust as not even to know that justice and the just are in reality
9503 another's good; that is to say, the interest of the ruler and stronger,
9504 and the loss of the subject and servant; and injustice the opposite; for
9505 the unjust is lord over the truly simple and just: he is the stronger,
9506 and his subjects do what is for his interest, and minister to his
9507 happiness, which is very far from being their own. Consider further,
9508 most foolish Socrates, that the just is always a loser in comparison
9509 with the unjust. First of all, in private contracts: wherever the unjust
9510 is the partner of the just you will find that, when the partnership is
9511 dissolved, the unjust man has always more and the just less. Secondly,
9512 in their dealings with the State: when there is an income-tax, the just
9513 man will pay more and the unjust less on the same amount of income;
9514 and when there is anything to be received the one gains nothing and the
9515 other much. Observe also what happens when they take an office; there is
9516 the just man neglecting his affairs and perhaps suffering other losses,
9517 and getting nothing out of the public, because he is just; moreover he
9518 is hated by his friends and acquaintance for refusing to serve them in
9519 unlawful ways. But all this is reversed in the case of the unjust man.
9520 I am speaking, as before, of injustice on a large scale in which the
9521 advantage of the unjust is most apparent; and my meaning will be most
9522 clearly seen if we turn to that highest form of injustice in which the
9523 criminal is the happiest of men, and the sufferers or those who refuse
9524 to do injustice are the most miserable--that is to say tyranny, which by
9525 fraud and force takes away the property of others, not little by little
9526 but wholesale; comprehending in one, things sacred as well as profane,
9527 private and public; for which acts of wrong, if he were detected
9528 perpetrating any one of them singly, he would be punished and incur
9529 great disgrace--they who do such wrong in particular cases are called
9530 robbers of temples, and man-stealers and burglars and swindlers and
9531 thieves. But when a man besides taking away the money of the citizens
9532 has made slaves of them, then, instead of these names of reproach, he is
9533 termed happy and blessed, not only by the citizens but by all who
9534 hear of his having achieved the consummation of injustice. For mankind
9535 censure injustice, fearing that they may be the victims of it and not
9536 because they shrink from committing it. And thus, as I have shown,
9537 Socrates, injustice, when on a sufficient scale, has more strength and
9538 freedom and mastery than justice; and, as I said at first, justice is
9539 the interest of the stronger, whereas injustice is a man's own profit
9540 and interest.
9541 
9542 Thrasymachus, when he had thus spoken, having, like a bath-man, deluged
9543 our ears with his words, had a mind to go away. But the company
9544 would not let him; they insisted that he should remain and defend his
9545 position; and I myself added my own humble request that he would not
9546 leave us. Thrasymachus, I said to him, excellent man, how suggestive
9547 are your remarks! And are you going to run away before you have fairly
9548 taught or learned whether they are true or not? Is the attempt to
9549 determine the way of man's life so small a matter in your eyes--to
9550 determine how life may be passed by each one of us to the greatest
9551 advantage?
9552 
9553 And do I differ from you, he said, as to the importance of the enquiry?
9554 
9555 You appear rather, I replied, to have no care or thought about us,
9556 Thrasymachus--whether we live better or worse from not knowing what you
9557 say you know, is to you a matter of indifference. Prithee, friend,
9558 do not keep your knowledge to yourself; we are a large party; and any
9559 benefit which you confer upon us will be amply rewarded. For my own
9560 part I openly declare that I am not convinced, and that I do not believe
9561 injustice to be more gainful than justice, even if uncontrolled and
9562 allowed to have free play. For, granting that there may be an unjust
9563 man who is able to commit injustice either by fraud or force, still this
9564 does not convince me of the superior advantage of injustice, and there
9565 may be others who are in the same predicament with myself. Perhaps we
9566 may be wrong; if so, you in your wisdom should convince us that we are
9567 mistaken in preferring justice to injustice.
9568 
9569 And how am I to convince you, he said, if you are not already convinced
9570 by what I have just said; what more can I do for you? Would you have me
9571 put the proof bodily into your souls?
9572 
9573 Heaven forbid! I said; I would only ask you to be consistent; or, if you
9574 change, change openly and let there be no deception. For I must remark,
9575 Thrasymachus, if you will recall what was previously said, that although
9576 you began by defining the true physician in an exact sense, you did not
9577 observe a like exactness when speaking of the shepherd; you thought that
9578 the shepherd as a shepherd tends the sheep not with a view to their own
9579 good, but like a mere diner or banquetter with a view to the pleasures
9580 of the table; or, again, as a trader for sale in the market, and not as
9581 a shepherd. Yet surely the art of the shepherd is concerned only with
9582 the good of his subjects; he has only to provide the best for them,
9583 since the perfection of the art is already ensured whenever all the
9584 requirements of it are satisfied. And that was what I was saying just
9585 now about the ruler. I conceived that the art of the ruler, considered
9586 as ruler, whether in a state or in private life, could only regard the
9587 good of his flock or subjects; whereas you seem to think that the rulers
9588 in states, that is to say, the true rulers, like being in authority.
9589 
9590 Think! Nay, I am sure of it.
9591 
9592 Then why in the case of lesser offices do men never take them willingly
9593 without payment, unless under the idea that they govern for the
9594 advantage not of themselves but of others? Let me ask you a question:
9595 Are not the several arts different, by reason of their each having a
9596 separate function? And, my dear illustrious friend, do say what you
9597 think, that we may make a little progress.
9598 
9599 Yes, that is the difference, he replied.
9600 
9601 And each art gives us a particular good and not merely a general
9602 one--medicine, for example, gives us health; navigation, safety at sea,
9603 and so on?
9604 
9605 Yes, he said.
9606 
9607 And the art of payment has the special function of giving pay: but we do
9608 not confuse this with other arts, any more than the art of the pilot is
9609 to be confused with the art of medicine, because the health of the pilot
9610 may be improved by a sea voyage. You would not be inclined to say, would
9611 you, that navigation is the art of medicine, at least if we are to adopt
9612 your exact use of language?
9613 
9614 Certainly not.
9615 
9616 Or because a man is in good health when he receives pay you would not
9617 say that the art of payment is medicine?
9618 
9619 I should not.
9620 
9621 Nor would you say that medicine is the art of receiving pay because a
9622 man takes fees when he is engaged in healing?
9623 
9624 Certainly not.
9625 
9626 And we have admitted, I said, that the good of each art is specially
9627 confined to the art?
9628 
9629 Yes.
9630 
9631 Then, if there be any good which all artists have in common, that is to
9632 be attributed to something of which they all have the common use?
9633 
9634 True, he replied.
9635 
9636 And when the artist is benefited by receiving pay the advantage is
9637 gained by an additional use of the art of pay, which is not the art
9638 professed by him?
9639 
9640 He gave a reluctant assent to this.
9641 
9642 Then the pay is not derived by the several artists from their respective
9643 arts. But the truth is, that while the art of medicine gives health, and
9644 the art of the builder builds a house, another art attends them which
9645 is the art of pay. The various arts may be doing their own business and
9646 benefiting that over which they preside, but would the artist receive
9647 any benefit from his art unless he were paid as well?
9648 
9649 I suppose not.
9650 
9651 But does he therefore confer no benefit when he works for nothing?
9652 
9653 Certainly, he confers a benefit.
9654 
9655 Then now, Thrasymachus, there is no longer any doubt that neither arts
9656 nor governments provide for their own interests; but, as we were before
9657 saying, they rule and provide for the interests of their subjects who
9658 are the weaker and not the stronger--to their good they attend and
9659 not to the good of the superior. And this is the reason, my dear
9660 Thrasymachus, why, as I was just now saying, no one is willing to
9661 govern; because no one likes to take in hand the reformation of evils
9662 which are not his concern without remuneration. For, in the execution of
9663 his work, and in giving his orders to another, the true artist does not
9664 regard his own interest, but always that of his subjects; and therefore
9665 in order that rulers may be willing to rule, they must be paid in one of
9666 three modes of payment, money, or honour, or a penalty for refusing.
9667 
9668 What do you mean, Socrates? said Glaucon. The first two modes of payment
9669 are intelligible enough, but what the penalty is I do not understand, or
9670 how a penalty can be a payment.
9671 
9672 You mean that you do not understand the nature of this payment which to
9673 the best men is the great inducement to rule? Of course you know that
9674 ambition and avarice are held to be, as indeed they are, a disgrace?
9675 
9676 Very true.
9677 
9678 And for this reason, I said, money and honour have no attraction for
9679 them; good men do not wish to be openly demanding payment for governing
9680 and so to get the name of hirelings, nor by secretly helping themselves
9681 out of the public revenues to get the name of thieves. And not being
9682 ambitious they do not care about honour. Wherefore necessity must be
9683 laid upon them, and they must be induced to serve from the fear of
9684 punishment. And this, as I imagine, is the reason why the forwardness
9685 to take office, instead of waiting to be compelled, has been deemed
9686 dishonourable. Now the worst part of the punishment is that he who
9687 refuses to rule is liable to be ruled by one who is worse than himself.
9688 And the fear of this, as I conceive, induces the good to take office,
9689 not because they would, but because they cannot help--not under the idea
9690 that they are going to have any benefit or enjoyment themselves, but as
9691 a necessity, and because they are not able to commit the task of ruling
9692 to any one who is better than themselves, or indeed as good. For there
9693 is reason to think that if a city were composed entirely of good men,
9694 then to avoid office would be as much an object of contention as to
9695 obtain office is at present; then we should have plain proof that the
9696 true ruler is not meant by nature to regard his own interest, but that
9697 of his subjects; and every one who knew this would choose rather to
9698 receive a benefit from another than to have the trouble of conferring
9699 one. So far am I from agreeing with Thrasymachus that justice is the
9700 interest of the stronger. This latter question need not be further
9701 discussed at present; but when Thrasymachus says that the life of the
9702 unjust is more advantageous than that of the just, his new statement
9703 appears to me to be of a far more serious character. Which of us has
9704 spoken truly? And which sort of life, Glaucon, do you prefer?
9705 
9706 I for my part deem the life of the just to be the more advantageous, he
9707 answered.
9708 
9709 Did you hear all the advantages of the unjust which Thrasymachus was
9710 rehearsing?
9711 
9712 Yes, I heard him, he replied, but he has not convinced me.
9713 
9714 Then shall we try to find some way of convincing him, if we can, that he
9715 is saying what is not true?
9716 
9717 Most certainly, he replied.
9718 
9719 If, I said, he makes a set speech and we make another recounting all the
9720 advantages of being just, and he answers and we rejoin, there must be a
9721 numbering and measuring of the goods which are claimed on either side,
9722 and in the end we shall want judges to decide; but if we proceed in our
9723 enquiry as we lately did, by making admissions to one another, we shall
9724 unite the offices of judge and advocate in our own persons.
9725 
9726 Very good, he said.
9727 
9728 And which method do I understand you to prefer? I said.
9729 
9730 That which you propose.
9731 
9732 Well, then, Thrasymachus, I said, suppose you begin at the beginning and
9733 answer me. You say that perfect injustice is more gainful than perfect
9734 justice?
9735 
9736 Yes, that is what I say, and I have given you my reasons.
9737 
9738 And what is your view about them? Would you call one of them virtue and
9739 the other vice?
9740 
9741 Certainly.
9742 
9743 I suppose that you would call justice virtue and injustice vice?
9744 
9745 What a charming notion! So likely too, seeing that I affirm injustice to
9746 be profitable and justice not.
9747 
9748 What else then would you say?
9749 
9750 The opposite, he replied.
9751 
9752 And would you call justice vice?
9753 
9754 No, I would rather say sublime simplicity.
9755 
9756 Then would you call injustice malignity?
9757 
9758 No; I would rather say discretion.
9759 
9760 And do the unjust appear to you to be wise and good?
9761 
9762 Yes, he said; at any rate those of them who are able to be perfectly
9763 unjust, and who have the power of subduing states and nations; but
9764 perhaps you imagine me to be talking of cutpurses. Even this profession
9765 if undetected has advantages, though they are not to be compared with
9766 those of which I was just now speaking.
9767 
9768 I do not think that I misapprehend your meaning, Thrasymachus, I
9769 replied; but still I cannot hear without amazement that you class
9770 injustice with wisdom and virtue, and justice with the opposite.
9771 
9772 Certainly I do so class them.
9773 
9774 Now, I said, you are on more substantial and almost unanswerable ground;
9775 for if the injustice which you were maintaining to be profitable had
9776 been admitted by you as by others to be vice and deformity, an answer
9777 might have been given to you on received principles; but now I perceive
9778 that you will call injustice honourable and strong, and to the unjust
9779 you will attribute all the qualities which were attributed by us before
9780 to the just, seeing that you do not hesitate to rank injustice with
9781 wisdom and virtue.
9782 
9783 You have guessed most infallibly, he replied.
9784 
9785 Then I certainly ought not to shrink from going through with the
9786 argument so long as I have reason to think that you, Thrasymachus, are
9787 speaking your real mind; for I do believe that you are now in earnest
9788 and are not amusing yourself at our expense.
9789 
9790 I may be in earnest or not, but what is that to you?--to refute the
9791 argument is your business.
9792 
9793 Very true, I said; that is what I have to do: But will you be so good
9794 as answer yet one more question? Does the just man try to gain any
9795 advantage over the just?
9796 
9797 Far otherwise; if he did he would not be the simple amusing creature
9798 which he is.
9799 
9800 And would he try to go beyond just action?
9801 
9802 He would not.
9803 
9804 And how would he regard the attempt to gain an advantage over the
9805 unjust; would that be considered by him as just or unjust?
9806 
9807 He would think it just, and would try to gain the advantage; but he
9808 would not be able.
9809 
9810 Whether he would or would not be able, I said, is not to the point. My
9811 question is only whether the just man, while refusing to have more than
9812 another just man, would wish and claim to have more than the unjust?
9813 
9814 Yes, he would.
9815 
9816 And what of the unjust--does he claim to have more than the just man and
9817 to do more than is just?
9818 
9819 Of course, he said, for he claims to have more than all men.
9820 
9821 And the unjust man will strive and struggle to obtain more than the
9822 unjust man or action, in order that he may have more than all?
9823 
9824 True.
9825 
9826 We may put the matter thus, I said--the just does not desire more than
9827 his like but more than his unlike, whereas the unjust desires more than
9828 both his like and his unlike?
9829 
9830 Nothing, he said, can be better than that statement.
9831 
9832 And the unjust is good and wise, and the just is neither?
9833 
9834 Good again, he said.
9835 
9836 And is not the unjust like the wise and good and the just unlike them?
9837 
9838 Of course, he said, he who is of a certain nature, is like those who are
9839 of a certain nature; he who is not, not.
9840 
9841 Each of them, I said, is such as his like is?
9842 
9843 Certainly, he replied.
9844 
9845 Very good, Thrasymachus, I said; and now to take the case of the arts:
9846 you would admit that one man is a musician and another not a musician?
9847 
9848 Yes.
9849 
9850 And which is wise and which is foolish?
9851 
9852 Clearly the musician is wise, and he who is not a musician is foolish.
9853 
9854 And he is good in as far as he is wise, and bad in as far as he is
9855 foolish?
9856 
9857 Yes.
9858 
9859 And you would say the same sort of thing of the physician?
9860 
9861 Yes.
9862 
9863 And do you think, my excellent friend, that a musician when he adjusts
9864 the lyre would desire or claim to exceed or go beyond a musician in the
9865 tightening and loosening the strings?
9866 
9867 I do not think that he would.
9868 
9869 But he would claim to exceed the non-musician?
9870 
9871 Of course.
9872 
9873 And what would you say of the physician? In prescribing meats and drinks
9874 would he wish to go beyond another physician or beyond the practice of
9875 medicine?
9876 
9877 He would not.
9878 
9879 But he would wish to go beyond the non-physician?
9880 
9881 Yes.
9882 
9883 And about knowledge and ignorance in general; see whether you think that
9884 any man who has knowledge ever would wish to have the choice of saying
9885 or doing more than another man who has knowledge. Would he not rather
9886 say or do the same as his like in the same case?
9887 
9888 That, I suppose, can hardly be denied.
9889 
9890 And what of the ignorant? would he not desire to have more than either
9891 the knowing or the ignorant?
9892 
9893 I dare say.
9894 
9895 And the knowing is wise?
9896 
9897 Yes.
9898 
9899 And the wise is good?
9900 
9901 True.
9902 
9903 Then the wise and good will not desire to gain more than his like, but
9904 more than his unlike and opposite?
9905 
9906 I suppose so.
9907 
9908 Whereas the bad and ignorant will desire to gain more than both?
9909 
9910 Yes.
9911 
9912 But did we not say, Thrasymachus, that the unjust goes beyond both his
9913 like and unlike? Were not these your words?
9914 
9915 They were.
9916 
9917 And you also said that the just will not go beyond his like but his
9918 unlike?
9919 
9920 Yes.
9921 
9922 Then the just is like the wise and good, and the unjust like the evil
9923 and ignorant?
9924 
9925 That is the inference.
9926 
9927 And each of them is such as his like is?
9928 
9929 That was admitted.
9930 
9931 Then the just has turned out to be wise and good and the unjust evil and
9932 ignorant.
9933 
9934 Thrasymachus made all these admissions, not fluently, as I repeat
9935 them, but with extreme reluctance; it was a hot summer's day, and the
9936 perspiration poured from him in torrents; and then I saw what I had
9937 never seen before, Thrasymachus blushing. As we were now agreed that
9938 justice was virtue and wisdom, and injustice vice and ignorance, I
9939 proceeded to another point:
9940 
9941 Well, I said, Thrasymachus, that matter is now settled; but were we not
9942 also saying that injustice had strength; do you remember?
9943 
9944 Yes, I remember, he said, but do not suppose that I approve of what you
9945 are saying or have no answer; if however I were to answer, you would be
9946 quite certain to accuse me of haranguing; therefore either permit me to
9947 have my say out, or if you would rather ask, do so, and I will answer
9948 'Very good,' as they say to story-telling old women, and will nod 'Yes'
9949 and 'No.'
9950 
9951 Certainly not, I said, if contrary to your real opinion.
9952 
9953 Yes, he said, I will, to please you, since you will not let me speak.
9954 What else would you have?
9955 
9956 Nothing in the world, I said; and if you are so disposed I will ask and
9957 you shall answer.
9958 
9959 Proceed.
9960 
9961 Then I will repeat the question which I asked before, in order that
9962 our examination of the relative nature of justice and injustice may be
9963 carried on regularly. A statement was made that injustice is stronger
9964 and more powerful than justice, but now justice, having been identified
9965 with wisdom and virtue, is easily shown to be stronger than injustice,
9966 if injustice is ignorance; this can no longer be questioned by any one.
9967 But I want to view the matter, Thrasymachus, in a different way: You
9968 would not deny that a state may be unjust and may be unjustly attempting
9969 to enslave other states, or may have already enslaved them, and may be
9970 holding many of them in subjection?
9971 
9972 True, he replied; and I will add that the best and most perfectly unjust
9973 state will be most likely to do so.
9974 
9975 I know, I said, that such was your position; but what I would further
9976 consider is, whether this power which is possessed by the superior state
9977 can exist or be exercised without justice or only with justice.
9978 
9979 If you are right in your view, and justice is wisdom, then only with
9980 justice; but if I am right, then without justice.
9981 
9982 I am delighted, Thrasymachus, to see you not only nodding assent and
9983 dissent, but making answers which are quite excellent.
9984 
9985 That is out of civility to you, he replied.
9986 
9987 You are very kind, I said; and would you have the goodness also to
9988 inform me, whether you think that a state, or an army, or a band of
9989 robbers and thieves, or any other gang of evil-doers could act at all if
9990 they injured one another?
9991 
9992 No indeed, he said, they could not.
9993 
9994 But if they abstained from injuring one another, then they might act
9995 together better?
9996 
9997 Yes.
9998 
9999 And this is because injustice creates divisions and hatreds and
10000 fighting, and justice imparts harmony and friendship; is not that true,
10001 Thrasymachus?
10002 
10003 I agree, he said, because I do not wish to quarrel with you.
10004 
10005 How good of you, I said; but I should like to know also whether
10006 injustice, having this tendency to arouse hatred, wherever existing,
10007 among slaves or among freemen, will not make them hate one another and
10008 set them at variance and render them incapable of common action?
10009 
10010 Certainly.
10011 
10012 And even if injustice be found in two only, will they not quarrel and
10013 fight, and become enemies to one another and to the just?
10014 
10015 They will.
10016 
10017 And suppose injustice abiding in a single person, would your wisdom say
10018 that she loses or that she retains her natural power?
10019 
10020 Let us assume that she retains her power.
10021 
10022 Yet is not the power which injustice exercises of such a nature that
10023 wherever she takes up her abode, whether in a city, in an army, in a
10024 family, or in any other body, that body is, to begin with, rendered
10025 incapable of united action by reason of sedition and distraction; and
10026 does it not become its own enemy and at variance with all that opposes
10027 it, and with the just? Is not this the case?
10028 
10029 Yes, certainly.
10030 
10031 And is not injustice equally fatal when existing in a single person; in
10032 the first place rendering him incapable of action because he is not
10033 at unity with himself, and in the second place making him an enemy to
10034 himself and the just? Is not that true, Thrasymachus?
10035 
10036 Yes.
10037 
10038 And O my friend, I said, surely the gods are just?
10039 
10040 Granted that they are.
10041 
10042 But if so, the unjust will be the enemy of the gods, and the just will
10043 be their friend?
10044 
10045 Feast away in triumph, and take your fill of the argument; I will not
10046 oppose you, lest I should displease the company.
10047 
10048 Well then, proceed with your answers, and let me have the remainder of
10049 my repast. For we have already shown that the just are clearly wiser and
10050 better and abler than the unjust, and that the unjust are incapable of
10051 common action; nay more, that to speak as we did of men who are evil
10052 acting at any time vigorously together, is not strictly true, for
10053 if they had been perfectly evil, they would have laid hands upon one
10054 another; but it is evident that there must have been some remnant of
10055 justice in them, which enabled them to combine; if there had not been
10056 they would have injured one another as well as their victims; they
10057 were but half-villains in their enterprises; for had they been whole
10058 villains, and utterly unjust, they would have been utterly incapable of
10059 action. That, as I believe, is the truth of the matter, and not what you
10060 said at first. But whether the just have a better and happier life than
10061 the unjust is a further question which we also proposed to consider. I
10062 think that they have, and for the reasons which I have given; but still
10063 I should like to examine further, for no light matter is at stake,
10064 nothing less than the rule of human life.
10065 
10066 Proceed.
10067 
10068 I will proceed by asking a question: Would you not say that a horse has
10069 some end?
10070 
10071 I should.
10072 
10073 And the end or use of a horse or of anything would be that which could
10074 not be accomplished, or not so well accomplished, by any other thing?
10075 
10076 I do not understand, he said.
10077 
10078 Let me explain: Can you see, except with the eye?
10079 
10080 Certainly not.
10081 
10082 Or hear, except with the ear?
10083 
10084 No.
10085 
10086 These then may be truly said to be the ends of these organs?
10087 
10088 They may.
10089 
10090 But you can cut off a vine-branch with a dagger or with a chisel, and in
10091 many other ways?
10092 
10093 Of course.
10094 
10095 And yet not so well as with a pruning-hook made for the purpose?
10096 
10097 True.
10098 
10099 May we not say that this is the end of a pruning-hook?
10100 
10101 We may.
10102 
10103 Then now I think you will have no difficulty in understanding my meaning
10104 when I asked the question whether the end of anything would be that
10105 which could not be accomplished, or not so well accomplished, by any
10106 other thing?
10107 
10108 I understand your meaning, he said, and assent.
10109 
10110 And that to which an end is appointed has also an excellence? Need I ask
10111 again whether the eye has an end?
10112 
10113 It has.
10114 
10115 And has not the eye an excellence?
10116 
10117 Yes.
10118 
10119 And the ear has an end and an excellence also?
10120 
10121 True.
10122 
10123 And the same is true of all other things; they have each of them an end
10124 and a special excellence?
10125 
10126 That is so.
10127 
10128 Well, and can the eyes fulfil their end if they are wanting in their own
10129 proper excellence and have a defect instead?
10130 
10131 How can they, he said, if they are blind and cannot see?
10132 
10133 You mean to say, if they have lost their proper excellence, which is
10134 sight; but I have not arrived at that point yet. I would rather ask
10135 the question more generally, and only enquire whether the things which
10136 fulfil their ends fulfil them by their own proper excellence, and fail
10137 of fulfilling them by their own defect?
10138 
10139 Certainly, he replied.
10140 
10141 I might say the same of the ears; when deprived of their own proper
10142 excellence they cannot fulfil their end?
10143 
10144 True.
10145 
10146 And the same observation will apply to all other things?
10147 
10148 I agree.
10149 
10150 Well; and has not the soul an end which nothing else can fulfil? for
10151 example, to superintend and command and deliberate and the like. Are not
10152 these functions proper to the soul, and can they rightly be assigned to
10153 any other?
10154 
10155 To no other.
10156 
10157 And is not life to be reckoned among the ends of the soul?
10158 
10159 Assuredly, he said.
10160 
10161 And has not the soul an excellence also?
10162 
10163 Yes.
10164 
10165 And can she or can she not fulfil her own ends when deprived of that
10166 excellence?
10167 
10168 She cannot.
10169 
10170 Then an evil soul must necessarily be an evil ruler and superintendent,
10171 and the good soul a good ruler?
10172 
10173 Yes, necessarily.
10174 
10175 And we have admitted that justice is the excellence of the soul, and
10176 injustice the defect of the soul?
10177 
10178 That has been admitted.
10179 
10180 Then the just soul and the just man will live well, and the unjust man
10181 will live ill?
10182 
10183 That is what your argument proves.
10184 
10185 And he who lives well is blessed and happy, and he who lives ill the
10186 reverse of happy?
10187 
10188 Certainly.
10189 
10190 Then the just is happy, and the unjust miserable?
10191 
10192 So be it.
10193 
10194 But happiness and not misery is profitable.
10195 
10196 Of course.
10197 
10198 Then, my blessed Thrasymachus, injustice can never be more profitable
10199 than justice.
10200 
10201 Let this, Socrates, he said, be your entertainment at the Bendidea.
10202 
10203 For which I am indebted to you, I said, now that you have grown gentle
10204 towards me and have left off scolding. Nevertheless, I have not been
10205 well entertained; but that was my own fault and not yours. As an epicure
10206 snatches a taste of every dish which is successively brought to table,
10207 he not having allowed himself time to enjoy the one before, so have I
10208 gone from one subject to another without having discovered what I sought
10209 at first, the nature of justice. I left that enquiry and turned away
10210 to consider whether justice is virtue and wisdom or evil and folly; and
10211 when there arose a further question about the comparative advantages of
10212 justice and injustice, I could not refrain from passing on to that. And
10213 the result of the whole discussion has been that I know nothing at all.
10214 For I know not what justice is, and therefore I am not likely to know
10215 whether it is or is not a virtue, nor can I say whether the just man is
10216 happy or unhappy.
10217 
10218 
10219 
10220 
10221 BOOK II.
10222 
10223 With these words I was thinking that I had made an end of the
10224 discussion; but the end, in truth, proved to be only a beginning. For
10225 Glaucon, who is always the most pugnacious of men, was dissatisfied at
10226 Thrasymachus' retirement; he wanted to have the battle out. So he said
10227 to me: Socrates, do you wish really to persuade us, or only to seem to
10228 have persuaded us, that to be just is always better than to be unjust?
10229 
10230 I should wish really to persuade you, I replied, if I could.
10231 
10232 Then you certainly have not succeeded. Let me ask you now:--How would
10233 you arrange goods--are there not some which we welcome for their
10234 own sakes, and independently of their consequences, as, for example,
10235 harmless pleasures and enjoyments, which delight us at the time,
10236 although nothing follows from them?
10237 
10238 I agree in thinking that there is such a class, I replied.
10239 
10240 Is there not also a second class of goods, such as knowledge, sight,
10241 health, which are desirable not only in themselves, but also for their
10242 results?
10243 
10244 Certainly, I said.
10245 
10246 And would you not recognize a third class, such as gymnastic, and the
10247 care of the sick, and the physician's art; also the various ways of
10248 money-making--these do us good but we regard them as disagreeable; and
10249 no one would choose them for their own sakes, but only for the sake of
10250 some reward or result which flows from them?
10251 
10252 There is, I said, this third class also. But why do you ask?
10253 
10254 Because I want to know in which of the three classes you would place
10255 justice?
10256 
10257 In the highest class, I replied,--among those goods which he who would
10258 be happy desires both for their own sake and for the sake of their
10259 results.
10260 
10261 Then the many are of another mind; they think that justice is to be
10262 reckoned in the troublesome class, among goods which are to be pursued
10263 for the sake of rewards and of reputation, but in themselves are
10264 disagreeable and rather to be avoided.
10265 
10266 I know, I said, that this is their manner of thinking, and that this was
10267 the thesis which Thrasymachus was maintaining just now, when he censured
10268 justice and praised injustice. But I am too stupid to be convinced by
10269 him.
10270 
10271 I wish, he said, that you would hear me as well as him, and then I shall
10272 see whether you and I agree. For Thrasymachus seems to me, like a snake,
10273 to have been charmed by your voice sooner than he ought to have been;
10274 but to my mind the nature of justice and injustice have not yet been
10275 made clear. Setting aside their rewards and results, I want to know what
10276 they are in themselves, and how they inwardly work in the soul. If you,
10277 please, then, I will revive the argument of Thrasymachus. And first I
10278 will speak of the nature and origin of justice according to the common
10279 view of them. Secondly, I will show that all men who practise justice do
10280 so against their will, of necessity, but not as a good. And thirdly, I
10281 will argue that there is reason in this view, for the life of the unjust
10282 is after all better far than the life of the just--if what they say
10283 is true, Socrates, since I myself am not of their opinion. But still I
10284 acknowledge that I am perplexed when I hear the voices of Thrasymachus
10285 and myriads of others dinning in my ears; and, on the other hand, I have
10286 never yet heard the superiority of justice to injustice maintained by
10287 any one in a satisfactory way. I want to hear justice praised in respect
10288 of itself; then I shall be satisfied, and you are the person from whom
10289 I think that I am most likely to hear this; and therefore I will praise
10290 the unjust life to the utmost of my power, and my manner of speaking
10291 will indicate the manner in which I desire to hear you too praising
10292 justice and censuring injustice. Will you say whether you approve of my
10293 proposal?
10294 
10295 Indeed I do; nor can I imagine any theme about which a man of sense
10296 would oftener wish to converse.
10297 
10298 I am delighted, he replied, to hear you say so, and shall begin by
10299 speaking, as I proposed, of the nature and origin of justice.
10300 
10301 They say that to do injustice is, by nature, good; to suffer injustice,
10302 evil; but that the evil is greater than the good. And so when men have
10303 both done and suffered injustice and have had experience of both, not
10304 being able to avoid the one and obtain the other, they think that they
10305 had better agree among themselves to have neither; hence there arise
10306 laws and mutual covenants; and that which is ordained by law is termed
10307 by them lawful and just. This they affirm to be the origin and nature of
10308 justice;--it is a mean or compromise, between the best of all, which is
10309 to do injustice and not be punished, and the worst of all, which is to
10310 suffer injustice without the power of retaliation; and justice, being at
10311 a middle point between the two, is tolerated not as a good, but as
10312 the lesser evil, and honoured by reason of the inability of men to do
10313 injustice. For no man who is worthy to be called a man would ever submit
10314 to such an agreement if he were able to resist; he would be mad if he
10315 did. Such is the received account, Socrates, of the nature and origin of
10316 justice.
10317 
10318 Now that those who practise justice do so involuntarily and because they
10319 have not the power to be unjust will best appear if we imagine something
10320 of this kind: having given both to the just and the unjust power to do
10321 what they will, let us watch and see whither desire will lead them;
10322 then we shall discover in the very act the just and unjust man to be
10323 proceeding along the same road, following their interest, which all
10324 natures deem to be their good, and are only diverted into the path of
10325 justice by the force of law. The liberty which we are supposing may be
10326 most completely given to them in the form of such a power as is said
10327 to have been possessed by Gyges, the ancestor of Croesus the Lydian.
10328 According to the tradition, Gyges was a shepherd in the service of
10329 the king of Lydia; there was a great storm, and an earthquake made an
10330 opening in the earth at the place where he was feeding his flock. Amazed
10331 at the sight, he descended into the opening, where, among other marvels,
10332 he beheld a hollow brazen horse, having doors, at which he stooping and
10333 looking in saw a dead body of stature, as appeared to him, more than
10334 human, and having nothing on but a gold ring; this he took from the
10335 finger of the dead and reascended. Now the shepherds met together,
10336 according to custom, that they might send their monthly report about the
10337 flocks to the king; into their assembly he came having the ring on his
10338 finger, and as he was sitting among them he chanced to turn the collet
10339 of the ring inside his hand, when instantly he became invisible to the
10340 rest of the company and they began to speak of him as if he were no
10341 longer present. He was astonished at this, and again touching the ring
10342 he turned the collet outwards and reappeared; he made several trials
10343 of the ring, and always with the same result--when he turned the collet
10344 inwards he became invisible, when outwards he reappeared. Whereupon he
10345 contrived to be chosen one of the messengers who were sent to the court;
10346 whereas soon as he arrived he seduced the queen, and with her help
10347 conspired against the king and slew him, and took the kingdom. Suppose
10348 now that there were two such magic rings, and the just put on one of
10349 them and the unjust the other; no man can be imagined to be of such an
10350 iron nature that he would stand fast in justice. No man would keep his
10351 hands off what was not his own when he could safely take what he
10352 liked out of the market, or go into houses and lie with any one at
10353 his pleasure, or kill or release from prison whom he would, and in all
10354 respects be like a God among men. Then the actions of the just would be
10355 as the actions of the unjust; they would both come at last to the same
10356 point. And this we may truly affirm to be a great proof that a man is
10357 just, not willingly or because he thinks that justice is any good to him
10358 individually, but of necessity, for wherever any one thinks that he
10359 can safely be unjust, there he is unjust. For all men believe in their
10360 hearts that injustice is far more profitable to the individual than
10361 justice, and he who argues as I have been supposing, will say that they
10362 are right. If you could imagine any one obtaining this power of becoming
10363 invisible, and never doing any wrong or touching what was another's, he
10364 would be thought by the lookers-on to be a most wretched idiot, although
10365 they would praise him to one another's faces, and keep up appearances
10366 with one another from a fear that they too might suffer injustice.
10367 Enough of this.
10368 
10369 Now, if we are to form a real judgment of the life of the just and
10370 unjust, we must isolate them; there is no other way; and how is the
10371 isolation to be effected? I answer: Let the unjust man be entirely
10372 unjust, and the just man entirely just; nothing is to be taken away from
10373 either of them, and both are to be perfectly furnished for the work
10374 of their respective lives. First, let the unjust be like other
10375 distinguished masters of craft; like the skilful pilot or physician, who
10376 knows intuitively his own powers and keeps within their limits, and who,
10377 if he fails at any point, is able to recover himself. So let the unjust
10378 make his unjust attempts in the right way, and lie hidden if he means
10379 to be great in his injustice: (he who is found out is nobody:) for
10380 the highest reach of injustice is, to be deemed just when you are not.
10381 Therefore I say that in the perfectly unjust man we must assume the most
10382 perfect injustice; there is to be no deduction, but we must allow
10383 him, while doing the most unjust acts, to have acquired the greatest
10384 reputation for justice. If he have taken a false step he must be able to
10385 recover himself; he must be one who can speak with effect, if any of his
10386 deeds come to light, and who can force his way where force is required
10387 by his courage and strength, and command of money and friends. And at
10388 his side let us place the just man in his nobleness and simplicity,
10389 wishing, as Aeschylus says, to be and not to seem good. There must be no
10390 seeming, for if he seem to be just he will be honoured and rewarded, and
10391 then we shall not know whether he is just for the sake of justice or
10392 for the sake of honours and rewards; therefore, let him be clothed in
10393 justice only, and have no other covering; and he must be imagined in a
10394 state of life the opposite of the former. Let him be the best of men,
10395 and let him be thought the worst; then he will have been put to the
10396 proof; and we shall see whether he will be affected by the fear of
10397 infamy and its consequences. And let him continue thus to the hour of
10398 death; being just and seeming to be unjust. When both have reached the
10399 uttermost extreme, the one of justice and the other of injustice, let
10400 judgment be given which of them is the happier of the two.
10401 
10402 Heavens! my dear Glaucon, I said, how energetically you polish them
10403 up for the decision, first one and then the other, as if they were two
10404 statues.
10405 
10406 I do my best, he said. And now that we know what they are like there
10407 is no difficulty in tracing out the sort of life which awaits either
10408 of them. This I will proceed to describe; but as you may think the
10409 description a little too coarse, I ask you to suppose, Socrates, that
10410 the words which follow are not mine.--Let me put them into the mouths of
10411 the eulogists of injustice: They will tell you that the just man who is
10412 thought unjust will be scourged, racked, bound--will have his eyes
10413 burnt out; and, at last, after suffering every kind of evil, he will be
10414 impaled: Then he will understand that he ought to seem only, and not to
10415 be, just; the words of Aeschylus may be more truly spoken of the unjust
10416 than of the just. For the unjust is pursuing a reality; he does not live
10417 with a view to appearances--he wants to be really unjust and not to seem
10418 only:--
10419 
10420 'His mind has a soil deep and fertile, Out of which spring his prudent
10421 counsels.'
10422 
10423 In the first place, he is thought just, and therefore bears rule in the
10424 city; he can marry whom he will, and give in marriage to whom he
10425 will; also he can trade and deal where he likes, and always to his own
10426 advantage, because he has no misgivings about injustice; and at every
10427 contest, whether in public or private, he gets the better of his
10428 antagonists, and gains at their expense, and is rich, and out of his
10429 gains he can benefit his friends, and harm his enemies; moreover, he
10430 can offer sacrifices, and dedicate gifts to the gods abundantly and
10431 magnificently, and can honour the gods or any man whom he wants to
10432 honour in a far better style than the just, and therefore he is likely
10433 to be dearer than they are to the gods. And thus, Socrates, gods and men
10434 are said to unite in making the life of the unjust better than the life
10435 of the just.
10436 
10437 I was going to say something in answer to Glaucon, when Adeimantus, his
10438 brother, interposed: Socrates, he said, you do not suppose that there is
10439 nothing more to be urged?
10440 
10441 Why, what else is there? I answered.
10442 
10443 The strongest point of all has not been even mentioned, he replied.
10444 
10445 Well, then, according to the proverb, 'Let brother help brother'--if
10446 he fails in any part do you assist him; although I must confess that
10447 Glaucon has already said quite enough to lay me in the dust, and take
10448 from me the power of helping justice.
10449 
10450 Nonsense, he replied. But let me add something more: There is another
10451 side to Glaucon's argument about the praise and censure of justice
10452 and injustice, which is equally required in order to bring out what I
10453 believe to be his meaning. Parents and tutors are always telling their
10454 sons and their wards that they are to be just; but why? not for the sake
10455 of justice, but for the sake of character and reputation; in the hope of
10456 obtaining for him who is reputed just some of those offices, marriages,
10457 and the like which Glaucon has enumerated among the advantages accruing
10458 to the unjust from the reputation of justice. More, however, is made of
10459 appearances by this class of persons than by the others; for they
10460 throw in the good opinion of the gods, and will tell you of a shower of
10461 benefits which the heavens, as they say, rain upon the pious; and this
10462 accords with the testimony of the noble Hesiod and Homer, the first of
10463 whom says, that the gods make the oaks of the just--
10464 
10465    'To bear acorns at their summit, and bees in the middle;
10466    And the sheep are bowed down with the weight of their fleeces,'
10467 
10468 and many other blessings of a like kind are provided for them. And Homer
10469 has a very similar strain; for he speaks of one whose fame is--
10470 
10471 'As the fame of some blameless king who, like a god, Maintains justice;
10472 to whom the black earth brings forth Wheat and barley, whose trees are
10473 bowed with fruit, And his sheep never fail to bear, and the sea gives
10474 him fish.'
10475 
10476 Still grander are the gifts of heaven which Musaeus and his son
10477 vouchsafe to the just; they take them down into the world below, where
10478 they have the saints lying on couches at a feast, everlastingly drunk,
10479 crowned with garlands; their idea seems to be that an immortality of
10480 drunkenness is the highest meed of virtue. Some extend their rewards
10481 yet further; the posterity, as they say, of the faithful and just shall
10482 survive to the third and fourth generation. This is the style in which
10483 they praise justice. But about the wicked there is another strain; they
10484 bury them in a slough in Hades, and make them carry water in a sieve;
10485 also while they are yet living they bring them to infamy, and inflict
10486 upon them the punishments which Glaucon described as the portion of the
10487 just who are reputed to be unjust; nothing else does their invention
10488 supply. Such is their manner of praising the one and censuring the
10489 other.
10490 
10491 Once more, Socrates, I will ask you to consider another way of speaking
10492 about justice and injustice, which is not confined to the poets, but
10493 is found in prose writers. The universal voice of mankind is always
10494 declaring that justice and virtue are honourable, but grievous and
10495 toilsome; and that the pleasures of vice and injustice are easy of
10496 attainment, and are only censured by law and opinion. They say also that
10497 honesty is for the most part less profitable than dishonesty; and they
10498 are quite ready to call wicked men happy, and to honour them both in
10499 public and private when they are rich or in any other way influential,
10500 while they despise and overlook those who may be weak and poor, even
10501 though acknowledging them to be better than the others. But most
10502 extraordinary of all is their mode of speaking about virtue and the
10503 gods: they say that the gods apportion calamity and misery to many good
10504 men, and good and happiness to the wicked. And mendicant prophets go to
10505 rich men's doors and persuade them that they have a power committed
10506 to them by the gods of making an atonement for a man's own or his
10507 ancestor's sins by sacrifices or charms, with rejoicings and feasts; and
10508 they promise to harm an enemy, whether just or unjust, at a small cost;
10509 with magic arts and incantations binding heaven, as they say, to execute
10510 their will. And the poets are the authorities to whom they appeal, now
10511 smoothing the path of vice with the words of Hesiod;--
10512 
10513 'Vice may be had in abundance without trouble; the way is smooth and her
10514 dwelling-place is near. But before virtue the gods have set toil,'
10515 
10516 and a tedious and uphill road: then citing Homer as a witness that the
10517 gods may be influenced by men; for he also says:--
10518 
10519 'The gods, too, may be turned from their purpose; and men pray to them
10520 and avert their wrath by sacrifices and soothing entreaties, and by
10521 libations and the odour of fat, when they have sinned and transgressed.'
10522 
10523 And they produce a host of books written by Musaeus and Orpheus,
10524 who were children of the Moon and the Muses--that is what they
10525 say--according to which they perform their ritual, and persuade not only
10526 individuals, but whole cities, that expiations and atonements for sin
10527 may be made by sacrifices and amusements which fill a vacant hour, and
10528 are equally at the service of the living and the dead; the latter sort
10529 they call mysteries, and they redeem us from the pains of hell, but if
10530 we neglect them no one knows what awaits us.
10531 
10532 He proceeded: And now when the young hear all this said about virtue and
10533 vice, and the way in which gods and men regard them, how are their minds
10534 likely to be affected, my dear Socrates,--those of them, I mean, who are
10535 quickwitted, and, like bees on the wing, light on every flower, and from
10536 all that they hear are prone to draw conclusions as to what manner of
10537 persons they should be and in what way they should walk if they would
10538 make the best of life? Probably the youth will say to himself in the
10539 words of Pindar--
10540 
10541 'Can I by justice or by crooked ways of deceit ascend a loftier tower
10542 which may be a fortress to me all my days?'
10543 
10544 For what men say is that, if I am really just and am not also thought
10545 just profit there is none, but the pain and loss on the other hand
10546 are unmistakeable. But if, though unjust, I acquire the reputation of
10547 justice, a heavenly life is promised to me. Since then, as philosophers
10548 prove, appearance tyrannizes over truth and is lord of happiness, to
10549 appearance I must devote myself. I will describe around me a picture and
10550 shadow of virtue to be the vestibule and exterior of my house; behind I
10551 will trail the subtle and crafty fox, as Archilochus, greatest of sages,
10552 recommends. But I hear some one exclaiming that the concealment of
10553 wickedness is often difficult; to which I answer, Nothing great is easy.
10554 Nevertheless, the argument indicates this, if we would be happy, to be
10555 the path along which we should proceed. With a view to concealment we
10556 will establish secret brotherhoods and political clubs. And there
10557 are professors of rhetoric who teach the art of persuading courts and
10558 assemblies; and so, partly by persuasion and partly by force, I shall
10559 make unlawful gains and not be punished. Still I hear a voice saying
10560 that the gods cannot be deceived, neither can they be compelled. But
10561 what if there are no gods? or, suppose them to have no care of human
10562 things--why in either case should we mind about concealment? And even if
10563 there are gods, and they do care about us, yet we know of them only
10564 from tradition and the genealogies of the poets; and these are the very
10565 persons who say that they may be influenced and turned by 'sacrifices
10566 and soothing entreaties and by offerings.' Let us be consistent then,
10567 and believe both or neither. If the poets speak truly, why then we had
10568 better be unjust, and offer of the fruits of injustice; for if we are
10569 just, although we may escape the vengeance of heaven, we shall lose the
10570 gains of injustice; but, if we are unjust, we shall keep the gains, and
10571 by our sinning and praying, and praying and sinning, the gods will be
10572 propitiated, and we shall not be punished. 'But there is a world below
10573 in which either we or our posterity will suffer for our unjust deeds.'
10574 Yes, my friend, will be the reflection, but there are mysteries and
10575 atoning deities, and these have great power. That is what mighty
10576 cities declare; and the children of the gods, who were their poets and
10577 prophets, bear a like testimony.
10578 
10579 On what principle, then, shall we any longer choose justice rather than
10580 the worst injustice? when, if we only unite the latter with a deceitful
10581 regard to appearances, we shall fare to our mind both with gods and
10582 men, in life and after death, as the most numerous and the highest
10583 authorities tell us. Knowing all this, Socrates, how can a man who
10584 has any superiority of mind or person or rank or wealth, be willing to
10585 honour justice; or indeed to refrain from laughing when he hears justice
10586 praised? And even if there should be some one who is able to disprove
10587 the truth of my words, and who is satisfied that justice is best, still
10588 he is not angry with the unjust, but is very ready to forgive them,
10589 because he also knows that men are not just of their own free will;
10590 unless, peradventure, there be some one whom the divinity within him may
10591 have inspired with a hatred of injustice, or who has attained knowledge
10592 of the truth--but no other man. He only blames injustice who, owing to
10593 cowardice or age or some weakness, has not the power of being unjust.
10594 And this is proved by the fact that when he obtains the power, he
10595 immediately becomes unjust as far as he can be.
10596 
10597 The cause of all this, Socrates, was indicated by us at the beginning of
10598 the argument, when my brother and I told you how astonished we were to
10599 find that of all the professing panegyrists of justice--beginning with
10600 the ancient heroes of whom any memorial has been preserved to us, and
10601 ending with the men of our own time--no one has ever blamed injustice or
10602 praised justice except with a view to the glories, honours, and benefits
10603 which flow from them. No one has ever adequately described either in
10604 verse or prose the true essential nature of either of them abiding in
10605 the soul, and invisible to any human or divine eye; or shown that of
10606 all the things of a man's soul which he has within him, justice is
10607 the greatest good, and injustice the greatest evil. Had this been the
10608 universal strain, had you sought to persuade us of this from our youth
10609 upwards, we should not have been on the watch to keep one another from
10610 doing wrong, but every one would have been his own watchman, because
10611 afraid, if he did wrong, of harbouring in himself the greatest of
10612 evils. I dare say that Thrasymachus and others would seriously hold the
10613 language which I have been merely repeating, and words even stronger
10614 than these about justice and injustice, grossly, as I conceive,
10615 perverting their true nature. But I speak in this vehement manner, as
10616 I must frankly confess to you, because I want to hear from you the
10617 opposite side; and I would ask you to show not only the superiority
10618 which justice has over injustice, but what effect they have on the
10619 possessor of them which makes the one to be a good and the other an evil
10620 to him. And please, as Glaucon requested of you, to exclude reputations;
10621 for unless you take away from each of them his true reputation and
10622 add on the false, we shall say that you do not praise justice, but the
10623 appearance of it; we shall think that you are only exhorting us to keep
10624 injustice dark, and that you really agree with Thrasymachus in thinking
10625 that justice is another's good and the interest of the stronger, and
10626 that injustice is a man's own profit and interest, though injurious to
10627 the weaker. Now as you have admitted that justice is one of that highest
10628 class of goods which are desired indeed for their results, but in a far
10629 greater degree for their own sakes--like sight or hearing or knowledge
10630 or health, or any other real and natural and not merely conventional
10631 good--I would ask you in your praise of justice to regard one point
10632 only: I mean the essential good and evil which justice and injustice
10633 work in the possessors of them. Let others praise justice and censure
10634 injustice, magnifying the rewards and honours of the one and abusing the
10635 other; that is a manner of arguing which, coming from them, I am
10636 ready to tolerate, but from you who have spent your whole life in the
10637 consideration of this question, unless I hear the contrary from your own
10638 lips, I expect something better. And therefore, I say, not only prove to
10639 us that justice is better than injustice, but show what they either of
10640 them do to the possessor of them, which makes the one to be a good and
10641 the other an evil, whether seen or unseen by gods and men.
10642 
10643 I had always admired the genius of Glaucon and Adeimantus, but on
10644 hearing these words I was quite delighted, and said: Sons of an
10645 illustrious father, that was not a bad beginning of the Elegiac verses
10646 which the admirer of Glaucon made in honour of you after you had
10647 distinguished yourselves at the battle of Megara:--
10648 
10649 'Sons of Ariston,' he sang, 'divine offspring of an illustrious hero.'
10650 
10651 The epithet is very appropriate, for there is something truly divine in
10652 being able to argue as you have done for the superiority of injustice,
10653 and remaining unconvinced by your own arguments. And I do believe that
10654 you are not convinced--this I infer from your general character, for had
10655 I judged only from your speeches I should have mistrusted you. But
10656 now, the greater my confidence in you, the greater is my difficulty in
10657 knowing what to say. For I am in a strait between two; on the one hand I
10658 feel that I am unequal to the task; and my inability is brought home to
10659 me by the fact that you were not satisfied with the answer which I made
10660 to Thrasymachus, proving, as I thought, the superiority which justice
10661 has over injustice. And yet I cannot refuse to help, while breath and
10662 speech remain to me; I am afraid that there would be an impiety in being
10663 present when justice is evil spoken of and not lifting up a hand in her
10664 defence. And therefore I had best give such help as I can.
10665 
10666 Glaucon and the rest entreated me by all means not to let the question
10667 drop, but to proceed in the investigation. They wanted to arrive at the
10668 truth, first, about the nature of justice and injustice, and secondly,
10669 about their relative advantages. I told them, what I really thought,
10670 that the enquiry would be of a serious nature, and would require very
10671 good eyes. Seeing then, I said, that we are no great wits, I think that
10672 we had better adopt a method which I may illustrate thus; suppose that
10673 a short-sighted person had been asked by some one to read small letters
10674 from a distance; and it occurred to some one else that they might be
10675 found in another place which was larger and in which the letters were
10676 larger--if they were the same and he could read the larger letters
10677 first, and then proceed to the lesser--this would have been thought a
10678 rare piece of good fortune.
10679 
10680 Very true, said Adeimantus; but how does the illustration apply to our
10681 enquiry?
10682 
10683 I will tell you, I replied; justice, which is the subject of our
10684 enquiry, is, as you know, sometimes spoken of as the virtue of an
10685 individual, and sometimes as the virtue of a State.
10686 
10687 True, he replied.
10688 
10689 And is not a State larger than an individual?
10690 
10691 It is.
10692 
10693 Then in the larger the quantity of justice is likely to be larger and
10694 more easily discernible. I propose therefore that we enquire into the
10695 nature of justice and injustice, first as they appear in the State, and
10696 secondly in the individual, proceeding from the greater to the lesser
10697 and comparing them.
10698 
10699 That, he said, is an excellent proposal.
10700 
10701 And if we imagine the State in process of creation, we shall see the
10702 justice and injustice of the State in process of creation also.
10703 
10704 I dare say.
10705 
10706 When the State is completed there may be a hope that the object of our
10707 search will be more easily discovered.
10708 
10709 Yes, far more easily.
10710 
10711 But ought we to attempt to construct one? I said; for to do so, as I am
10712 inclined to think, will be a very serious task. Reflect therefore.
10713 
10714 I have reflected, said Adeimantus, and am anxious that you should
10715 proceed.
10716 
10717 A State, I said, arises, as I conceive, out of the needs of mankind;
10718 no one is self-sufficing, but all of us have many wants. Can any other
10719 origin of a State be imagined?
10720 
10721 There can be no other.
10722 
10723 Then, as we have many wants, and many persons are needed to supply them,
10724 one takes a helper for one purpose and another for another; and when
10725 these partners and helpers are gathered together in one habitation the
10726 body of inhabitants is termed a State.
10727 
10728 True, he said.
10729 
10730 And they exchange with one another, and one gives, and another receives,
10731 under the idea that the exchange will be for their good.
10732 
10733 Very true.
10734 
10735 Then, I said, let us begin and create in idea a State; and yet the true
10736 creator is necessity, who is the mother of our invention.
10737 
10738 Of course, he replied.
10739 
10740 Now the first and greatest of necessities is food, which is the
10741 condition of life and existence.
10742 
10743 Certainly.
10744 
10745 The second is a dwelling, and the third clothing and the like.
10746 
10747 True.
10748 
10749 And now let us see how our city will be able to supply this great
10750 demand: We may suppose that one man is a husbandman, another a builder,
10751 some one else a weaver--shall we add to them a shoemaker, or perhaps
10752 some other purveyor to our bodily wants?
10753 
10754 Quite right.
10755 
10756 The barest notion of a State must include four or five men.
10757 
10758 Clearly.
10759 
10760 And how will they proceed? Will each bring the result of his labours
10761 into a common stock?--the individual husbandman, for example, producing
10762 for four, and labouring four times as long and as much as he need in the
10763 provision of food with which he supplies others as well as himself;
10764 or will he have nothing to do with others and not be at the trouble of
10765 producing for them, but provide for himself alone a fourth of the food
10766 in a fourth of the time, and in the remaining three fourths of his time
10767 be employed in making a house or a coat or a pair of shoes, having no
10768 partnership with others, but supplying himself all his own wants?
10769 
10770 Adeimantus thought that he should aim at producing food only and not at
10771 producing everything.
10772 
10773 Probably, I replied, that would be the better way; and when I hear you
10774 say this, I am myself reminded that we are not all alike; there
10775 are diversities of natures among us which are adapted to different
10776 occupations.
10777 
10778 Very true.
10779 
10780 And will you have a work better done when the workman has many
10781 occupations, or when he has only one?
10782 
10783 When he has only one.
10784 
10785 Further, there can be no doubt that a work is spoilt when not done at
10786 the right time?
10787 
10788 No doubt.
10789 
10790 For business is not disposed to wait until the doer of the business is
10791 at leisure; but the doer must follow up what he is doing, and make the
10792 business his first object.
10793 
10794 He must.
10795 
10796 And if so, we must infer that all things are produced more plentifully
10797 and easily and of a better quality when one man does one thing which is
10798 natural to him and does it at the right time, and leaves other things.
10799 
10800 Undoubtedly.
10801 
10802 Then more than four citizens will be required; for the husbandman will
10803 not make his own plough or mattock, or other implements of agriculture,
10804 if they are to be good for anything. Neither will the builder make
10805 his tools--and he too needs many; and in like manner the weaver and
10806 shoemaker.
10807 
10808 True.
10809 
10810 Then carpenters, and smiths, and many other artisans, will be sharers in
10811 our little State, which is already beginning to grow?
10812 
10813 True.
10814 
10815 Yet even if we add neatherds, shepherds, and other herdsmen, in order
10816 that our husbandmen may have oxen to plough with, and builders as well
10817 as husbandmen may have draught cattle, and curriers and weavers fleeces
10818 and hides,--still our State will not be very large.
10819 
10820 That is true; yet neither will it be a very small State which contains
10821 all these.
10822 
10823 Then, again, there is the situation of the city--to find a place where
10824 nothing need be imported is wellnigh impossible.
10825 
10826 Impossible.
10827 
10828 Then there must be another class of citizens who will bring the required
10829 supply from another city?
10830 
10831 There must.
10832 
10833 But if the trader goes empty-handed, having nothing which they require
10834 who would supply his need, he will come back empty-handed.
10835 
10836 That is certain.
10837 
10838 And therefore what they produce at home must be not only enough for
10839 themselves, but such both in quantity and quality as to accommodate
10840 those from whom their wants are supplied.
10841 
10842 Very true.
10843 
10844 Then more husbandmen and more artisans will be required?
10845 
10846 They will.
10847 
10848 Not to mention the importers and exporters, who are called merchants?
10849 
10850 Yes.
10851 
10852 Then we shall want merchants?
10853 
10854 We shall.
10855 
10856 And if merchandise is to be carried over the sea, skilful sailors will
10857 also be needed, and in considerable numbers?
10858 
10859 Yes, in considerable numbers.
10860 
10861 Then, again, within the city, how will they exchange their productions?
10862 To secure such an exchange was, as you will remember, one of our
10863 principal objects when we formed them into a society and constituted a
10864 State.
10865 
10866 Clearly they will buy and sell.
10867 
10868 Then they will need a market-place, and a money-token for purposes of
10869 exchange.
10870 
10871 Certainly.
10872 
10873 Suppose now that a husbandman, or an artisan, brings some production
10874 to market, and he comes at a time when there is no one to exchange with
10875 him,--is he to leave his calling and sit idle in the market-place?
10876 
10877 Not at all; he will find people there who, seeing the want, undertake
10878 the office of salesmen. In well-ordered states they are commonly those
10879 who are the weakest in bodily strength, and therefore of little use for
10880 any other purpose; their duty is to be in the market, and to give money
10881 in exchange for goods to those who desire to sell and to take money from
10882 those who desire to buy.
10883 
10884 This want, then, creates a class of retail-traders in our State. Is
10885 not 'retailer' the term which is applied to those who sit in the
10886 market-place engaged in buying and selling, while those who wander from
10887 one city to another are called merchants?
10888 
10889 Yes, he said.
10890 
10891 And there is another class of servants, who are intellectually hardly
10892 on the level of companionship; still they have plenty of bodily strength
10893 for labour, which accordingly they sell, and are called, if I do not
10894 mistake, hirelings, hire being the name which is given to the price of
10895 their labour.
10896 
10897 True.
10898 
10899 Then hirelings will help to make up our population?
10900 
10901 Yes.
10902 
10903 And now, Adeimantus, is our State matured and perfected?
10904 
10905 I think so.
10906 
10907 Where, then, is justice, and where is injustice, and in what part of the
10908 State did they spring up?
10909 
10910 Probably in the dealings of these citizens with one another. I cannot
10911 imagine that they are more likely to be found any where else.
10912 
10913 I dare say that you are right in your suggestion, I said; we had better
10914 think the matter out, and not shrink from the enquiry.
10915 
10916 Let us then consider, first of all, what will be their way of life,
10917 now that we have thus established them. Will they not produce corn, and
10918 wine, and clothes, and shoes, and build houses for themselves? And
10919 when they are housed, they will work, in summer, commonly, stripped and
10920 barefoot, but in winter substantially clothed and shod. They will feed
10921 on barley-meal and flour of wheat, baking and kneading them, making
10922 noble cakes and loaves; these they will serve up on a mat of reeds or on
10923 clean leaves, themselves reclining the while upon beds strewn with yew
10924 or myrtle. And they and their children will feast, drinking of the wine
10925 which they have made, wearing garlands on their heads, and hymning the
10926 praises of the gods, in happy converse with one another. And they will
10927 take care that their families do not exceed their means; having an eye
10928 to poverty or war.
10929
