10930 But, said Glaucon, interposing, you have not given them a relish to
10931 their meal.
10932 
10933 True, I replied, I had forgotten; of course they must have a
10934 relish--salt, and olives, and cheese, and they will boil roots and herbs
10935 such as country people prepare; for a dessert we shall give them figs,
10936 and peas, and beans; and they will roast myrtle-berries and acorns
10937 at the fire, drinking in moderation. And with such a diet they may be
10938 expected to live in peace and health to a good old age, and bequeath a
10939 similar life to their children after them.
10940 
10941 Yes, Socrates, he said, and if you were providing for a city of pigs,
10942 how else would you feed the beasts?
10943 
10944 But what would you have, Glaucon? I replied.
10945 
10946 Why, he said, you should give them the ordinary conveniences of life.
10947 People who are to be comfortable are accustomed to lie on sofas, and
10948 dine off tables, and they should have sauces and sweets in the modern
10949 style.
10950 
10951 Yes, I said, now I understand: the question which you would have me
10952 consider is, not only how a State, but how a luxurious State is created;
10953 and possibly there is no harm in this, for in such a State we shall be
10954 more likely to see how justice and injustice originate. In my opinion
10955 the true and healthy constitution of the State is the one which I have
10956 described. But if you wish also to see a State at fever-heat, I have
10957 no objection. For I suspect that many will not be satisfied with the
10958 simpler way of life. They will be for adding sofas, and tables,
10959 and other furniture; also dainties, and perfumes, and incense, and
10960 courtesans, and cakes, all these not of one sort only, but in every
10961 variety; we must go beyond the necessaries of which I was at first
10962 speaking, such as houses, and clothes, and shoes: the arts of the
10963 painter and the embroiderer will have to be set in motion, and gold and
10964 ivory and all sorts of materials must be procured.
10965 
10966 True, he said.
10967 
10968 Then we must enlarge our borders; for the original healthy State is
10969 no longer sufficient. Now will the city have to fill and swell with a
10970 multitude of callings which are not required by any natural want; such
10971 as the whole tribe of hunters and actors, of whom one large class
10972 have to do with forms and colours; another will be the votaries of
10973 music--poets and their attendant train of rhapsodists, players, dancers,
10974 contractors; also makers of divers kinds of articles, including women's
10975 dresses. And we shall want more servants. Will not tutors be also in
10976 request, and nurses wet and dry, tirewomen and barbers, as well as
10977 confectioners and cooks; and swineherds, too, who were not needed and
10978 therefore had no place in the former edition of our State, but are
10979 needed now? They must not be forgotten: and there will be animals of
10980 many other kinds, if people eat them.
10981 
10982 Certainly.
10983 
10984 And living in this way we shall have much greater need of physicians
10985 than before?
10986 
10987 Much greater.
10988 
10989 And the country which was enough to support the original inhabitants
10990 will be too small now, and not enough?
10991 
10992 Quite true.
10993 
10994 Then a slice of our neighbours' land will be wanted by us for pasture
10995 and tillage, and they will want a slice of ours, if, like ourselves,
10996 they exceed the limit of necessity, and give themselves up to the
10997 unlimited accumulation of wealth?
10998 
10999 That, Socrates, will be inevitable.
11000 
11001 And so we shall go to war, Glaucon. Shall we not?
11002 
11003 Most certainly, he replied.
11004 
11005 Then without determining as yet whether war does good or harm, thus much
11006 we may affirm, that now we have discovered war to be derived from causes
11007 which are also the causes of almost all the evils in States, private as
11008 well as public.
11009 
11010 Undoubtedly.
11011 
11012 And our State must once more enlarge; and this time the enlargement will
11013 be nothing short of a whole army, which will have to go out and fight
11014 with the invaders for all that we have, as well as for the things and
11015 persons whom we were describing above.
11016 
11017 Why? he said; are they not capable of defending themselves?
11018 
11019 No, I said; not if we were right in the principle which was acknowledged
11020 by all of us when we were framing the State: the principle, as you will
11021 remember, was that one man cannot practise many arts with success.
11022 
11023 Very true, he said.
11024 
11025 But is not war an art?
11026 
11027 Certainly.
11028 
11029 And an art requiring as much attention as shoemaking?
11030 
11031 Quite true.
11032 
11033 And the shoemaker was not allowed by us to be a husbandman, or a weaver,
11034 or a builder--in order that we might have our shoes well made; but to
11035 him and to every other worker was assigned one work for which he was by
11036 nature fitted, and at that he was to continue working all his life long
11037 and at no other; he was not to let opportunities slip, and then he would
11038 become a good workman. Now nothing can be more important than that
11039 the work of a soldier should be well done. But is war an art so easily
11040 acquired that a man may be a warrior who is also a husbandman, or
11041 shoemaker, or other artisan; although no one in the world would be a
11042 good dice or draught player who merely took up the game as a recreation,
11043 and had not from his earliest years devoted himself to this and nothing
11044 else? No tools will make a man a skilled workman, or master of defence,
11045 nor be of any use to him who has not learned how to handle them, and has
11046 never bestowed any attention upon them. How then will he who takes up
11047 a shield or other implement of war become a good fighter all in a day,
11048 whether with heavy-armed or any other kind of troops?
11049 
11050 Yes, he said, the tools which would teach men their own use would be
11051 beyond price.
11052 
11053 And the higher the duties of the guardian, I said, the more time, and
11054 skill, and art, and application will be needed by him?
11055 
11056 No doubt, he replied.
11057 
11058 Will he not also require natural aptitude for his calling?
11059 
11060 Certainly.
11061 
11062 Then it will be our duty to select, if we can, natures which are fitted
11063 for the task of guarding the city?
11064 
11065 It will.
11066 
11067 And the selection will be no easy matter, I said; but we must be brave
11068 and do our best.
11069 
11070 We must.
11071 
11072 Is not the noble youth very like a well-bred dog in respect of guarding
11073 and watching?
11074 
11075 What do you mean?
11076 
11077 I mean that both of them ought to be quick to see, and swift to overtake
11078 the enemy when they see him; and strong too if, when they have caught
11079 him, they have to fight with him.
11080 
11081 All these qualities, he replied, will certainly be required by them.
11082 
11083 Well, and your guardian must be brave if he is to fight well?
11084 
11085 Certainly.
11086 
11087 And is he likely to be brave who has no spirit, whether horse or dog
11088 or any other animal? Have you never observed how invincible and
11089 unconquerable is spirit and how the presence of it makes the soul of any
11090 creature to be absolutely fearless and indomitable?
11091 
11092 I have.
11093 
11094 Then now we have a clear notion of the bodily qualities which are
11095 required in the guardian.
11096 
11097 True.
11098 
11099 And also of the mental ones; his soul is to be full of spirit?
11100 
11101 Yes.
11102 
11103 But are not these spirited natures apt to be savage with one another,
11104 and with everybody else?
11105 
11106 A difficulty by no means easy to overcome, he replied.
11107 
11108 Whereas, I said, they ought to be dangerous to their enemies, and gentle
11109 to their friends; if not, they will destroy themselves without waiting
11110 for their enemies to destroy them.
11111 
11112 True, he said.
11113 
11114 What is to be done then? I said; how shall we find a gentle nature which
11115 has also a great spirit, for the one is the contradiction of the other?
11116 
11117 True.
11118 
11119 He will not be a good guardian who is wanting in either of these two
11120 qualities; and yet the combination of them appears to be impossible; and
11121 hence we must infer that to be a good guardian is impossible.
11122 
11123 I am afraid that what you say is true, he replied.
11124 
11125 Here feeling perplexed I began to think over what had preceded.--My
11126 friend, I said, no wonder that we are in a perplexity; for we have lost
11127 sight of the image which we had before us.
11128 
11129 What do you mean? he said.
11130 
11131 I mean to say that there do exist natures gifted with those opposite
11132 qualities.
11133 
11134 And where do you find them?
11135 
11136 Many animals, I replied, furnish examples of them; our friend the dog
11137 is a very good one: you know that well-bred dogs are perfectly gentle to
11138 their familiars and acquaintances, and the reverse to strangers.
11139 
11140 Yes, I know.
11141 
11142 Then there is nothing impossible or out of the order of nature in our
11143 finding a guardian who has a similar combination of qualities?
11144 
11145 Certainly not.
11146 
11147 Would not he who is fitted to be a guardian, besides the spirited
11148 nature, need to have the qualities of a philosopher?
11149 
11150 I do not apprehend your meaning.
11151 
11152 The trait of which I am speaking, I replied, may be also seen in the
11153 dog, and is remarkable in the animal.
11154 
11155 What trait?
11156 
11157 Why, a dog, whenever he sees a stranger, is angry; when an acquaintance,
11158 he welcomes him, although the one has never done him any harm, nor the
11159 other any good. Did this never strike you as curious?
11160 
11161 The matter never struck me before; but I quite recognise the truth of
11162 your remark.
11163 
11164 And surely this instinct of the dog is very charming;--your dog is a
11165 true philosopher.
11166 
11167 Why?
11168 
11169 Why, because he distinguishes the face of a friend and of an enemy only
11170 by the criterion of knowing and not knowing. And must not an animal be a
11171 lover of learning who determines what he likes and dislikes by the test
11172 of knowledge and ignorance?
11173 
11174 Most assuredly.
11175 
11176 And is not the love of learning the love of wisdom, which is philosophy?
11177 
11178 They are the same, he replied.
11179 
11180 And may we not say confidently of man also, that he who is likely to be
11181 gentle to his friends and acquaintances, must by nature be a lover of
11182 wisdom and knowledge?
11183 
11184 That we may safely affirm.
11185 
11186 Then he who is to be a really good and noble guardian of the State will
11187 require to unite in himself philosophy and spirit and swiftness and
11188 strength?
11189 
11190 Undoubtedly.
11191 
11192 Then we have found the desired natures; and now that we have found them,
11193 how are they to be reared and educated? Is not this an enquiry which
11194 may be expected to throw light on the greater enquiry which is our final
11195 end--How do justice and injustice grow up in States? for we do not want
11196 either to omit what is to the point or to draw out the argument to an
11197 inconvenient length.
11198 
11199 Adeimantus thought that the enquiry would be of great service to us.
11200 
11201 Then, I said, my dear friend, the task must not be given up, even if
11202 somewhat long.
11203 
11204 Certainly not.
11205 
11206 Come then, and let us pass a leisure hour in story-telling, and our
11207 story shall be the education of our heroes.
11208 
11209 By all means.
11210 
11211 And what shall be their education? Can we find a better than the
11212 traditional sort?--and this has two divisions, gymnastic for the body,
11213 and music for the soul.
11214 
11215 True.
11216 
11217 Shall we begin education with music, and go on to gymnastic afterwards?
11218 
11219 By all means.
11220 
11221 And when you speak of music, do you include literature or not?
11222 
11223 I do.
11224 
11225 And literature may be either true or false?
11226 
11227 Yes.
11228 
11229 And the young should be trained in both kinds, and we begin with the
11230 false?
11231 
11232 I do not understand your meaning, he said.
11233 
11234 You know, I said, that we begin by telling children stories which,
11235 though not wholly destitute of truth, are in the main fictitious;
11236 and these stories are told them when they are not of an age to learn
11237 gymnastics.
11238 
11239 Very true.
11240 
11241 That was my meaning when I said that we must teach music before
11242 gymnastics.
11243 
11244 Quite right, he said.
11245 
11246 You know also that the beginning is the most important part of any work,
11247 especially in the case of a young and tender thing; for that is the time
11248 at which the character is being formed and the desired impression is
11249 more readily taken.
11250 
11251 Quite true.
11252 
11253 And shall we just carelessly allow children to hear any casual tales
11254 which may be devised by casual persons, and to receive into their minds
11255 ideas for the most part the very opposite of those which we should wish
11256 them to have when they are grown up?
11257 
11258 We cannot.
11259 
11260 Then the first thing will be to establish a censorship of the writers of
11261 fiction, and let the censors receive any tale of fiction which is good,
11262 and reject the bad; and we will desire mothers and nurses to tell their
11263 children the authorised ones only. Let them fashion the mind with such
11264 tales, even more fondly than they mould the body with their hands; but
11265 most of those which are now in use must be discarded.
11266 
11267 Of what tales are you speaking? he said.
11268 
11269 You may find a model of the lesser in the greater, I said; for they are
11270 necessarily of the same type, and there is the same spirit in both of
11271 them.
11272 
11273 Very likely, he replied; but I do not as yet know what you would term
11274 the greater.
11275 
11276 Those, I said, which are narrated by Homer and Hesiod, and the rest of
11277 the poets, who have ever been the great story-tellers of mankind.
11278 
11279 But which stories do you mean, he said; and what fault do you find with
11280 them?
11281 
11282 A fault which is most serious, I said; the fault of telling a lie, and,
11283 what is more, a bad lie.
11284 
11285 But when is this fault committed?
11286 
11287 Whenever an erroneous representation is made of the nature of gods and
11288 heroes,--as when a painter paints a portrait not having the shadow of a
11289 likeness to the original.
11290 
11291 Yes, he said, that sort of thing is certainly very blameable; but what
11292 are the stories which you mean?
11293 
11294 First of all, I said, there was that greatest of all lies in high
11295 places, which the poet told about Uranus, and which was a bad lie
11296 too,--I mean what Hesiod says that Uranus did, and how Cronus retaliated
11297 on him. The doings of Cronus, and the sufferings which in turn his son
11298 inflicted upon him, even if they were true, ought certainly not to be
11299 lightly told to young and thoughtless persons; if possible, they had
11300 better be buried in silence. But if there is an absolute necessity
11301 for their mention, a chosen few might hear them in a mystery, and
11302 they should sacrifice not a common (Eleusinian) pig, but some huge and
11303 unprocurable victim; and then the number of the hearers will be very few
11304 indeed.
11305 
11306 Why, yes, said he, those stories are extremely objectionable.
11307 
11308 Yes, Adeimantus, they are stories not to be repeated in our State; the
11309 young man should not be told that in committing the worst of crimes he
11310 is far from doing anything outrageous; and that even if he chastises his
11311 father when he does wrong, in whatever manner, he will only be following
11312 the example of the first and greatest among the gods.
11313 
11314 I entirely agree with you, he said; in my opinion those stories are
11315 quite unfit to be repeated.
11316 
11317 Neither, if we mean our future guardians to regard the habit of
11318 quarrelling among themselves as of all things the basest, should
11319 any word be said to them of the wars in heaven, and of the plots and
11320 fightings of the gods against one another, for they are not true. No,
11321 we shall never mention the battles of the giants, or let them be
11322 embroidered on garments; and we shall be silent about the innumerable
11323 other quarrels of gods and heroes with their friends and relatives.
11324 If they would only believe us we would tell them that quarrelling
11325 is unholy, and that never up to this time has there been any quarrel
11326 between citizens; this is what old men and old women should begin by
11327 telling children; and when they grow up, the poets also should be told
11328 to compose for them in a similar spirit. But the narrative of Hephaestus
11329 binding Here his mother, or how on another occasion Zeus sent him flying
11330 for taking her part when she was being beaten, and all the battles of
11331 the gods in Homer--these tales must not be admitted into our State,
11332 whether they are supposed to have an allegorical meaning or not. For
11333 a young person cannot judge what is allegorical and what is literal;
11334 anything that he receives into his mind at that age is likely to become
11335 indelible and unalterable; and therefore it is most important that the
11336 tales which the young first hear should be models of virtuous thoughts.
11337 
11338 There you are right, he replied; but if any one asks where are such
11339 models to be found and of what tales are you speaking--how shall we
11340 answer him?
11341 
11342 I said to him, You and I, Adeimantus, at this moment are not poets,
11343 but founders of a State: now the founders of a State ought to know the
11344 general forms in which poets should cast their tales, and the limits
11345 which must be observed by them, but to make the tales is not their
11346 business.
11347 
11348 Very true, he said; but what are these forms of theology which you mean?
11349 
11350 Something of this kind, I replied:--God is always to be represented as
11351 he truly is, whatever be the sort of poetry, epic, lyric or tragic, in
11352 which the representation is given.
11353 
11354 Right.
11355 
11356 And is he not truly good? and must he not be represented as such?
11357 
11358 Certainly.
11359 
11360 And no good thing is hurtful?
11361 
11362 No, indeed.
11363 
11364 And that which is not hurtful hurts not?
11365 
11366 Certainly not.
11367 
11368 And that which hurts not does no evil?
11369 
11370 No.
11371 
11372 And can that which does no evil be a cause of evil?
11373 
11374 Impossible.
11375 
11376 And the good is advantageous?
11377 
11378 Yes.
11379 
11380 And therefore the cause of well-being?
11381 
11382 Yes.
11383 
11384 It follows therefore that the good is not the cause of all things, but
11385 of the good only?
11386 
11387 Assuredly.
11388 
11389 Then God, if he be good, is not the author of all things, as the many
11390 assert, but he is the cause of a few things only, and not of most things
11391 that occur to men. For few are the goods of human life, and many are the
11392 evils, and the good is to be attributed to God alone; of the evils the
11393 causes are to be sought elsewhere, and not in him.
11394 
11395 That appears to me to be most true, he said.
11396 
11397 Then we must not listen to Homer or to any other poet who is guilty of
11398 the folly of saying that two casks
11399 
11400 'Lie at the threshold of Zeus, full of lots, one of good, the other of
11401 evil lots,'
11402 
11403 and that he to whom Zeus gives a mixture of the two
11404 
11405 'Sometimes meets with evil fortune, at other times with good;'
11406 
11407 but that he to whom is given the cup of unmingled ill,
11408 
11409 'Him wild hunger drives o'er the beauteous earth.'
11410 
11411 And again--
11412 
11413 'Zeus, who is the dispenser of good and evil to us.'
11414 
11415 And if any one asserts that the violation of oaths and treaties, which
11416 was really the work of Pandarus, was brought about by Athene and Zeus,
11417 or that the strife and contention of the gods was instigated by Themis
11418 and Zeus, he shall not have our approval; neither will we allow our
11419 young men to hear the words of Aeschylus, that
11420 
11421 'God plants guilt among men when he desires utterly to destroy a house.'
11422 
11423 And if a poet writes of the sufferings of Niobe--the subject of the
11424 tragedy in which these iambic verses occur--or of the house of Pelops,
11425 or of the Trojan war or on any similar theme, either we must not permit
11426 him to say that these are the works of God, or if they are of God, he
11427 must devise some explanation of them such as we are seeking; he must say
11428 that God did what was just and right, and they were the better for being
11429 punished; but that those who are punished are miserable, and that God
11430 is the author of their misery--the poet is not to be permitted to say;
11431 though he may say that the wicked are miserable because they require
11432 to be punished, and are benefited by receiving punishment from God;
11433 but that God being good is the author of evil to any one is to be
11434 strenuously denied, and not to be said or sung or heard in verse or
11435 prose by any one whether old or young in any well-ordered commonwealth.
11436 Such a fiction is suicidal, ruinous, impious.
11437 
11438 I agree with you, he replied, and am ready to give my assent to the law.
11439 
11440 Let this then be one of our rules and principles concerning the gods, to
11441 which our poets and reciters will be expected to conform,--that God is
11442 not the author of all things, but of good only.
11443 
11444 That will do, he said.
11445 
11446 And what do you think of a second principle? Shall I ask you whether God
11447 is a magician, and of a nature to appear insidiously now in one shape,
11448 and now in another--sometimes himself changing and passing into
11449 many forms, sometimes deceiving us with the semblance of such
11450 transformations; or is he one and the same immutably fixed in his own
11451 proper image?
11452 
11453 I cannot answer you, he said, without more thought.
11454 
11455 Well, I said; but if we suppose a change in anything, that change must
11456 be effected either by the thing itself, or by some other thing?
11457 
11458 Most certainly.
11459 
11460 And things which are at their best are also least liable to be altered
11461 or discomposed; for example, when healthiest and strongest, the human
11462 frame is least liable to be affected by meats and drinks, and the plant
11463 which is in the fullest vigour also suffers least from winds or the heat
11464 of the sun or any similar causes.
11465 
11466 Of course.
11467 
11468 And will not the bravest and wisest soul be least confused or deranged
11469 by any external influence?
11470 
11471 True.
11472 
11473 And the same principle, as I should suppose, applies to all composite
11474 things--furniture, houses, garments: when good and well made, they are
11475 least altered by time and circumstances.
11476 
11477 Very true.
11478 
11479 Then everything which is good, whether made by art or nature, or both,
11480 is least liable to suffer change from without?
11481 
11482 True.
11483 
11484 But surely God and the things of God are in every way perfect?
11485 
11486 Of course they are.
11487 
11488 Then he can hardly be compelled by external influence to take many
11489 shapes?
11490 
11491 He cannot.
11492 
11493 But may he not change and transform himself?
11494 
11495 Clearly, he said, that must be the case if he is changed at all.
11496 
11497 And will he then change himself for the better and fairer, or for the
11498 worse and more unsightly?
11499 
11500 If he change at all he can only change for the worse, for we cannot
11501 suppose him to be deficient either in virtue or beauty.
11502 
11503 Very true, Adeimantus; but then, would any one, whether God or man,
11504 desire to make himself worse?
11505 
11506 Impossible.
11507 
11508 Then it is impossible that God should ever be willing to change; being,
11509 as is supposed, the fairest and best that is conceivable, every God
11510 remains absolutely and for ever in his own form.
11511 
11512 That necessarily follows, he said, in my judgment.
11513 
11514 Then, I said, my dear friend, let none of the poets tell us that
11515 
11516 'The gods, taking the disguise of strangers from other lands, walk up
11517 and down cities in all sorts of forms;'
11518 
11519 and let no one slander Proteus and Thetis, neither let any one, either
11520 in tragedy or in any other kind of poetry, introduce Here disguised in
11521 the likeness of a priestess asking an alms
11522 
11523 'For the life-giving daughters of Inachus the river of Argos;'
11524 
11525 --let us have no more lies of that sort. Neither must we have mothers
11526 under the influence of the poets scaring their children with a bad
11527 version of these myths--telling how certain gods, as they say, 'Go about
11528 by night in the likeness of so many strangers and in divers forms;' but
11529 let them take heed lest they make cowards of their children, and at the
11530 same time speak blasphemy against the gods.
11531 
11532 Heaven forbid, he said.
11533 
11534 But although the gods are themselves unchangeable, still by witchcraft
11535 and deception they may make us think that they appear in various forms?
11536 
11537 Perhaps, he replied.
11538 
11539 Well, but can you imagine that God will be willing to lie, whether in
11540 word or deed, or to put forth a phantom of himself?
11541 
11542 I cannot say, he replied.
11543 
11544 Do you not know, I said, that the true lie, if such an expression may be
11545 allowed, is hated of gods and men?
11546 
11547 What do you mean? he said.
11548 
11549 I mean that no one is willingly deceived in that which is the truest and
11550 highest part of himself, or about the truest and highest matters; there,
11551 above all, he is most afraid of a lie having possession of him.
11552 
11553 Still, he said, I do not comprehend you.
11554 
11555 The reason is, I replied, that you attribute some profound meaning to
11556 my words; but I am only saying that deception, or being deceived
11557 or uninformed about the highest realities in the highest part of
11558 themselves, which is the soul, and in that part of them to have and to
11559 hold the lie, is what mankind least like;--that, I say, is what they
11560 utterly detest.
11561 
11562 There is nothing more hateful to them.
11563 
11564 And, as I was just now remarking, this ignorance in the soul of him who
11565 is deceived may be called the true lie; for the lie in words is only a
11566 kind of imitation and shadowy image of a previous affection of the soul,
11567 not pure unadulterated falsehood. Am I not right?
11568 
11569 Perfectly right.
11570 
11571 The true lie is hated not only by the gods, but also by men?
11572 
11573 Yes.
11574 
11575 Whereas the lie in words is in certain cases useful and not hateful; in
11576 dealing with enemies--that would be an instance; or again, when those
11577 whom we call our friends in a fit of madness or illusion are going to
11578 do some harm, then it is useful and is a sort of medicine or
11579 preventive; also in the tales of mythology, of which we were just now
11580 speaking--because we do not know the truth about ancient times, we make
11581 falsehood as much like truth as we can, and so turn it to account.
11582 
11583 Very true, he said.
11584 
11585 But can any of these reasons apply to God? Can we suppose that he is
11586 ignorant of antiquity, and therefore has recourse to invention?
11587 
11588 That would be ridiculous, he said.
11589 
11590 Then the lying poet has no place in our idea of God?
11591 
11592 I should say not.
11593 
11594 Or perhaps he may tell a lie because he is afraid of enemies?
11595 
11596 That is inconceivable.
11597 
11598 But he may have friends who are senseless or mad?
11599 
11600 But no mad or senseless person can be a friend of God.
11601 
11602 Then no motive can be imagined why God should lie?
11603 
11604 None whatever.
11605 
11606 Then the superhuman and divine is absolutely incapable of falsehood?
11607 
11608 Yes.
11609 
11610 Then is God perfectly simple and true both in word and deed; he changes
11611 not; he deceives not, either by sign or word, by dream or waking vision.
11612 
11613 Your thoughts, he said, are the reflection of my own.
11614 
11615 You agree with me then, I said, that this is the second type or form in
11616 which we should write and speak about divine things. The gods are not
11617 magicians who transform themselves, neither do they deceive mankind in
11618 any way.
11619 
11620 I grant that.
11621 
11622 Then, although we are admirers of Homer, we do not admire the lying
11623 dream which Zeus sends to Agamemnon; neither will we praise the verses
11624 of Aeschylus in which Thetis says that Apollo at her nuptials
11625 
11626 'Was celebrating in song her fair progeny whose days were to be long,
11627 and to know no sickness. And when he had spoken of my lot as in all
11628 things blessed of heaven he raised a note of triumph and cheered my
11629 soul. And I thought that the word of Phoebus, being divine and full of
11630 prophecy, would not fail. And now he himself who uttered the strain,
11631 he who was present at the banquet, and who said this--he it is who has
11632 slain my son.'
11633 
11634 These are the kind of sentiments about the gods which will arouse our
11635 anger; and he who utters them shall be refused a chorus; neither shall
11636 we allow teachers to make use of them in the instruction of the young,
11637 meaning, as we do, that our guardians, as far as men can be, should be
11638 true worshippers of the gods and like them.
11639 
11640 I entirely agree, he said, in these principles, and promise to make them
11641 my laws.
11642 
11643 
11644 
11645 
11646 BOOK III.
11647 
11648 Such then, I said, are our principles of theology--some tales are to be
11649 told, and others are not to be told to our disciples from their youth
11650 upwards, if we mean them to honour the gods and their parents, and to
11651 value friendship with one another.
11652 
11653 Yes; and I think that our principles are right, he said.
11654 
11655 But if they are to be courageous, must they not learn other lessons
11656 besides these, and lessons of such a kind as will take away the fear of
11657 death? Can any man be courageous who has the fear of death in him?
11658 
11659 Certainly not, he said.
11660 
11661 And can he be fearless of death, or will he choose death in battle
11662 rather than defeat and slavery, who believes the world below to be real
11663 and terrible?
11664 
11665 Impossible.
11666 
11667 Then we must assume a control over the narrators of this class of tales
11668 as well as over the others, and beg them not simply to revile but rather
11669 to commend the world below, intimating to them that their descriptions
11670 are untrue, and will do harm to our future warriors.
11671 
11672 That will be our duty, he said.
11673 
11674 Then, I said, we shall have to obliterate many obnoxious passages,
11675 beginning with the verses,
11676 
11677 'I would rather be a serf on the land of a poor and portionless man than
11678 rule over all the dead who have come to nought.'
11679 
11680 We must also expunge the verse, which tells us how Pluto feared,
11681 
11682 'Lest the mansions grim and squalid which the gods abhor should be seen
11683 both of mortals and immortals.'
11684 
11685 And again:--
11686 
11687 'O heavens! verily in the house of Hades there is soul and ghostly form
11688 but no mind at all!'
11689 
11690 Again of Tiresias:--
11691 
11692 '(To him even after death did Persephone grant mind,) that he alone
11693 should be wise; but the other souls are flitting shades.'
11694 
11695 Again:--
11696 
11697 'The soul flying from the limbs had gone to Hades, lamenting her fate,
11698 leaving manhood and youth.'
11699 
11700 Again:--
11701 
11702 'And the soul, with shrilling cry, passed like smoke beneath the earth.'
11703 
11704 And,--
11705 
11706 'As bats in hollow of mystic cavern, whenever any of them has dropped
11707 out of the string and falls from the rock, fly shrilling and cling
11708 to one another, so did they with shrilling cry hold together as they
11709 moved.'
11710 
11711 And we must beg Homer and the other poets not to be angry if we strike
11712 out these and similar passages, not because they are unpoetical, or
11713 unattractive to the popular ear, but because the greater the poetical
11714 charm of them, the less are they meet for the ears of boys and men who
11715 are meant to be free, and who should fear slavery more than death.
11716 
11717 Undoubtedly.
11718 
11719 Also we shall have to reject all the terrible and appalling names which
11720 describe the world below--Cocytus and Styx, ghosts under the earth, and
11721 sapless shades, and any similar words of which the very mention causes a
11722 shudder to pass through the inmost soul of him who hears them. I do not
11723 say that these horrible stories may not have a use of some kind; but
11724 there is a danger that the nerves of our guardians may be rendered too
11725 excitable and effeminate by them.
11726 
11727 There is a real danger, he said.
11728 
11729 Then we must have no more of them.
11730 
11731 True.
11732 
11733 Another and a nobler strain must be composed and sung by us.
11734 
11735 Clearly.
11736 
11737 And shall we proceed to get rid of the weepings and wailings of famous
11738 men?
11739 
11740 They will go with the rest.
11741 
11742 But shall we be right in getting rid of them? Reflect: our principle is
11743 that the good man will not consider death terrible to any other good man
11744 who is his comrade.
11745 
11746 Yes; that is our principle.
11747 
11748 And therefore he will not sorrow for his departed friend as though he
11749 had suffered anything terrible?
11750 
11751 He will not.
11752 
11753 Such an one, as we further maintain, is sufficient for himself and his
11754 own happiness, and therefore is least in need of other men.
11755 
11756 True, he said.
11757 
11758 And for this reason the loss of a son or brother, or the deprivation of
11759 fortune, is to him of all men least terrible.
11760 
11761 Assuredly.
11762 
11763 And therefore he will be least likely to lament, and will bear with the
11764 greatest equanimity any misfortune of this sort which may befall him.
11765 
11766 Yes, he will feel such a misfortune far less than another.
11767 
11768 Then we shall be right in getting rid of the lamentations of famous men,
11769 and making them over to women (and not even to women who are good for
11770 anything), or to men of a baser sort, that those who are being educated
11771 by us to be the defenders of their country may scorn to do the like.
11772 
11773 That will be very right.
11774 
11775 Then we will once more entreat Homer and the other poets not to depict
11776 Achilles, who is the son of a goddess, first lying on his side, then on
11777 his back, and then on his face; then starting up and sailing in a frenzy
11778 along the shores of the barren sea; now taking the sooty ashes in both
11779 his hands and pouring them over his head, or weeping and wailing in the
11780 various modes which Homer has delineated. Nor should he describe Priam
11781 the kinsman of the gods as praying and beseeching,
11782 
11783 'Rolling in the dirt, calling each man loudly by his name.'
11784 
11785 Still more earnestly will we beg of him at all events not to introduce
11786 the gods lamenting and saying,
11787 
11788 'Alas! my misery! Alas! that I bore the bravest to my sorrow.'
11789 
11790 But if he must introduce the gods, at any rate let him not dare so
11791 completely to misrepresent the greatest of the gods, as to make him
11792 say--
11793 
11794 'O heavens! with my eyes verily I behold a dear friend of mine chased
11795 round and round the city, and my heart is sorrowful.'
11796 
11797 Or again:--
11798 
11799 Woe is me that I am fated to have Sarpedon, dearest of men to me,
11800 subdued at the hands of Patroclus the son of Menoetius.'
11801 
11802 For if, my sweet Adeimantus, our youth seriously listen to such unworthy
11803 representations of the gods, instead of laughing at them as they ought,
11804 hardly will any of them deem that he himself, being but a man, can be
11805 dishonoured by similar actions; neither will he rebuke any inclination
11806 which may arise in his mind to say and do the like. And instead
11807 of having any shame or self-control, he will be always whining and
11808 lamenting on slight occasions.
11809 
11810 Yes, he said, that is most true.
11811 
11812 Yes, I replied; but that surely is what ought not to be, as the argument
11813 has just proved to us; and by that proof we must abide until it is
11814 disproved by a better.
11815 
11816 It ought not to be.
11817 
11818 Neither ought our guardians to be given to laughter. For a fit of
11819 laughter which has been indulged to excess almost always produces a
11820 violent reaction.
11821 
11822 So I believe.
11823 
11824 Then persons of worth, even if only mortal men, must not be represented
11825 as overcome by laughter, and still less must such a representation of
11826 the gods be allowed.
11827 
11828 Still less of the gods, as you say, he replied.
11829 
11830 Then we shall not suffer such an expression to be used about the gods as
11831 that of Homer when he describes how
11832 
11833 'Inextinguishable laughter arose among the blessed gods, when they saw
11834 Hephaestus bustling about the mansion.'
11835 
11836 On your views, we must not admit them.
11837 
11838 On my views, if you like to father them on me; that we must not admit
11839 them is certain.
11840 
11841 Again, truth should be highly valued; if, as we were saying, a lie is
11842 useless to the gods, and useful only as a medicine to men, then the
11843 use of such medicines should be restricted to physicians; private
11844 individuals have no business with them.
11845 
11846 Clearly not, he said.
11847 
11848 Then if any one at all is to have the privilege of lying, the rulers of
11849 the State should be the persons; and they, in their dealings either with
11850 enemies or with their own citizens, may be allowed to lie for the public
11851 good. But nobody else should meddle with anything of the kind; and
11852 although the rulers have this privilege, for a private man to lie to
11853 them in return is to be deemed a more heinous fault than for the patient
11854 or the pupil of a gymnasium not to speak the truth about his own bodily
11855 illnesses to the physician or to the trainer, or for a sailor not to
11856 tell the captain what is happening about the ship and the rest of the
11857 crew, and how things are going with himself or his fellow sailors.
11858 
11859 Most true, he said.
11860 
11861 If, then, the ruler catches anybody beside himself lying in the State,
11862 
11863 'Any of the craftsmen, whether he be priest or physician or carpenter,'
11864 
11865 he will punish him for introducing a practice which is equally
11866 subversive and destructive of ship or State.
11867 
11868 Most certainly, he said, if our idea of the State is ever carried out.
11869 
11870 In the next place our youth must be temperate?
11871 
11872 Certainly.
11873 
11874 Are not the chief elements of temperance, speaking generally, obedience
11875 to commanders and self-control in sensual pleasures?
11876 
11877 True.
11878 
11879 Then we shall approve such language as that of Diomede in Homer,
11880 
11881 'Friend, sit still and obey my word,'
11882 
11883 and the verses which follow,
11884 
11885 'The Greeks marched breathing prowess, ...in silent awe of their
11886 leaders,'
11887 
11888 and other sentiments of the same kind.
11889 
11890 We shall.
11891 
11892 What of this line,
11893 
11894 'O heavy with wine, who hast the eyes of a dog and the heart of a stag,'
11895 
11896 and of the words which follow? Would you say that these, or any similar
11897 impertinences which private individuals are supposed to address to their
11898 rulers, whether in verse or prose, are well or ill spoken?
11899 
11900 They are ill spoken.
11901 
11902 They may very possibly afford some amusement, but they do not conduce
11903 to temperance. And therefore they are likely to do harm to our young
11904 men--you would agree with me there?
11905 
11906 Yes.
11907 
11908 And then, again, to make the wisest of men say that nothing in his
11909 opinion is more glorious than
11910 
11911 'When the tables are full of bread and meat, and the cup-bearer carries
11912 round wine which he draws from the bowl and pours into the cups,'
11913 
11914 is it fit or conducive to temperance for a young man to hear such words?
11915 Or the verse
11916 
11917 'The saddest of fates is to die and meet destiny from hunger?'
11918 
11919 What would you say again to the tale of Zeus, who, while other gods and
11920 men were asleep and he the only person awake, lay devising plans, but
11921 forgot them all in a moment through his lust, and was so completely
11922 overcome at the sight of Here that he would not even go into the hut,
11923 but wanted to lie with her on the ground, declaring that he had never
11924 been in such a state of rapture before, even when they first met one
11925 another
11926 
11927 'Without the knowledge of their parents;'
11928 
11929 or that other tale of how Hephaestus, because of similar goings on, cast
11930 a chain around Ares and Aphrodite?
11931 
11932 Indeed, he said, I am strongly of opinion that they ought not to hear
11933 that sort of thing.
11934 
11935 But any deeds of endurance which are done or told by famous men, these
11936 they ought to see and hear; as, for example, what is said in the verses,
11937 
11938 'He smote his breast, and thus reproached his heart, Endure, my heart;
11939 far worse hast thou endured!'
11940 
11941 Certainly, he said.
11942 
11943 In the next place, we must not let them be receivers of gifts or lovers
11944 of money.
11945 
11946 Certainly not.
11947 
11948 Neither must we sing to them of
11949 
11950 'Gifts persuading gods, and persuading reverend kings.'
11951 
11952 Neither is Phoenix, the tutor of Achilles, to be approved or deemed to
11953 have given his pupil good counsel when he told him that he should take
11954 the gifts of the Greeks and assist them; but that without a gift he
11955 should not lay aside his anger. Neither will we believe or acknowledge
11956 Achilles himself to have been such a lover of money that he took
11957 Agamemnon's gifts, or that when he had received payment he restored the
11958 dead body of Hector, but that without payment he was unwilling to do so.
11959 
11960 Undoubtedly, he said, these are not sentiments which can be approved.
11961 
11962 Loving Homer as I do, I hardly like to say that in attributing these
11963 feelings to Achilles, or in believing that they are truly attributed
11964 to him, he is guilty of downright impiety. As little can I believe the
11965 narrative of his insolence to Apollo, where he says,
11966 
11967 'Thou hast wronged me, O far-darter, most abominable of deities. Verily
11968 I would be even with thee, if I had only the power;'
11969 
11970 or his insubordination to the river-god, on whose divinity he is ready
11971 to lay hands; or his offering to the dead Patroclus of his own hair,
11972 which had been previously dedicated to the other river-god Spercheius,
11973 and that he actually performed this vow; or that he dragged Hector round
11974 the tomb of Patroclus, and slaughtered the captives at the pyre; of all
11975 this I cannot believe that he was guilty, any more than I can allow
11976 our citizens to believe that he, the wise Cheiron's pupil, the son of a
11977 goddess and of Peleus who was the gentlest of men and third in descent
11978 from Zeus, was so disordered in his wits as to be at one time the slave
11979 of two seemingly inconsistent passions, meanness, not untainted by
11980 avarice, combined with overweening contempt of gods and men.
11981 
11982 You are quite right, he replied.
11983 
11984 And let us equally refuse to believe, or allow to be repeated, the tale
11985 of Theseus son of Poseidon, or of Peirithous son of Zeus, going forth as
11986 they did to perpetrate a horrid rape; or of any other hero or son of
11987 a god daring to do such impious and dreadful things as they falsely
11988 ascribe to them in our day: and let us further compel the poets to
11989 declare either that these acts were not done by them, or that they
11990 were not the sons of gods;--both in the same breath they shall not be
11991 permitted to affirm. We will not have them trying to persuade our youth
11992 that the gods are the authors of evil, and that heroes are no better
11993 than men--sentiments which, as we were saying, are neither pious nor
11994 true, for we have already proved that evil cannot come from the gods.
11995 
11996 Assuredly not.
11997 
11998 And further they are likely to have a bad effect on those who hear them;
11999 for everybody will begin to excuse his own vices when he is convinced
12000 that similar wickednesses are always being perpetrated by--
12001 
12002 'The kindred of the gods, the relatives of Zeus, whose ancestral altar,
12003 the altar of Zeus, is aloft in air on the peak of Ida,'
12004 
12005 and who have
12006 
12007 'the blood of deities yet flowing in their veins.'
12008 
12009 And therefore let us put an end to such tales, lest they engender laxity
12010 of morals among the young.
12011 
12012 By all means, he replied.
12013 
12014 But now that we are determining what classes of subjects are or are not
12015 to be spoken of, let us see whether any have been omitted by us. The
12016 manner in which gods and demigods and heroes and the world below should
12017 be treated has been already laid down.
12018 
12019 Very true.
12020 
12021 And what shall we say about men? That is clearly the remaining portion
12022 of our subject.
12023 
12024 Clearly so.
12025 
12026 But we are not in a condition to answer this question at present, my
12027 friend.
12028 
12029 Why not?
12030 
12031 Because, if I am not mistaken, we shall have to say that about men poets
12032 and story-tellers are guilty of making the gravest misstatements when
12033 they tell us that wicked men are often happy, and the good miserable;
12034 and that injustice is profitable when undetected, but that justice is a
12035 man's own loss and another's gain--these things we shall forbid them to
12036 utter, and command them to sing and say the opposite.
12037 
12038 To be sure we shall, he replied.
12039 
12040 But if you admit that I am right in this, then I shall maintain that you
12041 have implied the principle for which we have been all along contending.
12042 
12043 I grant the truth of your inference.
12044 
12045 That such things are or are not to be said about men is a question which
12046 we cannot determine until we have discovered what justice is, and how
12047 naturally advantageous to the possessor, whether he seem to be just or
12048 not.
12049 
12050 Most true, he said.
12051 
12052 Enough of the subjects of poetry: let us now speak of the style; and
12053 when this has been considered, both matter and manner will have been
12054 completely treated.
12055 
12056 I do not understand what you mean, said Adeimantus.
12057 
12058 Then I must make you understand; and perhaps I may be more intelligible
12059 if I put the matter in this way. You are aware, I suppose, that all
12060 mythology and poetry is a narration of events, either past, present, or
12061 to come?
12062 
12063 Certainly, he replied.
12064 
12065 And narration may be either simple narration, or imitation, or a union
12066 of the two?
12067 
12068 That again, he said, I do not quite understand.
12069 
12070 I fear that I must be a ridiculous teacher when I have so much
12071 difficulty in making myself apprehended. Like a bad speaker, therefore,
12072 I will not take the whole of the subject, but will break a piece off in
12073 illustration of my meaning. You know the first lines of the Iliad,
12074 in which the poet says that Chryses prayed Agamemnon to release his
12075 daughter, and that Agamemnon flew into a passion with him; whereupon
12076 Chryses, failing of his object, invoked the anger of the God against the
12077 Achaeans. Now as far as these lines,
12078 
12079 'And he prayed all the Greeks, but especially the two sons of Atreus,
12080 the chiefs of the people,'
12081 
12082 the poet is speaking in his own person; he never leads us to suppose
12083 that he is any one else. But in what follows he takes the person of
12084 Chryses, and then he does all that he can to make us believe that the
12085 speaker is not Homer, but the aged priest himself. And in this double
12086 form he has cast the entire narrative of the events which occurred at
12087 Troy and in Ithaca and throughout the Odyssey.
12088 
12089 Yes.
12090 
12091 And a narrative it remains both in the speeches which the poet recites
12092 from time to time and in the intermediate passages?
12093 
12094 Quite true.
12095 
12096 But when the poet speaks in the person of another, may we not say that
12097 he assimilates his style to that of the person who, as he informs you,
12098 is going to speak?
12099 
12100 Certainly.
12101 
12102 And this assimilation of himself to another, either by the use of voice
12103 or gesture, is the imitation of the person whose character he assumes?
12104 
12105 Of course.
12106 
12107 Then in this case the narrative of the poet may be said to proceed by
12108 way of imitation?
12109 
12110 Very true.
12111 
12112 Or, if the poet everywhere appears and never conceals himself, then
12113 again the imitation is dropped, and his poetry becomes simple narration.
12114 However, in order that I may make my meaning quite clear, and that you
12115 may no more say, 'I don't understand,' I will show how the change might
12116 be effected. If Homer had said, 'The priest came, having his daughter's
12117 ransom in his hands, supplicating the Achaeans, and above all the
12118 kings;' and then if, instead of speaking in the person of Chryses,
12119 he had continued in his own person, the words would have been, not
12120 imitation, but simple narration. The passage would have run as follows
12121 (I am no poet, and therefore I drop the metre), 'The priest came and
12122 prayed the gods on behalf of the Greeks that they might capture Troy
12123 and return safely home, but begged that they would give him back his
12124 daughter, and take the ransom which he brought, and respect the God.
12125 Thus he spoke, and the other Greeks revered the priest and assented. But
12126 Agamemnon was wroth, and bade him depart and not come again, lest the
12127 staff and chaplets of the God should be of no avail to him--the daughter
12128 of Chryses should not be released, he said--she should grow old with him
12129 in Argos. And then he told him to go away and not to provoke him, if he
12130 intended to get home unscathed. And the old man went away in fear and
12131 silence, and, when he had left the camp, he called upon Apollo by his
12132 many names, reminding him of everything which he had done pleasing to
12133 him, whether in building his temples, or in offering sacrifice, and
12134 praying that his good deeds might be returned to him, and that the
12135 Achaeans might expiate his tears by the arrows of the god,'--and so on.
12136 In this way the whole becomes simple narrative.
12137 
12138 I understand, he said.
12139 
12140 Or you may suppose the opposite case--that the intermediate passages are
12141 omitted, and the dialogue only left.
12142 
12143 That also, he said, I understand; you mean, for example, as in tragedy.
12144 
12145 You have conceived my meaning perfectly; and if I mistake not, what you
12146 failed to apprehend before is now made clear to you, that poetry and
12147 mythology are, in some cases, wholly imitative--instances of this are
12148 supplied by tragedy and comedy; there is likewise the opposite style,
12149 in which the poet is the only speaker--of this the dithyramb affords
12150 the best example; and the combination of both is found in epic, and in
12151 several other styles of poetry. Do I take you with me?
12152 
12153 Yes, he said; I see now what you meant.
12154 
12155 I will ask you to remember also what I began by saying, that we had done
12156 with the subject and might proceed to the style.
12157 
12158 Yes, I remember.
12159 
12160 In saying this, I intended to imply that we must come to an
12161 understanding about the mimetic art,--whether the poets, in narrating
12162 their stories, are to be allowed by us to imitate, and if so, whether
12163 in whole or in part, and if the latter, in what parts; or should all
12164 imitation be prohibited?
12165 
12166 You mean, I suspect, to ask whether tragedy and comedy shall be admitted
12167 into our State?
12168 
12169 Yes, I said; but there may be more than this in question: I really do
12170 not know as yet, but whither the argument may blow, thither we go.
12171 
12172 And go we will, he said.
12173 
12174 Then, Adeimantus, let me ask you whether our guardians ought to be
12175 imitators; or rather, has not this question been decided by the rule
12176 already laid down that one man can only do one thing well, and not many;
12177 and that if he attempt many, he will altogether fail of gaining much
12178 reputation in any?
12179 
12180 Certainly.
12181 
12182 And this is equally true of imitation; no one man can imitate many
12183 things as well as he would imitate a single one?
12184 
12185 He cannot.
12186 
12187 Then the same person will hardly be able to play a serious part in life,
12188 and at the same time to be an imitator and imitate many other parts as
12189 well; for even when two species of imitation are nearly allied, the same
12190 persons cannot succeed in both, as, for example, the writers of tragedy
12191 and comedy--did you not just now call them imitations?
12192 
12193 Yes, I did; and you are right in thinking that the same persons cannot
12194 succeed in both.
12195 
12196 Any more than they can be rhapsodists and actors at once?
12197 
12198 True.
12199 
12200 Neither are comic and tragic actors the same; yet all these things are
12201 but imitations.
12202 
12203 They are so.
12204 
12205 And human nature, Adeimantus, appears to have been coined into yet
12206 smaller pieces, and to be as incapable of imitating many things well, as
12207 of performing well the actions of which the imitations are copies.
12208 
12209 Quite true, he replied.
12210 
12211 If then we adhere to our original notion and bear in mind that
12212 our guardians, setting aside every other business, are to dedicate
12213 themselves wholly to the maintenance of freedom in the State, making
12214 this their craft, and engaging in no work which does not bear on this
12215 end, they ought not to practise or imitate anything else; if they
12216 imitate at all, they should imitate from youth upward only those
12217 characters which are suitable to their profession--the courageous,
12218 temperate, holy, free, and the like; but they should not depict or be
12219 skilful at imitating any kind of illiberality or baseness, lest from
12220 imitation they should come to be what they imitate. Did you never
12221 observe how imitations, beginning in early youth and continuing far into
12222 life, at length grow into habits and become a second nature, affecting
12223 body, voice, and mind?
12224 
12225 Yes, certainly, he said.
12226 
12227 Then, I said, we will not allow those for whom we profess a care and of
12228 whom we say that they ought to be good men, to imitate a woman, whether
12229 young or old, quarrelling with her husband, or striving and vaunting
12230 against the gods in conceit of her happiness, or when she is in
12231 affliction, or sorrow, or weeping; and certainly not one who is in
12232 sickness, love, or labour.
12233 
12234 Very right, he said.
12235 
12236 Neither must they represent slaves, male or female, performing the
12237 offices of slaves?
12238 
12239 They must not.
12240 
12241 And surely not bad men, whether cowards or any others, who do the
12242 reverse of what we have just been prescribing, who scold or mock or
12243 revile one another in drink or out of drink, or who in any other manner
12244 sin against themselves and their neighbours in word or deed, as the
12245 manner of such is. Neither should they be trained to imitate the action
12246 or speech of men or women who are mad or bad; for madness, like vice, is
12247 to be known but not to be practised or imitated.
12248 
12249 Very true, he replied.
12250 
12251 Neither may they imitate smiths or other artificers, or oarsmen, or
12252 boatswains, or the like?
12253 
12254 How can they, he said, when they are not allowed to apply their minds to
12255 the callings of any of these?
12256 
12257 Nor may they imitate the neighing of horses, the bellowing of bulls, the
12258 murmur of rivers and roll of the ocean, thunder, and all that sort of
12259 thing?
12260 
12261 Nay, he said, if madness be forbidden, neither may they copy the
12262 behaviour of madmen.
12263 
12264 You mean, I said, if I understand you aright, that there is one sort of
12265 narrative style which may be employed by a truly good man when he has
12266 anything to say, and that another sort will be used by a man of an
12267 opposite character and education.
12268 
12269 And which are these two sorts? he asked.
12270 
12271 Suppose, I answered, that a just and good man in the course of a
12272 narration comes on some saying or action of another good man,--I should
12273 imagine that he will like to personate him, and will not be ashamed of
12274 this sort of imitation: he will be most ready to play the part of the
12275 good man when he is acting firmly and wisely; in a less degree when
12276 he is overtaken by illness or love or drink, or has met with any other
12277 disaster. But when he comes to a character which is unworthy of him, he
12278 will not make a study of that; he will disdain such a person, and will
12279 assume his likeness, if at all, for a moment only when he is performing
12280 some good action; at other times he will be ashamed to play a part which
12281 he has never practised, nor will he like to fashion and frame himself
12282 after the baser models; he feels the employment of such an art, unless
12283 in jest, to be beneath him, and his mind revolts at it.
12284 
12285 So I should expect, he replied.
12286 
12287 Then he will adopt a mode of narration such as we have illustrated
12288 out of Homer, that is to say, his style will be both imitative and
12289 narrative; but there will be very little of the former, and a great deal
12290 of the latter. Do you agree?
12291 
12292 Certainly, he said; that is the model which such a speaker must
12293 necessarily take.
12294 
12295 But there is another sort of character who will narrate anything, and,
12296 the worse he is, the more unscrupulous he will be; nothing will be too
12297 bad for him: and he will be ready to imitate anything, not as a joke,
12298 but in right good earnest, and before a large company. As I was just now
12299 saying, he will attempt to represent the roll of thunder, the noise of
12300 wind and hail, or the creaking of wheels, and pulleys, and the various
12301 sounds of flutes, pipes, trumpets, and all sorts of instruments: he will
12302 bark like a dog, bleat like a sheep, or crow like a cock; his entire art
12303 will consist in imitation of voice and gesture, and there will be very
12304 little narration.
12305 
12306 That, he said, will be his mode of speaking.
12307 
12308 These, then, are the two kinds of style?
12309 
12310 Yes.
12311 
12312 And you would agree with me in saying that one of them is simple and has
12313 but slight changes; and if the harmony and rhythm are also chosen
12314 for their simplicity, the result is that the speaker, if he speaks
12315 correctly, is always pretty much the same in style, and he will keep
12316 within the limits of a single harmony (for the changes are not great),
12317 and in like manner he will make use of nearly the same rhythm?
12318 
12319 That is quite true, he said.
12320 
12321 Whereas the other requires all sorts of harmonies and all sorts of
12322 rhythms, if the music and the style are to correspond, because the style
12323 has all sorts of changes.
12324 
12325 That is also perfectly true, he replied.
12326 
12327 And do not the two styles, or the mixture of the two, comprehend all
12328 poetry, and every form of expression in words? No one can say anything
12329 except in one or other of them or in both together.
12330 
12331 They include all, he said.
12332 
12333 And shall we receive into our State all the three styles, or one only of
12334 the two unmixed styles? or would you include the mixed?
12335 
12336 I should prefer only to admit the pure imitator of virtue.
12337 
12338 Yes, I said, Adeimantus, but the mixed style is also very charming: and
12339 indeed the pantomimic, which is the opposite of the one chosen by you,
12340 is the most popular style with children and their attendants, and with
12341 the world in general.
12342 
12343 I do not deny it.
12344 
12345 But I suppose you would argue that such a style is unsuitable to our
12346 State, in which human nature is not twofold or manifold, for one man
12347 plays one part only?
12348 
12349 Yes; quite unsuitable.
12350 
12351 And this is the reason why in our State, and in our State only, we
12352 shall find a shoemaker to be a shoemaker and not a pilot also, and a
12353 husbandman to be a husbandman and not a dicast also, and a soldier a
12354 soldier and not a trader also, and the same throughout?
12355 
12356 True, he said.
12357 
12358 And therefore when any one of these pantomimic gentlemen, who are so
12359 clever that they can imitate anything, comes to us, and makes a proposal
12360 to exhibit himself and his poetry, we will fall down and worship him as
12361 a sweet and holy and wonderful being; but we must also inform him that
12362 in our State such as he are not permitted to exist; the law will not
12363 allow them. And so when we have anointed him with myrrh, and set a
12364 garland of wool upon his head, we shall send him away to another city.
12365 For we mean to employ for our souls' health the rougher and severer poet
12366 or story-teller, who will imitate the style of the virtuous only, and
12367 will follow those models which we prescribed at first when we began the
12368 education of our soldiers.
12369 
12370 We certainly will, he said, if we have the power.
12371 
12372 Then now, my friend, I said, that part of music or literary education
12373 which relates to the story or myth may be considered to be finished; for
12374 the matter and manner have both been discussed.
12375 
12376 I think so too, he said.
12377 
12378 Next in order will follow melody and song.
12379 
12380 That is obvious.
12381 
12382 Every one can see already what we ought to say about them, if we are to
12383 be consistent with ourselves.
12384 
12385 I fear, said Glaucon, laughing, that the word 'every one' hardly
12386 includes me, for I cannot at the moment say what they should be; though
12387 I may guess.
12388 
12389 At any rate you can tell that a song or ode has three parts--the words,
12390 the melody, and the rhythm; that degree of knowledge I may presuppose?
12391 
12392 Yes, he said; so much as that you may.
12393 
12394 And as for the words, there will surely be no difference between words
12395 which are and which are not set to music; both will conform to the same
12396 laws, and these have been already determined by us?
12397 
12398 Yes.
12399 
12400 And the melody and rhythm will depend upon the words?
12401 
12402 Certainly.
12403 
12404 We were saying, when we spoke of the subject-matter, that we had no need
12405 of lamentation and strains of sorrow?
12406 
12407 True.
12408 
12409 And which are the harmonies expressive of sorrow? You are musical, and
12410 can tell me.
12411 
12412 The harmonies which you mean are the mixed or tenor Lydian, and the
12413 full-toned or bass Lydian, and such like.
12414 
12415 These then, I said, must be banished; even to women who have a character
12416 to maintain they are of no use, and much less to men.
12417 
12418 Certainly.
12419 
12420 In the next place, drunkenness and softness and indolence are utterly
12421 unbecoming the character of our guardians.
12422 
12423 Utterly unbecoming.
12424 
12425 And which are the soft or drinking harmonies?
12426 
12427 The Ionian, he replied, and the Lydian; they are termed 'relaxed.'
12428 
12429 Well, and are these of any military use?
12430 
12431 Quite the reverse, he replied; and if so the Dorian and the Phrygian are
12432 the only ones which you have left.
12433 
12434 I answered: Of the harmonies I know nothing, but I want to have one
12435 warlike, to sound the note or accent which a brave man utters in the
12436 hour of danger and stern resolve, or when his cause is failing, and he
12437 is going to wounds or death or is overtaken by some other evil, and
12438 at every such crisis meets the blows of fortune with firm step and a
12439 determination to endure; and another to be used by him in times of peace
12440 and freedom of action, when there is no pressure of necessity, and he is
12441 seeking to persuade God by prayer, or man by instruction and admonition,
12442 or on the other hand, when he is expressing his willingness to yield to
12443 persuasion or entreaty or admonition, and which represents him when
12444 by prudent conduct he has attained his end, not carried away by his
12445 success, but acting moderately and wisely under the circumstances, and
12446 acquiescing in the event. These two harmonies I ask you to leave;
12447 the strain of necessity and the strain of freedom, the strain of the
12448 unfortunate and the strain of the fortunate, the strain of courage, and
12449 the strain of temperance; these, I say, leave.
12450 
12451 And these, he replied, are the Dorian and Phrygian harmonies of which I
12452 was just now speaking.
12453 
12454 Then, I said, if these and these only are to be used in our songs and
12455 melodies, we shall not want multiplicity of notes or a panharmonic
12456 scale?
12457 
12458 I suppose not.
12459 
12460 Then we shall not maintain the artificers of lyres with three
12461 corners and complex scales, or the makers of any other many-stringed
12462 curiously-harmonised instruments?
12463 
12464 Certainly not.
12465 
12466 But what do you say to flute-makers and flute-players? Would you admit
12467 them into our State when you reflect that in this composite use of
12468 harmony the flute is worse than all the stringed instruments put
12469 together; even the panharmonic music is only an imitation of the flute?
12470 
12471 Clearly not.
12472 
12473 There remain then only the lyre and the harp for use in the city, and
12474 the shepherds may have a pipe in the country.
12475 
12476 That is surely the conclusion to be drawn from the argument.
12477 
12478 The preferring of Apollo and his instruments to Marsyas and his
12479 instruments is not at all strange, I said.
12480 
12481 Not at all, he replied.
12482 
12483 And so, by the dog of Egypt, we have been unconsciously purging the
12484 State, which not long ago we termed luxurious.
12485 
12486 And we have done wisely, he replied.
12487 
12488 Then let us now finish the purgation, I said. Next in order to
12489 harmonies, rhythms will naturally follow, and they should be subject to
12490 the same rules, for we ought not to seek out complex systems of metre,
12491 or metres of every kind, but rather to discover what rhythms are the
12492 expressions of a courageous and harmonious life; and when we have found
12493 them, we shall adapt the foot and the melody to words having a like
12494 spirit, not the words to the foot and melody. To say what these rhythms
12495 are will be your duty--you must teach me them, as you have already
12496 taught me the harmonies.
12497 
12498 But, indeed, he replied, I cannot tell you. I only know that there
12499 are some three principles of rhythm out of which metrical systems are
12500 framed, just as in sounds there are four notes (i.e. the four notes of
12501 the tetrachord.) out of which all the harmonies are composed; that is
12502 an observation which I have made. But of what sort of lives they are
12503 severally the imitations I am unable to say.
12504 
12505 Then, I said, we must take Damon into our counsels; and he will tell us
12506 what rhythms are expressive of meanness, or insolence, or fury, or other
12507 unworthiness, and what are to be reserved for the expression of opposite
12508 feelings. And I think that I have an indistinct recollection of his
12509 mentioning a complex Cretic rhythm; also a dactylic or heroic, and he
12510 arranged them in some manner which I do not quite understand, making
12511 the rhythms equal in the rise and fall of the foot, long and short
12512 alternating; and, unless I am mistaken, he spoke of an iambic as well
12513 as of a trochaic rhythm, and assigned to them short and long quantities.
12514 Also in some cases he appeared to praise or censure the movement of the
12515 foot quite as much as the rhythm; or perhaps a combination of the two;
12516 for I am not certain what he meant. These matters, however, as I was
12517 saying, had better be referred to Damon himself, for the analysis of
12518 the subject would be difficult, you know? (Socrates expresses himself
12519 carelessly in accordance with his assumed ignorance of the details of
12520 the subject. In the first part of the sentence he appears to be speaking
12521 of paeonic rhythms which are in the ratio of 3/2; in the second part, of
12522 dactylic and anapaestic rhythms, which are in the ratio of 1/1; in the
12523 last clause, of iambic and trochaic rhythms, which are in the ratio of
12524 1/2 or 2/1.)
12525 
12526 Rather so, I should say.
12527 
12528 But there is no difficulty in seeing that grace or the absence of grace
12529 is an effect of good or bad rhythm.
12530 
12531 None at all.
12532 
12533 And also that good and bad rhythm naturally assimilate to a good and bad
12534 style; and that harmony and discord in like manner follow style; for our
12535 principle is that rhythm and harmony are regulated by the words, and not
12536 the words by them.
12537 
12538 Just so, he said, they should follow the words.
12539 
12540 And will not the words and the character of the style depend on the
12541 temper of the soul?
12542 
12543 Yes.
12544 
12545 And everything else on the style?
12546 
12547 Yes.
12548 
12549 Then beauty of style and harmony and grace and good rhythm depend on
12550 simplicity,--I mean the true simplicity of a rightly and nobly ordered
12551 mind and character, not that other simplicity which is only an euphemism
12552 for folly?
12553 
12554 Very true, he replied.
12555 
12556 And if our youth are to do their work in life, must they not make these
12557 graces and harmonies their perpetual aim?
12558 
12559 They must.
12560 
12561 And surely the art of the painter and every other creative and
12562 constructive art are full of them,--weaving, embroidery, architecture,
12563 and every kind of manufacture; also nature, animal and vegetable,--in
12564 all of them there is grace or the absence of grace. And ugliness and
12565 discord and inharmonious motion are nearly allied to ill words and ill
12566 nature, as grace and harmony are the twin sisters of goodness and virtue
12567 and bear their likeness.
12568 
12569 That is quite true, he said.
12570 
12571 But shall our superintendence go no further, and are the poets only to
12572 be required by us to express the image of the good in their works, on
12573 pain, if they do anything else, of expulsion from our State? Or is the
12574 same control to be extended to other artists, and are they also to be
12575 prohibited from exhibiting the opposite forms of vice and intemperance
12576 and meanness and indecency in sculpture and building and the other
12577 creative arts; and is he who cannot conform to this rule of ours to be
12578 prevented from practising his art in our State, lest the taste of our
12579 citizens be corrupted by him? We would not have our guardians grow up
12580 amid images of moral deformity, as in some noxious pasture, and there
12581 browse and feed upon many a baneful herb and flower day by day, little
12582 by little, until they silently gather a festering mass of corruption
12583 in their own soul. Let our artists rather be those who are gifted to
12584 discern the true nature of the beautiful and graceful; then will our
12585 youth dwell in a land of health, amid fair sights and sounds, and
12586 receive the good in everything; and beauty, the effluence of fair works,
12587 shall flow into the eye and ear, like a health-giving breeze from a
12588 purer region, and insensibly draw the soul from earliest years into
12589 likeness and sympathy with the beauty of reason.
12590 
12591 There can be no nobler training than that, he replied.
12592 
12593 And therefore, I said, Glaucon, musical training is a more potent
12594 instrument than any other, because rhythm and harmony find their way
12595 into the inward places of the soul, on which they mightily fasten,
12596 imparting grace, and making the soul of him who is rightly educated
12597 graceful, or of him who is ill-educated ungraceful; and also because
12598 he who has received this true education of the inner being will most
12599 shrewdly perceive omissions or faults in art and nature, and with a true
12600 taste, while he praises and rejoices over and receives into his soul the
12601 good, and becomes noble and good, he will justly blame and hate the bad,
12602 now in the days of his youth, even before he is able to know the reason
12603 why; and when reason comes he will recognise and salute the friend with
12604 whom his education has made him long familiar.
12605 
12606 Yes, he said, I quite agree with you in thinking that our youth should
12607 be trained in music and on the grounds which you mention.
12608 
12609 Just as in learning to read, I said, we were satisfied when we knew
12610 the letters of the alphabet, which are very few, in all their recurring
12611 sizes and combinations; not slighting them as unimportant whether they
12612 occupy a space large or small, but everywhere eager to make them out;
12613 and not thinking ourselves perfect in the art of reading until we
12614 recognise them wherever they are found:
12615 
12616 True--
12617 
12618 Or, as we recognise the reflection of letters in the water, or in a
12619 mirror, only when we know the letters themselves; the same art and study
12620 giving us the knowledge of both:
12621 
12622 Exactly--
12623 
12624 Even so, as I maintain, neither we nor our guardians, whom we have to
12625 educate, can ever become musical until we and they know the essential
12626 forms of temperance, courage, liberality, magnificence, and their
12627 kindred, as well as the contrary forms, in all their combinations,
12628 and can recognise them and their images wherever they are found, not
12629 slighting them either in small things or great, but believing them all
12630 to be within the sphere of one art and study.
12631 
12632 Most assuredly.
12633 
12634 And when a beautiful soul harmonizes with a beautiful form, and the two
12635 are cast in one mould, that will be the fairest of sights to him who has
12636 an eye to see it?
12637 
12638 The fairest indeed.
12639 
12640 And the fairest is also the loveliest?
12641 
12642 That may be assumed.
12643 
12644 And the man who has the spirit of harmony will be most in love with the
12645 loveliest; but he will not love him who is of an inharmonious soul?
12646 
12647 That is true, he replied, if the deficiency be in his soul; but if there
12648 be any merely bodily defect in another he will be patient of it, and
12649 will love all the same.
12650 
12651 I perceive, I said, that you have or have had experiences of this sort,
12652 and I agree. But let me ask you another question: Has excess of pleasure
12653 any affinity to temperance?
12654 
12655 How can that be? he replied; pleasure deprives a man of the use of his
12656 faculties quite as much as pain.
12657 
12658 Or any affinity to virtue in general?
12659 
12660 None whatever.
12661 
12662 Any affinity to wantonness and intemperance?
12663 
12664 Yes, the greatest.
12665 
12666 And is there any greater or keener pleasure than that of sensual love?
12667 
12668 No, nor a madder.
12669 
12670 Whereas true love is a love of beauty and order--temperate and
12671 harmonious?
12672 
12673 Quite true, he said.
12674 
12675 Then no intemperance or madness should be allowed to approach true love?
12676 
12677 Certainly not.
12678 
12679 Then mad or intemperate pleasure must never be allowed to come near the
12680 lover and his beloved; neither of them can have any part in it if their
12681 love is of the right sort?
12682 
12683 No, indeed, Socrates, it must never come near them.
12684
