12685 Then I suppose that in the city which we are founding you would make a
12686 law to the effect that a friend should use no other familiarity to
12687 his love than a father would use to his son, and then only for a noble
12688 purpose, and he must first have the other's consent; and this rule is
12689 to limit him in all his intercourse, and he is never to be seen going
12690 further, or, if he exceeds, he is to be deemed guilty of coarseness and
12691 bad taste.
12692 
12693 I quite agree, he said.
12694 
12695 Thus much of music, which makes a fair ending; for what should be the
12696 end of music if not the love of beauty?
12697 
12698 I agree, he said.
12699 
12700 After music comes gymnastic, in which our youth are next to be trained.
12701 
12702 Certainly.
12703 
12704 Gymnastic as well as music should begin in early years; the training
12705 in it should be careful and should continue through life. Now my belief
12706 is,--and this is a matter upon which I should like to have your opinion
12707 in confirmation of my own, but my own belief is,--not that the good body
12708 by any bodily excellence improves the soul, but, on the contrary, that
12709 the good soul, by her own excellence, improves the body as far as this
12710 may be possible. What do you say?
12711 
12712 Yes, I agree.
12713 
12714 Then, to the mind when adequately trained, we shall be right in handing
12715 over the more particular care of the body; and in order to avoid
12716 prolixity we will now only give the general outlines of the subject.
12717 
12718 Very good.
12719 
12720 That they must abstain from intoxication has been already remarked by
12721 us; for of all persons a guardian should be the last to get drunk and
12722 not know where in the world he is.
12723 
12724 Yes, he said; that a guardian should require another guardian to take
12725 care of him is ridiculous indeed.
12726 
12727 But next, what shall we say of their food; for the men are in training
12728 for the great contest of all--are they not?
12729 
12730 Yes, he said.
12731 
12732 And will the habit of body of our ordinary athletes be suited to them?
12733 
12734 Why not?
12735 
12736 I am afraid, I said, that a habit of body such as they have is but a
12737 sleepy sort of thing, and rather perilous to health. Do you not observe
12738 that these athletes sleep away their lives, and are liable to most
12739 dangerous illnesses if they depart, in ever so slight a degree, from
12740 their customary regimen?
12741 
12742 Yes, I do.
12743 
12744 Then, I said, a finer sort of training will be required for our warrior
12745 athletes, who are to be like wakeful dogs, and to see and hear with the
12746 utmost keenness; amid the many changes of water and also of food, of
12747 summer heat and winter cold, which they will have to endure when on a
12748 campaign, they must not be liable to break down in health.
12749 
12750 That is my view.
12751 
12752 The really excellent gymnastic is twin sister of that simple music which
12753 we were just now describing.
12754 
12755 How so?
12756 
12757 Why, I conceive that there is a gymnastic which, like our music, is
12758 simple and good; and especially the military gymnastic.
12759 
12760 What do you mean?
12761 
12762 My meaning may be learned from Homer; he, you know, feeds his heroes at
12763 their feasts, when they are campaigning, on soldiers' fare; they have
12764 no fish, although they are on the shores of the Hellespont, and they
12765 are not allowed boiled meats but only roast, which is the food most
12766 convenient for soldiers, requiring only that they should light a fire,
12767 and not involving the trouble of carrying about pots and pans.
12768 
12769 True.
12770 
12771 And I can hardly be mistaken in saying that sweet sauces are nowhere
12772 mentioned in Homer. In proscribing them, however, he is not singular;
12773 all professional athletes are well aware that a man who is to be in good
12774 condition should take nothing of the kind.
12775 
12776 Yes, he said; and knowing this, they are quite right in not taking them.
12777 
12778 Then you would not approve of Syracusan dinners, and the refinements of
12779 Sicilian cookery?
12780 
12781 I think not.
12782 
12783 Nor, if a man is to be in condition, would you allow him to have a
12784 Corinthian girl as his fair friend?
12785 
12786 Certainly not.
12787 
12788 Neither would you approve of the delicacies, as they are thought, of
12789 Athenian confectionary?
12790 
12791 Certainly not.
12792 
12793 All such feeding and living may be rightly compared by us to melody and
12794 song composed in the panharmonic style, and in all the rhythms.
12795 
12796 Exactly.
12797 
12798 There complexity engendered licence, and here disease; whereas
12799 simplicity in music was the parent of temperance in the soul; and
12800 simplicity in gymnastic of health in the body.
12801 
12802 Most true, he said.
12803 
12804 But when intemperance and diseases multiply in a State, halls of justice
12805 and medicine are always being opened; and the arts of the doctor and the
12806 lawyer give themselves airs, finding how keen is the interest which not
12807 only the slaves but the freemen of a city take about them.
12808 
12809 Of course.
12810 
12811 And yet what greater proof can there be of a bad and disgraceful state
12812 of education than this, that not only artisans and the meaner sort of
12813 people need the skill of first-rate physicians and judges, but also
12814 those who would profess to have had a liberal education? Is it not
12815 disgraceful, and a great sign of want of good-breeding, that a man
12816 should have to go abroad for his law and physic because he has none of
12817 his own at home, and must therefore surrender himself into the hands of
12818 other men whom he makes lords and judges over him?
12819 
12820 Of all things, he said, the most disgraceful.
12821 
12822 Would you say 'most,' I replied, when you consider that there is
12823 a further stage of the evil in which a man is not only a life-long
12824 litigant, passing all his days in the courts, either as plaintiff or
12825 defendant, but is actually led by his bad taste to pride himself on his
12826 litigiousness; he imagines that he is a master in dishonesty; able to
12827 take every crooked turn, and wriggle into and out of every hole,
12828 bending like a withy and getting out of the way of justice: and all
12829 for what?--in order to gain small points not worth mentioning, he not
12830 knowing that so to order his life as to be able to do without a napping
12831 judge is a far higher and nobler sort of thing. Is not that still more
12832 disgraceful?
12833 
12834 Yes, he said, that is still more disgraceful.
12835 
12836 Well, I said, and to require the help of medicine, not when a wound
12837 has to be cured, or on occasion of an epidemic, but just because, by
12838 indolence and a habit of life such as we have been describing, men
12839 fill themselves with waters and winds, as if their bodies were a marsh,
12840 compelling the ingenious sons of Asclepius to find more names for
12841 diseases, such as flatulence and catarrh; is not this, too, a disgrace?
12842 
12843 Yes, he said, they do certainly give very strange and newfangled names
12844 to diseases.
12845 
12846 Yes, I said, and I do not believe that there were any such diseases in
12847 the days of Asclepius; and this I infer from the circumstance that the
12848 hero Eurypylus, after he has been wounded in Homer, drinks a posset of
12849 Pramnian wine well besprinkled with barley-meal and grated cheese, which
12850 are certainly inflammatory, and yet the sons of Asclepius who were
12851 at the Trojan war do not blame the damsel who gives him the drink, or
12852 rebuke Patroclus, who is treating his case.
12853 
12854 Well, he said, that was surely an extraordinary drink to be given to a
12855 person in his condition.
12856 
12857 Not so extraordinary, I replied, if you bear in mind that in former
12858 days, as is commonly said, before the time of Herodicus, the guild of
12859 Asclepius did not practise our present system of medicine, which may be
12860 said to educate diseases. But Herodicus, being a trainer, and himself of
12861 a sickly constitution, by a combination of training and doctoring found
12862 out a way of torturing first and chiefly himself, and secondly the rest
12863 of the world.
12864 
12865 How was that? he said.
12866 
12867 By the invention of lingering death; for he had a mortal disease which
12868 he perpetually tended, and as recovery was out of the question, he
12869 passed his entire life as a valetudinarian; he could do nothing but
12870 attend upon himself, and he was in constant torment whenever he departed
12871 in anything from his usual regimen, and so dying hard, by the help of
12872 science he struggled on to old age.
12873 
12874 A rare reward of his skill!
12875 
12876 Yes, I said; a reward which a man might fairly expect who never
12877 understood that, if Asclepius did not instruct his descendants
12878 in valetudinarian arts, the omission arose, not from ignorance or
12879 inexperience of such a branch of medicine, but because he knew that in
12880 all well-ordered states every individual has an occupation to which he
12881 must attend, and has therefore no leisure to spend in continually being
12882 ill. This we remark in the case of the artisan, but, ludicrously enough,
12883 do not apply the same rule to people of the richer sort.
12884 
12885 How do you mean? he said.
12886 
12887 I mean this: When a carpenter is ill he asks the physician for a rough
12888 and ready cure; an emetic or a purge or a cautery or the knife,--these
12889 are his remedies. And if some one prescribes for him a course of
12890 dietetics, and tells him that he must swathe and swaddle his head, and
12891 all that sort of thing, he replies at once that he has no time to be
12892 ill, and that he sees no good in a life which is spent in nursing
12893 his disease to the neglect of his customary employment; and therefore
12894 bidding good-bye to this sort of physician, he resumes his ordinary
12895 habits, and either gets well and lives and does his business, or, if his
12896 constitution fails, he dies and has no more trouble.
12897 
12898 Yes, he said, and a man in his condition of life ought to use the art of
12899 medicine thus far only.
12900 
12901 Has he not, I said, an occupation; and what profit would there be in his
12902 life if he were deprived of his occupation?
12903 
12904 Quite true, he said.
12905 
12906 But with the rich man this is otherwise; of him we do not say that he
12907 has any specially appointed work which he must perform, if he would
12908 live.
12909 
12910 He is generally supposed to have nothing to do.
12911 
12912 Then you never heard of the saying of Phocylides, that as soon as a man
12913 has a livelihood he should practise virtue?
12914 
12915 Nay, he said, I think that he had better begin somewhat sooner.
12916 
12917 Let us not have a dispute with him about this, I said; but rather ask
12918 ourselves: Is the practice of virtue obligatory on the rich man, or
12919 can he live without it? And if obligatory on him, then let us raise
12920 a further question, whether this dieting of disorders, which is an
12921 impediment to the application of the mind in carpentering and the
12922 mechanical arts, does not equally stand in the way of the sentiment of
12923 Phocylides?
12924 
12925 Of that, he replied, there can be no doubt; such excessive care of the
12926 body, when carried beyond the rules of gymnastic, is most inimical to
12927 the practice of virtue.
12928 
12929 Yes, indeed, I replied, and equally incompatible with the management of
12930 a house, an army, or an office of state; and, what is most important
12931 of all, irreconcileable with any kind of study or thought or
12932 self-reflection--there is a constant suspicion that headache and
12933 giddiness are to be ascribed to philosophy, and hence all practising or
12934 making trial of virtue in the higher sense is absolutely stopped; for
12935 a man is always fancying that he is being made ill, and is in constant
12936 anxiety about the state of his body.
12937 
12938 Yes, likely enough.
12939 
12940 And therefore our politic Asclepius may be supposed to have exhibited
12941 the power of his art only to persons who, being generally of healthy
12942 constitution and habits of life, had a definite ailment; such as these
12943 he cured by purges and operations, and bade them live as usual, herein
12944 consulting the interests of the State; but bodies which disease had
12945 penetrated through and through he would not have attempted to cure
12946 by gradual processes of evacuation and infusion: he did not want to
12947 lengthen out good-for-nothing lives, or to have weak fathers begetting
12948 weaker sons;--if a man was not able to live in the ordinary way he
12949 had no business to cure him; for such a cure would have been of no use
12950 either to himself, or to the State.
12951 
12952 Then, he said, you regard Asclepius as a statesman.
12953 
12954 Clearly; and his character is further illustrated by his sons. Note that
12955 they were heroes in the days of old and practised the medicines of which
12956 I am speaking at the siege of Troy: You will remember how, when Pandarus
12957 wounded Menelaus, they
12958 
12959 'Sucked the blood out of the wound, and sprinkled soothing remedies,'
12960 
12961 but they never prescribed what the patient was afterwards to eat or
12962 drink in the case of Menelaus, any more than in the case of Eurypylus;
12963 the remedies, as they conceived, were enough to heal any man who before
12964 he was wounded was healthy and regular in his habits; and even though he
12965 did happen to drink a posset of Pramnian wine, he might get well all the
12966 same. But they would have nothing to do with unhealthy and intemperate
12967 subjects, whose lives were of no use either to themselves or others; the
12968 art of medicine was not designed for their good, and though they were as
12969 rich as Midas, the sons of Asclepius would have declined to attend them.
12970 
12971 They were very acute persons, those sons of Asclepius.
12972 
12973 Naturally so, I replied. Nevertheless, the tragedians and Pindar
12974 disobeying our behests, although they acknowledge that Asclepius was the
12975 son of Apollo, say also that he was bribed into healing a rich man
12976 who was at the point of death, and for this reason he was struck by
12977 lightning. But we, in accordance with the principle already affirmed by
12978 us, will not believe them when they tell us both;--if he was the son of
12979 a god, we maintain that he was not avaricious; or, if he was avaricious,
12980 he was not the son of a god.
12981 
12982 All that, Socrates, is excellent; but I should like to put a question to
12983 you: Ought there not to be good physicians in a State, and are not the
12984 best those who have treated the greatest number of constitutions good
12985 and bad? and are not the best judges in like manner those who are
12986 acquainted with all sorts of moral natures?
12987 
12988 Yes, I said, I too would have good judges and good physicians. But do
12989 you know whom I think good?
12990 
12991 Will you tell me?
12992 
12993 I will, if I can. Let me however note that in the same question you join
12994 two things which are not the same.
12995 
12996 How so? he asked.
12997 
12998 Why, I said, you join physicians and judges. Now the most skilful
12999 physicians are those who, from their youth upwards, have combined with
13000 the knowledge of their art the greatest experience of disease; they
13001 had better not be robust in health, and should have had all manner of
13002 diseases in their own persons. For the body, as I conceive, is not the
13003 instrument with which they cure the body; in that case we could not
13004 allow them ever to be or to have been sickly; but they cure the body
13005 with the mind, and the mind which has become and is sick can cure
13006 nothing.
13007 
13008 That is very true, he said.
13009 
13010 But with the judge it is otherwise; since he governs mind by mind; he
13011 ought not therefore to have been trained among vicious minds, and to
13012 have associated with them from youth upwards, and to have gone through
13013 the whole calendar of crime, only in order that he may quickly infer
13014 the crimes of others as he might their bodily diseases from his own
13015 self-consciousness; the honourable mind which is to form a healthy
13016 judgment should have had no experience or contamination of evil habits
13017 when young. And this is the reason why in youth good men often appear to
13018 be simple, and are easily practised upon by the dishonest, because they
13019 have no examples of what evil is in their own souls.
13020 
13021 Yes, he said, they are far too apt to be deceived.
13022 
13023 Therefore, I said, the judge should not be young; he should have learned
13024 to know evil, not from his own soul, but from late and long observation
13025 of the nature of evil in others: knowledge should be his guide, not
13026 personal experience.
13027 
13028 Yes, he said, that is the ideal of a judge.
13029 
13030 Yes, I replied, and he will be a good man (which is my answer to your
13031 question); for he is good who has a good soul. But the cunning and
13032 suspicious nature of which we spoke,--he who has committed many crimes,
13033 and fancies himself to be a master in wickedness, when he is amongst
13034 his fellows, is wonderful in the precautions which he takes, because he
13035 judges of them by himself: but when he gets into the company of men of
13036 virtue, who have the experience of age, he appears to be a fool again,
13037 owing to his unseasonable suspicions; he cannot recognise an honest man,
13038 because he has no pattern of honesty in himself; at the same time, as
13039 the bad are more numerous than the good, and he meets with them oftener,
13040 he thinks himself, and is by others thought to be, rather wise than
13041 foolish.
13042 
13043 Most true, he said.
13044 
13045 Then the good and wise judge whom we are seeking is not this man, but
13046 the other; for vice cannot know virtue too, but a virtuous nature,
13047 educated by time, will acquire a knowledge both of virtue and vice: the
13048 virtuous, and not the vicious, man has wisdom--in my opinion.
13049 
13050 And in mine also.
13051 
13052 This is the sort of medicine, and this is the sort of law, which you
13053 will sanction in your state. They will minister to better natures,
13054 giving health both of soul and of body; but those who are diseased in
13055 their bodies they will leave to die, and the corrupt and incurable souls
13056 they will put an end to themselves.
13057 
13058 That is clearly the best thing both for the patients and for the State.
13059 
13060 And thus our youth, having been educated only in that simple music
13061 which, as we said, inspires temperance, will be reluctant to go to law.
13062 
13063 Clearly.
13064 
13065 And the musician, who, keeping to the same track, is content to practise
13066 the simple gymnastic, will have nothing to do with medicine unless in
13067 some extreme case.
13068 
13069 That I quite believe.
13070 
13071 The very exercises and tolls which he undergoes are intended to
13072 stimulate the spirited element of his nature, and not to increase his
13073 strength; he will not, like common athletes, use exercise and regimen to
13074 develope his muscles.
13075 
13076 Very right, he said.
13077 
13078 Neither are the two arts of music and gymnastic really designed, as is
13079 often supposed, the one for the training of the soul, the other for the
13080 training of the body.
13081 
13082 What then is the real object of them?
13083 
13084 I believe, I said, that the teachers of both have in view chiefly the
13085 improvement of the soul.
13086 
13087 How can that be? he asked.
13088 
13089 Did you never observe, I said, the effect on the mind itself of
13090 exclusive devotion to gymnastic, or the opposite effect of an exclusive
13091 devotion to music?
13092 
13093 In what way shown? he said.
13094 
13095 The one producing a temper of hardness and ferocity, the other of
13096 softness and effeminacy, I replied.
13097 
13098 Yes, he said, I am quite aware that the mere athlete becomes too much of
13099 a savage, and that the mere musician is melted and softened beyond what
13100 is good for him.
13101 
13102 Yet surely, I said, this ferocity only comes from spirit, which, if
13103 rightly educated, would give courage, but, if too much intensified, is
13104 liable to become hard and brutal.
13105 
13106 That I quite think.
13107 
13108 On the other hand the philosopher will have the quality of gentleness.
13109 And this also, when too much indulged, will turn to softness, but, if
13110 educated rightly, will be gentle and moderate.
13111 
13112 True.
13113 
13114 And in our opinion the guardians ought to have both these qualities?
13115 
13116 Assuredly.
13117 
13118 And both should be in harmony?
13119 
13120 Beyond question.
13121 
13122 And the harmonious soul is both temperate and courageous?
13123 
13124 Yes.
13125 
13126 And the inharmonious is cowardly and boorish?
13127 
13128 Very true.
13129 
13130 And, when a man allows music to play upon him and to pour into his soul
13131 through the funnel of his ears those sweet and soft and melancholy airs
13132 of which we were just now speaking, and his whole life is passed in
13133 warbling and the delights of song; in the first stage of the process
13134 the passion or spirit which is in him is tempered like iron, and made
13135 useful, instead of brittle and useless. But, if he carries on the
13136 softening and soothing process, in the next stage he begins to melt and
13137 waste, until he has wasted away his spirit and cut out the sinews of his
13138 soul; and he becomes a feeble warrior.
13139 
13140 Very true.
13141 
13142 If the element of spirit is naturally weak in him the change is speedily
13143 accomplished, but if he have a good deal, then the power of music
13144 weakening the spirit renders him excitable;--on the least provocation
13145 he flames up at once, and is speedily extinguished; instead of having
13146 spirit he grows irritable and passionate and is quite impracticable.
13147 
13148 Exactly.
13149 
13150 And so in gymnastics, if a man takes violent exercise and is a great
13151 feeder, and the reverse of a great student of music and philosophy, at
13152 first the high condition of his body fills him with pride and spirit,
13153 and he becomes twice the man that he was.
13154 
13155 Certainly.
13156 
13157 And what happens? if he do nothing else, and holds no converse with the
13158 Muses, does not even that intelligence which there may be in him, having
13159 no taste of any sort of learning or enquiry or thought or culture,
13160 grow feeble and dull and blind, his mind never waking up or receiving
13161 nourishment, and his senses not being purged of their mists?
13162 
13163 True, he said.
13164 
13165 And he ends by becoming a hater of philosophy, uncivilized, never using
13166 the weapon of persuasion,--he is like a wild beast, all violence and
13167 fierceness, and knows no other way of dealing; and he lives in all
13168 ignorance and evil conditions, and has no sense of propriety and grace.
13169 
13170 That is quite true, he said.
13171 
13172 And as there are two principles of human nature, one the spirited
13173 and the other the philosophical, some God, as I should say, has given
13174 mankind two arts answering to them (and only indirectly to the soul
13175 and body), in order that these two principles (like the strings of
13176 an instrument) may be relaxed or drawn tighter until they are duly
13177 harmonized.
13178 
13179 That appears to be the intention.
13180 
13181 And he who mingles music with gymnastic in the fairest proportions, and
13182 best attempers them to the soul, may be rightly called the true musician
13183 and harmonist in a far higher sense than the tuner of the strings.
13184 
13185 You are quite right, Socrates.
13186 
13187 And such a presiding genius will be always required in our State if the
13188 government is to last.
13189 
13190 Yes, he will be absolutely necessary.
13191 
13192 Such, then, are our principles of nurture and education: Where would be
13193 the use of going into further details about the dances of our citizens,
13194 or about their hunting and coursing, their gymnastic and equestrian
13195 contests? For these all follow the general principle, and having found
13196 that, we shall have no difficulty in discovering them.
13197 
13198 I dare say that there will be no difficulty.
13199 
13200 Very good, I said; then what is the next question? Must we not ask who
13201 are to be rulers and who subjects?
13202 
13203 Certainly.
13204 
13205 There can be no doubt that the elder must rule the younger.
13206 
13207 Clearly.
13208 
13209 And that the best of these must rule.
13210 
13211 That is also clear.
13212 
13213 Now, are not the best husbandmen those who are most devoted to
13214 husbandry?
13215 
13216 Yes.
13217 
13218 And as we are to have the best of guardians for our city, must they not
13219 be those who have most the character of guardians?
13220 
13221 Yes.
13222 
13223 And to this end they ought to be wise and efficient, and to have a
13224 special care of the State?
13225 
13226 True.
13227 
13228 And a man will be most likely to care about that which he loves?
13229 
13230 To be sure.
13231 
13232 And he will be most likely to love that which he regards as having the
13233 same interests with himself, and that of which the good or evil fortune
13234 is supposed by him at any time most to affect his own?
13235 
13236 Very true, he replied.
13237 
13238 Then there must be a selection. Let us note among the guardians those
13239 who in their whole life show the greatest eagerness to do what is for
13240 the good of their country, and the greatest repugnance to do what is
13241 against her interests.
13242 
13243 Those are the right men.
13244 
13245 And they will have to be watched at every age, in order that we may see
13246 whether they preserve their resolution, and never, under the influence
13247 either of force or enchantment, forget or cast off their sense of duty
13248 to the State.
13249 
13250 How cast off? he said.
13251 
13252 I will explain to you, I replied. A resolution may go out of a man's
13253 mind either with his will or against his will; with his will when he
13254 gets rid of a falsehood and learns better, against his will whenever he
13255 is deprived of a truth.
13256 
13257 I understand, he said, the willing loss of a resolution; the meaning of
13258 the unwilling I have yet to learn.
13259 
13260 Why, I said, do you not see that men are unwillingly deprived of good,
13261 and willingly of evil? Is not to have lost the truth an evil, and to
13262 possess the truth a good? and you would agree that to conceive things as
13263 they are is to possess the truth?
13264 
13265 Yes, he replied; I agree with you in thinking that mankind are deprived
13266 of truth against their will.
13267 
13268 And is not this involuntary deprivation caused either by theft, or
13269 force, or enchantment?
13270 
13271 Still, he replied, I do not understand you.
13272 
13273 I fear that I must have been talking darkly, like the tragedians. I only
13274 mean that some men are changed by persuasion and that others forget;
13275 argument steals away the hearts of one class, and time of the other; and
13276 this I call theft. Now you understand me?
13277 
13278 Yes.
13279 
13280 Those again who are forced, are those whom the violence of some pain or
13281 grief compels to change their opinion.
13282 
13283 I understand, he said, and you are quite right.
13284 
13285 And you would also acknowledge that the enchanted are those who change
13286 their minds either under the softer influence of pleasure, or the
13287 sterner influence of fear?
13288 
13289 Yes, he said; everything that deceives may be said to enchant.
13290 
13291 Therefore, as I was just now saying, we must enquire who are the best
13292 guardians of their own conviction that what they think the interest
13293 of the State is to be the rule of their lives. We must watch them from
13294 their youth upwards, and make them perform actions in which they are
13295 most likely to forget or to be deceived, and he who remembers and is
13296 not deceived is to be selected, and he who fails in the trial is to be
13297 rejected. That will be the way?
13298 
13299 Yes.
13300 
13301 And there should also be toils and pains and conflicts prescribed for
13302 them, in which they will be made to give further proof of the same
13303 qualities.
13304 
13305 Very right, he replied.
13306 
13307 And then, I said, we must try them with enchantments--that is the third
13308 sort of test--and see what will be their behaviour: like those who take
13309 colts amid noise and tumult to see if they are of a timid nature, so
13310 must we take our youth amid terrors of some kind, and again pass them
13311 into pleasures, and prove them more thoroughly than gold is proved in
13312 the furnace, that we may discover whether they are armed against
13313 all enchantments, and of a noble bearing always, good guardians of
13314 themselves and of the music which they have learned, and retaining under
13315 all circumstances a rhythmical and harmonious nature, such as will be
13316 most serviceable to the individual and to the State. And he who at every
13317 age, as boy and youth and in mature life, has come out of the trial
13318 victorious and pure, shall be appointed a ruler and guardian of the
13319 State; he shall be honoured in life and death, and shall receive
13320 sepulture and other memorials of honour, the greatest that we have to
13321 give. But him who fails, we must reject. I am inclined to think that
13322 this is the sort of way in which our rulers and guardians should be
13323 chosen and appointed. I speak generally, and not with any pretension to
13324 exactness.
13325 
13326 And, speaking generally, I agree with you, he said.
13327 
13328 And perhaps the word 'guardian' in the fullest sense ought to be applied
13329 to this higher class only who preserve us against foreign enemies and
13330 maintain peace among our citizens at home, that the one may not have the
13331 will, or the others the power, to harm us. The young men whom we
13332 before called guardians may be more properly designated auxiliaries and
13333 supporters of the principles of the rulers.
13334 
13335 I agree with you, he said.
13336 
13337 How then may we devise one of those needful falsehoods of which we
13338 lately spoke--just one royal lie which may deceive the rulers, if that
13339 be possible, and at any rate the rest of the city?
13340 
13341 What sort of lie? he said.
13342 
13343 Nothing new, I replied; only an old Phoenician tale (Laws) of what has
13344 often occurred before now in other places, (as the poets say, and have
13345 made the world believe,) though not in our time, and I do not know
13346 whether such an event could ever happen again, or could now even be made
13347 probable, if it did.
13348 
13349 How your words seem to hesitate on your lips!
13350 
13351 You will not wonder, I replied, at my hesitation when you have heard.
13352 
13353 Speak, he said, and fear not.
13354 
13355 Well then, I will speak, although I really know not how to look you
13356 in the face, or in what words to utter the audacious fiction, which
13357 I propose to communicate gradually, first to the rulers, then to the
13358 soldiers, and lastly to the people. They are to be told that their youth
13359 was a dream, and the education and training which they received from
13360 us, an appearance only; in reality during all that time they were being
13361 formed and fed in the womb of the earth, where they themselves and their
13362 arms and appurtenances were manufactured; when they were completed, the
13363 earth, their mother, sent them up; and so, their country being their
13364 mother and also their nurse, they are bound to advise for her good, and
13365 to defend her against attacks, and her citizens they are to regard as
13366 children of the earth and their own brothers.
13367 
13368 You had good reason, he said, to be ashamed of the lie which you were
13369 going to tell.
13370 
13371 True, I replied, but there is more coming; I have only told you half.
13372 Citizens, we shall say to them in our tale, you are brothers, yet God
13373 has framed you differently. Some of you have the power of command, and
13374 in the composition of these he has mingled gold, wherefore also
13375 they have the greatest honour; others he has made of silver, to be
13376 auxiliaries; others again who are to be husbandmen and craftsmen he has
13377 composed of brass and iron; and the species will generally be preserved
13378 in the children. But as all are of the same original stock, a golden
13379 parent will sometimes have a silver son, or a silver parent a golden
13380 son. And God proclaims as a first principle to the rulers, and above all
13381 else, that there is nothing which they should so anxiously guard, or of
13382 which they are to be such good guardians, as of the purity of the race.
13383 They should observe what elements mingle in their offspring; for if the
13384 son of a golden or silver parent has an admixture of brass and iron,
13385 then nature orders a transposition of ranks, and the eye of the ruler
13386 must not be pitiful towards the child because he has to descend in the
13387 scale and become a husbandman or artisan, just as there may be sons of
13388 artisans who having an admixture of gold or silver in them are raised
13389 to honour, and become guardians or auxiliaries. For an oracle says that
13390 when a man of brass or iron guards the State, it will be destroyed. Such
13391 is the tale; is there any possibility of making our citizens believe in
13392 it?
13393 
13394 Not in the present generation, he replied; there is no way of
13395 accomplishing this; but their sons may be made to believe in the tale,
13396 and their sons' sons, and posterity after them.
13397 
13398 I see the difficulty, I replied; yet the fostering of such a belief will
13399 make them care more for the city and for one another. Enough, however,
13400 of the fiction, which may now fly abroad upon the wings of rumour, while
13401 we arm our earth-born heroes, and lead them forth under the command of
13402 their rulers. Let them look round and select a spot whence they can best
13403 suppress insurrection, if any prove refractory within, and also defend
13404 themselves against enemies, who like wolves may come down on the fold
13405 from without; there let them encamp, and when they have encamped, let
13406 them sacrifice to the proper Gods and prepare their dwellings.
13407 
13408 Just so, he said.
13409 
13410 And their dwellings must be such as will shield them against the cold of
13411 winter and the heat of summer.
13412 
13413 I suppose that you mean houses, he replied.
13414 
13415 Yes, I said; but they must be the houses of soldiers, and not of
13416 shop-keepers.
13417 
13418 What is the difference? he said.
13419 
13420 That I will endeavour to explain, I replied. To keep watch-dogs, who,
13421 from want of discipline or hunger, or some evil habit or other, would
13422 turn upon the sheep and worry them, and behave not like dogs but wolves,
13423 would be a foul and monstrous thing in a shepherd?
13424 
13425 Truly monstrous, he said.
13426 
13427 And therefore every care must be taken that our auxiliaries, being
13428 stronger than our citizens, may not grow to be too much for them and
13429 become savage tyrants instead of friends and allies?
13430 
13431 Yes, great care should be taken.
13432 
13433 And would not a really good education furnish the best safeguard?
13434 
13435 But they are well-educated already, he replied.
13436 
13437 I cannot be so confident, my dear Glaucon, I said; I am much more
13438 certain that they ought to be, and that true education, whatever that
13439 may be, will have the greatest tendency to civilize and humanize them
13440 in their relations to one another, and to those who are under their
13441 protection.
13442 
13443 Very true, he replied.
13444 
13445 And not only their education, but their habitations, and all that
13446 belongs to them, should be such as will neither impair their virtue as
13447 guardians, nor tempt them to prey upon the other citizens. Any man of
13448 sense must acknowledge that.
13449 
13450 He must.
13451 
13452 Then now let us consider what will be their way of life, if they are to
13453 realize our idea of them. In the first place, none of them should have
13454 any property of his own beyond what is absolutely necessary; neither
13455 should they have a private house or store closed against any one who has
13456 a mind to enter; their provisions should be only such as are required
13457 by trained warriors, who are men of temperance and courage; they should
13458 agree to receive from the citizens a fixed rate of pay, enough to meet
13459 the expenses of the year and no more; and they will go to mess and live
13460 together like soldiers in a camp. Gold and silver we will tell them
13461 that they have from God; the diviner metal is within them, and they have
13462 therefore no need of the dross which is current among men, and ought not
13463 to pollute the divine by any such earthly admixture; for that commoner
13464 metal has been the source of many unholy deeds, but their own is
13465 undefiled. And they alone of all the citizens may not touch or handle
13466 silver or gold, or be under the same roof with them, or wear them, or
13467 drink from them. And this will be their salvation, and they will be the
13468 saviours of the State. But should they ever acquire homes or lands
13469 or moneys of their own, they will become housekeepers and husbandmen
13470 instead of guardians, enemies and tyrants instead of allies of the other
13471 citizens; hating and being hated, plotting and being plotted against,
13472 they will pass their whole life in much greater terror of internal than
13473 of external enemies, and the hour of ruin, both to themselves and to the
13474 rest of the State, will be at hand. For all which reasons may we not
13475 say that thus shall our State be ordered, and that these shall be the
13476 regulations appointed by us for guardians concerning their houses and
13477 all other matters?
13478 
13479 Yes, said Glaucon.
13480 
13481 
13482 
13483 
13484 BOOK IV.
13485 
13486 Here Adeimantus interposed a question: How would you answer, Socrates,
13487 said he, if a person were to say that you are making these people
13488 miserable, and that they are the cause of their own unhappiness; the
13489 city in fact belongs to them, but they are none the better for it;
13490 whereas other men acquire lands, and build large and handsome houses,
13491 and have everything handsome about them, offering sacrifices to the gods
13492 on their own account, and practising hospitality; moreover, as you were
13493 saying just now, they have gold and silver, and all that is usual among
13494 the favourites of fortune; but our poor citizens are no better than
13495 mercenaries who are quartered in the city and are always mounting guard?
13496 
13497 Yes, I said; and you may add that they are only fed, and not paid in
13498 addition to their food, like other men; and therefore they cannot, if
13499 they would, take a journey of pleasure; they have no money to spend on
13500 a mistress or any other luxurious fancy, which, as the world goes, is
13501 thought to be happiness; and many other accusations of the same nature
13502 might be added.
13503 
13504 But, said he, let us suppose all this to be included in the charge.
13505 
13506 You mean to ask, I said, what will be our answer?
13507 
13508 Yes.
13509 
13510 If we proceed along the old path, my belief, I said, is that we shall
13511 find the answer. And our answer will be that, even as they are, our
13512 guardians may very likely be the happiest of men; but that our aim in
13513 founding the State was not the disproportionate happiness of any one
13514 class, but the greatest happiness of the whole; we thought that in a
13515 State which is ordered with a view to the good of the whole we should
13516 be most likely to find justice, and in the ill-ordered State injustice:
13517 and, having found them, we might then decide which of the two is the
13518 happier. At present, I take it, we are fashioning the happy State,
13519 not piecemeal, or with a view of making a few happy citizens, but as a
13520 whole; and by-and-by we will proceed to view the opposite kind of State.
13521 Suppose that we were painting a statue, and some one came up to us
13522 and said, Why do you not put the most beautiful colours on the most
13523 beautiful parts of the body--the eyes ought to be purple, but you have
13524 made them black--to him we might fairly answer, Sir, you would not
13525 surely have us beautify the eyes to such a degree that they are no
13526 longer eyes; consider rather whether, by giving this and the other
13527 features their due proportion, we make the whole beautiful. And so I say
13528 to you, do not compel us to assign to the guardians a sort of happiness
13529 which will make them anything but guardians; for we too can clothe our
13530 husbandmen in royal apparel, and set crowns of gold on their heads, and
13531 bid them till the ground as much as they like, and no more. Our potters
13532 also might be allowed to repose on couches, and feast by the fireside,
13533 passing round the winecup, while their wheel is conveniently at hand,
13534 and working at pottery only as much as they like; in this way we might
13535 make every class happy--and then, as you imagine, the whole State would
13536 be happy. But do not put this idea into our heads; for, if we listen
13537 to you, the husbandman will be no longer a husbandman, the potter will
13538 cease to be a potter, and no one will have the character of any distinct
13539 class in the State. Now this is not of much consequence where the
13540 corruption of society, and pretension to be what you are not, is
13541 confined to cobblers; but when the guardians of the laws and of the
13542 government are only seeming and not real guardians, then see how they
13543 turn the State upside down; and on the other hand they alone have the
13544 power of giving order and happiness to the State. We mean our guardians
13545 to be true saviours and not the destroyers of the State, whereas our
13546 opponent is thinking of peasants at a festival, who are enjoying a life
13547 of revelry, not of citizens who are doing their duty to the State. But,
13548 if so, we mean different things, and he is speaking of something which
13549 is not a State. And therefore we must consider whether in appointing
13550 our guardians we would look to their greatest happiness individually, or
13551 whether this principle of happiness does not rather reside in the State
13552 as a whole. But if the latter be the truth, then the guardians and
13553 auxiliaries, and all others equally with them, must be compelled or
13554 induced to do their own work in the best way. And thus the whole State
13555 will grow up in a noble order, and the several classes will receive the
13556 proportion of happiness which nature assigns to them.
13557 
13558 I think that you are quite right.
13559 
13560 I wonder whether you will agree with another remark which occurs to me.
13561 
13562 What may that be?
13563 
13564 There seem to be two causes of the deterioration of the arts.
13565 
13566 What are they?
13567 
13568 Wealth, I said, and poverty.
13569 
13570 How do they act?
13571 
13572 The process is as follows: When a potter becomes rich, will he, think
13573 you, any longer take the same pains with his art?
13574 
13575 Certainly not.
13576 
13577 He will grow more and more indolent and careless?
13578 
13579 Very true.
13580 
13581 And the result will be that he becomes a worse potter?
13582 
13583 Yes; he greatly deteriorates.
13584 
13585 But, on the other hand, if he has no money, and cannot provide himself
13586 with tools or instruments, he will not work equally well himself, nor
13587 will he teach his sons or apprentices to work equally well.
13588 
13589 Certainly not.
13590 
13591 Then, under the influence either of poverty or of wealth, workmen and
13592 their work are equally liable to degenerate?
13593 
13594 That is evident.
13595 
13596 Here, then, is a discovery of new evils, I said, against which
13597 the guardians will have to watch, or they will creep into the city
13598 unobserved.
13599 
13600 What evils?
13601 
13602 Wealth, I said, and poverty; the one is the parent of luxury and
13603 indolence, and the other of meanness and viciousness, and both of
13604 discontent.
13605 
13606 That is very true, he replied; but still I should like to know,
13607 Socrates, how our city will be able to go to war, especially against an
13608 enemy who is rich and powerful, if deprived of the sinews of war.
13609 
13610 There would certainly be a difficulty, I replied, in going to war with
13611 one such enemy; but there is no difficulty where there are two of them.
13612 
13613 How so? he asked.
13614 
13615 In the first place, I said, if we have to fight, our side will be
13616 trained warriors fighting against an army of rich men.
13617 
13618 That is true, he said.
13619 
13620 And do you not suppose, Adeimantus, that a single boxer who was
13621 perfect in his art would easily be a match for two stout and well-to-do
13622 gentlemen who were not boxers?
13623 
13624 Hardly, if they came upon him at once.
13625 
13626 What, now, I said, if he were able to run away and then turn and strike
13627 at the one who first came up? And supposing he were to do this several
13628 times under the heat of a scorching sun, might he not, being an expert,
13629 overturn more than one stout personage?
13630 
13631 Certainly, he said, there would be nothing wonderful in that.
13632 
13633 And yet rich men probably have a greater superiority in the science and
13634 practise of boxing than they have in military qualities.
13635 
13636 Likely enough.
13637 
13638 Then we may assume that our athletes will be able to fight with two or
13639 three times their own number?
13640 
13641 I agree with you, for I think you right.
13642 
13643 And suppose that, before engaging, our citizens send an embassy to one
13644 of the two cities, telling them what is the truth: Silver and gold we
13645 neither have nor are permitted to have, but you may; do you therefore
13646 come and help us in war, and take the spoils of the other city: Who,
13647 on hearing these words, would choose to fight against lean wiry dogs,
13648 rather than, with the dogs on their side, against fat and tender sheep?
13649 
13650 That is not likely; and yet there might be a danger to the poor State if
13651 the wealth of many States were to be gathered into one.
13652 
13653 But how simple of you to use the term State at all of any but our own!
13654 
13655 Why so?
13656 
13657 You ought to speak of other States in the plural number; not one of
13658 them is a city, but many cities, as they say in the game. For indeed any
13659 city, however small, is in fact divided into two, one the city of the
13660 poor, the other of the rich; these are at war with one another; and in
13661 either there are many smaller divisions, and you would be altogether
13662 beside the mark if you treated them all as a single State. But if you
13663 deal with them as many, and give the wealth or power or persons of the
13664 one to the others, you will always have a great many friends and not
13665 many enemies. And your State, while the wise order which has now been
13666 prescribed continues to prevail in her, will be the greatest of States,
13667 I do not mean to say in reputation or appearance, but in deed and truth,
13668 though she number not more than a thousand defenders. A single State
13669 which is her equal you will hardly find, either among Hellenes or
13670 barbarians, though many that appear to be as great and many times
13671 greater.
13672 
13673 That is most true, he said.
13674 
13675 And what, I said, will be the best limit for our rulers to fix when they
13676 are considering the size of the State and the amount of territory which
13677 they are to include, and beyond which they will not go?
13678 
13679 What limit would you propose?
13680 
13681 I would allow the State to increase so far as is consistent with unity;
13682 that, I think, is the proper limit.
13683 
13684 Very good, he said.
13685 
13686 Here then, I said, is another order which will have to be conveyed to
13687 our guardians: Let our city be accounted neither large nor small, but
13688 one and self-sufficing.
13689 
13690 And surely, said he, this is not a very severe order which we impose
13691 upon them.
13692 
13693 And the other, said I, of which we were speaking before is lighter
13694 still,--I mean the duty of degrading the offspring of the guardians when
13695 inferior, and of elevating into the rank of guardians the offspring of
13696 the lower classes, when naturally superior. The intention was, that, in
13697 the case of the citizens generally, each individual should be put to the
13698 use for which nature intended him, one to one work, and then every man
13699 would do his own business, and be one and not many; and so the whole
13700 city would be one and not many.
13701 
13702 Yes, he said; that is not so difficult.
13703 
13704 The regulations which we are prescribing, my good Adeimantus, are not,
13705 as might be supposed, a number of great principles, but trifles all,
13706 if care be taken, as the saying is, of the one great thing,--a thing,
13707 however, which I would rather call, not great, but sufficient for our
13708 purpose.
13709 
13710 What may that be? he asked.
13711 
13712 Education, I said, and nurture: If our citizens are well educated,
13713 and grow into sensible men, they will easily see their way through all
13714 these, as well as other matters which I omit; such, for example, as
13715 marriage, the possession of women and the procreation of children, which
13716 will all follow the general principle that friends have all things in
13717 common, as the proverb says.
13718 
13719 That will be the best way of settling them.
13720 
13721 Also, I said, the State, if once started well, moves with accumulating
13722 force like a wheel. For good nurture and education implant good
13723 constitutions, and these good constitutions taking root in a good
13724 education improve more and more, and this improvement affects the breed
13725 in man as in other animals.
13726 
13727 Very possibly, he said.
13728 
13729 Then to sum up: This is the point to which, above all, the attention of
13730 our rulers should be directed,--that music and gymnastic be preserved in
13731 their original form, and no innovation made. They must do their utmost
13732 to maintain them intact. And when any one says that mankind most regard
13733 
13734 'The newest song which the singers have,'
13735 
13736 they will be afraid that he may be praising, not new songs, but a new
13737 kind of song; and this ought not to be praised, or conceived to be the
13738 meaning of the poet; for any musical innovation is full of danger to the
13739 whole State, and ought to be prohibited. So Damon tells me, and I
13740 can quite believe him;--he says that when modes of music change, the
13741 fundamental laws of the State always change with them.
13742 
13743 Yes, said Adeimantus; and you may add my suffrage to Damon's and your
13744 own.
13745 
13746 Then, I said, our guardians must lay the foundations of their fortress
13747 in music?
13748 
13749 Yes, he said; the lawlessness of which you speak too easily steals in.
13750 
13751 Yes, I replied, in the form of amusement; and at first sight it appears
13752 harmless.
13753 
13754 Why, yes, he said, and there is no harm; were it not that little by
13755 little this spirit of licence, finding a home, imperceptibly penetrates
13756 into manners and customs; whence, issuing with greater force, it invades
13757 contracts between man and man, and from contracts goes on to laws and
13758 constitutions, in utter recklessness, ending at last, Socrates, by an
13759 overthrow of all rights, private as well as public.
13760 
13761 Is that true? I said.
13762 
13763 That is my belief, he replied.
13764 
13765 Then, as I was saying, our youth should be trained from the first in
13766 a stricter system, for if amusements become lawless, and the youths
13767 themselves become lawless, they can never grow up into well-conducted
13768 and virtuous citizens.
13769 
13770 Very true, he said.
13771 
13772 And when they have made a good beginning in play, and by the help of
13773 music have gained the habit of good order, then this habit of order, in
13774 a manner how unlike the lawless play of the others! will accompany them
13775 in all their actions and be a principle of growth to them, and if there
13776 be any fallen places in the State will raise them up again.
13777 
13778 Very true, he said.
13779 
13780 Thus educated, they will invent for themselves any lesser rules which
13781 their predecessors have altogether neglected.
13782 
13783 What do you mean?
13784 
13785 I mean such things as these:--when the young are to be silent before
13786 their elders; how they are to show respect to them by standing and
13787 making them sit; what honour is due to parents; what garments or shoes
13788 are to be worn; the mode of dressing the hair; deportment and manners in
13789 general. You would agree with me?
13790 
13791 Yes.
13792 
13793 But there is, I think, small wisdom in legislating about such
13794 matters,--I doubt if it is ever done; nor are any precise written
13795 enactments about them likely to be lasting.
13796 
13797 Impossible.
13798 
13799 It would seem, Adeimantus, that the direction in which education starts
13800 a man, will determine his future life. Does not like always attract
13801 like?
13802 
13803 To be sure.
13804 
13805 Until some one rare and grand result is reached which may be good, and
13806 may be the reverse of good?
13807 
13808 That is not to be denied.
13809 
13810 And for this reason, I said, I shall not attempt to legislate further
13811 about them.
13812 
13813 Naturally enough, he replied.
13814 
13815 Well, and about the business of the agora, and the ordinary dealings
13816 between man and man, or again about agreements with artisans; about
13817 insult and injury, or the commencement of actions, and the appointment
13818 of juries, what would you say? there may also arise questions about
13819 any impositions and exactions of market and harbour dues which may
13820 be required, and in general about the regulations of markets, police,
13821 harbours, and the like. But, oh heavens! shall we condescend to
13822 legislate on any of these particulars?
13823 
13824 I think, he said, that there is no need to impose laws about them on
13825 good men; what regulations are necessary they will find out soon enough
13826 for themselves.
13827 
13828 Yes, I said, my friend, if God will only preserve to them the laws which
13829 we have given them.
13830 
13831 And without divine help, said Adeimantus, they will go on for ever
13832 making and mending their laws and their lives in the hope of attaining
13833 perfection.
13834 
13835 You would compare them, I said, to those invalids who, having no
13836 self-restraint, will not leave off their habits of intemperance?
13837 
13838 Exactly.
13839 
13840 Yes, I said; and what a delightful life they lead! they are always
13841 doctoring and increasing and complicating their disorders, and always
13842 fancying that they will be cured by any nostrum which anybody advises
13843 them to try.
13844 
13845 Such cases are very common, he said, with invalids of this sort.
13846 
13847 Yes, I replied; and the charming thing is that they deem him their worst
13848 enemy who tells them the truth, which is simply that, unless they give
13849 up eating and drinking and wenching and idling, neither drug nor cautery
13850 nor spell nor amulet nor any other remedy will avail.
13851 
13852 Charming! he replied. I see nothing charming in going into a passion
13853 with a man who tells you what is right.
13854 
13855 These gentlemen, I said, do not seem to be in your good graces.
13856 
13857 Assuredly not.
13858 
13859 Nor would you praise the behaviour of States which act like the men whom
13860 I was just now describing. For are there not ill-ordered States in
13861 which the citizens are forbidden under pain of death to alter the
13862 constitution; and yet he who most sweetly courts those who live under
13863 this regime and indulges them and fawns upon them and is skilful in
13864 anticipating and gratifying their humours is held to be a great and
13865 good statesman--do not these States resemble the persons whom I was
13866 describing?
13867 
13868 Yes, he said; the States are as bad as the men; and I am very far from
13869 praising them.
13870 
13871 But do you not admire, I said, the coolness and dexterity of these ready
13872 ministers of political corruption?
13873 
13874 Yes, he said, I do; but not of all of them, for there are some whom
13875 the applause of the multitude has deluded into the belief that they are
13876 really statesmen, and these are not much to be admired.
13877 
13878 What do you mean? I said; you should have more feeling for them. When a
13879 man cannot measure, and a great many others who cannot measure declare
13880 that he is four cubits high, can he help believing what they say?
13881 
13882 Nay, he said, certainly not in that case.
13883 
13884 Well, then, do not be angry with them; for are they not as good as a
13885 play, trying their hand at paltry reforms such as I was describing; they
13886 are always fancying that by legislation they will make an end of frauds
13887 in contracts, and the other rascalities which I was mentioning, not
13888 knowing that they are in reality cutting off the heads of a hydra?
13889 
13890 Yes, he said; that is just what they are doing.
13891 
13892 I conceive, I said, that the true legislator will not trouble
13893 himself with this class of enactments whether concerning laws or the
13894 constitution either in an ill-ordered or in a well-ordered State; for
13895 in the former they are quite useless, and in the latter there will be no
13896 difficulty in devising them; and many of them will naturally flow out of
13897 our previous regulations.
13898 
13899 What, then, he said, is still remaining to us of the work of
13900 legislation?
13901 
13902 Nothing to us, I replied; but to Apollo, the God of Delphi, there
13903 remains the ordering of the greatest and noblest and chiefest things of
13904 all.
13905 
13906 Which are they? he said.
13907 
13908 The institution of temples and sacrifices, and the entire service of
13909 gods, demigods, and heroes; also the ordering of the repositories of
13910 the dead, and the rites which have to be observed by him who would
13911 propitiate the inhabitants of the world below. These are matters of
13912 which we are ignorant ourselves, and as founders of a city we should be
13913 unwise in trusting them to any interpreter but our ancestral deity. He
13914 is the god who sits in the centre, on the navel of the earth, and he is
13915 the interpreter of religion to all mankind.
13916 
13917 You are right, and we will do as you propose.
13918 
13919 But where, amid all this, is justice? son of Ariston, tell me where. Now
13920 that our city has been made habitable, light a candle and search, and
13921 get your brother and Polemarchus and the rest of our friends to help,
13922 and let us see where in it we can discover justice and where injustice,
13923 and in what they differ from one another, and which of them the man who
13924 would be happy should have for his portion, whether seen or unseen by
13925 gods and men.
13926 
13927 Nonsense, said Glaucon: did you not promise to search yourself, saying
13928 that for you not to help justice in her need would be an impiety?
13929 
13930 I do not deny that I said so, and as you remind me, I will be as good as
13931 my word; but you must join.
13932 
13933 We will, he replied.
13934 
13935 Well, then, I hope to make the discovery in this way: I mean to begin
13936 with the assumption that our State, if rightly ordered, is perfect.
13937 
13938 That is most certain.
13939 
13940 And being perfect, is therefore wise and valiant and temperate and just.
13941 
13942 That is likewise clear.
13943 
13944 And whichever of these qualities we find in the State, the one which is
13945 not found will be the residue?
13946 
13947 Very good.
13948 
13949 If there were four things, and we were searching for one of them,
13950 wherever it might be, the one sought for might be known to us from the
13951 first, and there would be no further trouble; or we might know the other
13952 three first, and then the fourth would clearly be the one left.
13953 
13954 Very true, he said.
13955 
13956 And is not a similar method to be pursued about the virtues, which are
13957 also four in number?
13958 
13959 Clearly.
13960 
13961 First among the virtues found in the State, wisdom comes into view, and
13962 in this I detect a certain peculiarity.
13963 
13964 What is that?
13965 
13966 The State which we have been describing is said to be wise as being good
13967 in counsel?
13968 
13969 Very true.
13970 
13971 And good counsel is clearly a kind of knowledge, for not by ignorance,
13972 but by knowledge, do men counsel well?
13973 
13974 Clearly.
13975 
13976 And the kinds of knowledge in a State are many and diverse?
13977 
13978 Of course.
13979 
13980 There is the knowledge of the carpenter; but is that the sort of
13981 knowledge which gives a city the title of wise and good in counsel?
13982 
13983 Certainly not; that would only give a city the reputation of skill in
13984 carpentering.
13985 
13986 Then a city is not to be called wise because possessing a knowledge
13987 which counsels for the best about wooden implements?
13988 
13989 Certainly not.
13990 
13991 Nor by reason of a knowledge which advises about brazen pots, I said,
13992 nor as possessing any other similar knowledge?
13993 
13994 Not by reason of any of them, he said.
13995 
13996 Nor yet by reason of a knowledge which cultivates the earth; that would
13997 give the city the name of agricultural?
13998 
13999 Yes.
14000 
14001 Well, I said, and is there any knowledge in our recently-founded State
14002 among any of the citizens which advises, not about any particular thing
14003 in the State, but about the whole, and considers how a State can best
14004 deal with itself and with other States?
14005 
14006 There certainly is.
14007 
14008 And what is this knowledge, and among whom is it found? I asked.
14009 
14010 It is the knowledge of the guardians, he replied, and is found among
14011 those whom we were just now describing as perfect guardians.
14012 
14013 And what is the name which the city derives from the possession of this
14014 sort of knowledge?
14015 
14016 The name of good in counsel and truly wise.
14017 
14018 And will there be in our city more of these true guardians or more
14019 smiths?
14020 
14021 The smiths, he replied, will be far more numerous.
14022 
14023 Will not the guardians be the smallest of all the classes who receive a
14024 name from the profession of some kind of knowledge?
14025 
14026 Much the smallest.
14027 
14028 And so by reason of the smallest part or class, and of the knowledge
14029 which resides in this presiding and ruling part of itself, the whole
14030 State, being thus constituted according to nature, will be wise; and
14031 this, which has the only knowledge worthy to be called wisdom, has been
14032 ordained by nature to be of all classes the least.
14033 
14034 Most true.
14035 
14036 Thus, then, I said, the nature and place in the State of one of the four
14037 virtues has somehow or other been discovered.
14038 
14039 And, in my humble opinion, very satisfactorily discovered, he replied.
14040 
14041 Again, I said, there is no difficulty in seeing the nature of courage,
14042 and in what part that quality resides which gives the name of courageous
14043 to the State.
14044 
14045 How do you mean?
14046 
14047 Why, I said, every one who calls any State courageous or cowardly, will
14048 be thinking of the part which fights and goes out to war on the State's
14049 behalf.
14050 
14051 No one, he replied, would ever think of any other.
14052 
14053 The rest of the citizens may be courageous or may be cowardly, but their
14054 courage or cowardice will not, as I conceive, have the effect of making
14055 the city either the one or the other.
14056 
14057 Certainly not.
14058 
14059 The city will be courageous in virtue of a portion of herself which
14060 preserves under all circumstances that opinion about the nature of
14061 things to be feared and not to be feared in which our legislator
14062 educated them; and this is what you term courage.
14063 
14064 I should like to hear what you are saying once more, for I do not think
14065 that I perfectly understand you.
14066 
14067 I mean that courage is a kind of salvation.
14068 
14069 Salvation of what?
14070 
14071 Of the opinion respecting things to be feared, what they are and of
14072 what nature, which the law implants through education; and I mean by the
14073 words 'under all circumstances' to intimate that in pleasure or in pain,
14074 or under the influence of desire or fear, a man preserves, and does not
14075 lose this opinion. Shall I give you an illustration?
14076 
14077 If you please.
14078 
14079 You know, I said, that dyers, when they want to dye wool for making the
14080 true sea-purple, begin by selecting their white colour first; this they
14081 prepare and dress with much care and pains, in order that the white
14082 ground may take the purple hue in full perfection. The dyeing then
14083 proceeds; and whatever is dyed in this manner becomes a fast colour,
14084 and no washing either with lyes or without them can take away the bloom.
14085 But, when the ground has not been duly prepared, you will have noticed
14086 how poor is the look either of purple or of any other colour.
14087 
14088 Yes, he said; I know that they have a washed-out and ridiculous
14089 appearance.
14090 
14091 Then now, I said, you will understand what our object was in selecting
14092 our soldiers, and educating them in music and gymnastic; we were
14093 contriving influences which would prepare them to take the dye of the
14094 laws in perfection, and the colour of their opinion about dangers and
14095 of every other opinion was to be indelibly fixed by their nurture
14096 and training, not to be washed away by such potent lyes as
14097 pleasure--mightier agent far in washing the soul than any soda or lye;
14098 or by sorrow, fear, and desire, the mightiest of all other solvents. And
14099 this sort of universal saving power of true opinion in conformity with
14100 law about real and false dangers I call and maintain to be courage,
14101 unless you disagree.
14102 
14103 But I agree, he replied; for I suppose that you mean to exclude mere
14104 uninstructed courage, such as that of a wild beast or of a slave--this,
14105 in your opinion, is not the courage which the law ordains, and ought to
14106 have another name.
14107 
14108 Most certainly.
14109 
14110 Then I may infer courage to be such as you describe?
14111 
14112 Why, yes, said I, you may, and if you add the words 'of a citizen,'
14113 you will not be far wrong;--hereafter, if you like, we will carry the
14114 examination further, but at present we are seeking not for courage but
14115 justice; and for the purpose of our enquiry we have said enough.
14116 
14117 You are right, he replied.
14118 
14119 Two virtues remain to be discovered in the State--first, temperance, and
14120 then justice which is the end of our search.
14121 
14122 Very true.
14123 
14124 Now, can we find justice without troubling ourselves about temperance?
14125 
14126 I do not know how that can be accomplished, he said, nor do I desire
14127 that justice should be brought to light and temperance lost sight of;
14128 and therefore I wish that you would do me the favour of considering
14129 temperance first.
14130 
14131 Certainly, I replied, I should not be justified in refusing your
14132 request.
14133 
14134 Then consider, he said.
14135 
14136 Yes, I replied; I will; and as far as I can at present see, the virtue
14137 of temperance has more of the nature of harmony and symphony than the
14138 preceding.
14139 
14140 How so? he asked.
14141 
14142 Temperance, I replied, is the ordering or controlling of certain
14143 pleasures and desires; this is curiously enough implied in the saying of
14144 'a man being his own master;' and other traces of the same notion may be
14145 found in language.
14146 
14147 No doubt, he said.
14148 
14149 There is something ridiculous in the expression 'master of himself;' for
14150 the master is also the servant and the servant the master; and in all
14151 these modes of speaking the same person is denoted.
14152 
14153 Certainly.
14154 
14155 The meaning is, I believe, that in the human soul there is a better and
14156 also a worse principle; and when the better has the worse under control,
14157 then a man is said to be master of himself; and this is a term of
14158 praise: but when, owing to evil education or association, the better
14159 principle, which is also the smaller, is overwhelmed by the greater mass
14160 of the worse--in this case he is blamed and is called the slave of self
14161 and unprincipled.
14162 
14163 Yes, there is reason in that.
14164 
14165 And now, I said, look at our newly-created State, and there you will
14166 find one of these two conditions realized; for the State, as you
14167 will acknowledge, may be justly called master of itself, if the words
14168 'temperance' and 'self-mastery' truly express the rule of the better
14169 part over the worse.
14170 
14171 Yes, he said, I see that what you say is true.
14172 
14173 Let me further note that the manifold and complex pleasures and desires
14174 and pains are generally found in children and women and servants, and in
14175 the freemen so called who are of the lowest and more numerous class.
14176 
14177 Certainly, he said.
14178 
14179 Whereas the simple and moderate desires which follow reason, and are
14180 under the guidance of mind and true opinion, are to be found only in a
14181 few, and those the best born and best educated.
14182 
14183 Very true.
14184 
14185 These two, as you may perceive, have a place in our State; and the
14186 meaner desires of the many are held down by the virtuous desires and
14187 wisdom of the few.
14188 
14189 That I perceive, he said.
14190 
14191 Then if there be any city which may be described as master of its own
14192 pleasures and desires, and master of itself, ours may claim such a
14193 designation?
14194 
14195 Certainly, he replied.
14196 
14197 It may also be called temperate, and for the same reasons?
14198 
14199 Yes.
14200 
14201 And if there be any State in which rulers and subjects will be agreed as
14202 to the question who are to rule, that again will be our State?
14203 
14204 Undoubtedly.
14205 
14206 And the citizens being thus agreed among themselves, in which class will
14207 temperance be found--in the rulers or in the subjects?
14208 
14209 In both, as I should imagine, he replied.
14210 
14211 Do you observe that we were not far wrong in our guess that temperance
14212 was a sort of harmony?
14213 
14214 Why so?
14215 
14216 Why, because temperance is unlike courage and wisdom, each of which
14217 resides in a part only, the one making the State wise and the other
14218 valiant; not so temperance, which extends to the whole, and runs through
14219 all the notes of the scale, and produces a harmony of the weaker and the
14220 stronger and the middle class, whether you suppose them to be stronger
14221 or weaker in wisdom or power or numbers or wealth, or anything else.
14222 Most truly then may we deem temperance to be the agreement of the
14223 naturally superior and inferior, as to the right to rule of either, both
14224 in states and individuals.
14225 
14226 I entirely agree with you.
14227 
14228 And so, I said, we may consider three out of the four virtues to have
14229 been discovered in our State. The last of those qualities which make a
14230 state virtuous must be justice, if we only knew what that was.
14231 
14232 The inference is obvious.
14233 
14234 The time then has arrived, Glaucon, when, like huntsmen, we should
14235 surround the cover, and look sharp that justice does not steal away, and
14236 pass out of sight and escape us; for beyond a doubt she is somewhere in
14237 this country: watch therefore and strive to catch a sight of her, and if
14238 you see her first, let me know.
14239 
14240 Would that I could! but you should regard me rather as a follower who
14241 has just eyes enough to see what you show him--that is about as much as
14242 I am good for.
14243 
14244 Offer up a prayer with me and follow.
14245 
14246 I will, but you must show me the way.
14247 
14248 Here is no path, I said, and the wood is dark and perplexing; still we
14249 must push on.
14250 
14251 Let us push on.
14252 
14253 Here I saw something: Halloo! I said, I begin to perceive a track, and I
14254 believe that the quarry will not escape.
14255 
14256 Good news, he said.
14257 
14258 Truly, I said, we are stupid fellows.
14259 
14260 Why so?
14261 
14262 Why, my good sir, at the beginning of our enquiry, ages ago, there was
14263 justice tumbling out at our feet, and we never saw her; nothing could be
14264 more ridiculous. Like people who go about looking for what they have
14265 in their hands--that was the way with us--we looked not at what we
14266 were seeking, but at what was far off in the distance; and therefore, I
14267 suppose, we missed her.
14268 
14269 What do you mean?
14270 
14271 I mean to say that in reality for a long time past we have been talking
14272 of justice, and have failed to recognise her.
14273 
14274 I grow impatient at the length of your exordium.
14275 
14276 Well then, tell me, I said, whether I am right or not: You remember the
14277 original principle which we were always laying down at the foundation
14278 of the State, that one man should practise one thing only, the thing to
14279 which his nature was best adapted;--now justice is this principle or a
14280 part of it.
14281 
14282 Yes, we often said that one man should do one thing only.
14283 
14284 Further, we affirmed that justice was doing one's own business, and not
14285 being a busybody; we said so again and again, and many others have said
14286 the same to us.
14287 
14288 Yes, we said so.
14289 
14290 Then to do one's own business in a certain way may be assumed to be
14291 justice. Can you tell me whence I derive this inference?
14292 
14293 I cannot, but I should like to be told.
14294 
14295 Because I think that this is the only virtue which remains in the
14296 State when the other virtues of temperance and courage and wisdom are
14297 abstracted; and, that this is the ultimate cause and condition of the
14298 existence of all of them, and while remaining in them is also their
14299 preservative; and we were saying that if the three were discovered by
14300 us, justice would be the fourth or remaining one.
14301 
14302 That follows of necessity.
14303 
14304 If we are asked to determine which of these four qualities by its
14305 presence contributes most to the excellence of the State, whether the
14306 agreement of rulers and subjects, or the preservation in the soldiers of
14307 the opinion which the law ordains about the true nature of dangers, or
14308 wisdom and watchfulness in the rulers, or whether this other which I am
14309 mentioning, and which is found in children and women, slave and freeman,
14310 artisan, ruler, subject,--the quality, I mean, of every one doing his
14311 own work, and not being a busybody, would claim the palm--the question
14312 is not so easily answered.
14313 
14314 Certainly, he replied, there would be a difficulty in saying which.
14315 
14316 Then the power of each individual in the State to do his own work
14317 appears to compete with the other political virtues, wisdom, temperance,
14318 courage.
14319 
14320 Yes, he said.
14321 
14322 And the virtue which enters into this competition is justice?
14323 
14324 Exactly.
14325 
14326 Let us look at the question from another point of view: Are not
14327 the rulers in a State those to whom you would entrust the office of
14328 determining suits at law?
14329 
14330 Certainly.
14331 
14332 And are suits decided on any other ground but that a man may neither
14333 take what is another's, nor be deprived of what is his own?
14334 
14335 Yes; that is their principle.
14336 
14337 Which is a just principle?
14338 
14339 Yes.
14340 
14341 Then on this view also justice will be admitted to be the having and
14342 doing what is a man's own, and belongs to him?
14343 
14344 Very true.
14345 
14346 Think, now, and say whether you agree with me or not. Suppose a
14347 carpenter to be doing the business of a cobbler, or a cobbler of a
14348 carpenter; and suppose them to exchange their implements or their
