14349 duties, or the same person to be doing the work of both, or whatever be
14350 the change; do you think that any great harm would result to the State?
14351 
14352 Not much.
14353 
14354 But when the cobbler or any other man whom nature designed to be a
14355 trader, having his heart lifted up by wealth or strength or the number
14356 of his followers, or any like advantage, attempts to force his way
14357 into the class of warriors, or a warrior into that of legislators and
14358 guardians, for which he is unfitted, and either to take the implements
14359 or the duties of the other; or when one man is trader, legislator, and
14360 warrior all in one, then I think you will agree with me in saying that
14361 this interchange and this meddling of one with another is the ruin of
14362 the State.
14363 
14364 Most true.
14365 
14366 Seeing then, I said, that there are three distinct classes, any meddling
14367 of one with another, or the change of one into another, is the greatest
14368 harm to the State, and may be most justly termed evil-doing?
14369 
14370 Precisely.
14371 
14372 And the greatest degree of evil-doing to one's own city would be termed
14373 by you injustice?
14374 
14375 Certainly.
14376 
14377 This then is injustice; and on the other hand when the trader, the
14378 auxiliary, and the guardian each do their own business, that is justice,
14379 and will make the city just.
14380 
14381 I agree with you.
14382 
14383 We will not, I said, be over-positive as yet; but if, on trial, this
14384 conception of justice be verified in the individual as well as in
14385 the State, there will be no longer any room for doubt; if it be not
14386 verified, we must have a fresh enquiry. First let us complete the old
14387 investigation, which we began, as you remember, under the impression
14388 that, if we could previously examine justice on the larger scale, there
14389 would be less difficulty in discerning her in the individual. That
14390 larger example appeared to be the State, and accordingly we constructed
14391 as good a one as we could, knowing well that in the good State justice
14392 would be found. Let the discovery which we made be now applied to the
14393 individual--if they agree, we shall be satisfied; or, if there be a
14394 difference in the individual, we will come back to the State and
14395 have another trial of the theory. The friction of the two when rubbed
14396 together may possibly strike a light in which justice will shine forth,
14397 and the vision which is then revealed we will fix in our souls.
14398 
14399 That will be in regular course; let us do as you say.
14400 
14401 I proceeded to ask: When two things, a greater and less, are called by
14402 the same name, are they like or unlike in so far as they are called the
14403 same?
14404 
14405 Like, he replied.
14406 
14407 The just man then, if we regard the idea of justice only, will be like
14408 the just State?
14409 
14410 He will.
14411 
14412 And a State was thought by us to be just when the three classes in the
14413 State severally did their own business; and also thought to be temperate
14414 and valiant and wise by reason of certain other affections and qualities
14415 of these same classes?
14416 
14417 True, he said.
14418 
14419 And so of the individual; we may assume that he has the same three
14420 principles in his own soul which are found in the State; and he may be
14421 rightly described in the same terms, because he is affected in the same
14422 manner?
14423 
14424 Certainly, he said.
14425 
14426 Once more then, O my friend, we have alighted upon an easy
14427 question--whether the soul has these three principles or not?
14428 
14429 An easy question! Nay, rather, Socrates, the proverb holds that hard is
14430 the good.
14431 
14432 Very true, I said; and I do not think that the method which we are
14433 employing is at all adequate to the accurate solution of this question;
14434 the true method is another and a longer one. Still we may arrive at a
14435 solution not below the level of the previous enquiry.
14436 
14437 May we not be satisfied with that? he said;--under the circumstances, I
14438 am quite content.
14439 
14440 I too, I replied, shall be extremely well satisfied.
14441 
14442 Then faint not in pursuing the speculation, he said.
14443 
14444 Must we not acknowledge, I said, that in each of us there are the same
14445 principles and habits which there are in the State; and that from the
14446 individual they pass into the State?--how else can they come there? Take
14447 the quality of passion or spirit;--it would be ridiculous to imagine
14448 that this quality, when found in States, is not derived from the
14449 individuals who are supposed to possess it, e.g. the Thracians,
14450 Scythians, and in general the northern nations; and the same may be said
14451 of the love of knowledge, which is the special characteristic of our
14452 part of the world, or of the love of money, which may, with equal truth,
14453 be attributed to the Phoenicians and Egyptians.
14454 
14455 Exactly so, he said.
14456 
14457 There is no difficulty in understanding this.
14458 
14459 None whatever.
14460 
14461 But the question is not quite so easy when we proceed to ask whether
14462 these principles are three or one; whether, that is to say, we learn
14463 with one part of our nature, are angry with another, and with a third
14464 part desire the satisfaction of our natural appetites; or whether the
14465 whole soul comes into play in each sort of action--to determine that is
14466 the difficulty.
14467 
14468 Yes, he said; there lies the difficulty.
14469 
14470 Then let us now try and determine whether they are the same or
14471 different.
14472 
14473 How can we? he asked.
14474 
14475 I replied as follows: The same thing clearly cannot act or be acted upon
14476 in the same part or in relation to the same thing at the same time,
14477 in contrary ways; and therefore whenever this contradiction occurs in
14478 things apparently the same, we know that they are really not the same,
14479 but different.
14480 
14481 Good.
14482 
14483 For example, I said, can the same thing be at rest and in motion at the
14484 same time in the same part?
14485 
14486 Impossible.
14487 
14488 Still, I said, let us have a more precise statement of terms, lest we
14489 should hereafter fall out by the way. Imagine the case of a man who is
14490 standing and also moving his hands and his head, and suppose a person
14491 to say that one and the same person is in motion and at rest at the same
14492 moment--to such a mode of speech we should object, and should rather say
14493 that one part of him is in motion while another is at rest.
14494 
14495 Very true.
14496 
14497 And suppose the objector to refine still further, and to draw the nice
14498 distinction that not only parts of tops, but whole tops, when they spin
14499 round with their pegs fixed on the spot, are at rest and in motion at
14500 the same time (and he may say the same of anything which revolves in the
14501 same spot), his objection would not be admitted by us, because in
14502 such cases things are not at rest and in motion in the same parts of
14503 themselves; we should rather say that they have both an axis and a
14504 circumference, and that the axis stands still, for there is no deviation
14505 from the perpendicular; and that the circumference goes round. But if,
14506 while revolving, the axis inclines either to the right or left, forwards
14507 or backwards, then in no point of view can they be at rest.
14508 
14509 That is the correct mode of describing them, he replied.
14510 
14511 Then none of these objections will confuse us, or incline us to believe
14512 that the same thing at the same time, in the same part or in relation to
14513 the same thing, can act or be acted upon in contrary ways.
14514 
14515 Certainly not, according to my way of thinking.
14516 
14517 Yet, I said, that we may not be compelled to examine all such
14518 objections, and prove at length that they are untrue, let us assume
14519 their absurdity, and go forward on the understanding that hereafter, if
14520 this assumption turn out to be untrue, all the consequences which follow
14521 shall be withdrawn.
14522 
14523 Yes, he said, that will be the best way.
14524 
14525 Well, I said, would you not allow that assent and dissent, desire and
14526 aversion, attraction and repulsion, are all of them opposites, whether
14527 they are regarded as active or passive (for that makes no difference in
14528 the fact of their opposition)?
14529 
14530 Yes, he said, they are opposites.
14531 
14532 Well, I said, and hunger and thirst, and the desires in general, and
14533 again willing and wishing,--all these you would refer to the classes
14534 already mentioned. You would say--would you not?--that the soul of him
14535 who desires is seeking after the object of his desire; or that he is
14536 drawing to himself the thing which he wishes to possess: or again,
14537 when a person wants anything to be given him, his mind, longing for the
14538 realization of his desire, intimates his wish to have it by a nod of
14539 assent, as if he had been asked a question?
14540 
14541 Very true.
14542 
14543 And what would you say of unwillingness and dislike and the absence of
14544 desire; should not these be referred to the opposite class of repulsion
14545 and rejection?
14546 
14547 Certainly.
14548 
14549 Admitting this to be true of desire generally, let us suppose a
14550 particular class of desires, and out of these we will select hunger and
14551 thirst, as they are termed, which are the most obvious of them?
14552 
14553 Let us take that class, he said.
14554 
14555 The object of one is food, and of the other drink?
14556 
14557 Yes.
14558 
14559 And here comes the point: is not thirst the desire which the soul has of
14560 drink, and of drink only; not of drink qualified by anything else; for
14561 example, warm or cold, or much or little, or, in a word, drink of any
14562 particular sort: but if the thirst be accompanied by heat, then the
14563 desire is of cold drink; or, if accompanied by cold, then of warm drink;
14564 or, if the thirst be excessive, then the drink which is desired will be
14565 excessive; or, if not great, the quantity of drink will also be small:
14566 but thirst pure and simple will desire drink pure and simple, which is
14567 the natural satisfaction of thirst, as food is of hunger?
14568 
14569 Yes, he said; the simple desire is, as you say, in every case of the
14570 simple object, and the qualified desire of the qualified object.
14571 
14572 But here a confusion may arise; and I should wish to guard against an
14573 opponent starting up and saying that no man desires drink only, but good
14574 drink, or food only, but good food; for good is the universal object of
14575 desire, and thirst being a desire, will necessarily be thirst after good
14576 drink; and the same is true of every other desire.
14577 
14578 Yes, he replied, the opponent might have something to say.
14579 
14580 Nevertheless I should still maintain, that of relatives some have a
14581 quality attached to either term of the relation; others are simple and
14582 have their correlatives simple.
14583 
14584 I do not know what you mean.
14585 
14586 Well, you know of course that the greater is relative to the less?
14587 
14588 Certainly.
14589 
14590 And the much greater to the much less?
14591 
14592 Yes.
14593 
14594 And the sometime greater to the sometime less, and the greater that is
14595 to be to the less that is to be?
14596 
14597 Certainly, he said.
14598 
14599 And so of more and less, and of other correlative terms, such as the
14600 double and the half, or again, the heavier and the lighter, the swifter
14601 and the slower; and of hot and cold, and of any other relatives;--is not
14602 this true of all of them?
14603 
14604 Yes.
14605 
14606 And does not the same principle hold in the sciences? The object of
14607 science is knowledge (assuming that to be the true definition), but
14608 the object of a particular science is a particular kind of knowledge;
14609 I mean, for example, that the science of house-building is a kind of
14610 knowledge which is defined and distinguished from other kinds and is
14611 therefore termed architecture.
14612 
14613 Certainly.
14614 
14615 Because it has a particular quality which no other has?
14616 
14617 Yes.
14618 
14619 And it has this particular quality because it has an object of a
14620 particular kind; and this is true of the other arts and sciences?
14621 
14622 Yes.
14623 
14624 Now, then, if I have made myself clear, you will understand my original
14625 meaning in what I said about relatives. My meaning was, that if one term
14626 of a relation is taken alone, the other is taken alone; if one term
14627 is qualified, the other is also qualified. I do not mean to say that
14628 relatives may not be disparate, or that the science of health is
14629 healthy, or of disease necessarily diseased, or that the sciences of
14630 good and evil are therefore good and evil; but only that, when the term
14631 science is no longer used absolutely, but has a qualified object which
14632 in this case is the nature of health and disease, it becomes defined,
14633 and is hence called not merely science, but the science of medicine.
14634 
14635 I quite understand, and I think as you do.
14636 
14637 Would you not say that thirst is one of these essentially relative
14638 terms, having clearly a relation--
14639 
14640 Yes, thirst is relative to drink.
14641 
14642 And a certain kind of thirst is relative to a certain kind of drink; but
14643 thirst taken alone is neither of much nor little, nor of good nor bad,
14644 nor of any particular kind of drink, but of drink only?
14645 
14646 Certainly.
14647 
14648 Then the soul of the thirsty one, in so far as he is thirsty, desires
14649 only drink; for this he yearns and tries to obtain it?
14650 
14651 That is plain.
14652 
14653 And if you suppose something which pulls a thirsty soul away from drink,
14654 that must be different from the thirsty principle which draws him like
14655 a beast to drink; for, as we were saying, the same thing cannot at the
14656 same time with the same part of itself act in contrary ways about the
14657 same.
14658 
14659 Impossible.
14660 
14661 No more than you can say that the hands of the archer push and pull the
14662 bow at the same time, but what you say is that one hand pushes and the
14663 other pulls.
14664 
14665 Exactly so, he replied.
14666 
14667 And might a man be thirsty, and yet unwilling to drink?
14668 
14669 Yes, he said, it constantly happens.
14670 
14671 And in such a case what is one to say? Would you not say that there
14672 was something in the soul bidding a man to drink, and something else
14673 forbidding him, which is other and stronger than the principle which
14674 bids him?
14675 
14676 I should say so.
14677 
14678 And the forbidding principle is derived from reason, and that which bids
14679 and attracts proceeds from passion and disease?
14680 
14681 Clearly.
14682 
14683 Then we may fairly assume that they are two, and that they differ from
14684 one another; the one with which a man reasons, we may call the rational
14685 principle of the soul, the other, with which he loves and hungers and
14686 thirsts and feels the flutterings of any other desire, may be termed
14687 the irrational or appetitive, the ally of sundry pleasures and
14688 satisfactions?
14689 
14690 Yes, he said, we may fairly assume them to be different.
14691 
14692 Then let us finally determine that there are two principles existing in
14693 the soul. And what of passion, or spirit? Is it a third, or akin to one
14694 of the preceding?
14695 
14696 I should be inclined to say--akin to desire.
14697 
14698 Well, I said, there is a story which I remember to have heard, and in
14699 which I put faith. The story is, that Leontius, the son of Aglaion,
14700 coming up one day from the Piraeus, under the north wall on the outside,
14701 observed some dead bodies lying on the ground at the place of execution.
14702 He felt a desire to see them, and also a dread and abhorrence of them;
14703 for a time he struggled and covered his eyes, but at length the desire
14704 got the better of him; and forcing them open, he ran up to the dead
14705 bodies, saying, Look, ye wretches, take your fill of the fair sight.
14706 
14707 I have heard the story myself, he said.
14708 
14709 The moral of the tale is, that anger at times goes to war with desire,
14710 as though they were two distinct things.
14711 
14712 Yes; that is the meaning, he said.
14713 
14714 And are there not many other cases in which we observe that when a man's
14715 desires violently prevail over his reason, he reviles himself, and is
14716 angry at the violence within him, and that in this struggle, which is
14717 like the struggle of factions in a State, his spirit is on the side of
14718 his reason;--but for the passionate or spirited element to take part
14719 with the desires when reason decides that she should not be opposed,
14720 is a sort of thing which I believe that you never observed occurring in
14721 yourself, nor, as I should imagine, in any one else?
14722 
14723 Certainly not.
14724 
14725 Suppose that a man thinks he has done a wrong to another, the nobler
14726 he is the less able is he to feel indignant at any suffering, such as
14727 hunger, or cold, or any other pain which the injured person may inflict
14728 upon him--these he deems to be just, and, as I say, his anger refuses to
14729 be excited by them.
14730 
14731 True, he said.
14732 
14733 But when he thinks that he is the sufferer of the wrong, then he boils
14734 and chafes, and is on the side of what he believes to be justice; and
14735 because he suffers hunger or cold or other pain he is only the more
14736 determined to persevere and conquer. His noble spirit will not be
14737 quelled until he either slays or is slain; or until he hears the voice
14738 of the shepherd, that is, reason, bidding his dog bark no more.
14739 
14740 The illustration is perfect, he replied; and in our State, as we were
14741 saying, the auxiliaries were to be dogs, and to hear the voice of the
14742 rulers, who are their shepherds.
14743 
14744 I perceive, I said, that you quite understand me; there is, however, a
14745 further point which I wish you to consider.
14746 
14747 What point?
14748 
14749 You remember that passion or spirit appeared at first sight to be a kind
14750 of desire, but now we should say quite the contrary; for in the conflict
14751 of the soul spirit is arrayed on the side of the rational principle.
14752 
14753 Most assuredly.
14754 
14755 But a further question arises: Is passion different from reason also, or
14756 only a kind of reason; in which latter case, instead of three principles
14757 in the soul, there will only be two, the rational and the concupiscent;
14758 or rather, as the State was composed of three classes, traders,
14759 auxiliaries, counsellors, so may there not be in the individual soul a
14760 third element which is passion or spirit, and when not corrupted by bad
14761 education is the natural auxiliary of reason?
14762 
14763 Yes, he said, there must be a third.
14764 
14765 Yes, I replied, if passion, which has already been shown to be different
14766 from desire, turn out also to be different from reason.
14767 
14768 But that is easily proved:--We may observe even in young children that
14769 they are full of spirit almost as soon as they are born, whereas some
14770 of them never seem to attain to the use of reason, and most of them late
14771 enough.
14772 
14773 Excellent, I said, and you may see passion equally in brute animals,
14774 which is a further proof of the truth of what you are saying. And we may
14775 once more appeal to the words of Homer, which have been already quoted
14776 by us,
14777 
14778 'He smote his breast, and thus rebuked his soul,'
14779 
14780 for in this verse Homer has clearly supposed the power which reasons
14781 about the better and worse to be different from the unreasoning anger
14782 which is rebuked by it.
14783 
14784 Very true, he said.
14785 
14786 And so, after much tossing, we have reached land, and are fairly agreed
14787 that the same principles which exist in the State exist also in the
14788 individual, and that they are three in number.
14789 
14790 Exactly.
14791 
14792 Must we not then infer that the individual is wise in the same way, and
14793 in virtue of the same quality which makes the State wise?
14794 
14795 Certainly.
14796 
14797 Also that the same quality which constitutes courage in the State
14798 constitutes courage in the individual, and that both the State and the
14799 individual bear the same relation to all the other virtues?
14800 
14801 Assuredly.
14802 
14803 And the individual will be acknowledged by us to be just in the same way
14804 in which the State is just?
14805 
14806 That follows, of course.
14807 
14808 We cannot but remember that the justice of the State consisted in each
14809 of the three classes doing the work of its own class?
14810 
14811 We are not very likely to have forgotten, he said.
14812 
14813 We must recollect that the individual in whom the several qualities of
14814 his nature do their own work will be just, and will do his own work?
14815 
14816 Yes, he said, we must remember that too.
14817 
14818 And ought not the rational principle, which is wise, and has the care of
14819 the whole soul, to rule, and the passionate or spirited principle to be
14820 the subject and ally?
14821 
14822 Certainly.
14823 
14824 And, as we were saying, the united influence of music and gymnastic will
14825 bring them into accord, nerving and sustaining the reason with noble
14826 words and lessons, and moderating and soothing and civilizing the
14827 wildness of passion by harmony and rhythm?
14828 
14829 Quite true, he said.
14830 
14831 And these two, thus nurtured and educated, and having learned truly to
14832 know their own functions, will rule over the concupiscent, which in each
14833 of us is the largest part of the soul and by nature most insatiable of
14834 gain; over this they will keep guard, lest, waxing great and strong with
14835 the fulness of bodily pleasures, as they are termed, the concupiscent
14836 soul, no longer confined to her own sphere, should attempt to enslave
14837 and rule those who are not her natural-born subjects, and overturn the
14838 whole life of man?
14839 
14840 Very true, he said.
14841 
14842 Both together will they not be the best defenders of the whole soul and
14843 the whole body against attacks from without; the one counselling, and
14844 the other fighting under his leader, and courageously executing his
14845 commands and counsels?
14846 
14847 True.
14848 
14849 And he is to be deemed courageous whose spirit retains in pleasure and
14850 in pain the commands of reason about what he ought or ought not to fear?
14851 
14852 Right, he replied.
14853 
14854 And him we call wise who has in him that little part which rules, and
14855 which proclaims these commands; that part too being supposed to have a
14856 knowledge of what is for the interest of each of the three parts and of
14857 the whole?
14858 
14859 Assuredly.
14860 
14861 And would you not say that he is temperate who has these same elements
14862 in friendly harmony, in whom the one ruling principle of reason, and
14863 the two subject ones of spirit and desire are equally agreed that reason
14864 ought to rule, and do not rebel?
14865 
14866 Certainly, he said, that is the true account of temperance whether in
14867 the State or individual.
14868 
14869 And surely, I said, we have explained again and again how and by virtue
14870 of what quality a man will be just.
14871 
14872 That is very certain.
14873 
14874 And is justice dimmer in the individual, and is her form different, or
14875 is she the same which we found her to be in the State?
14876 
14877 There is no difference in my opinion, he said.
14878 
14879 Because, if any doubt is still lingering in our minds, a few commonplace
14880 instances will satisfy us of the truth of what I am saying.
14881 
14882 What sort of instances do you mean?
14883 
14884 If the case is put to us, must we not admit that the just State, or
14885 the man who is trained in the principles of such a State, will be less
14886 likely than the unjust to make away with a deposit of gold or silver?
14887 Would any one deny this?
14888 
14889 No one, he replied.
14890 
14891 Will the just man or citizen ever be guilty of sacrilege or theft, or
14892 treachery either to his friends or to his country?
14893 
14894 Never.
14895 
14896 Neither will he ever break faith where there have been oaths or
14897 agreements?
14898 
14899 Impossible.
14900 
14901 No one will be less likely to commit adultery, or to dishonour his
14902 father and mother, or to fail in his religious duties?
14903 
14904 No one.
14905 
14906 And the reason is that each part of him is doing its own business,
14907 whether in ruling or being ruled?
14908 
14909 Exactly so.
14910 
14911 Are you satisfied then that the quality which makes such men and such
14912 states is justice, or do you hope to discover some other?
14913 
14914 Not I, indeed.
14915 
14916 Then our dream has been realized; and the suspicion which we entertained
14917 at the beginning of our work of construction, that some divine power
14918 must have conducted us to a primary form of justice, has now been
14919 verified?
14920 
14921 Yes, certainly.
14922 
14923 And the division of labour which required the carpenter and the
14924 shoemaker and the rest of the citizens to be doing each his own
14925 business, and not another's, was a shadow of justice, and for that
14926 reason it was of use?
14927 
14928 Clearly.
14929 
14930 But in reality justice was such as we were describing, being concerned
14931 however, not with the outward man, but with the inward, which is the
14932 true self and concernment of man: for the just man does not permit the
14933 several elements within him to interfere with one another, or any of
14934 them to do the work of others,--he sets in order his own inner life, and
14935 is his own master and his own law, and at peace with himself; and when
14936 he has bound together the three principles within him, which may be
14937 compared to the higher, lower, and middle notes of the scale, and the
14938 intermediate intervals--when he has bound all these together, and is
14939 no longer many, but has become one entirely temperate and perfectly
14940 adjusted nature, then he proceeds to act, if he has to act, whether in
14941 a matter of property, or in the treatment of the body, or in some affair
14942 of politics or private business; always thinking and calling that which
14943 preserves and co-operates with this harmonious condition, just and good
14944 action, and the knowledge which presides over it, wisdom, and that which
14945 at any time impairs this condition, he will call unjust action, and the
14946 opinion which presides over it ignorance.
14947 
14948 You have said the exact truth, Socrates.
14949 
14950 Very good; and if we were to affirm that we had discovered the just man
14951 and the just State, and the nature of justice in each of them, we should
14952 not be telling a falsehood?
14953 
14954 Most certainly not.
14955 
14956 May we say so, then?
14957 
14958 Let us say so.
14959 
14960 And now, I said, injustice has to be considered.
14961 
14962 Clearly.
14963 
14964 Must not injustice be a strife which arises among the three
14965 principles--a meddlesomeness, and interference, and rising up of a part
14966 of the soul against the whole, an assertion of unlawful authority, which
14967 is made by a rebellious subject against a true prince, of whom he is the
14968 natural vassal,--what is all this confusion and delusion but injustice,
14969 and intemperance and cowardice and ignorance, and every form of vice?
14970 
14971 Exactly so.
14972 
14973 And if the nature of justice and injustice be known, then the meaning of
14974 acting unjustly and being unjust, or, again, of acting justly, will also
14975 be perfectly clear?
14976 
14977 What do you mean? he said.
14978 
14979 Why, I said, they are like disease and health; being in the soul just
14980 what disease and health are in the body.
14981 
14982 How so? he said.
14983 
14984 Why, I said, that which is healthy causes health, and that which is
14985 unhealthy causes disease.
14986 
14987 Yes.
14988 
14989 And just actions cause justice, and unjust actions cause injustice?
14990 
14991 That is certain.
14992 
14993 And the creation of health is the institution of a natural order and
14994 government of one by another in the parts of the body; and the creation
14995 of disease is the production of a state of things at variance with this
14996 natural order?
14997 
14998 True.
14999 
15000 And is not the creation of justice the institution of a natural order
15001 and government of one by another in the parts of the soul, and the
15002 creation of injustice the production of a state of things at variance
15003 with the natural order?
15004 
15005 Exactly so, he said.
15006 
15007 Then virtue is the health and beauty and well-being of the soul, and
15008 vice the disease and weakness and deformity of the same?
15009 
15010 True.
15011 
15012 And do not good practices lead to virtue, and evil practices to vice?
15013 
15014 Assuredly.
15015 
15016 Still our old question of the comparative advantage of justice and
15017 injustice has not been answered: Which is the more profitable, to be
15018 just and act justly and practise virtue, whether seen or unseen of
15019 gods and men, or to be unjust and act unjustly, if only unpunished and
15020 unreformed?
15021 
15022 In my judgment, Socrates, the question has now become ridiculous. We
15023 know that, when the bodily constitution is gone, life is no longer
15024 endurable, though pampered with all kinds of meats and drinks, and
15025 having all wealth and all power; and shall we be told that when the
15026 very essence of the vital principle is undermined and corrupted, life
15027 is still worth having to a man, if only he be allowed to do whatever he
15028 likes with the single exception that he is not to acquire justice and
15029 virtue, or to escape from injustice and vice; assuming them both to be
15030 such as we have described?
15031 
15032 Yes, I said, the question is, as you say, ridiculous. Still, as we are
15033 near the spot at which we may see the truth in the clearest manner with
15034 our own eyes, let us not faint by the way.
15035 
15036 Certainly not, he replied.
15037 
15038 Come up hither, I said, and behold the various forms of vice, those of
15039 them, I mean, which are worth looking at.
15040 
15041 I am following you, he replied: proceed.
15042 
15043 I said, The argument seems to have reached a height from which, as from
15044 some tower of speculation, a man may look down and see that virtue
15045 is one, but that the forms of vice are innumerable; there being four
15046 special ones which are deserving of note.
15047 
15048 What do you mean? he said.
15049 
15050 I mean, I replied, that there appear to be as many forms of the soul as
15051 there are distinct forms of the State.
15052 
15053 How many?
15054 
15055 There are five of the State, and five of the soul, I said.
15056 
15057 What are they?
15058 
15059 The first, I said, is that which we have been describing, and which may
15060 be said to have two names, monarchy and aristocracy, accordingly as rule
15061 is exercised by one distinguished man or by many.
15062 
15063 True, he replied.
15064 
15065 But I regard the two names as describing one form only; for whether the
15066 government is in the hands of one or many, if the governors have been
15067 trained in the manner which we have supposed, the fundamental laws of
15068 the State will be maintained.
15069 
15070 That is true, he replied.
15071 
15072 
15073 
15074 
15075 BOOK V.
15076 
15077 Such is the good and true City or State, and the good and true man is
15078 of the same pattern; and if this is right every other is wrong; and the
15079 evil is one which affects not only the ordering of the State, but also
15080 the regulation of the individual soul, and is exhibited in four forms.
15081 
15082 What are they? he said.
15083 
15084 I was proceeding to tell the order in which the four evil forms appeared
15085 to me to succeed one another, when Polemarchus, who was sitting a little
15086 way off, just beyond Adeimantus, began to whisper to him: stretching
15087 forth his hand, he took hold of the upper part of his coat by the
15088 shoulder, and drew him towards him, leaning forward himself so as to be
15089 quite close and saying something in his ear, of which I only caught the
15090 words, 'Shall we let him off, or what shall we do?'
15091 
15092 Certainly not, said Adeimantus, raising his voice.
15093 
15094 Who is it, I said, whom you are refusing to let off?
15095 
15096 You, he said.
15097 
15098 I repeated, Why am I especially not to be let off?
15099 
15100 Why, he said, we think that you are lazy, and mean to cheat us out of a
15101 whole chapter which is a very important part of the story; and you fancy
15102 that we shall not notice your airy way of proceeding; as if it were
15103 self-evident to everybody, that in the matter of women and children
15104 'friends have all things in common.'
15105 
15106 And was I not right, Adeimantus?
15107 
15108 Yes, he said; but what is right in this particular case, like everything
15109 else, requires to be explained; for community may be of many kinds.
15110 Please, therefore, to say what sort of community you mean. We have been
15111 long expecting that you would tell us something about the family life
15112 of your citizens--how they will bring children into the world, and rear
15113 them when they have arrived, and, in general, what is the nature of this
15114 community of women and children--for we are of opinion that the right
15115 or wrong management of such matters will have a great and paramount
15116 influence on the State for good or for evil. And now, since the question
15117 is still undetermined, and you are taking in hand another State, we have
15118 resolved, as you heard, not to let you go until you give an account of
15119 all this.
15120 
15121 To that resolution, said Glaucon, you may regard me as saying Agreed.
15122 
15123 And without more ado, said Thrasymachus, you may consider us all to be
15124 equally agreed.
15125 
15126 I said, You know not what you are doing in thus assailing me: What an
15127 argument are you raising about the State! Just as I thought that I had
15128 finished, and was only too glad that I had laid this question to sleep,
15129 and was reflecting how fortunate I was in your acceptance of what I then
15130 said, you ask me to begin again at the very foundation, ignorant of what
15131 a hornet's nest of words you are stirring. Now I foresaw this gathering
15132 trouble, and avoided it.
15133 
15134 For what purpose do you conceive that we have come here, said
15135 Thrasymachus,--to look for gold, or to hear discourse?
15136 
15137 Yes, but discourse should have a limit.
15138 
15139 Yes, Socrates, said Glaucon, and the whole of life is the only limit
15140 which wise men assign to the hearing of such discourses. But never mind
15141 about us; take heart yourself and answer the question in your own way:
15142 What sort of community of women and children is this which is to prevail
15143 among our guardians? and how shall we manage the period between birth
15144 and education, which seems to require the greatest care? Tell us how
15145 these things will be.
15146 
15147 Yes, my simple friend, but the answer is the reverse of easy; many more
15148 doubts arise about this than about our previous conclusions. For the
15149 practicability of what is said may be doubted; and looked at in another
15150 point of view, whether the scheme, if ever so practicable, would be for
15151 the best, is also doubtful. Hence I feel a reluctance to approach the
15152 subject, lest our aspiration, my dear friend, should turn out to be a
15153 dream only.
15154 
15155 Fear not, he replied, for your audience will not be hard upon you; they
15156 are not sceptical or hostile.
15157 
15158 I said: My good friend, I suppose that you mean to encourage me by these
15159 words.
15160 
15161 Yes, he said.
15162 
15163 Then let me tell you that you are doing just the reverse; the
15164 encouragement which you offer would have been all very well had I myself
15165 believed that I knew what I was talking about: to declare the truth
15166 about matters of high interest which a man honours and loves among wise
15167 men who love him need occasion no fear or faltering in his mind; but to
15168 carry on an argument when you are yourself only a hesitating enquirer,
15169 which is my condition, is a dangerous and slippery thing; and the danger
15170 is not that I shall be laughed at (of which the fear would be childish),
15171 but that I shall miss the truth where I have most need to be sure of my
15172 footing, and drag my friends after me in my fall. And I pray Nemesis not
15173 to visit upon me the words which I am going to utter. For I do indeed
15174 believe that to be an involuntary homicide is a less crime than to be a
15175 deceiver about beauty or goodness or justice in the matter of laws.
15176 And that is a risk which I would rather run among enemies than among
15177 friends, and therefore you do well to encourage me.
15178 
15179 Glaucon laughed and said: Well then, Socrates, in case you and your
15180 argument do us any serious injury you shall be acquitted beforehand of
15181 the homicide, and shall not be held to be a deceiver; take courage then
15182 and speak.
15183 
15184 Well, I said, the law says that when a man is acquitted he is free from
15185 guilt, and what holds at law may hold in argument.
15186 
15187 Then why should you mind?
15188 
15189 Well, I replied, I suppose that I must retrace my steps and say what I
15190 perhaps ought to have said before in the proper place. The part of the
15191 men has been played out, and now properly enough comes the turn of the
15192 women. Of them I will proceed to speak, and the more readily since I am
15193 invited by you.
15194 
15195 For men born and educated like our citizens, the only way, in my
15196 opinion, of arriving at a right conclusion about the possession and
15197 use of women and children is to follow the path on which we originally
15198 started, when we said that the men were to be the guardians and
15199 watchdogs of the herd.
15200 
15201 True.
15202 
15203 Let us further suppose the birth and education of our women to be
15204 subject to similar or nearly similar regulations; then we shall see
15205 whether the result accords with our design.
15206 
15207 What do you mean?
15208 
15209 What I mean may be put into the form of a question, I said: Are dogs
15210 divided into hes and shes, or do they both share equally in hunting and
15211 in keeping watch and in the other duties of dogs? or do we entrust to
15212 the males the entire and exclusive care of the flocks, while we leave
15213 the females at home, under the idea that the bearing and suckling their
15214 puppies is labour enough for them?
15215 
15216 No, he said, they share alike; the only difference between them is that
15217 the males are stronger and the females weaker.
15218 
15219 But can you use different animals for the same purpose, unless they are
15220 bred and fed in the same way?
15221 
15222 You cannot.
15223 
15224 Then, if women are to have the same duties as men, they must have the
15225 same nurture and education?
15226 
15227 Yes.
15228 
15229 The education which was assigned to the men was music and gymnastic.
15230 
15231 Yes.
15232 
15233 Then women must be taught music and gymnastic and also the art of war,
15234 which they must practise like the men?
15235 
15236 That is the inference, I suppose.
15237 
15238 I should rather expect, I said, that several of our proposals, if they
15239 are carried out, being unusual, may appear ridiculous.
15240 
15241 No doubt of it.
15242 
15243 Yes, and the most ridiculous thing of all will be the sight of women
15244 naked in the palaestra, exercising with the men, especially when they
15245 are no longer young; they certainly will not be a vision of beauty, any
15246 more than the enthusiastic old men who in spite of wrinkles and ugliness
15247 continue to frequent the gymnasia.
15248 
15249 Yes, indeed, he said: according to present notions the proposal would be
15250 thought ridiculous.
15251 
15252 But then, I said, as we have determined to speak our minds, we must not
15253 fear the jests of the wits which will be directed against this sort of
15254 innovation; how they will talk of women's attainments both in music
15255 and gymnastic, and above all about their wearing armour and riding upon
15256 horseback!
15257 
15258 Very true, he replied.
15259 
15260 Yet having begun we must go forward to the rough places of the law; at
15261 the same time begging of these gentlemen for once in their life to be
15262 serious. Not long ago, as we shall remind them, the Hellenes were of the
15263 opinion, which is still generally received among the barbarians, that
15264 the sight of a naked man was ridiculous and improper; and when first the
15265 Cretans and then the Lacedaemonians introduced the custom, the wits of
15266 that day might equally have ridiculed the innovation.
15267 
15268 No doubt.
15269 
15270 But when experience showed that to let all things be uncovered was far
15271 better than to cover them up, and the ludicrous effect to the outward
15272 eye vanished before the better principle which reason asserted, then the
15273 man was perceived to be a fool who directs the shafts of his ridicule
15274 at any other sight but that of folly and vice, or seriously inclines to
15275 weigh the beautiful by any other standard but that of the good.
15276 
15277 Very true, he replied.
15278 
15279 First, then, whether the question is to be put in jest or in earnest,
15280 let us come to an understanding about the nature of woman: Is she
15281 capable of sharing either wholly or partially in the actions of men, or
15282 not at all? And is the art of war one of those arts in which she can or
15283 can not share? That will be the best way of commencing the enquiry, and
15284 will probably lead to the fairest conclusion.
15285 
15286 That will be much the best way.
15287 
15288 Shall we take the other side first and begin by arguing against
15289 ourselves; in this manner the adversary's position will not be
15290 undefended.
15291 
15292 Why not? he said.
15293 
15294 Then let us put a speech into the mouths of our opponents. They will
15295 say: 'Socrates and Glaucon, no adversary need convict you, for you
15296 yourselves, at the first foundation of the State, admitted the principle
15297 that everybody was to do the one work suited to his own nature.' And
15298 certainly, if I am not mistaken, such an admission was made by us. 'And
15299 do not the natures of men and women differ very much indeed?' And we
15300 shall reply: Of course they do. Then we shall be asked, 'Whether the
15301 tasks assigned to men and to women should not be different, and such as
15302 are agreeable to their different natures?' Certainly they should. 'But
15303 if so, have you not fallen into a serious inconsistency in saying that
15304 men and women, whose natures are so entirely different, ought to perform
15305 the same actions?'--What defence will you make for us, my good Sir,
15306 against any one who offers these objections?
15307 
15308 That is not an easy question to answer when asked suddenly; and I shall
15309 and I do beg of you to draw out the case on our side.
15310 
15311 These are the objections, Glaucon, and there are many others of a like
15312 kind, which I foresaw long ago; they made me afraid and reluctant to
15313 take in hand any law about the possession and nurture of women and
15314 children.
15315 
15316 By Zeus, he said, the problem to be solved is anything but easy.
15317 
15318 Why yes, I said, but the fact is that when a man is out of his depth,
15319 whether he has fallen into a little swimming bath or into mid ocean, he
15320 has to swim all the same.
15321 
15322 Very true.
15323 
15324 And must not we swim and try to reach the shore: we will hope that
15325 Arion's dolphin or some other miraculous help may save us?
15326 
15327 I suppose so, he said.
15328 
15329 Well then, let us see if any way of escape can be found. We
15330 acknowledged--did we not? that different natures ought to have different
15331 pursuits, and that men's and women's natures are different. And now
15332 what are we saying?--that different natures ought to have the same
15333 pursuits,--this is the inconsistency which is charged upon us.
15334 
15335 Precisely.
15336 
15337 Verily, Glaucon, I said, glorious is the power of the art of
15338 contradiction!
15339 
15340 Why do you say so?
15341 
15342 Because I think that many a man falls into the practice against his
15343 will. When he thinks that he is reasoning he is really disputing, just
15344 because he cannot define and divide, and so know that of which he is
15345 speaking; and he will pursue a merely verbal opposition in the spirit of
15346 contention and not of fair discussion.
15347 
15348 Yes, he replied, such is very often the case; but what has that to do
15349 with us and our argument?
15350 
15351 A great deal; for there is certainly a danger of our getting
15352 unintentionally into a verbal opposition.
15353 
15354 In what way?
15355 
15356 Why we valiantly and pugnaciously insist upon the verbal truth, that
15357 different natures ought to have different pursuits, but we never
15358 considered at all what was the meaning of sameness or difference of
15359 nature, or why we distinguished them when we assigned different pursuits
15360 to different natures and the same to the same natures.
15361 
15362 Why, no, he said, that was never considered by us.
15363 
15364 I said: Suppose that by way of illustration we were to ask the question
15365 whether there is not an opposition in nature between bald men and hairy
15366 men; and if this is admitted by us, then, if bald men are cobblers, we
15367 should forbid the hairy men to be cobblers, and conversely?
15368 
15369 That would be a jest, he said.
15370 
15371 Yes, I said, a jest; and why? because we never meant when we constructed
15372 the State, that the opposition of natures should extend to every
15373 difference, but only to those differences which affected the pursuit
15374 in which the individual is engaged; we should have argued, for example,
15375 that a physician and one who is in mind a physician may be said to have
15376 the same nature.
15377 
15378 True.
15379 
15380 Whereas the physician and the carpenter have different natures?
15381 
15382 Certainly.
15383 
15384 And if, I said, the male and female sex appear to differ in their
15385 fitness for any art or pursuit, we should say that such pursuit or art
15386 ought to be assigned to one or the other of them; but if the difference
15387 consists only in women bearing and men begetting children, this does not
15388 amount to a proof that a woman differs from a man in respect of the
15389 sort of education she should receive; and we shall therefore continue
15390 to maintain that our guardians and their wives ought to have the same
15391 pursuits.
15392 
15393 Very true, he said.
15394 
15395 Next, we shall ask our opponent how, in reference to any of the pursuits
15396 or arts of civic life, the nature of a woman differs from that of a man?
15397 
15398 That will be quite fair.
15399 
15400 And perhaps he, like yourself, will reply that to give a sufficient
15401 answer on the instant is not easy; but after a little reflection there
15402 is no difficulty.
15403 
15404 Yes, perhaps.
15405 
15406 Suppose then that we invite him to accompany us in the argument, and
15407 then we may hope to show him that there is nothing peculiar in the
15408 constitution of women which would affect them in the administration of
15409 the State.
15410 
15411 By all means.
15412 
15413 Let us say to him: Come now, and we will ask you a question:--when you
15414 spoke of a nature gifted or not gifted in any respect, did you mean to
15415 say that one man will acquire a thing easily, another with difficulty; a
15416 little learning will lead the one to discover a great deal; whereas
15417 the other, after much study and application, no sooner learns than he
15418 forgets; or again, did you mean, that the one has a body which is a
15419 good servant to his mind, while the body of the other is a hindrance to
15420 him?--would not these be the sort of differences which distinguish the
15421 man gifted by nature from the one who is ungifted?
15422 
15423 No one will deny that.
15424 
15425 And can you mention any pursuit of mankind in which the male sex has not
15426 all these gifts and qualities in a higher degree than the female? Need
15427 I waste time in speaking of the art of weaving, and the management of
15428 pancakes and preserves, in which womankind does really appear to be
15429 great, and in which for her to be beaten by a man is of all things the
15430 most absurd?
15431 
15432 You are quite right, he replied, in maintaining the general inferiority
15433 of the female sex: although many women are in many things superior to
15434 many men, yet on the whole what you say is true.
15435 
15436 And if so, my friend, I said, there is no special faculty of
15437 administration in a state which a woman has because she is a woman, or
15438 which a man has by virtue of his sex, but the gifts of nature are alike
15439 diffused in both; all the pursuits of men are the pursuits of women
15440 also, but in all of them a woman is inferior to a man.
15441 
15442 Very true.
15443 
15444 Then are we to impose all our enactments on men and none of them on
15445 women?
15446 
15447 That will never do.
15448 
15449 One woman has a gift of healing, another not; one is a musician, and
15450 another has no music in her nature?
15451 
15452 Very true.
15453 
15454 And one woman has a turn for gymnastic and military exercises, and
15455 another is unwarlike and hates gymnastics?
15456 
15457 Certainly.
15458 
15459 And one woman is a philosopher, and another is an enemy of philosophy;
15460 one has spirit, and another is without spirit?
15461 
15462 That is also true.
15463 
15464 Then one woman will have the temper of a guardian, and another not. Was
15465 not the selection of the male guardians determined by differences of
15466 this sort?
15467 
15468 Yes.
15469 
15470 Men and women alike possess the qualities which make a guardian; they
15471 differ only in their comparative strength or weakness.
15472 
15473 Obviously.
15474 
15475 And those women who have such qualities are to be selected as the
15476 companions and colleagues of men who have similar qualities and whom
15477 they resemble in capacity and in character?
15478 
15479 Very true.
15480 
15481 And ought not the same natures to have the same pursuits?
15482 
15483 They ought.
15484 
15485 Then, as we were saying before, there is nothing unnatural in assigning
15486 music and gymnastic to the wives of the guardians--to that point we come
15487 round again.
15488 
15489 Certainly not.
15490 
15491 The law which we then enacted was agreeable to nature, and therefore not
15492 an impossibility or mere aspiration; and the contrary practice, which
15493 prevails at present, is in reality a violation of nature.
15494 
15495 That appears to be true.
15496 
15497 We had to consider, first, whether our proposals were possible, and
15498 secondly whether they were the most beneficial?
15499 
15500 Yes.
15501 
15502 And the possibility has been acknowledged?
15503 
15504 Yes.
15505 
15506 The very great benefit has next to be established?
15507 
15508 Quite so.
15509 
15510 You will admit that the same education which makes a man a good guardian
15511 will make a woman a good guardian; for their original nature is the
15512 same?
15513 
15514 Yes.
15515 
15516 I should like to ask you a question.
15517 
15518 What is it?
15519 
15520 Would you say that all men are equal in excellence, or is one man better
15521 than another?
15522 
15523 The latter.
15524 
15525 And in the commonwealth which we were founding do you conceive the
15526 guardians who have been brought up on our model system to be more
15527 perfect men, or the cobblers whose education has been cobbling?
15528 
15529 What a ridiculous question!
15530 
15531 You have answered me, I replied: Well, and may we not further say that
15532 our guardians are the best of our citizens?
15533 
15534 By far the best.
15535 
15536 And will not their wives be the best women?
15537 
15538 Yes, by far the best.
15539 
15540 And can there be anything better for the interests of the State than
15541 that the men and women of a State should be as good as possible?
15542 
15543 There can be nothing better.
15544 
15545 And this is what the arts of music and gymnastic, when present in such
15546 manner as we have described, will accomplish?
15547 
15548 Certainly.
15549 
15550 Then we have made an enactment not only possible but in the highest
15551 degree beneficial to the State?
15552 
15553 True.
15554 
15555 Then let the wives of our guardians strip, for their virtue will be
15556 their robe, and let them share in the toils of war and the defence of
15557 their country; only in the distribution of labours the lighter are to be
15558 assigned to the women, who are the weaker natures, but in other respects
15559 their duties are to be the same. And as for the man who laughs at naked
15560 women exercising their bodies from the best of motives, in his laughter
15561 he is plucking
15562 
15563 'A fruit of unripe wisdom,'
15564 
15565 and he himself is ignorant of what he is laughing at, or what he is
15566 about;--for that is, and ever will be, the best of sayings, That the
15567 useful is the noble and the hurtful is the base.
15568 
15569 Very true.
15570 
15571 Here, then, is one difficulty in our law about women, which we may say
15572 that we have now escaped; the wave has not swallowed us up alive for
15573 enacting that the guardians of either sex should have all their
15574 pursuits in common; to the utility and also to the possibility of this
15575 arrangement the consistency of the argument with itself bears witness.
15576 
15577 Yes, that was a mighty wave which you have escaped.
15578 
15579 Yes, I said, but a greater is coming; you will not think much of this
15580 when you see the next.
15581 
15582 Go on; let me see.
15583 
15584 The law, I said, which is the sequel of this and of all that has
15585 preceded, is to the following effect,--'that the wives of our guardians
15586 are to be common, and their children are to be common, and no parent is
15587 to know his own child, nor any child his parent.'
15588 
15589 Yes, he said, that is a much greater wave than the other; and
15590 the possibility as well as the utility of such a law are far more
15591 questionable.
15592 
15593 I do not think, I said, that there can be any dispute about the very
15594 great utility of having wives and children in common; the possibility is
15595 quite another matter, and will be very much disputed.
15596 
15597 I think that a good many doubts may be raised about both.
15598 
15599 You imply that the two questions must be combined, I replied. Now I
15600 meant that you should admit the utility; and in this way, as I thought,
15601 I should escape from one of them, and then there would remain only the
15602 possibility.
15603 
15604 But that little attempt is detected, and therefore you will please to
15605 give a defence of both.
15606 
15607 Well, I said, I submit to my fate. Yet grant me a little favour: let
15608 me feast my mind with the dream as day dreamers are in the habit of
15609 feasting themselves when they are walking alone; for before they have
15610 discovered any means of effecting their wishes--that is a matter which
15611 never troubles them--they would rather not tire themselves by thinking
15612 about possibilities; but assuming that what they desire is already
15613 granted to them, they proceed with their plan, and delight in detailing
15614 what they mean to do when their wish has come true--that is a way which
15615 they have of not doing much good to a capacity which was never good for
15616 much. Now I myself am beginning to lose heart, and I should like, with
15617 your permission, to pass over the question of possibility at present.
15618 Assuming therefore the possibility of the proposal, I shall now proceed
15619 to enquire how the rulers will carry out these arrangements, and I shall
15620 demonstrate that our plan, if executed, will be of the greatest benefit
15621 to the State and to the guardians. First of all, then, if you have no
15622 objection, I will endeavour with your help to consider the advantages of
15623 the measure; and hereafter the question of possibility.
15624 
15625 I have no objection; proceed.
15626 
15627 First, I think that if our rulers and their auxiliaries are to be worthy
15628 of the name which they bear, there must be willingness to obey in the
15629 one and the power of command in the other; the guardians must themselves
15630 obey the laws, and they must also imitate the spirit of them in any
15631 details which are entrusted to their care.
15632 
15633 That is right, he said.
15634 
15635 You, I said, who are their legislator, having selected the men, will now
15636 select the women and give them to them;--they must be as far as possible
15637 of like natures with them; and they must live in common houses and meet
15638 at common meals. None of them will have anything specially his or her
15639 own; they will be together, and will be brought up together, and
15640 will associate at gymnastic exercises. And so they will be drawn by
15641 a necessity of their natures to have intercourse with each
15642 other--necessity is not too strong a word, I think?
15643 
15644 Yes, he said;--necessity, not geometrical, but another sort of necessity
15645 which lovers know, and which is far more convincing and constraining to
15646 the mass of mankind.
15647 
15648 True, I said; and this, Glaucon, like all the rest, must proceed after
15649 an orderly fashion; in a city of the blessed, licentiousness is an
15650 unholy thing which the rulers will forbid.
15651 
15652 Yes, he said, and it ought not to be permitted.
15653 
15654 Then clearly the next thing will be to make matrimony sacred in the
15655 highest degree, and what is most beneficial will be deemed sacred?
15656 
15657 Exactly.
15658 
15659 And how can marriages be made most beneficial?--that is a question which
15660 I put to you, because I see in your house dogs for hunting, and of the
15661 nobler sort of birds not a few. Now, I beseech you, do tell me, have you
15662 ever attended to their pairing and breeding?
15663 
15664 In what particulars?
15665 
15666 Why, in the first place, although they are all of a good sort, are not
15667 some better than others?
15668 
15669 True.
15670 
15671 And do you breed from them all indifferently, or do you take care to
15672 breed from the best only?
15673 
15674 From the best.
15675 
15676 And do you take the oldest or the youngest, or only those of ripe age?
15677 
15678 I choose only those of ripe age.
15679 
15680 And if care was not taken in the breeding, your dogs and birds would
15681 greatly deteriorate?
15682 
15683 Certainly.
15684 
15685 And the same of horses and animals in general?
15686 
15687 Undoubtedly.
15688 
15689 Good heavens! my dear friend, I said, what consummate skill will our
15690 rulers need if the same principle holds of the human species!
15691 
15692 Certainly, the same principle holds; but why does this involve any
15693 particular skill?
15694 
15695 Because, I said, our rulers will often have to practise upon the body
15696 corporate with medicines. Now you know that when patients do not require
15697 medicines, but have only to be put under a regimen, the inferior sort
15698 of practitioner is deemed to be good enough; but when medicine has to be
15699 given, then the doctor should be more of a man.
15700 
15701 That is quite true, he said; but to what are you alluding?
15702 
15703 I mean, I replied, that our rulers will find a considerable dose of
15704 falsehood and deceit necessary for the good of their subjects: we were
15705 saying that the use of all these things regarded as medicines might be
15706 of advantage.
15707 
15708 And we were very right.
15709 
15710 And this lawful use of them seems likely to be often needed in the
15711 regulations of marriages and births.
15712 
15713 How so?
15714 
15715 Why, I said, the principle has been already laid down that the best of
15716 either sex should be united with the best as often, and the inferior
15717 with the inferior, as seldom as possible; and that they should rear the
15718 offspring of the one sort of union, but not of the other, if the flock
15719 is to be maintained in first-rate condition. Now these goings on must be
15720 a secret which the rulers only know, or there will be a further
15721 danger of our herd, as the guardians may be termed, breaking out into
15722 rebellion.
15723 
15724 Very true.
15725 
15726 Had we not better appoint certain festivals at which we will bring
15727 together the brides and bridegrooms, and sacrifices will be offered and
15728 suitable hymeneal songs composed by our poets: the number of weddings is
15729 a matter which must be left to the discretion of the rulers, whose aim
15730 will be to preserve the average of population? There are many other
15731 things which they will have to consider, such as the effects of wars and
15732 diseases and any similar agencies, in order as far as this is possible
15733 to prevent the State from becoming either too large or too small.
15734 
15735 Certainly, he replied.
15736 
15737 We shall have to invent some ingenious kind of lots which the less
15738 worthy may draw on each occasion of our bringing them together, and then
15739 they will accuse their own ill-luck and not the rulers.
15740 
15741 To be sure, he said.
15742 
15743 And I think that our braver and better youth, besides their other
15744 honours and rewards, might have greater facilities of intercourse with
15745 women given them; their bravery will be a reason, and such fathers ought
15746 to have as many sons as possible.
15747 
15748 True.
15749 
15750 And the proper officers, whether male or female or both, for offices are
15751 to be held by women as well as by men--
15752 
15753 Yes--
15754 
15755 The proper officers will take the offspring of the good parents to the
15756 pen or fold, and there they will deposit them with certain nurses who
15757 dwell in a separate quarter; but the offspring of the inferior, or of
15758 the better when they chance to be deformed, will be put away in some
15759 mysterious, unknown place, as they should be.
15760 
15761 Yes, he said, that must be done if the breed of the guardians is to be
15762 kept pure.
15763 
15764 They will provide for their nurture, and will bring the mothers to the
15765 fold when they are full of milk, taking the greatest possible care that
15766 no mother recognises her own child; and other wet-nurses may be engaged
15767 if more are required. Care will also be taken that the process of
15768 suckling shall not be protracted too long; and the mothers will have no
15769 getting up at night or other trouble, but will hand over all this sort
15770 of thing to the nurses and attendants.
15771 
15772 You suppose the wives of our guardians to have a fine easy time of it
15773 when they are having children.
15774 
15775 Why, said I, and so they ought. Let us, however, proceed with our
15776 scheme. We were saying that the parents should be in the prime of life?
15777 
15778 Very true.
15779 
15780 And what is the prime of life? May it not be defined as a period of
15781 about twenty years in a woman's life, and thirty in a man's?
15782 
15783 Which years do you mean to include?
15784 
15785 A woman, I said, at twenty years of age may begin to bear children to
15786 the State, and continue to bear them until forty; a man may begin at
15787 five-and-twenty, when he has passed the point at which the pulse of life
15788 beats quickest, and continue to beget children until he be fifty-five.
15789 
15790 Certainly, he said, both in men and women those years are the prime of
15791 physical as well as of intellectual vigour.
15792 
15793 Any one above or below the prescribed ages who takes part in the public
15794 hymeneals shall be said to have done an unholy and unrighteous thing;
15795 the child of which he is the father, if it steals into life, will have
15796 been conceived under auspices very unlike the sacrifices and prayers,
15797 which at each hymeneal priestesses and priest and the whole city will
15798 offer, that the new generation may be better and more useful than their
15799 good and useful parents, whereas his child will be the offspring of
15800 darkness and strange lust.
15801 
15802 Very true, he replied.
15803 
15804 And the same law will apply to any one of those within the prescribed
15805 age who forms a connection with any woman in the prime of life without
15806 the sanction of the rulers; for we shall say that he is raising up a
15807 bastard to the State, uncertified and unconsecrated.
15808 
15809 Very true, he replied.
15810 
15811 This applies, however, only to those who are within the specified age:
15812 after that we allow them to range at will, except that a man may not
15813 marry his daughter or his daughter's daughter, or his mother or his
15814 mother's mother; and women, on the other hand, are prohibited from
15815 marrying their sons or fathers, or son's son or father's father, and
15816 so on in either direction. And we grant all this, accompanying the
15817 permission with strict orders to prevent any embryo which may come into
15818 being from seeing the light; and if any force a way to the birth, the
15819 parents must understand that the offspring of such an union cannot be
15820 maintained, and arrange accordingly.
15821 
15822 That also, he said, is a reasonable proposition. But how will they know
15823 who are fathers and daughters, and so on?
15824 
15825 They will never know. The way will be this:--dating from the day of the
15826 hymeneal, the bridegroom who was then married will call all the male
15827 children who are born in the seventh and tenth month afterwards his
15828 sons, and the female children his daughters, and they will call him
15829 father, and he will call their children his grandchildren, and they will
15830 call the elder generation grandfathers and grandmothers. All who were
15831 begotten at the time when their fathers and mothers came together will
15832 be called their brothers and sisters, and these, as I was saying, will
15833 be forbidden to inter-marry. This, however, is not to be understood as
15834 an absolute prohibition of the marriage of brothers and sisters; if the
15835 lot favours them, and they receive the sanction of the Pythian oracle,
15836 the law will allow them.
15837 
15838 Quite right, he replied.
15839 
15840 Such is the scheme, Glaucon, according to which the guardians of our
15841 State are to have their wives and families in common. And now you would
15842 have the argument show that this community is consistent with the rest
15843 of our polity, and also that nothing can be better--would you not?
15844 
15845 Yes, certainly.
15846 
15847 Shall we try to find a common basis by asking of ourselves what ought
15848 to be the chief aim of the legislator in making laws and in the
15849 organization of a State,--what is the greatest good, and what is the
15850 greatest evil, and then consider whether our previous description has
15851 the stamp of the good or of the evil?
15852 
15853 By all means.
15854 
15855 Can there be any greater evil than discord and distraction and plurality
15856 where unity ought to reign? or any greater good than the bond of unity?
15857 
15858 There cannot.
15859 
15860 And there is unity where there is community of pleasures and
15861 pains--where all the citizens are glad or grieved on the same occasions
15862 of joy and sorrow?
15863 
15864 No doubt.
15865 
15866 Yes; and where there is no common but only private feeling a State is
15867 disorganized--when you have one half of the world triumphing and the
15868 other plunged in grief at the same events happening to the city or the
15869 citizens?
15870 
15871 Certainly.
15872 
15873 Such differences commonly originate in a disagreement about the use of
15874 the terms 'mine' and 'not mine,' 'his' and 'not his.'
15875 
15876 Exactly so.
15877 
15878 And is not that the best-ordered State in which the greatest number of
15879 persons apply the terms 'mine' and 'not mine' in the same way to the
15880 same thing?
15881 
15882 Quite true.
15883 
15884 Or that again which most nearly approaches to the condition of the
15885 individual--as in the body, when but a finger of one of us is hurt, the
15886 whole frame, drawn towards the soul as a centre and forming one kingdom
15887 under the ruling power therein, feels the hurt and sympathizes all
15888 together with the part affected, and we say that the man has a pain in
15889 his finger; and the same expression is used about any other part of the
15890 body, which has a sensation of pain at suffering or of pleasure at the
15891 alleviation of suffering.
15892 
15893 Very true, he replied; and I agree with you that in the best-ordered
15894 State there is the nearest approach to this common feeling which you
15895 describe.
15896 
15897 Then when any one of the citizens experiences any good or evil, the
15898 whole State will make his case their own, and will either rejoice or
15899 sorrow with him?
15900 
15901 Yes, he said, that is what will happen in a well-ordered State.
15902 
15903 It will now be time, I said, for us to return to our State and see
15904 whether this or some other form is most in accordance with these
15905 fundamental principles.
15906 
15907 Very good.
15908 
15909 Our State like every other has rulers and subjects?
15910 
15911 True.
15912 
15913 All of whom will call one another citizens?
15914 
15915 Of course.
15916 
15917 But is there not another name which people give to their rulers in other
15918 States?
15919 
15920 Generally they call them masters, but in democratic States they simply
15921 call them rulers.
15922 
15923 And in our State what other name besides that of citizens do the people
15924 give the rulers?
15925 
15926 They are called saviours and helpers, he replied.
15927 
15928 And what do the rulers call the people?
15929 
15930 Their maintainers and foster-fathers.
15931 
15932 And what do they call them in other States?
15933 
15934 Slaves.
15935 
15936 And what do the rulers call one another in other States?
15937 
15938 Fellow-rulers.
15939 
15940 And what in ours?
15941 
15942 Fellow-guardians.
15943 
15944 Did you ever know an example in any other State of a ruler who would
15945 speak of one of his colleagues as his friend and of another as not being
15946 his friend?
15947 
15948 Yes, very often.
15949 
15950 And the friend he regards and describes as one in whom he has an
15951 interest, and the other as a stranger in whom he has no interest?
15952 
15953 Exactly.
15954 
15955 But would any of your guardians think or speak of any other guardian as
15956 a stranger?
15957 
15958 Certainly he would not; for every one whom they meet will be regarded
15959 by them either as a brother or sister, or father or mother, or son or
15960 daughter, or as the child or parent of those who are thus connected with
15961 him.
15962 
15963 Capital, I said; but let me ask you once more: Shall they be a family in
15964 name only; or shall they in all their actions be true to the name? For
15965 example, in the use of the word 'father,' would the care of a father be
15966 implied and the filial reverence and duty and obedience to him which the
15967 law commands; and is the violator of these duties to be regarded as an
15968 impious and unrighteous person who is not likely to receive much good
15969 either at the hands of God or of man? Are these to be or not to be the
15970 strains which the children will hear repeated in their ears by all the
15971 citizens about those who are intimated to them to be their parents and
15972 the rest of their kinsfolk?
15973 
15974 These, he said, and none other; for what can be more ridiculous than for
15975 them to utter the names of family ties with the lips only and not to act
15976 in the spirit of them?
15977 
15978 Then in our city the language of harmony and concord will be more often
15979 heard than in any other. As I was describing before, when any one is
15980 well or ill, the universal word will be 'with me it is well' or 'it is
15981 ill.'
15982 
15983 Most true.
15984 
15985 And agreeably to this mode of thinking and speaking, were we not saying
15986 that they will have their pleasures and pains in common?
15987 
15988 Yes, and so they will.
15989 
15990 And they will have a common interest in the same thing which they will
15991 alike call 'my own,' and having this common interest they will have a
15992 common feeling of pleasure and pain?
15993 
15994 Yes, far more so than in other States.
15995 
15996 And the reason of this, over and above the general constitution of the
15997 State, will be that the guardians will have a community of women and
15998 children?
15999 
16000 That will be the chief reason.
16001 
16002 And this unity of feeling we admitted to be the greatest good, as was
16003 implied in our own comparison of a well-ordered State to the relation of
16004 the body and the members, when affected by pleasure or pain?
16005 
16006 That we acknowledged, and very rightly.
16007 
16008 Then the community of wives and children among our citizens is clearly
16009 the source of the greatest good to the State?
16010 
16011 Certainly.
16012 
16013 And this agrees with the other principle which we were affirming,--that
16014 the guardians were not to have houses or lands or any other property;
16015 their pay was to be their food, which they were to receive from the
16016 other citizens, and they were to have no private expenses; for we
16017 intended them to preserve their true character of guardians.
16018 
16019 Right, he replied.
16020 
16021 Both the community of property and the community of families, as I am
16022 saying, tend to make them more truly guardians; they will not tear
16023 the city in pieces by differing about 'mine' and 'not mine;' each man
16024 dragging any acquisition which he has made into a separate house of his
16025 own, where he has a separate wife and children and private pleasures and
16026 pains; but all will be affected as far as may be by the same pleasures
16027 and pains because they are all of one opinion about what is near and
16028 dear to them, and therefore they all tend towards a common end.
16029 
16030 Certainly, he replied.
16031 
16032 And as they have nothing but their persons which they can call their
16033 own, suits and complaints will have no existence among them; they will
16034 be delivered from all those quarrels of which money or children or
16035 relations are the occasion.
16036 
16037 Of course they will.
16038 
16039 Neither will trials for assault or insult ever be likely to occur among
16040 them. For that equals should defend themselves against equals we shall
16041 maintain to be honourable and right; we shall make the protection of the
16042 person a matter of necessity.
16043 
16044 That is good, he said.
16045 
16046 Yes; and there is a further good in the law; viz. that if a man has a
16047 quarrel with another he will satisfy his resentment then and there, and
16048 not proceed to more dangerous lengths.
16049 
16050 Certainly.
16051 
16052 To the elder shall be assigned the duty of ruling and chastising the
16053 younger.
16054 
16055 Clearly.
16056 
16057 Nor can there be a doubt that the younger will not strike or do any
16058 other violence to an elder, unless the magistrates command him; nor will
16059 he slight him in any way. For there are two guardians, shame and fear,
16060 mighty to prevent him: shame, which makes men refrain from laying hands
16061 on those who are to them in the relation of parents; fear, that the
16062 injured one will be succoured by the others who are his brothers, sons,
16063 fathers.
16064 
16065 That is true, he replied.
16066 
16067 Then in every way the laws will help the citizens to keep the peace with
16068 one another?
16069 
16070 Yes, there will be no want of peace.
16071 
16072 And as the guardians will never quarrel among themselves there will be
16073 no danger of the rest of the city being divided either against them or
16074 against one another.
16075 
16076 None whatever.
16077 
16078 I hardly like even to mention the little meannesses of which they will
16079 be rid, for they are beneath notice: such, for example, as the
16080 flattery of the rich by the poor, and all the pains and pangs which
16081 men experience in bringing up a family, and in finding money to buy
16082 necessaries for their household, borrowing and then repudiating, getting
