16083 how they can, and giving the money into the hands of women and slaves
16084 to keep--the many evils of so many kinds which people suffer in this way
16085 are mean enough and obvious enough, and not worth speaking of.
16086 
16087 Yes, he said, a man has no need of eyes in order to perceive that.
16088 
16089 And from all these evils they will be delivered, and their life will be
16090 blessed as the life of Olympic victors and yet more blessed.
16091 
16092 How so?
16093 
16094 The Olympic victor, I said, is deemed happy in receiving a part only of
16095 the blessedness which is secured to our citizens, who have won a more
16096 glorious victory and have a more complete maintenance at the public
16097 cost. For the victory which they have won is the salvation of the whole
16098 State; and the crown with which they and their children are crowned is
16099 the fulness of all that life needs; they receive rewards from the
16100 hands of their country while living, and after death have an honourable
16101 burial.
16102 
16103 Yes, he said, and glorious rewards they are.
16104 
16105 Do you remember, I said, how in the course of the previous discussion
16106 some one who shall be nameless accused us of making our guardians
16107 unhappy--they had nothing and might have possessed all things--to whom
16108 we replied that, if an occasion offered, we might perhaps hereafter
16109 consider this question, but that, as at present advised, we would make
16110 our guardians truly guardians, and that we were fashioning the State
16111 with a view to the greatest happiness, not of any particular class, but
16112 of the whole?
16113 
16114 Yes, I remember.
16115 
16116 And what do you say, now that the life of our protectors is made out to
16117 be far better and nobler than that of Olympic victors--is the life of
16118 shoemakers, or any other artisans, or of husbandmen, to be compared with
16119 it?
16120 
16121 Certainly not.
16122 
16123 At the same time I ought here to repeat what I have said elsewhere, that
16124 if any of our guardians shall try to be happy in such a manner that
16125 he will cease to be a guardian, and is not content with this safe and
16126 harmonious life, which, in our judgment, is of all lives the best, but
16127 infatuated by some youthful conceit of happiness which gets up into his
16128 head shall seek to appropriate the whole state to himself, then he will
16129 have to learn how wisely Hesiod spoke, when he said, 'half is more than
16130 the whole.'
16131 
16132 If he were to consult me, I should say to him: Stay where you are, when
16133 you have the offer of such a life.
16134 
16135 You agree then, I said, that men and women are to have a common way of
16136 life such as we have described--common education, common children; and
16137 they are to watch over the citizens in common whether abiding in the
16138 city or going out to war; they are to keep watch together, and to hunt
16139 together like dogs; and always and in all things, as far as they are
16140 able, women are to share with the men? And in so doing they will do what
16141 is best, and will not violate, but preserve the natural relation of the
16142 sexes.
16143 
16144 I agree with you, he replied.
16145 
16146 The enquiry, I said, has yet to be made, whether such a community
16147 be found possible--as among other animals, so also among men--and if
16148 possible, in what way possible?
16149 
16150 You have anticipated the question which I was about to suggest.
16151 
16152 There is no difficulty, I said, in seeing how war will be carried on by
16153 them.
16154 
16155 How?
16156 
16157 Why, of course they will go on expeditions together; and will take with
16158 them any of their children who are strong enough, that, after the manner
16159 of the artisan's child, they may look on at the work which they will
16160 have to do when they are grown up; and besides looking on they will
16161 have to help and be of use in war, and to wait upon their fathers and
16162 mothers. Did you never observe in the arts how the potters' boys look on
16163 and help, long before they touch the wheel?
16164 
16165 Yes, I have.
16166 
16167 And shall potters be more careful in educating their children and in
16168 giving them the opportunity of seeing and practising their duties than
16169 our guardians will be?
16170 
16171 The idea is ridiculous, he said.
16172 
16173 There is also the effect on the parents, with whom, as with other
16174 animals, the presence of their young ones will be the greatest incentive
16175 to valour.
16176 
16177 That is quite true, Socrates; and yet if they are defeated, which may
16178 often happen in war, how great the danger is! the children will be lost
16179 as well as their parents, and the State will never recover.
16180 
16181 True, I said; but would you never allow them to run any risk?
16182 
16183 I am far from saying that.
16184 
16185 Well, but if they are ever to run a risk should they not do so on some
16186 occasion when, if they escape disaster, they will be the better for it?
16187 
16188 Clearly.
16189 
16190 Whether the future soldiers do or do not see war in the days of their
16191 youth is a very important matter, for the sake of which some risk may
16192 fairly be incurred.
16193 
16194 Yes, very important.
16195 
16196 This then must be our first step,--to make our children spectators
16197 of war; but we must also contrive that they shall be secured against
16198 danger; then all will be well.
16199 
16200 True.
16201 
16202 Their parents may be supposed not to be blind to the risks of war, but
16203 to know, as far as human foresight can, what expeditions are safe and
16204 what dangerous?
16205 
16206 That may be assumed.
16207 
16208 And they will take them on the safe expeditions and be cautious about
16209 the dangerous ones?
16210 
16211 True.
16212 
16213 And they will place them under the command of experienced veterans who
16214 will be their leaders and teachers?
16215 
16216 Very properly.
16217 
16218 Still, the dangers of war cannot be always foreseen; there is a good
16219 deal of chance about them?
16220 
16221 True.
16222 
16223 Then against such chances the children must be at once furnished with
16224 wings, in order that in the hour of need they may fly away and escape.
16225 
16226 What do you mean? he said.
16227 
16228 I mean that we must mount them on horses in their earliest youth, and
16229 when they have learnt to ride, take them on horseback to see war: the
16230 horses must not be spirited and warlike, but the most tractable and yet
16231 the swiftest that can be had. In this way they will get an excellent
16232 view of what is hereafter to be their own business; and if there is
16233 danger they have only to follow their elder leaders and escape.
16234 
16235 I believe that you are right, he said.
16236 
16237 Next, as to war; what are to be the relations of your soldiers to one
16238 another and to their enemies? I should be inclined to propose that the
16239 soldier who leaves his rank or throws away his arms, or is guilty of any
16240 other act of cowardice, should be degraded into the rank of a husbandman
16241 or artisan. What do you think?
16242 
16243 By all means, I should say.
16244 
16245 And he who allows himself to be taken prisoner may as well be made a
16246 present of to his enemies; he is their lawful prey, and let them do what
16247 they like with him.
16248 
16249 Certainly.
16250 
16251 But the hero who has distinguished himself, what shall be done to
16252 him? In the first place, he shall receive honour in the army from his
16253 youthful comrades; every one of them in succession shall crown him. What
16254 do you say?
16255 
16256 I approve.
16257 
16258 And what do you say to his receiving the right hand of fellowship?
16259 
16260 To that too, I agree.
16261 
16262 But you will hardly agree to my next proposal.
16263 
16264 What is your proposal?
16265 
16266 That he should kiss and be kissed by them.
16267 
16268 Most certainly, and I should be disposed to go further, and say: Let
16269 no one whom he has a mind to kiss refuse to be kissed by him while the
16270 expedition lasts. So that if there be a lover in the army, whether
16271 his love be youth or maiden, he may be more eager to win the prize of
16272 valour.
16273 
16274 Capital, I said. That the brave man is to have more wives than others
16275 has been already determined: and he is to have first choices in such
16276 matters more than others, in order that he may have as many children as
16277 possible?
16278 
16279 Agreed.
16280 
16281 Again, there is another manner in which, according to Homer, brave
16282 youths should be honoured; for he tells how Ajax, after he had
16283 distinguished himself in battle, was rewarded with long chines, which
16284 seems to be a compliment appropriate to a hero in the flower of his age,
16285 being not only a tribute of honour but also a very strengthening thing.
16286 
16287 Most true, he said.
16288 
16289 Then in this, I said, Homer shall be our teacher; and we too, at
16290 sacrifices and on the like occasions, will honour the brave according to
16291 the measure of their valour, whether men or women, with hymns and those
16292 other distinctions which we were mentioning; also with
16293 
16294 'seats of precedence, and meats and full cups;'
16295 
16296 and in honouring them, we shall be at the same time training them.
16297 
16298 That, he replied, is excellent.
16299 
16300 Yes, I said; and when a man dies gloriously in war shall we not say, in
16301 the first place, that he is of the golden race?
16302 
16303 To be sure.
16304 
16305 Nay, have we not the authority of Hesiod for affirming that when they
16306 are dead
16307 
16308 'They are holy angels upon the earth, authors of good, averters of evil,
16309 the guardians of speech-gifted men'?
16310 
16311 Yes; and we accept his authority.
16312 
16313 We must learn of the god how we are to order the sepulture of divine and
16314 heroic personages, and what is to be their special distinction; and we
16315 must do as he bids?
16316 
16317 By all means.
16318 
16319 And in ages to come we will reverence them and kneel before their
16320 sepulchres as at the graves of heroes. And not only they but any who are
16321 deemed pre-eminently good, whether they die from age, or in any other
16322 way, shall be admitted to the same honours.
16323 
16324 That is very right, he said.
16325 
16326 Next, how shall our soldiers treat their enemies? What about this?
16327 
16328 In what respect do you mean?
16329 
16330 First of all, in regard to slavery? Do you think it right that Hellenes
16331 should enslave Hellenic States, or allow others to enslave them, if
16332 they can help? Should not their custom be to spare them, considering
16333 the danger which there is that the whole race may one day fall under the
16334 yoke of the barbarians?
16335 
16336 To spare them is infinitely better.
16337 
16338 Then no Hellene should be owned by them as a slave; that is a rule which
16339 they will observe and advise the other Hellenes to observe.
16340 
16341 Certainly, he said; they will in this way be united against the
16342 barbarians and will keep their hands off one another.
16343 
16344 Next as to the slain; ought the conquerors, I said, to take anything
16345 but their armour? Does not the practice of despoiling an enemy afford
16346 an excuse for not facing the battle? Cowards skulk about the dead,
16347 pretending that they are fulfilling a duty, and many an army before now
16348 has been lost from this love of plunder.
16349 
16350 Very true.
16351 
16352 And is there not illiberality and avarice in robbing a corpse, and also
16353 a degree of meanness and womanishness in making an enemy of the dead
16354 body when the real enemy has flown away and left only his fighting
16355 gear behind him,--is not this rather like a dog who cannot get at his
16356 assailant, quarrelling with the stones which strike him instead?
16357 
16358 Very like a dog, he said.
16359 
16360 Then we must abstain from spoiling the dead or hindering their burial?
16361 
16362 Yes, he replied, we most certainly must.
16363 
16364 Neither shall we offer up arms at the temples of the gods, least of all
16365 the arms of Hellenes, if we care to maintain good feeling with other
16366 Hellenes; and, indeed, we have reason to fear that the offering of
16367 spoils taken from kinsmen may be a pollution unless commanded by the god
16368 himself?
16369 
16370 Very true.
16371 
16372 Again, as to the devastation of Hellenic territory or the burning of
16373 houses, what is to be the practice?
16374 
16375 May I have the pleasure, he said, of hearing your opinion?
16376 
16377 Both should be forbidden, in my judgment; I would take the annual
16378 produce and no more. Shall I tell you why?
16379 
16380 Pray do.
16381 
16382 Why, you see, there is a difference in the names 'discord' and 'war,'
16383 and I imagine that there is also a difference in their natures; the one
16384 is expressive of what is internal and domestic, the other of what is
16385 external and foreign; and the first of the two is termed discord, and
16386 only the second, war.
16387 
16388 That is a very proper distinction, he replied.
16389 
16390 And may I not observe with equal propriety that the Hellenic race is all
16391 united together by ties of blood and friendship, and alien and strange
16392 to the barbarians?
16393 
16394 Very good, he said.
16395 
16396 And therefore when Hellenes fight with barbarians and barbarians with
16397 Hellenes, they will be described by us as being at war when they fight,
16398 and by nature enemies, and this kind of antagonism should be called war;
16399 but when Hellenes fight with one another we shall say that Hellas is
16400 then in a state of disorder and discord, they being by nature friends;
16401 and such enmity is to be called discord.
16402 
16403 I agree.
16404 
16405 Consider then, I said, when that which we have acknowledged to be
16406 discord occurs, and a city is divided, if both parties destroy the lands
16407 and burn the houses of one another, how wicked does the strife appear!
16408 No true lover of his country would bring himself to tear in pieces his
16409 own nurse and mother: There might be reason in the conqueror depriving
16410 the conquered of their harvest, but still they would have the idea of
16411 peace in their hearts and would not mean to go on fighting for ever.
16412 
16413 Yes, he said, that is a better temper than the other.
16414 
16415 And will not the city, which you are founding, be an Hellenic city?
16416 
16417 It ought to be, he replied.
16418 
16419 Then will not the citizens be good and civilized?
16420 
16421 Yes, very civilized.
16422 
16423 And will they not be lovers of Hellas, and think of Hellas as their own
16424 land, and share in the common temples?
16425 
16426 Most certainly.
16427 
16428 And any difference which arises among them will be regarded by them as
16429 discord only--a quarrel among friends, which is not to be called a war?
16430 
16431 Certainly not.
16432 
16433 Then they will quarrel as those who intend some day to be reconciled?
16434 
16435 Certainly.
16436 
16437 They will use friendly correction, but will not enslave or destroy their
16438 opponents; they will be correctors, not enemies?
16439 
16440 Just so.
16441 
16442 And as they are Hellenes themselves they will not devastate Hellas, nor
16443 will they burn houses, nor ever suppose that the whole population of a
16444 city--men, women, and children--are equally their enemies, for they know
16445 that the guilt of war is always confined to a few persons and that the
16446 many are their friends. And for all these reasons they will be unwilling
16447 to waste their lands and rase their houses; their enmity to them will
16448 only last until the many innocent sufferers have compelled the guilty
16449 few to give satisfaction?
16450 
16451 I agree, he said, that our citizens should thus deal with their Hellenic
16452 enemies; and with barbarians as the Hellenes now deal with one another.
16453 
16454 Then let us enact this law also for our guardians:--that they are
16455 neither to devastate the lands of Hellenes nor to burn their houses.
16456 
16457 Agreed; and we may agree also in thinking that these, like all our
16458 previous enactments, are very good.
16459 
16460 But still I must say, Socrates, that if you are allowed to go on in
16461 this way you will entirely forget the other question which at the
16462 commencement of this discussion you thrust aside:--Is such an order of
16463 things possible, and how, if at all? For I am quite ready to acknowledge
16464 that the plan which you propose, if only feasible, would do all sorts of
16465 good to the State. I will add, what you have omitted, that your citizens
16466 will be the bravest of warriors, and will never leave their ranks, for
16467 they will all know one another, and each will call the other father,
16468 brother, son; and if you suppose the women to join their armies, whether
16469 in the same rank or in the rear, either as a terror to the enemy, or as
16470 auxiliaries in case of need, I know that they will then be absolutely
16471 invincible; and there are many domestic advantages which might also be
16472 mentioned and which I also fully acknowledge: but, as I admit all these
16473 advantages and as many more as you please, if only this State of yours
16474 were to come into existence, we need say no more about them; assuming
16475 then the existence of the State, let us now turn to the question of
16476 possibility and ways and means--the rest may be left.
16477 
16478 If I loiter for a moment, you instantly make a raid upon me, I said, and
16479 have no mercy; I have hardly escaped the first and second waves, and you
16480 seem not to be aware that you are now bringing upon me the third, which
16481 is the greatest and heaviest. When you have seen and heard the third
16482 wave, I think you will be more considerate and will acknowledge
16483 that some fear and hesitation was natural respecting a proposal so
16484 extraordinary as that which I have now to state and investigate.
16485 
16486 The more appeals of this sort which you make, he said, the more
16487 determined are we that you shall tell us how such a State is possible:
16488 speak out and at once.
16489 
16490 Let me begin by reminding you that we found our way hither in the search
16491 after justice and injustice.
16492 
16493 True, he replied; but what of that?
16494 
16495 I was only going to ask whether, if we have discovered them, we are to
16496 require that the just man should in nothing fail of absolute justice; or
16497 may we be satisfied with an approximation, and the attainment in him of
16498 a higher degree of justice than is to be found in other men?
16499 
16500 The approximation will be enough.
16501 
16502 We were enquiring into the nature of absolute justice and into the
16503 character of the perfectly just, and into injustice and the perfectly
16504 unjust, that we might have an ideal. We were to look at these in order
16505 that we might judge of our own happiness and unhappiness according to
16506 the standard which they exhibited and the degree in which we resembled
16507 them, but not with any view of showing that they could exist in fact.
16508 
16509 True, he said.
16510 
16511 Would a painter be any the worse because, after having delineated with
16512 consummate art an ideal of a perfectly beautiful man, he was unable to
16513 show that any such man could ever have existed?
16514 
16515 He would be none the worse.
16516 
16517 Well, and were we not creating an ideal of a perfect State?
16518 
16519 To be sure.
16520 
16521 And is our theory a worse theory because we are unable to prove the
16522 possibility of a city being ordered in the manner described?
16523 
16524 Surely not, he replied.
16525 
16526 That is the truth, I said. But if, at your request, I am to try and show
16527 how and under what conditions the possibility is highest, I must ask
16528 you, having this in view, to repeat your former admissions.
16529 
16530 What admissions?
16531 
16532 I want to know whether ideals are ever fully realized in language?
16533 Does not the word express more than the fact, and must not the actual,
16534 whatever a man may think, always, in the nature of things, fall short of
16535 the truth? What do you say?
16536 
16537 I agree.
16538 
16539 Then you must not insist on my proving that the actual State will in
16540 every respect coincide with the ideal: if we are only able to discover
16541 how a city may be governed nearly as we proposed, you will admit that we
16542 have discovered the possibility which you demand; and will be contented.
16543 I am sure that I should be contented--will not you?
16544 
16545 Yes, I will.
16546 
16547 Let me next endeavour to show what is that fault in States which is the
16548 cause of their present maladministration, and what is the least change
16549 which will enable a State to pass into the truer form; and let the
16550 change, if possible, be of one thing only, or, if not, of two; at any
16551 rate, let the changes be as few and slight as possible.
16552 
16553 Certainly, he replied.
16554 
16555 I think, I said, that there might be a reform of the State if only one
16556 change were made, which is not a slight or easy though still a possible
16557 one.
16558 
16559 What is it? he said.
16560 
16561 Now then, I said, I go to meet that which I liken to the greatest of
16562 the waves; yet shall the word be spoken, even though the wave break and
16563 drown me in laughter and dishonour; and do you mark my words.
16564 
16565 Proceed.
16566 
16567 I said: 'Until philosophers are kings, or the kings and princes of this
16568 world have the spirit and power of philosophy, and political greatness
16569 and wisdom meet in one, and those commoner natures who pursue either
16570 to the exclusion of the other are compelled to stand aside, cities
16571 will never have rest from their evils,--nor the human race, as I
16572 believe,--and then only will this our State have a possibility of life
16573 and behold the light of day.' Such was the thought, my dear Glaucon,
16574 which I would fain have uttered if it had not seemed too extravagant;
16575 for to be convinced that in no other State can there be happiness
16576 private or public is indeed a hard thing.
16577 
16578 Socrates, what do you mean? I would have you consider that the word
16579 which you have uttered is one at which numerous persons, and very
16580 respectable persons too, in a figure pulling off their coats all in a
16581 moment, and seizing any weapon that comes to hand, will run at you might
16582 and main, before you know where you are, intending to do heaven knows
16583 what; and if you don't prepare an answer, and put yourself in motion,
16584 you will be 'pared by their fine wits,' and no mistake.
16585 
16586 You got me into the scrape, I said.
16587 
16588 And I was quite right; however, I will do all I can to get you out of
16589 it; but I can only give you good-will and good advice, and, perhaps, I
16590 may be able to fit answers to your questions better than another--that
16591 is all. And now, having such an auxiliary, you must do your best to show
16592 the unbelievers that you are right.
16593 
16594 I ought to try, I said, since you offer me such invaluable assistance.
16595 And I think that, if there is to be a chance of our escaping, we must
16596 explain to them whom we mean when we say that philosophers are to rule
16597 in the State; then we shall be able to defend ourselves: There will be
16598 discovered to be some natures who ought to study philosophy and to be
16599 leaders in the State; and others who are not born to be philosophers,
16600 and are meant to be followers rather than leaders.
16601 
16602 Then now for a definition, he said.
16603 
16604 Follow me, I said, and I hope that I may in some way or other be able to
16605 give you a satisfactory explanation.
16606 
16607 Proceed.
16608 
16609 I dare say that you remember, and therefore I need not remind you, that
16610 a lover, if he is worthy of the name, ought to show his love, not to
16611 some one part of that which he loves, but to the whole.
16612 
16613 I really do not understand, and therefore beg of you to assist my
16614 memory.
16615 
16616 Another person, I said, might fairly reply as you do; but a man of
16617 pleasure like yourself ought to know that all who are in the flower of
16618 youth do somehow or other raise a pang or emotion in a lover's breast,
16619 and are thought by him to be worthy of his affectionate regards. Is not
16620 this a way which you have with the fair: one has a snub nose, and you
16621 praise his charming face; the hook-nose of another has, you say, a
16622 royal look; while he who is neither snub nor hooked has the grace of
16623 regularity: the dark visage is manly, the fair are children of the gods;
16624 and as to the sweet 'honey pale,' as they are called, what is the very
16625 name but the invention of a lover who talks in diminutives, and is not
16626 averse to paleness if appearing on the cheek of youth? In a word, there
16627 is no excuse which you will not make, and nothing which you will not
16628 say, in order not to lose a single flower that blooms in the spring-time
16629 of youth.
16630 
16631 If you make me an authority in matters of love, for the sake of the
16632 argument, I assent.
16633 
16634 And what do you say of lovers of wine? Do you not see them doing the
16635 same? They are glad of any pretext of drinking any wine.
16636 
16637 Very good.
16638 
16639 And the same is true of ambitious men; if they cannot command an army,
16640 they are willing to command a file; and if they cannot be honoured by
16641 really great and important persons, they are glad to be honoured by
16642 lesser and meaner people,--but honour of some kind they must have.
16643 
16644 Exactly.
16645 
16646 Once more let me ask: Does he who desires any class of goods, desire the
16647 whole class or a part only?
16648 
16649 The whole.
16650 
16651 And may we not say of the philosopher that he is a lover, not of a part
16652 of wisdom only, but of the whole?
16653 
16654 Yes, of the whole.
16655 
16656 And he who dislikes learning, especially in youth, when he has no power
16657 of judging what is good and what is not, such an one we maintain not
16658 to be a philosopher or a lover of knowledge, just as he who refuses his
16659 food is not hungry, and may be said to have a bad appetite and not a
16660 good one?
16661 
16662 Very true, he said.
16663 
16664 Whereas he who has a taste for every sort of knowledge and who is
16665 curious to learn and is never satisfied, may be justly termed a
16666 philosopher? Am I not right?
16667 
16668 Glaucon said: If curiosity makes a philosopher, you will find many a
16669 strange being will have a title to the name. All the lovers of sights
16670 have a delight in learning, and must therefore be included. Musical
16671 amateurs, too, are a folk strangely out of place among philosophers, for
16672 they are the last persons in the world who would come to anything like
16673 a philosophical discussion, if they could help, while they run about at
16674 the Dionysiac festivals as if they had let out their ears to hear every
16675 chorus; whether the performance is in town or country--that makes no
16676 difference--they are there. Now are we to maintain that all these and
16677 any who have similar tastes, as well as the professors of quite minor
16678 arts, are philosophers?
16679 
16680 Certainly not, I replied; they are only an imitation.
16681 
16682 He said: Who then are the true philosophers?
16683 
16684 Those, I said, who are lovers of the vision of truth.
16685 
16686 That is also good, he said; but I should like to know what you mean?
16687 
16688 To another, I replied, I might have a difficulty in explaining; but I am
16689 sure that you will admit a proposition which I am about to make.
16690 
16691 What is the proposition?
16692 
16693 That since beauty is the opposite of ugliness, they are two?
16694 
16695 Certainly.
16696 
16697 And inasmuch as they are two, each of them is one?
16698 
16699 True again.
16700 
16701 And of just and unjust, good and evil, and of every other class, the
16702 same remark holds: taken singly, each of them is one; but from the
16703 various combinations of them with actions and things and with one
16704 another, they are seen in all sorts of lights and appear many?
16705 
16706 Very true.
16707 
16708 And this is the distinction which I draw between the sight-loving,
16709 art-loving, practical class and those of whom I am speaking, and who are
16710 alone worthy of the name of philosophers.
16711 
16712 How do you distinguish them? he said.
16713 
16714 The lovers of sounds and sights, I replied, are, as I conceive, fond of
16715 fine tones and colours and forms and all the artificial products that
16716 are made out of them, but their mind is incapable of seeing or loving
16717 absolute beauty.
16718 
16719 True, he replied.
16720 
16721 Few are they who are able to attain to the sight of this.
16722 
16723 Very true.
16724 
16725 And he who, having a sense of beautiful things has no sense of absolute
16726 beauty, or who, if another lead him to a knowledge of that beauty is
16727 unable to follow--of such an one I ask, Is he awake or in a dream
16728 only? Reflect: is not the dreamer, sleeping or waking, one who likens
16729 dissimilar things, who puts the copy in the place of the real object?
16730 
16731 I should certainly say that such an one was dreaming.
16732 
16733 But take the case of the other, who recognises the existence of absolute
16734 beauty and is able to distinguish the idea from the objects which
16735 participate in the idea, neither putting the objects in the place of the
16736 idea nor the idea in the place of the objects--is he a dreamer, or is he
16737 awake?
16738 
16739 He is wide awake.
16740 
16741 And may we not say that the mind of the one who knows has knowledge, and
16742 that the mind of the other, who opines only, has opinion?
16743 
16744 Certainly.
16745 
16746 But suppose that the latter should quarrel with us and dispute our
16747 statement, can we administer any soothing cordial or advice to him,
16748 without revealing to him that there is sad disorder in his wits?
16749 
16750 We must certainly offer him some good advice, he replied.
16751 
16752 Come, then, and let us think of something to say to him. Shall we begin
16753 by assuring him that he is welcome to any knowledge which he may have,
16754 and that we are rejoiced at his having it? But we should like to ask him
16755 a question: Does he who has knowledge know something or nothing? (You
16756 must answer for him.)
16757 
16758 I answer that he knows something.
16759 
16760 Something that is or is not?
16761 
16762 Something that is; for how can that which is not ever be known?
16763 
16764 And are we assured, after looking at the matter from many points of
16765 view, that absolute being is or may be absolutely known, but that the
16766 utterly non-existent is utterly unknown?
16767 
16768 Nothing can be more certain.
16769 
16770 Good. But if there be anything which is of such a nature as to be and
16771 not to be, that will have a place intermediate between pure being and
16772 the absolute negation of being?
16773 
16774 Yes, between them.
16775 
16776 And, as knowledge corresponded to being and ignorance of necessity to
16777 not-being, for that intermediate between being and not-being there has
16778 to be discovered a corresponding intermediate between ignorance and
16779 knowledge, if there be such?
16780 
16781 Certainly.
16782 
16783 Do we admit the existence of opinion?
16784 
16785 Undoubtedly.
16786 
16787 As being the same with knowledge, or another faculty?
16788 
16789 Another faculty.
16790 
16791 Then opinion and knowledge have to do with different kinds of matter
16792 corresponding to this difference of faculties?
16793 
16794 Yes.
16795 
16796 And knowledge is relative to being and knows being. But before I proceed
16797 further I will make a division.
16798 
16799 What division?
16800 
16801 I will begin by placing faculties in a class by themselves: they are
16802 powers in us, and in all other things, by which we do as we do. Sight
16803 and hearing, for example, I should call faculties. Have I clearly
16804 explained the class which I mean?
16805 
16806 Yes, I quite understand.
16807 
16808 Then let me tell you my view about them. I do not see them, and
16809 therefore the distinctions of figure, colour, and the like, which enable
16810 me to discern the differences of some things, do not apply to them. In
16811 speaking of a faculty I think only of its sphere and its result; and
16812 that which has the same sphere and the same result I call the same
16813 faculty, but that which has another sphere and another result I call
16814 different. Would that be your way of speaking?
16815 
16816 Yes.
16817 
16818 And will you be so very good as to answer one more question? Would you
16819 say that knowledge is a faculty, or in what class would you place it?
16820 
16821 Certainly knowledge is a faculty, and the mightiest of all faculties.
16822 
16823 And is opinion also a faculty?
16824 
16825 Certainly, he said; for opinion is that with which we are able to form
16826 an opinion.
16827 
16828 And yet you were acknowledging a little while ago that knowledge is not
16829 the same as opinion?
16830 
16831 Why, yes, he said: how can any reasonable being ever identify that which
16832 is infallible with that which errs?
16833 
16834 An excellent answer, proving, I said, that we are quite conscious of a
16835 distinction between them.
16836 
16837 Yes.
16838 
16839 Then knowledge and opinion having distinct powers have also distinct
16840 spheres or subject-matters?
16841 
16842 That is certain.
16843 
16844 Being is the sphere or subject-matter of knowledge, and knowledge is to
16845 know the nature of being?
16846 
16847 Yes.
16848 
16849 And opinion is to have an opinion?
16850 
16851 Yes.
16852 
16853 And do we know what we opine? or is the subject-matter of opinion the
16854 same as the subject-matter of knowledge?
16855 
16856 Nay, he replied, that has been already disproven; if difference in
16857 faculty implies difference in the sphere or subject-matter, and if, as
16858 we were saying, opinion and knowledge are distinct faculties, then the
16859 sphere of knowledge and of opinion cannot be the same.
16860 
16861 Then if being is the subject-matter of knowledge, something else must be
16862 the subject-matter of opinion?
16863 
16864 Yes, something else.
16865 
16866 Well then, is not-being the subject-matter of opinion? or, rather, how
16867 can there be an opinion at all about not-being? Reflect: when a man
16868 has an opinion, has he not an opinion about something? Can he have an
16869 opinion which is an opinion about nothing?
16870 
16871 Impossible.
16872 
16873 He who has an opinion has an opinion about some one thing?
16874 
16875 Yes.
16876 
16877 And not-being is not one thing but, properly speaking, nothing?
16878 
16879 True.
16880 
16881 Of not-being, ignorance was assumed to be the necessary correlative; of
16882 being, knowledge?
16883 
16884 True, he said.
16885 
16886 Then opinion is not concerned either with being or with not-being?
16887 
16888 Not with either.
16889 
16890 And can therefore neither be ignorance nor knowledge?
16891 
16892 That seems to be true.
16893 
16894 But is opinion to be sought without and beyond either of them, in
16895 a greater clearness than knowledge, or in a greater darkness than
16896 ignorance?
16897 
16898 In neither.
16899 
16900 Then I suppose that opinion appears to you to be darker than knowledge,
16901 but lighter than ignorance?
16902 
16903 Both; and in no small degree.
16904 
16905 And also to be within and between them?
16906 
16907 Yes.
16908 
16909 Then you would infer that opinion is intermediate?
16910 
16911 No question.
16912 
16913 But were we not saying before, that if anything appeared to be of a sort
16914 which is and is not at the same time, that sort of thing would appear
16915 also to lie in the interval between pure being and absolute not-being;
16916 and that the corresponding faculty is neither knowledge nor ignorance,
16917 but will be found in the interval between them?
16918 
16919 True.
16920 
16921 And in that interval there has now been discovered something which we
16922 call opinion?
16923 
16924 There has.
16925 
16926 Then what remains to be discovered is the object which partakes equally
16927 of the nature of being and not-being, and cannot rightly be termed
16928 either, pure and simple; this unknown term, when discovered, we may
16929 truly call the subject of opinion, and assign each to their proper
16930 faculty,--the extremes to the faculties of the extremes and the mean to
16931 the faculty of the mean.
16932 
16933 True.
16934 
16935 This being premised, I would ask the gentleman who is of opinion that
16936 there is no absolute or unchangeable idea of beauty--in whose opinion
16937 the beautiful is the manifold--he, I say, your lover of beautiful
16938 sights, who cannot bear to be told that the beautiful is one, and the
16939 just is one, or that anything is one--to him I would appeal, saying,
16940 Will you be so very kind, sir, as to tell us whether, of all these
16941 beautiful things, there is one which will not be found ugly; or of the
16942 just, which will not be found unjust; or of the holy, which will not
16943 also be unholy?
16944 
16945 No, he replied; the beautiful will in some point of view be found ugly;
16946 and the same is true of the rest.
16947 
16948 And may not the many which are doubles be also halves?--doubles, that
16949 is, of one thing, and halves of another?
16950 
16951 Quite true.
16952 
16953 And things great and small, heavy and light, as they are termed, will
16954 not be denoted by these any more than by the opposite names?
16955 
16956 True; both these and the opposite names will always attach to all of
16957 them.
16958 
16959 And can any one of those many things which are called by particular
16960 names be said to be this rather than not to be this?
16961 
16962 He replied: They are like the punning riddles which are asked at feasts
16963 or the children's puzzle about the eunuch aiming at the bat, with
16964 what he hit him, as they say in the puzzle, and upon what the bat
16965 was sitting. The individual objects of which I am speaking are also
16966 a riddle, and have a double sense: nor can you fix them in your mind,
16967 either as being or not-being, or both, or neither.
16968 
16969 Then what will you do with them? I said. Can they have a better place
16970 than between being and not-being? For they are clearly not in greater
16971 darkness or negation than not-being, or more full of light and existence
16972 than being.
16973 
16974 That is quite true, he said.
16975 
16976 Thus then we seem to have discovered that the many ideas which the
16977 multitude entertain about the beautiful and about all other things are
16978 tossing about in some region which is half-way between pure being and
16979 pure not-being?
16980 
16981 We have.
16982 
16983 Yes; and we had before agreed that anything of this kind which we might
16984 find was to be described as matter of opinion, and not as matter of
16985 knowledge; being the intermediate flux which is caught and detained by
16986 the intermediate faculty.
16987 
16988 Quite true.
16989 
16990 Then those who see the many beautiful, and who yet neither see absolute
16991 beauty, nor can follow any guide who points the way thither; who see the
16992 many just, and not absolute justice, and the like,--such persons may be
16993 said to have opinion but not knowledge?
16994 
16995 That is certain.
16996 
16997 But those who see the absolute and eternal and immutable may be said to
16998 know, and not to have opinion only?
16999 
17000 Neither can that be denied.
17001 
17002 The one love and embrace the subjects of knowledge, the other those of
17003 opinion? The latter are the same, as I dare say you will remember, who
17004 listened to sweet sounds and gazed upon fair colours, but would not
17005 tolerate the existence of absolute beauty.
17006 
17007 Yes, I remember.
17008 
17009 Shall we then be guilty of any impropriety in calling them lovers of
17010 opinion rather than lovers of wisdom, and will they be very angry with
17011 us for thus describing them?
17012 
17013 I shall tell them not to be angry; no man should be angry at what is
17014 true.
17015 
17016 But those who love the truth in each thing are to be called lovers of
17017 wisdom and not lovers of opinion.
17018 
17019 Assuredly.
17020 
17021 
17022 
17023 
17024 BOOK VI.
17025 
17026 And thus, Glaucon, after the argument has gone a weary way, the true and
17027 the false philosophers have at length appeared in view.
17028 
17029 I do not think, he said, that the way could have been shortened.
17030 
17031 I suppose not, I said; and yet I believe that we might have had a better
17032 view of both of them if the discussion could have been confined to this
17033 one subject and if there were not many other questions awaiting us,
17034 which he who desires to see in what respect the life of the just differs
17035 from that of the unjust must consider.
17036 
17037 And what is the next question? he asked.
17038 
17039 Surely, I said, the one which follows next in order. Inasmuch as
17040 philosophers only are able to grasp the eternal and unchangeable,
17041 and those who wander in the region of the many and variable are not
17042 philosophers, I must ask you which of the two classes should be the
17043 rulers of our State?
17044 
17045 And how can we rightly answer that question?
17046 
17047 Whichever of the two are best able to guard the laws and institutions of
17048 our State--let them be our guardians.
17049 
17050 Very good.
17051 
17052 Neither, I said, can there be any question that the guardian who is to
17053 keep anything should have eyes rather than no eyes?
17054 
17055 There can be no question of that.
17056 
17057 And are not those who are verily and indeed wanting in the knowledge
17058 of the true being of each thing, and who have in their souls no clear
17059 pattern, and are unable as with a painter's eye to look at the absolute
17060 truth and to that original to repair, and having perfect vision of the
17061 other world to order the laws about beauty, goodness, justice in this,
17062 if not already ordered, and to guard and preserve the order of them--are
17063 not such persons, I ask, simply blind?
17064 
17065 Truly, he replied, they are much in that condition.
17066 
17067 And shall they be our guardians when there are others who, besides being
17068 their equals in experience and falling short of them in no particular of
17069 virtue, also know the very truth of each thing?
17070 
17071 There can be no reason, he said, for rejecting those who have this
17072 greatest of all great qualities; they must always have the first place
17073 unless they fail in some other respect.
17074 
17075 Suppose then, I said, that we determine how far they can unite this and
17076 the other excellences.
17077 
17078 By all means.
17079 
17080 In the first place, as we began by observing, the nature of the
17081 philosopher has to be ascertained. We must come to an understanding
17082 about him, and, when we have done so, then, if I am not mistaken, we
17083 shall also acknowledge that such an union of qualities is possible, and
17084 that those in whom they are united, and those only, should be rulers in
17085 the State.
17086 
17087 What do you mean?
17088 
17089 Let us suppose that philosophical minds always love knowledge of a sort
17090 which shows them the eternal nature not varying from generation and
17091 corruption.
17092 
17093 Agreed.
17094 
17095 And further, I said, let us agree that they are lovers of all true
17096 being; there is no part whether greater or less, or more or less
17097 honourable, which they are willing to renounce; as we said before of the
17098 lover and the man of ambition.
17099 
17100 True.
17101 
17102 And if they are to be what we were describing, is there not another
17103 quality which they should also possess?
17104 
17105 What quality?
17106 
17107 Truthfulness: they will never intentionally receive into their mind
17108 falsehood, which is their detestation, and they will love the truth.
17109 
17110 Yes, that may be safely affirmed of them.
17111 
17112 'May be,' my friend, I replied, is not the word; say rather 'must be
17113 affirmed:' for he whose nature is amorous of anything cannot help loving
17114 all that belongs or is akin to the object of his affections.
17115 
17116 Right, he said.
17117 
17118 And is there anything more akin to wisdom than truth?
17119 
17120 How can there be?
17121 
17122 Can the same nature be a lover of wisdom and a lover of falsehood?
17123 
17124 Never.
17125 
17126 The true lover of learning then must from his earliest youth, as far as
17127 in him lies, desire all truth?
17128 
17129 Assuredly.
17130 
17131 But then again, as we know by experience, he whose desires are strong
17132 in one direction will have them weaker in others; they will be like a
17133 stream which has been drawn off into another channel.
17134 
17135 True.
17136 
17137 He whose desires are drawn towards knowledge in every form will be
17138 absorbed in the pleasures of the soul, and will hardly feel bodily
17139 pleasure--I mean, if he be a true philosopher and not a sham one.
17140 
17141 That is most certain.
17142 
17143 Such an one is sure to be temperate and the reverse of covetous; for the
17144 motives which make another man desirous of having and spending, have no
17145 place in his character.
17146 
17147 Very true.
17148 
17149 Another criterion of the philosophical nature has also to be considered.
17150 
17151 What is that?
17152 
17153 There should be no secret corner of illiberality; nothing can be more
17154 antagonistic than meanness to a soul which is ever longing after the
17155 whole of things both divine and human.
17156 
17157 Most true, he replied.
17158 
17159 Then how can he who has magnificence of mind and is the spectator of all
17160 time and all existence, think much of human life?
17161 
17162 He cannot.
17163 
17164 Or can such an one account death fearful?
17165 
17166 No indeed.
17167 
17168 Then the cowardly and mean nature has no part in true philosophy?
17169 
17170 Certainly not.
17171 
17172 Or again: can he who is harmoniously constituted, who is not covetous or
17173 mean, or a boaster, or a coward--can he, I say, ever be unjust or hard
17174 in his dealings?
17175 
17176 Impossible.
17177 
17178 Then you will soon observe whether a man is just and gentle, or rude
17179 and unsociable; these are the signs which distinguish even in youth the
17180 philosophical nature from the unphilosophical.
17181 
17182 True.
17183 
17184 There is another point which should be remarked.
17185 
17186 What point?
17187 
17188 Whether he has or has not a pleasure in learning; for no one will love
17189 that which gives him pain, and in which after much toil he makes little
17190 progress.
17191 
17192 Certainly not.
17193 
17194 And again, if he is forgetful and retains nothing of what he learns,
17195 will he not be an empty vessel?
17196 
17197 That is certain.
17198 
17199 Labouring in vain, he must end in hating himself and his fruitless
17200 occupation? Yes.
17201 
17202 Then a soul which forgets cannot be ranked among genuine philosophic
17203 natures; we must insist that the philosopher should have a good memory?
17204 
17205 Certainly.
17206 
17207 And once more, the inharmonious and unseemly nature can only tend to
17208 disproportion?
17209 
17210 Undoubtedly.
17211 
17212 And do you consider truth to be akin to proportion or to disproportion?
17213 
17214 To proportion.
17215 
17216 Then, besides other qualities, we must try to find a naturally
17217 well-proportioned and gracious mind, which will move spontaneously
17218 towards the true being of everything.
17219 
17220 Certainly.
17221 
17222 Well, and do not all these qualities, which we have been enumerating, go
17223 together, and are they not, in a manner, necessary to a soul, which is
17224 to have a full and perfect participation of being?
17225 
17226 They are absolutely necessary, he replied.
17227 
17228 And must not that be a blameless study which he only can pursue who has
17229 the gift of a good memory, and is quick to learn,--noble, gracious, the
17230 friend of truth, justice, courage, temperance, who are his kindred?
17231 
17232 The god of jealousy himself, he said, could find no fault with such a
17233 study.
17234 
17235 And to men like him, I said, when perfected by years and education, and
17236 to these only you will entrust the State.
17237 
17238 Here Adeimantus interposed and said: To these statements, Socrates, no
17239 one can offer a reply; but when you talk in this way, a strange feeling
17240 passes over the minds of your hearers: They fancy that they are led
17241 astray a little at each step in the argument, owing to their own want of
17242 skill in asking and answering questions; these littles accumulate, and
17243 at the end of the discussion they are found to have sustained a mighty
17244 overthrow and all their former notions appear to be turned upside down.
17245 And as unskilful players of draughts are at last shut up by their
17246 more skilful adversaries and have no piece to move, so they too find
17247 themselves shut up at last; for they have nothing to say in this new
17248 game of which words are the counters; and yet all the time they are in
17249 the right. The observation is suggested to me by what is now occurring.
17250 For any one of us might say, that although in words he is not able
17251 to meet you at each step of the argument, he sees as a fact that the
17252 votaries of philosophy, when they carry on the study, not only in youth
17253 as a part of education, but as the pursuit of their maturer years, most
17254 of them become strange monsters, not to say utter rogues, and that those
17255 who may be considered the best of them are made useless to the world by
17256 the very study which you extol.
17257 
17258 Well, and do you think that those who say so are wrong?
17259 
17260 I cannot tell, he replied; but I should like to know what is your
17261 opinion.
17262 
17263 Hear my answer; I am of opinion that they are quite right.
17264 
17265 Then how can you be justified in saying that cities will not cease from
17266 evil until philosophers rule in them, when philosophers are acknowledged
17267 by us to be of no use to them?
17268 
17269 You ask a question, I said, to which a reply can only be given in a
17270 parable.
17271 
17272 Yes, Socrates; and that is a way of speaking to which you are not at all
17273 accustomed, I suppose.
17274 
17275 I perceive, I said, that you are vastly amused at having plunged me into
17276 such a hopeless discussion; but now hear the parable, and then you will
17277 be still more amused at the meagreness of my imagination: for the manner
17278 in which the best men are treated in their own States is so grievous
17279 that no single thing on earth is comparable to it; and therefore, if
17280 I am to plead their cause, I must have recourse to fiction, and put
17281 together a figure made up of many things, like the fabulous unions of
17282 goats and stags which are found in pictures. Imagine then a fleet or a
17283 ship in which there is a captain who is taller and stronger than any of
17284 the crew, but he is a little deaf and has a similar infirmity in sight,
17285 and his knowledge of navigation is not much better. The sailors are
17286 quarrelling with one another about the steering--every one is of opinion
17287 that he has a right to steer, though he has never learned the art of
17288 navigation and cannot tell who taught him or when he learned, and will
17289 further assert that it cannot be taught, and they are ready to cut in
17290 pieces any one who says the contrary. They throng about the captain,
17291 begging and praying him to commit the helm to them; and if at any time
17292 they do not prevail, but others are preferred to them, they kill the
17293 others or throw them overboard, and having first chained up the noble
17294 captain's senses with drink or some narcotic drug, they mutiny and take
17295 possession of the ship and make free with the stores; thus, eating
17296 and drinking, they proceed on their voyage in such manner as might be
17297 expected of them. Him who is their partisan and cleverly aids them in
17298 their plot for getting the ship out of the captain's hands into their
17299 own whether by force or persuasion, they compliment with the name of
17300 sailor, pilot, able seaman, and abuse the other sort of man, whom they
17301 call a good-for-nothing; but that the true pilot must pay attention
17302 to the year and seasons and sky and stars and winds, and whatever else
17303 belongs to his art, if he intends to be really qualified for the command
17304 of a ship, and that he must and will be the steerer, whether other
17305 people like or not--the possibility of this union of authority with the
17306 steerer's art has never seriously entered into their thoughts or been
17307 made part of their calling. Now in vessels which are in a state of
17308 mutiny and by sailors who are mutineers, how will the true pilot be
17309 regarded? Will he not be called by them a prater, a star-gazer, a
17310 good-for-nothing?
17311 
17312 Of course, said Adeimantus.
17313 
17314 Then you will hardly need, I said, to hear the interpretation of the
17315 figure, which describes the true philosopher in his relation to the
17316 State; for you understand already.
17317 
17318 Certainly.
17319 
17320 Then suppose you now take this parable to the gentleman who is surprised
17321 at finding that philosophers have no honour in their cities; explain
17322 it to him and try to convince him that their having honour would be far
17323 more extraordinary.
17324 
17325 I will.
17326 
17327 Say to him, that, in deeming the best votaries of philosophy to be
17328 useless to the rest of the world, he is right; but also tell him to
17329 attribute their uselessness to the fault of those who will not use them,
17330 and not to themselves. The pilot should not humbly beg the sailors to be
17331 commanded by him--that is not the order of nature; neither are 'the wise
17332 to go to the doors of the rich'--the ingenious author of this saying
17333 told a lie--but the truth is, that, when a man is ill, whether he
17334 be rich or poor, to the physician he must go, and he who wants to
17335 be governed, to him who is able to govern. The ruler who is good for
17336 anything ought not to beg his subjects to be ruled by him; although
17337 the present governors of mankind are of a different stamp; they may be
17338 justly compared to the mutinous sailors, and the true helmsmen to those
17339 who are called by them good-for-nothings and star-gazers.
17340 
17341 Precisely so, he said.
17342 
17343 For these reasons, and among men like these, philosophy, the noblest
17344 pursuit of all, is not likely to be much esteemed by those of the
17345 opposite faction; not that the greatest and most lasting injury is done
17346 to her by her opponents, but by her own professing followers, the same
17347 of whom you suppose the accuser to say, that the greater number of them
17348 are arrant rogues, and the best are useless; in which opinion I agreed.
17349 
17350 Yes.
17351 
17352 And the reason why the good are useless has now been explained?
17353 
17354 True.
17355 
17356 Then shall we proceed to show that the corruption of the majority is
17357 also unavoidable, and that this is not to be laid to the charge of
17358 philosophy any more than the other?
17359 
17360 By all means.
17361 
17362 And let us ask and answer in turn, first going back to the description
17363 of the gentle and noble nature. Truth, as you will remember, was his
17364 leader, whom he followed always and in all things; failing in this, he
17365 was an impostor, and had no part or lot in true philosophy.
17366 
17367 Yes, that was said.
17368 
17369 Well, and is not this one quality, to mention no others, greatly at
17370 variance with present notions of him?
17371 
17372 Certainly, he said.
17373 
17374 And have we not a right to say in his defence, that the true lover of
17375 knowledge is always striving after being--that is his nature; he will
17376 not rest in the multiplicity of individuals which is an appearance only,
17377 but will go on--the keen edge will not be blunted, nor the force of his
17378 desire abate until he have attained the knowledge of the true nature
17379 of every essence by a sympathetic and kindred power in the soul, and by
17380 that power drawing near and mingling and becoming incorporate with very
17381 being, having begotten mind and truth, he will have knowledge and will
17382 live and grow truly, and then, and not till then, will he cease from his
17383 travail.
17384 
17385 Nothing, he said, can be more just than such a description of him.
17386 
17387 And will the love of a lie be any part of a philosopher's nature? Will
17388 he not utterly hate a lie?
17389 
17390 He will.
17391 
17392 And when truth is the captain, we cannot suspect any evil of the band
17393 which he leads?
17394 
17395 Impossible.
17396 
17397 Justice and health of mind will be of the company, and temperance will
17398 follow after?
17399 
17400 True, he replied.
17401 
17402 Neither is there any reason why I should again set in array the
17403 philosopher's virtues, as you will doubtless remember that courage,
17404 magnificence, apprehension, memory, were his natural gifts. And you
17405 objected that, although no one could deny what I then said, still, if
17406 you leave words and look at facts, the persons who are thus described
17407 are some of them manifestly useless, and the greater number utterly
17408 depraved; we were then led to enquire into the grounds of these
17409 accusations, and have now arrived at the point of asking why are
17410 the majority bad, which question of necessity brought us back to the
17411 examination and definition of the true philosopher.
17412 
17413 Exactly.
17414 
17415 And we have next to consider the corruptions of the philosophic nature,
17416 why so many are spoiled and so few escape spoiling--I am speaking of
17417 those who were said to be useless but not wicked--and, when we have done
17418 with them, we will speak of the imitators of philosophy, what manner of
17419 men are they who aspire after a profession which is above them and of
17420 which they are unworthy, and then, by their manifold inconsistencies,
17421 bring upon philosophy, and upon all philosophers, that universal
17422 reprobation of which we speak.
17423 
17424 What are these corruptions? he said.
17425 
17426 I will see if I can explain them to you. Every one will admit that a
17427 nature having in perfection all the qualities which we required in a
17428 philosopher, is a rare plant which is seldom seen among men.
17429 
17430 Rare indeed.
17431 
17432 And what numberless and powerful causes tend to destroy these rare
17433 natures!
17434 
17435 What causes?
17436 
17437 In the first place there are their own virtues, their courage,
17438 temperance, and the rest of them, every one of which praiseworthy
17439 qualities (and this is a most singular circumstance) destroys and
17440 distracts from philosophy the soul which is the possessor of them.
17441 
17442 That is very singular, he replied.
17443 
17444 Then there are all the ordinary goods of life--beauty, wealth, strength,
17445 rank, and great connections in the State--you understand the sort of
17446 things--these also have a corrupting and distracting effect.
17447 
17448 I understand; but I should like to know more precisely what you mean
17449 about them.
17450 
17451 Grasp the truth as a whole, I said, and in the right way; you will then
17452 have no difficulty in apprehending the preceding remarks, and they will
17453 no longer appear strange to you.
17454 
17455 And how am I to do so? he asked.
17456 
17457 Why, I said, we know that all germs or seeds, whether vegetable or
17458 animal, when they fail to meet with proper nutriment or climate or soil,
17459 in proportion to their vigour, are all the more sensitive to the want of
17460 a suitable environment, for evil is a greater enemy to what is good than
17461 to what is not.
17462 
17463 Very true.
17464 
17465 There is reason in supposing that the finest natures, when under alien
17466 conditions, receive more injury than the inferior, because the contrast
17467 is greater.
17468 
17469 Certainly.
17470 
17471 And may we not say, Adeimantus, that the most gifted minds, when they
17472 are ill-educated, become pre-eminently bad? Do not great crimes and
17473 the spirit of pure evil spring out of a fulness of nature ruined by
17474 education rather than from any inferiority, whereas weak natures are
17475 scarcely capable of any very great good or very great evil?
17476 
17477 There I think that you are right.
17478 
17479 And our philosopher follows the same analogy--he is like a plant which,
17480 having proper nurture, must necessarily grow and mature into all virtue,
17481 but, if sown and planted in an alien soil, becomes the most noxious of
17482 all weeds, unless he be preserved by some divine power. Do you really
17483 think, as people so often say, that our youth are corrupted by Sophists,
17484 or that private teachers of the art corrupt them in any degree worth
17485 speaking of? Are not the public who say these things the greatest of all
17486 Sophists? And do they not educate to perfection young and old, men and
17487 women alike, and fashion them after their own hearts?
17488 
17489 When is this accomplished? he said.
17490 
17491 When they meet together, and the world sits down at an assembly, or in
17492 a court of law, or a theatre, or a camp, or in any other popular resort,
17493 and there is a great uproar, and they praise some things which are
17494 being said or done, and blame other things, equally exaggerating both,
17495 shouting and clapping their hands, and the echo of the rocks and the
17496 place in which they are assembled redoubles the sound of the praise or
17497 blame--at such a time will not a young man's heart, as they say, leap
17498 within him? Will any private training enable him to stand firm against
17499 the overwhelming flood of popular opinion? or will he be carried away
17500 by the stream? Will he not have the notions of good and evil which the
17501 public in general have--he will do as they do, and as they are, such
17502 will he be?
17503 
17504 Yes, Socrates; necessity will compel him.
17505 
17506 And yet, I said, there is a still greater necessity, which has not been
17507 mentioned.
17508 
17509 What is that?
17510 
17511 The gentle force of attainder or confiscation or death, which, as you
17512 are aware, these new Sophists and educators, who are the public, apply
17513 when their words are powerless.
17514 
17515 Indeed they do; and in right good earnest.
17516 
17517 Now what opinion of any other Sophist, or of any private person, can be
17518 expected to overcome in such an unequal contest?
17519 
17520 None, he replied.
17521 
17522 No, indeed, I said, even to make the attempt is a great piece of folly;
17523 there neither is, nor has been, nor is ever likely to be, any different
17524 type of character which has had no other training in virtue but that
17525 which is supplied by public opinion--I speak, my friend, of human virtue
17526 only; what is more than human, as the proverb says, is not included:
17527 for I would not have you ignorant that, in the present evil state of
17528 governments, whatever is saved and comes to good is saved by the power
17529 of God, as we may truly say.
17530 
17531 I quite assent, he replied.
17532 
17533 Then let me crave your assent also to a further observation.
17534 
17535 What are you going to say?
17536 
17537 Why, that all those mercenary individuals, whom the many call Sophists
17538 and whom they deem to be their adversaries, do, in fact, teach nothing
17539 but the opinion of the many, that is to say, the opinions of their
17540 assemblies; and this is their wisdom. I might compare them to a man who
17541 should study the tempers and desires of a mighty strong beast who is
17542 fed by him--he would learn how to approach and handle him, also at what
17543 times and from what causes he is dangerous or the reverse, and what
17544 is the meaning of his several cries, and by what sounds, when another
17545 utters them, he is soothed or infuriated; and you may suppose further,
17546 that when, by continually attending upon him, he has become perfect in
17547 all this, he calls his knowledge wisdom, and makes of it a system or
17548 art, which he proceeds to teach, although he has no real notion of what
17549 he means by the principles or passions of which he is speaking, but
17550 calls this honourable and that dishonourable, or good or evil, or just
17551 or unjust, all in accordance with the tastes and tempers of the great
17552 brute. Good he pronounces to be that in which the beast delights and
17553 evil to be that which he dislikes; and he can give no other account
17554 of them except that the just and noble are the necessary, having never
17555 himself seen, and having no power of explaining to others the nature
17556 of either, or the difference between them, which is immense. By heaven,
17557 would not such an one be a rare educator?
17558 
17559 Indeed he would.
17560 
17561 And in what way does he who thinks that wisdom is the discernment of
17562 the tempers and tastes of the motley multitude, whether in painting
17563 or music, or, finally, in politics, differ from him whom I have been
17564 describing? For when a man consorts with the many, and exhibits to
17565 them his poem or other work of art or the service which he has done
17566 the State, making them his judges when he is not obliged, the so-called
17567 necessity of Diomede will oblige him to produce whatever they
17568 praise. And yet the reasons are utterly ludicrous which they give in
17569 confirmation of their own notions about the honourable and good. Did you
17570 ever hear any of them which were not?
17571 
17572 No, nor am I likely to hear.
17573 
17574 You recognise the truth of what I have been saying? Then let me ask you
17575 to consider further whether the world will ever be induced to believe in
17576 the existence of absolute beauty rather than of the many beautiful, or
17577 of the absolute in each kind rather than of the many in each kind?
17578 
17579 Certainly not.
17580 
17581 Then the world cannot possibly be a philosopher?
17582 
17583 Impossible.
17584 
17585 And therefore philosophers must inevitably fall under the censure of the
17586 world?
17587 
17588 They must.
17589 
17590 And of individuals who consort with the mob and seek to please them?
17591 
17592 That is evident.
17593 
17594 Then, do you see any way in which the philosopher can be preserved in
17595 his calling to the end? and remember what we were saying of him, that
17596 he was to have quickness and memory and courage and magnificence--these
17597 were admitted by us to be the true philosopher's gifts.
17598 
17599 Yes.
17600 
17601 Will not such an one from his early childhood be in all things first
17602 among all, especially if his bodily endowments are like his mental ones?
17603 
17604 Certainly, he said.
17605 
17606 And his friends and fellow-citizens will want to use him as he gets
17607 older for their own purposes?
17608 
17609 No question.
17610 
17611 Falling at his feet, they will make requests to him and do him honour
17612 and flatter him, because they want to get into their hands now, the
17613 power which he will one day possess.
17614 
17615 That often happens, he said.
17616 
17617 And what will a man such as he is be likely to do under such
17618 circumstances, especially if he be a citizen of a great city, rich
17619 and noble, and a tall proper youth? Will he not be full of boundless
17620 aspirations, and fancy himself able to manage the affairs of Hellenes
17621 and of barbarians, and having got such notions into his head will he
17622 not dilate and elevate himself in the fulness of vain pomp and senseless
17623 pride?
17624 
17625 To be sure he will.
17626 
17627 Now, when he is in this state of mind, if some one gently comes to him
17628 and tells him that he is a fool and must get understanding, which can
17629 only be got by slaving for it, do you think that, under such adverse
17630 circumstances, he will be easily induced to listen?
17631 
17632 Far otherwise.
17633 
17634 And even if there be some one who through inherent goodness or natural
17635 reasonableness has had his eyes opened a little and is humbled and taken
17636 captive by philosophy, how will his friends behave when they think that
17637 they are likely to lose the advantage which they were hoping to reap
17638 from his companionship? Will they not do and say anything to prevent him
17639 from yielding to his better nature and to render his teacher powerless,
17640 using to this end private intrigues as well as public prosecutions?
17641 
17642 There can be no doubt of it.
17643 
17644 And how can one who is thus circumstanced ever become a philosopher?
17645 
17646 Impossible.
17647 
17648 Then were we not right in saying that even the very qualities which
17649 make a man a philosopher may, if he be ill-educated, divert him from
17650 philosophy, no less than riches and their accompaniments and the other
17651 so-called goods of life?
17652 
17653 We were quite right.
17654 
17655 Thus, my excellent friend, is brought about all that ruin and failure
17656 which I have been describing of the natures best adapted to the best of
17657 all pursuits; they are natures which we maintain to be rare at any time;
17658 this being the class out of which come the men who are the authors of
17659 the greatest evil to States and individuals; and also of the greatest
17660 good when the tide carries them in that direction; but a small man never
17661 was the doer of any great thing either to individuals or to States.
17662 
17663 That is most true, he said.
17664 
17665 And so philosophy is left desolate, with her marriage rite incomplete:
17666 for her own have fallen away and forsaken her, and while they are
17667 leading a false and unbecoming life, other unworthy persons, seeing that
17668 she has no kinsmen to be her protectors, enter in and dishonour her; and
17669 fasten upon her the reproaches which, as you say, her reprovers utter,
17670 who affirm of her votaries that some are good for nothing, and that the
17671 greater number deserve the severest punishment.
17672 
17673 That is certainly what people say.
17674 
17675 Yes; and what else would you expect, I said, when you think of the puny
17676 creatures who, seeing this land open to them--a land well stocked with
17677 fair names and showy titles--like prisoners running out of prison into a
17678 sanctuary, take a leap out of their trades into philosophy; those who
17679 do so being probably the cleverest hands at their own miserable crafts?
17680 For, although philosophy be in this evil case, still there remains a
17681 dignity about her which is not to be found in the arts. And many are
17682 thus attracted by her whose natures are imperfect and whose souls are
17683 maimed and disfigured by their meannesses, as their bodies are by their
17684 trades and crafts. Is not this unavoidable?
17685 
17686 Yes.
17687 
17688 Are they not exactly like a bald little tinker who has just got out of
17689 durance and come into a fortune; he takes a bath and puts on a new coat,
17690 and is decked out as a bridegroom going to marry his master's daughter,
17691 who is left poor and desolate?
17692 
17693 A most exact parallel.
17694 
17695 What will be the issue of such marriages? Will they not be vile and
17696 bastard?
17697 
17698 There can be no question of it.
17699 
17700 And when persons who are unworthy of education approach philosophy and
17701 make an alliance with her who is in a rank above them what sort of
17702 ideas and opinions are likely to be generated? Will they not be sophisms
17703 captivating to the ear, having nothing in them genuine, or worthy of or
17704 akin to true wisdom?
17705 
17706 No doubt, he said.
17707 
17708 Then, Adeimantus, I said, the worthy disciples of philosophy will be but
17709 a small remnant: perchance some noble and well-educated person, detained
17710 by exile in her service, who in the absence of corrupting influences
17711 remains devoted to her; or some lofty soul born in a mean city, the
17712 politics of which he contemns and neglects; and there may be a gifted
17713 few who leave the arts, which they justly despise, and come to her;--or
17714 peradventure there are some who are restrained by our friend Theages'
17715 bridle; for everything in the life of Theages conspired to divert him
17716 from philosophy; but ill-health kept him away from politics. My own case
17717 of the internal sign is hardly worth mentioning, for rarely, if ever,
17718 has such a monitor been given to any other man. Those who belong to this
17719 small class have tasted how sweet and blessed a possession philosophy
17720 is, and have also seen enough of the madness of the multitude; and they
17721 know that no politician is honest, nor is there any champion of justice
17722 at whose side they may fight and be saved. Such an one may be compared
17723 to a man who has fallen among wild beasts--he will not join in the
17724 wickedness of his fellows, but neither is he able singly to resist all
17725 their fierce natures, and therefore seeing that he would be of no use to
17726 the State or to his friends, and reflecting that he would have to throw
17727 away his life without doing any good either to himself or others, he
17728 holds his peace, and goes his own way. He is like one who, in the storm
17729 of dust and sleet which the driving wind hurries along, retires
17730 under the shelter of a wall; and seeing the rest of mankind full of
17731 wickedness, he is content, if only he can live his own life and be pure
17732 from evil or unrighteousness, and depart in peace and good-will, with
17733 bright hopes.
17734 
17735 Yes, he said, and he will have done a great work before he departs.
17736 
17737 A great work--yes; but not the greatest, unless he find a State suitable
17738 to him; for in a State which is suitable to him, he will have a larger
17739 growth and be the saviour of his country, as well as of himself.
17740 
17741 The causes why philosophy is in such an evil name have now been
17742 sufficiently explained: the injustice of the charges against her has
17743 been shown--is there anything more which you wish to say?
17744 
17745 Nothing more on that subject, he replied; but I should like to know
17746 which of the governments now existing is in your opinion the one adapted
17747 to her.
17748 
17749 Not any of them, I said; and that is precisely the accusation which I
17750 bring against them--not one of them is worthy of the philosophic nature,
17751 and hence that nature is warped and estranged;--as the exotic seed
17752 which is sown in a foreign land becomes denaturalized, and is wont to be
17753 overpowered and to lose itself in the new soil, even so this growth
17754 of philosophy, instead of persisting, degenerates and receives another
17755 character. But if philosophy ever finds in the State that perfection
17756 which she herself is, then will be seen that she is in truth divine, and
17757 that all other things, whether natures of men or institutions, are but
17758 human;--and now, I know, that you are going to ask, What that State is:
17759 
17760 No, he said; there you are wrong, for I was going to ask another
17761 question--whether it is the State of which we are the founders and
17762 inventors, or some other?
17763 
17764 Yes, I replied, ours in most respects; but you may remember my saying
17765 before, that some living authority would always be required in the
17766 State having the same idea of the constitution which guided you when as
17767 legislator you were laying down the laws.
17768 
17769 That was said, he replied.
17770 
17771 Yes, but not in a satisfactory manner; you frightened us by interposing
17772 objections, which certainly showed that the discussion would be long and
17773 difficult; and what still remains is the reverse of easy.
17774 
17775 What is there remaining?
17776 
17777 The question how the study of philosophy may be so ordered as not to be
17778 the ruin of the State: All great attempts are attended with risk; 'hard
17779 is the good,' as men say.
17780 
17781 Still, he said, let the point be cleared up, and the enquiry will then
17782 be complete.
17783 
17784 I shall not be hindered, I said, by any want of will, but, if at all,
17785 by a want of power: my zeal you may see for yourselves; and please to
17786 remark in what I am about to say how boldly and unhesitatingly I declare
17787 that States should pursue philosophy, not as they do now, but in a
17788 different spirit.
17789 
17790 In what manner?
17791 
17792 At present, I said, the students of philosophy are quite young;
