17793 beginning when they are hardly past childhood, they devote only the time
17794 saved from moneymaking and housekeeping to such pursuits; and even those
17795 of them who are reputed to have most of the philosophic spirit, when
17796 they come within sight of the great difficulty of the subject, I mean
17797 dialectic, take themselves off. In after life when invited by some one
17798 else, they may, perhaps, go and hear a lecture, and about this they make
17799 much ado, for philosophy is not considered by them to be their
17800 proper business: at last, when they grow old, in most cases they are
17801 extinguished more truly than Heracleitus' sun, inasmuch as they never
17802 light up again. (Heraclitus said that the sun was extinguished every
17803 evening and relighted every morning.)
17804 
17805 But what ought to be their course?
17806 
17807 Just the opposite. In childhood and youth their study, and what
17808 philosophy they learn, should be suited to their tender years: during
17809 this period while they are growing up towards manhood, the chief and
17810 special care should be given to their bodies that they may have them
17811 to use in the service of philosophy; as life advances and the intellect
17812 begins to mature, let them increase the gymnastics of the soul; but
17813 when the strength of our citizens fails and is past civil and military
17814 duties, then let them range at will and engage in no serious labour,
17815 as we intend them to live happily here, and to crown this life with a
17816 similar happiness in another.
17817 
17818 How truly in earnest you are, Socrates! he said; I am sure of that; and
17819 yet most of your hearers, if I am not mistaken, are likely to be still
17820 more earnest in their opposition to you, and will never be convinced;
17821 Thrasymachus least of all.
17822 
17823 Do not make a quarrel, I said, between Thrasymachus and me, who have
17824 recently become friends, although, indeed, we were never enemies; for I
17825 shall go on striving to the utmost until I either convert him and other
17826 men, or do something which may profit them against the day when they
17827 live again, and hold the like discourse in another state of existence.
17828 
17829 You are speaking of a time which is not very near.
17830 
17831 Rather, I replied, of a time which is as nothing in comparison with
17832 eternity. Nevertheless, I do not wonder that the many refuse to believe;
17833 for they have never seen that of which we are now speaking realized;
17834 they have seen only a conventional imitation of philosophy, consisting
17835 of words artificially brought together, not like these of ours having
17836 a natural unity. But a human being who in word and work is perfectly
17837 moulded, as far as he can be, into the proportion and likeness of
17838 virtue--such a man ruling in a city which bears the same image, they
17839 have never yet seen, neither one nor many of them--do you think that
17840 they ever did?
17841 
17842 No indeed.
17843 
17844 No, my friend, and they have seldom, if ever, heard free and noble
17845 sentiments; such as men utter when they are earnestly and by every means
17846 in their power seeking after truth for the sake of knowledge, while
17847 they look coldly on the subtleties of controversy, of which the end is
17848 opinion and strife, whether they meet with them in the courts of law or
17849 in society.
17850 
17851 They are strangers, he said, to the words of which you speak.
17852 
17853 And this was what we foresaw, and this was the reason why truth forced
17854 us to admit, not without fear and hesitation, that neither cities nor
17855 States nor individuals will ever attain perfection until the small
17856 class of philosophers whom we termed useless but not corrupt are
17857 providentially compelled, whether they will or not, to take care of the
17858 State, and until a like necessity be laid on the State to obey them; or
17859 until kings, or if not kings, the sons of kings or princes, are divinely
17860 inspired with a true love of true philosophy. That either or both of
17861 these alternatives are impossible, I see no reason to affirm: if
17862 they were so, we might indeed be justly ridiculed as dreamers and
17863 visionaries. Am I not right?
17864 
17865 Quite right.
17866 
17867 If then, in the countless ages of the past, or at the present hour in
17868 some foreign clime which is far away and beyond our ken, the perfected
17869 philosopher is or has been or hereafter shall be compelled by a superior
17870 power to have the charge of the State, we are ready to assert to the
17871 death, that this our constitution has been, and is--yea, and will be
17872 whenever the Muse of Philosophy is queen. There is no impossibility in
17873 all this; that there is a difficulty, we acknowledge ourselves.
17874 
17875 My opinion agrees with yours, he said.
17876 
17877 But do you mean to say that this is not the opinion of the multitude?
17878 
17879 I should imagine not, he replied.
17880 
17881 O my friend, I said, do not attack the multitude: they will change their
17882 minds, if, not in an aggressive spirit, but gently and with the view
17883 of soothing them and removing their dislike of over-education, you show
17884 them your philosophers as they really are and describe as you were just
17885 now doing their character and profession, and then mankind will see that
17886 he of whom you are speaking is not such as they supposed--if they view
17887 him in this new light, they will surely change their notion of him, and
17888 answer in another strain. Who can be at enmity with one who loves them,
17889 who that is himself gentle and free from envy will be jealous of one
17890 in whom there is no jealousy? Nay, let me answer for you, that in a few
17891 this harsh temper may be found but not in the majority of mankind.
17892 
17893 I quite agree with you, he said.
17894 
17895 And do you not also think, as I do, that the harsh feeling which the
17896 many entertain towards philosophy originates in the pretenders, who rush
17897 in uninvited, and are always abusing them, and finding fault with them,
17898 who make persons instead of things the theme of their conversation? and
17899 nothing can be more unbecoming in philosophers than this.
17900 
17901 It is most unbecoming.
17902 
17903 For he, Adeimantus, whose mind is fixed upon true being, has surely no
17904 time to look down upon the affairs of earth, or to be filled with malice
17905 and envy, contending against men; his eye is ever directed towards
17906 things fixed and immutable, which he sees neither injuring nor injured
17907 by one another, but all in order moving according to reason; these he
17908 imitates, and to these he will, as far as he can, conform himself. Can a
17909 man help imitating that with which he holds reverential converse?
17910 
17911 Impossible.
17912 
17913 And the philosopher holding converse with the divine order, becomes
17914 orderly and divine, as far as the nature of man allows; but like every
17915 one else, he will suffer from detraction.
17916 
17917 Of course.
17918 
17919 And if a necessity be laid upon him of fashioning, not only himself,
17920 but human nature generally, whether in States or individuals, into
17921 that which he beholds elsewhere, will he, think you, be an unskilful
17922 artificer of justice, temperance, and every civil virtue?
17923 
17924 Anything but unskilful.
17925 
17926 And if the world perceives that what we are saying about him is the
17927 truth, will they be angry with philosophy? Will they disbelieve us, when
17928 we tell them that no State can be happy which is not designed by artists
17929 who imitate the heavenly pattern?
17930 
17931 They will not be angry if they understand, he said. But how will they
17932 draw out the plan of which you are speaking?
17933 
17934 They will begin by taking the State and the manners of men, from which,
17935 as from a tablet, they will rub out the picture, and leave a clean
17936 surface. This is no easy task. But whether easy or not, herein will lie
17937 the difference between them and every other legislator,--they will have
17938 nothing to do either with individual or State, and will inscribe no
17939 laws, until they have either found, or themselves made, a clean surface.
17940 
17941 They will be very right, he said.
17942 
17943 Having effected this, they will proceed to trace an outline of the
17944 constitution?
17945 
17946 No doubt.
17947 
17948 And when they are filling in the work, as I conceive, they will often
17949 turn their eyes upwards and downwards: I mean that they will first look
17950 at absolute justice and beauty and temperance, and again at the human
17951 copy; and will mingle and temper the various elements of life into the
17952 image of a man; and this they will conceive according to that other
17953 image, which, when existing among men, Homer calls the form and likeness
17954 of God.
17955 
17956 Very true, he said.
17957 
17958 And one feature they will erase, and another they will put in, until
17959 they have made the ways of men, as far as possible, agreeable to the
17960 ways of God?
17961 
17962 Indeed, he said, in no way could they make a fairer picture.
17963 
17964 And now, I said, are we beginning to persuade those whom you described
17965 as rushing at us with might and main, that the painter of constitutions
17966 is such an one as we are praising; at whom they were so very indignant
17967 because to his hands we committed the State; and are they growing a
17968 little calmer at what they have just heard?
17969 
17970 Much calmer, if there is any sense in them.
17971 
17972 Why, where can they still find any ground for objection? Will they doubt
17973 that the philosopher is a lover of truth and being?
17974 
17975 They would not be so unreasonable.
17976 
17977 Or that his nature, being such as we have delineated, is akin to the
17978 highest good?
17979 
17980 Neither can they doubt this.
17981 
17982 But again, will they tell us that such a nature, placed under favourable
17983 circumstances, will not be perfectly good and wise if any ever was? Or
17984 will they prefer those whom we have rejected?
17985 
17986 Surely not.
17987 
17988 Then will they still be angry at our saying, that, until philosophers
17989 bear rule, States and individuals will have no rest from evil, nor will
17990 this our imaginary State ever be realized?
17991 
17992 I think that they will be less angry.
17993 
17994 Shall we assume that they are not only less angry but quite gentle,
17995 and that they have been converted and for very shame, if for no other
17996 reason, cannot refuse to come to terms?
17997 
17998 By all means, he said.
17999 
18000 Then let us suppose that the reconciliation has been effected. Will any
18001 one deny the other point, that there may be sons of kings or princes who
18002 are by nature philosophers?
18003 
18004 Surely no man, he said.
18005 
18006 And when they have come into being will any one say that they must of
18007 necessity be destroyed; that they can hardly be saved is not denied even
18008 by us; but that in the whole course of ages no single one of them can
18009 escape--who will venture to affirm this?
18010 
18011 Who indeed!
18012 
18013 But, said I, one is enough; let there be one man who has a city obedient
18014 to his will, and he might bring into existence the ideal polity about
18015 which the world is so incredulous.
18016 
18017 Yes, one is enough.
18018 
18019 The ruler may impose the laws and institutions which we have been
18020 describing, and the citizens may possibly be willing to obey them?
18021 
18022 Certainly.
18023 
18024 And that others should approve, of what we approve, is no miracle or
18025 impossibility?
18026 
18027 I think not.
18028 
18029 But we have sufficiently shown, in what has preceded, that all this, if
18030 only possible, is assuredly for the best.
18031 
18032 We have.
18033 
18034 And now we say not only that our laws, if they could be enacted, would
18035 be for the best, but also that the enactment of them, though difficult,
18036 is not impossible.
18037 
18038 Very good.
18039 
18040 And so with pain and toil we have reached the end of one subject, but
18041 more remains to be discussed;--how and by what studies and pursuits will
18042 the saviours of the constitution be created, and at what ages are they
18043 to apply themselves to their several studies?
18044 
18045 Certainly.
18046 
18047 I omitted the troublesome business of the possession of women, and the
18048 procreation of children, and the appointment of the rulers, because
18049 I knew that the perfect State would be eyed with jealousy and was
18050 difficult of attainment; but that piece of cleverness was not of much
18051 service to me, for I had to discuss them all the same. The women and
18052 children are now disposed of, but the other question of the rulers must
18053 be investigated from the very beginning. We were saying, as you will
18054 remember, that they were to be lovers of their country, tried by the
18055 test of pleasures and pains, and neither in hardships, nor in dangers,
18056 nor at any other critical moment were to lose their patriotism--he was
18057 to be rejected who failed, but he who always came forth pure, like gold
18058 tried in the refiner's fire, was to be made a ruler, and to receive
18059 honours and rewards in life and after death. This was the sort of thing
18060 which was being said, and then the argument turned aside and veiled her
18061 face; not liking to stir the question which has now arisen.
18062 
18063 I perfectly remember, he said.
18064 
18065 Yes, my friend, I said, and I then shrank from hazarding the bold
18066 word; but now let me dare to say--that the perfect guardian must be a
18067 philosopher.
18068 
18069 Yes, he said, let that be affirmed.
18070 
18071 And do not suppose that there will be many of them; for the gifts which
18072 were deemed by us to be essential rarely grow together; they are mostly
18073 found in shreds and patches.
18074 
18075 What do you mean? he said.
18076 
18077 You are aware, I replied, that quick intelligence, memory, sagacity,
18078 cleverness, and similar qualities, do not often grow together, and that
18079 persons who possess them and are at the same time high-spirited and
18080 magnanimous are not so constituted by nature as to live orderly and in a
18081 peaceful and settled manner; they are driven any way by their impulses,
18082 and all solid principle goes out of them.
18083 
18084 Very true, he said.
18085 
18086 On the other hand, those steadfast natures which can better be depended
18087 upon, which in a battle are impregnable to fear and immovable, are
18088 equally immovable when there is anything to be learned; they are
18089 always in a torpid state, and are apt to yawn and go to sleep over any
18090 intellectual toil.
18091 
18092 Quite true.
18093 
18094 And yet we were saying that both qualities were necessary in those to
18095 whom the higher education is to be imparted, and who are to share in any
18096 office or command.
18097 
18098 Certainly, he said.
18099 
18100 And will they be a class which is rarely found?
18101 
18102 Yes, indeed.
18103 
18104 Then the aspirant must not only be tested in those labours and dangers
18105 and pleasures which we mentioned before, but there is another kind of
18106 probation which we did not mention--he must be exercised also in many
18107 kinds of knowledge, to see whether the soul will be able to endure the
18108 highest of all, or will faint under them, as in any other studies and
18109 exercises.
18110 
18111 Yes, he said, you are quite right in testing him. But what do you mean
18112 by the highest of all knowledge?
18113 
18114 You may remember, I said, that we divided the soul into three parts; and
18115 distinguished the several natures of justice, temperance, courage, and
18116 wisdom?
18117 
18118 Indeed, he said, if I had forgotten, I should not deserve to hear more.
18119 
18120 And do you remember the word of caution which preceded the discussion of
18121 them?
18122 
18123 To what do you refer?
18124 
18125 We were saying, if I am not mistaken, that he who wanted to see them in
18126 their perfect beauty must take a longer and more circuitous way, at
18127 the end of which they would appear; but that we could add on a popular
18128 exposition of them on a level with the discussion which had preceded.
18129 And you replied that such an exposition would be enough for you, and so
18130 the enquiry was continued in what to me seemed to be a very inaccurate
18131 manner; whether you were satisfied or not, it is for you to say.
18132 
18133 Yes, he said, I thought and the others thought that you gave us a fair
18134 measure of truth.
18135 
18136 But, my friend, I said, a measure of such things which in any degree
18137 falls short of the whole truth is not fair measure; for nothing
18138 imperfect is the measure of anything, although persons are too apt to be
18139 contented and think that they need search no further.
18140 
18141 Not an uncommon case when people are indolent.
18142 
18143 Yes, I said; and there cannot be any worse fault in a guardian of the
18144 State and of the laws.
18145 
18146 True.
18147 
18148 The guardian then, I said, must be required to take the longer circuit,
18149 and toil at learning as well as at gymnastics, or he will never reach
18150 the highest knowledge of all which, as we were just now saying, is his
18151 proper calling.
18152 
18153 What, he said, is there a knowledge still higher than this--higher than
18154 justice and the other virtues?
18155 
18156 Yes, I said, there is. And of the virtues too we must behold not the
18157 outline merely, as at present--nothing short of the most finished
18158 picture should satisfy us. When little things are elaborated with an
18159 infinity of pains, in order that they may appear in their full beauty
18160 and utmost clearness, how ridiculous that we should not think the
18161 highest truths worthy of attaining the highest accuracy!
18162 
18163 A right noble thought; but do you suppose that we shall refrain from
18164 asking you what is this highest knowledge?
18165 
18166 Nay, I said, ask if you will; but I am certain that you have heard the
18167 answer many times, and now you either do not understand me or, as I
18168 rather think, you are disposed to be troublesome; for you have often
18169 been told that the idea of good is the highest knowledge, and that all
18170 other things become useful and advantageous only by their use of this.
18171 You can hardly be ignorant that of this I was about to speak, concerning
18172 which, as you have often heard me say, we know so little; and, without
18173 which, any other knowledge or possession of any kind will profit us
18174 nothing. Do you think that the possession of all other things is of
18175 any value if we do not possess the good? or the knowledge of all other
18176 things if we have no knowledge of beauty and goodness?
18177 
18178 Assuredly not.
18179 
18180 You are further aware that most people affirm pleasure to be the good,
18181 but the finer sort of wits say it is knowledge?
18182 
18183 Yes.
18184 
18185 And you are aware too that the latter cannot explain what they mean by
18186 knowledge, but are obliged after all to say knowledge of the good?
18187 
18188 How ridiculous!
18189 
18190 Yes, I said, that they should begin by reproaching us with our ignorance
18191 of the good, and then presume our knowledge of it--for the good they
18192 define to be knowledge of the good, just as if we understood them when
18193 they use the term 'good'--this is of course ridiculous.
18194 
18195 Most true, he said.
18196 
18197 And those who make pleasure their good are in equal perplexity; for they
18198 are compelled to admit that there are bad pleasures as well as good.
18199 
18200 Certainly.
18201 
18202 And therefore to acknowledge that bad and good are the same?
18203 
18204 True.
18205 
18206 There can be no doubt about the numerous difficulties in which this
18207 question is involved.
18208 
18209 There can be none.
18210 
18211 Further, do we not see that many are willing to do or to have or to seem
18212 to be what is just and honourable without the reality; but no one is
18213 satisfied with the appearance of good--the reality is what they seek; in
18214 the case of the good, appearance is despised by every one.
18215 
18216 Very true, he said.
18217 
18218 Of this then, which every soul of man pursues and makes the end of all
18219 his actions, having a presentiment that there is such an end, and
18220 yet hesitating because neither knowing the nature nor having the same
18221 assurance of this as of other things, and therefore losing whatever
18222 good there is in other things,--of a principle such and so great as this
18223 ought the best men in our State, to whom everything is entrusted, to be
18224 in the darkness of ignorance?
18225 
18226 Certainly not, he said.
18227 
18228 I am sure, I said, that he who does not know how the beautiful and
18229 the just are likewise good will be but a sorry guardian of them; and
18230 I suspect that no one who is ignorant of the good will have a true
18231 knowledge of them.
18232 
18233 That, he said, is a shrewd suspicion of yours.
18234 
18235 And if we only have a guardian who has this knowledge our State will be
18236 perfectly ordered?
18237 
18238 Of course, he replied; but I wish that you would tell me whether you
18239 conceive this supreme principle of the good to be knowledge or pleasure,
18240 or different from either?
18241 
18242 Aye, I said, I knew all along that a fastidious gentleman like you would
18243 not be contented with the thoughts of other people about these matters.
18244 
18245 True, Socrates; but I must say that one who like you has passed a
18246 lifetime in the study of philosophy should not be always repeating the
18247 opinions of others, and never telling his own.
18248 
18249 Well, but has any one a right to say positively what he does not know?
18250 
18251 Not, he said, with the assurance of positive certainty; he has no right
18252 to do that: but he may say what he thinks, as a matter of opinion.
18253 
18254 And do you not know, I said, that all mere opinions are bad, and the
18255 best of them blind? You would not deny that those who have any true
18256 notion without intelligence are only like blind men who feel their way
18257 along the road?
18258 
18259 Very true.
18260 
18261 And do you wish to behold what is blind and crooked and base, when
18262 others will tell you of brightness and beauty?
18263 
18264 Still, I must implore you, Socrates, said Glaucon, not to turn away just
18265 as you are reaching the goal; if you will only give such an explanation
18266 of the good as you have already given of justice and temperance and the
18267 other virtues, we shall be satisfied.
18268 
18269 Yes, my friend, and I shall be at least equally satisfied, but I cannot
18270 help fearing that I shall fail, and that my indiscreet zeal will bring
18271 ridicule upon me. No, sweet sirs, let us not at present ask what is the
18272 actual nature of the good, for to reach what is now in my thoughts
18273 would be an effort too great for me. But of the child of the good who
18274 is likest him, I would fain speak, if I could be sure that you wished to
18275 hear--otherwise, not.
18276 
18277 By all means, he said, tell us about the child, and you shall remain in
18278 our debt for the account of the parent.
18279 
18280 I do indeed wish, I replied, that I could pay, and you receive, the
18281 account of the parent, and not, as now, of the offspring only; take,
18282 however, this latter by way of interest, and at the same time have a
18283 care that I do not render a false account, although I have no intention
18284 of deceiving you.
18285 
18286 Yes, we will take all the care that we can: proceed.
18287 
18288 Yes, I said, but I must first come to an understanding with you, and
18289 remind you of what I have mentioned in the course of this discussion,
18290 and at many other times.
18291 
18292 What?
18293 
18294 The old story, that there is a many beautiful and a many good, and so
18295 of other things which we describe and define; to all of them the term
18296 'many' is applied.
18297 
18298 True, he said.
18299 
18300 And there is an absolute beauty and an absolute good, and of other
18301 things to which the term 'many' is applied there is an absolute; for
18302 they may be brought under a single idea, which is called the essence of
18303 each.
18304 
18305 Very true.
18306 
18307 The many, as we say, are seen but not known, and the ideas are known but
18308 not seen.
18309 
18310 Exactly.
18311 
18312 And what is the organ with which we see the visible things?
18313 
18314 The sight, he said.
18315 
18316 And with the hearing, I said, we hear, and with the other senses
18317 perceive the other objects of sense?
18318 
18319 True.
18320 
18321 But have you remarked that sight is by far the most costly and complex
18322 piece of workmanship which the artificer of the senses ever contrived?
18323 
18324 No, I never have, he said.
18325 
18326 Then reflect; has the ear or voice need of any third or additional
18327 nature in order that the one may be able to hear and the other to be
18328 heard?
18329 
18330 Nothing of the sort.
18331 
18332 No, indeed, I replied; and the same is true of most, if not all, the
18333 other senses--you would not say that any of them requires such an
18334 addition?
18335 
18336 Certainly not.
18337 
18338 But you see that without the addition of some other nature there is no
18339 seeing or being seen?
18340 
18341 How do you mean?
18342 
18343 Sight being, as I conceive, in the eyes, and he who has eyes wanting to
18344 see; colour being also present in them, still unless there be a third
18345 nature specially adapted to the purpose, the owner of the eyes will see
18346 nothing and the colours will be invisible.
18347 
18348 Of what nature are you speaking?
18349 
18350 Of that which you term light, I replied.
18351 
18352 True, he said.
18353 
18354 Noble, then, is the bond which links together sight and visibility, and
18355 great beyond other bonds by no small difference of nature; for light is
18356 their bond, and light is no ignoble thing?
18357 
18358 Nay, he said, the reverse of ignoble.
18359 
18360 And which, I said, of the gods in heaven would you say was the lord of
18361 this element? Whose is that light which makes the eye to see perfectly
18362 and the visible to appear?
18363 
18364 You mean the sun, as you and all mankind say.
18365 
18366 May not the relation of sight to this deity be described as follows?
18367 
18368 How?
18369 
18370 Neither sight nor the eye in which sight resides is the sun?
18371 
18372 No.
18373 
18374 Yet of all the organs of sense the eye is the most like the sun?
18375 
18376 By far the most like.
18377 
18378 And the power which the eye possesses is a sort of effluence which is
18379 dispensed from the sun?
18380 
18381 Exactly.
18382 
18383 Then the sun is not sight, but the author of sight who is recognised by
18384 sight?
18385 
18386 True, he said.
18387 
18388 And this is he whom I call the child of the good, whom the good begat in
18389 his own likeness, to be in the visible world, in relation to sight
18390 and the things of sight, what the good is in the intellectual world in
18391 relation to mind and the things of mind:
18392 
18393 Will you be a little more explicit? he said.
18394 
18395 Why, you know, I said, that the eyes, when a person directs them towards
18396 objects on which the light of day is no longer shining, but the moon
18397 and stars only, see dimly, and are nearly blind; they seem to have no
18398 clearness of vision in them?
18399 
18400 Very true.
18401 
18402 But when they are directed towards objects on which the sun shines, they
18403 see clearly and there is sight in them?
18404 
18405 Certainly.
18406 
18407 And the soul is like the eye: when resting upon that on which truth and
18408 being shine, the soul perceives and understands, and is radiant with
18409 intelligence; but when turned towards the twilight of becoming and
18410 perishing, then she has opinion only, and goes blinking about, and
18411 is first of one opinion and then of another, and seems to have no
18412 intelligence?
18413 
18414 Just so.
18415 
18416 Now, that which imparts truth to the known and the power of knowing to
18417 the knower is what I would have you term the idea of good, and this
18418 you will deem to be the cause of science, and of truth in so far as
18419 the latter becomes the subject of knowledge; beautiful too, as are both
18420 truth and knowledge, you will be right in esteeming this other nature as
18421 more beautiful than either; and, as in the previous instance, light and
18422 sight may be truly said to be like the sun, and yet not to be the sun,
18423 so in this other sphere, science and truth may be deemed to be like the
18424 good, but not the good; the good has a place of honour yet higher.
18425 
18426 What a wonder of beauty that must be, he said, which is the author of
18427 science and truth, and yet surpasses them in beauty; for you surely
18428 cannot mean to say that pleasure is the good?
18429 
18430 God forbid, I replied; but may I ask you to consider the image in
18431 another point of view?
18432 
18433 In what point of view?
18434 
18435 You would say, would you not, that the sun is not only the author of
18436 visibility in all visible things, but of generation and nourishment and
18437 growth, though he himself is not generation?
18438 
18439 Certainly.
18440 
18441 In like manner the good may be said to be not only the author of
18442 knowledge to all things known, but of their being and essence, and yet
18443 the good is not essence, but far exceeds essence in dignity and power.
18444 
18445 Glaucon said, with a ludicrous earnestness: By the light of heaven, how
18446 amazing!
18447 
18448 Yes, I said, and the exaggeration may be set down to you; for you made
18449 me utter my fancies.
18450 
18451 And pray continue to utter them; at any rate let us hear if there is
18452 anything more to be said about the similitude of the sun.
18453 
18454 Yes, I said, there is a great deal more.
18455 
18456 Then omit nothing, however slight.
18457 
18458 I will do my best, I said; but I should think that a great deal will
18459 have to be omitted.
18460 
18461 I hope not, he said.
18462 
18463 You have to imagine, then, that there are two ruling powers, and that
18464 one of them is set over the intellectual world, the other over the
18465 visible. I do not say heaven, lest you should fancy that I am playing
18466 upon the name ('ourhanoz, orhatoz'). May I suppose that you have this
18467 distinction of the visible and intelligible fixed in your mind?
18468 
18469 I have.
18470 
18471 Now take a line which has been cut into two unequal parts, and divide
18472 each of them again in the same proportion, and suppose the two
18473 main divisions to answer, one to the visible and the other to the
18474 intelligible, and then compare the subdivisions in respect of their
18475 clearness and want of clearness, and you will find that the first
18476 section in the sphere of the visible consists of images. And by images I
18477 mean, in the first place, shadows, and in the second place, reflections
18478 in water and in solid, smooth and polished bodies and the like: Do you
18479 understand?
18480 
18481 Yes, I understand.
18482 
18483 Imagine, now, the other section, of which this is only the resemblance,
18484 to include the animals which we see, and everything that grows or is
18485 made.
18486 
18487 Very good.
18488 
18489 Would you not admit that both the sections of this division have
18490 different degrees of truth, and that the copy is to the original as the
18491 sphere of opinion is to the sphere of knowledge?
18492 
18493 Most undoubtedly.
18494 
18495 Next proceed to consider the manner in which the sphere of the
18496 intellectual is to be divided.
18497 
18498 In what manner?
18499 
18500 Thus:--There are two subdivisions, in the lower of which the soul uses
18501 the figures given by the former division as images; the enquiry can only
18502 be hypothetical, and instead of going upwards to a principle descends
18503 to the other end; in the higher of the two, the soul passes out of
18504 hypotheses, and goes up to a principle which is above hypotheses, making
18505 no use of images as in the former case, but proceeding only in and
18506 through the ideas themselves.
18507 
18508 I do not quite understand your meaning, he said.
18509 
18510 Then I will try again; you will understand me better when I have made
18511 some preliminary remarks. You are aware that students of geometry,
18512 arithmetic, and the kindred sciences assume the odd and the even and the
18513 figures and three kinds of angles and the like in their several branches
18514 of science; these are their hypotheses, which they and every body are
18515 supposed to know, and therefore they do not deign to give any account of
18516 them either to themselves or others; but they begin with them, and go
18517 on until they arrive at last, and in a consistent manner, at their
18518 conclusion?
18519 
18520 Yes, he said, I know.
18521 
18522 And do you not know also that although they make use of the visible
18523 forms and reason about them, they are thinking not of these, but of the
18524 ideals which they resemble; not of the figures which they draw, but
18525 of the absolute square and the absolute diameter, and so on--the forms
18526 which they draw or make, and which have shadows and reflections in water
18527 of their own, are converted by them into images, but they are really
18528 seeking to behold the things themselves, which can only be seen with the
18529 eye of the mind?
18530 
18531 That is true.
18532 
18533 And of this kind I spoke as the intelligible, although in the search
18534 after it the soul is compelled to use hypotheses; not ascending to
18535 a first principle, because she is unable to rise above the region of
18536 hypothesis, but employing the objects of which the shadows below are
18537 resemblances in their turn as images, they having in relation to the
18538 shadows and reflections of them a greater distinctness, and therefore a
18539 higher value.
18540 
18541 I understand, he said, that you are speaking of the province of geometry
18542 and the sister arts.
18543 
18544 And when I speak of the other division of the intelligible, you will
18545 understand me to speak of that other sort of knowledge which reason
18546 herself attains by the power of dialectic, using the hypotheses not as
18547 first principles, but only as hypotheses--that is to say, as steps and
18548 points of departure into a world which is above hypotheses, in order
18549 that she may soar beyond them to the first principle of the whole; and
18550 clinging to this and then to that which depends on this, by successive
18551 steps she descends again without the aid of any sensible object, from
18552 ideas, through ideas, and in ideas she ends.
18553 
18554 I understand you, he replied; not perfectly, for you seem to me to
18555 be describing a task which is really tremendous; but, at any rate, I
18556 understand you to say that knowledge and being, which the science of
18557 dialectic contemplates, are clearer than the notions of the arts, as
18558 they are termed, which proceed from hypotheses only: these are also
18559 contemplated by the understanding, and not by the senses: yet, because
18560 they start from hypotheses and do not ascend to a principle, those who
18561 contemplate them appear to you not to exercise the higher reason
18562 upon them, although when a first principle is added to them they are
18563 cognizable by the higher reason. And the habit which is concerned
18564 with geometry and the cognate sciences I suppose that you would term
18565 understanding and not reason, as being intermediate between opinion and
18566 reason.
18567 
18568 You have quite conceived my meaning, I said; and now, corresponding to
18569 these four divisions, let there be four faculties in the soul--reason
18570 answering to the highest, understanding to the second, faith (or
18571 conviction) to the third, and perception of shadows to the last--and let
18572 there be a scale of them, and let us suppose that the several faculties
18573 have clearness in the same degree that their objects have truth.
18574 
18575 I understand, he replied, and give my assent, and accept your
18576 arrangement.
18577 
18578 
18579 
18580 
18581 BOOK VII.
18582 
18583 And now, I said, let me show in a figure how far our nature is
18584 enlightened or unenlightened:--Behold! human beings living in a
18585 underground den, which has a mouth open towards the light and reaching
18586 all along the den; here they have been from their childhood, and have
18587 their legs and necks chained so that they cannot move, and can only
18588 see before them, being prevented by the chains from turning round
18589 their heads. Above and behind them a fire is blazing at a distance, and
18590 between the fire and the prisoners there is a raised way; and you will
18591 see, if you look, a low wall built along the way, like the screen which
18592 marionette players have in front of them, over which they show the
18593 puppets.
18594 
18595 I see.
18596 
18597 And do you see, I said, men passing along the wall carrying all sorts of
18598 vessels, and statues and figures of animals made of wood and stone and
18599 various materials, which appear over the wall? Some of them are talking,
18600 others silent.
18601 
18602 You have shown me a strange image, and they are strange prisoners.
18603 
18604 Like ourselves, I replied; and they see only their own shadows, or the
18605 shadows of one another, which the fire throws on the opposite wall of
18606 the cave?
18607 
18608 True, he said; how could they see anything but the shadows if they were
18609 never allowed to move their heads?
18610 
18611 And of the objects which are being carried in like manner they would
18612 only see the shadows?
18613 
18614 Yes, he said.
18615 
18616 And if they were able to converse with one another, would they not
18617 suppose that they were naming what was actually before them?
18618 
18619 Very true.
18620 
18621 And suppose further that the prison had an echo which came from the
18622 other side, would they not be sure to fancy when one of the passers-by
18623 spoke that the voice which they heard came from the passing shadow?
18624 
18625 No question, he replied.
18626 
18627 To them, I said, the truth would be literally nothing but the shadows of
18628 the images.
18629 
18630 That is certain.
18631 
18632 And now look again, and see what will naturally follow if the prisoners
18633 are released and disabused of their error. At first, when any of them is
18634 liberated and compelled suddenly to stand up and turn his neck round and
18635 walk and look towards the light, he will suffer sharp pains; the glare
18636 will distress him, and he will be unable to see the realities of which
18637 in his former state he had seen the shadows; and then conceive some one
18638 saying to him, that what he saw before was an illusion, but that now,
18639 when he is approaching nearer to being and his eye is turned towards
18640 more real existence, he has a clearer vision,--what will be his reply?
18641 And you may further imagine that his instructor is pointing to the
18642 objects as they pass and requiring him to name them,--will he not be
18643 perplexed? Will he not fancy that the shadows which he formerly saw are
18644 truer than the objects which are now shown to him?
18645 
18646 Far truer.
18647 
18648 And if he is compelled to look straight at the light, will he not have
18649 a pain in his eyes which will make him turn away to take refuge in the
18650 objects of vision which he can see, and which he will conceive to be in
18651 reality clearer than the things which are now being shown to him?
18652 
18653 True, he said.
18654 
18655 And suppose once more, that he is reluctantly dragged up a steep and
18656 rugged ascent, and held fast until he is forced into the presence of
18657 the sun himself, is he not likely to be pained and irritated? When he
18658 approaches the light his eyes will be dazzled, and he will not be able
18659 to see anything at all of what are now called realities.
18660 
18661 Not all in a moment, he said.
18662 
18663 He will require to grow accustomed to the sight of the upper world.
18664 And first he will see the shadows best, next the reflections of men and
18665 other objects in the water, and then the objects themselves; then he
18666 will gaze upon the light of the moon and the stars and the spangled
18667 heaven; and he will see the sky and the stars by night better than the
18668 sun or the light of the sun by day?
18669 
18670 Certainly.
18671 
18672 Last of all he will be able to see the sun, and not mere reflections of
18673 him in the water, but he will see him in his own proper place, and not
18674 in another; and he will contemplate him as he is.
18675 
18676 Certainly.
18677 
18678 He will then proceed to argue that this is he who gives the season and
18679 the years, and is the guardian of all that is in the visible world, and
18680 in a certain way the cause of all things which he and his fellows have
18681 been accustomed to behold?
18682 
18683 Clearly, he said, he would first see the sun and then reason about him.
18684 
18685 And when he remembered his old habitation, and the wisdom of the den
18686 and his fellow-prisoners, do you not suppose that he would felicitate
18687 himself on the change, and pity them?
18688 
18689 Certainly, he would.
18690 
18691 And if they were in the habit of conferring honours among themselves
18692 on those who were quickest to observe the passing shadows and to remark
18693 which of them went before, and which followed after, and which were
18694 together; and who were therefore best able to draw conclusions as to the
18695 future, do you think that he would care for such honours and glories, or
18696 envy the possessors of them? Would he not say with Homer,
18697 
18698 'Better to be the poor servant of a poor master,'
18699 
18700 and to endure anything, rather than think as they do and live after
18701 their manner?
18702 
18703 Yes, he said, I think that he would rather suffer anything than
18704 entertain these false notions and live in this miserable manner.
18705 
18706 Imagine once more, I said, such an one coming suddenly out of the sun
18707 to be replaced in his old situation; would he not be certain to have his
18708 eyes full of darkness?
18709 
18710 To be sure, he said.
18711 
18712 And if there were a contest, and he had to compete in measuring the
18713 shadows with the prisoners who had never moved out of the den, while
18714 his sight was still weak, and before his eyes had become steady (and the
18715 time which would be needed to acquire this new habit of sight might be
18716 very considerable), would he not be ridiculous? Men would say of him
18717 that up he went and down he came without his eyes; and that it was
18718 better not even to think of ascending; and if any one tried to loose
18719 another and lead him up to the light, let them only catch the offender,
18720 and they would put him to death.
18721 
18722 No question, he said.
18723 
18724 This entire allegory, I said, you may now append, dear Glaucon, to the
18725 previous argument; the prison-house is the world of sight, the light of
18726 the fire is the sun, and you will not misapprehend me if you interpret
18727 the journey upwards to be the ascent of the soul into the intellectual
18728 world according to my poor belief, which, at your desire, I have
18729 expressed--whether rightly or wrongly God knows. But, whether true or
18730 false, my opinion is that in the world of knowledge the idea of good
18731 appears last of all, and is seen only with an effort; and, when seen,
18732 is also inferred to be the universal author of all things beautiful and
18733 right, parent of light and of the lord of light in this visible world,
18734 and the immediate source of reason and truth in the intellectual; and
18735 that this is the power upon which he who would act rationally either in
18736 public or private life must have his eye fixed.
18737 
18738 I agree, he said, as far as I am able to understand you.
18739 
18740 Moreover, I said, you must not wonder that those who attain to this
18741 beatific vision are unwilling to descend to human affairs; for their
18742 souls are ever hastening into the upper world where they desire to
18743 dwell; which desire of theirs is very natural, if our allegory may be
18744 trusted.
18745 
18746 Yes, very natural.
18747 
18748 And is there anything surprising in one who passes from divine
18749 contemplations to the evil state of man, misbehaving himself in a
18750 ridiculous manner; if, while his eyes are blinking and before he has
18751 become accustomed to the surrounding darkness, he is compelled to fight
18752 in courts of law, or in other places, about the images or the shadows of
18753 images of justice, and is endeavouring to meet the conceptions of those
18754 who have never yet seen absolute justice?
18755 
18756 Anything but surprising, he replied.
18757 
18758 Any one who has common sense will remember that the bewilderments of the
18759 eyes are of two kinds, and arise from two causes, either from coming out
18760 of the light or from going into the light, which is true of the mind's
18761 eye, quite as much as of the bodily eye; and he who remembers this when
18762 he sees any one whose vision is perplexed and weak, will not be too
18763 ready to laugh; he will first ask whether that soul of man has come out
18764 of the brighter life, and is unable to see because unaccustomed to the
18765 dark, or having turned from darkness to the day is dazzled by excess
18766 of light. And he will count the one happy in his condition and state of
18767 being, and he will pity the other; or, if he have a mind to laugh at the
18768 soul which comes from below into the light, there will be more reason
18769 in this than in the laugh which greets him who returns from above out of
18770 the light into the den.
18771 
18772 That, he said, is a very just distinction.
18773 
18774 But then, if I am right, certain professors of education must be wrong
18775 when they say that they can put a knowledge into the soul which was not
18776 there before, like sight into blind eyes.
18777 
18778 They undoubtedly say this, he replied.
18779 
18780 Whereas, our argument shows that the power and capacity of learning
18781 exists in the soul already; and that just as the eye was unable to turn
18782 from darkness to light without the whole body, so too the instrument of
18783 knowledge can only by the movement of the whole soul be turned from the
18784 world of becoming into that of being, and learn by degrees to endure
18785 the sight of being, and of the brightest and best of being, or in other
18786 words, of the good.
18787 
18788 Very true.
18789 
18790 And must there not be some art which will effect conversion in the
18791 easiest and quickest manner; not implanting the faculty of sight, for
18792 that exists already, but has been turned in the wrong direction, and is
18793 looking away from the truth?
18794 
18795 Yes, he said, such an art may be presumed.
18796 
18797 And whereas the other so-called virtues of the soul seem to be akin to
18798 bodily qualities, for even when they are not originally innate they can
18799 be implanted later by habit and exercise, the virtue of wisdom more than
18800 anything else contains a divine element which always remains, and by
18801 this conversion is rendered useful and profitable; or, on the other
18802 hand, hurtful and useless. Did you never observe the narrow intelligence
18803 flashing from the keen eye of a clever rogue--how eager he is, how
18804 clearly his paltry soul sees the way to his end; he is the reverse of
18805 blind, but his keen eye-sight is forced into the service of evil, and he
18806 is mischievous in proportion to his cleverness?
18807 
18808 Very true, he said.
18809 
18810 But what if there had been a circumcision of such natures in the days
18811 of their youth; and they had been severed from those sensual pleasures,
18812 such as eating and drinking, which, like leaden weights, were attached
18813 to them at their birth, and which drag them down and turn the vision
18814 of their souls upon the things that are below--if, I say, they had been
18815 released from these impediments and turned in the opposite direction,
18816 the very same faculty in them would have seen the truth as keenly as
18817 they see what their eyes are turned to now.
18818 
18819 Very likely.
18820 
18821 Yes, I said; and there is another thing which is likely, or rather a
18822 necessary inference from what has preceded, that neither the uneducated
18823 and uninformed of the truth, nor yet those who never make an end of
18824 their education, will be able ministers of State; not the former,
18825 because they have no single aim of duty which is the rule of all their
18826 actions, private as well as public; nor the latter, because they will
18827 not act at all except upon compulsion, fancying that they are already
18828 dwelling apart in the islands of the blest.
18829 
18830 Very true, he replied.
18831 
18832 Then, I said, the business of us who are the founders of the State
18833 will be to compel the best minds to attain that knowledge which we have
18834 already shown to be the greatest of all--they must continue to ascend
18835 until they arrive at the good; but when they have ascended and seen
18836 enough we must not allow them to do as they do now.
18837 
18838 What do you mean?
18839 
18840 I mean that they remain in the upper world: but this must not be
18841 allowed; they must be made to descend again among the prisoners in the
18842 den, and partake of their labours and honours, whether they are worth
18843 having or not.
18844 
18845 But is not this unjust? he said; ought we to give them a worse life,
18846 when they might have a better?
18847 
18848 You have again forgotten, my friend, I said, the intention of the
18849 legislator, who did not aim at making any one class in the State happy
18850 above the rest; the happiness was to be in the whole State, and he
18851 held the citizens together by persuasion and necessity, making them
18852 benefactors of the State, and therefore benefactors of one another;
18853 to this end he created them, not to please themselves, but to be his
18854 instruments in binding up the State.
18855 
18856 True, he said, I had forgotten.
18857 
18858 Observe, Glaucon, that there will be no injustice in compelling our
18859 philosophers to have a care and providence of others; we shall explain
18860 to them that in other States, men of their class are not obliged to
18861 share in the toils of politics: and this is reasonable, for they grow up
18862 at their own sweet will, and the government would rather not have them.
18863 Being self-taught, they cannot be expected to show any gratitude for a
18864 culture which they have never received. But we have brought you into
18865 the world to be rulers of the hive, kings of yourselves and of the other
18866 citizens, and have educated you far better and more perfectly than they
18867 have been educated, and you are better able to share in the double duty.
18868 Wherefore each of you, when his turn comes, must go down to the general
18869 underground abode, and get the habit of seeing in the dark. When you
18870 have acquired the habit, you will see ten thousand times better than the
18871 inhabitants of the den, and you will know what the several images are,
18872 and what they represent, because you have seen the beautiful and just
18873 and good in their truth. And thus our State, which is also yours, will
18874 be a reality, and not a dream only, and will be administered in a spirit
18875 unlike that of other States, in which men fight with one another about
18876 shadows only and are distracted in the struggle for power, which in
18877 their eyes is a great good. Whereas the truth is that the State in which
18878 the rulers are most reluctant to govern is always the best and most
18879 quietly governed, and the State in which they are most eager, the worst.
18880 
18881 Quite true, he replied.
18882 
18883 And will our pupils, when they hear this, refuse to take their turn at
18884 the toils of State, when they are allowed to spend the greater part of
18885 their time with one another in the heavenly light?
18886 
18887 Impossible, he answered; for they are just men, and the commands which
18888 we impose upon them are just; there can be no doubt that every one of
18889 them will take office as a stern necessity, and not after the fashion of
18890 our present rulers of State.
18891 
18892 Yes, my friend, I said; and there lies the point. You must contrive for
18893 your future rulers another and a better life than that of a ruler, and
18894 then you may have a well-ordered State; for only in the State which
18895 offers this, will they rule who are truly rich, not in silver and gold,
18896 but in virtue and wisdom, which are the true blessings of life. Whereas
18897 if they go to the administration of public affairs, poor and hungering
18898 after their own private advantage, thinking that hence they are to
18899 snatch the chief good, order there can never be; for they will be
18900 fighting about office, and the civil and domestic broils which thus
18901 arise will be the ruin of the rulers themselves and of the whole State.
18902 
18903 Most true, he replied.
18904 
18905 And the only life which looks down upon the life of political ambition
18906 is that of true philosophy. Do you know of any other?
18907 
18908 Indeed, I do not, he said.
18909 
18910 And those who govern ought not to be lovers of the task? For, if they
18911 are, there will be rival lovers, and they will fight.
18912 
18913 No question.
18914 
18915 Who then are those whom we shall compel to be guardians? Surely they
18916 will be the men who are wisest about affairs of State, and by whom the
18917 State is best administered, and who at the same time have other honours
18918 and another and a better life than that of politics?
18919 
18920 They are the men, and I will choose them, he replied.
18921 
18922 And now shall we consider in what way such guardians will be produced,
18923 and how they are to be brought from darkness to light,--as some are said
18924 to have ascended from the world below to the gods?
18925 
18926 By all means, he replied.
18927 
18928 The process, I said, is not the turning over of an oyster-shell (In
18929 allusion to a game in which two parties fled or pursued according as an
18930 oyster-shell which was thrown into the air fell with the dark or light
18931 side uppermost.), but the turning round of a soul passing from a day
18932 which is little better than night to the true day of being, that is, the
18933 ascent from below, which we affirm to be true philosophy?
18934 
18935 Quite so.
18936 
18937 And should we not enquire what sort of knowledge has the power of
18938 effecting such a change?
18939 
18940 Certainly.
18941 
18942 What sort of knowledge is there which would draw the soul from becoming
18943 to being? And another consideration has just occurred to me: You will
18944 remember that our young men are to be warrior athletes?
18945 
18946 Yes, that was said.
18947 
18948 Then this new kind of knowledge must have an additional quality?
18949 
18950 What quality?
18951 
18952 Usefulness in war.
18953 
18954 Yes, if possible.
18955 
18956 There were two parts in our former scheme of education, were there not?
18957 
18958 Just so.
18959 
18960 There was gymnastic which presided over the growth and decay of the
18961 body, and may therefore be regarded as having to do with generation and
18962 corruption?
18963 
18964 True.
18965 
18966 Then that is not the knowledge which we are seeking to discover?
18967 
18968 No.
18969 
18970 But what do you say of music, which also entered to a certain extent
18971 into our former scheme?
18972 
18973 Music, he said, as you will remember, was the counterpart of gymnastic,
18974 and trained the guardians by the influences of habit, by harmony making
18975 them harmonious, by rhythm rhythmical, but not giving them science; and
18976 the words, whether fabulous or possibly true, had kindred elements of
18977 rhythm and harmony in them. But in music there was nothing which tended
18978 to that good which you are now seeking.
18979 
18980 You are most accurate, I said, in your recollection; in music there
18981 certainly was nothing of the kind. But what branch of knowledge is
18982 there, my dear Glaucon, which is of the desired nature; since all the
18983 useful arts were reckoned mean by us?
18984 
18985 Undoubtedly; and yet if music and gymnastic are excluded, and the arts
18986 are also excluded, what remains?
18987 
18988 Well, I said, there may be nothing left of our special subjects; and
18989 then we shall have to take something which is not special, but of
18990 universal application.
18991 
18992 What may that be?
18993 
18994 A something which all arts and sciences and intelligences use in common,
18995 and which every one first has to learn among the elements of education.
18996 
18997 What is that?
18998 
18999 The little matter of distinguishing one, two, and three--in a word,
19000 number and calculation:--do not all arts and sciences necessarily
19001 partake of them?
19002 
19003 Yes.
19004 
19005 Then the art of war partakes of them?
19006 
19007 To be sure.
19008 
19009 Then Palamedes, whenever he appears in tragedy, proves Agamemnon
19010 ridiculously unfit to be a general. Did you never remark how he declares
19011 that he had invented number, and had numbered the ships and set in array
19012 the ranks of the army at Troy; which implies that they had never been
19013 numbered before, and Agamemnon must be supposed literally to have been
19014 incapable of counting his own feet--how could he if he was ignorant of
19015 number? And if that is true, what sort of general must he have been?
19016 
19017 I should say a very strange one, if this was as you say.
19018 
19019 Can we deny that a warrior should have a knowledge of arithmetic?
19020 
19021 Certainly he should, if he is to have the smallest understanding of
19022 military tactics, or indeed, I should rather say, if he is to be a man
19023 at all.
19024 
19025 I should like to know whether you have the same notion which I have of
19026 this study?
19027 
19028 What is your notion?
19029 
19030 It appears to me to be a study of the kind which we are seeking, and
19031 which leads naturally to reflection, but never to have been rightly
19032 used; for the true use of it is simply to draw the soul towards being.
19033 
19034 Will you explain your meaning? he said.
19035 
19036 I will try, I said; and I wish you would share the enquiry with me,
19037 and say 'yes' or 'no' when I attempt to distinguish in my own mind what
19038 branches of knowledge have this attracting power, in order that we may
19039 have clearer proof that arithmetic is, as I suspect, one of them.
19040 
19041 Explain, he said.
19042 
19043 I mean to say that objects of sense are of two kinds; some of them do
19044 not invite thought because the sense is an adequate judge of them; while
19045 in the case of other objects sense is so untrustworthy that further
19046 enquiry is imperatively demanded.
19047 
19048 You are clearly referring, he said, to the manner in which the senses
19049 are imposed upon by distance, and by painting in light and shade.
19050 
19051 No, I said, that is not at all my meaning.
19052 
19053 Then what is your meaning?
19054 
19055 When speaking of uninviting objects, I mean those which do not pass from
19056 one sensation to the opposite; inviting objects are those which do; in
19057 this latter case the sense coming upon the object, whether at a distance
19058 or near, gives no more vivid idea of anything in particular than of its
19059 opposite. An illustration will make my meaning clearer:--here are three
19060 fingers--a little finger, a second finger, and a middle finger.
19061 
19062 Very good.
19063 
19064 You may suppose that they are seen quite close: And here comes the
19065 point.
19066 
19067 What is it?
19068 
19069 Each of them equally appears a finger, whether seen in the middle or
19070 at the extremity, whether white or black, or thick or thin--it makes no
19071 difference; a finger is a finger all the same. In these cases a man is
19072 not compelled to ask of thought the question what is a finger? for the
19073 sight never intimates to the mind that a finger is other than a finger.
19074 
19075 True.
19076 
19077 And therefore, I said, as we might expect, there is nothing here which
19078 invites or excites intelligence.
19079 
19080 There is not, he said.
19081 
19082 But is this equally true of the greatness and smallness of the fingers?
19083 Can sight adequately perceive them? and is no difference made by the
19084 circumstance that one of the fingers is in the middle and another at
19085 the extremity? And in like manner does the touch adequately perceive the
19086 qualities of thickness or thinness, of softness or hardness? And so of
19087 the other senses; do they give perfect intimations of such matters? Is
19088 not their mode of operation on this wise--the sense which is concerned
19089 with the quality of hardness is necessarily concerned also with the
19090 quality of softness, and only intimates to the soul that the same thing
19091 is felt to be both hard and soft?
19092 
19093 You are quite right, he said.
19094 
19095 And must not the soul be perplexed at this intimation which the sense
19096 gives of a hard which is also soft? What, again, is the meaning of
19097 light and heavy, if that which is light is also heavy, and that which is
19098 heavy, light?
19099 
19100 Yes, he said, these intimations which the soul receives are very curious
19101 and require to be explained.
19102 
19103 Yes, I said, and in these perplexities the soul naturally summons to her
19104 aid calculation and intelligence, that she may see whether the several
19105 objects announced to her are one or two.
19106 
19107 True.
19108 
19109 And if they turn out to be two, is not each of them one and different?
19110 
19111 Certainly.
19112 
19113 And if each is one, and both are two, she will conceive the two as in
19114 a state of division, for if there were undivided they could only be
19115 conceived of as one?
19116 
19117 True.
19118 
19119 The eye certainly did see both small and great, but only in a confused
19120 manner; they were not distinguished.
19121 
19122 Yes.
19123 
19124 Whereas the thinking mind, intending to light up the chaos, was
19125 compelled to reverse the process, and look at small and great as
19126 separate and not confused.
19127 
19128 Very true.
19129 
19130 Was not this the beginning of the enquiry 'What is great?' and 'What is
19131 small?'
19132 
19133 Exactly so.
19134 
19135 And thus arose the distinction of the visible and the intelligible.
19136 
19137 Most true.
19138 
19139 This was what I meant when I spoke of impressions which invited the
19140 intellect, or the reverse--those which are simultaneous with opposite
19141 impressions, invite thought; those which are not simultaneous do not.
19142 
19143 I understand, he said, and agree with you.
19144 
19145 And to which class do unity and number belong?
19146 
19147 I do not know, he replied.
19148 
19149 Think a little and you will see that what has preceded will supply the
19150 answer; for if simple unity could be adequately perceived by the sight
19151 or by any other sense, then, as we were saying in the case of the
19152 finger, there would be nothing to attract towards being; but when there
19153 is some contradiction always present, and one is the reverse of one and
19154 involves the conception of plurality, then thought begins to be aroused
19155 within us, and the soul perplexed and wanting to arrive at a decision
19156 asks 'What is absolute unity?' This is the way in which the study of the
19157 one has a power of drawing and converting the mind to the contemplation
19158 of true being.
19159 
19160 And surely, he said, this occurs notably in the case of one; for we see
19161 the same thing to be both one and infinite in multitude?
19162 
19163 Yes, I said; and this being true of one must be equally true of all
19164 number?
19165 
19166 Certainly.
19167 
19168 And all arithmetic and calculation have to do with number?
19169 
19170 Yes.
19171 
19172 And they appear to lead the mind towards truth?
19173 
19174 Yes, in a very remarkable manner.
19175 
19176 Then this is knowledge of the kind for which we are seeking, having a
19177 double use, military and philosophical; for the man of war must learn
19178 the art of number or he will not know how to array his troops, and the
19179 philosopher also, because he has to rise out of the sea of change and
19180 lay hold of true being, and therefore he must be an arithmetician.
19181 
19182 That is true.
19183 
19184 And our guardian is both warrior and philosopher?
19185 
19186 Certainly.
19187 
19188 Then this is a kind of knowledge which legislation may fitly prescribe;
19189 and we must endeavour to persuade those who are to be the principal men
19190 of our State to go and learn arithmetic, not as amateurs, but they must
19191 carry on the study until they see the nature of numbers with the mind
19192 only; nor again, like merchants or retail-traders, with a view to buying
19193 or selling, but for the sake of their military use, and of the soul
19194 herself; and because this will be the easiest way for her to pass from
19195 becoming to truth and being.
19196 
19197 That is excellent, he said.
19198 
19199 Yes, I said, and now having spoken of it, I must add how charming the
19200 science is! and in how many ways it conduces to our desired end, if
19201 pursued in the spirit of a philosopher, and not of a shopkeeper!
19202 
19203 How do you mean?
19204 
19205 I mean, as I was saying, that arithmetic has a very great and elevating
19206 effect, compelling the soul to reason about abstract number, and
19207 rebelling against the introduction of visible or tangible objects into
19208 the argument. You know how steadily the masters of the art repel and
19209 ridicule any one who attempts to divide absolute unity when he is
19210 calculating, and if you divide, they multiply (Meaning either (1)
19211 that they integrate the number because they deny the possibility of
19212 fractions; or (2) that division is regarded by them as a process of
19213 multiplication, for the fractions of one continue to be units.), taking
19214 care that one shall continue one and not become lost in fractions.
19215 
19216 That is very true.
19217 
19218 Now, suppose a person were to say to them: O my friends, what are these
19219 wonderful numbers about which you are reasoning, in which, as you say,
19220 there is a unity such as you demand, and each unit is equal, invariable,
19221 indivisible,--what would they answer?
19222 
19223 They would answer, as I should conceive, that they were speaking of
19224 those numbers which can only be realized in thought.
19225 
19226 Then you see that this knowledge may be truly called necessary,
19227 necessitating as it clearly does the use of the pure intelligence in the
19228 attainment of pure truth?
19229 
19230 Yes; that is a marked characteristic of it.
19231 
19232 And have you further observed, that those who have a natural talent for
19233 calculation are generally quick at every other kind of knowledge; and
19234 even the dull, if they have had an arithmetical training, although they
19235 may derive no other advantage from it, always become much quicker than
19236 they would otherwise have been.
19237 
19238 Very true, he said.
19239 
19240 And indeed, you will not easily find a more difficult study, and not
19241 many as difficult.
19242 
19243 You will not.
19244 
19245 And, for all these reasons, arithmetic is a kind of knowledge in which
19246 the best natures should be trained, and which must not be given up.
19247 
19248 I agree.
19249 
19250 Let this then be made one of our subjects of education. And next, shall
19251 we enquire whether the kindred science also concerns us?
19252 
19253 You mean geometry?
19254 
19255 Exactly so.
19256 
19257 Clearly, he said, we are concerned with that part of geometry which
19258 relates to war; for in pitching a camp, or taking up a position,
19259 or closing or extending the lines of an army, or any other military
19260 manoeuvre, whether in actual battle or on a march, it will make all the
19261 difference whether a general is or is not a geometrician.
19262 
19263 Yes, I said, but for that purpose a very little of either geometry or
19264 calculation will be enough; the question relates rather to the greater
19265 and more advanced part of geometry--whether that tends in any degree
19266 to make more easy the vision of the idea of good; and thither, as I was
19267 saying, all things tend which compel the soul to turn her gaze towards
19268 that place, where is the full perfection of being, which she ought, by
19269 all means, to behold.
19270 
19271 True, he said.
19272 
19273 Then if geometry compels us to view being, it concerns us; if becoming
19274 only, it does not concern us?
19275 
19276 Yes, that is what we assert.
19277 
19278 Yet anybody who has the least acquaintance with geometry will not deny
19279 that such a conception of the science is in flat contradiction to the
19280 ordinary language of geometricians.
19281 
19282 How so?
19283 
19284 They have in view practice only, and are always speaking, in a narrow
19285 and ridiculous manner, of squaring and extending and applying and the
19286 like--they confuse the necessities of geometry with those of daily life;
19287 whereas knowledge is the real object of the whole science.
19288 
19289 Certainly, he said.
19290 
19291 Then must not a further admission be made?
19292 
19293 What admission?
19294 
19295 That the knowledge at which geometry aims is knowledge of the eternal,
19296 and not of aught perishing and transient.
19297 
19298 That, he replied, may be readily allowed, and is true.
19299 
19300 Then, my noble friend, geometry will draw the soul towards truth,
19301 and create the spirit of philosophy, and raise up that which is now
19302 unhappily allowed to fall down.
19303 
19304 Nothing will be more likely to have such an effect.
19305 
19306 Then nothing should be more sternly laid down than that the inhabitants
19307 of your fair city should by all means learn geometry. Moreover the
19308 science has indirect effects, which are not small.
19309 
19310 Of what kind? he said.
19311 
19312 There are the military advantages of which you spoke, I said; and in all
19313 departments of knowledge, as experience proves, any one who has studied
19314 geometry is infinitely quicker of apprehension than one who has not.
19315 
19316 Yes indeed, he said, there is an infinite difference between them.
19317 
19318 Then shall we propose this as a second branch of knowledge which our
19319 youth will study?
19320 
19321 Let us do so, he replied.
19322 
19323 And suppose we make astronomy the third--what do you say?
19324 
19325 I am strongly inclined to it, he said; the observation of the seasons
19326 and of months and years is as essential to the general as it is to the
19327 farmer or sailor.
19328 
19329 I am amused, I said, at your fear of the world, which makes you guard
19330 against the appearance of insisting upon useless studies; and I quite
19331 admit the difficulty of believing that in every man there is an eye
19332 of the soul which, when by other pursuits lost and dimmed, is by these
19333 purified and re-illumined; and is more precious far than ten thousand
19334 bodily eyes, for by it alone is truth seen. Now there are two classes of
19335 persons: one class of those who will agree with you and will take
19336 your words as a revelation; another class to whom they will be utterly
19337 unmeaning, and who will naturally deem them to be idle tales, for they
19338 see no sort of profit which is to be obtained from them. And therefore
19339 you had better decide at once with which of the two you are proposing to
19340 argue. You will very likely say with neither, and that your chief aim in
19341 carrying on the argument is your own improvement; at the same time you
19342 do not grudge to others any benefit which they may receive.
19343 
19344 I think that I should prefer to carry on the argument mainly on my own
19345 behalf.
19346 
19347 Then take a step backward, for we have gone wrong in the order of the
19348 sciences.
19349 
19350 What was the mistake? he said.
19351 
19352 After plane geometry, I said, we proceeded at once to solids in
19353 revolution, instead of taking solids in themselves; whereas after the
19354 second dimension the third, which is concerned with cubes and dimensions
19355 of depth, ought to have followed.
19356 
19357 That is true, Socrates; but so little seems to be known as yet about
19358 these subjects.
19359 
19360 Why, yes, I said, and for two reasons:--in the first place, no
19361 government patronises them; this leads to a want of energy in the
19362 pursuit of them, and they are difficult; in the second place, students
19363 cannot learn them unless they have a director. But then a director
19364 can hardly be found, and even if he could, as matters now stand,
19365 the students, who are very conceited, would not attend to him. That,
19366 however, would be otherwise if the whole State became the director of
19367 these studies and gave honour to them; then disciples would want to
19368 come, and there would be continuous and earnest search, and discoveries
19369 would be made; since even now, disregarded as they are by the world, and
19370 maimed of their fair proportions, and although none of their votaries
19371 can tell the use of them, still these studies force their way by their
19372 natural charm, and very likely, if they had the help of the State, they
19373 would some day emerge into light.
19374 
19375 Yes, he said, there is a remarkable charm in them. But I do not clearly
19376 understand the change in the order. First you began with a geometry of
19377 plane surfaces?
19378 
19379 Yes, I said.
19380 
19381 And you placed astronomy next, and then you made a step backward?
19382 
19383 Yes, and I have delayed you by my hurry; the ludicrous state of solid
19384 geometry, which, in natural order, should have followed, made me pass
19385 over this branch and go on to astronomy, or motion of solids.
19386 
19387 True, he said.
19388 
19389 Then assuming that the science now omitted would come into existence
19390 if encouraged by the State, let us go on to astronomy, which will be
19391 fourth.
19392 
19393 The right order, he replied. And now, Socrates, as you rebuked the
19394 vulgar manner in which I praised astronomy before, my praise shall
19395 be given in your own spirit. For every one, as I think, must see that
19396 astronomy compels the soul to look upwards and leads us from this world
19397 to another.
19398 
19399 Every one but myself, I said; to every one else this may be clear, but
19400 not to me.
19401 
19402 And what then would you say?
19403 
19404 I should rather say that those who elevate astronomy into philosophy
19405 appear to me to make us look downwards and not upwards.
19406 
19407 What do you mean? he asked.
19408 
19409 You, I replied, have in your mind a truly sublime conception of our
19410 knowledge of the things above. And I dare say that if a person were to
19411 throw his head back and study the fretted ceiling, you would still think
19412 that his mind was the percipient, and not his eyes. And you are very
19413 likely right, and I may be a simpleton: but, in my opinion, that
19414 knowledge only which is of being and of the unseen can make the soul
19415 look upwards, and whether a man gapes at the heavens or blinks on the
19416 ground, seeking to learn some particular of sense, I would deny that he
19417 can learn, for nothing of that sort is matter of science; his soul is
19418 looking downwards, not upwards, whether his way to knowledge is by water
19419 or by land, whether he floats, or only lies on his back.
19420 
19421 I acknowledge, he said, the justice of your rebuke. Still, I should like
19422 to ascertain how astronomy can be learned in any manner more conducive
19423 to that knowledge of which we are speaking?
19424 
19425 I will tell you, I said: The starry heaven which we behold is wrought
19426 upon a visible ground, and therefore, although the fairest and most
19427 perfect of visible things, must necessarily be deemed inferior far to
19428 the true motions of absolute swiftness and absolute slowness, which are
19429 relative to each other, and carry with them that which is contained in
19430 them, in the true number and in every true figure. Now, these are to be
19431 apprehended by reason and intelligence, but not by sight.
19432 
19433 True, he replied.
19434 
19435 The spangled heavens should be used as a pattern and with a view to that
19436 higher knowledge; their beauty is like the beauty of figures or pictures
19437 excellently wrought by the hand of Daedalus, or some other great artist,
