19438 which we may chance to behold; any geometrician who saw them would
19439 appreciate the exquisiteness of their workmanship, but he would never
19440 dream of thinking that in them he could find the true equal or the true
19441 double, or the truth of any other proportion.
19442 
19443 No, he replied, such an idea would be ridiculous.
19444 
19445 And will not a true astronomer have the same feeling when he looks at
19446 the movements of the stars? Will he not think that heaven and the things
19447 in heaven are framed by the Creator of them in the most perfect manner?
19448 But he will never imagine that the proportions of night and day, or of
19449 both to the month, or of the month to the year, or of the stars to these
19450 and to one another, and any other things that are material and visible
19451 can also be eternal and subject to no deviation--that would be absurd;
19452 and it is equally absurd to take so much pains in investigating their
19453 exact truth.
19454 
19455 I quite agree, though I never thought of this before.
19456 
19457 Then, I said, in astronomy, as in geometry, we should employ problems,
19458 and let the heavens alone if we would approach the subject in the right
19459 way and so make the natural gift of reason to be of any real use.
19460 
19461 That, he said, is a work infinitely beyond our present astronomers.
19462 
19463 Yes, I said; and there are many other things which must also have a
19464 similar extension given to them, if our legislation is to be of any
19465 value. But can you tell me of any other suitable study?
19466 
19467 No, he said, not without thinking.
19468 
19469 Motion, I said, has many forms, and not one only; two of them are
19470 obvious enough even to wits no better than ours; and there are others,
19471 as I imagine, which may be left to wiser persons.
19472 
19473 But where are the two?
19474 
19475 There is a second, I said, which is the counterpart of the one already
19476 named.
19477 
19478 And what may that be?
19479 
19480 The second, I said, would seem relatively to the ears to be what the
19481 first is to the eyes; for I conceive that as the eyes are designed to
19482 look up at the stars, so are the ears to hear harmonious motions; and
19483 these are sister sciences--as the Pythagoreans say, and we, Glaucon,
19484 agree with them?
19485 
19486 Yes, he replied.
19487 
19488 But this, I said, is a laborious study, and therefore we had better go
19489 and learn of them; and they will tell us whether there are any other
19490 applications of these sciences. At the same time, we must not lose sight
19491 of our own higher object.
19492 
19493 What is that?
19494 
19495 There is a perfection which all knowledge ought to reach, and which our
19496 pupils ought also to attain, and not to fall short of, as I was saying
19497 that they did in astronomy. For in the science of harmony, as you
19498 probably know, the same thing happens. The teachers of harmony compare
19499 the sounds and consonances which are heard only, and their labour, like
19500 that of the astronomers, is in vain.
19501 
19502 Yes, by heaven! he said; and 'tis as good as a play to hear them talking
19503 about their condensed notes, as they call them; they put their ears
19504 close alongside of the strings like persons catching a sound from their
19505 neighbour's wall--one set of them declaring that they distinguish an
19506 intermediate note and have found the least interval which should be
19507 the unit of measurement; the others insisting that the two sounds have
19508 passed into the same--either party setting their ears before their
19509 understanding.
19510 
19511 You mean, I said, those gentlemen who tease and torture the strings and
19512 rack them on the pegs of the instrument: I might carry on the metaphor
19513 and speak after their manner of the blows which the plectrum gives,
19514 and make accusations against the strings, both of backwardness and
19515 forwardness to sound; but this would be tedious, and therefore I will
19516 only say that these are not the men, and that I am referring to the
19517 Pythagoreans, of whom I was just now proposing to enquire about harmony.
19518 For they too are in error, like the astronomers; they investigate the
19519 numbers of the harmonies which are heard, but they never attain to
19520 problems--that is to say, they never reach the natural harmonies of
19521 number, or reflect why some numbers are harmonious and others not.
19522 
19523 That, he said, is a thing of more than mortal knowledge.
19524 
19525 A thing, I replied, which I would rather call useful; that is, if sought
19526 after with a view to the beautiful and good; but if pursued in any other
19527 spirit, useless.
19528 
19529 Very true, he said.
19530 
19531 Now, when all these studies reach the point of inter-communion and
19532 connection with one another, and come to be considered in their mutual
19533 affinities, then, I think, but not till then, will the pursuit of them
19534 have a value for our objects; otherwise there is no profit in them.
19535 
19536 I suspect so; but you are speaking, Socrates, of a vast work.
19537 
19538 What do you mean? I said; the prelude or what? Do you not know that all
19539 this is but the prelude to the actual strain which we have to learn? For
19540 you surely would not regard the skilled mathematician as a dialectician?
19541 
19542 Assuredly not, he said; I have hardly ever known a mathematician who was
19543 capable of reasoning.
19544 
19545 But do you imagine that men who are unable to give and take a reason
19546 will have the knowledge which we require of them?
19547 
19548 Neither can this be supposed.
19549 
19550 And so, Glaucon, I said, we have at last arrived at the hymn of
19551 dialectic. This is that strain which is of the intellect only, but which
19552 the faculty of sight will nevertheless be found to imitate; for sight,
19553 as you may remember, was imagined by us after a while to behold the
19554 real animals and stars, and last of all the sun himself. And so with
19555 dialectic; when a person starts on the discovery of the absolute by
19556 the light of reason only, and without any assistance of sense, and
19557 perseveres until by pure intelligence he arrives at the perception
19558 of the absolute good, he at last finds himself at the end of the
19559 intellectual world, as in the case of sight at the end of the visible.
19560 
19561 Exactly, he said.
19562 
19563 Then this is the progress which you call dialectic?
19564 
19565 True.
19566 
19567 But the release of the prisoners from chains, and their translation
19568 from the shadows to the images and to the light, and the ascent from the
19569 underground den to the sun, while in his presence they are vainly trying
19570 to look on animals and plants and the light of the sun, but are able to
19571 perceive even with their weak eyes the images in the water (which are
19572 divine), and are the shadows of true existence (not shadows of images
19573 cast by a light of fire, which compared with the sun is only an
19574 image)--this power of elevating the highest principle in the soul to
19575 the contemplation of that which is best in existence, with which we may
19576 compare the raising of that faculty which is the very light of the body
19577 to the sight of that which is brightest in the material and visible
19578 world--this power is given, as I was saying, by all that study and
19579 pursuit of the arts which has been described.
19580 
19581 I agree in what you are saying, he replied, which may be hard to
19582 believe, yet, from another point of view, is harder still to deny. This,
19583 however, is not a theme to be treated of in passing only, but will have
19584 to be discussed again and again. And so, whether our conclusion be true
19585 or false, let us assume all this, and proceed at once from the prelude
19586 or preamble to the chief strain (A play upon the Greek word, which means
19587 both 'law' and 'strain.'), and describe that in like manner. Say, then,
19588 what is the nature and what are the divisions of dialectic, and what
19589 are the paths which lead thither; for these paths will also lead to our
19590 final rest.
19591 
19592 Dear Glaucon, I said, you will not be able to follow me here, though
19593 I would do my best, and you should behold not an image only but the
19594 absolute truth, according to my notion. Whether what I told you would
19595 or would not have been a reality I cannot venture to say; but you would
19596 have seen something like reality; of that I am confident.
19597 
19598 Doubtless, he replied.
19599 
19600 But I must also remind you, that the power of dialectic alone can reveal
19601 this, and only to one who is a disciple of the previous sciences.
19602 
19603 Of that assertion you may be as confident as of the last.
19604 
19605 And assuredly no one will argue that there is any other method
19606 of comprehending by any regular process all true existence or of
19607 ascertaining what each thing is in its own nature; for the arts in
19608 general are concerned with the desires or opinions of men, or are
19609 cultivated with a view to production and construction, or for the
19610 preservation of such productions and constructions; and as to the
19611 mathematical sciences which, as we were saying, have some apprehension
19612 of true being--geometry and the like--they only dream about being,
19613 but never can they behold the waking reality so long as they leave the
19614 hypotheses which they use unexamined, and are unable to give an account
19615 of them. For when a man knows not his own first principle, and when the
19616 conclusion and intermediate steps are also constructed out of he knows
19617 not what, how can he imagine that such a fabric of convention can ever
19618 become science?
19619 
19620 Impossible, he said.
19621 
19622 Then dialectic, and dialectic alone, goes directly to the first
19623 principle and is the only science which does away with hypotheses in
19624 order to make her ground secure; the eye of the soul, which is literally
19625 buried in an outlandish slough, is by her gentle aid lifted upwards;
19626 and she uses as handmaids and helpers in the work of conversion, the
19627 sciences which we have been discussing. Custom terms them sciences,
19628 but they ought to have some other name, implying greater clearness
19629 than opinion and less clearness than science: and this, in our previous
19630 sketch, was called understanding. But why should we dispute about names
19631 when we have realities of such importance to consider?
19632 
19633 Why indeed, he said, when any name will do which expresses the thought
19634 of the mind with clearness?
19635 
19636 At any rate, we are satisfied, as before, to have four divisions;
19637 two for intellect and two for opinion, and to call the first division
19638 science, the second understanding, the third belief, and the fourth
19639 perception of shadows, opinion being concerned with becoming, and
19640 intellect with being; and so to make a proportion:--
19641 
19642 As being is to becoming, so is pure intellect to opinion. And as
19643 intellect is to opinion, so is science to belief, and understanding to
19644 the perception of shadows.
19645 
19646 But let us defer the further correlation and subdivision of the subjects
19647 of opinion and of intellect, for it will be a long enquiry, many times
19648 longer than this has been.
19649 
19650 As far as I understand, he said, I agree.
19651 
19652 And do you also agree, I said, in describing the dialectician as one who
19653 attains a conception of the essence of each thing? And he who does not
19654 possess and is therefore unable to impart this conception, in
19655 whatever degree he fails, may in that degree also be said to fail in
19656 intelligence? Will you admit so much?
19657 
19658 Yes, he said; how can I deny it?
19659 
19660 And you would say the same of the conception of the good? Until the
19661 person is able to abstract and define rationally the idea of good,
19662 and unless he can run the gauntlet of all objections, and is ready to
19663 disprove them, not by appeals to opinion, but to absolute truth, never
19664 faltering at any step of the argument--unless he can do all this, you
19665 would say that he knows neither the idea of good nor any other good; he
19666 apprehends only a shadow, if anything at all, which is given by opinion
19667 and not by science;--dreaming and slumbering in this life, before he
19668 is well awake here, he arrives at the world below, and has his final
19669 quietus.
19670 
19671 In all that I should most certainly agree with you.
19672 
19673 And surely you would not have the children of your ideal State, whom you
19674 are nurturing and educating--if the ideal ever becomes a reality--you
19675 would not allow the future rulers to be like posts (Literally 'lines,'
19676 probably the starting-point of a race-course.), having no reason in
19677 them, and yet to be set in authority over the highest matters?
19678 
19679 Certainly not.
19680 
19681 Then you will make a law that they shall have such an education as
19682 will enable them to attain the greatest skill in asking and answering
19683 questions?
19684 
19685 Yes, he said, you and I together will make it.
19686 
19687 Dialectic, then, as you will agree, is the coping-stone of the sciences,
19688 and is set over them; no other science can be placed higher--the nature
19689 of knowledge can no further go?
19690 
19691 I agree, he said.
19692 
19693 But to whom we are to assign these studies, and in what way they are to
19694 be assigned, are questions which remain to be considered.
19695 
19696 Yes, clearly.
19697 
19698 You remember, I said, how the rulers were chosen before?
19699 
19700 Certainly, he said.
19701 
19702 The same natures must still be chosen, and the preference again given
19703 to the surest and the bravest, and, if possible, to the fairest; and,
19704 having noble and generous tempers, they should also have the natural
19705 gifts which will facilitate their education.
19706 
19707 And what are these?
19708 
19709 Such gifts as keenness and ready powers of acquisition; for the mind
19710 more often faints from the severity of study than from the severity of
19711 gymnastics: the toil is more entirely the mind's own, and is not shared
19712 with the body.
19713 
19714 Very true, he replied.
19715 
19716 Further, he of whom we are in search should have a good memory, and be
19717 an unwearied solid man who is a lover of labour in any line; or he will
19718 never be able to endure the great amount of bodily exercise and to go
19719 through all the intellectual discipline and study which we require of
19720 him.
19721 
19722 Certainly, he said; he must have natural gifts.
19723 
19724 The mistake at present is, that those who study philosophy have no
19725 vocation, and this, as I was before saying, is the reason why she has
19726 fallen into disrepute: her true sons should take her by the hand and not
19727 bastards.
19728 
19729 What do you mean?
19730 
19731 In the first place, her votary should not have a lame or halting
19732 industry--I mean, that he should not be half industrious and half idle:
19733 as, for example, when a man is a lover of gymnastic and hunting, and all
19734 other bodily exercises, but a hater rather than a lover of the labour
19735 of learning or listening or enquiring. Or the occupation to which he
19736 devotes himself may be of an opposite kind, and he may have the other
19737 sort of lameness.
19738 
19739 Certainly, he said.
19740 
19741 And as to truth, I said, is not a soul equally to be deemed halt and
19742 lame which hates voluntary falsehood and is extremely indignant at
19743 herself and others when they tell lies, but is patient of involuntary
19744 falsehood, and does not mind wallowing like a swinish beast in the mire
19745 of ignorance, and has no shame at being detected?
19746 
19747 To be sure.
19748 
19749 And, again, in respect of temperance, courage, magnificence, and every
19750 other virtue, should we not carefully distinguish between the true son
19751 and the bastard? for where there is no discernment of such qualities
19752 states and individuals unconsciously err; and the state makes a ruler,
19753 and the individual a friend, of one who, being defective in some part of
19754 virtue, is in a figure lame or a bastard.
19755 
19756 That is very true, he said.
19757 
19758 All these things, then, will have to be carefully considered by us; and
19759 if only those whom we introduce to this vast system of education and
19760 training are sound in body and mind, justice herself will have nothing
19761 to say against us, and we shall be the saviours of the constitution and
19762 of the State; but, if our pupils are men of another stamp, the reverse
19763 will happen, and we shall pour a still greater flood of ridicule on
19764 philosophy than she has to endure at present.
19765 
19766 That would not be creditable.
19767 
19768 Certainly not, I said; and yet perhaps, in thus turning jest into
19769 earnest I am equally ridiculous.
19770 
19771 In what respect?
19772 
19773 I had forgotten, I said, that we were not serious, and spoke with too
19774 much excitement. For when I saw philosophy so undeservedly trampled
19775 under foot of men I could not help feeling a sort of indignation at the
19776 authors of her disgrace: and my anger made me too vehement.
19777 
19778 Indeed! I was listening, and did not think so.
19779 
19780 But I, who am the speaker, felt that I was. And now let me remind you
19781 that, although in our former selection we chose old men, we must not do
19782 so in this. Solon was under a delusion when he said that a man when he
19783 grows old may learn many things--for he can no more learn much than he
19784 can run much; youth is the time for any extraordinary toil.
19785 
19786 Of course.
19787 
19788 And, therefore, calculation and geometry and all the other elements of
19789 instruction, which are a preparation for dialectic, should be presented
19790 to the mind in childhood; not, however, under any notion of forcing our
19791 system of education.
19792 
19793 Why not?
19794 
19795 Because a freeman ought not to be a slave in the acquisition of
19796 knowledge of any kind. Bodily exercise, when compulsory, does no harm
19797 to the body; but knowledge which is acquired under compulsion obtains no
19798 hold on the mind.
19799 
19800 Very true.
19801 
19802 Then, my good friend, I said, do not use compulsion, but let early
19803 education be a sort of amusement; you will then be better able to find
19804 out the natural bent.
19805 
19806 That is a very rational notion, he said.
19807 
19808 Do you remember that the children, too, were to be taken to see the
19809 battle on horseback; and that if there were no danger they were to be
19810 brought close up and, like young hounds, have a taste of blood given
19811 them?
19812 
19813 Yes, I remember.
19814 
19815 The same practice may be followed, I said, in all these things--labours,
19816 lessons, dangers--and he who is most at home in all of them ought to be
19817 enrolled in a select number.
19818 
19819 At what age?
19820 
19821 At the age when the necessary gymnastics are over: the period whether of
19822 two or three years which passes in this sort of training is useless for
19823 any other purpose; for sleep and exercise are unpropitious to learning;
19824 and the trial of who is first in gymnastic exercises is one of the most
19825 important tests to which our youth are subjected.
19826 
19827 Certainly, he replied.
19828 
19829 After that time those who are selected from the class of twenty years
19830 old will be promoted to higher honour, and the sciences which they
19831 learned without any order in their early education will now be brought
19832 together, and they will be able to see the natural relationship of them
19833 to one another and to true being.
19834 
19835 Yes, he said, that is the only kind of knowledge which takes lasting
19836 root.
19837 
19838 Yes, I said; and the capacity for such knowledge is the great criterion
19839 of dialectical talent: the comprehensive mind is always the dialectical.
19840 
19841 I agree with you, he said.
19842 
19843 These, I said, are the points which you must consider; and those who
19844 have most of this comprehension, and who are most steadfast in their
19845 learning, and in their military and other appointed duties, when they
19846 have arrived at the age of thirty have to be chosen by you out of the
19847 select class, and elevated to higher honour; and you will have to prove
19848 them by the help of dialectic, in order to learn which of them is able
19849 to give up the use of sight and the other senses, and in company with
19850 truth to attain absolute being: And here, my friend, great caution is
19851 required.
19852 
19853 Why great caution?
19854 
19855 Do you not remark, I said, how great is the evil which dialectic has
19856 introduced?
19857 
19858 What evil? he said.
19859 
19860 The students of the art are filled with lawlessness.
19861 
19862 Quite true, he said.
19863 
19864 Do you think that there is anything so very unnatural or inexcusable in
19865 their case? or will you make allowance for them?
19866 
19867 In what way make allowance?
19868 
19869 I want you, I said, by way of parallel, to imagine a supposititious son
19870 who is brought up in great wealth; he is one of a great and numerous
19871 family, and has many flatterers. When he grows up to manhood, he learns
19872 that his alleged are not his real parents; but who the real are he
19873 is unable to discover. Can you guess how he will be likely to behave
19874 towards his flatterers and his supposed parents, first of all during the
19875 period when he is ignorant of the false relation, and then again when he
19876 knows? Or shall I guess for you?
19877 
19878 If you please.
19879 
19880 Then I should say, that while he is ignorant of the truth he will be
19881 likely to honour his father and his mother and his supposed relations
19882 more than the flatterers; he will be less inclined to neglect them when
19883 in need, or to do or say anything against them; and he will be less
19884 willing to disobey them in any important matter.
19885 
19886 He will.
19887 
19888 But when he has made the discovery, I should imagine that he would
19889 diminish his honour and regard for them, and would become more devoted
19890 to the flatterers; their influence over him would greatly increase; he
19891 would now live after their ways, and openly associate with them, and,
19892 unless he were of an unusually good disposition, he would trouble
19893 himself no more about his supposed parents or other relations.
19894 
19895 Well, all that is very probable. But how is the image applicable to the
19896 disciples of philosophy?
19897 
19898 In this way: you know that there are certain principles about justice
19899 and honour, which were taught us in childhood, and under their parental
19900 authority we have been brought up, obeying and honouring them.
19901 
19902 That is true.
19903 
19904 There are also opposite maxims and habits of pleasure which flatter and
19905 attract the soul, but do not influence those of us who have any sense of
19906 right, and they continue to obey and honour the maxims of their fathers.
19907 
19908 True.
19909 
19910 Now, when a man is in this state, and the questioning spirit asks what
19911 is fair or honourable, and he answers as the legislator has taught him,
19912 and then arguments many and diverse refute his words, until he is driven
19913 into believing that nothing is honourable any more than dishonourable,
19914 or just and good any more than the reverse, and so of all the notions
19915 which he most valued, do you think that he will still honour and obey
19916 them as before?
19917 
19918 Impossible.
19919 
19920 And when he ceases to think them honourable and natural as heretofore,
19921 and he fails to discover the true, can he be expected to pursue any life
19922 other than that which flatters his desires?
19923 
19924 He cannot.
19925 
19926 And from being a keeper of the law he is converted into a breaker of it?
19927 
19928 Unquestionably.
19929 
19930 Now all this is very natural in students of philosophy such as I have
19931 described, and also, as I was just now saying, most excusable.
19932 
19933 Yes, he said; and, I may add, pitiable.
19934 
19935 Therefore, that your feelings may not be moved to pity about our
19936 citizens who are now thirty years of age, every care must be taken in
19937 introducing them to dialectic.
19938 
19939 Certainly.
19940 
19941 There is a danger lest they should taste the dear delight too early; for
19942 youngsters, as you may have observed, when they first get the taste
19943 in their mouths, argue for amusement, and are always contradicting and
19944 refuting others in imitation of those who refute them; like puppy-dogs,
19945 they rejoice in pulling and tearing at all who come near them.
19946 
19947 Yes, he said, there is nothing which they like better.
19948 
19949 And when they have made many conquests and received defeats at the hands
19950 of many, they violently and speedily get into a way of not believing
19951 anything which they believed before, and hence, not only they, but
19952 philosophy and all that relates to it is apt to have a bad name with the
19953 rest of the world.
19954 
19955 Too true, he said.
19956 
19957 But when a man begins to get older, he will no longer be guilty of such
19958 insanity; he will imitate the dialectician who is seeking for truth, and
19959 not the eristic, who is contradicting for the sake of amusement; and the
19960 greater moderation of his character will increase instead of diminishing
19961 the honour of the pursuit.
19962 
19963 Very true, he said.
19964 
19965 And did we not make special provision for this, when we said that the
19966 disciples of philosophy were to be orderly and steadfast, not, as now,
19967 any chance aspirant or intruder?
19968 
19969 Very true.
19970 
19971 Suppose, I said, the study of philosophy to take the place of gymnastics
19972 and to be continued diligently and earnestly and exclusively for twice
19973 the number of years which were passed in bodily exercise--will that be
19974 enough?
19975 
19976 Would you say six or four years? he asked.
19977 
19978 Say five years, I replied; at the end of the time they must be sent down
19979 again into the den and compelled to hold any military or other office
19980 which young men are qualified to hold: in this way they will get their
19981 experience of life, and there will be an opportunity of trying whether,
19982 when they are drawn all manner of ways by temptation, they will stand
19983 firm or flinch.
19984 
19985 And how long is this stage of their lives to last?
19986 
19987 Fifteen years, I answered; and when they have reached fifty years of
19988 age, then let those who still survive and have distinguished themselves
19989 in every action of their lives and in every branch of knowledge come at
19990 last to their consummation: the time has now arrived at which they must
19991 raise the eye of the soul to the universal light which lightens all
19992 things, and behold the absolute good; for that is the pattern according
19993 to which they are to order the State and the lives of individuals, and
19994 the remainder of their own lives also; making philosophy their chief
19995 pursuit, but, when their turn comes, toiling also at politics and ruling
19996 for the public good, not as though they were performing some heroic
19997 action, but simply as a matter of duty; and when they have brought up in
19998 each generation others like themselves and left them in their place to
19999 be governors of the State, then they will depart to the Islands of the
20000 Blest and dwell there; and the city will give them public memorials and
20001 sacrifices and honour them, if the Pythian oracle consent, as demigods,
20002 but if not, as in any case blessed and divine.
20003 
20004 You are a sculptor, Socrates, and have made statues of our governors
20005 faultless in beauty.
20006 
20007 Yes, I said, Glaucon, and of our governesses too; for you must not
20008 suppose that what I have been saying applies to men only and not to
20009 women as far as their natures can go.
20010 
20011 There you are right, he said, since we have made them to share in all
20012 things like the men.
20013 
20014 Well, I said, and you would agree (would you not?) that what has
20015 been said about the State and the government is not a mere dream, and
20016 although difficult not impossible, but only possible in the way which
20017 has been supposed; that is to say, when the true philosopher kings are
20018 born in a State, one or more of them, despising the honours of this
20019 present world which they deem mean and worthless, esteeming above all
20020 things right and the honour that springs from right, and regarding
20021 justice as the greatest and most necessary of all things, whose
20022 ministers they are, and whose principles will be exalted by them when
20023 they set in order their own city?
20024 
20025 How will they proceed?
20026 
20027 They will begin by sending out into the country all the inhabitants of
20028 the city who are more than ten years old, and will take possession of
20029 their children, who will be unaffected by the habits of their parents;
20030 these they will train in their own habits and laws, I mean in the laws
20031 which we have given them: and in this way the State and constitution of
20032 which we were speaking will soonest and most easily attain happiness,
20033 and the nation which has such a constitution will gain most.
20034 
20035 Yes, that will be the best way. And I think, Socrates, that you have
20036 very well described how, if ever, such a constitution might come into
20037 being.
20038 
20039 Enough then of the perfect State, and of the man who bears its
20040 image--there is no difficulty in seeing how we shall describe him.
20041 
20042 There is no difficulty, he replied; and I agree with you in thinking
20043 that nothing more need be said.
20044 
20045 
20046 
20047 
20048 BOOK VIII.
20049 
20050 And so, Glaucon, we have arrived at the conclusion that in the perfect
20051 State wives and children are to be in common; and that all education
20052 and the pursuits of war and peace are also to be common, and the best
20053 philosophers and the bravest warriors are to be their kings?
20054 
20055 That, replied Glaucon, has been acknowledged.
20056 
20057 Yes, I said; and we have further acknowledged that the governors, when
20058 appointed themselves, will take their soldiers and place them in houses
20059 such as we were describing, which are common to all, and contain nothing
20060 private, or individual; and about their property, you remember what we
20061 agreed?
20062 
20063 Yes, I remember that no one was to have any of the ordinary possessions
20064 of mankind; they were to be warrior athletes and guardians, receiving
20065 from the other citizens, in lieu of annual payment, only their
20066 maintenance, and they were to take care of themselves and of the whole
20067 State.
20068 
20069 True, I said; and now that this division of our task is concluded, let
20070 us find the point at which we digressed, that we may return into the old
20071 path.
20072 
20073 There is no difficulty in returning; you implied, then as now, that you
20074 had finished the description of the State: you said that such a State
20075 was good, and that the man was good who answered to it, although, as now
20076 appears, you had more excellent things to relate both of State and man.
20077 And you said further, that if this was the true form, then the others
20078 were false; and of the false forms, you said, as I remember, that there
20079 were four principal ones, and that their defects, and the defects of
20080 the individuals corresponding to them, were worth examining. When we had
20081 seen all the individuals, and finally agreed as to who was the best and
20082 who was the worst of them, we were to consider whether the best was not
20083 also the happiest, and the worst the most miserable. I asked you
20084 what were the four forms of government of which you spoke, and then
20085 Polemarchus and Adeimantus put in their word; and you began again, and
20086 have found your way to the point at which we have now arrived.
20087 
20088 Your recollection, I said, is most exact.
20089 
20090 Then, like a wrestler, he replied, you must put yourself again in the
20091 same position; and let me ask the same questions, and do you give me the
20092 same answer which you were about to give me then.
20093 
20094 Yes, if I can, I will, I said.
20095 
20096 I shall particularly wish to hear what were the four constitutions of
20097 which you were speaking.
20098 
20099 That question, I said, is easily answered: the four governments of which
20100 I spoke, so far as they have distinct names, are, first, those of Crete
20101 and Sparta, which are generally applauded; what is termed oligarchy
20102 comes next; this is not equally approved, and is a form of government
20103 which teems with evils: thirdly, democracy, which naturally follows
20104 oligarchy, although very different: and lastly comes tyranny, great
20105 and famous, which differs from them all, and is the fourth and worst
20106 disorder of a State. I do not know, do you? of any other constitution
20107 which can be said to have a distinct character. There are lordships and
20108 principalities which are bought and sold, and some other intermediate
20109 forms of government. But these are nondescripts and may be found equally
20110 among Hellenes and among barbarians.
20111 
20112 Yes, he replied, we certainly hear of many curious forms of government
20113 which exist among them.
20114 
20115 Do you know, I said, that governments vary as the dispositions of men
20116 vary, and that there must be as many of the one as there are of the
20117 other? For we cannot suppose that States are made of 'oak and rock,' and
20118 not out of the human natures which are in them, and which in a figure
20119 turn the scale and draw other things after them?
20120 
20121 Yes, he said, the States are as the men are; they grow out of human
20122 characters.
20123 
20124 Then if the constitutions of States are five, the dispositions of
20125 individual minds will also be five?
20126 
20127 Certainly.
20128 
20129 Him who answers to aristocracy, and whom we rightly call just and good,
20130 we have already described.
20131 
20132 We have.
20133 
20134 Then let us now proceed to describe the inferior sort of natures, being
20135 the contentious and ambitious, who answer to the Spartan polity; also
20136 the oligarchical, democratical, and tyrannical. Let us place the most
20137 just by the side of the most unjust, and when we see them we shall be
20138 able to compare the relative happiness or unhappiness of him who leads
20139 a life of pure justice or pure injustice. The enquiry will then be
20140 completed. And we shall know whether we ought to pursue injustice,
20141 as Thrasymachus advises, or in accordance with the conclusions of the
20142 argument to prefer justice.
20143 
20144 Certainly, he replied, we must do as you say.
20145 
20146 Shall we follow our old plan, which we adopted with a view to clearness,
20147 of taking the State first and then proceeding to the individual, and
20148 begin with the government of honour?--I know of no name for such a
20149 government other than timocracy, or perhaps timarchy. We will compare
20150 with this the like character in the individual; and, after that,
20151 consider oligarchy and the oligarchical man; and then again we will turn
20152 our attention to democracy and the democratical man; and lastly, we
20153 will go and view the city of tyranny, and once more take a look into the
20154 tyrant's soul, and try to arrive at a satisfactory decision.
20155 
20156 That way of viewing and judging of the matter will be very suitable.
20157 
20158 First, then, I said, let us enquire how timocracy (the government of
20159 honour) arises out of aristocracy (the government of the best). Clearly,
20160 all political changes originate in divisions of the actual governing
20161 power; a government which is united, however small, cannot be moved.
20162 
20163 Very true, he said.
20164 
20165 In what way, then, will our city be moved, and in what manner will the
20166 two classes of auxiliaries and rulers disagree among themselves or with
20167 one another? Shall we, after the manner of Homer, pray the Muses to tell
20168 us 'how discord first arose'? Shall we imagine them in solemn mockery,
20169 to play and jest with us as if we were children, and to address us in a
20170 lofty tragic vein, making believe to be in earnest?
20171 
20172 How would they address us?
20173 
20174 After this manner:--A city which is thus constituted can hardly be
20175 shaken; but, seeing that everything which has a beginning has also an
20176 end, even a constitution such as yours will not last for ever, but will
20177 in time be dissolved. And this is the dissolution:--In plants that grow
20178 in the earth, as well as in animals that move on the earth's surface,
20179 fertility and sterility of soul and body occur when the circumferences
20180 of the circles of each are completed, which in short-lived existences
20181 pass over a short space, and in long-lived ones over a long space. But
20182 to the knowledge of human fecundity and sterility all the wisdom and
20183 education of your rulers will not attain; the laws which regulate them
20184 will not be discovered by an intelligence which is alloyed with sense,
20185 but will escape them, and they will bring children into the world when
20186 they ought not. Now that which is of divine birth has a period which is
20187 contained in a perfect number (i.e. a cyclical number, such as 6, which
20188 is equal to the sum of its divisors 1, 2, 3, so that when the circle
20189 or time represented by 6 is completed, the lesser times or rotations
20190 represented by 1, 2, 3 are also completed.), but the period of
20191 human birth is comprehended in a number in which first increments
20192 by involution and evolution (or squared and cubed) obtaining three
20193 intervals and four terms of like and unlike, waxing and waning numbers,
20194 make all the terms commensurable and agreeable to one another. (Probably
20195 the numbers 3, 4, 5, 6 of which the three first = the sides of the
20196 Pythagorean triangle. The terms will then be 3 cubed, 4 cubed, 5 cubed,
20197 which together = 6 cubed = 216.) The base of these (3) with a third
20198 added (4) when combined with five (20) and raised to the third power
20199 furnishes two harmonies; the first a square which is a hundred times
20200 as great (400 = 4 x 100) (Or the first a square which is 100 x 100 =
20201 10,000. The whole number will then be 17,500 = a square of 100, and an
20202 oblong of 100 by 75.), and the other a figure having one side equal to
20203 the former, but oblong, consisting of a hundred numbers squared upon
20204 rational diameters of a square (i.e. omitting fractions), the side of
20205 which is five (7 x 7 = 49 x 100 = 4900), each of them being less by one
20206 (than the perfect square which includes the fractions, sc. 50) or less
20207 by (Or, 'consisting of two numbers squared upon irrational diameters,'
20208 etc. = 100. For other explanations of the passage see Introduction.) two
20209 perfect squares of irrational diameters (of a square the side of which
20210 is five = 50 + 50 = 100); and a hundred cubes of three (27 x 100 = 2700
20211 + 4900 + 400 = 8000). Now this number represents a geometrical figure
20212 which has control over the good and evil of births. For when your
20213 guardians are ignorant of the law of births, and unite bride and
20214 bridegroom out of season, the children will not be goodly or
20215 fortunate. And though only the best of them will be appointed by their
20216 predecessors, still they will be unworthy to hold their fathers' places,
20217 and when they come into power as guardians, they will soon be found
20218 to fail in taking care of us, the Muses, first by under-valuing music;
20219 which neglect will soon extend to gymnastic; and hence the young men of
20220 your State will be less cultivated. In the succeeding generation rulers
20221 will be appointed who have lost the guardian power of testing the metal
20222 of your different races, which, like Hesiod's, are of gold and silver
20223 and brass and iron. And so iron will be mingled with silver, and brass
20224 with gold, and hence there will arise dissimilarity and inequality and
20225 irregularity, which always and in all places are causes of hatred
20226 and war. This the Muses affirm to be the stock from which discord has
20227 sprung, wherever arising; and this is their answer to us.
20228 
20229 Yes, and we may assume that they answer truly.
20230 
20231 Why, yes, I said, of course they answer truly; how can the Muses speak
20232 falsely?
20233 
20234 And what do the Muses say next?
20235 
20236 When discord arose, then the two races were drawn different ways: the
20237 iron and brass fell to acquiring money and land and houses and gold and
20238 silver; but the gold and silver races, not wanting money but having the
20239 true riches in their own nature, inclined towards virtue and the ancient
20240 order of things. There was a battle between them, and at last they
20241 agreed to distribute their land and houses among individual owners;
20242 and they enslaved their friends and maintainers, whom they had formerly
20243 protected in the condition of freemen, and made of them subjects and
20244 servants; and they themselves were engaged in war and in keeping a watch
20245 against them.
20246 
20247 I believe that you have rightly conceived the origin of the change.
20248 
20249 And the new government which thus arises will be of a form intermediate
20250 between oligarchy and aristocracy?
20251 
20252 Very true.
20253 
20254 Such will be the change, and after the change has been made, how will
20255 they proceed? Clearly, the new State, being in a mean between oligarchy
20256 and the perfect State, will partly follow one and partly the other, and
20257 will also have some peculiarities.
20258 
20259 True, he said.
20260 
20261 In the honour given to rulers, in the abstinence of the warrior class
20262 from agriculture, handicrafts, and trade in general, in the institution
20263 of common meals, and in the attention paid to gymnastics and military
20264 training--in all these respects this State will resemble the former.
20265 
20266 True.
20267 
20268 But in the fear of admitting philosophers to power, because they are no
20269 longer to be had simple and earnest, but are made up of mixed elements;
20270 and in turning from them to passionate and less complex characters, who
20271 are by nature fitted for war rather than peace; and in the value set
20272 by them upon military stratagems and contrivances, and in the waging of
20273 everlasting wars--this State will be for the most part peculiar.
20274 
20275 Yes.
20276 
20277 Yes, I said; and men of this stamp will be covetous of money, like those
20278 who live in oligarchies; they will have, a fierce secret longing after
20279 gold and silver, which they will hoard in dark places, having magazines
20280 and treasuries of their own for the deposit and concealment of them;
20281 also castles which are just nests for their eggs, and in which they will
20282 spend large sums on their wives, or on any others whom they please.
20283 
20284 That is most true, he said.
20285 
20286 And they are miserly because they have no means of openly acquiring the
20287 money which they prize; they will spend that which is another man's on
20288 the gratification of their desires, stealing their pleasures and running
20289 away like children from the law, their father: they have been schooled
20290 not by gentle influences but by force, for they have neglected her
20291 who is the true Muse, the companion of reason and philosophy, and have
20292 honoured gymnastic more than music.
20293 
20294 Undoubtedly, he said, the form of government which you describe is a
20295 mixture of good and evil.
20296 
20297 Why, there is a mixture, I said; but one thing, and one thing only, is
20298 predominantly seen,--the spirit of contention and ambition; and these
20299 are due to the prevalence of the passionate or spirited element.
20300 
20301 Assuredly, he said.
20302 
20303 Such is the origin and such the character of this State, which has been
20304 described in outline only; the more perfect execution was not required,
20305 for a sketch is enough to show the type of the most perfectly just and
20306 most perfectly unjust; and to go through all the States and all the
20307 characters of men, omitting none of them, would be an interminable
20308 labour.
20309 
20310 Very true, he replied.
20311 
20312 Now what man answers to this form of government-how did he come into
20313 being, and what is he like?
20314 
20315 I think, said Adeimantus, that in the spirit of contention which
20316 characterises him, he is not unlike our friend Glaucon.
20317 
20318 Perhaps, I said, he may be like him in that one point; but there are
20319 other respects in which he is very different.
20320 
20321 In what respects?
20322 
20323 He should have more of self-assertion and be less cultivated, and yet
20324 a friend of culture; and he should be a good listener, but no speaker.
20325 Such a person is apt to be rough with slaves, unlike the educated man,
20326 who is too proud for that; and he will also be courteous to freemen, and
20327 remarkably obedient to authority; he is a lover of power and a lover of
20328 honour; claiming to be a ruler, not because he is eloquent, or on any
20329 ground of that sort, but because he is a soldier and has performed feats
20330 of arms; he is also a lover of gymnastic exercises and of the chase.
20331 
20332 Yes, that is the type of character which answers to timocracy.
20333 
20334 Such an one will despise riches only when he is young; but as he gets
20335 older he will be more and more attracted to them, because he has a
20336 piece of the avaricious nature in him, and is not single-minded towards
20337 virtue, having lost his best guardian.
20338 
20339 Who was that? said Adeimantus.
20340 
20341 Philosophy, I said, tempered with music, who comes and takes up her
20342 abode in a man, and is the only saviour of his virtue throughout life.
20343 
20344 Good, he said.
20345 
20346 Such, I said, is the timocratical youth, and he is like the timocratical
20347 State.
20348 
20349 Exactly.
20350 
20351 His origin is as follows:--He is often the young son of a brave father,
20352 who dwells in an ill-governed city, of which he declines the honours
20353 and offices, and will not go to law, or exert himself in any way, but is
20354 ready to waive his rights in order that he may escape trouble.
20355 
20356 And how does the son come into being?
20357 
20358 The character of the son begins to develope when he hears his mother
20359 complaining that her husband has no place in the government, of which
20360 the consequence is that she has no precedence among other women.
20361 Further, when she sees her husband not very eager about money, and
20362 instead of battling and railing in the law courts or assembly, taking
20363 whatever happens to him quietly; and when she observes that his thoughts
20364 always centre in himself, while he treats her with very considerable
20365 indifference, she is annoyed, and says to her son that his father is
20366 only half a man and far too easy-going: adding all the other complaints
20367 about her own ill-treatment which women are so fond of rehearsing.
20368 
20369 Yes, said Adeimantus, they give us plenty of them, and their complaints
20370 are so like themselves.
20371 
20372 And you know, I said, that the old servants also, who are supposed to
20373 be attached to the family, from time to time talk privately in the same
20374 strain to the son; and if they see any one who owes money to his father,
20375 or is wronging him in any way, and he fails to prosecute them, they tell
20376 the youth that when he grows up he must retaliate upon people of this
20377 sort, and be more of a man than his father. He has only to walk abroad
20378 and he hears and sees the same sort of thing: those who do their own
20379 business in the city are called simpletons, and held in no esteem, while
20380 the busy-bodies are honoured and applauded. The result is that the young
20381 man, hearing and seeing all these things--hearing, too, the words of
20382 his father, and having a nearer view of his way of life, and making
20383 comparisons of him and others--is drawn opposite ways: while his father
20384 is watering and nourishing the rational principle in his soul, the
20385 others are encouraging the passionate and appetitive; and he being not
20386 originally of a bad nature, but having kept bad company, is at last
20387 brought by their joint influence to a middle point, and gives up the
20388 kingdom which is within him to the middle principle of contentiousness
20389 and passion, and becomes arrogant and ambitious.
20390 
20391 You seem to me to have described his origin perfectly.
20392 
20393 Then we have now, I said, the second form of government and the second
20394 type of character?
20395 
20396 We have.
20397 
20398 Next, let us look at another man who, as Aeschylus says,
20399 
20400 'Is set over against another State;'
20401 
20402 or rather, as our plan requires, begin with the State.
20403 
20404 By all means.
20405 
20406 I believe that oligarchy follows next in order.
20407 
20408 And what manner of government do you term oligarchy?
20409 
20410 A government resting on a valuation of property, in which the rich have
20411 power and the poor man is deprived of it.
20412 
20413 I understand, he replied.
20414 
20415 Ought I not to begin by describing how the change from timocracy to
20416 oligarchy arises?
20417 
20418 Yes.
20419 
20420 Well, I said, no eyes are required in order to see how the one passes
20421 into the other.
20422 
20423 How?
20424 
20425 The accumulation of gold in the treasury of private individuals is the
20426 ruin of timocracy; they invent illegal modes of expenditure; for what do
20427 they or their wives care about the law?
20428 
20429 Yes, indeed.
20430 
20431 And then one, seeing another grow rich, seeks to rival him, and thus the
20432 great mass of the citizens become lovers of money.
20433 
20434 Likely enough.
20435 
20436 And so they grow richer and richer, and the more they think of making
20437 a fortune the less they think of virtue; for when riches and virtue are
20438 placed together in the scales of the balance, the one always rises as
20439 the other falls.
20440 
20441 True.
20442 
20443 And in proportion as riches and rich men are honoured in the State,
20444 virtue and the virtuous are dishonoured.
20445 
20446 Clearly.
20447 
20448 And what is honoured is cultivated, and that which has no honour is
20449 neglected.
20450 
20451 That is obvious.
20452 
20453 And so at last, instead of loving contention and glory, men become
20454 lovers of trade and money; they honour and look up to the rich man, and
20455 make a ruler of him, and dishonour the poor man.
20456 
20457 They do so.
20458 
20459 They next proceed to make a law which fixes a sum of money as the
20460 qualification of citizenship; the sum is higher in one place and lower
20461 in another, as the oligarchy is more or less exclusive; and they allow
20462 no one whose property falls below the amount fixed to have any share in
20463 the government. These changes in the constitution they effect by force
20464 of arms, if intimidation has not already done their work.
20465 
20466 Very true.
20467 
20468 And this, speaking generally, is the way in which oligarchy is
20469 established.
20470 
20471 Yes, he said; but what are the characteristics of this form of
20472 government, and what are the defects of which we were speaking?
20473 
20474 First of all, I said, consider the nature of the qualification. Just
20475 think what would happen if pilots were to be chosen according to their
20476 property, and a poor man were refused permission to steer, even though
20477 he were a better pilot?
20478 
20479 You mean that they would shipwreck?
20480 
20481 Yes; and is not this true of the government of anything?
20482 
20483 I should imagine so.
20484 
20485 Except a city?--or would you include a city?
20486 
20487 Nay, he said, the case of a city is the strongest of all, inasmuch as
20488 the rule of a city is the greatest and most difficult of all.
20489 
20490 This, then, will be the first great defect of oligarchy?
20491 
20492 Clearly.
20493 
20494 And here is another defect which is quite as bad.
20495 
20496 What defect?
20497 
20498 The inevitable division: such a State is not one, but two States, the
20499 one of poor, the other of rich men; and they are living on the same spot
20500 and always conspiring against one another.
20501 
20502 That, surely, is at least as bad.
20503 
20504 Another discreditable feature is, that, for a like reason, they are
20505 incapable of carrying on any war. Either they arm the multitude, and
20506 then they are more afraid of them than of the enemy; or, if they do not
20507 call them out in the hour of battle, they are oligarchs indeed, few to
20508 fight as they are few to rule. And at the same time their fondness for
20509 money makes them unwilling to pay taxes.
20510 
20511 How discreditable!
20512 
20513 And, as we said before, under such a constitution the same persons have
20514 too many callings--they are husbandmen, tradesmen, warriors, all in one.
20515 Does that look well?
20516 
20517 Anything but well.
20518 
20519 There is another evil which is, perhaps, the greatest of all, and to
20520 which this State first begins to be liable.
20521 
20522 What evil?
20523 
20524 A man may sell all that he has, and another may acquire his property;
20525 yet after the sale he may dwell in the city of which he is no longer a
20526 part, being neither trader, nor artisan, nor horseman, nor hoplite, but
20527 only a poor, helpless creature.
20528 
20529 Yes, that is an evil which also first begins in this State.
20530 
20531 The evil is certainly not prevented there; for oligarchies have both the
20532 extremes of great wealth and utter poverty.
20533 
20534 True.
20535 
20536 But think again: In his wealthy days, while he was spending his money,
20537 was a man of this sort a whit more good to the State for the purposes
20538 of citizenship? Or did he only seem to be a member of the ruling
20539 body, although in truth he was neither ruler nor subject, but just a
20540 spendthrift?
20541 
20542 As you say, he seemed to be a ruler, but was only a spendthrift.
20543 
20544 May we not say that this is the drone in the house who is like the drone
20545 in the honeycomb, and that the one is the plague of the city as the
20546 other is of the hive?
20547 
20548 Just so, Socrates.
20549 
20550 And God has made the flying drones, Adeimantus, all without stings,
20551 whereas of the walking drones he has made some without stings but others
20552 have dreadful stings; of the stingless class are those who in their old
20553 age end as paupers; of the stingers come all the criminal class, as they
20554 are termed.
20555 
20556 Most true, he said.
20557 
20558 Clearly then, whenever you see paupers in a State, somewhere in that
20559 neighborhood there are hidden away thieves, and cut-purses and robbers
20560 of temples, and all sorts of malefactors.
20561 
20562 Clearly.
20563 
20564 Well, I said, and in oligarchical States do you not find paupers?
20565 
20566 Yes, he said; nearly everybody is a pauper who is not a ruler.
20567 
20568 And may we be so bold as to affirm that there are also many criminals to
20569 be found in them, rogues who have stings, and whom the authorities are
20570 careful to restrain by force?
20571 
20572 Certainly, we may be so bold.
20573 
20574 The existence of such persons is to be attributed to want of education,
20575 ill-training, and an evil constitution of the State?
20576 
20577 True.
20578 
20579 Such, then, is the form and such are the evils of oligarchy; and there
20580 may be many other evils.
20581 
20582 Very likely.
20583 
20584 Then oligarchy, or the form of government in which the rulers are
20585 elected for their wealth, may now be dismissed. Let us next proceed to
20586 consider the nature and origin of the individual who answers to this
20587 State.
20588 
20589 By all means.
20590 
20591 Does not the timocratical man change into the oligarchical on this wise?
20592 
20593 How?
20594 
20595 A time arrives when the representative of timocracy has a son: at first
20596 he begins by emulating his father and walking in his footsteps, but
20597 presently he sees him of a sudden foundering against the State as upon
20598 a sunken reef, and he and all that he has is lost; he may have been
20599 a general or some other high officer who is brought to trial under a
20600 prejudice raised by informers, and either put to death, or exiled, or
20601 deprived of the privileges of a citizen, and all his property taken from
20602 him.
20603 
20604 Nothing more likely.
20605 
20606 And the son has seen and known all this--he is a ruined man, and his
20607 fear has taught him to knock ambition and passion headforemost from his
20608 bosom's throne; humbled by poverty he takes to money-making and by mean
20609 and miserly savings and hard work gets a fortune together. Is not such
20610 an one likely to seat the concupiscent and covetous element on the
20611 vacant throne and to suffer it to play the great king within him, girt
20612 with tiara and chain and scimitar?
20613 
20614 Most true, he replied.
20615 
20616 And when he has made reason and spirit sit down on the ground obediently
20617 on either side of their sovereign, and taught them to know their place,
20618 he compels the one to think only of how lesser sums may be turned into
20619 larger ones, and will not allow the other to worship and admire anything
20620 but riches and rich men, or to be ambitious of anything so much as the
20621 acquisition of wealth and the means of acquiring it.
20622 
20623 Of all changes, he said, there is none so speedy or so sure as the
20624 conversion of the ambitious youth into the avaricious one.
20625 
20626 And the avaricious, I said, is the oligarchical youth?
20627 
20628 Yes, he said; at any rate the individual out of whom he came is like the
20629 State out of which oligarchy came.
20630 
20631 Let us then consider whether there is any likeness between them.
20632 
20633 Very good.
20634 
20635 First, then, they resemble one another in the value which they set upon
20636 wealth?
20637 
20638 Certainly.
20639 
20640 Also in their penurious, laborious character; the individual only
20641 satisfies his necessary appetites, and confines his expenditure to them;
20642 his other desires he subdues, under the idea that they are unprofitable.
20643 
20644 True.
20645 
20646 He is a shabby fellow, who saves something out of everything and makes a
20647 purse for himself; and this is the sort of man whom the vulgar applaud.
20648 Is he not a true image of the State which he represents?
20649 
20650 He appears to me to be so; at any rate money is highly valued by him as
20651 well as by the State.
20652 
20653 You see that he is not a man of cultivation, I said.
20654 
20655 I imagine not, he said; had he been educated he would never have made a
20656 blind god director of his chorus, or given him chief honour.
20657 
20658 Excellent! I said. Yet consider: Must we not further admit that owing to
20659 this want of cultivation there will be found in him dronelike desires as
20660 of pauper and rogue, which are forcibly kept down by his general habit
20661 of life?
20662 
20663 True.
20664 
20665 Do you know where you will have to look if you want to discover his
20666 rogueries?
20667 
20668 Where must I look?
20669 
20670 You should see him where he has some great opportunity of acting
20671 dishonestly, as in the guardianship of an orphan.
20672 
20673 Aye.
20674 
20675 It will be clear enough then that in his ordinary dealings which give
20676 him a reputation for honesty he coerces his bad passions by an enforced
20677 virtue; not making them see that they are wrong, or taming them by
20678 reason, but by necessity and fear constraining them, and because he
20679 trembles for his possessions.
20680 
20681 To be sure.
20682 
20683 Yes, indeed, my dear friend, but you will find that the natural desires
20684 of the drone commonly exist in him all the same whenever he has to spend
20685 what is not his own.
20686 
20687 Yes, and they will be strong in him too.
20688 
20689 The man, then, will be at war with himself; he will be two men, and not
20690 one; but, in general, his better desires will be found to prevail over
20691 his inferior ones.
20692 
20693 True.
20694 
20695 For these reasons such an one will be more respectable than most people;
20696 yet the true virtue of a unanimous and harmonious soul will flee far
20697 away and never come near him.
20698 
20699 I should expect so.
20700 
20701 And surely, the miser individually will be an ignoble competitor in a
20702 State for any prize of victory, or other object of honourable ambition;
20703 he will not spend his money in the contest for glory; so afraid is he of
20704 awakening his expensive appetites and inviting them to help and join in
20705 the struggle; in true oligarchical fashion he fights with a small part
20706 only of his resources, and the result commonly is that he loses the
20707 prize and saves his money.
20708 
20709 Very true.
20710 
20711 Can we any longer doubt, then, that the miser and money-maker answers to
20712 the oligarchical State?
20713 
20714 There can be no doubt.
20715 
20716 Next comes democracy; of this the origin and nature have still to
20717 be considered by us; and then we will enquire into the ways of the
20718 democratic man, and bring him up for judgment.
20719 
20720 That, he said, is our method.
20721 
20722 Well, I said, and how does the change from oligarchy into democracy
20723 arise? Is it not on this wise?--The good at which such a State aims is
20724 to become as rich as possible, a desire which is insatiable?
20725 
20726 What then?
20727 
20728 The rulers, being aware that their power rests upon their wealth, refuse
20729 to curtail by law the extravagance of the spendthrift youth because
20730 they gain by their ruin; they take interest from them and buy up their
20731 estates and thus increase their own wealth and importance?
20732 
20733 To be sure.
20734 
20735 There can be no doubt that the love of wealth and the spirit of
20736 moderation cannot exist together in citizens of the same state to any
20737 considerable extent; one or the other will be disregarded.
20738 
20739 That is tolerably clear.
20740 
20741 And in oligarchical States, from the general spread of carelessness and
20742 extravagance, men of good family have often been reduced to beggary?
20743 
20744 Yes, often.
20745 
20746 And still they remain in the city; there they are, ready to sting and
20747 fully armed, and some of them owe money, some have forfeited their
20748 citizenship; a third class are in both predicaments; and they hate
20749 and conspire against those who have got their property, and against
20750 everybody else, and are eager for revolution.
20751 
20752 That is true.
20753 
20754 On the other hand, the men of business, stooping as they walk, and
20755 pretending not even to see those whom they have already ruined, insert
20756 their sting--that is, their money--into some one else who is not on
20757 his guard against them, and recover the parent sum many times over
20758 multiplied into a family of children: and so they make drone and pauper
20759 to abound in the State.
20760 
20761 Yes, he said, there are plenty of them--that is certain.
20762 
20763 The evil blazes up like a fire; and they will not extinguish it, either
20764 by restricting a man's use of his own property, or by another remedy:
20765 
20766 What other?
20767 
20768 One which is the next best, and has the advantage of compelling the
20769 citizens to look to their characters:--Let there be a general rule that
20770 every one shall enter into voluntary contracts at his own risk, and
20771 there will be less of this scandalous money-making, and the evils of
20772 which we were speaking will be greatly lessened in the State.
20773 
20774 Yes, they will be greatly lessened.
20775 
20776 At present the governors, induced by the motives which I have named,
20777 treat their subjects badly; while they and their adherents, especially
20778 the young men of the governing class, are habituated to lead a life
20779 of luxury and idleness both of body and mind; they do nothing, and are
20780 incapable of resisting either pleasure or pain.
20781 
20782 Very true.
20783 
20784 They themselves care only for making money, and are as indifferent as
20785 the pauper to the cultivation of virtue.
20786 
20787 Yes, quite as indifferent.
20788 
20789 Such is the state of affairs which prevails among them. And often rulers
20790 and their subjects may come in one another's way, whether on a journey
20791 or on some other occasion of meeting, on a pilgrimage or a march,
20792 as fellow-soldiers or fellow-sailors; aye and they may observe the
20793 behaviour of each other in the very moment of danger--for where danger
20794 is, there is no fear that the poor will be despised by the rich--and
20795 very likely the wiry sunburnt poor man may be placed in battle at the
20796 side of a wealthy one who has never spoilt his complexion and has
20797 plenty of superfluous flesh--when he sees such an one puffing and at his
20798 wits'-end, how can he avoid drawing the conclusion that men like him are
20799 only rich because no one has the courage to despoil them? And when they
20800 meet in private will not people be saying to one another 'Our warriors
20801 are not good for much'?
20802 
20803 Yes, he said, I am quite aware that this is their way of talking.
20804 
20805 And, as in a body which is diseased the addition of a touch from without
20806 may bring on illness, and sometimes even when there is no external
20807 provocation a commotion may arise within--in the same way wherever there
20808 is weakness in the State there is also likely to be illness, of which
20809 the occasion may be very slight, the one party introducing from without
20810 their oligarchical, the other their democratical allies, and then
20811 the State falls sick, and is at war with herself; and may be at times
20812 distracted, even when there is no external cause.
20813 
20814 Yes, surely.
20815 
20816 And then democracy comes into being after the poor have conquered their
20817 opponents, slaughtering some and banishing some, while to the remainder
20818 they give an equal share of freedom and power; and this is the form of
20819 government in which the magistrates are commonly elected by lot.
20820 
20821 Yes, he said, that is the nature of democracy, whether the revolution
20822 has been effected by arms, or whether fear has caused the opposite party
20823 to withdraw.
20824 
20825 And now what is their manner of life, and what sort of a government have
20826 they? for as the government is, such will be the man.
20827 
20828 Clearly, he said.
20829 
20830 In the first place, are they not free; and is not the city full of
20831 freedom and frankness--a man may say and do what he likes?
20832 
20833 'Tis said so, he replied.
20834 
20835 And where freedom is, the individual is clearly able to order for
20836 himself his own life as he pleases?
20837 
20838 Clearly.
20839 
20840 Then in this kind of State there will be the greatest variety of human
20841 natures?
20842 
20843 There will.
20844 
20845 This, then, seems likely to be the fairest of States, being like an
20846 embroidered robe which is spangled with every sort of flower. And just
20847 as women and children think a variety of colours to be of all things
20848 most charming, so there are many men to whom this State, which is
20849 spangled with the manners and characters of mankind, will appear to be
20850 the fairest of States.
20851 
20852 Yes.
20853 
20854 Yes, my good Sir, and there will be no better in which to look for a
20855 government.
20856 
20857 Why?
20858 
20859 Because of the liberty which reigns there--they have a complete
20860 assortment of constitutions; and he who has a mind to establish a State,
20861 as we have been doing, must go to a democracy as he would to a bazaar at
20862 which they sell them, and pick out the one that suits him; then, when he
20863 has made his choice, he may found his State.
20864 
20865 He will be sure to have patterns enough.
20866 
20867 And there being no necessity, I said, for you to govern in this State,
20868 even if you have the capacity, or to be governed, unless you like, or
20869 go to war when the rest go to war, or to be at peace when others are
20870 at peace, unless you are so disposed--there being no necessity also,
20871 because some law forbids you to hold office or be a dicast, that you
20872 should not hold office or be a dicast, if you have a fancy--is not this
20873 a way of life which for the moment is supremely delightful?
20874 
20875 For the moment, yes.
20876 
20877 And is not their humanity to the condemned in some cases quite charming?
20878 Have you not observed how, in a democracy, many persons, although they
20879 have been sentenced to death or exile, just stay where they are and walk
20880 about the world--the gentleman parades like a hero, and nobody sees or
20881 cares?
20882 
20883 Yes, he replied, many and many a one.
20884 
20885 See too, I said, the forgiving spirit of democracy, and the 'don't
20886 care' about trifles, and the disregard which she shows of all the fine
20887 principles which we solemnly laid down at the foundation of the city--as
20888 when we said that, except in the case of some rarely gifted nature,
20889 there never will be a good man who has not from his childhood been used
20890 to play amid things of beauty and make of them a joy and a study--how
20891 grandly does she trample all these fine notions of ours under her feet,
20892 never giving a thought to the pursuits which make a statesman, and
20893 promoting to honour any one who professes to be the people's friend.
20894 
20895 Yes, she is of a noble spirit.
20896 
20897 These and other kindred characteristics are proper to democracy, which
20898 is a charming form of government, full of variety and disorder, and
20899 dispensing a sort of equality to equals and unequals alike.
20900 
20901 We know her well.
20902 
20903 Consider now, I said, what manner of man the individual is, or rather
20904 consider, as in the case of the State, how he comes into being.
20905 
20906 Very good, he said.
20907 
20908 Is not this the way--he is the son of the miserly and oligarchical
20909 father who has trained him in his own habits?
20910 
20911 Exactly.
20912 
20913 And, like his father, he keeps under by force the pleasures which are of
20914 the spending and not of the getting sort, being those which are called
20915 unnecessary?
20916 
20917 Obviously.
20918 
20919 Would you like, for the sake of clearness, to distinguish which are the
20920 necessary and which are the unnecessary pleasures?
20921 
20922 I should.
20923 
20924 Are not necessary pleasures those of which we cannot get rid, and of
20925 which the satisfaction is a benefit to us? And they are rightly called
20926 so, because we are framed by nature to desire both what is beneficial
20927 and what is necessary, and cannot help it.
20928 
20929 True.
20930 
20931 We are not wrong therefore in calling them necessary?
20932 
20933 We are not.
20934 
20935 And the desires of which a man may get rid, if he takes pains from his
20936 youth upwards--of which the presence, moreover, does no good, and in
20937 some cases the reverse of good--shall we not be right in saying that all
20938 these are unnecessary?
20939 
20940 Yes, certainly.
20941 
20942 Suppose we select an example of either kind, in order that we may have a
20943 general notion of them?
20944 
20945 Very good.
20946 
20947 Will not the desire of eating, that is, of simple food and condiments,
20948 in so far as they are required for health and strength, be of the
20949 necessary class?
20950 
20951 That is what I should suppose.
20952 
20953 The pleasure of eating is necessary in two ways; it does us good and it
20954 is essential to the continuance of life?
20955 
20956 Yes.
20957 
20958 But the condiments are only necessary in so far as they are good for
20959 health?
20960 
20961 Certainly.
20962 
20963 And the desire which goes beyond this, of more delicate food, or other
20964 luxuries, which might generally be got rid of, if controlled and trained
20965 in youth, and is hurtful to the body, and hurtful to the soul in the
20966 pursuit of wisdom and virtue, may be rightly called unnecessary?
20967 
20968 Very true.
20969 
20970 May we not say that these desires spend, and that the others make money
20971 because they conduce to production?
20972 
20973 Certainly.
20974 
20975 And of the pleasures of love, and all other pleasures, the same holds
20976 good?
20977 
20978 True.
20979 
20980 And the drone of whom we spoke was he who was surfeited in pleasures
20981 and desires of this sort, and was the slave of the unnecessary desires,
20982 whereas he who was subject to the necessary only was miserly and
20983 oligarchical?
20984 
20985 Very true.
20986 
20987 Again, let us see how the democratical man grows out of the
20988 oligarchical: the following, as I suspect, is commonly the process.
20989 
20990 What is the process?
20991 
20992 When a young man who has been brought up as we were just now describing,
20993 in a vulgar and miserly way, has tasted drones' honey and has come to
20994 associate with fierce and crafty natures who are able to provide for
20995 him all sorts of refinements and varieties of pleasure--then, as you may
20996 imagine, the change will begin of the oligarchical principle within him
20997 into the democratical?
20998 
20999 Inevitably.
21000 
21001 And as in the city like was helping like, and the change was effected by
21002 an alliance from without assisting one division of the citizens, so too
21003 the young man is changed by a class of desires coming from without
21004 to assist the desires within him, that which is akin and alike again
21005 helping that which is akin and alike?
21006 
21007 Certainly.
21008 
21009 And if there be any ally which aids the oligarchical principle within
21010 him, whether the influence of a father or of kindred, advising or
21011 rebuking him, then there arises in his soul a faction and an opposite
21012 faction, and he goes to war with himself.
21013 
21014 It must be so.
21015 
21016 And there are times when the democratical principle gives way to the
21017 oligarchical, and some of his desires die, and others are banished;
21018 a spirit of reverence enters into the young man's soul and order is
21019 restored.
21020 
21021 Yes, he said, that sometimes happens.
21022 
21023 And then, again, after the old desires have been driven out, fresh ones
21024 spring up, which are akin to them, and because he their father does not
21025 know how to educate them, wax fierce and numerous.
21026 
21027 Yes, he said, that is apt to be the way.
21028 
21029 They draw him to his old associates, and holding secret intercourse with
21030 them, breed and multiply in him.
21031 
21032 Very true.
21033 
21034 At length they seize upon the citadel of the young man's soul, which
21035 they perceive to be void of all accomplishments and fair pursuits and
21036 true words, which make their abode in the minds of men who are dear to
21037 the gods, and are their best guardians and sentinels.
21038 
21039 None better.
21040 
21041 False and boastful conceits and phrases mount upwards and take their
21042 place.
21043 
21044 They are certain to do so.
21045 
21046 And so the young man returns into the country of the lotus-eaters, and
21047 takes up his dwelling there in the face of all men; and if any help be
21048 sent by his friends to the oligarchical part of him, the aforesaid vain
21049 conceits shut the gate of the king's fastness; and they will neither
21050 allow the embassy itself to enter, nor if private advisers offer the
21051 fatherly counsel of the aged will they listen to them or receive them.
21052 There is a battle and they gain the day, and then modesty, which
21053 they call silliness, is ignominiously thrust into exile by them, and
21054 temperance, which they nickname unmanliness, is trampled in the mire and
21055 cast forth; they persuade men that moderation and orderly expenditure
21056 are vulgarity and meanness, and so, by the help of a rabble of evil
21057 appetites, they drive them beyond the border.
21058 
21059 Yes, with a will.
21060 
21061 And when they have emptied and swept clean the soul of him who is now in
21062 their power and who is being initiated by them in great mysteries, the
21063 next thing is to bring back to their house insolence and anarchy and
21064 waste and impudence in bright array having garlands on their heads, and
21065 a great company with them, hymning their praises and calling them by
