21066 sweet names; insolence they term breeding, and anarchy liberty, and
21067 waste magnificence, and impudence courage. And so the young man
21068 passes out of his original nature, which was trained in the school of
21069 necessity, into the freedom and libertinism of useless and unnecessary
21070 pleasures.
21071 
21072 Yes, he said, the change in him is visible enough.
21073 
21074 After this he lives on, spending his money and labour and time on
21075 unnecessary pleasures quite as much as on necessary ones; but if he be
21076 fortunate, and is not too much disordered in his wits, when years have
21077 elapsed, and the heyday of passion is over--supposing that he then
21078 re-admits into the city some part of the exiled virtues, and does not
21079 wholly give himself up to their successors--in that case he balances his
21080 pleasures and lives in a sort of equilibrium, putting the government of
21081 himself into the hands of the one which comes first and wins the turn;
21082 and when he has had enough of that, then into the hands of another; he
21083 despises none of them but encourages them all equally.
21084 
21085 Very true, he said.
21086 
21087 Neither does he receive or let pass into the fortress any true word of
21088 advice; if any one says to him that some pleasures are the satisfactions
21089 of good and noble desires, and others of evil desires, and that he ought
21090 to use and honour some and chastise and master the others--whenever this
21091 is repeated to him he shakes his head and says that they are all alike,
21092 and that one is as good as another.
21093 
21094 Yes, he said; that is the way with him.
21095 
21096 Yes, I said, he lives from day to day indulging the appetite of the
21097 hour; and sometimes he is lapped in drink and strains of the flute; then
21098 he becomes a water-drinker, and tries to get thin; then he takes a turn
21099 at gymnastics; sometimes idling and neglecting everything, then once
21100 more living the life of a philosopher; often he is busy with politics,
21101 and starts to his feet and says and does whatever comes into his head;
21102 and, if he is emulous of any one who is a warrior, off he is in that
21103 direction, or of men of business, once more in that. His life has
21104 neither law nor order; and this distracted existence he terms joy and
21105 bliss and freedom; and so he goes on.
21106 
21107 Yes, he replied, he is all liberty and equality.
21108 
21109 Yes, I said; his life is motley and manifold and an epitome of the
21110 lives of many;--he answers to the State which we described as fair
21111 and spangled. And many a man and many a woman will take him for their
21112 pattern, and many a constitution and many an example of manners is
21113 contained in him.
21114 
21115 Just so.
21116 
21117 Let him then be set over against democracy; he may truly be called the
21118 democratic man.
21119 
21120 Let that be his place, he said.
21121 
21122 Last of all comes the most beautiful of all, man and State alike,
21123 tyranny and the tyrant; these we have now to consider.
21124 
21125 Quite true, he said.
21126 
21127 Say then, my friend, In what manner does tyranny arise?--that it has a
21128 democratic origin is evident.
21129 
21130 Clearly.
21131 
21132 And does not tyranny spring from democracy in the same manner as
21133 democracy from oligarchy--I mean, after a sort?
21134 
21135 How?
21136 
21137 The good which oligarchy proposed to itself and the means by which it
21138 was maintained was excess of wealth--am I not right?
21139 
21140 Yes.
21141 
21142 And the insatiable desire of wealth and the neglect of all other things
21143 for the sake of money-getting was also the ruin of oligarchy?
21144 
21145 True.
21146 
21147 And democracy has her own good, of which the insatiable desire brings
21148 her to dissolution?
21149 
21150 What good?
21151 
21152 Freedom, I replied; which, as they tell you in a democracy, is the glory
21153 of the State--and that therefore in a democracy alone will the freeman
21154 of nature deign to dwell.
21155 
21156 Yes; the saying is in every body's mouth.
21157 
21158 I was going to observe, that the insatiable desire of this and the
21159 neglect of other things introduces the change in democracy, which
21160 occasions a demand for tyranny.
21161 
21162 How so?
21163 
21164 When a democracy which is thirsting for freedom has evil cup-bearers
21165 presiding over the feast, and has drunk too deeply of the strong wine of
21166 freedom, then, unless her rulers are very amenable and give a plentiful
21167 draught, she calls them to account and punishes them, and says that they
21168 are cursed oligarchs.
21169 
21170 Yes, he replied, a very common occurrence.
21171 
21172 Yes, I said; and loyal citizens are insultingly termed by her slaves who
21173 hug their chains and men of naught; she would have subjects who are like
21174 rulers, and rulers who are like subjects: these are men after her own
21175 heart, whom she praises and honours both in private and public. Now, in
21176 such a State, can liberty have any limit?
21177 
21178 Certainly not.
21179 
21180 By degrees the anarchy finds a way into private houses, and ends by
21181 getting among the animals and infecting them.
21182 
21183 How do you mean?
21184 
21185 I mean that the father grows accustomed to descend to the level of his
21186 sons and to fear them, and the son is on a level with his father, he
21187 having no respect or reverence for either of his parents; and this is
21188 his freedom, and the metic is equal with the citizen and the citizen
21189 with the metic, and the stranger is quite as good as either.
21190 
21191 Yes, he said, that is the way.
21192 
21193 And these are not the only evils, I said--there are several lesser ones:
21194 In such a state of society the master fears and flatters his scholars,
21195 and the scholars despise their masters and tutors; young and old are
21196 all alike; and the young man is on a level with the old, and is ready
21197 to compete with him in word or deed; and old men condescend to the
21198 young and are full of pleasantry and gaiety; they are loth to be thought
21199 morose and authoritative, and therefore they adopt the manners of the
21200 young.
21201 
21202 Quite true, he said.
21203 
21204 The last extreme of popular liberty is when the slave bought with money,
21205 whether male or female, is just as free as his or her purchaser; nor
21206 must I forget to tell of the liberty and equality of the two sexes in
21207 relation to each other.
21208 
21209 Why not, as Aeschylus says, utter the word which rises to our lips?
21210 
21211 That is what I am doing, I replied; and I must add that no one who
21212 does not know would believe, how much greater is the liberty which the
21213 animals who are under the dominion of man have in a democracy than in
21214 any other State: for truly, the she-dogs, as the proverb says, are as
21215 good as their she-mistresses, and the horses and asses have a way of
21216 marching along with all the rights and dignities of freemen; and they
21217 will run at any body who comes in their way if he does not leave
21218 the road clear for them: and all things are just ready to burst with
21219 liberty.
21220 
21221 When I take a country walk, he said, I often experience what you
21222 describe. You and I have dreamed the same thing.
21223 
21224 And above all, I said, and as the result of all, see how sensitive the
21225 citizens become; they chafe impatiently at the least touch of authority,
21226 and at length, as you know, they cease to care even for the laws,
21227 written or unwritten; they will have no one over them.
21228 
21229 Yes, he said, I know it too well.
21230 
21231 Such, my friend, I said, is the fair and glorious beginning out of which
21232 springs tyranny.
21233 
21234 Glorious indeed, he said. But what is the next step?
21235 
21236 The ruin of oligarchy is the ruin of democracy; the same disease
21237 magnified and intensified by liberty overmasters democracy--the truth
21238 being that the excessive increase of anything often causes a reaction in
21239 the opposite direction; and this is the case not only in the seasons and
21240 in vegetable and animal life, but above all in forms of government.
21241 
21242 True.
21243 
21244 The excess of liberty, whether in States or individuals, seems only to
21245 pass into excess of slavery.
21246 
21247 Yes, the natural order.
21248 
21249 And so tyranny naturally arises out of democracy, and the most
21250 aggravated form of tyranny and slavery out of the most extreme form of
21251 liberty?
21252 
21253 As we might expect.
21254 
21255 That, however, was not, as I believe, your question--you rather desired
21256 to know what is that disorder which is generated alike in oligarchy and
21257 democracy, and is the ruin of both?
21258 
21259 Just so, he replied.
21260 
21261 Well, I said, I meant to refer to the class of idle spendthrifts,
21262 of whom the more courageous are the leaders and the more timid the
21263 followers, the same whom we were comparing to drones, some stingless,
21264 and others having stings.
21265 
21266 A very just comparison.
21267 
21268 These two classes are the plagues of every city in which they are
21269 generated, being what phlegm and bile are to the body. And the good
21270 physician and lawgiver of the State ought, like the wise bee-master, to
21271 keep them at a distance and prevent, if possible, their ever coming in;
21272 and if they have anyhow found a way in, then he should have them and
21273 their cells cut out as speedily as possible.
21274 
21275 Yes, by all means, he said.
21276 
21277 Then, in order that we may see clearly what we are doing, let us imagine
21278 democracy to be divided, as indeed it is, into three classes; for in the
21279 first place freedom creates rather more drones in the democratic than
21280 there were in the oligarchical State.
21281 
21282 That is true.
21283 
21284 And in the democracy they are certainly more intensified.
21285 
21286 How so?
21287 
21288 Because in the oligarchical State they are disqualified and driven from
21289 office, and therefore they cannot train or gather strength; whereas in a
21290 democracy they are almost the entire ruling power, and while the keener
21291 sort speak and act, the rest keep buzzing about the bema and do not
21292 suffer a word to be said on the other side; hence in democracies almost
21293 everything is managed by the drones.
21294 
21295 Very true, he said.
21296 
21297 Then there is another class which is always being severed from the mass.
21298 
21299 What is that?
21300 
21301 They are the orderly class, which in a nation of traders is sure to be
21302 the richest.
21303 
21304 Naturally so.
21305 
21306 They are the most squeezable persons and yield the largest amount of
21307 honey to the drones.
21308 
21309 Why, he said, there is little to be squeezed out of people who have
21310 little.
21311 
21312 And this is called the wealthy class, and the drones feed upon them.
21313 
21314 That is pretty much the case, he said.
21315 
21316 The people are a third class, consisting of those who work with their
21317 own hands; they are not politicians, and have not much to live upon.
21318 This, when assembled, is the largest and most powerful class in a
21319 democracy.
21320 
21321 True, he said; but then the multitude is seldom willing to congregate
21322 unless they get a little honey.
21323 
21324 And do they not share? I said. Do not their leaders deprive the rich
21325 of their estates and distribute them among the people; at the same time
21326 taking care to reserve the larger part for themselves?
21327 
21328 Why, yes, he said, to that extent the people do share.
21329 
21330 And the persons whose property is taken from them are compelled to
21331 defend themselves before the people as they best can?
21332 
21333 What else can they do?
21334 
21335 And then, although they may have no desire of change, the others charge
21336 them with plotting against the people and being friends of oligarchy?
21337 
21338 True.
21339 
21340 And the end is that when they see the people, not of their own accord,
21341 but through ignorance, and because they are deceived by informers,
21342 seeking to do them wrong, then at last they are forced to become
21343 oligarchs in reality; they do not wish to be, but the sting of the
21344 drones torments them and breeds revolution in them.
21345 
21346 That is exactly the truth.
21347 
21348 Then come impeachments and judgments and trials of one another.
21349 
21350 True.
21351 
21352 The people have always some champion whom they set over them and nurse
21353 into greatness.
21354 
21355 Yes, that is their way.
21356 
21357 This and no other is the root from which a tyrant springs; when he first
21358 appears above ground he is a protector.
21359 
21360 Yes, that is quite clear.
21361 
21362 How then does a protector begin to change into a tyrant? Clearly when
21363 he does what the man is said to do in the tale of the Arcadian temple of
21364 Lycaean Zeus.
21365 
21366 What tale?
21367 
21368 The tale is that he who has tasted the entrails of a single human victim
21369 minced up with the entrails of other victims is destined to become a
21370 wolf. Did you never hear it?
21371 
21372 Oh, yes.
21373 
21374 And the protector of the people is like him; having a mob entirely at
21375 his disposal, he is not restrained from shedding the blood of kinsmen;
21376 by the favourite method of false accusation he brings them into court
21377 and murders them, making the life of man to disappear, and with unholy
21378 tongue and lips tasting the blood of his fellow citizens; some he kills
21379 and others he banishes, at the same time hinting at the abolition of
21380 debts and partition of lands: and after this, what will be his destiny?
21381 Must he not either perish at the hands of his enemies, or from being a
21382 man become a wolf--that is, a tyrant?
21383 
21384 Inevitably.
21385 
21386 This, I said, is he who begins to make a party against the rich?
21387 
21388 The same.
21389 
21390 After a while he is driven out, but comes back, in spite of his enemies,
21391 a tyrant full grown.
21392 
21393 That is clear.
21394 
21395 And if they are unable to expel him, or to get him condemned to death by
21396 a public accusation, they conspire to assassinate him.
21397 
21398 Yes, he said, that is their usual way.
21399 
21400 Then comes the famous request for a body-guard, which is the device of
21401 all those who have got thus far in their tyrannical career--'Let not the
21402 people's friend,' as they say, 'be lost to them.'
21403 
21404 Exactly.
21405 
21406 The people readily assent; all their fears are for him--they have none
21407 for themselves.
21408 
21409 Very true.
21410 
21411 And when a man who is wealthy and is also accused of being an enemy of
21412 the people sees this, then, my friend, as the oracle said to Croesus,
21413 
21414 'By pebbly Hermus' shore he flees and rests not, and is not ashamed to
21415 be a coward.'
21416 
21417 And quite right too, said he, for if he were, he would never be ashamed
21418 again.
21419 
21420 But if he is caught he dies.
21421 
21422 Of course.
21423 
21424 And he, the protector of whom we spoke, is to be seen, not 'larding the
21425 plain' with his bulk, but himself the overthrower of many, standing up
21426 in the chariot of State with the reins in his hand, no longer protector,
21427 but tyrant absolute.
21428 
21429 No doubt, he said.
21430 
21431 And now let us consider the happiness of the man, and also of the State
21432 in which a creature like him is generated.
21433 
21434 Yes, he said, let us consider that.
21435 
21436 At first, in the early days of his power, he is full of smiles, and
21437 he salutes every one whom he meets;--he to be called a tyrant, who is
21438 making promises in public and also in private! liberating debtors, and
21439 distributing land to the people and his followers, and wanting to be so
21440 kind and good to every one!
21441 
21442 Of course, he said.
21443 
21444 But when he has disposed of foreign enemies by conquest or treaty, and
21445 there is nothing to fear from them, then he is always stirring up some
21446 war or other, in order that the people may require a leader.
21447 
21448 To be sure.
21449 
21450 Has he not also another object, which is that they may be impoverished
21451 by payment of taxes, and thus compelled to devote themselves to their
21452 daily wants and therefore less likely to conspire against him?
21453 
21454 Clearly.
21455 
21456 And if any of them are suspected by him of having notions of freedom,
21457 and of resistance to his authority, he will have a good pretext for
21458 destroying them by placing them at the mercy of the enemy; and for all
21459 these reasons the tyrant must be always getting up a war.
21460 
21461 He must.
21462 
21463 Now he begins to grow unpopular.
21464 
21465 A necessary result.
21466 
21467 Then some of those who joined in setting him up, and who are in power,
21468 speak their minds to him and to one another, and the more courageous of
21469 them cast in his teeth what is being done.
21470 
21471 Yes, that may be expected.
21472 
21473 And the tyrant, if he means to rule, must get rid of them; he cannot
21474 stop while he has a friend or an enemy who is good for anything.
21475 
21476 He cannot.
21477 
21478 And therefore he must look about him and see who is valiant, who is
21479 high-minded, who is wise, who is wealthy; happy man, he is the enemy
21480 of them all, and must seek occasion against them whether he will or no,
21481 until he has made a purgation of the State.
21482 
21483 Yes, he said, and a rare purgation.
21484 
21485 Yes, I said, not the sort of purgation which the physicians make of the
21486 body; for they take away the worse and leave the better part, but he
21487 does the reverse.
21488 
21489 If he is to rule, I suppose that he cannot help himself.
21490 
21491 What a blessed alternative, I said:--to be compelled to dwell only with
21492 the many bad, and to be by them hated, or not to live at all!
21493 
21494 Yes, that is the alternative.
21495 
21496 And the more detestable his actions are to the citizens the more
21497 satellites and the greater devotion in them will he require?
21498 
21499 Certainly.
21500 
21501 And who are the devoted band, and where will he procure them?
21502 
21503 They will flock to him, he said, of their own accord, if he pays them.
21504 
21505 By the dog! I said, here are more drones, of every sort and from every
21506 land.
21507 
21508 Yes, he said, there are.
21509 
21510 But will he not desire to get them on the spot?
21511 
21512 How do you mean?
21513 
21514 He will rob the citizens of their slaves; he will then set them free and
21515 enrol them in his body-guard.
21516 
21517 To be sure, he said; and he will be able to trust them best of all.
21518 
21519 What a blessed creature, I said, must this tyrant be; he has put to
21520 death the others and has these for his trusted friends.
21521 
21522 Yes, he said; they are quite of his sort.
21523 
21524 Yes, I said, and these are the new citizens whom he has called into
21525 existence, who admire him and are his companions, while the good hate
21526 and avoid him.
21527 
21528 Of course.
21529 
21530 Verily, then, tragedy is a wise thing and Euripides a great tragedian.
21531 
21532 Why so?
21533 
21534 Why, because he is the author of the pregnant saying,
21535 
21536 'Tyrants are wise by living with the wise;'
21537 
21538 and he clearly meant to say that they are the wise whom the tyrant makes
21539 his companions.
21540 
21541 Yes, he said, and he also praises tyranny as godlike; and many other
21542 things of the same kind are said by him and by the other poets.
21543 
21544 And therefore, I said, the tragic poets being wise men will forgive us
21545 and any others who live after our manner if we do not receive them into
21546 our State, because they are the eulogists of tyranny.
21547 
21548 Yes, he said, those who have the wit will doubtless forgive us.
21549 
21550 But they will continue to go to other cities and attract mobs, and
21551 hire voices fair and loud and persuasive, and draw the cities over to
21552 tyrannies and democracies.
21553 
21554 Very true.
21555 
21556 Moreover, they are paid for this and receive honour--the greatest
21557 honour, as might be expected, from tyrants, and the next greatest from
21558 democracies; but the higher they ascend our constitution hill, the more
21559 their reputation fails, and seems unable from shortness of breath to
21560 proceed further.
21561 
21562 True.
21563 
21564 But we are wandering from the subject: Let us therefore return and
21565 enquire how the tyrant will maintain that fair and numerous and various
21566 and ever-changing army of his.
21567 
21568 If, he said, there are sacred treasures in the city, he will confiscate
21569 and spend them; and in so far as the fortunes of attainted persons may
21570 suffice, he will be able to diminish the taxes which he would otherwise
21571 have to impose upon the people.
21572 
21573 And when these fail?
21574 
21575 Why, clearly, he said, then he and his boon companions, whether male or
21576 female, will be maintained out of his father's estate.
21577 
21578 You mean to say that the people, from whom he has derived his being,
21579 will maintain him and his companions?
21580 
21581 Yes, he said; they cannot help themselves.
21582 
21583 But what if the people fly into a passion, and aver that a grown-up son
21584 ought not to be supported by his father, but that the father should be
21585 supported by the son? The father did not bring him into being, or settle
21586 him in life, in order that when his son became a man he should himself
21587 be the servant of his own servants and should support him and his rabble
21588 of slaves and companions; but that his son should protect him, and that
21589 by his help he might be emancipated from the government of the rich and
21590 aristocratic, as they are termed. And so he bids him and his companions
21591 depart, just as any other father might drive out of the house a riotous
21592 son and his undesirable associates.
21593 
21594 By heaven, he said, then the parent will discover what a monster he has
21595 been fostering in his bosom; and, when he wants to drive him out, he
21596 will find that he is weak and his son strong.
21597 
21598 Why, you do not mean to say that the tyrant will use violence? What!
21599 beat his father if he opposes him?
21600 
21601 Yes, he will, having first disarmed him.
21602 
21603 Then he is a parricide, and a cruel guardian of an aged parent; and this
21604 is real tyranny, about which there can be no longer a mistake: as the
21605 saying is, the people who would escape the smoke which is the slavery of
21606 freemen, has fallen into the fire which is the tyranny of slaves. Thus
21607 liberty, getting out of all order and reason, passes into the harshest
21608 and bitterest form of slavery.
21609 
21610 True, he said.
21611 
21612 Very well; and may we not rightly say that we have sufficiently
21613 discussed the nature of tyranny, and the manner of the transition from
21614 democracy to tyranny?
21615 
21616 Yes, quite enough, he said.
21617 
21618 
21619 
21620 
21621 BOOK IX.
21622 
21623 Last of all comes the tyrannical man; about whom we have once more to
21624 ask, how is he formed out of the democratical? and how does he live, in
21625 happiness or in misery?
21626 
21627 Yes, he said, he is the only one remaining.
21628 
21629 There is, however, I said, a previous question which remains unanswered.
21630 
21631 What question?
21632 
21633 I do not think that we have adequately determined the nature and number
21634 of the appetites, and until this is accomplished the enquiry will always
21635 be confused.
21636 
21637 Well, he said, it is not too late to supply the omission.
21638 
21639 Very true, I said; and observe the point which I want to understand:
21640 Certain of the unnecessary pleasures and appetites I conceive to be
21641 unlawful; every one appears to have them, but in some persons they are
21642 controlled by the laws and by reason, and the better desires prevail
21643 over them--either they are wholly banished or they become few and weak;
21644 while in the case of others they are stronger, and there are more of
21645 them.
21646 
21647 Which appetites do you mean?
21648 
21649 I mean those which are awake when the reasoning and human and ruling
21650 power is asleep; then the wild beast within us, gorged with meat or
21651 drink, starts up and having shaken off sleep, goes forth to satisfy
21652 his desires; and there is no conceivable folly or crime--not excepting
21653 incest or any other unnatural union, or parricide, or the eating of
21654 forbidden food--which at such a time, when he has parted company with
21655 all shame and sense, a man may not be ready to commit.
21656 
21657 Most true, he said.
21658 
21659 But when a man's pulse is healthy and temperate, and when before going
21660 to sleep he has awakened his rational powers, and fed them on noble
21661 thoughts and enquiries, collecting himself in meditation; after having
21662 first indulged his appetites neither too much nor too little, but just
21663 enough to lay them to sleep, and prevent them and their enjoyments and
21664 pains from interfering with the higher principle--which he leaves in
21665 the solitude of pure abstraction, free to contemplate and aspire to
21666 the knowledge of the unknown, whether in past, present, or future: when
21667 again he has allayed the passionate element, if he has a quarrel against
21668 any one--I say, when, after pacifying the two irrational principles, he
21669 rouses up the third, which is reason, before he takes his rest, then,
21670 as you know, he attains truth most nearly, and is least likely to be the
21671 sport of fantastic and lawless visions.
21672 
21673 I quite agree.
21674 
21675 In saying this I have been running into a digression; but the point
21676 which I desire to note is that in all of us, even in good men, there is
21677 a lawless wild-beast nature, which peers out in sleep. Pray, consider
21678 whether I am right, and you agree with me.
21679 
21680 Yes, I agree.
21681 
21682 And now remember the character which we attributed to the democratic
21683 man. He was supposed from his youth upwards to have been trained under
21684 a miserly parent, who encouraged the saving appetites in him, but
21685 discountenanced the unnecessary, which aim only at amusement and
21686 ornament?
21687 
21688 True.
21689 
21690 And then he got into the company of a more refined, licentious sort of
21691 people, and taking to all their wanton ways rushed into the opposite
21692 extreme from an abhorrence of his father's meanness. At last, being a
21693 better man than his corruptors, he was drawn in both directions until he
21694 halted midway and led a life, not of vulgar and slavish passion, but
21695 of what he deemed moderate indulgence in various pleasures. After this
21696 manner the democrat was generated out of the oligarch?
21697 
21698 Yes, he said; that was our view of him, and is so still.
21699 
21700 And now, I said, years will have passed away, and you must conceive this
21701 man, such as he is, to have a son, who is brought up in his father's
21702 principles.
21703 
21704 I can imagine him.
21705 
21706 Then you must further imagine the same thing to happen to the son
21707 which has already happened to the father:--he is drawn into a perfectly
21708 lawless life, which by his seducers is termed perfect liberty; and his
21709 father and friends take part with his moderate desires, and the opposite
21710 party assist the opposite ones. As soon as these dire magicians and
21711 tyrant-makers find that they are losing their hold on him, they contrive
21712 to implant in him a master passion, to be lord over his idle and
21713 spendthrift lusts--a sort of monstrous winged drone--that is the only
21714 image which will adequately describe him.
21715 
21716 Yes, he said, that is the only adequate image of him.
21717 
21718 And when his other lusts, amid clouds of incense and perfumes and
21719 garlands and wines, and all the pleasures of a dissolute life, now let
21720 loose, come buzzing around him, nourishing to the utmost the sting of
21721 desire which they implant in his drone-like nature, then at last this
21722 lord of the soul, having Madness for the captain of his guard, breaks
21723 out into a frenzy: and if he finds in himself any good opinions or
21724 appetites in process of formation, and there is in him any sense of
21725 shame remaining, to these better principles he puts an end, and casts
21726 them forth until he has purged away temperance and brought in madness to
21727 the full.
21728 
21729 Yes, he said, that is the way in which the tyrannical man is generated.
21730 
21731 And is not this the reason why of old love has been called a tyrant?
21732 
21733 I should not wonder.
21734 
21735 Further, I said, has not a drunken man also the spirit of a tyrant?
21736 
21737 He has.
21738 
21739 And you know that a man who is deranged and not right in his mind, will
21740 fancy that he is able to rule, not only over men, but also over the
21741 gods?
21742 
21743 That he will.
21744 
21745 And the tyrannical man in the true sense of the word comes into being
21746 when, either under the influence of nature, or habit, or both, he
21747 becomes drunken, lustful, passionate? O my friend, is not that so?
21748 
21749 Assuredly.
21750 
21751 Such is the man and such is his origin. And next, how does he live?
21752 
21753 Suppose, as people facetiously say, you were to tell me.
21754 
21755 I imagine, I said, at the next step in his progress, that there will be
21756 feasts and carousals and revellings and courtezans, and all that sort
21757 of thing; Love is the lord of the house within him, and orders all the
21758 concerns of his soul.
21759 
21760 That is certain.
21761 
21762 Yes; and every day and every night desires grow up many and formidable,
21763 and their demands are many.
21764 
21765 They are indeed, he said.
21766 
21767 His revenues, if he has any, are soon spent.
21768 
21769 True.
21770 
21771 Then comes debt and the cutting down of his property.
21772 
21773 Of course.
21774 
21775 When he has nothing left, must not his desires, crowding in the nest
21776 like young ravens, be crying aloud for food; and he, goaded on by them,
21777 and especially by love himself, who is in a manner the captain of them,
21778 is in a frenzy, and would fain discover whom he can defraud or despoil
21779 of his property, in order that he may gratify them?
21780 
21781 Yes, that is sure to be the case.
21782 
21783 He must have money, no matter how, if he is to escape horrid pains and
21784 pangs.
21785 
21786 He must.
21787 
21788 And as in himself there was a succession of pleasures, and the new got
21789 the better of the old and took away their rights, so he being younger
21790 will claim to have more than his father and his mother, and if he has
21791 spent his own share of the property, he will take a slice of theirs.
21792 
21793 No doubt he will.
21794 
21795 And if his parents will not give way, then he will try first of all to
21796 cheat and deceive them.
21797 
21798 Very true.
21799 
21800 And if he fails, then he will use force and plunder them.
21801 
21802 Yes, probably.
21803 
21804 And if the old man and woman fight for their own, what then, my friend?
21805 Will the creature feel any compunction at tyrannizing over them?
21806 
21807 Nay, he said, I should not feel at all comfortable about his parents.
21808 
21809 But, O heavens! Adeimantus, on account of some new-fangled love of a
21810 harlot, who is anything but a necessary connection, can you believe that
21811 he would strike the mother who is his ancient friend and necessary
21812 to his very existence, and would place her under the authority of the
21813 other, when she is brought under the same roof with her; or that, under
21814 like circumstances, he would do the same to his withered old father,
21815 first and most indispensable of friends, for the sake of some
21816 newly-found blooming youth who is the reverse of indispensable?
21817 
21818 Yes, indeed, he said; I believe that he would.
21819 
21820 Truly, then, I said, a tyrannical son is a blessing to his father and
21821 mother.
21822 
21823 He is indeed, he replied.
21824 
21825 He first takes their property, and when that fails, and pleasures are
21826 beginning to swarm in the hive of his soul, then he breaks into a house,
21827 or steals the garments of some nightly wayfarer; next he proceeds to
21828 clear a temple. Meanwhile the old opinions which he had when a child,
21829 and which gave judgment about good and evil, are overthrown by those
21830 others which have just been emancipated, and are now the body-guard of
21831 love and share his empire. These in his democratic days, when he was
21832 still subject to the laws and to his father, were only let loose in
21833 the dreams of sleep. But now that he is under the dominion of love, he
21834 becomes always and in waking reality what he was then very rarely and in
21835 a dream only; he will commit the foulest murder, or eat forbidden food,
21836 or be guilty of any other horrid act. Love is his tyrant, and lives
21837 lordly in him and lawlessly, and being himself a king, leads him on, as
21838 a tyrant leads a State, to the performance of any reckless deed by which
21839 he can maintain himself and the rabble of his associates, whether those
21840 whom evil communications have brought in from without, or those whom
21841 he himself has allowed to break loose within him by reason of a similar
21842 evil nature in himself. Have we not here a picture of his way of life?
21843 
21844 Yes, indeed, he said.
21845 
21846 And if there are only a few of them in the State, and the rest of the
21847 people are well disposed, they go away and become the body-guard or
21848 mercenary soldiers of some other tyrant who may probably want them for a
21849 war; and if there is no war, they stay at home and do many little pieces
21850 of mischief in the city.
21851 
21852 What sort of mischief?
21853 
21854 For example, they are the thieves, burglars, cut-purses, foot-pads,
21855 robbers of temples, man-stealers of the community; or if they are able
21856 to speak they turn informers, and bear false witness, and take bribes.
21857 
21858 A small catalogue of evils, even if the perpetrators of them are few in
21859 number.
21860 
21861 Yes, I said; but small and great are comparative terms, and all these
21862 things, in the misery and evil which they inflict upon a State, do not
21863 come within a thousand miles of the tyrant; when this noxious class and
21864 their followers grow numerous and become conscious of their strength,
21865 assisted by the infatuation of the people, they choose from among
21866 themselves the one who has most of the tyrant in his own soul, and him
21867 they create their tyrant.
21868 
21869 Yes, he said, and he will be the most fit to be a tyrant.
21870 
21871 If the people yield, well and good; but if they resist him, as he began
21872 by beating his own father and mother, so now, if he has the power, he
21873 beats them, and will keep his dear old fatherland or motherland, as the
21874 Cretans say, in subjection to his young retainers whom he has introduced
21875 to be their rulers and masters. This is the end of his passions and
21876 desires.
21877 
21878 Exactly.
21879 
21880 When such men are only private individuals and before they get power,
21881 this is their character; they associate entirely with their own
21882 flatterers or ready tools; or if they want anything from anybody, they
21883 in their turn are equally ready to bow down before them: they profess
21884 every sort of affection for them; but when they have gained their point
21885 they know them no more.
21886 
21887 Yes, truly.
21888 
21889 They are always either the masters or servants and never the friends of
21890 anybody; the tyrant never tastes of true freedom or friendship.
21891 
21892 Certainly not.
21893 
21894 And may we not rightly call such men treacherous?
21895 
21896 No question.
21897 
21898 Also they are utterly unjust, if we were right in our notion of justice?
21899 
21900 Yes, he said, and we were perfectly right.
21901 
21902 Let us then sum up in a word, I said, the character of the worst man: he
21903 is the waking reality of what we dreamed.
21904 
21905 Most true.
21906 
21907 And this is he who being by nature most of a tyrant bears rule, and the
21908 longer he lives the more of a tyrant he becomes.
21909 
21910 That is certain, said Glaucon, taking his turn to answer.
21911 
21912 And will not he who has been shown to be the wickedest, be also the most
21913 miserable? and he who has tyrannized longest and most, most continually
21914 and truly miserable; although this may not be the opinion of men in
21915 general?
21916 
21917 Yes, he said, inevitably.
21918 
21919 And must not the tyrannical man be like the tyrannical State, and
21920 the democratical man like the democratical State; and the same of the
21921 others?
21922 
21923 Certainly.
21924 
21925 And as State is to State in virtue and happiness, so is man in relation
21926 to man?
21927 
21928 To be sure.
21929 
21930 Then comparing our original city, which was under a king, and the city
21931 which is under a tyrant, how do they stand as to virtue?
21932 
21933 They are the opposite extremes, he said, for one is the very best and
21934 the other is the very worst.
21935 
21936 There can be no mistake, I said, as to which is which, and therefore
21937 I will at once enquire whether you would arrive at a similar decision
21938 about their relative happiness and misery. And here we must not allow
21939 ourselves to be panic-stricken at the apparition of the tyrant, who is
21940 only a unit and may perhaps have a few retainers about him; but let us
21941 go as we ought into every corner of the city and look all about, and
21942 then we will give our opinion.
21943 
21944 A fair invitation, he replied; and I see, as every one must, that a
21945 tyranny is the wretchedest form of government, and the rule of a king
21946 the happiest.
21947 
21948 And in estimating the men too, may I not fairly make a like request,
21949 that I should have a judge whose mind can enter into and see through
21950 human nature? he must not be like a child who looks at the outside and
21951 is dazzled at the pompous aspect which the tyrannical nature assumes to
21952 the beholder, but let him be one who has a clear insight. May I suppose
21953 that the judgment is given in the hearing of us all by one who is able
21954 to judge, and has dwelt in the same place with him, and been present at
21955 his dally life and known him in his family relations, where he may be
21956 seen stripped of his tragedy attire, and again in the hour of public
21957 danger--he shall tell us about the happiness and misery of the tyrant
21958 when compared with other men?
21959 
21960 That again, he said, is a very fair proposal.
21961 
21962 Shall I assume that we ourselves are able and experienced judges and
21963 have before now met with such a person? We shall then have some one who
21964 will answer our enquiries.
21965 
21966 By all means.
21967 
21968 Let me ask you not to forget the parallel of the individual and the
21969 State; bearing this in mind, and glancing in turn from one to the other
21970 of them, will you tell me their respective conditions?
21971 
21972 What do you mean? he asked.
21973 
21974 Beginning with the State, I replied, would you say that a city which is
21975 governed by a tyrant is free or enslaved?
21976 
21977 No city, he said, can be more completely enslaved.
21978 
21979 And yet, as you see, there are freemen as well as masters in such a
21980 State?
21981 
21982 Yes, he said, I see that there are--a few; but the people, speaking
21983 generally, and the best of them are miserably degraded and enslaved.
21984 
21985 Then if the man is like the State, I said, must not the same rule
21986 prevail? his soul is full of meanness and vulgarity--the best elements
21987 in him are enslaved; and there is a small ruling part, which is also the
21988 worst and maddest.
21989 
21990 Inevitably.
21991 
21992 And would you say that the soul of such an one is the soul of a freeman,
21993 or of a slave?
21994 
21995 He has the soul of a slave, in my opinion.
21996 
21997 And the State which is enslaved under a tyrant is utterly incapable of
21998 acting voluntarily?
21999 
22000 Utterly incapable.
22001 
22002 And also the soul which is under a tyrant (I am speaking of the soul
22003 taken as a whole) is least capable of doing what she desires; there is a
22004 gadfly which goads her, and she is full of trouble and remorse?
22005 
22006 Certainly.
22007 
22008 And is the city which is under a tyrant rich or poor?
22009 
22010 Poor.
22011 
22012 And the tyrannical soul must be always poor and insatiable?
22013 
22014 True.
22015 
22016 And must not such a State and such a man be always full of fear?
22017 
22018 Yes, indeed.
22019 
22020 Is there any State in which you will find more of lamentation and sorrow
22021 and groaning and pain?
22022 
22023 Certainly not.
22024 
22025 And is there any man in whom you will find more of this sort of misery
22026 than in the tyrannical man, who is in a fury of passions and desires?
22027 
22028 Impossible.
22029 
22030 Reflecting upon these and similar evils, you held the tyrannical State
22031 to be the most miserable of States?
22032 
22033 And I was right, he said.
22034 
22035 Certainly, I said. And when you see the same evils in the tyrannical
22036 man, what do you say of him?
22037 
22038 I say that he is by far the most miserable of all men.
22039 
22040 There, I said, I think that you are beginning to go wrong.
22041 
22042 What do you mean?
22043 
22044 I do not think that he has as yet reached the utmost extreme of misery.
22045 
22046 Then who is more miserable?
22047 
22048 One of whom I am about to speak.
22049 
22050 Who is that?
22051 
22052 He who is of a tyrannical nature, and instead of leading a private life
22053 has been cursed with the further misfortune of being a public tyrant.
22054 
22055 From what has been said, I gather that you are right.
22056 
22057 Yes, I replied, but in this high argument you should be a little more
22058 certain, and should not conjecture only; for of all questions, this
22059 respecting good and evil is the greatest.
22060 
22061 Very true, he said.
22062 
22063 Let me then offer you an illustration, which may, I think, throw a light
22064 upon this subject.
22065 
22066 What is your illustration?
22067 
22068 The case of rich individuals in cities who possess many slaves: from
22069 them you may form an idea of the tyrant's condition, for they both have
22070 slaves; the only difference is that he has more slaves.
22071 
22072 Yes, that is the difference.
22073 
22074 You know that they live securely and have nothing to apprehend from
22075 their servants?
22076 
22077 What should they fear?
22078 
22079 Nothing. But do you observe the reason of this?
22080 
22081 Yes; the reason is, that the whole city is leagued together for the
22082 protection of each individual.
22083 
22084 Very true, I said. But imagine one of these owners, the master say of
22085 some fifty slaves, together with his family and property and slaves,
22086 carried off by a god into the wilderness, where there are no freemen to
22087 help him--will he not be in an agony of fear lest he and his wife and
22088 children should be put to death by his slaves?
22089 
22090 Yes, he said, he will be in the utmost fear.
22091 
22092 The time has arrived when he will be compelled to flatter divers of his
22093 slaves, and make many promises to them of freedom and other things, much
22094 against his will--he will have to cajole his own servants.
22095 
22096 Yes, he said, that will be the only way of saving himself.
22097 
22098 And suppose the same god, who carried him away, to surround him with
22099 neighbours who will not suffer one man to be the master of another, and
22100 who, if they could catch the offender, would take his life?
22101 
22102 His case will be still worse, if you suppose him to be everywhere
22103 surrounded and watched by enemies.
22104 
22105 And is not this the sort of prison in which the tyrant will be bound--he
22106 who being by nature such as we have described, is full of all sorts of
22107 fears and lusts? His soul is dainty and greedy, and yet alone, of all
22108 men in the city, he is never allowed to go on a journey, or to see the
22109 things which other freemen desire to see, but he lives in his hole like
22110 a woman hidden in the house, and is jealous of any other citizen who
22111 goes into foreign parts and sees anything of interest.
22112 
22113 Very true, he said.
22114 
22115 And amid evils such as these will not he who is ill-governed in his own
22116 person--the tyrannical man, I mean--whom you just now decided to be the
22117 most miserable of all--will not he be yet more miserable when, instead
22118 of leading a private life, he is constrained by fortune to be a public
22119 tyrant? He has to be master of others when he is not master of himself:
22120 he is like a diseased or paralytic man who is compelled to pass his
22121 life, not in retirement, but fighting and combating with other men.
22122 
22123 Yes, he said, the similitude is most exact.
22124 
22125 Is not his case utterly miserable? and does not the actual tyrant lead a
22126 worse life than he whose life you determined to be the worst?
22127 
22128 Certainly.
22129 
22130 He who is the real tyrant, whatever men may think, is the real slave,
22131 and is obliged to practise the greatest adulation and servility, and to
22132 be the flatterer of the vilest of mankind. He has desires which he is
22133 utterly unable to satisfy, and has more wants than any one, and is truly
22134 poor, if you know how to inspect the whole soul of him: all his life
22135 long he is beset with fear and is full of convulsions and distractions,
22136 even as the State which he resembles: and surely the resemblance holds?
22137 
22138 Very true, he said.
22139 
22140 Moreover, as we were saying before, he grows worse from having power: he
22141 becomes and is of necessity more jealous, more faithless, more unjust,
22142 more friendless, more impious, than he was at first; he is the purveyor
22143 and cherisher of every sort of vice, and the consequence is that he is
22144 supremely miserable, and that he makes everybody else as miserable as
22145 himself.
22146 
22147 No man of any sense will dispute your words.
22148 
22149 Come then, I said, and as the general umpire in theatrical contests
22150 proclaims the result, do you also decide who in your opinion is first
22151 in the scale of happiness, and who second, and in what order the others
22152 follow: there are five of them in all--they are the royal, timocratical,
22153 oligarchical, democratical, tyrannical.
22154 
22155 The decision will be easily given, he replied; they shall be choruses
22156 coming on the stage, and I must judge them in the order in which they
22157 enter, by the criterion of virtue and vice, happiness and misery.
22158 
22159 Need we hire a herald, or shall I announce, that the son of Ariston (the
22160 best) has decided that the best and justest is also the happiest, and
22161 that this is he who is the most royal man and king over himself; and
22162 that the worst and most unjust man is also the most miserable, and that
22163 this is he who being the greatest tyrant of himself is also the greatest
22164 tyrant of his State?
22165 
22166 Make the proclamation yourself, he said.
22167 
22168 And shall I add, 'whether seen or unseen by gods and men'?
22169 
22170 Let the words be added.
22171 
22172 Then this, I said, will be our first proof; and there is another, which
22173 may also have some weight.
22174 
22175 What is that?
22176 
22177 The second proof is derived from the nature of the soul: seeing that
22178 the individual soul, like the State, has been divided by us into three
22179 principles, the division may, I think, furnish a new demonstration.
22180 
22181 Of what nature?
22182 
22183 It seems to me that to these three principles three pleasures
22184 correspond; also three desires and governing powers.
22185 
22186 How do you mean? he said.
22187 
22188 There is one principle with which, as we were saying, a man learns,
22189 another with which he is angry; the third, having many forms, has no
22190 special name, but is denoted by the general term appetitive, from
22191 the extraordinary strength and vehemence of the desires of eating and
22192 drinking and the other sensual appetites which are the main elements of
22193 it; also money-loving, because such desires are generally satisfied by
22194 the help of money.
22195 
22196 That is true, he said.
22197 
22198 If we were to say that the loves and pleasures of this third part were
22199 concerned with gain, we should then be able to fall back on a single
22200 notion; and might truly and intelligibly describe this part of the soul
22201 as loving gain or money.
22202 
22203 I agree with you.
22204 
22205 Again, is not the passionate element wholly set on ruling and conquering
22206 and getting fame?
22207 
22208 True.
22209 
22210 Suppose we call it the contentious or ambitious--would the term be
22211 suitable?
22212 
22213 Extremely suitable.
22214 
22215 On the other hand, every one sees that the principle of knowledge is
22216 wholly directed to the truth, and cares less than either of the others
22217 for gain or fame.
22218 
22219 Far less.
22220 
22221 'Lover of wisdom,' 'lover of knowledge,' are titles which we may fitly
22222 apply to that part of the soul?
22223 
22224 Certainly.
22225 
22226 One principle prevails in the souls of one class of men, another in
22227 others, as may happen?
22228 
22229 Yes.
22230 
22231 Then we may begin by assuming that there are three classes of
22232 men--lovers of wisdom, lovers of honour, lovers of gain?
22233 
22234 Exactly.
22235 
22236 And there are three kinds of pleasure, which are their several objects?
22237 
22238 Very true.
22239 
22240 Now, if you examine the three classes of men, and ask of them in turn
22241 which of their lives is pleasantest, each will be found praising his
22242 own and depreciating that of others: the money-maker will contrast the
22243 vanity of honour or of learning if they bring no money with the solid
22244 advantages of gold and silver?
22245 
22246 True, he said.
22247 
22248 And the lover of honour--what will be his opinion? Will he not think
22249 that the pleasure of riches is vulgar, while the pleasure of learning,
22250 if it brings no distinction, is all smoke and nonsense to him?
22251 
22252 Very true.
22253 
22254 And are we to suppose, I said, that the philosopher sets any value on
22255 other pleasures in comparison with the pleasure of knowing the truth,
22256 and in that pursuit abiding, ever learning, not so far indeed from the
22257 heaven of pleasure? Does he not call the other pleasures necessary,
22258 under the idea that if there were no necessity for them, he would rather
22259 not have them?
22260 
22261 There can be no doubt of that, he replied.
22262 
22263 Since, then, the pleasures of each class and the life of each are in
22264 dispute, and the question is not which life is more or less honourable,
22265 or better or worse, but which is the more pleasant or painless--how
22266 shall we know who speaks truly?
22267 
22268 I cannot myself tell, he said.
22269 
22270 Well, but what ought to be the criterion? Is any better than experience
22271 and wisdom and reason?
22272 
22273 There cannot be a better, he said.
22274 
22275 Then, I said, reflect. Of the three individuals, which has the greatest
22276 experience of all the pleasures which we enumerated? Has the lover of
22277 gain, in learning the nature of essential truth, greater experience of
22278 the pleasure of knowledge than the philosopher has of the pleasure of
22279 gain?
22280 
22281 The philosopher, he replied, has greatly the advantage; for he has
22282 of necessity always known the taste of the other pleasures from his
22283 childhood upwards: but the lover of gain in all his experience has not
22284 of necessity tasted--or, I should rather say, even had he desired, could
22285 hardly have tasted--the sweetness of learning and knowing truth.
22286 
22287 Then the lover of wisdom has a great advantage over the lover of gain,
22288 for he has a double experience?
22289 
22290 Yes, very great.
22291 
22292 Again, has he greater experience of the pleasures of honour, or the
22293 lover of honour of the pleasures of wisdom?
22294 
22295 Nay, he said, all three are honoured in proportion as they attain their
22296 object; for the rich man and the brave man and the wise man alike have
22297 their crowd of admirers, and as they all receive honour they all have
22298 experience of the pleasures of honour; but the delight which is to be
22299 found in the knowledge of true being is known to the philosopher only.
22300 
22301 His experience, then, will enable him to judge better than any one?
22302 
22303 Far better.
22304 
22305 And he is the only one who has wisdom as well as experience?
22306 
22307 Certainly.
22308 
22309 Further, the very faculty which is the instrument of judgment is not
22310 possessed by the covetous or ambitious man, but only by the philosopher?
22311 
22312 What faculty?
22313 
22314 Reason, with whom, as we were saying, the decision ought to rest.
22315 
22316 Yes.
22317 
22318 And reasoning is peculiarly his instrument?
22319 
22320 Certainly.
22321 
22322 If wealth and gain were the criterion, then the praise or blame of the
22323 lover of gain would surely be the most trustworthy?
22324 
22325 Assuredly.
22326 
22327 Or if honour or victory or courage, in that case the judgment of the
22328 ambitious or pugnacious would be the truest?
22329 
22330 Clearly.
22331 
22332 But since experience and wisdom and reason are the judges--
22333 
22334 The only inference possible, he replied, is that pleasures which are
22335 approved by the lover of wisdom and reason are the truest.
22336 
22337 And so we arrive at the result, that the pleasure of the intelligent
22338 part of the soul is the pleasantest of the three, and that he of us in
22339 whom this is the ruling principle has the pleasantest life.
22340 
22341 Unquestionably, he said, the wise man speaks with authority when he
22342 approves of his own life.
22343 
22344 And what does the judge affirm to be the life which is next, and the
22345 pleasure which is next?
22346 
22347 Clearly that of the soldier and lover of honour; who is nearer to
22348 himself than the money-maker.
22349 
22350 Last comes the lover of gain?
22351 
22352 Very true, he said.
22353 
22354 Twice in succession, then, has the just man overthrown the unjust in
22355 this conflict; and now comes the third trial, which is dedicated to
22356 Olympian Zeus the saviour: a sage whispers in my ear that no pleasure
22357 except that of the wise is quite true and pure--all others are a shadow
22358 only; and surely this will prove the greatest and most decisive of
22359 falls?
22360 
22361 Yes, the greatest; but will you explain yourself?
22362 
22363 I will work out the subject and you shall answer my questions.
22364 
22365 Proceed.
22366 
22367 Say, then, is not pleasure opposed to pain?
22368 
22369 True.
22370 
22371 And there is a neutral state which is neither pleasure nor pain?
22372 
22373 There is.
22374 
22375 A state which is intermediate, and a sort of repose of the soul about
22376 either--that is what you mean?
22377 
22378 Yes.
22379 
22380 You remember what people say when they are sick?
22381 
22382 What do they say?
22383 
22384 That after all nothing is pleasanter than health. But then they never
22385 knew this to be the greatest of pleasures until they were ill.
22386 
22387 Yes, I know, he said.
22388 
22389 And when persons are suffering from acute pain, you must have heard them
22390 say that there is nothing pleasanter than to get rid of their pain?
22391 
22392 I have.
22393 
22394 And there are many other cases of suffering in which the mere rest and
22395 cessation of pain, and not any positive enjoyment, is extolled by them
22396 as the greatest pleasure?
22397 
22398 Yes, he said; at the time they are pleased and well content to be at
22399 rest.
22400 
22401 Again, when pleasure ceases, that sort of rest or cessation will be
22402 painful?
22403 
22404 Doubtless, he said.
22405 
22406 Then the intermediate state of rest will be pleasure and will also be
22407 pain?
22408 
22409 So it would seem.
22410 
22411 But can that which is neither become both?
22412 
22413 I should say not.
22414 
22415 And both pleasure and pain are motions of the soul, are they not?
22416 
22417 Yes.
22418 
22419 But that which is neither was just now shown to be rest and not motion,
22420 and in a mean between them?
22421 
22422 Yes.
22423 
22424 How, then, can we be right in supposing that the absence of pain is
22425 pleasure, or that the absence of pleasure is pain?
22426 
22427 Impossible.
22428 
22429 This then is an appearance only and not a reality; that is to say, the
22430 rest is pleasure at the moment and in comparison of what is painful,
22431 and painful in comparison of what is pleasant; but all these
22432 representations, when tried by the test of true pleasure, are not real
22433 but a sort of imposition?
22434 
22435 That is the inference.
22436 
22437 Look at the other class of pleasures which have no antecedent pains and
22438 you will no longer suppose, as you perhaps may at present, that pleasure
22439 is only the cessation of pain, or pain of pleasure.
22440 
22441 What are they, he said, and where shall I find them?
22442 
22443 There are many of them: take as an example the pleasures of smell, which
22444 are very great and have no antecedent pains; they come in a moment, and
22445 when they depart leave no pain behind them.
22446 
22447 Most true, he said.
22448 
22449 Let us not, then, be induced to believe that pure pleasure is the
22450 cessation of pain, or pain of pleasure.
22451 
22452 No.
22453 
22454 Still, the more numerous and violent pleasures which reach the soul
22455 through the body are generally of this sort--they are reliefs of pain.
22456 
22457 That is true.
22458 
22459 And the anticipations of future pleasures and pains are of a like
22460 nature?
22461 
22462 Yes.
22463 
22464 Shall I give you an illustration of them?
22465 
22466 Let me hear.
22467 
22468 You would allow, I said, that there is in nature an upper and lower and
22469 middle region?
22470 
22471 I should.
22472 
22473 And if a person were to go from the lower to the middle region, would
22474 he not imagine that he is going up; and he who is standing in the middle
22475 and sees whence he has come, would imagine that he is already in the
22476 upper region, if he has never seen the true upper world?
22477 
22478 To be sure, he said; how can he think otherwise?
22479 
22480 But if he were taken back again he would imagine, and truly imagine,
22481 that he was descending?
22482 
22483 No doubt.
22484 
22485 All that would arise out of his ignorance of the true upper and middle
22486 and lower regions?
22487 
22488 Yes.
22489 
22490 Then can you wonder that persons who are inexperienced in the truth, as
22491 they have wrong ideas about many other things, should also have wrong
22492 ideas about pleasure and pain and the intermediate state; so that when
22493 they are only being drawn towards the painful they feel pain and think
22494 the pain which they experience to be real, and in like manner, when
22495 drawn away from pain to the neutral or intermediate state, they firmly
22496 believe that they have reached the goal of satiety and pleasure; they,
22497 not knowing pleasure, err in contrasting pain with the absence of pain,
22498 which is like contrasting black with grey instead of white--can you
22499 wonder, I say, at this?
22500 
22501 No, indeed; I should be much more disposed to wonder at the opposite.
22502 
22503 Look at the matter thus:--Hunger, thirst, and the like, are inanitions
22504 of the bodily state?
22505 
22506 Yes.
22507 
22508 And ignorance and folly are inanitions of the soul?
22509 
22510 True.
22511 
22512 And food and wisdom are the corresponding satisfactions of either?
22513 
22514 Certainly.
22515 
22516 And is the satisfaction derived from that which has less or from that
22517 which has more existence the truer?
22518 
22519 Clearly, from that which has more.
22520 
22521 What classes of things have a greater share of pure existence in your
22522 judgment--those of which food and drink and condiments and all kinds of
22523 sustenance are examples, or the class which contains true opinion
22524 and knowledge and mind and all the different kinds of virtue? Put
22525 the question in this way:--Which has a more pure being--that which is
22526 concerned with the invariable, the immortal, and the true, and is of
22527 such a nature, and is found in such natures; or that which is concerned
22528 with and found in the variable and mortal, and is itself variable and
22529 mortal?
22530 
22531 Far purer, he replied, is the being of that which is concerned with the
22532 invariable.
22533 
22534 And does the essence of the invariable partake of knowledge in the same
22535 degree as of essence?
22536 
22537 Yes, of knowledge in the same degree.
22538 
22539 And of truth in the same degree?
22540 
22541 Yes.
22542 
22543 And, conversely, that which has less of truth will also have less of
22544 essence?
22545 
22546 Necessarily.
22547 
22548 Then, in general, those kinds of things which are in the service of the
22549 body have less of truth and essence than those which are in the service
22550 of the soul?
22551 
22552 Far less.
22553 
22554 And has not the body itself less of truth and essence than the soul?
22555 
22556 Yes.
22557 
22558 What is filled with more real existence, and actually has a more real
22559 existence, is more really filled than that which is filled with less
22560 real existence and is less real?
22561 
22562 Of course.
22563 
22564 And if there be a pleasure in being filled with that which is according
22565 to nature, that which is more really filled with more real being
22566 will more really and truly enjoy true pleasure; whereas that which
22567 participates in less real being will be less truly and surely satisfied,
22568 and will participate in an illusory and less real pleasure?
22569 
22570 Unquestionably.
22571 
22572 Those then who know not wisdom and virtue, and are always busy with
22573 gluttony and sensuality, go down and up again as far as the mean; and
22574 in this region they move at random throughout life, but they never pass
22575 into the true upper world; thither they neither look, nor do they ever
22576 find their way, neither are they truly filled with true being, nor do
22577 they taste of pure and abiding pleasure. Like cattle, with their eyes
22578 always looking down and their heads stooping to the earth, that is,
22579 to the dining-table, they fatten and feed and breed, and, in their
22580 excessive love of these delights, they kick and butt at one another with
22581 horns and hoofs which are made of iron; and they kill one another by
22582 reason of their insatiable lust. For they fill themselves with that
22583 which is not substantial, and the part of themselves which they fill is
22584 also unsubstantial and incontinent.
22585 
22586 Verily, Socrates, said Glaucon, you describe the life of the many like
22587 an oracle.
22588 
22589 Their pleasures are mixed with pains--how can they be otherwise? For
22590 they are mere shadows and pictures of the true, and are coloured by
22591 contrast, which exaggerates both light and shade, and so they implant
22592 in the minds of fools insane desires of themselves; and they are fought
22593 about as Stesichorus says that the Greeks fought about the shadow of
22594 Helen at Troy in ignorance of the truth.
22595 
22596 Something of that sort must inevitably happen.
22597 
22598 And must not the like happen with the spirited or passionate element
22599 of the soul? Will not the passionate man who carries his passion into
22600 action, be in the like case, whether he is envious and ambitious, or
22601 violent and contentious, or angry and discontented, if he be seeking
22602 to attain honour and victory and the satisfaction of his anger without
22603 reason or sense?
22604 
22605 Yes, he said, the same will happen with the spirited element also.
22606 
22607 Then may we not confidently assert that the lovers of money and honour,
22608 when they seek their pleasures under the guidance and in the company
22609 of reason and knowledge, and pursue after and win the pleasures which
22610 wisdom shows them, will also have the truest pleasures in the highest
22611 degree which is attainable to them, inasmuch as they follow truth; and
22612 they will have the pleasures which are natural to them, if that which is
22613 best for each one is also most natural to him?
22614 
22615 Yes, certainly; the best is the most natural.
22616 
22617 And when the whole soul follows the philosophical principle, and there
22618 is no division, the several parts are just, and do each of them their
22619 own business, and enjoy severally the best and truest pleasures of which
22620 they are capable?
22621 
22622 Exactly.
22623 
22624 But when either of the two other principles prevails, it fails in
22625 attaining its own pleasure, and compels the rest to pursue after a
22626 pleasure which is a shadow only and which is not their own?
22627 
22628 True.
22629 
22630 And the greater the interval which separates them from philosophy and
22631 reason, the more strange and illusive will be the pleasure?
22632 
22633 Yes.
22634 
22635 And is not that farthest from reason which is at the greatest distance
22636 from law and order?
22637 
22638 Clearly.
22639 
22640 And the lustful and tyrannical desires are, as we saw, at the greatest
22641 distance? Yes.
22642 
22643 And the royal and orderly desires are nearest?
22644 
22645 Yes.
22646 
22647 Then the tyrant will live at the greatest distance from true or natural
22648 pleasure, and the king at the least?
22649 
22650 Certainly.
22651 
22652 But if so, the tyrant will live most unpleasantly, and the king most
22653 pleasantly?
22654 
22655 Inevitably.
22656 
22657 Would you know the measure of the interval which separates them?
22658 
22659 Will you tell me?
22660 
22661 There appear to be three pleasures, one genuine and two spurious: now
22662 the transgression of the tyrant reaches a point beyond the spurious; he
22663 has run away from the region of law and reason, and taken up his abode
22664 with certain slave pleasures which are his satellites, and the measure
22665 of his inferiority can only be expressed in a figure.
22666 
22667 How do you mean?
22668 
22669 I assume, I said, that the tyrant is in the third place from the
22670 oligarch; the democrat was in the middle?
22671 
22672 Yes.
22673 
22674 And if there is truth in what has preceded, he will be wedded to an
22675 image of pleasure which is thrice removed as to truth from the pleasure
22676 of the oligarch?
22677 
22678 He will.
22679 
22680 And the oligarch is third from the royal; since we count as one royal
22681 and aristocratical?
22682 
22683 Yes, he is third.
22684 
22685 Then the tyrant is removed from true pleasure by the space of a number
22686 which is three times three?
22687 
22688 Manifestly.
22689 
22690 The shadow then of tyrannical pleasure determined by the number of
22691 length will be a plane figure.
22692 
22693 Certainly.
22694 
22695 And if you raise the power and make the plane a solid, there is no
22696 difficulty in seeing how vast is the interval by which the tyrant is
22697 parted from the king.
22698 
22699 Yes; the arithmetician will easily do the sum.
22700 
22701 Or if some person begins at the other end and measures the interval by
22702 which the king is parted from the tyrant in truth of pleasure, he will
22703 find him, when the multiplication is completed, living 729 times more
22704 pleasantly, and the tyrant more painfully by this same interval.
22705 
22706 What a wonderful calculation! And how enormous is the distance which
22707 separates the just from the unjust in regard to pleasure and pain!
22708 
22709 Yet a true calculation, I said, and a number which nearly concerns human
22710 life, if human beings are concerned with days and nights and months and
22711 years. (729 NEARLY equals the number of days and nights in the year.)
22712 
22713 Yes, he said, human life is certainly concerned with them.
22714 
22715 Then if the good and just man be thus superior in pleasure to the evil
22716 and unjust, his superiority will be infinitely greater in propriety of
22717 life and in beauty and virtue?
22718 
22719 Immeasurably greater.
22720 
22721 Well, I said, and now having arrived at this stage of the argument, we
22722 may revert to the words which brought us hither: Was not some one saying
22723 that injustice was a gain to the perfectly unjust who was reputed to be
22724 just?
22725 
22726 Yes, that was said.
22727 
22728 Now then, having determined the power and quality of justice and
22729 injustice, let us have a little conversation with him.
22730 
22731 What shall we say to him?
22732 
22733 Let us make an image of the soul, that he may have his own words
22734 presented before his eyes.
22735 
22736 Of what sort?
22737 
22738 An ideal image of the soul, like the composite creations of ancient
22739 mythology, such as the Chimera or Scylla or Cerberus, and there are many
22740 others in which two or more different natures are said to grow into one.
22741 
22742 There are said of have been such unions.
22743 
22744 Then do you now model the form of a multitudinous, many-headed monster,
22745 having a ring of heads of all manner of beasts, tame and wild, which he
22746 is able to generate and metamorphose at will.
22747 
22748 You suppose marvellous powers in the artist; but, as language is more
22749 pliable than wax or any similar substance, let there be such a model as
22750 you propose.
22751 
22752 Suppose now that you make a second form as of a lion, and a third of a
22753 man, the second smaller than the first, and the third smaller than the
22754 second.
22755 
22756 That, he said, is an easier task; and I have made them as you say.
22757 
22758 And now join them, and let the three grow into one.
22759 
22760 That has been accomplished.
22761 
22762 Next fashion the outside of them into a single image, as of a man, so
22763 that he who is not able to look within, and sees only the outer hull,
22764 may believe the beast to be a single human creature.
22765 
22766 I have done so, he said.
22767 
22768 And now, to him who maintains that it is profitable for the human
22769 creature to be unjust, and unprofitable to be just, let us reply
22770 that, if he be right, it is profitable for this creature to feast
22771 the multitudinous monster and strengthen the lion and the lion-like
22772 qualities, but to starve and weaken the man, who is consequently liable
22773 to be dragged about at the mercy of either of the other two; and he is
22774 not to attempt to familiarize or harmonize them with one another--he
22775 ought rather to suffer them to fight and bite and devour one another.
22776 
22777 Certainly, he said; that is what the approver of injustice says.
22778 
22779 To him the supporter of justice makes answer that he should ever so
22780 speak and act as to give the man within him in some way or other the
22781 most complete mastery over the entire human creature. He should watch
22782 over the many-headed monster like a good husbandman, fostering and
22783 cultivating the gentle qualities, and preventing the wild ones from
22784 growing; he should be making the lion-heart his ally, and in common care
22785 of them all should be uniting the several parts with one another and
22786 with himself.
22787 
22788 Yes, he said, that is quite what the maintainer of justice say.
22789 
22790 And so from every point of view, whether of pleasure, honour, or
22791 advantage, the approver of justice is right and speaks the truth, and
22792 the disapprover is wrong and false and ignorant?
22793 
22794 Yes, from every point of view.
22795 
22796 Come, now, and let us gently reason with the unjust, who is not
22797 intentionally in error. 'Sweet Sir,' we will say to him, 'what think
22798 you of things esteemed noble and ignoble? Is not the noble that which
22799 subjects the beast to the man, or rather to the god in man; and the
22800 ignoble that which subjects the man to the beast?' He can hardly avoid
22801 saying Yes--can he now?
22802 
22803 Not if he has any regard for my opinion.
22804 
22805 But, if he agree so far, we may ask him to answer another question:
22806 'Then how would a man profit if he received gold and silver on the
22807 condition that he was to enslave the noblest part of him to the worst?
22808 Who can imagine that a man who sold his son or daughter into slavery for
22809 money, especially if he sold them into the hands of fierce and evil men,
22810 would be the gainer, however large might be the sum which he
22811 received? And will any one say that he is not a miserable caitiff who
22812 remorselessly sells his own divine being to that which is most godless
22813 and detestable? Eriphyle took the necklace as the price of her husband's
22814 life, but he is taking a bribe in order to compass a worse ruin.'
22815 
22816 Yes, said Glaucon, far worse--I will answer for him.
22817 
22818 Has not the intemperate been censured of old, because in him the huge
22819 multiform monster is allowed to be too much at large?
22820 
22821 Clearly.
22822 
22823 And men are blamed for pride and bad temper when the lion and serpent
22824 element in them disproportionately grows and gains strength?
22825 
22826 Yes.
22827 
22828 And luxury and softness are blamed, because they relax and weaken this
22829 same creature, and make a coward of him?
22830 
22831 Very true.
22832 
22833 And is not a man reproached for flattery and meanness who subordinates
22834 the spirited animal to the unruly monster, and, for the sake of money,
22835 of which he can never have enough, habituates him in the days of his
22836 youth to be trampled in the mire, and from being a lion to become a
22837 monkey?
22838 
22839 True, he said.
22840 
22841 And why are mean employments and manual arts a reproach? Only because
22842 they imply a natural weakness of the higher principle; the individual is
22843 unable to control the creatures within him, but has to court them, and
22844 his great study is how to flatter them.
22845 
22846 Such appears to be the reason.
22847 
22848 And therefore, being desirous of placing him under a rule like that of
22849 the best, we say that he ought to be the servant of the best, in whom
22850 the Divine rules; not, as Thrasymachus supposed, to the injury of the
22851 servant, but because every one had better be ruled by divine wisdom
22852 dwelling within him; or, if this be impossible, then by an external
22853 authority, in order that we may be all, as far as possible, under the
22854 same government, friends and equals.
22855 
22856 True, he said.
22857 
22858 And this is clearly seen to be the intention of the law, which is the
22859 ally of the whole city; and is seen also in the authority which we
22860 exercise over children, and the refusal to let them be free until we
22861 have established in them a principle analogous to the constitution of
22862 a state, and by cultivation of this higher element have set up in their
22863 hearts a guardian and ruler like our own, and when this is done they may
22864 go their ways.
22865 
22866 Yes, he said, the purpose of the law is manifest.
22867 
22868 From what point of view, then, and on what ground can we say that a man
22869 is profited by injustice or intemperance or other baseness, which will
22870 make him a worse man, even though he acquire money or power by his
22871 wickedness?
22872 
22873 From no point of view at all.
22874 
22875 What shall he profit, if his injustice be undetected and unpunished?
22876 He who is undetected only gets worse, whereas he who is detected and
22877 punished has the brutal part of his nature silenced and humanized; the
22878 gentler element in him is liberated, and his whole soul is perfected and
22879 ennobled by the acquirement of justice and temperance and wisdom, more
22880 than the body ever is by receiving gifts of beauty, strength and health,
22881 in proportion as the soul is more honourable than the body.
22882 
22883 Certainly, he said.
22884 
22885 To this nobler purpose the man of understanding will devote the energies
22886 of his life. And in the first place, he will honour studies which
22887 impress these qualities on his soul and will disregard others?
22888 
22889 Clearly, he said.
22890 
22891 In the next place, he will regulate his bodily habit and training, and
22892 so far will he be from yielding to brutal and irrational pleasures, that
