22893 he will regard even health as quite a secondary matter; his first object
22894 will be not that he may be fair or strong or well, unless he is likely
22895 thereby to gain temperance, but he will always desire so to attemper the
22896 body as to preserve the harmony of the soul?
22897 
22898 Certainly he will, if he has true music in him.
22899 
22900 And in the acquisition of wealth there is a principle of order and
22901 harmony which he will also observe; he will not allow himself to be
22902 dazzled by the foolish applause of the world, and heap up riches to his
22903 own infinite harm?
22904 
22905 Certainly not, he said.
22906 
22907 He will look at the city which is within him, and take heed that no
22908 disorder occur in it, such as might arise either from superfluity or
22909 from want; and upon this principle he will regulate his property and
22910 gain or spend according to his means.
22911 
22912 Very true.
22913 
22914 And, for the same reason, he will gladly accept and enjoy such honours
22915 as he deems likely to make him a better man; but those, whether private
22916 or public, which are likely to disorder his life, he will avoid?
22917 
22918 Then, if that is his motive, he will not be a statesman.
22919 
22920 By the dog of Egypt, he will! in the city which is his own he certainly
22921 will, though in the land of his birth perhaps not, unless he have a
22922 divine call.
22923 
22924 I understand; you mean that he will be a ruler in the city of which we
22925 are the founders, and which exists in idea only; for I do not believe
22926 that there is such an one anywhere on earth?
22927 
22928 In heaven, I replied, there is laid up a pattern of it, methinks, which
22929 he who desires may behold, and beholding, may set his own house in
22930 order. But whether such an one exists, or ever will exist in fact, is no
22931 matter; for he will live after the manner of that city, having nothing
22932 to do with any other.
22933 
22934 I think so, he said.
22935 
22936 
22937 
22938 
22939 BOOK X.
22940 
22941 Of the many excellences which I perceive in the order of our State,
22942 there is none which upon reflection pleases me better than the rule
22943 about poetry.
22944 
22945 To what do you refer?
22946 
22947 To the rejection of imitative poetry, which certainly ought not to be
22948 received; as I see far more clearly now that the parts of the soul have
22949 been distinguished.
22950 
22951 What do you mean?
22952 
22953 Speaking in confidence, for I should not like to have my words repeated
22954 to the tragedians and the rest of the imitative tribe--but I do not
22955 mind saying to you, that all poetical imitations are ruinous to the
22956 understanding of the hearers, and that the knowledge of their true
22957 nature is the only antidote to them.
22958 
22959 Explain the purport of your remark.
22960 
22961 Well, I will tell you, although I have always from my earliest youth had
22962 an awe and love of Homer, which even now makes the words falter on
22963 my lips, for he is the great captain and teacher of the whole of that
22964 charming tragic company; but a man is not to be reverenced more than the
22965 truth, and therefore I will speak out.
22966 
22967 Very good, he said.
22968 
22969 Listen to me then, or rather, answer me.
22970 
22971 Put your question.
22972 
22973 Can you tell me what imitation is? for I really do not know.
22974 
22975 A likely thing, then, that I should know.
22976 
22977 Why not? for the duller eye may often see a thing sooner than the
22978 keener.
22979 
22980 Very true, he said; but in your presence, even if I had any faint
22981 notion, I could not muster courage to utter it. Will you enquire
22982 yourself?
22983 
22984 Well then, shall we begin the enquiry in our usual manner: Whenever a
22985 number of individuals have a common name, we assume them to have also a
22986 corresponding idea or form:--do you understand me?
22987 
22988 I do.
22989 
22990 Let us take any common instance; there are beds and tables in the
22991 world--plenty of them, are there not?
22992 
22993 Yes.
22994 
22995 But there are only two ideas or forms of them--one the idea of a bed,
22996 the other of a table.
22997 
22998 True.
22999 
23000 And the maker of either of them makes a bed or he makes a table for our
23001 use, in accordance with the idea--that is our way of speaking in this
23002 and similar instances--but no artificer makes the ideas themselves: how
23003 could he?
23004 
23005 Impossible.
23006 
23007 And there is another artist,--I should like to know what you would say
23008 of him.
23009 
23010 Who is he?
23011 
23012 One who is the maker of all the works of all other workmen.
23013 
23014 What an extraordinary man!
23015 
23016 Wait a little, and there will be more reason for your saying so. For
23017 this is he who is able to make not only vessels of every kind, but
23018 plants and animals, himself and all other things--the earth and heaven,
23019 and the things which are in heaven or under the earth; he makes the gods
23020 also.
23021 
23022 He must be a wizard and no mistake.
23023 
23024 Oh! you are incredulous, are you? Do you mean that there is no such
23025 maker or creator, or that in one sense there might be a maker of all
23026 these things but in another not? Do you see that there is a way in which
23027 you could make them all yourself?
23028 
23029 What way?
23030 
23031 An easy way enough; or rather, there are many ways in which the feat
23032 might be quickly and easily accomplished, none quicker than that of
23033 turning a mirror round and round--you would soon enough make the sun and
23034 the heavens, and the earth and yourself, and other animals and plants,
23035 and all the other things of which we were just now speaking, in the
23036 mirror.
23037 
23038 Yes, he said; but they would be appearances only.
23039 
23040 Very good, I said, you are coming to the point now. And the painter too
23041 is, as I conceive, just such another--a creator of appearances, is he
23042 not?
23043 
23044 Of course.
23045 
23046 But then I suppose you will say that what he creates is untrue. And yet
23047 there is a sense in which the painter also creates a bed?
23048 
23049 Yes, he said, but not a real bed.
23050 
23051 And what of the maker of the bed? were you not saying that he too makes,
23052 not the idea which, according to our view, is the essence of the bed,
23053 but only a particular bed?
23054 
23055 Yes, I did.
23056 
23057 Then if he does not make that which exists he cannot make true
23058 existence, but only some semblance of existence; and if any one were to
23059 say that the work of the maker of the bed, or of any other workman, has
23060 real existence, he could hardly be supposed to be speaking the truth.
23061 
23062 At any rate, he replied, philosophers would say that he was not speaking
23063 the truth.
23064 
23065 No wonder, then, that his work too is an indistinct expression of truth.
23066 
23067 No wonder.
23068 
23069 Suppose now that by the light of the examples just offered we enquire
23070 who this imitator is?
23071 
23072 If you please.
23073 
23074 Well then, here are three beds: one existing in nature, which is made by
23075 God, as I think that we may say--for no one else can be the maker?
23076 
23077 No.
23078 
23079 There is another which is the work of the carpenter?
23080 
23081 Yes.
23082 
23083 And the work of the painter is a third?
23084 
23085 Yes.
23086 
23087 Beds, then, are of three kinds, and there are three artists who
23088 superintend them: God, the maker of the bed, and the painter?
23089 
23090 Yes, there are three of them.
23091 
23092 God, whether from choice or from necessity, made one bed in nature and
23093 one only; two or more such ideal beds neither ever have been nor ever
23094 will be made by God.
23095 
23096 Why is that?
23097 
23098 Because even if He had made but two, a third would still appear behind
23099 them which both of them would have for their idea, and that would be the
23100 ideal bed and not the two others.
23101 
23102 Very true, he said.
23103 
23104 God knew this, and He desired to be the real maker of a real bed, not
23105 a particular maker of a particular bed, and therefore He created a bed
23106 which is essentially and by nature one only.
23107 
23108 So we believe.
23109 
23110 Shall we, then, speak of Him as the natural author or maker of the bed?
23111 
23112 Yes, he replied; inasmuch as by the natural process of creation He is
23113 the author of this and of all other things.
23114 
23115 And what shall we say of the carpenter--is not he also the maker of the
23116 bed?
23117 
23118 Yes.
23119 
23120 But would you call the painter a creator and maker?
23121 
23122 Certainly not.
23123 
23124 Yet if he is not the maker, what is he in relation to the bed?
23125 
23126 I think, he said, that we may fairly designate him as the imitator of
23127 that which the others make.
23128 
23129 Good, I said; then you call him who is third in the descent from nature
23130 an imitator?
23131 
23132 Certainly, he said.
23133 
23134 And the tragic poet is an imitator, and therefore, like all other
23135 imitators, he is thrice removed from the king and from the truth?
23136 
23137 That appears to be so.
23138 
23139 Then about the imitator we are agreed. And what about the painter?--I
23140 would like to know whether he may be thought to imitate that which
23141 originally exists in nature, or only the creations of artists?
23142 
23143 The latter.
23144 
23145 As they are or as they appear? you have still to determine this.
23146 
23147 What do you mean?
23148 
23149 I mean, that you may look at a bed from different points of view,
23150 obliquely or directly or from any other point of view, and the bed will
23151 appear different, but there is no difference in reality. And the same of
23152 all things.
23153 
23154 Yes, he said, the difference is only apparent.
23155 
23156 Now let me ask you another question: Which is the art of painting
23157 designed to be--an imitation of things as they are, or as they
23158 appear--of appearance or of reality?
23159 
23160 Of appearance.
23161 
23162 Then the imitator, I said, is a long way off the truth, and can do all
23163 things because he lightly touches on a small part of them, and that part
23164 an image. For example: A painter will paint a cobbler, carpenter, or
23165 any other artist, though he knows nothing of their arts; and, if he is
23166 a good artist, he may deceive children or simple persons, when he shows
23167 them his picture of a carpenter from a distance, and they will fancy
23168 that they are looking at a real carpenter.
23169 
23170 Certainly.
23171 
23172 And whenever any one informs us that he has found a man who knows all
23173 the arts, and all things else that anybody knows, and every single thing
23174 with a higher degree of accuracy than any other man--whoever tells us
23175 this, I think that we can only imagine him to be a simple creature who
23176 is likely to have been deceived by some wizard or actor whom he met, and
23177 whom he thought all-knowing, because he himself was unable to analyse
23178 the nature of knowledge and ignorance and imitation.
23179 
23180 Most true.
23181 
23182 And so, when we hear persons saying that the tragedians, and Homer, who
23183 is at their head, know all the arts and all things human, virtue as well
23184 as vice, and divine things too, for that the good poet cannot compose
23185 well unless he knows his subject, and that he who has not this knowledge
23186 can never be a poet, we ought to consider whether here also there may
23187 not be a similar illusion. Perhaps they may have come across imitators
23188 and been deceived by them; they may not have remembered when they saw
23189 their works that these were but imitations thrice removed from the
23190 truth, and could easily be made without any knowledge of the truth,
23191 because they are appearances only and not realities? Or, after all, they
23192 may be in the right, and poets do really know the things about which
23193 they seem to the many to speak so well?
23194 
23195 The question, he said, should by all means be considered.
23196 
23197 Now do you suppose that if a person were able to make the original as
23198 well as the image, he would seriously devote himself to the image-making
23199 branch? Would he allow imitation to be the ruling principle of his life,
23200 as if he had nothing higher in him?
23201 
23202 I should say not.
23203 
23204 The real artist, who knew what he was imitating, would be interested in
23205 realities and not in imitations; and would desire to leave as memorials
23206 of himself works many and fair; and, instead of being the author of
23207 encomiums, he would prefer to be the theme of them.
23208 
23209 Yes, he said, that would be to him a source of much greater honour and
23210 profit.
23211 
23212 Then, I said, we must put a question to Homer; not about medicine, or
23213 any of the arts to which his poems only incidentally refer: we are not
23214 going to ask him, or any other poet, whether he has cured patients
23215 like Asclepius, or left behind him a school of medicine such as the
23216 Asclepiads were, or whether he only talks about medicine and other arts
23217 at second-hand; but we have a right to know respecting military tactics,
23218 politics, education, which are the chiefest and noblest subjects of his
23219 poems, and we may fairly ask him about them. 'Friend Homer,' then we say
23220 to him, 'if you are only in the second remove from truth in what you say
23221 of virtue, and not in the third--not an image maker or imitator--and
23222 if you are able to discern what pursuits make men better or worse in
23223 private or public life, tell us what State was ever better governed by
23224 your help? The good order of Lacedaemon is due to Lycurgus, and many
23225 other cities great and small have been similarly benefited by others;
23226 but who says that you have been a good legislator to them and have done
23227 them any good? Italy and Sicily boast of Charondas, and there is Solon
23228 who is renowned among us; but what city has anything to say about you?'
23229 Is there any city which he might name?
23230 
23231 I think not, said Glaucon; not even the Homerids themselves pretend that
23232 he was a legislator.
23233 
23234 Well, but is there any war on record which was carried on successfully
23235 by him, or aided by his counsels, when he was alive?
23236 
23237 There is not.
23238 
23239 Or is there any invention of his, applicable to the arts or to human
23240 life, such as Thales the Milesian or Anacharsis the Scythian, and other
23241 ingenious men have conceived, which is attributed to him?
23242 
23243 There is absolutely nothing of the kind.
23244 
23245 But, if Homer never did any public service, was he privately a guide or
23246 teacher of any? Had he in his lifetime friends who loved to associate
23247 with him, and who handed down to posterity an Homeric way of life, such
23248 as was established by Pythagoras who was so greatly beloved for his
23249 wisdom, and whose followers are to this day quite celebrated for the
23250 order which was named after him?
23251 
23252 Nothing of the kind is recorded of him. For surely, Socrates,
23253 Creophylus, the companion of Homer, that child of flesh, whose name
23254 always makes us laugh, might be more justly ridiculed for his stupidity,
23255 if, as is said, Homer was greatly neglected by him and others in his own
23256 day when he was alive?
23257 
23258 Yes, I replied, that is the tradition. But can you imagine, Glaucon,
23259 that if Homer had really been able to educate and improve mankind--if he
23260 had possessed knowledge and not been a mere imitator--can you imagine,
23261 I say, that he would not have had many followers, and been honoured and
23262 loved by them? Protagoras of Abdera, and Prodicus of Ceos, and a host of
23263 others, have only to whisper to their contemporaries: 'You will never be
23264 able to manage either your own house or your own State until you appoint
23265 us to be your ministers of education'--and this ingenious device of
23266 theirs has such an effect in making men love them that their companions
23267 all but carry them about on their shoulders. And is it conceivable that
23268 the contemporaries of Homer, or again of Hesiod, would have allowed
23269 either of them to go about as rhapsodists, if they had really been able
23270 to make mankind virtuous? Would they not have been as unwilling to part
23271 with them as with gold, and have compelled them to stay at home with
23272 them? Or, if the master would not stay, then the disciples would have
23273 followed him about everywhere, until they had got education enough?
23274 
23275 Yes, Socrates, that, I think, is quite true.
23276 
23277 Then must we not infer that all these poetical individuals, beginning
23278 with Homer, are only imitators; they copy images of virtue and the like,
23279 but the truth they never reach? The poet is like a painter who, as
23280 we have already observed, will make a likeness of a cobbler though he
23281 understands nothing of cobbling; and his picture is good enough for
23282 those who know no more than he does, and judge only by colours and
23283 figures.
23284 
23285 Quite so.
23286 
23287 In like manner the poet with his words and phrases may be said to lay on
23288 the colours of the several arts, himself understanding their nature only
23289 enough to imitate them; and other people, who are as ignorant as he is,
23290 and judge only from his words, imagine that if he speaks of cobbling,
23291 or of military tactics, or of anything else, in metre and harmony and
23292 rhythm, he speaks very well--such is the sweet influence which melody
23293 and rhythm by nature have. And I think that you must have observed again
23294 and again what a poor appearance the tales of poets make when stripped
23295 of the colours which music puts upon them, and recited in simple prose.
23296 
23297 Yes, he said.
23298 
23299 They are like faces which were never really beautiful, but only
23300 blooming; and now the bloom of youth has passed away from them?
23301 
23302 Exactly.
23303 
23304 Here is another point: The imitator or maker of the image knows nothing
23305 of true existence; he knows appearances only. Am I not right?
23306 
23307 Yes.
23308 
23309 Then let us have a clear understanding, and not be satisfied with half
23310 an explanation.
23311 
23312 Proceed.
23313 
23314 Of the painter we say that he will paint reins, and he will paint a bit?
23315 
23316 Yes.
23317 
23318 And the worker in leather and brass will make them?
23319 
23320 Certainly.
23321 
23322 But does the painter know the right form of the bit and reins? Nay,
23323 hardly even the workers in brass and leather who make them; only the
23324 horseman who knows how to use them--he knows their right form.
23325 
23326 Most true.
23327 
23328 And may we not say the same of all things?
23329 
23330 What?
23331 
23332 That there are three arts which are concerned with all things: one which
23333 uses, another which makes, a third which imitates them?
23334 
23335 Yes.
23336 
23337 And the excellence or beauty or truth of every structure, animate or
23338 inanimate, and of every action of man, is relative to the use for which
23339 nature or the artist has intended them.
23340 
23341 True.
23342 
23343 Then the user of them must have the greatest experience of them, and
23344 he must indicate to the maker the good or bad qualities which develop
23345 themselves in use; for example, the flute-player will tell the
23346 flute-maker which of his flutes is satisfactory to the performer; he
23347 will tell him how he ought to make them, and the other will attend to
23348 his instructions?
23349 
23350 Of course.
23351 
23352 The one knows and therefore speaks with authority about the goodness and
23353 badness of flutes, while the other, confiding in him, will do what he is
23354 told by him?
23355 
23356 True.
23357 
23358 The instrument is the same, but about the excellence or badness of it
23359 the maker will only attain to a correct belief; and this he will gain
23360 from him who knows, by talking to him and being compelled to hear what
23361 he has to say, whereas the user will have knowledge?
23362 
23363 True.
23364 
23365 But will the imitator have either? Will he know from use whether or no
23366 his drawing is correct or beautiful? or will he have right opinion
23367 from being compelled to associate with another who knows and gives him
23368 instructions about what he should draw?
23369 
23370 Neither.
23371 
23372 Then he will no more have true opinion than he will have knowledge about
23373 the goodness or badness of his imitations?
23374 
23375 I suppose not.
23376 
23377 The imitative artist will be in a brilliant state of intelligence about
23378 his own creations?
23379 
23380 Nay, very much the reverse.
23381 
23382 And still he will go on imitating without knowing what makes a thing
23383 good or bad, and may be expected therefore to imitate only that which
23384 appears to be good to the ignorant multitude?
23385 
23386 Just so.
23387 
23388 Thus far then we are pretty well agreed that the imitator has no
23389 knowledge worth mentioning of what he imitates. Imitation is only a kind
23390 of play or sport, and the tragic poets, whether they write in Iambic or
23391 in Heroic verse, are imitators in the highest degree?
23392 
23393 Very true.
23394 
23395 And now tell me, I conjure you, has not imitation been shown by us to be
23396 concerned with that which is thrice removed from the truth?
23397 
23398 Certainly.
23399 
23400 And what is the faculty in man to which imitation is addressed?
23401 
23402 What do you mean?
23403 
23404 I will explain: The body which is large when seen near, appears small
23405 when seen at a distance?
23406 
23407 True.
23408 
23409 And the same object appears straight when looked at out of the water,
23410 and crooked when in the water; and the concave becomes convex, owing to
23411 the illusion about colours to which the sight is liable. Thus every sort
23412 of confusion is revealed within us; and this is that weakness of the
23413 human mind on which the art of conjuring and of deceiving by light and
23414 shadow and other ingenious devices imposes, having an effect upon us
23415 like magic.
23416 
23417 True.
23418 
23419 And the arts of measuring and numbering and weighing come to the
23420 rescue of the human understanding--there is the beauty of them--and the
23421 apparent greater or less, or more or heavier, no longer have the mastery
23422 over us, but give way before calculation and measure and weight?
23423 
23424 Most true.
23425 
23426 And this, surely, must be the work of the calculating and rational
23427 principle in the soul?
23428 
23429 To be sure.
23430 
23431 And when this principle measures and certifies that some things are
23432 equal, or that some are greater or less than others, there occurs an
23433 apparent contradiction?
23434 
23435 True.
23436 
23437 But were we not saying that such a contradiction is impossible--the same
23438 faculty cannot have contrary opinions at the same time about the same
23439 thing?
23440 
23441 Very true.
23442 
23443 Then that part of the soul which has an opinion contrary to measure is
23444 not the same with that which has an opinion in accordance with measure?
23445 
23446 True.
23447 
23448 And the better part of the soul is likely to be that which trusts to
23449 measure and calculation?
23450 
23451 Certainly.
23452 
23453 And that which is opposed to them is one of the inferior principles of
23454 the soul?
23455 
23456 No doubt.
23457 
23458 This was the conclusion at which I was seeking to arrive when I said
23459 that painting or drawing, and imitation in general, when doing their own
23460 proper work, are far removed from truth, and the companions and friends
23461 and associates of a principle within us which is equally removed from
23462 reason, and that they have no true or healthy aim.
23463 
23464 Exactly.
23465 
23466 The imitative art is an inferior who marries an inferior, and has
23467 inferior offspring.
23468 
23469 Very true.
23470 
23471 And is this confined to the sight only, or does it extend to the hearing
23472 also, relating in fact to what we term poetry?
23473 
23474 Probably the same would be true of poetry.
23475 
23476 Do not rely, I said, on a probability derived from the analogy of
23477 painting; but let us examine further and see whether the faculty with
23478 which poetical imitation is concerned is good or bad.
23479 
23480 By all means.
23481 
23482 We may state the question thus:--Imitation imitates the actions of men,
23483 whether voluntary or involuntary, on which, as they imagine, a good or
23484 bad result has ensued, and they rejoice or sorrow accordingly. Is there
23485 anything more?
23486 
23487 No, there is nothing else.
23488 
23489 But in all this variety of circumstances is the man at unity with
23490 himself--or rather, as in the instance of sight there was confusion and
23491 opposition in his opinions about the same things, so here also is there
23492 not strife and inconsistency in his life? Though I need hardly raise the
23493 question again, for I remember that all this has been already admitted;
23494 and the soul has been acknowledged by us to be full of these and ten
23495 thousand similar oppositions occurring at the same moment?
23496 
23497 And we were right, he said.
23498 
23499 Yes, I said, thus far we were right; but there was an omission which
23500 must now be supplied.
23501 
23502 What was the omission?
23503 
23504 Were we not saying that a good man, who has the misfortune to lose his
23505 son or anything else which is most dear to him, will bear the loss with
23506 more equanimity than another?
23507 
23508 Yes.
23509 
23510 But will he have no sorrow, or shall we say that although he cannot help
23511 sorrowing, he will moderate his sorrow?
23512 
23513 The latter, he said, is the truer statement.
23514 
23515 Tell me: will he be more likely to struggle and hold out against his
23516 sorrow when he is seen by his equals, or when he is alone?
23517 
23518 It will make a great difference whether he is seen or not.
23519 
23520 When he is by himself he will not mind saying or doing many things which
23521 he would be ashamed of any one hearing or seeing him do?
23522 
23523 True.
23524 
23525 There is a principle of law and reason in him which bids him resist, as
23526 well as a feeling of his misfortune which is forcing him to indulge his
23527 sorrow?
23528 
23529 True.
23530 
23531 But when a man is drawn in two opposite directions, to and from the same
23532 object, this, as we affirm, necessarily implies two distinct principles
23533 in him?
23534 
23535 Certainly.
23536 
23537 One of them is ready to follow the guidance of the law?
23538 
23539 How do you mean?
23540 
23541 The law would say that to be patient under suffering is best, and that
23542 we should not give way to impatience, as there is no knowing whether
23543 such things are good or evil; and nothing is gained by impatience; also,
23544 because no human thing is of serious importance, and grief stands in the
23545 way of that which at the moment is most required.
23546 
23547 What is most required? he asked.
23548 
23549 That we should take counsel about what has happened, and when the dice
23550 have been thrown order our affairs in the way which reason deems best;
23551 not, like children who have had a fall, keeping hold of the part struck
23552 and wasting time in setting up a howl, but always accustoming the soul
23553 forthwith to apply a remedy, raising up that which is sickly and fallen,
23554 banishing the cry of sorrow by the healing art.
23555 
23556 Yes, he said, that is the true way of meeting the attacks of fortune.
23557 
23558 Yes, I said; and the higher principle is ready to follow this suggestion
23559 of reason?
23560 
23561 Clearly.
23562 
23563 And the other principle, which inclines us to recollection of our
23564 troubles and to lamentation, and can never have enough of them, we may
23565 call irrational, useless, and cowardly?
23566 
23567 Indeed, we may.
23568 
23569 And does not the latter--I mean the rebellious principle--furnish a
23570 great variety of materials for imitation? Whereas the wise and calm
23571 temperament, being always nearly equable, is not easy to imitate or
23572 to appreciate when imitated, especially at a public festival when a
23573 promiscuous crowd is assembled in a theatre. For the feeling represented
23574 is one to which they are strangers.
23575 
23576 Certainly.
23577 
23578 Then the imitative poet who aims at being popular is not by nature made,
23579 nor is his art intended, to please or to affect the rational principle
23580 in the soul; but he will prefer the passionate and fitful temper, which
23581 is easily imitated?
23582 
23583 Clearly.
23584 
23585 And now we may fairly take him and place him by the side of the painter,
23586 for he is like him in two ways: first, inasmuch as his creations have an
23587 inferior degree of truth--in this, I say, he is like him; and he is
23588 also like him in being concerned with an inferior part of the soul; and
23589 therefore we shall be right in refusing to admit him into a well-ordered
23590 State, because he awakens and nourishes and strengthens the feelings
23591 and impairs the reason. As in a city when the evil are permitted to have
23592 authority and the good are put out of the way, so in the soul of man,
23593 as we maintain, the imitative poet implants an evil constitution, for he
23594 indulges the irrational nature which has no discernment of greater
23595 and less, but thinks the same thing at one time great and at another
23596 small--he is a manufacturer of images and is very far removed from the
23597 truth.
23598 
23599 Exactly.
23600 
23601 But we have not yet brought forward the heaviest count in our
23602 accusation:--the power which poetry has of harming even the good (and
23603 there are very few who are not harmed), is surely an awful thing?
23604 
23605 Yes, certainly, if the effect is what you say.
23606 
23607 Hear and judge: The best of us, as I conceive, when we listen to a
23608 passage of Homer, or one of the tragedians, in which he represents
23609 some pitiful hero who is drawling out his sorrows in a long oration, or
23610 weeping, and smiting his breast--the best of us, you know, delight in
23611 giving way to sympathy, and are in raptures at the excellence of the
23612 poet who stirs our feelings most.
23613 
23614 Yes, of course I know.
23615 
23616 But when any sorrow of our own happens to us, then you may observe that
23617 we pride ourselves on the opposite quality--we would fain be quiet and
23618 patient; this is the manly part, and the other which delighted us in the
23619 recitation is now deemed to be the part of a woman.
23620 
23621 Very true, he said.
23622 
23623 Now can we be right in praising and admiring another who is doing that
23624 which any one of us would abominate and be ashamed of in his own person?
23625 
23626 No, he said, that is certainly not reasonable.
23627 
23628 Nay, I said, quite reasonable from one point of view.
23629 
23630 What point of view?
23631 
23632 If you consider, I said, that when in misfortune we feel a natural
23633 hunger and desire to relieve our sorrow by weeping and lamentation, and
23634 that this feeling which is kept under control in our own calamities is
23635 satisfied and delighted by the poets;--the better nature in each of
23636 us, not having been sufficiently trained by reason or habit, allows the
23637 sympathetic element to break loose because the sorrow is another's;
23638 and the spectator fancies that there can be no disgrace to himself in
23639 praising and pitying any one who comes telling him what a good man he
23640 is, and making a fuss about his troubles; he thinks that the pleasure
23641 is a gain, and why should he be supercilious and lose this and the poem
23642 too? Few persons ever reflect, as I should imagine, that from the evil
23643 of other men something of evil is communicated to themselves. And so
23644 the feeling of sorrow which has gathered strength at the sight of the
23645 misfortunes of others is with difficulty repressed in our own.
23646 
23647 How very true!
23648 
23649 And does not the same hold also of the ridiculous? There are jests which
23650 you would be ashamed to make yourself, and yet on the comic stage, or
23651 indeed in private, when you hear them, you are greatly amused by them,
23652 and are not at all disgusted at their unseemliness;--the case of pity
23653 is repeated;--there is a principle in human nature which is disposed to
23654 raise a laugh, and this which you once restrained by reason, because you
23655 were afraid of being thought a buffoon, is now let out again; and
23656 having stimulated the risible faculty at the theatre, you are betrayed
23657 unconsciously to yourself into playing the comic poet at home.
23658 
23659 Quite true, he said.
23660 
23661 And the same may be said of lust and anger and all the other affections,
23662 of desire and pain and pleasure, which are held to be inseparable
23663 from every action--in all of them poetry feeds and waters the passions
23664 instead of drying them up; she lets them rule, although they ought to be
23665 controlled, if mankind are ever to increase in happiness and virtue.
23666 
23667 I cannot deny it.
23668 
23669 Therefore, Glaucon, I said, whenever you meet with any of the eulogists
23670 of Homer declaring that he has been the educator of Hellas, and that he
23671 is profitable for education and for the ordering of human things, and
23672 that you should take him up again and again and get to know him and
23673 regulate your whole life according to him, we may love and honour those
23674 who say these things--they are excellent people, as far as their lights
23675 extend; and we are ready to acknowledge that Homer is the greatest
23676 of poets and first of tragedy writers; but we must remain firm in our
23677 conviction that hymns to the gods and praises of famous men are the only
23678 poetry which ought to be admitted into our State. For if you go beyond
23679 this and allow the honeyed muse to enter, either in epic or lyric verse,
23680 not law and the reason of mankind, which by common consent have ever
23681 been deemed best, but pleasure and pain will be the rulers in our State.
23682 
23683 That is most true, he said.
23684 
23685 And now since we have reverted to the subject of poetry, let this our
23686 defence serve to show the reasonableness of our former judgment in
23687 sending away out of our State an art having the tendencies which we have
23688 described; for reason constrained us. But that she may not impute to us
23689 any harshness or want of politeness, let us tell her that there is an
23690 ancient quarrel between philosophy and poetry; of which there are many
23691 proofs, such as the saying of 'the yelping hound howling at her lord,'
23692 or of one 'mighty in the vain talk of fools,' and 'the mob of sages
23693 circumventing Zeus,' and the 'subtle thinkers who are beggars after
23694 all'; and there are innumerable other signs of ancient enmity between
23695 them. Notwithstanding this, let us assure our sweet friend and the
23696 sister arts of imitation, that if she will only prove her title to exist
23697 in a well-ordered State we shall be delighted to receive her--we are
23698 very conscious of her charms; but we may not on that account betray the
23699 truth. I dare say, Glaucon, that you are as much charmed by her as I am,
23700 especially when she appears in Homer?
23701 
23702 Yes, indeed, I am greatly charmed.
23703 
23704 Shall I propose, then, that she be allowed to return from exile, but
23705 upon this condition only--that she make a defence of herself in lyrical
23706 or some other metre?
23707 
23708 Certainly.
23709 
23710 And we may further grant to those of her defenders who are lovers of
23711 poetry and yet not poets the permission to speak in prose on her behalf:
23712 let them show not only that she is pleasant but also useful to States
23713 and to human life, and we will listen in a kindly spirit; for if this
23714 can be proved we shall surely be the gainers--I mean, if there is a use
23715 in poetry as well as a delight?
23716 
23717 Certainly, he said, we shall be the gainers.
23718 
23719 If her defence fails, then, my dear friend, like other persons who are
23720 enamoured of something, but put a restraint upon themselves when they
23721 think their desires are opposed to their interests, so too must we after
23722 the manner of lovers give her up, though not without a struggle. We too
23723 are inspired by that love of poetry which the education of noble States
23724 has implanted in us, and therefore we would have her appear at her best
23725 and truest; but so long as she is unable to make good her defence,
23726 this argument of ours shall be a charm to us, which we will repeat to
23727 ourselves while we listen to her strains; that we may not fall away into
23728 the childish love of her which captivates the many. At all events we
23729 are well aware that poetry being such as we have described is not to be
23730 regarded seriously as attaining to the truth; and he who listens to her,
23731 fearing for the safety of the city which is within him, should be on his
23732 guard against her seductions and make our words his law.
23733 
23734 Yes, he said, I quite agree with you.
23735 
23736 Yes, I said, my dear Glaucon, for great is the issue at stake, greater
23737 than appears, whether a man is to be good or bad. And what will any one
23738 be profited if under the influence of honour or money or power, aye, or
23739 under the excitement of poetry, he neglect justice and virtue?
23740 
23741 Yes, he said; I have been convinced by the argument, as I believe that
23742 any one else would have been.
23743 
23744 And yet no mention has been made of the greatest prizes and rewards
23745 which await virtue.
23746 
23747 What, are there any greater still? If there are, they must be of an
23748 inconceivable greatness.
23749 
23750 Why, I said, what was ever great in a short time? The whole period of
23751 three score years and ten is surely but a little thing in comparison
23752 with eternity?
23753 
23754 Say rather 'nothing,' he replied.
23755 
23756 And should an immortal being seriously think of this little space rather
23757 than of the whole?
23758 
23759 Of the whole, certainly. But why do you ask?
23760 
23761 Are you not aware, I said, that the soul of man is immortal and
23762 imperishable?
23763 
23764 He looked at me in astonishment, and said: No, by heaven: And are you
23765 really prepared to maintain this?
23766 
23767 Yes, I said, I ought to be, and you too--there is no difficulty in
23768 proving it.
23769 
23770 I see a great difficulty; but I should like to hear you state this
23771 argument of which you make so light.
23772 
23773 Listen then.
23774 
23775 I am attending.
23776 
23777 There is a thing which you call good and another which you call evil?
23778 
23779 Yes, he replied.
23780 
23781 Would you agree with me in thinking that the corrupting and destroying
23782 element is the evil, and the saving and improving element the good?
23783 
23784 Yes.
23785 
23786 And you admit that every thing has a good and also an evil; as
23787 ophthalmia is the evil of the eyes and disease of the whole body; as
23788 mildew is of corn, and rot of timber, or rust of copper and iron: in
23789 everything, or in almost everything, there is an inherent evil and
23790 disease?
23791 
23792 Yes, he said.
23793 
23794 And anything which is infected by any of these evils is made evil, and
23795 at last wholly dissolves and dies?
23796 
23797 True.
23798 
23799 The vice and evil which is inherent in each is the destruction of each;
23800 and if this does not destroy them there is nothing else that will; for
23801 good certainly will not destroy them, nor again, that which is neither
23802 good nor evil.
23803 
23804 Certainly not.
23805 
23806 If, then, we find any nature which having this inherent corruption
23807 cannot be dissolved or destroyed, we may be certain that of such a
23808 nature there is no destruction?
23809 
23810 That may be assumed.
23811 
23812 Well, I said, and is there no evil which corrupts the soul?
23813 
23814 Yes, he said, there are all the evils which we were just now passing in
23815 review: unrighteousness, intemperance, cowardice, ignorance.
23816 
23817 But does any of these dissolve or destroy her?--and here do not let us
23818 fall into the error of supposing that the unjust and foolish man, when
23819 he is detected, perishes through his own injustice, which is an evil
23820 of the soul. Take the analogy of the body: The evil of the body is a
23821 disease which wastes and reduces and annihilates the body; and all the
23822 things of which we were just now speaking come to annihilation through
23823 their own corruption attaching to them and inhering in them and so
23824 destroying them. Is not this true?
23825 
23826 Yes.
23827 
23828 Consider the soul in like manner. Does the injustice or other evil which
23829 exists in the soul waste and consume her? Do they by attaching to the
23830 soul and inhering in her at last bring her to death, and so separate her
23831 from the body?
23832 
23833 Certainly not.
23834 
23835 And yet, I said, it is unreasonable to suppose that anything can perish
23836 from without through affection of external evil which could not be
23837 destroyed from within by a corruption of its own?
23838 
23839 It is, he replied.
23840 
23841 Consider, I said, Glaucon, that even the badness of food, whether
23842 staleness, decomposition, or any other bad quality, when confined to
23843 the actual food, is not supposed to destroy the body; although, if the
23844 badness of food communicates corruption to the body, then we should say
23845 that the body has been destroyed by a corruption of itself, which is
23846 disease, brought on by this; but that the body, being one thing, can be
23847 destroyed by the badness of food, which is another, and which does not
23848 engender any natural infection--this we shall absolutely deny?
23849 
23850 Very true.
23851 
23852 And, on the same principle, unless some bodily evil can produce an evil
23853 of the soul, we must not suppose that the soul, which is one thing, can
23854 be dissolved by any merely external evil which belongs to another?
23855 
23856 Yes, he said, there is reason in that.
23857 
23858 Either, then, let us refute this conclusion, or, while it remains
23859 unrefuted, let us never say that fever, or any other disease, or the
23860 knife put to the throat, or even the cutting up of the whole body into
23861 the minutest pieces, can destroy the soul, until she herself is proved
23862 to become more unholy or unrighteous in consequence of these things
23863 being done to the body; but that the soul, or anything else if not
23864 destroyed by an internal evil, can be destroyed by an external one, is
23865 not to be affirmed by any man.
23866 
23867 And surely, he replied, no one will ever prove that the souls of men
23868 become more unjust in consequence of death.
23869 
23870 But if some one who would rather not admit the immortality of the soul
23871 boldly denies this, and says that the dying do really become more
23872 evil and unrighteous, then, if the speaker is right, I suppose that
23873 injustice, like disease, must be assumed to be fatal to the unjust, and
23874 that those who take this disorder die by the natural inherent power of
23875 destruction which evil has, and which kills them sooner or later, but
23876 in quite another way from that in which, at present, the wicked receive
23877 death at the hands of others as the penalty of their deeds?
23878 
23879 Nay, he said, in that case injustice, if fatal to the unjust, will not
23880 be so very terrible to him, for he will be delivered from evil. But I
23881 rather suspect the opposite to be the truth, and that injustice which,
23882 if it have the power, will murder others, keeps the murderer alive--aye,
23883 and well awake too; so far removed is her dwelling-place from being a
23884 house of death.
23885 
23886 True, I said; if the inherent natural vice or evil of the soul is unable
23887 to kill or destroy her, hardly will that which is appointed to be the
23888 destruction of some other body, destroy a soul or anything else except
23889 that of which it was appointed to be the destruction.
23890 
23891 Yes, that can hardly be.
23892 
23893 But the soul which cannot be destroyed by an evil, whether inherent
23894 or external, must exist for ever, and if existing for ever, must be
23895 immortal?
23896 
23897 Certainly.
23898 
23899 That is the conclusion, I said; and, if a true conclusion, then the
23900 souls must always be the same, for if none be destroyed they will not
23901 diminish in number. Neither will they increase, for the increase of the
23902 immortal natures must come from something mortal, and all things would
23903 thus end in immortality.
23904 
23905 Very true.
23906 
23907 But this we cannot believe--reason will not allow us--any more than we
23908 can believe the soul, in her truest nature, to be full of variety and
23909 difference and dissimilarity.
23910 
23911 What do you mean? he said.
23912 
23913 The soul, I said, being, as is now proven, immortal, must be the fairest
23914 of compositions and cannot be compounded of many elements?
23915 
23916 Certainly not.
23917 
23918 Her immortality is demonstrated by the previous argument, and there are
23919 many other proofs; but to see her as she really is, not as we now behold
23920 her, marred by communion with the body and other miseries, you must
23921 contemplate her with the eye of reason, in her original purity; and
23922 then her beauty will be revealed, and justice and injustice and all the
23923 things which we have described will be manifested more clearly. Thus
23924 far, we have spoken the truth concerning her as she appears at present,
23925 but we must remember also that we have seen her only in a condition
23926 which may be compared to that of the sea-god Glaucus, whose original
23927 image can hardly be discerned because his natural members are broken
23928 off and crushed and damaged by the waves in all sorts of ways, and
23929 incrustations have grown over them of seaweed and shells and stones, so
23930 that he is more like some monster than he is to his own natural form.
23931 And the soul which we behold is in a similar condition, disfigured by
23932 ten thousand ills. But not there, Glaucon, not there must we look.
23933 
23934 Where then?
23935 
23936 At her love of wisdom. Let us see whom she affects, and what society and
23937 converse she seeks in virtue of her near kindred with the immortal
23938 and eternal and divine; also how different she would become if wholly
23939 following this superior principle, and borne by a divine impulse out of
23940 the ocean in which she now is, and disengaged from the stones and shells
23941 and things of earth and rock which in wild variety spring up around her
23942 because she feeds upon earth, and is overgrown by the good things of
23943 this life as they are termed: then you would see her as she is, and know
23944 whether she have one shape only or many, or what her nature is. Of her
23945 affections and of the forms which she takes in this present life I think
23946 that we have now said enough.
23947 
23948 True, he replied.
23949 
23950 And thus, I said, we have fulfilled the conditions of the argument; we
23951 have not introduced the rewards and glories of justice, which, as you
23952 were saying, are to be found in Homer and Hesiod; but justice in her own
23953 nature has been shown to be best for the soul in her own nature. Let a
23954 man do what is just, whether he have the ring of Gyges or not, and even
23955 if in addition to the ring of Gyges he put on the helmet of Hades.
23956 
23957 Very true.
23958 
23959 And now, Glaucon, there will be no harm in further enumerating how
23960 many and how great are the rewards which justice and the other virtues
23961 procure to the soul from gods and men, both in life and after death.
23962 
23963 Certainly not, he said.
23964 
23965 Will you repay me, then, what you borrowed in the argument?
23966 
23967 What did I borrow?
23968 
23969 The assumption that the just man should appear unjust and the unjust
23970 just: for you were of opinion that even if the true state of the case
23971 could not possibly escape the eyes of gods and men, still this admission
23972 ought to be made for the sake of the argument, in order that pure
23973 justice might be weighed against pure injustice. Do you remember?
23974 
23975 I should be much to blame if I had forgotten.
23976 
23977 Then, as the cause is decided, I demand on behalf of justice that the
23978 estimation in which she is held by gods and men and which we acknowledge
23979 to be her due should now be restored to her by us; since she has been
23980 shown to confer reality, and not to deceive those who truly possess her,
23981 let what has been taken from her be given back, that so she may win that
23982 palm of appearance which is hers also, and which she gives to her own.
23983 
23984 The demand, he said, is just.
23985 
23986 In the first place, I said--and this is the first thing which you will
23987 have to give back--the nature both of the just and unjust is truly known
23988 to the gods.
23989 
23990 Granted.
23991 
23992 And if they are both known to them, one must be the friend and the other
23993 the enemy of the gods, as we admitted from the beginning?
23994 
23995 True.
23996 
23997 And the friend of the gods may be supposed to receive from them all
23998 things at their best, excepting only such evil as is the necessary
23999 consequence of former sins?
24000 
24001 Certainly.
24002 
24003 Then this must be our notion of the just man, that even when he is in
24004 poverty or sickness, or any other seeming misfortune, all things will
24005 in the end work together for good to him in life and death: for the gods
24006 have a care of any one whose desire is to become just and to be like
24007 God, as far as man can attain the divine likeness, by the pursuit of
24008 virtue?
24009 
24010 Yes, he said; if he is like God he will surely not be neglected by him.
24011 
24012 And of the unjust may not the opposite be supposed?
24013 
24014 Certainly.
24015 
24016 Such, then, are the palms of victory which the gods give the just?
24017 
24018 That is my conviction.
24019 
24020 And what do they receive of men? Look at things as they really are, and
24021 you will see that the clever unjust are in the case of runners, who run
24022 well from the starting-place to the goal but not back again from the
24023 goal: they go off at a great pace, but in the end only look foolish,
24024 slinking away with their ears draggling on their shoulders, and without
24025 a crown; but the true runner comes to the finish and receives the prize
24026 and is crowned. And this is the way with the just; he who endures to the
24027 end of every action and occasion of his entire life has a good report
24028 and carries off the prize which men have to bestow.
24029 
24030 True.
24031 
24032 And now you must allow me to repeat of the just the blessings which you
24033 were attributing to the fortunate unjust. I shall say of them, what you
24034 were saying of the others, that as they grow older, they become rulers
24035 in their own city if they care to be; they marry whom they like and give
24036 in marriage to whom they will; all that you said of the others I now say
24037 of these. And, on the other hand, of the unjust I say that the greater
24038 number, even though they escape in their youth, are found out at last
24039 and look foolish at the end of their course, and when they come to be
24040 old and miserable are flouted alike by stranger and citizen; they are
24041 beaten and then come those things unfit for ears polite, as you truly
24042 term them; they will be racked and have their eyes burned out, as you
24043 were saying. And you may suppose that I have repeated the remainder of
24044 your tale of horrors. But will you let me assume, without reciting them,
24045 that these things are true?
24046 
24047 Certainly, he said, what you say is true.
24048 
24049 These, then, are the prizes and rewards and gifts which are bestowed
24050 upon the just by gods and men in this present life, in addition to the
24051 other good things which justice of herself provides.
24052 
24053 Yes, he said; and they are fair and lasting.
24054 
24055 And yet, I said, all these are as nothing either in number or greatness
24056 in comparison with those other recompenses which await both just and
24057 unjust after death. And you ought to hear them, and then both just and
24058 unjust will have received from us a full payment of the debt which the
24059 argument owes to them.
24060 
24061 Speak, he said; there are few things which I would more gladly hear.
24062 
24063 Well, I said, I will tell you a tale; not one of the tales which
24064 Odysseus tells to the hero Alcinous, yet this too is a tale of a hero,
24065 Er the son of Armenius, a Pamphylian by birth. He was slain in battle,
24066 and ten days afterwards, when the bodies of the dead were taken up
24067 already in a state of corruption, his body was found unaffected by
24068 decay, and carried away home to be buried. And on the twelfth day, as he
24069 was lying on the funeral pile, he returned to life and told them what he
24070 had seen in the other world. He said that when his soul left the body
24071 he went on a journey with a great company, and that they came to a
24072 mysterious place at which there were two openings in the earth; they
24073 were near together, and over against them were two other openings in the
24074 heaven above. In the intermediate space there were judges seated, who
24075 commanded the just, after they had given judgment on them and had bound
24076 their sentences in front of them, to ascend by the heavenly way on the
24077 right hand; and in like manner the unjust were bidden by them to descend
24078 by the lower way on the left hand; these also bore the symbols of their
24079 deeds, but fastened on their backs. He drew near, and they told him that
24080 he was to be the messenger who would carry the report of the other world
24081 to men, and they bade him hear and see all that was to be heard and seen
24082 in that place. Then he beheld and saw on one side the souls departing at
24083 either opening of heaven and earth when sentence had been given on them;
24084 and at the two other openings other souls, some ascending out of the
24085 earth dusty and worn with travel, some descending out of heaven clean
24086 and bright. And arriving ever and anon they seemed to have come from a
24087 long journey, and they went forth with gladness into the meadow, where
24088 they encamped as at a festival; and those who knew one another embraced
24089 and conversed, the souls which came from earth curiously enquiring about
24090 the things above, and the souls which came from heaven about the things
24091 beneath. And they told one another of what had happened by the way,
24092 those from below weeping and sorrowing at the remembrance of the things
24093 which they had endured and seen in their journey beneath the earth
24094 (now the journey lasted a thousand years), while those from above were
24095 describing heavenly delights and visions of inconceivable beauty. The
24096 story, Glaucon, would take too long to tell; but the sum was this:--He
24097 said that for every wrong which they had done to any one they suffered
24098 tenfold; or once in a hundred years--such being reckoned to be the
24099 length of man's life, and the penalty being thus paid ten times in a
24100 thousand years. If, for example, there were any who had been the cause
24101 of many deaths, or had betrayed or enslaved cities or armies, or been
24102 guilty of any other evil behaviour, for each and all of their offences
24103 they received punishment ten times over, and the rewards of beneficence
24104 and justice and holiness were in the same proportion. I need hardly
24105 repeat what he said concerning young children dying almost as soon
24106 as they were born. Of piety and impiety to gods and parents, and of
24107 murderers, there were retributions other and greater far which he
24108 described. He mentioned that he was present when one of the spirits
24109 asked another, 'Where is Ardiaeus the Great?' (Now this Ardiaeus lived
24110 a thousand years before the time of Er: he had been the tyrant of
24111 some city of Pamphylia, and had murdered his aged father and his elder
24112 brother, and was said to have committed many other abominable crimes.)
24113 The answer of the other spirit was: 'He comes not hither and will never
24114 come. And this,' said he, 'was one of the dreadful sights which we
24115 ourselves witnessed. We were at the mouth of the cavern, and, having
24116 completed all our experiences, were about to reascend, when of a sudden
24117 Ardiaeus appeared and several others, most of whom were tyrants; and
24118 there were also besides the tyrants private individuals who had been
24119 great criminals: they were just, as they fancied, about to return into
24120 the upper world, but the mouth, instead of admitting them, gave a roar,
24121 whenever any of these incurable sinners or some one who had not been
24122 sufficiently punished tried to ascend; and then wild men of fiery
24123 aspect, who were standing by and heard the sound, seized and carried
24124 them off; and Ardiaeus and others they bound head and foot and hand, and
24125 threw them down and flayed them with scourges, and dragged them along
24126 the road at the side, carding them on thorns like wool, and declaring
24127 to the passers-by what were their crimes, and that they were being taken
24128 away to be cast into hell.' And of all the many terrors which they had
24129 endured, he said that there was none like the terror which each of them
24130 felt at that moment, lest they should hear the voice; and when there was
24131 silence, one by one they ascended with exceeding joy. These, said Er,
24132 were the penalties and retributions, and there were blessings as great.
24133 
24134 Now when the spirits which were in the meadow had tarried seven days,
24135 on the eighth they were obliged to proceed on their journey, and, on the
24136 fourth day after, he said that they came to a place where they could
24137 see from above a line of light, straight as a column, extending right
24138 through the whole heaven and through the earth, in colour resembling the
24139 rainbow, only brighter and purer; another day's journey brought them to
24140 the place, and there, in the midst of the light, they saw the ends of
24141 the chains of heaven let down from above: for this light is the belt
24142 of heaven, and holds together the circle of the universe, like the
24143 under-girders of a trireme. From these ends is extended the spindle of
24144 Necessity, on which all the revolutions turn. The shaft and hook of this
24145 spindle are made of steel, and the whorl is made partly of steel and
24146 also partly of other materials. Now the whorl is in form like the whorl
24147 used on earth; and the description of it implied that there is one large
24148 hollow whorl which is quite scooped out, and into this is fitted another
24149 lesser one, and another, and another, and four others, making eight
24150 in all, like vessels which fit into one another; the whorls show their
24151 edges on the upper side, and on their lower side all together form one
24152 continuous whorl. This is pierced by the spindle, which is driven home
24153 through the centre of the eighth. The first and outermost whorl has the
24154 rim broadest, and the seven inner whorls are narrower, in the following
24155 proportions--the sixth is next to the first in size, the fourth next
24156 to the sixth; then comes the eighth; the seventh is fifth, the fifth
24157 is sixth, the third is seventh, last and eighth comes the second.
24158 The largest (or fixed stars) is spangled, and the seventh (or sun) is
24159 brightest; the eighth (or moon) coloured by the reflected light of the
24160 seventh; the second and fifth (Saturn and Mercury) are in colour like
24161 one another, and yellower than the preceding; the third (Venus) has the
24162 whitest light; the fourth (Mars) is reddish; the sixth (Jupiter) is in
24163 whiteness second. Now the whole spindle has the same motion; but, as the
24164 whole revolves in one direction, the seven inner circles move slowly in
24165 the other, and of these the swiftest is the eighth; next in swiftness
24166 are the seventh, sixth, and fifth, which move together; third in
24167 swiftness appeared to move according to the law of this reversed motion
24168 the fourth; the third appeared fourth and the second fifth. The spindle
24169 turns on the knees of Necessity; and on the upper surface of each circle
24170 is a siren, who goes round with them, hymning a single tone or note. The
24171 eight together form one harmony; and round about, at equal intervals,
24172 there is another band, three in number, each sitting upon her throne:
24173 these are the Fates, daughters of Necessity, who are clothed in white
24174 robes and have chaplets upon their heads, Lachesis and Clotho
24175 and Atropos, who accompany with their voices the harmony of the
24176 sirens--Lachesis singing of the past, Clotho of the present, Atropos of
24177 the future; Clotho from time to time assisting with a touch of her right
24178 hand the revolution of the outer circle of the whorl or spindle, and
24179 Atropos with her left hand touching and guiding the inner ones, and
24180 Lachesis laying hold of either in turn, first with one hand and then
24181 with the other.
24182 
24183 When Er and the spirits arrived, their duty was to go at once to
24184 Lachesis; but first of all there came a prophet who arranged them in
24185 order; then he took from the knees of Lachesis lots and samples of
24186 lives, and having mounted a high pulpit, spoke as follows: 'Hear the
24187 word of Lachesis, the daughter of Necessity. Mortal souls, behold a new
24188 cycle of life and mortality. Your genius will not be allotted to you,
24189 but you will choose your genius; and let him who draws the first lot
24190 have the first choice, and the life which he chooses shall be his
24191 destiny. Virtue is free, and as a man honours or dishonours her he will
24192 have more or less of her; the responsibility is with the chooser--God
24193 is justified.' When the Interpreter had thus spoken he scattered lots
24194 indifferently among them all, and each of them took up the lot which
24195 fell near him, all but Er himself (he was not allowed), and each as
24196 he took his lot perceived the number which he had obtained. Then the
24197 Interpreter placed on the ground before them the samples of lives; and
24198 there were many more lives than the souls present, and they were of all
24199 sorts. There were lives of every animal and of man in every condition.
24200 And there were tyrannies among them, some lasting out the tyrant's life,
24201 others which broke off in the middle and came to an end in poverty and
24202 exile and beggary; and there were lives of famous men, some who were
24203 famous for their form and beauty as well as for their strength and
24204 success in games, or, again, for their birth and the qualities of their
24205 ancestors; and some who were the reverse of famous for the opposite
24206 qualities. And of women likewise; there was not, however, any definite
24207 character in them, because the soul, when choosing a new life, must of
24208 necessity become different. But there was every other quality, and
24209 the all mingled with one another, and also with elements of wealth and
24210 poverty, and disease and health; and there were mean states also. And
24211 here, my dear Glaucon, is the supreme peril of our human state; and
24212 therefore the utmost care should be taken. Let each one of us leave
24213 every other kind of knowledge and seek and follow one thing only, if
24214 peradventure he may be able to learn and may find some one who will make
24215 him able to learn and discern between good and evil, and so to choose
24216 always and everywhere the better life as he has opportunity. He should
24217 consider the bearing of all these things which have been mentioned
24218 severally and collectively upon virtue; he should know what the effect
24219 of beauty is when combined with poverty or wealth in a particular soul,
24220 and what are the good and evil consequences of noble and humble birth,
24221 of private and public station, of strength and weakness, of cleverness
24222 and dullness, and of all the natural and acquired gifts of the soul, and
24223 the operation of them when conjoined; he will then look at the nature of
24224 the soul, and from the consideration of all these qualities he will be
24225 able to determine which is the better and which is the worse; and so
24226 he will choose, giving the name of evil to the life which will make his
24227 soul more unjust, and good to the life which will make his soul more
24228 just; all else he will disregard. For we have seen and know that this is
24229 the best choice both in life and after death. A man must take with him
24230 into the world below an adamantine faith in truth and right, that there
24231 too he may be undazzled by the desire of wealth or the other allurements
24232 of evil, lest, coming upon tyrannies and similar villainies, he do
24233 irremediable wrongs to others and suffer yet worse himself; but let him
24234 know how to choose the mean and avoid the extremes on either side, as
24235 far as possible, not only in this life but in all that which is to come.
24236 For this is the way of happiness.
24237 
24238 And according to the report of the messenger from the other world this
24239 was what the prophet said at the time: 'Even for the last comer, if he
24240 chooses wisely and will live diligently, there is appointed a happy and
24241 not undesirable existence. Let not him who chooses first be careless,
24242 and let not the last despair.' And when he had spoken, he who had the
24243 first choice came forward and in a moment chose the greatest tyranny;
24244 his mind having been darkened by folly and sensuality, he had not
24245 thought out the whole matter before he chose, and did not at first
24246 sight perceive that he was fated, among other evils, to devour his own
24247 children. But when he had time to reflect, and saw what was in the lot,
24248 he began to beat his breast and lament over his choice, forgetting the
24249 proclamation of the prophet; for, instead of throwing the blame of his
24250 misfortune on himself, he accused chance and the gods, and everything
24251 rather than himself. Now he was one of those who came from heaven, and
24252 in a former life had dwelt in a well-ordered State, but his virtue was
24253 a matter of habit only, and he had no philosophy. And it was true of
24254 others who were similarly overtaken, that the greater number of them
24255 came from heaven and therefore they had never been schooled by trial,
24256 whereas the pilgrims who came from earth having themselves suffered and
24257 seen others suffer, were not in a hurry to choose. And owing to this
24258 inexperience of theirs, and also because the lot was a chance, many of
24259 the souls exchanged a good destiny for an evil or an evil for a good.
24260 For if a man had always on his arrival in this world dedicated himself
24261 from the first to sound philosophy, and had been moderately fortunate
24262 in the number of the lot, he might, as the messenger reported, be happy
24263 here, and also his journey to another life and return to this, instead
24264 of being rough and underground, would be smooth and heavenly. Most
24265 curious, he said, was the spectacle--sad and laughable and strange; for
24266 the choice of the souls was in most cases based on their experience of
24267 a previous life. There he saw the soul which had once been Orpheus
24268 choosing the life of a swan out of enmity to the race of women, hating
24269 to be born of a woman because they had been his murderers; he beheld
24270 also the soul of Thamyras choosing the life of a nightingale; birds, on
24271 the other hand, like the swan and other musicians, wanting to be men.
24272 The soul which obtained the twentieth lot chose the life of a lion, and
24273 this was the soul of Ajax the son of Telamon, who would not be a man,
24274 remembering the injustice which was done him in the judgment about the
24275 arms. The next was Agamemnon, who took the life of an eagle, because,
24276 like Ajax, he hated human nature by reason of his sufferings. About
24277 the middle came the lot of Atalanta; she, seeing the great fame of
24278 an athlete, was unable to resist the temptation: and after her there
24279 followed the soul of Epeus the son of Panopeus passing into the nature
24280 of a woman cunning in the arts; and far away among the last who chose,
24281 the soul of the jester Thersites was putting on the form of a monkey.
24282 There came also the soul of Odysseus having yet to make a choice, and
24283 his lot happened to be the last of them all. Now the recollection of
24284 former toils had disenchanted him of ambition, and he went about for
24285 a considerable time in search of the life of a private man who had no
24286 cares; he had some difficulty in finding this, which was lying about and
24287 had been neglected by everybody else; and when he saw it, he said that
24288 he would have done the same had his lot been first instead of last,
24289 and that he was delighted to have it. And not only did men pass into
24290 animals, but I must also mention that there were animals tame and wild
24291 who changed into one another and into corresponding human natures--the
24292 good into the gentle and the evil into the savage, in all sorts of
24293 combinations.
24294 
24295 All the souls had now chosen their lives, and they went in the order of
24296 their choice to Lachesis, who sent with them the genius whom they had
24297 severally chosen, to be the guardian of their lives and the fulfiller
24298 of the choice: this genius led the souls first to Clotho, and drew
24299 them within the revolution of the spindle impelled by her hand, thus
24300 ratifying the destiny of each; and then, when they were fastened to
24301 this, carried them to Atropos, who spun the threads and made them
24302 irreversible, whence without turning round they passed beneath the
24303 throne of Necessity; and when they had all passed, they marched on in a
24304 scorching heat to the plain of Forgetfulness, which was a barren waste
24305 destitute of trees and verdure; and then towards evening they encamped
24306 by the river of Unmindfulness, whose water no vessel can hold; of this
24307 they were all obliged to drink a certain quantity, and those who were
24308 not saved by wisdom drank more than was necessary; and each one as he
24309 drank forgot all things. Now after they had gone to rest, about the
24310 middle of the night there was a thunderstorm and earthquake, and then
24311 in an instant they were driven upwards in all manner of ways to their
24312 birth, like stars shooting. He himself was hindered from drinking the
24313 water. But in what manner or by what means he returned to the body he
24314 could not say; only, in the morning, awaking suddenly, he found himself
24315 lying on the pyre.
24316 
24317 And thus, Glaucon, the tale has been saved and has not perished, and
24318 will save us if we are obedient to the word spoken; and we shall pass
24319 safely over the river of Forgetfulness and our soul will not be defiled.
24320 Wherefore my counsel is, that we hold fast ever to the heavenly way and
24321 follow after justice and virtue always, considering that the soul is
24322 immortal and able to endure every sort of good and every sort of evil.
24323 Thus shall we live dear to one another and to the gods, both while
24324 remaining here and when, like conquerors in the games who go round to
24325 gather gifts, we receive our reward. And it shall be well with us both
24326 in this life and in the pilgrimage of a thousand years which we have
24327 been describing.
24328
